title: Not Recommended
comment: As a longtime civ player, I just can't get into this latest version. I avoided the game at launch due to the goofy graphics and the 80$ price tag. After getting it on 50% off, i've tried very hard to enjoy it but I just can't. I'll be trying for a refund but after 30 hours played, I don't think i'll have much luck.It seems to appeal much more to a mobile RTS style of game whereas I prefer the immersion and civ building aspects of the franchise. I also feel like I need to use the strategic view to actually see what's going on on the map. This only emphasizes the mobile aspect of the art style and makes the immersion more difficult, which is ironic because the art style change was suppose to make things more visible and easier to see. I don't feel like i'm guiding a civilization to greatness, everything is a game-mechanic decision to maximize your pursuit of a win condition, routes that are very narrow and linear to chase.For example, civ policy cards are being constantly swapped out based on whatever your next immediate goal is, contrary to any sense of persistent or organic cultural development and, on standard at least, tech and policy advances happen at a very rapid pace. I always disliked how quickly tech becomes obsolete and replaced in the civ games, I always wanted to feel like each era was actually an era you play through but this rapid development (first game the AI hit modern era in 1200 AD) just makes it feel like a mad dash to the end and Civ 6 is much worse than the previous games for this.The new distrinct and wonder placement system feels cumbersome to manage and plan for. With each using a tile space, thus losing the tile yields, and requiring specific hex conditions, it makes trying to plan city placement and the development of a civilization annoying even after managing to learn and remember those requirements. The rate of border expansion is also very slow without specifically pursuing culture or buying tiles outright. It feels more complex than deep, which just leads to ungratifying work on my end. At times the research and policy process felt more like starcraft build progression paths than a civilization growing through the ages, too linear and too obvious.The civs and mechanics are utterly uninspiring. Admittedly much of this was due to not fully understanding all the mechanics and how everything works now but even after reading and watching walkthroughs, I couldn't get excited selecting any particular civ. Many of the civs are hyper specific to a map type or play style and useless otherwise. This kind of sucks. At the least i would have much prefered each civ having multiple leaders that are designed to pursue different win paths so I could play a civ I liked for the historic, aethstetic or narrative aspect. Again, the civ builder in me wanted more immersion and playing a leader or civ that FEELS exciting outside mechanic bonuses would have been nice.Another option would have been to separate the narrative and mechanics from each other more like Stellaris, which has an awesome, though content limited, system. I understand dev choosing civs and abilities based on historic presendent has always been a part of civ (and I do like that) but when it's all about mechanics, it stops feeling like civ for me. Why not allow default civs and custom ones? As a side note, the custom religion symbols are really boring and all of the same animal theme. A wider variety of art and styles here would have been nice. Also, why can't I use an existing religion and just rename it?Seafaring also has little impact on anything unless required on specific map types. Most games, even with coasts, I barely made use of water units(or tiles) other than exploration. Seafaring was a huge part of asian and european development, this isn't at all present in the game and feels really wierd that there is no significant benefit to seafaring.tldr; if you want a mechanic heavy time-sink with an RTS/Mobile feel, civ 6 might be for you. If you want an immersive, historic rich civilization builder, this one probably isn't gonna work for you anymore than it did for me. I think Stellaris or Civ 5 are still my go-to for that type of game.

title: Recommended
comment: I Pre-ordered this game and it was worth it. Though buggy from the start, the developers really tried to bring something new into this game. Coming from CIV 5 there are substantial differences. I do not understand the hate for this game. Maybe they're comparing it to CIV 5 which is for me unfair. The standard should have been what CIV games are about; building multiple cities with your leader and enacting decisions based on what resources you have and against your environment.Pros:1. Better Graphics - Yes, the graphics for me is better in CIV 6. Despite it's cartoonish feel and a side step from the more practical graphics Civilization games had in the past, the animations and the combat graphics are still better.2. Music - The narration of Sean Bean is perfect, hands down to that. Moreover, music is tailored to whatever civilization you are playing so you'll get a variation of sounds.3. A more challenging opener - I don't know why people are complaining that barbarians are everywhere or they spawn everywhere during the game. Isn't that the point? Barbarians pose athreat early on because you are just starting. All the more the reason why you should take outtheir scout once he spots your city.4. Game is still developing - I love the fact they added leaders from African and Asian countries,this was not seen as much in CIV 5 and we have more female leaders as well! In addition, is thedistrict system which is a plus for me at least we have process in how to devise our city. Hence the need for city planning. At least, we have5. Creativity - Your creativity will be tested here. This is not a game for stiff people. Apologies but you will lose if you don't adapt quickly.Cons1. Pace - Pace of the game slows down somewhere between the mid-game to end game and it can be a bit draggy. So it's up to the player how to makes things interesting (which will dependwhat victory route he/she wants to pursue).2. Agenda system - This is such a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ since you'll never know the combination of things to please your AI players. I guess this is part of the challenge, but it may turn offnew players.3. Not a New Player friendly game - Coming from point 2, this is not a newbie game. You arebetter off in CIV 5 or CIV 4, The game can be very challenging for new players as the gameplayentails a lot of things (city building, AI, etc.).This game is not perfect and it appeals to certain groups of people and I would rate this game around a 7.5/10.Get this game on sale but it's still worth the price. :)

title: Not Recommended
comment: After playing for a long time, I really wanted to like the game but the game is just boring. All the new mechanics like unstacked cities add value for a while but after playing for 100+ hours, I dont see enough values. Also, where is the damn workshop? There is steam workshop advertised but none in sight. Is that suppose to be another "feature" later added to bring back players? Its infuriating.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Honestly save your money. The game devs first launched the game and instantly bugs everywhere. There was no cross-platform multiplayer (and still isn't), the AI didnt use air or naval troops (and still use them badly), the AI even on the hardest mode is still like playing against a child, the devs continue to push out dlcs instead of fixing issues that were reported months ago, and any update they release, they take months to fix any bugs that it adds (if ever). It is a real dissappointment compared to Civ 5 and in the end i just don't see this game ever becoming worth the 60 dollars they charged for the half a game they gave.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm here from Civilization 4, having skipped Civilization 5 and received this game from a friend (it wasn't free to him, but he did get a game from me!). On the surface there's a fair bit to like. I mean, it's a 4X game. We love 4X games! And there are new civs to hang out with, with special objectives (which, I'm told, was brought out in Civ 5) that make the AIs simultaneously easier to predict and more fun to engage with as a general idea. Inspirations and Eurekas! I can do things to get bonuses toward research! Civics get researched in tandem with techs instead of being unlocked by them! The civs all have something unique about them beyond a special unit and a special building. Who'd have thought you could research new civics by beating up barbarians?!But then there were a few bugs. Not glitches, but stinging insects that got too noisome to ignore, and these are going to make me wait for some major content patching before I'll be ready to hop back in:1. Districts. I hate them. I hate that a single military unit can set me back dozens of turns by burning down a couple of buildings because they were set outside the main city tile. I found this out when a barbarian chose not to run away from a unit that was absolutely going to destroy the barbarian, and burned my university down instead. I hate also that I have to spend a couple dozen turns before I can even *start* building my library and university because I first have to...what. Clear the land for them?2. SCALING COSTS, capitalized for emphasis. The first builder you produce will cost X. The second will cost X+Y. The third will cost X+Y+Z. The same holds true for buildings, districts, all other units, whether you built them with gears or bought them with gold or faith. It's bad enough that I first have to put down an industrial zone before I can start my workshops and factories, but my modern-aged new city will take FOREVER to finish that zone because a few other cities had already built one. This is backwards beyond belief, and possibly worst of all...the game documentation DOES NOT TELL YOU that this is happening! It isn't in the manual anywhere that building a musketman now will make the next musketman cost more gears to produce or more gold to buy.I've heard this is to encourage you to 'build tall' instead of 'build wide', which I assume means to focus your cities so that this one is the commercial city, that one's the factory city, this other one makes soldiers...but, as before, your districts sit outside your city and can be pillaged. Three turns can ruin a hundred of yours.3. Hex grid movement. This one isn't going to change, and I'm willing to put up with it, but ultimately I find I dislike hex grids for how restrictive they are to movement. Further, the game is often very poor at telling you that moving, for example, through a threatened series of grids costs more movement to pull off.4. Builder charges. WTF with builder charges. I heard the reason for them (now you don't have a bunch of buildings sitting around and doing nothing!), but they're bogus (You could just disband them, y'know). The increasing cost of builders, as with everything else, makes builder charges one of the worst mechanics I've seen in a Civ game.5. Roads. They can only be built by trade caravans, but you can't cancel and reroute trade caravans that I've seen. They stop when a trading post is built (seems random to me so far), but there's otherwise no reliable way to get roads between your cities.There are others, but these are some of the most frustrating on the list.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Its a good game however it feels lacking compared to civ V and I would not says that it's worth £50

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just Dont. Get Civ 5. I regret buying this game. This game just "looks" good. The core is crap like beyond earth.

title: Recommended
comment: How to beat Delty enemy:Congrats! You unlock 12 achivements.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It is a like all Civs at launch, a work in process. It is some what fun but the AI is not good and the board game additions are not the best. My biggest gripe is the DLCs are not worth the cost imo. I mean if they are worth the price they are asking then the game at launch was worth less the nothing. I mean $60 got you like 15+ leaders and Civs and they want $5 apiece now so if they were worth it, then the game play aqnd engine is worth crap. Seems like a gready money grab to me for something that is not to much to make. If they charged $2 or $3 I would get them but $5 is just twice what the DLC are worth. Wait for a sale and go from there. Civ 5 complete is a great game you can get at a good price for the complete package. They did not nickel and dime us loyal players that have been here from the start, well until now.

title: Not Recommended
comment: If you are considering buying this game, I assume you are a long time Civilization player like myself. There is a long laundry list of reasons to not buy this game, but I'll give you a couple big ones: Still broken AI that borders on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, busted diplomacy that makes everyone mad at you for no reason (before even having done anything aggressive), and weird pseudo-cartoony choice of graphics (doesn't fit this style of game at all).On the plus side you now have a Civics tree and can make districts! Woo hoo!Still, I do not recommend buying this game until it costs 10-20 dollars and includes all DLC.11/23/17 - Checking back in after multiple updates. This game is still a heaping pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI and diplomacy are still broken and military conflicts take forever due to the fact you have to wait for the AI to take its turn leading to you waiting forever between turns on later ages...

title: Not Recommended
comment: My first review. I can't recommend this game. It will be good in a few years, much like Civ 5. In it's current form, CIV 5 is far superior. I do like some of the changes in this game but having to get new civs as DLC is beyond irritating. They are slow with their patches. They had a bug where the world tracker would pop up every turn even if you disabled it that lasted 3 patches. I imagine they had bigger concerns, which should make you hesitate in purchasing this game. It was a unfinished product. I hate that there is no "restart" option. I hate that it does not save your map settings between matches. So if you dislike your start, you have to reset each individual option. No WASD rebinding unless you dig deep into the LUA files which resets with each patch. wait 2-3 years when it and all DLC is 75% off.

title: Recommended
comment: Sid Meier's Civilization VISid Meier's Civilization VI is the next installation in the Civilization series. I have played all of the Civilization games from Civilization IV until now. Most of the reviews are comparing Civilization VI to V, so that is what I will do, because this is the game that will replace V. VI has many sweeping differences like the visual style, the district system, diplomacy, government types, civic and technology trees, and even different win conditions. These changes bring new methods to playing that users have to adapt to in order to succeed, for example, city planning is major. City planning can make or break your cities in that you cannot just settle near luxury resources and thrive, you need to have locations for districts, and if you're cunning, have good adjacency bonuses too. Wonders also play a major key in city planning, some wonders require that they, for example, are next to a river that is adjacent to a Commercial Hub (type of district). Now all of these changes bring the question, is it any good, and then, is it any better?+Visual style is refreshing for this series+ Districts and wonders require careful city planning+ Difficulty settings are more difficult than before+ Barbarians are relentless and seem more true to life+ Leaders have agendas that fit ingame scenarios and historical ones, too+ Declaring war must have reason, or you are considered a warmongerer+ Fantastic visuals on leader screens (individual hairs and pores!)+ New score is incredible and enticing. (personally, I like it better than Baba Yetu)+ User interface redesign is intuitive and detailed- Game is difficult to get involved in, more so than previous titles- Visual style is comparable to mobile games- Minor bugs and removals that are apparent (may be fixed soon)- Minor spelling errors (no periods, you instead of your, etc)- Some inconsistenties and weird stuff (dialogue when demanding stuff is the same as when trading)Civilization VI is a new title, released on October 21, and is still getting its footing. It has large shoes to fill for its predecessors and will certainly take some time to get everything in order, with bugs and DLC expansions to fix these issues or lackings. Now, the DLCs are still to come and there are minor issues to fix, so this review can't confirm or deny that it will get better, but it is likely. In conclusion, it is worth the full retail price of USD $60.

title: Recommended
comment: TL/DR: It's a good game. If you're a strategy fan or a past Civ player, buying now is money well spent. If not, when it comes on sale, you'll be having a blast with the rest of us.I'm going to write the rest of this review in a sort of Question / Answer format, just to get through the things that I think most people will actually want to know.Is it a proper Civ game?Yes. It's Civ at its finest again. This isn't a cut-down version like Civ 5 originally was. This is the whole delicious package, Religion, victory conditions, warfare and all.Doesn't the art style bother you?No. The art style grows on you as you play, I think. If you look at a lategame screenshot, you might find yourself overwhelmed with information - but if it's a playthrough you've been a part of, you'll quickly find yourself getting literate in what all those colourful chappies are. Firaxis have struck an elegant balance between distinctive, quirky appearance and enough visual clarity to tell what everything is.The thing that bothered me about Civ 5 was that the difficulty was entirely artificial. The AI was dumb. In Civ 6, I'm pleased to say the AI is still a moron, but it's a moron with a purpose. Rather than worrying about making the AI player a genius, which is probably nigh impossible, Firaxis have instead made the characters more colourful. They are going to give you hell, because they all have their own mini mission on the go, and will definitely feel more like living, interesting people playing the game right along with you. Glaringly obvious mistakes and all. Well. If they INSIST on leaving their tech level at the Renaissance, I for one won't feel the least bit bad about driving a tank into it...I haven't encountered any problems. Maybe that will change. If it does, expect an [edit] below.This game does a much better job of keeping the entire playthrough fresh and interesting. There's always something new to decide about, and because the global happiness/unhappiness mechanic is gone, there's no harm in expanding quite broadly, to fill up as much of the world as you can. Of course, you can choose to sulk behind your city's Ancient Walls if you choose, but if you insist on being a boring person, you'll probably find the AI manoeuvres you into a corner. Seriously, watch Philip of Spain. His religious build is a nightmare once it gets going.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The workshop tag was removed after launch. As the SDK is withheld, the modding scene is nowhere as big as it was for previous titles.Months after launch, and the AI has not been fixed.I don't see a reason buying this over Civ 4, which I found much more compelling in terms of diplomacy, AI behaviour, culture and religion mechanics, and policies ("civics"). Also, there is more content in the Civ 4 GOTY edition than you will encounter in Civ 6 for the next few years of DLC milking.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Boring. No fun at all.Civ V is a way better!(Playing Civ since 1991)

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is not finished. Of all the times I have given a game a chance dispaite the obvious cashgrab, this was one of the worst experiences I've ever had. I expected better from this franchise.

title: Recommended
comment: Another great Civ release. Unfortunatley we will be waiting for the rest of the game for awhile. Civ V took until the last DLC to become a full game, and I expect the same for this one. It's just the way it is nowadays. But gameplay is great, I'm really liking the new Wonder and district tiles, changes things up a bit. I've read alot of negative reviews, but there isn't a game out there that releases the full great version anymore. Patience is key, but if you've been a Civilization fiend since Civ 1, I'd recommend it. It's a beautiful game to look at as well.

title: Not Recommended
comment: My first review. I can't recommend this game. It will be good in a few years, much like Civ 5. In it's current form, CIV 5 is far superior. I do like some of the changes in this game but having to get new civs as DLC is beyond irritating. They are slow with their patches. They had a bug where the world tracker would pop up every turn even if you disabled it that lasted 3 patches. I imagine they had bigger concerns, which should make you hesitate in purchasing this game. It was a unfinished product. I hate that there is no "restart" option. I hate that it does not save your map settings between matches. So if you dislike your start, you have to reset each individual option. No WASD rebinding unless you dig deep into the LUA files which resets with each patch. wait 2-3 years when it and all DLC is 75% off.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Initially I really enjoyed the new Civ formula, spreading out the cities was a great idea.Unfortunately this was not enough to allow me to recommend this game. The concept was implemented poorly, the civic cards being far and few in usefulness to be worth it, the buildings are too sparse, feeling like there is nothing to build for long periods. Mods do make this a lot more bearable however.I have to talk about the reason that pushed this review over the edge, the DLC. Civ 5 introduced DLC perfectly but this game proceeds to add very similar "Leaders" (not always a different empire) for an extremely high price, with minimal benefit or change to the game itself. It was a real shame, I have loved this franchise ever since the 3rd game and this one has put me off a bit due to the pure lack of care and attention.If you are looking for a change to Civ 5 and can get it on sale, then go ahead, although do be warned about the poor AI and weak multiplayer...EDIT: With the recent announcement of more paid DLC it shocks me to see that they realise how broken the game is, but only offer to fix it via a PAID DLC. There is also no season pass. Screw you 2K and Fraxis. I hope you go the same was as EA.Also, when they update your game your mods stop working, so I can't play it for another month or so! :D

title: Recommended
comment: This is a very good game. I have played it alot and i feel like I have the authority to have a valid opinion.PROS- The art style is great. (in my opinion)- Better mechs than civ 5... trades, religion, politicts (goverments), civs and their personallities. etc- Multiplayer mod support aswell as the steam workshopNote that you will have a limit on multiplayer games depending on where you live.Its a good game overall.CONS- the AI needs fixing. Example:Norway: Ohh hello their! I am Harald!20 turns later...Norway: thanks for the delegation you sended.10 turns later....Norway: Thanks for not settling close to me10 turns later...Norway: Thanks for....Wait a sec...you have a weak navy! I denounce you!5 turns later...Norway: I declare war on you...despite everything good you did to me...but you have no navy soooo...As you can see. The AI is thinking to much on its agenda rather then thinking about other stuff.That is Civ 6's problem. But I am happy to tell you that there is a mod in the workshop that is called AI+ or something. That mod is the solution, so I guess you can fix the problem rather easy.Overall I give this game 95/100 points. If you like the civ games, you need to buy this one. If you have no clue what this is but likes strategy, then I would recommend this game. Thumbs up!

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's not BAD, but it's not great. They might as well call it Civ 40K because in this game... there is only war.Seriously though, AI will go to war with you at the drop of a hat - then take it back in 5 turns. Then call you a warmonger and go to war with you again. Then will declare peace after 30 turns. Also you might not even see an enemy unit in that entire time, lol, which makes it all the more absurd.If you can ignore the AI nonsense, it's a pretty good game but damn do they need to fire whoever was in charge of their AI system, as they dropped the ball in a massive fashion.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Since the last update I cant play a game beyond mid-game. Before the updates I had no problems. Non of the fixes that 2K suggested work. They were really more of a blame others for their programming then anything else. In it's current state I DO NOT reccomend this game. The devs broke it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ IV was the last title worth paying for. Once you learn a decent build order in V/VI there is no point playing beyond the Ancient Era. The game will be snowballing in your favor and the AI will *never* comeback.Unstackable troops and ranged defenders allow you to easily advance through the game with a single ranged unit defending each base. The AI will randomly declare war, throw away 2-4 units and sue for peace.When two AI factions are warring with eachother, wait until a city defense is low. Declare war and annex/raze the city on a single turn. The victim will sue for peace and the attacker just moves on. Rinse and repeat.There is no punishment for these tactics. They will lead to a quick and easy domination win on the highest difficulties while producing only a handful of units.Without stackable units the only way to make the game challenging is to DISABLE WAR COMPLETELY. What a joke. Don't buy.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As some other reviewers mentioned, don't bother with this when you can just get your Civ fix with 5. In comparison, Civ V is far more streamlined than Civ VI. This game adds "complexity" in the form of extra micromanagement; turns take longer but I don't gain any enjoyment from that. In particular, I'm not fond of the new city management. It bogs everything down. Happiness, while a bit simple, was far better than this nonsense.I also don't like the new tile management, with placing districts and wonders. Districts is okay, I guess, but having to deal with both districts and wonder placement just takes too much extra effort and foresight. In order to optimize each city, you have to have each tile it currently has and will have planned out for at least a few dozen turns, though 100 or more is ideal. Oh, and how each of those plans fit into your empire as a whole is important too.I feel like I need to start taking notes or make a spreadsheet while playing this game. . . And, to me, that isn't Civ. The franchise has always been on the lighter end of 4x games, particularly if you are playing single player. And that's what I liked: I like being able to open a relatively easy game of Civ to pass the time, or play when I'm tired, or to run while I'm watching a show. It's relaxing. But Civ VI takes that away from me without really giving me anything worthwhile in return.Is this a popular opinion? I don't know. Have I played it a bunch? No. I'm staring at my 6.6 hours thinking about how much crap I'm going to get for a negative review with under 20 hours in a 4x game, but guess what? It didn't take long to figure out that the game just isn't my thing. I have no interest in playing the current game. And, based on playtime, my friends seem to feel the same way.If you like it, well, great! But I can't recommend a game when I'd rather be playing the previous game in the series.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ 5 is 10 times better. More civs, better graphics, better gameplay in general.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Every single game devolves into getting denounced for defending myself from an invader. Every. Single. Game. Maybe in a couple years it'll be worth a purchase, but I'd just buy any other Civ title if I were you.

title: Not Recommended
comment: What a boring♥♥♥♥♥game. For some reason every single player match seems the same. Ghandi goes loco, islam is the overtaking religion, China always has the biggest population and most cities. (It actually plays like that, I dont intend to start anything here).The game is extremely repetative and not exciting. I never really felt like finishing a match, and that is because of the worst part of this game: After you researched and upgraded everything, there is nothing more to it. Its just moving your units around and keep upgrading your cities like you did with the previous 900. The dialogue with other factions in this game is so horrible and limited. Its either ''gib monie'' or star a war.For some reason I get really nauseous when playing this game. You'll get that sometimes when you're REALLY bored.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've played all of the civ games - and this is the worst. It has a lot of good ideas in the game but is badly let down in three areas.1. Religion. This is a frankly tedious game mechanic and becomes the dominant strategy in every game I've played. I spend every turn working out how to stop religious infiltration and little else. The only way to stop it permanently is to go to war.2. UI is terrible. Very laggy, clunky and counter-intuitive meaning frequent unintended moves.3. The processing is woefully slow. Each turn I spend a minute or so deciding how to counter the religious invasion. A few seconds managing research and construction. Then five minutes waiting for the next turn. This had always been an issue with civ games but is much, much worse with civ 6.If history is anything to go by, religion will most likely be fixed in a patch or upgrade. But the UI and turn speed aren't likely to go away. A very disappointing game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is not ready. Lots of annoying bugs, stupid AI. Just don't.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game is as good as V but the way Firaxis treated Polish customers is a disgrace. They put winged hussars in the Civ6 launch trailer, and finaly didn't give Poland as playable nation in base version, which was a pure lie. Than after ppl buy the game and don't get what they were supposed to get they offer us 13mb "dlc" that unlocks Poland for only 5 euro. If I bought Civ6 for 50 euro I will pay that 5 for their damn "dlc" to make Poland into space and they knew that many Poles will think this way. This is the last time they get my money...

title: Not Recommended
comment: Completely broken, unbalanced, unstable game. Like Civlilzation III, only worse due to needless complexity, irrational game design concepts, and poorly conceived game mechanics.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just look at the DLC page, developer released unfinished game that is borderline unplayable thanks to broken diplomacy and then added fixes in expansion pack along with nations that each cost 5$. Got the game on sale and I still think it was a waste of 23$, I got Civ V with both expansions and it looks and plays ten times better then this s...tuff.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In December of 2014, my brother introduced me to what quickly became (and has remained) my absolute favorite video game, and one of my preferred modes of entertainment- Civilization V. As someone who has always enjoyed studying history and playing turn-based strategy games (i.e. Risk), Civilzation V was a dream come true. Because of my experience with Civ V, I was very excited for the release of this game, and (after initially restraining myself from pre-ordering) actually decided to shell out $60 to buy the game shortly after its release instead of waiting for a sale. You can see from the gigantic red thumbs-down next to this post that I was disappointed. Since I bought the game, I've tried over and over again to enjoy it or, at the very least, find some way to justify spending as much as I did on this, but I can never stick with it for very long.Other than how bare-bones this game feels when compared to Civ V (which, admittedly, has had 6.5 years not to be expanded upon), my largest issue with this game would have to be the change in the way players can interact with other civilizations. The diplomacy feels much more superficial and the interactions are much more limited- for example. you can no longer pay a civilization to declare war on another. Also, diplomacy in Civ 6 doesn't seem to be very useful- asking civilization to stop sending missionaries and apostles to your cities doesn't seem to have any effect, other than to give you casus belli when they invariably break their promise by sending wave after wave of missionaries and apostles (which are prohibitively expensive for players, but surprisingly common for AI) to convert your cities back.I understand that comparing a game that had (at the time I purchased it) 4.5 years of enhancements and bug-fixes to a (now) 4 month old game is not going to be a fair comparison. That being said, I don't believe that this game is currently worth the ~$60 that I paid for it. If you are a fan of the Civilization franchise, stick with the other installments for awhile- if you haven't yet played any of the Civ games, I would suggest paying the $45 to buy Civilization 5 Complete, which is currently a much better and more complete game, instead of spending $60 on Civ 6.Since it's 2 in the morning and I'm exhausted, I have to throw this onto the end: I do like the introduction of districts in this game and the emphasis that places on city planning, as well as the separate research trees for technology and civics. I also like the way you have to unlock governments, each of which provide unique bonuses and provide different policy card slots.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Seriously don't bother, at least not yet.Civ4 remains by far the best in the series, and Civ 6 is just not a game at this time. The AI is the worst in any game every. For a game they charged £50 for, to have AI that walk around with warriors when you have Machine gunners on highest difficulty beggars belief. They are destroying this franchise, civ5 was poor and this is just much worse.Although - there is scope to fix and improve, there are seeds of good ideas, but they are only useful if the game actually works and the AI is a credible opponent. This is primarily a single player game, so it needs depth and quality AI, it has neither.If you must buy, get it for £10 in a year, by then they may have improved it. What a shame, has been my favorite game since Civ2.

title: Not Recommended
comment: If there was a "neutral" rating option, I would have picked it. Since there isn't, I went with the thumbs down because of three issues that to me are important and would affect my own decision on whether or not to buy the game again. Decide for yourself if these are aspects that matter to you:- As of writing this, the game still does not have a UI/font scaling option that works with all resolutions. It appears to be available at 4k, but at 1440p (2560x1440) the upscaling option is disabled and can't be enabled by editing the config file. Text and icons are uncomfortably tiny.- No teams. Surprisingly, the co-op option was removed in Civ6. You can only play against your friends, but not team up with them to play against the AI. You also can't form teams with the AI.- The AI is peculiar and has major trouble with combat and diplomacy. Yes, just like in Civ5, though just more so. It also doesn't understand districts well and seems to be mostly focused on spamming missionaries.It's fundamentally a good game and rather promising, but since we pay for games the way they are now, not for how the may or may not turn out in a year's time, I gave my recommendation based on the game as it is (it's not an inexpensive game). I'll update the review as the game evolves.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I think this series kind of peaked at Civ 4. I've been playing since the original Civ back on my 386 (iirc) so I've seen most iterations of the game. I bought Civ 5, and didn't overly enjoy it. The videos of Civ 6 and the idea of districts really interested me, so I forked out another sixty goddamned dollars on a game I might not like.This game plays at an absolute snails pace, and was not enjoyable for me at all. If you are an older Civ fan, you might not like this game. If you are a newcomer to the series, buy Civ 4 and all its expansions, it'll cost you maybe a fifth of the cost of this game, and you will get a better experience for it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have to give this a thumbs down for the moment as the dev philosophy is miserable. I bought this for full price (Deluxe version) but I am in fact a second class customer. The fall update (released on 19th Oct 2017) is as of today (20th Dec) still not available for Mac.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ VI has the potential to be the best in the franchise, however the current version feels like an alpha build. The UI is bad, the AI is worse, and the tech tree is in need of some serious adjustment. I'd say wait for a patch or DLC, but for now stay away.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Unplayable since spring "patch". Barbarians hang the game. Excessive turn times. The AI was bad enough, now it is reduced to unplayable status. If you like using your brain to play a game, waiting 5 to 10 minutes for a turn to complete (if you are lucky) in the classical era simply because a barbarian appears and pillages a square is a game ender for me. I'm disgusted Firaxis and Sid Meyer would let this happen. The money grab of DLC is bad enough, but you'd expect the game to actually work. Sadly this is not the case. Nothing is sacred. Thanks Sid. Pointing the finger at you.

title: Recommended
comment: Despite the world congress missing from the game, I'm quiet enjoying it. Honestly, more so than 5. I have a much smoother experience and it crashes less. All in all, I believe it was a good buy.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just look at the DLC page, developer released unfinished game that is borderline unplayable thanks to broken diplomacy and then added fixes in expansion pack along with nations that each cost 5$. Got the game on sale and I still think it was a waste of 23$, I got Civ V with both expansions and it looks and plays ten times better then this s...tuff.

title: Recommended
comment: After my first few hours, I can say that this iteration certainly feels more involved than the previous. The city state bonuses are a much welcomed improvement, with enough variation between them that they have a fairly significant impact on each game. The fact that envoys in city states are permanent and you don't have that annoying notification "no longer friend/ally with city state" that prompted you to splurge more gold to keep the benefit is gone.Combat feels much the same as Civ 5 - I haven't experimented with the new corps feature yet - only to protect settlers and builders.Having a military early game suddenly became a whole lot more important. Where I used to just sit back and build wonders, you can't do this any longer because you will either get stomped by an aggressive opponent (surprise war) or barbarians will just amass and sack you.The 1-more turn feeling is very much alive.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game has no quality control whatsoever. Every 3 months a patch is released which usually introduces just as many easy to discover bugs as it fixes. For example in the summer patch a bug was introduced where an opponent would present you with a deal but would act like you presented it to them and they diapproved of the deal. If you clicked the "Propose" button the AI would accept it. This doesn't happen occasionally, it happened every single time. I think this particular bug has been fixed but if the devs spent 5 minutes actually playing the game they would have caught this bug. In the fall patch that was released a week or two ago starting spawns were broken. So if your civ was a coastal sea-faring nation you could find yourself on a single tile of snow in the middle of the ocean.Wait maybe 6 months or so and maybe the devs will stop being dumb and actually fix this nonsense.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am another veteran of the glorious 90's years, when a genius like Sid unleashed the powers of suspended disbelief with his masterpiece, Civ 1, by just applying a simple axiom: "We make games that we want to play". Long gone are those times. I wanted to give the Civ 6 team the benefit of the doubt after they basically saved the previous iteration from the initial disaster. I got the Deluxe Edition, and waited... played some 400+ hours, nothing compared to the thousands in previous iterations, and waited... did some modding (CQUI), and waited some more, only to be met by the Summer "patch". I have to say that, from my point of view, the latest Summer "patch" is the worst in the franchise's history bar none. Never before has a civ patch not only fail to fix glaring bugs that existed for months, but also introduced new ones, some of them plain shameful. Such disrespect for the customer base and the fans can only be met by one sentence: DO NOT BUY. If you still want to give Firaxis the benefit of the doubt, wait until the customer base has a final veredict, probably only after the cosmetic DLC's cycle is over, and perhaps the expansions are out. Wait, until either Firaxis betters the quality of their updates, or the price drops so far down to be consistent with the present quality of the product. Wait. Wait and see.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's beautifully presented. Sean Bean! Many choirs and orchestras! But ultimately, at the moment, this game rings hollow. This might change with expansions--it usually does; but at the moment, if you'd like some Civ satisfaction, stick with Civ 5. This one is dreadful, especially in the later stages of the game.

title: Recommended
comment: Disclaimer: Since there is no "Maybe" option for "Do you recommend this game?" I am putting "Yes". I really mean, "Yes, for people who LOVE a challenge and who want to play the latest Civ game."I've been playing Civ since number 2, which I spent an absurd amount of time playing during my formative years and I love this series to death, but I have no idea how I feel about this game. It feels like an abusive relationship that I can't escape because I just keep believing that the game will treat me right if I just do it better next time...and then it slaps me in the face again and tells me to shut my mouth.I love some of the changes and additions they made to the game such as making you think about placement of cities, districts and improvements because it has a huge impact on your future, the change to governments and the civics tree, technology and civics boosts, and the improvement of trade routes and trading posts. I especially love the changes to city states and the awesome bonuses they give you for becoming suzerain/sovereign of them.On the other hand, I don't understand how they think the AI is coded correctly in any way. They will declare war on you for no reason, constantly refuse requests for friendship even if they are "friendly" toward you; and once they are at war with you, they will barely assault a single city (usually just my capital so far). I've just sat there and picked off troops one by one with my city defenses as they just stand outside my city not attacking it. Meanwhile, the civs I'm not at war with denounce me because they think I'm a warmonger, when all I've done is DEFEND my cities and never once declared war on anyone!It's nearly impossible to appease any of the other civs. First impressions of you? Negative; almost always. Have more positive numbers going for you than negative in the relationship window? They're still unfriendly toward you even though the math they show you on screen should put you at neutral or above. Pumping all of your resources into culture? Brasil, who likes civs with more science and culture than they have (and hates those with less), still won't like you because you're dumb and have less science than they do. After Montezuma finally grew tired enough of waging war on me and not winning (because he barely sent any troops and they just stood outside my gates), he offered me peace and a TON of his luxuries. Which would be great, except that his main personality trait is that he hates anyone who has more luxuries than him/luxuries he doesn't have yet. So...he made peace and completely set himself up to get mad at me again later.Also, barbarians are insane. I spent ALL of my time until the medieval era trying to get rid of them and they still were everywhere; I could barely get anything built in my cities! Now if they spawn near horses, they have horsemen. And they have scouts that report back once they see your city and get the barbarians to come attack it. I only got to play long enough to get to the modern era after turning them off.All of my above experience has been on the standard difficulty. Maybe I'll try one of the wimpy difficulties and see if I can just crush the civs that will become a pain before they grow powerful enough to matter.Firaxis, PLEASE fix the AI in this game. I love this series and hate to see "features" that are just clearly bugs. I can't possibly fathom how you coded it so that the pacifistic defending civilization can be seen as a warmonger. If my feelings on the game change I will update my review, but for now my relationship with Civ VI remains...strained.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After playing more than 800 hours of Civ 5, I was really looking forward to this game. Iv tried civ 6 over and over again, hoping that it will be decent. But it isn't. It is horrible.There are several bugs, even now months after release. The AI had no improvement at all since civ 5. AI spam units, while throw them at you for free experience. The game has way less content than civ 5 overall. The victory types seem unbalanced, especially religious units that can easily be picked off by military. Your choices seem to make no difference. Diplomacy is either random or illogical. The new amenity system and how more cities increase district cost meens u have to make cities in stacks of 4 (4, 8, 12, 16 etc) and with no posibilty to arange amenities yourself. Worst off all i find how overpowered military is. This is especially true versus AI, as they can't controll their units at all. But also against players, the fact that cities have no defence, and even when upgraded they can be taken down by just a pair of soldiers. Also while districts become more costly after number of districts you got, units is always same price. You will have a hard time going all out for science, while you can produce millitary in every city with no problem at all.All games are done in king or higher difficulty

title: Not Recommended
comment: Great game features and great layout.BUT F*** i hate the new diplomacy and constant war!It do not matter, wether you make a friend or foe, because they attack you either way!Thank you for a pointless game!I used to love civilizationen.. but this.. makes no sense..

title: Not Recommended
comment: I must concur the AI is terrible. No matter what I do, even being peaceful, everyone hates me. Often times as soon as two AIs can do a Joint War they declare one on me, and I have done absoutely nothing to them. This includes Gandhi and Roosevelt. I even traded with them. I dare defend myself, capture a city, and am branded a warmonger forever more. I just don't care anymore what the AI civs think. They'll hate me eventually. It's as bad if not worse than the original Civilization game where the default is everyone hates you as soon as they meet you.Tchaikovsky is in error. When it says 1812 Overture the music played is Romeo and Juliet. When it says Romero and Juliet, the music played is Nutcracker.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Fraxis & 2k Games are total♥♥♥♥♥♥ cant make multiplayer stable after an entire year, their employees are ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Talk about fixing what isn't broken, what a massive disappointment.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The workshop tag was removed after launch. As the SDK is withheld, the modding scene is nowhere as big as it was for previous titles.Months after launch, and the AI has not been fixed.I don't see a reason buying this over Civ 4, which I found much more compelling in terms of diplomacy, AI behaviour, culture and religion mechanics, and policies ("civics"). Also, there is more content in the Civ 4 GOTY edition than you will encounter in Civ 6 for the next few years of DLC milking.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's not BAD, but it's not great. They might as well call it Civ 40K because in this game... there is only war.Seriously though, AI will go to war with you at the drop of a hat - then take it back in 5 turns. Then call you a warmonger and go to war with you again. Then will declare peace after 30 turns. Also you might not even see an enemy unit in that entire time, lol, which makes it all the more absurd.If you can ignore the AI nonsense, it's a pretty good game but damn do they need to fire whoever was in charge of their AI system, as they dropped the ball in a massive fashion.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Since the last update I cant play a game beyond mid-game. Before the updates I had no problems. Non of the fixes that 2K suggested work. They were really more of a blame others for their programming then anything else. In it's current state I DO NOT reccomend this game. The devs broke it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Initially I really enjoyed the new Civ formula, spreading out the cities was a great idea.Unfortunately this was not enough to allow me to recommend this game. The concept was implemented poorly, the civic cards being far and few in usefulness to be worth it, the buildings are too sparse, feeling like there is nothing to build for long periods. Mods do make this a lot more bearable however.I have to talk about the reason that pushed this review over the edge, the DLC. Civ 5 introduced DLC perfectly but this game proceeds to add very similar "Leaders" (not always a different empire) for an extremely high price, with minimal benefit or change to the game itself. It was a real shame, I have loved this franchise ever since the 3rd game and this one has put me off a bit due to the pure lack of care and attention.If you are looking for a change to Civ 5 and can get it on sale, then go ahead, although do be warned about the poor AI and weak multiplayer...EDIT: With the recent announcement of more paid DLC it shocks me to see that they realise how broken the game is, but only offer to fix it via a PAID DLC. There is also no season pass. Screw you 2K and Fraxis. I hope you go the same was as EA.Also, when they update your game your mods stop working, so I can't play it for another month or so! :D

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just from playing one game in Civ 6, i am bored and probably going back to Civ 5. I wasnt planning on concurring the entire continent but the AI is just annoying. I was able to destroy 7 players with 2 cannons, 2 rifleman, a machine gun team, and 2 tanks. Thats it. It was ridiculous.Like many others i found the lack of information about each city annoying, the housing, amenity, food, combo was also annoying. I enjoy the wonder finish videos but like many others, you have to have special tiles for each wonder. Just let me build it wherever i want!There is more and many others have already stated what is good and bad. But, at this point, i cant give this game a thumbs up.

Not too much has changed from the vanilla versions. Firaxis/2k love their money, so only buy if it's on sale

title: Not Recommended
comment: It took several months but the game still has a lot of bugs. It looks like a beta at best, not a production-ready AAA-title.Firaxis has many game-designers and screenwriters which create new nations and skins, but this game is not playable as Civ 5. I'm talking about fair multiplayer game. You cant play equitable match in vanilla civ6, you need to install third-party mods that provide you better UI, better balance, fewer bugs. For example, for this 6 months Hellblazer brings much more things, features and bug fixes than WHOLE FIRAXIS Dev team. I do not literally understand what they really do.I think, Hellblazer deserves my money (i mean cost of the game) more then firaxis.

title: Not Recommended
comment: To say this game is a disappointment is not harsh enough. This game is multiple steps backward for the Civ series. Instead of taking what worked in Civ 5 and improving on it, they destroyed it and created a game with less strategy, less control and a slight improvement in graphics quality. If you don't own Civ 5, buy that instead, save money and enjoy a game that is much much better. My hope is they will realize how bad Civ 6 is, go back to Civ 5 and improve on the AI, graphics and increase the ability to engage in diplomacy (one thing Civ 6 does right) as well as improvements in empire management. There are aspects of Civ 6 that would work better as an improvement on Civ 5, but the downsides far outweigh the few improvements Civ 6 has.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Delayed this review since I believed that this game would become better with time like previous entries in the series. There is honestly a lot to like about Civ 6 and as a core the game is good. Chances are you've heard what the najor issues are but here is what I think is right and wrong with the game:-The game is impressive graphically and I really like the art style, however I would say it isn't better or worse than Civ 5 just different-Districts are a nice additon to the game as well-Barbarians are no longer a nuisance and now can be an oturight threat to your progression in any given game, killing them provides certain inspirations and eurekas which help development of the tech and civics tree but ultimately they're not that impacting in a positive way-Most Civs tend to either be focussed toward being a warmonger or nothing in particular, having versatility can be a good thing but I also feel that this further enphasizes being a warmonger. Most of the games I've played tend to be kill everyone or endure their petty complaints-The AI agendas whilst promising in nature for some variation in diplomatic goals basically almost means you're hated by everyone since you can't do the abitrary things they want you to do. Even when you do fulfil them other civs hate you or the fulfilment isn't recognised (I've had mulitple 'money grubbers' tell me it's great my economy is doing well one turn to then tell me 20 turns later my economy is terrible even though it hadn't changed in that time). When one civ declares war on you it tends to make others do the same even if they had no reason to and the friendly with them until that point-Like previous titles I was expecting that we would receive additional content through expansions containing signifcant updates, but given the announcement and release of Macedonia and Persia I think that content will just be drip fed through to the community as one or two civs as dlc. It would be nice if game was given some more substantial expansion as seen in Civ 5In short I can't recommend this game in it's current state

title: Not Recommended
comment: Talk about fixing what isn't broken, what a massive disappointment.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Very expensive, no more engaging than Civ V and it's very clear the aim of the DLC is to bleed you dry. Just get/stay with Civ V for a similar experience with more content for less extortionate prices.

comment: Well, as fan of the series since second entry, this was a dissapointment. Jusst check out top rated negative reviews, they said it all.I'll just add: **** you Firaxis for this **** DLC policy.
