title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ 6 while being a decent game, is lacking in comparison to other civ titles. The total content of Civ 6 right now is nowhere near Civ 5 while being much more expensive. The minor technical changes in the game aren't worth the price. Overall, Civ 6 introduces some interesting mechanics that provide minor game changes, but with a lack of content and steep price in comparison to other civ games forces me to recommend not wasting your money on this game and instead buying Civ 5 with all the dlc unless you want to complete your civ collection.Some may argue that I shouldn't compare Civ 6 to Civ 5 because one is a completed game and the other still has content being released, however being that one is currently much cheaper with all of it's content delivered and the other is much more expensive, with less content, and that any additional content will require more high prices.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Great game if you only plan to play solo.Absolute garbage when you try multiplayer (especially 5+ players). Multiple forum posts exist on the problem with connecting 5+ players, yet their support does not even attempt to aknowledge the problem. We have a group of 7 guys that (used to) play Civ every week. Civ 5 was... ok (multiplayer issues were abundant, but at least we could get it to work). Civ 6, we can't even get 7 people in the game at the same time. Absolute garbage. I say for the third time: ABSOLUTE GARBAGE.Do not buy this if you plan to ever play with friends.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Stcik to Civ5 this game is utter crap besides the graphics.Instead of my babyrage comment now that I have put some hours in I'll try to hit valid complaints.GRAPHICS:Lets start with the good. The graphics and animations are beautiful. It really feels like the majority of the buget went to the art and animation department. Everything in the game is crisp it, it flows super well and is a huge improvement over Civ5.AI:Lets get the elephant in the room out of the way here. The AI is the worst I've seen since early gen FPS. The first 100 turns it feels like your could actually lose to them but after that they disappear (not really). The trades they offer are absoultely insane. I got offered 1 gold for 5 Lux resources, it kind of floored me. Peace trades are also pretty insane. I think the best I got offered was for my peace (I was doing a dom vic) was peace + 5gold a turn. Another thing I don't see much about on these reviews is the constant assualt of taunts and getting spammed by the AI. Holy mother of god is it bad. If playing with 6 AI you will get 40 AI taunts per turn. Not really but it feels that bad The worst is you can only turn off the animations and not the pointless taunts themselves. It takes a lot out of the game having to spam the esc key after your turn just to make it out of the spam phase. The AI's military tactics are laughable at best. They send units 1 by 1 to get picked off by whatever you have. After you get walls the chance of losing a city is pretty much none. The barbarians are stronger and play better then the player AI's.GAMEPLAY:Now the real heart of the game is the gameplay. It has the same but different vibe going for it. The resources such as food, production, and gold work the same way. The luxury items now count for amenities. Which is like happiness but each city has it own seperate want . The builders count as work boats now and instead of lasting forever they get a couple of builds then poof like a great person. Now tile improvements if where the game feels bare. Most of the improvements form Civ5 come way later into the game around 200ish turns, such as lumber camps and mines; unless you tech for those. Majority of tile imrpovements come from district which act as main hubs for building. Before you would have a forge, workshop, factory etc. Now you have a industry district which takes up a tile and you then have to research the buildings for it. This makes the game feel slower than normal as you can get all the districts pretty quickly but to get the sub buildings, that takes a while. Citys now have housing and amenities. I have never had a problem with housing and once you get a entertainment district its pretty much gg on amenities. So the housing is a waste of development time and adds nothing to the game. The have neighborhoods which is 2-6 housing and once u get that you really never have to worry about over population.Trades and spies get a short seperate piece since they work and I like them but there is something that is never said about them. THEY SPAM THE LIVING ♥♥♥♥ OUT OF THE SCREEN WITH CONSTANT PLAYER UPDATE INFORMATION. I wish I had a screenshot of this but is so bad. Sometime is takes up a good 80% of your screen and its junk info. China build a road. Brazil made a trade route with its own city. Just a bunch of stupid crap and it really, really needs to go. I would Google img search this to get a good idea infact I saw a reddit post.I can go into a lot more about how early game is basically spam units the protect form the massive barb onslaught or how civs from across the map will literally make a city on your lap, but thats the fun you get to figure out if you buy this steamer. I hope expansions make it better but at the same time they sold a 60doller sell game. I bought this from GMG for 46% off and I would still not reccoment it for anything under 70%. As it stands this game is a solid 4 out of 10.

comment: way overrated! just play CIV5, its just as good, Endless Legends is better.

comment: Don't ever buy anything Civ related in launch. Wait for the bundle with discounts. They screwed early buyers and Deluxe edition buyers.

comment: buy Civ V, do NOT make my mistake. 60 Dollars I would rather have spent on ♥♥♥♥♥s and crack (or even burned it).

comment: I thought I could learn to love this game, but the warmongering AI is making it impossible.

title: Recommended
comment: It put the clock at top right for a reason. So u know it is not time for you to go one more turn at 5am

title: Not Recommended
comment: Really haven't got into Civ VI that much. There is just something missing, that the previous Civ's had. I can't pinpoint what it is, but the graphics to me seem too "childish" or "candy", I liked the previous versions much more. Also the AI is a bit weak and dumb, declaring continuous wars that they have been declaring for the past 1000 years and loosing their territory in progress. And still, with only 1 city left they declare war and think they can win. Silly. I'm sure I will keep playing and enjoying the game, but doesn't suck me in as the previous versions did.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As a long time Civilization game player since Civilization II, I found Civ VI to be a tedious, slow board game filled with repetitive micro actions that emphasized optimizing game mechanics for war over all else, with inferior AI, subpar diplomacy, and inexplicably irritating game design.The incredibly slow and cluttered one unit per tile unit movement made the all too frequent wars by every AI opponent a boring chore. The AI opponents do not strategize interestingly nor are there multiple strong strategic warfare options for the player. Manually moving around units without the ability to construct permanent roads is dull and breaks immersion, Most of my game time felt like clicking and waiting. War is also unavoidable first with agressive early barbarians and then with the frequent inevitable surprise wars that every friendly AI declared. For example, the Vikings denounced my completely landlocked civ for lacking a strong navy, then attacked!The map art design makes it hard to see information at a glance such as where resources are located and oddly the areas already explored but out of view look almost like the fog of war, and many quality of life features from earlier versions of the Civ series are simply missing.Now that I have played Civ VI, I realize that I prefer earlier Civilization series games' more immersive simulation, strategic open-endedness and role-playing aspects. The earlier Civ series games Civ 4 and Civ 5, as well as Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, and the Civ 4 Fall from Heaven 2 mod, offer a much wider range of interesting decisions. Their one more turn addictive charm came from both superb game mechanics and an immersive world in which to play out decisions.Civ VI's focus is board game-like mechanics that focus overwhelmingly on competitive war among players as a path to victory. This, combined with the irritatingly limited AI/diplomacy and tediously paced gameplay felt unfun to me despite 40 hours of trying to enjoy the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Finally I feel pushed to write a recommendation not to buy this gem (yet). I will start off by saying that it is a good game, beautiful graphics and all that. But it doesn't matter because the most basic check box has not been fulfilled - the game cannot be played.The game crashes the same time every time. This is the second playthrough, that i've had to abandon because - well - I couldn't play onI have been in contact with customer service, and they were helpful although they asked a lot of help from me. Now it turns out that the error, they say they fixed suddenly occurs in another playthrough, so they probably just took the easy solution.At this time, I would not advice people to buy it simply because it's broken.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I actually pre-ordered this game and regret it. I love strategy and 4X games and have played them for 10+ years, but I can't think of a reason to recommend this game over any of the numerous other entries in the genre. Learn from my mistake and give this one a pass.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Imagine a minimalist version of Civilisation V seeking to make a return to Civ 2-4 that is purposfully slowed down in order to draw attention from the lack of content.Faction leaders are very well animated but its not enough to justify either the full price nor the £40 "sale" price.The game lacks too much content for £40 to be reasonable in any world, I'd reccomend Civ V to any newcomers to the series over this.

title: Not Recommended

title: Not Recommended
comment: The core concept of Civilization VI is strong, but the execution is weak. I love the idea of creating civilizations and interacting with leaders of another country, but the leaders lack personality and the static images come off as boring. 12 hours in and the dialogue options are stale. If you don't comply with everything they say they will just plain not like you. With the exception of Ghandi, Cleopatra, Montezuma, and a few others, I have no clue who the others are and I don't get a sense of excitement when I discover them in the world.However, my main gripe with this game is that it's boring. The point is to advance from era to era, but it doesn't feel like you are advancing in this game. The pacing is way too slow and the payoff is thin. I also wish there was less clutter and more clarity in the menus. Being my first entry in the series, the tutorial wasn't great either.Although it sounds I hate Civilization VI, there is a charm to it. It has the potential to be fun and great, but currently the game is just boring. Most people recommended Civilization V, and seeing the reviews and the gameplay, there's more life and love put in that game.I've yet to try playing online, but if, like me, you were planning to play with the A.I. (or a story mode--there's no story mode T_T), you'll come out disappointed.

The graphics are way too cartoony. I had to force mysef to play through. It makes city building more strategic. Unit stacking is also a nice tactical addition.But in all the other changes, its all for a much worse 4x gaming experience.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I had a hard time deciding how to rate Civilization 6, on one hand I really like it. It introduces a nice level of complexity that I felt Civilization 5 was missing, and there are many conceptual improvements. The empire-wide happiness mechanic is gone, which means that settling more than 4 cities is once again a staple.At the same time, this game was released unfinished. It's clear that it will need many more months of development, maybe even years, to reach the level of polish that Civilization 5 currently has. That's a shame too, they should not have sold the game as a finished product knowing its problems, but here we are. The short of it is, if you aren't a dedicated Civilization player or a fan of the series, go pick up Civilization 5 instead. It's cheaper, has more content, and is decently balanced. This game is not.The DLC for this game is also pretty underwhelming. Adding additional Civs to play as is nice, charging $5 each is not.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As a long time Civilization game player since Civilization II, I found Civ VI to be a tedious, slow board game filled with repetitive micro actions that emphasized optimizing game mechanics for war over all else, with inferior AI, subpar diplomacy, and inexplicably irritating game design.The incredibly slow and cluttered one unit per tile unit movement made the all too frequent wars by every AI opponent a boring chore. The AI opponents do not strategize interestingly nor are there multiple strong strategic warfare options for the player. Manually moving around units without the ability to construct permanent roads is dull and breaks immersion, Most of my game time felt like clicking and waiting. War is also unavoidable first with agressive early barbarians and then with the frequent inevitable surprise wars that every friendly AI declared. For example, the Vikings denounced my completely landlocked civ for lacking a strong navy, then attacked!The map art design makes it hard to see information at a glance such as where resources are located and oddly the areas already explored but out of view look almost like the fog of war, and many quality of life features from earlier versions of the Civ series are simply missing.Now that I have played Civ VI, I realize that I prefer earlier Civilization series games' more immersive simulation, strategic open-endedness and role-playing aspects. The earlier Civ series games Civ 4 and Civ 5, as well as Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, and the Civ 4 Fall from Heaven 2 mod, offer a much wider range of interesting decisions. Their one more turn addictive charm came from both superb game mechanics and an immersive world in which to play out decisions.Civ VI's focus is board game-like mechanics that focus overwhelmingly on competitive war among players as a path to victory. This, combined with the irritatingly limited AI/diplomacy and tediously paced gameplay felt unfun to me despite 40 hours of trying to enjoy the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI is absolutely atrotious in this game. I have played 2 full campaigns and quit in the middle of another because of the infuriating AI. They refuse to make peace unless you're on the verge of destroying you, end up denouncing you no matter what and just generally act stupid. I quit my most recent game since Japan refused to make peace unless I gave them a city (despite the fact that I destroyed their entire military) and then my citizens became unhappy because of the new war exhaustion system, which led to half of my empire revolting with nearly unkillable cavalry units pillaging all of my tiles. This game has so much going for it with the district system, interesting new unique civ abilities and units, and it's really great art style. The absolutely horrendous AI makes this game nearly unplayable in my opinion unless you play with friends, (I assume) which I haven't been able to do since none of them have bought this game. It's fun to a point but I can't recommend it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After playing the game for less than 6 hours, I'm already starting to see a few flaws that they REALLY need to polish out.Major Problems : Map GenerationOne major flaw that I've noticed is something that was a problem during the previous civilization games. That flaw is the lack of resources you can get at the start (Or within this game, the lack of unique tiles or specific tile types) will result in you having less than someone else because you wasn't given it. You're rewarding players because of randomness. I feel like Civ 5 did a decent job on balancing it out, but it may become a huge problem during some playthroughs of this.You could say that ''Well you're meant to focus your city depending on what you're given''. But the problem is to advance in any form of focus, you need science to research additional culture, faith or production based buildings. Esentially, because of you not being given mountain or jungle tiles at the beginning of the game, you can fall behind VERY quickly because you can't research the production buildings to make up for what you wasn't given but everyone else was.This doesn't seem as much of a problem late game if you learn what are the best landscapes for the additional bonuses you need. But again, those practical areas might be taken by someone else, leaving you with nothing but trash.My second flaw that I've noticed is the unfair reward and climax of creating war. The AI they have recently implimented to this game is a LOT better than previous iterations from what I've currently experianced. The AI actually knows what its doing.However, the only reason it knows what its doing is because its so easy to suddenly attack or defend from the opponent. I could make troops for 50 turns and gain a huge army, but because its so easy and quick to product units, it makes it waaay too easy to actually defend your city if it gets attacked. In multiple cases I've attacked the AI or the AI attacked me and we would just focus on defending by pumping out units and quickly out produce the speed the opponents attack. So there is no reward for keeping track of other civilization's armies and comparing it your own in order to defend yourself IF you actually get attacked.During previous games it would take between 2-6 turns to build a unit, so it was a lot harder to defend, but a lot more rewarding to attack or defend if you prepared beforehand. Now I can produce units in 1-3 turns that are equally as powerful as the ones attacking my city. I could not produce an army for the entire game and if someone attacks me with a huge army out of nowhere, its very easy to produce the same army in a small amount of time to defend. It makes wars worthless.And most of the time, you don't have an equal production tile spawn to someone else. So on turn one if someone else was to produce units and just smash everyone else quickly before they can build tiles required to defend, you have nothing to stop them from taking you out quickly and no production to do anything about it because you require technology in order to get the additional production you didn't have to start with. But you can't get the science because you wasn't given a bunch of mountains and a bunch of jungle THAT THE PERSON ATTACKING YOU WAS RANDOMLY GIVEN.Everything boils down to spawning with tiles that give you additonal science. Regardless of if you plan your cities really well or not, you can't just move your first settler away to find a bunch of mountain tiles because it takes 2-10 turns to find suitable land. Which again, makes you fall back in science and the production you didn't have to start with.A new cool feature is the way how technology can now be boosted depending on you doing things at the beginning of the game through out to make you save half of you time researching. But my complaint with this is that sometimes the boosted research depends on farming a resource. A resource you might not be randomly given at the beginning of the game which others might.It's a nice feature because it allows you to actually produce units and do certain events in order to get ahead. It's a neat way of micro management. But it needs to be adjusted a tad to not be so dependant on you spawning with something early game and delay those for later game when you start making multiple cities.I love the new policy system and the new govenment system. The government system is a new way to create the policy trees without some trees being completely useless. Instead you pick and choose what government you want and that allows you to pick diffrent amounts of the diffrent types of policies. Depending on what you want to do will depend on which ones you pick. Amazing.The policy system works in a similar manor as the research system but doesn't depend as much on what is randomly given to you. It's pretty neat. If you focus on culture, you can work your way to things that you wasn't given at the start of the game such as additonal science from the great libary earlier than anyone else. This is the CORRECT way to counter the problems I mentioned previously, and this system actually improves you culture a lot more instead of culture being dependant on science completely like in previous civilization games.The world generation is pretty good at giving you recources and stuff. However, resources aren't that important anymore due to the new districts. Most of the time it comes to the point you have to build the districts on some of the recources because they give you more of a boost than they otherwise would have anywhere else.Now before you say "But you said that the world generation is unfair as it gives stuff to certain people and not everyone else". That's not what I said. The world generation is good. But the way how you get a bonus for having the lucky roll of a die and then you get rewarded for that good roll isn't an efficent way how to make a fair strategic game. It makes players too dependant on randomization instead of skill which is what this kind of game isn't about.Knowing and understanding the best places to put things in your city is a great addition. But it needs balancing simply due to the fact that some people get terrain that give you easy bonuses and some terrains don't.The game itself looks amazing, I love all the details they did along with the new art style and direction they're trying. But for the love of god make it less dependant on how good your randomly generated start is.The day or night cycle is an additional graphical feature that doesn't add anymore to the gameplay, but it makes the game feel more dynamic and actually help you in feeling that you're controlling an empire.I love the new worker system. It doesn't take 1000 years to build on tiles anymore.I adore the looks of the user interface. It makes the game a unique tone of being modern and sleek but still makes it feel welcoming for players.A small complaint I have (which might just be a bug) is that you have to turn on the recource icons every time you start up the game because it resets every time you play it. I don't understand why this wouldn't be on by default, but I guess people who were play testing didn't need to know what they where getting from each tile. It's not like it's a Civilization game or anything.Regardless of what I say, I'm probably going to play it anyway. Because it's generally a well made game but right now it needs balancing. If I was to actually say yes or no to recommend this game, I'm gonna say no for the moment in time. Please don't NOT buy the game for this review Come back when some balancing is done.

title: Not Recommended

And for that reason, Civ VI seems to lack the endless playability present in V. I can't recommend this game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I just can't do it.The game makes some significant improvements over Civ5, but couteracts those with absolutely horrendous detractions.Pros over V:-The New district system for cities was a genuinely good idea, and as far as i'm concerned-- a major improvement.- few other minor tweaks and aesthetic details like continents-Delegations to city-states-Artifacts and greatworks-Wonders taking up space-housingCons--500 turn limit with no visible way to turn it off.-No way to customize your Civ's names-Fewer civs-Lock on how many civs you can put in a game (I like to play very crowded small-empire games)-AmenitiesHUGE Con:-An absolutely unplayable Diplomacy set up. and it's not something that can be fixed by simple updates, it's hard-coded into each civs personality. your best friends will randomly gang up on you for no reason, and youll gain warmonger just for defending yourself. then when you declare peace the game will tell you theyre friendly again.It's absolutely unnacceptable that this game have such a terrible problem and make it to the end of development. Im not someone who plays Civ and min-maxes everything, or even plays it like a boardgame. I'm someone who likes to put 20 Civs on a Small map with 50 City-states, turn off all victory conditions and play and role-play indefinently. but even if i was someone who played the game in a more intended fashion, the diplomacy system would still absolutely destroy any chance of me actually enjoying myself.There is not "Just one more turn..." feeling here... just disappointment in what is the worst Civilization game to date to me.Just play IV or V and give VI a pass unless a DLC comes out that overhauls this trash.

title: Recommended
comment: It's difficult to truly judge a Civilization game this early for more than a few reasons, but among them include the level of depth in the game that makes first impressions difficult to accurately form and the fact that Civilization games tend to start out of the gate significantly weaker than they end up being weeks, months, and especially years post-release.That being said, I would like to throw a strong recommendation for anyone on the fence about this one while still outlining a few issues that may or may not convince you to at least wait it out.Right off the bat though, the biggest question - does the game feel lacking after playing Civilization V with both expansion packs? Surprsingly no, it doesn't. In fact, I was very impressed with how many mechanics were not only carried over from Civilization V, but dramatically improved upon.Faith was a neat add-on in Civ5, providing nice perks that made it worth the effort to get involved with religion. However in Civilization VI, religious benefits aren't dramatically different, but the whole religious warfare aspect is much deeper. There's something incredibly satisfying about being able to fight a religious war with units, without the bloodshed of a full fledged war. The unit variety is smaller and religious units obviously can't attack anything but other religious units, but it provides a surprising amount to do, especially during the mid-game.City states feel much more fleshed out. You actively compete for their loyalty without needing to constantly run around completing quests that may or may not either go out of your way or worse, result in unwanted war or hatred from other civs and/or city states. This was improved upon in Brave New World, but Civilization VI absolutely tops it by making the loyalty itself a mechanic you can directly contribute to, while keeping "quests" as an alternate way to gain loyalty.Great Works and culture feel just as fleshed out as they did in Brave New World, making Great People such as Writers and Painters feel valuable by contributing Great Works. Added too are relecs which work much the same, but just goes that not only was nothing lost, but a little was gained.The World Congress isn't in Civilization VI right out of the gate, but if Firaxis is to be believed, this was due to not being entirely sure how to best add it. Just brace yourself and don't be surprised if it's in a paid expansion pack.The new mechanics work very well and give you a much stronger sense of control. City districts are surpisingly strategic, especially later in the game when you start buffing their output, specifically via adjacency bonuses. Even something as simple as builders building instantly but having limited charges makes the act of improving tiles feel more meaningful since you're actively seeking improvements with a finite resource.However this is also where one of the biggest issues of the game start to glare their ugly head. Transparency, or a lack there of, is a major concern. The new mechanics add a huge amount of depth and breath of life into the game, but the mechanics, both new and old, seem to have taken a major step back in terms of ease of visibility for important stats. Information like district output, housing/amenity income, great work locations, etc, are difficult to find, assuming it even exists, and is often burried and consolidated into generic numbers, making it unnecessarily difficult to keep track of and micro-manage them. It's almost as though the game treats these mechanics as less important than they really are. And tooltips are a lot less helpful than you'd expect them to be, either displaying generic information, seemingly useless information or relevant information, or just not displaying anything of value that you can't already see by just looking at it.The game also has a surprising number of glitches or AI quarks. I've seen cases where certain overlay features will get stuck on - such as traderoutes, cluttering your view. Trade deals seem very broken in that on more occasions than I can count, I've asked AI for a deal that they thought was better, only for them to actually ask for less or even offer me more. I've also been actively either dismissed or praised by other civilizations for not having a high gold income when my profit margins are very strong. I've even encountered an issue where a civilization will declare friendship with me - only to declare war on me two turns later.All and all, the game holds a remarkable amount of promise. I have little doubt that these issues will be ironed out in Civ6 just as they were in Civ5. That being said, it can't be emphisized strongly enough that this game released in what feels like a far, far more "complete" base game than Civilization V did when it was first released. If Firaxes trend is anything to go on, it's very easy to imagine that this game has the potential to be the absolute best Civilization game yet.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I played the tutorial and at first Cleopatra seemed to like me, then after 3 more minutes she denounced me for no reason.If I want that, I can go on a date.Seriously though, this seems to be a real problem that makes the game kind of pointless because there is no real feeling of diplomacy.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After around 30 hours logged into this game I can say that I am left utterly unimpressed. Civilization Six is not a bad game, rather a dissapointing one when compared to its predecessors. It does little that improves on civilization 5 in any major way, and in very many ways it makes backwards progress. The graphical style in this game gives of a cartoonish feeling that makes taking the game seriously difficult. The leaders are often animated worse than their civilization 5 counterparts as well. Despite this, the graphical style actually did not bother me all that much. What really did bother me in terms of graphics was the absolutely atrocious design of the minimap. The minimap in civ 5 provided a nice, clean overview of the geography of the map and the territories of the various nations. Its civ 6 counterpart is almost unreadable, I honestly struggled to read the minimap throughout my entire time with the game. While the minimap is not necessary in either game, it did lend towards a feeling of running an actual empire, as it accurately charted your territory. The lack of an accurate minimap may seem like a petty complaint, but I truly feel it continues to lend towards the cartoonish feel of the game. The game fails in areas aside fom graphics as well. The ai seems to have made little to no improvements over civ 5, the religion system feels rather shallow, and again cartoonish, in comparison to civ 5, and the world congress is removed entirely just to name a few. The game also tries to expand upon the civics system, which sounds like a great idea. However, the execution of the civics system was lackluster to say the least, and I often found myself not caring or even wanting to dig into the heaps of civic cards the game gives you. In all fairness, there were a few changes that i found to be actually good. In my opinion, the best change that they made was to the city system with the addition of districts. This added an interesting layer of depth to the cities and made effective planning of cities more necessary. Another minor improvement the game makes is to the millitary system with the ability to combine units to form corps and armies, which does make orginization slightly easier than the one unit per tile system of civ 5. Aside from the improvements I mentioned, the game fails to improve on civ 5 at all in my opinion. In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game simply due to how much better civ 5 is. Civ 6 may very well improve with dlc, however at the time of writing this the few pros are simply not worth the many cons. Go buy civ 5 and its dlc instead.

title: Recommended
comment: ===[ ❤ Audience: ]===☐ Kids (Kids may find this game boring)☐ Everyone☑ Casual players☐ Pro players===[ ☼ Graphics: ]===☐ Potato☐ Really bad☐ Bad☐ OK☐ Good☑ Beautiful☐ Masterpiece===[ $ Price/quality: ]===☐ Full price☑ Wait for sale☑ Average☐ Refund it if you can☐ Don't do it☐ Free===[ ☣ Requirments: ]===☐ 90' PC☐ Minimum☑ Medium☑ Fast☑ High end☐ NASA computer===[ ☼ Difficulty: ]===☐ Ez☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master☐ Medium☑ Hard (first few hours)☐ Makes you cry===[ ۞ Game time/length ]===☐ Really short ( 0 - 2 hours)☐ Short ( 2 - 8 hours)☐ Few hours ( 8 - 12 hours)☑ Long ( 12+ hours) (One single match can last for days or even a week)☐ Endless===[ ♬ Story] ===☑ It doesn't have☐ Still better than Twilight☐ Average☐ Good☐ Fantastic===[ § Bugs ]===☐ Game itself is one big BUG☐ Bugs destroying the game☐ Lot of bugs☐ Few Bugs☑ Nothing (Didn't found any bug yet)===[ ♪ Soundtrack] ===☐ Horrible☑ Flow with the game but needs better work☐ Good to hear / Follows the situation you are into☐ Sounds like angels whispering in your earsConsiderations: For some people, music in strategy games can be annoying and frustating, but for me, a good sountrack along with the game makes it even better. Your barracks, theatres and libraries now exist on individual hexes on the map itself, where they both gather bonus abilities with their placement (either by drawing on neighbouring districts or resources) and lie vulnerable to enemy sabotage and attack.===[ ♟ Visuals/Directions: ]===☑ Complete Mess☐ Flows like water☐ Has better directions than my lifeConsiderations: Well this is a major point in CIV 6. Besides the great changes the visual and directions are a complete mess by now. Like when you are moving into a whole new technological era, which are just kinda glossed over by the game, briefly flashing up a message before moving on. If you’d got up to get a cup of tea, you’d have missed it, then struggled to find the information somewhere else. The game needs to be polish===[ ♟ Diplomacy: ]===☑ Step Backwards☐ Great improvement☐ PerfectConsiderations: Leaders contact you less and have more simplistic reactions. Some leaders may warn you about your current condition (citizens unhappy, low income, not expanding your territory) and even go to war against you. The AI Learders seems to be a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ waiting for a minimum reason to denounce you (some of them denounce you just because they don't like you, like some minor child wtf).===[ ♆ Overall: ]===Civ has always been very conservative historically and CIV 6 changes this so it's a great thing to see fresh ideas in the game, they have much space for improvement and I hope they fix it soon.===[ ✦ Others: ]===Multiplayer: YESSingleplayer: YES

title: Recommended
comment: First, I would like to start by saying I personally enjoy the game very much. Yes, the game has its flaws but what game doesn’t. Another thing I remember very well when Civilization V came out, gamers were complaining about that game too. But now they are telling you, you’re better off playing Civilization V and yes Civ V also had flaws per some gamers and supposedly you were better off playing Civilization IV, so you see the pattern. We as gamers are never happy and always complaining about a game. Civ VI is getting better, the developer are still tweaking the game. They haven’t abandon it. So yes, it should have been fix before launch, but the game is out and let’s just hope the tweaks they are doing fixes the flaws the games has which aren’t as bad as some people making seem. In short, the game is enjoyable and playable and if you love or are new to the series than I recommend you purchase Civilization VI. Good luck gamers!

title: Not Recommended
comment: When you have announced this game, I hoped that with its release you will fix all problems that Civilization 5 had. However, you have created a completely naked game or, in other words, a piece of trash. And you sell this trash for 60 EUROS.Firaxis, I just cannot understand how you can be so greedy and have such a depraved vision on the future of your company. Instead of fixing Civilization 5, you made Civilization 6. Instead of creating a masterpiece Civilization 6, you made incomplete game and later on you released a DLC which, by the way, costs half the price of the game. Freaking 30 EUROS.I hope you will stop going for outlandish profits, because in the end, customer trust is the most important thing. Being greedy will just cost you your future.Getting back to the topic:- Poor in-game customization- Awkward game graphics, jesus christ, it's so impossible to see the hills.- The resource yields are just horrible. I have to play on Legendary start each time and even then, sometimes I get to spawn in terrible locations- In CIV5 when you upgraded certain things with your workers - you received extra hammers, in CIV6 you receive EXTRA GOLD. How is that possible?- The gold or faith just does not matter in this game anymore. You cannot buy anything valuable and troops just cost tonns of bucks.- Miserable fog of war- The problems from CIV5 still exist- Incredibly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI- Takes ages for AI to make their move after I tick ''Finish Move'' (and my specs are far beyond the recommended ones)- Lack of content which CIV5 had (Why the hell would you ever add golden ages in DLC instead of the original game??)- And I am pretty sure there is much more things.Overal Conclusion: I would not recommend this game because it is not worth of 60 EUROS. Buy during the sale for a great discount.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The cartoony graphics were a big disappointment. The game is great and I love the intricacies they have added in terms of tech/social trees. I wish they would have kept the moderate realism.It's okay. I would have preferred an overhaul of Civ V over the entirety of this, however. Only bought this game because it was 40% off. I'm sure I'll log some hours. However, the longevity I sense will be far less than it was with it's predecessor.The gameplay and all-around strategy are great. The graphics are far too like watching the intro to Shrek. That's a shame.5/10. Could take it or leave it.

title: Recommended
comment: If there was a reward for the "most re-invigorated series of 2016" this would take it.First time ive been excited about a Civ release and havnt been dissapointed since 3.

title: Not Recommended
comment: You thought the AI in Civ 5 was bad.. this is next level crap.

comment: The most buggy and crappy Civ ever made. Unplayable.

title: Recommended
comment: I bought this game at the release (Oct 2016), was really loved but was too buggy to play. Then I gave it up for sometime.Recently I bought new DLC's and Start playing again.Super fun really love this game so as the CIV franchise.AI also seems to be pretty impressive than before. The way they are attacking, sieging improved lot per my understanding.Even at the average difficulty level like KIng level, AI is pretty smart and that's what I call it smart rather than having them cheating bonuses in higher difficulty levels.Love the graphics too. I see lots of people complaining about fancy graphics, but I really loves it.10 / 10

title: Not Recommended
comment: Been a lover of Civilization since the MS-DOS era. The fact that additional civilizations (piecemeal i might add) are hidden behnd DLCs IRKS me to no end. We paid for a full game. What gives wth you guys trying to GOUGE money from those who actually support and play this game .Civilizaton is Civilization. Everything revolves around the game design mechanics. Every iteration should refresh it to some degree but this DLC needs to stop.Simply put, I can still stomach it if DLCs are a token amount or packaged in a worthwhile manner, but nah I will not buy into this DLC nonsense when it adds up to an actuial complete game.

title: Recommended
comment: I'm about 5 hours or so into my first game. I honestly don't understand where all the hate for this game is coming from. After seeing low user reviews I had low expectations. But so far this game has been very enjoyable.It may not be revolutionary, but it's the classic 4X turned based strategy game with sunny Firaxis twist to it.The game crashed on me twice throughout the 5 hours so that maybe something I'd consider as a negative, but auto save feature did its job so no harm done. (only allows up to 10 autosaves as opposed to unlimited number of auto saves they offered back in civ 5 in case you care)Great graphics, great music, I'm loving it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Heres an honest opinion of Civ 6. Being the natural progression from Civ 5 the natural assumption of this game is that it will encompass sections of Civ 5 that were good and then add new things to make the game better. Civ 6 in my opinion accomplishes the later, but throws everything that was loved about Civ 5 out the window.Pros:Districts: Districts are fairly well thought out, there are some problems in regard to the scaling of district production later in the game but I think for the most part it works extremely well and is a solid addition to the Civilization game. It also means you cant wonder spam which in my opinion was one of the main problems of Civ 5 as it allowed for people to snowball quite easily if you got set up correctly.Diplomacy: The diplomacy system in Civ 6 is really quite good if you ask me and was needed in the Civilization games, while it is not flawless (i.e. the intel crap that spams your screen or the AI diplomacy) the diplomacy is a good thing for the game.Civics Tree: The civics tree is a good addition and adds a lot of dynamics to the game if you ask me. It makes a culture a necessary in any game you play, while in Civ 5 culture was mainly just a defense against a tourist victory (could be used for policies but policies werent necessary to win a game).Cons:AI: The AI is obviously a big deal in a civilization game and the AI is pretty damn bad, if theyre not basically just suiciding against your nation theyre declaring wars that make 0 sense and are rarely using the war justification system built into the game. They just hit you with some stupid suprise war or they take someone who is a declared friend of yours, and declare a joint war (which isnt as punishing as a suprise war for some reason even though its basically the same damn thing). This game is a multiplayer game NOT A SINGLEPLAYER GAME.Religion: The religion game is much more detailed and I actually enjoy this quite a lot, however the religion game against AI is actually impossible. I have played games where I have done nothing but spam religion and there is no way I can come close to the amount of missionaries that the enemies are pumping out, despite having more faith per turn than them. Its utterly ridiculous.Civilization Choices: One thing that I actually gives me depression is the choices of Civilizations in this game. There are some solid choices that nobody can really disagree with, but there are also some awful choices and some nations that easily could've replaces them. The Khmer for example is effectively Cambodia, and yet there is no Ottomans in the game. We are given Australia and there is no Austria, in the Rise and Fall DLC we are given some random Chilean Tribe but we arent given the famous Incans. We are even given the Georgians, when we couldve been given Sweden, a nation who actually had an impact on the global state of affairs. I don't know what is with the decisions for countries, but they are seriously flawed, when important nations as the Ottomans are not in the game.Cost: This game costs way too much and is going to cost an insane amount of money. I bought the deluxe edition in pre-order. I knew this game was going to have a lot of DLC if Civ 5 is anything to base it off of. In Civ 5 you could buy the entire game, all DLCs for $80. This isnt cheap but its better than spending an even larger amount to get everything seperately. This is not the case in Civ 6. The Rise and Fall DLC is not included in the Deluxe which if you ask me is a huge sham. It also means that the deluxe edition no longer includes any more future nations that are to be added. I can not condone this game to my friends, that they have to spend over $100 just to buy a game that 1) Is already getting bad popularity 2) Needs to be fixed 3) Is showing that its going to require even more payments. Its not worth it to them, and frankly its not worth me spending more on it unless there is a serious sale.Overall:The game is alright, its building up to have a good amount of mechanics that I believe the game needed, and the mechanics being introduced in Rise and Fall further make me believe the game is headed in the right direction to be exceptional.BUT I can not recommend the game. The cost to get this game is the biggest draw back with you having already to spend over $100 to get a game that is not even close to finishing what it needs to be a good game or even what the developers plan to do with it. Get it on sale DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE FOR THIS GAME ITS NOT WORTH IT. And make sure you have friends who are willing to play it, once again this is not a singleplayer game as it is a multiplayer game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm a longtime Civ fan, and it breaks my heart to give this a "no" recommendation. Rather than rehash the negatives listed by the previous reviewers, I'll just suggest you read them. I've played quite a few games - and have only finished one. Why? Because towards the end of every other game, I reach a point where I realize that I'm not having fun anymore.Here's what I'd like to see fixed in a patch - and buying version 0.1 of one of their games seems to be the way Firaxis does things.1) Provide an option to automate workers. Yes, workers have "charges" but the AI still suggests tile improvements, so it doesn't seem like it would be much additional work to allow you to automate them. This change annoyed me because it was Firaxis telling us how to play the game - I'm a filthy casual, and I hate having to micromanage the damn workers.2) Provide an option to turn off Espionage, as Civ 5 did. Espionage continues to be based on discrete units which have to be built, moved around, and assigned a new/ordered to repeat a mission every several turns. Just a nuisance, especially now since spies can't just be assigned to cities, but must be assigned to specific DISTRICTS. So even if you just want to park a spy in each of your cities so you're not bothered overmuch by other nations, you've got to decide which tiles in what city are going to be protected. Why would anyone think change would be a good idea?3) The tech/social trees are terrible. It's much too easy to beeline to specific techs and skip techs that would logically be required - explain to me again how I can build infantry without learning Rifling or ever having used gunpowder?4) I was about to list #4 as "make the AI better" but if they've not been able to do it on the sixth iteration of the series, I'm assuming they are unwilling or unable to do it at this point.Deeply frustrating. So much potential, and yet another product where we wind up buying what should be a late-beta version of the game.

title: Recommended
comment: Overall a good but flawed game. AI can be a bit underwhelming and simple, but it's still difficult with the harder difficulty levels (AI gets pretty big buffs). It's not a perfect game, but it's enjoyable to play. The wonders have good bonuses and you get to watch them being built again (Civ IV). The tech tree is long and varied. The new features work well and the interface layout is much improved. The game has mod support finally, which adds a lot to the experience. I enjoy Civ 6 but do find myself getting bored more often than I did in previous titles. It's hard for me to put my finger on it but the game just isn't as fun as Civ 5 or Civ 4 were. Civ 6 is worth picking up on sale.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Why does the full game (as of 2/10/2018) cost $128

title: Not Recommended
comment: CIV 6's cross platform mutliplayer still does not function between PC and Mac players, despite being promised on launch. This game has been out for over a year now, why has this still not been fixed?!

title: Not Recommended
comment: There are many improvements from Civ V here in Civ VI. However, I feel as if nearly every improvement is nullified due to the unbalanced nature of the AI in Civ VI.I've spent hundreds of hours on Civ V, and after playing a bit of VI, I think it's time I moved back. VI simply isn't as good of a game and, arguably, not a good game in general.Its AI has infuriated me. They are very tempermental, even on the lower difficulties. They will offer bogus trades, such as 10 gold for two of your luxury resources. They will denounce you a single turn after meeting you, immediately again after the previous denunciation has expired, and for the entire length of the rest of the game, simply for following a different path of government. Diplomacy is nonexistant, and only is maintained by walking a fine line, which in turn makes the other AIs hate you. I understand that AI isn't human, but I feel as if it was better and more human-like in Civ V. It feels like the AI are playing you, instead of playing alongside you.If you have and enjoy Civ V, purchasing and playing this would most likely be a waste of time and money. If you are new to the series, only purchase Civ VI if you plan on strictly playing with humans. Otherwise, purchase Civ V. Regardless, until there's a suitable overhaul, this game cannot be recommended.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Nice!In this game you have:- bugs- glitches- terrible AI- medieval times 600 b.c.- city state archers and catapults in 2000- admirals on 1x2 lake- graphics from ipad game for six year olds, but don't worry you won't see anything on the map- districts are nice idea, but in game it looks like you are building few big cities next to each other. Doesn't feel like wide civilization.- full scale DLCs! GIVE ME MONI- I could go on and on with things like "your trader informes you that india and america are doing something together ". That's cool info bro. Well played. I am playing america though...I can't believe that anyone actually playtested this after playing civ 5 and said "yes, that's a good game".For full price it's PURE SCAM.Fog of war LOOKS nice.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ VI is really good. It playes the best over any other Civ game. There are many thnigs going on besides basic research, such as Civics research, Great Poeple recruiting points, building Districts, Espionage, Religion, Housing, less tile terrafroming but it is still important, Tourism. City States. Barbarians. ... and Deer.Just one thing: The AI is Very Cut Throat. NEVER give open borders or you will be Surprise Attacked and DOOMED. Also, your Capitol needs Walls as early as possible and a military Ecampment or you are DOOMED. ALL cities need a full time Garrison.I played all the Civ games except #4 and this is the best one yet.

title: Recommended
comment: Pros:A good starting point for people who are new to the 4X genre.Gorgeous graphics and effects.21:9 monitor support.Great soundtrack.Very detailed and well animated civ characters, that speak their native language.Runs very stable, the only time I've noticed any stuttering was when I changed policies late in the game, and only for about 5 seconds after I changed them.New districts/city building mechanics.New culture tree.Builders running on charges instead of taking turns per terrain upgrade.Despite it all I'm still enjoying my time with Civ VI. I recommend it, but barely. (Seriously, please fix the AI.)

title: Not Recommended
comment: My problem with Civ 6 is that it is too repetitive. It seems like nowadays whenever they add a new civ they are guarunteed a pretty trashy unique tile improvement or building that is extremely limited in use and doesn't really add anything special to the civ, and it seems like all of the unique abilities now are just 'extra (insert yield) for adjacency bonuses next to (insert land feature here)'. There is no variety in the game, and I am tired of looking at the same old boring Cleopatra and Frederick Barbarosa every game.CIvilization 5 was better in my opinion because each civ had an extremely different unique ability, from Morocco's extra gold for trade and Babylon's free Great Scientist. The games felt much more fun, as it took more strategy to beat and counter the several different civs in the game, because they were all extremely varied in playstyle and strengths. Another thing that I liked about Civ 5 compared to Civ 6 is that the games felt a lot more involved and interesting, and getting the victory in the end felt like much more of a challenge, as the AI or another player would always be right at your tail threatening to win another victory type, leading to some extremely fun and close games. Winning in Civ 6 however feels too much like a chore, as the victories themselves are extremely boring and tedious, and the AI is either never competitive or way ahead of you in everything, and the games feel like they are decided long before it actually ends. Getting a science victory or religious victory in this game is extremely boring and tedious, as the theological combat mechanic is bland and uninteresting and the micromanaging of buying the missionaries and spreading the religion is too boring. Civ 6 has some interesing ideas, but they are executed extremely poorly and they fail to capture any sort of interest from the players, i.e. the extreme inactivity in the Workshop compared to Civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Bought the digital deluxe, only got some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ add-ons, now expects me to pay 30 bucks for new full dlc, total money spent on game: 100 bucks. If I would get it of course.And all while the AI is still horrible, which for me just doesn't make the game that fun to play after you've seen the new stuff and fancy graphics. Do yourself a favour and spend your money elsewhere.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Because for some reason my pacifist civilization gets attacked by its own allies. Got attacked by two of my allies who I had +50 relationship score. Reloaded the game and it happened again. Kinda a tedious time sink only to be used if you have time to kill. I'll jump back on the bandwagon if Firaxis ever makes good AI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Hello everyone,Steam sadly got only YES or NO. I would give that game 60% which would qualify as a Yes, but I have to vote No this time.For a triple AAA title this game was launched AGAIN in a seemingly non tested BETA state (at best).I love Civ (got quite some hours on the previous titles Civ I-V). But for a game for that price It ain't done yet.Complete imbalanced and bugged. The AI is literally not existing and gets advantages simply by cheating. It is even worse than Civ V.Diplomacy is a complete mess. Well it doesn't really exist tbh.Do not try to get a religion on higher difficulties. Just ignore it. Religion doesn't really exist for the Player. It is an AI privilidge.AI got none whatsoever Diplomacy consequences.For example:If your troops are close to AI Boarders (even if it is inside your borders) AI will complain.AI will move troops next to your capital and you can't complain it is no reason to declare war.Troops will remin there for centuries. Nothing you can do bout it.AI will convert your cities, you tell them to stop that. They agree. They do it again (promise broken) nothing you can do about it. It doesn't qulify as "causal bell" for war. same goes for spies.They attack you. YOU ARE THE WARMONGER.If you want to play the game higher than prince prepare to feel the entire game as you were Hitler.Every AI will hate you the entire game. Even if you started out to do a peaceful game.I'm not talking here about the little annoying bugs which are plentyhere a few.-Land units will attempt to engage your naval units (they encircle your ships and you can kill their entire army witha few ships)- Completly overpowered races (Germans, Sumerian)-Missionaries overrun your cities and encircle them making it impossible to move around in your own country ( I counted up to 30 units on my city)I'm used to issues with Civ shortly after launch. But this time it is even worse. Same with Civ V it was really a god game with the first expansion.A playable Civ version cost like 90 bucks here Game + first expansion.I feel that is too much...If you are a civ fan and you can wait I suggest you do so and wait for a bundle price with the first expansion.I hope that review was helpful.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Still no fix for late game crashes during the end turn phase.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Paid BETA with tons of bugs and bad UI.

title: Recommended
comment: So this review was writen after my first hour of the game.TL;DR: the game has a great atmosphere to it but has some noticable holes in it that will hopefully be fixed with expansions, i'd say pay at most $40 CAD ($30 USD) for this game (hopefully around christmas this year)Things i liked:-Combat is better-Sound effects are awesome-Love the music-the map seeds are different and more unique than civ 5-The way districts and cities work-Sean Bean (funny quotes for techs)-map modes for continents, religion, nations and more. (people coming from EU4 will like this)-Fog of war is visible on the minimap; you can see what you have vision of on the minimap.-AI IS AWESOME (i was denounced in the first 15 turns from hyper aggressive egypt because my military was too small and i was called a cruel leader by Russia that is hardcore science and art)-continents is a neat little featureThings i didn't like:-the fog of war, takes too long to update for my units vision and is hard to read-Ancient ruins/Tribes are hard to see-the movement is difficult to get used to.-did the developers just miss this? there is no ability to turn off auto unit cycle which is super annoying to me (where the game automatically jumps between units for you)-very limited ammount of map seeds (continents, pangea, fractal, inner ocean, and archipellago)-only 19 civs for people who didnt preorder (which will be changed in the future for sure)-barely any change to the pantheons (which means whoever gets one first is pretty much gurenteed to get fertility rights)

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civilization VI(Also Know As: Why Should You Should Wait for DLC)Score: 6/10 (As of Vanilla)The improvements of this game are vast and the unstacking of cities will likely be viewed as at least as monumental of a change as the unstacking of units in V's system. The units (although need aesthtic development) are overall alright although the new movement feature that leaves you with 0.25 of a movement credit left that you can't use is somewhat irritating when playing on faster game modes. However for every step forward, Firaxis has seemingly learned nothing from even the fully developed civilization V game. The AI is without any better word to describe it is "f*cking atrocious and idiotic". The fact that you can use the diplomacy system to gain trust only to be declared war upon and denounced is unbelievable. At the start I anticipated the "era penalty reductions" to solve this but the slightest transgression will result in an all out war. Science victory's and the collective rest of the possible conditions are only fully possible if you can face off the brunt of the attack and eventually beat them into submission in order to ensure they dont raid your land again. This has happened every game I have played up to emperor (and I imagine the trend will continue and only make the game more difficult to play, and not in a good way). This game is well rounded in style and intial ideas but it needs major work in order to become a fully fledged game worth of the Civilization heritage it claims.In conclusion, wait for the DLC, wait for AI improvements, if they never come (to my potential chagrin) then save your money and time and stick with V unitil VI goes on sale.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeIncrediably slow turns(even by Civilization standard), and a cartoony UI right out of a mobile pay to win clickfest with arbitary gameplay staples from civilization franchise removed "For Reasons".This is an incrediably disappointing entry in the civilization franchise.At least I didn't spend money on this game directly, after getting it as a promotion when I bought a new graphics card.

title: Recommended
comment: Impressive game, there are already many features in the vanilla game ( religions, commercial routes, 18 different empires, etc ), the game runs very smooth and so far i've found 0 bugs. The district system and politic system are very interesting, also the AI and diplocacy seems a lot better than Civ V. To be honest i also like the cartoonish sytle of the game, add a layer of visual fun. One of the best Civ game if not the best oneUpdate after the first big patch : The game has improved a lot after the first update. The Ai seems better but there's still room for more adjustments. Let's see what happe nafter the first DLC

title: Not Recommended
comment: In Civilization VI's current state I cannot recommend this game. It's understandable that major patch deployments will result in bugs here and there but this has become such a problem with Civilization VI that I've thrown my hands up. So many broken systems resulted from the Summer Patch that it's difficult to properly enjoy a base level game of Civ 6.Honestly I could deal with it all if Fireaxis/2K would just communicate with customers. Yet here we are almost a month out and there hasn't been a single word concerning a patch. It has been so silent that we honestly have no idea if the fixes are going to happen soon or if they will be withheld until the 'Fall Update" 2-3 months from now.I'd love to update this review in the future if they can turn this game around. As it stands do not invest your money or time into Civ VI. Do yourself a favor and pickup the complete Civ V pack (often seen for $12) and enjoy.

title: Not Recommended

It seems like nowadays whenever they add a new civ they are guarunteed a pretty trashy unique tile improvement or building that is extremely limited in use and doesn't really add anything special to the civ, and it seems like all of the unique abilities now are just 'extra (insert yield) for adjacency bonuses next to (insert land feature here)'. There is no variety in the game, and I am tired of looking at the same old boring Cleopatra and Frederick Barbarosa every game.CIvilization 5 was better in my opinion because each civ had an extremely different unique ability, from Morocco's extra gold for trade and Babylon's free Great Scientist. title: Not Recommended
comment: I am not too sure how i feel about Civ VI. I've played many of the games in the civilization series, and have 1500+ hours on civilization v on this account alone.Every time I played Civilization V I would literally play an entire game and spend HOURS in one sitting. The graphics seemed great for the time of release, and even before the release of DLC there was alot of replayability.When Civilization VI came out, I was so excited. I heard that the gameplay was totally different.This is the only game in the Civilization series in which I have never finished an entire game. I know i've only played about 7 hours on this account, but for me, 7 hours was about the time I would spend per game in Civ V!There's so much wrong with this game.Case in point, Diplomacy.A nation will be your best friend on one turn and then declare war on you the next turn. At first I thought this was clever espionage, but nope. Its nearly impossible to win over nations with trade deals. Diplomacy is an utter sh*tstorm. Declarations of friendship are almost meaningless. I can't count how many times my declared friends sneaked attacked me... Diplomacy is truly broken. I didn't buy this game at release just because of this issue when i saw all the thumbs down. However, I figured they would have patched this by now.Adding housing was a mistake.Dear god is this irritating. It's nearly impossible to satisfy your people. You think you've got a handle on things and 20 turns later your city is screaming at you for more housing. You can't add more districts because there is a population threshold and you can't reach that population threshold because you cannot add more districts. It's a never-ending cycle and it gets annoying early on. This was never a problem in Civilization V.There are a few positive aspects of the game that I like.They made the game more realistic and balanced by no longer allowing people to hoarde wonders in a single city. It used to be that whoever had the most production would get all of the good wonder, but i'm glad to see that this has changed. Also, despite what other people say, I actually like the new cartoony graphics.But overall, this game was just a complete let down for me. I couldn't say that I would recommend this game, but I would definitly recommend it's predecessor, Civilization V. Perhaps this game will be improved with future DLC, but I just don't find it enjoyable in it's current state.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is a step down from CIV 5,1. Music: its the same set of songs and at one point you would rather play in silence rather than hear the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ peruvian flute music song for the 1,000th time. Also all the music is happy and while I don't expect mozart's Requiem being every song I would like some serious music to be on the track.2. Lack of diversity in leaders: almost every leader is medieval-ancient era, and while I have nothing against this era I would really like to see more leaders from the machine age or even the modern era.3. Too cartoony: this is a little more subjective but I feel as though CIV 6 is a whole lot less emersive than CIV 54. 60$: yeah I know its customary for a new game but CIV 6 doesn't add anything ground breaking so there really is no need for a 60 dollar price tag5. Districts: The whole district thing is a cool thought but I feel as though it is very rough around the edges6. AI: It is♥♥♥♥♥♥ I've had ancient era units attack me during the machine age7. AI diplomacy: This has to do with AI but it is so awful I felt it deserved a section all for itself. No matter how hard you try most people will hate you (just like in real life).Overall this game is about a 5/10 for me and really isn't worth 60$, I recommend just getting CIV 5 with all the expansions.Also don't fall prey to all the positive reviews, a lot of people were in denial of how bad this game is at first, I know I was. But after hours grinding to make that perfect modern age empire and declaring war on the next strongest empire hoping for an epic battle only to be attacked with archers really lifted the veil of denial.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I thoroughly enjoyed Civ V and was considerably excited for Civ VI at its release. I am a Mac player, and waited patiently for my version to come out a month later. I then played single player games and was happy, but wanted to join my other friends in multiplayer games, all PC players.Civ V became a greater game for me because I could play hours upon hours with my friends, but whenever I wanted to play Civ VI with my friends, I couldn't because of our updates not being at the same time. They would get the Australian Civ Pack and I had to wait a month to receive it, but by the time I did they had a new update making our games incompatible to play.I recently tried to have another multiplayer game since all updates were the same for both Mac and PC, and saw that they no longer can support trying to have cross-platform multiplayer play. I hope in the future they can fix the bugs that will allow multiplayer support for cross-platform, as it is what I bought Civ VI for and am utterly disappointed that it has taken 6 months for this to be addressed publicly. It should not be advertised as cross-platform if IT IS NOT.If you want to play on your own, Civ VI gives the next great challenge for the Civ play, but for Mac and PC friends to play together, it is not available and keeps me from playing the game further.

comment: Crippling bad and irrational AI that is best summed up by an anecdote:Me, Ghandi and Cleopetra are neighbors.Ghandi asks me for a Joint war against Cleopetra, and I think why not?The turn after declaring a JOINT WAR Ghandi denounces me for being a warmonger.A few turns after that he declares war on me aswell.Wait for Firaxis to release a large expansion/fixthat isn't another overcharged Civilisation shackled to Scenario packs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been a fan of the Civ franchise from the start. I think I've given this, in its current state, enough of a shot to make a fair assessment. It's the worst offering yet, by far. There is virtually nothing enjoyable about the game. The religion component just feels like a chore, like swatting at mosquitos. Another chore...workers (builders) are no longer able to be automated.I guess the districts are a little interesting, but they don't really add much to actual gameplay.The graphics are pretty. I like the cartoonish aspect, the map and fog of war effect are great.It's been pretty well pointed out how terrible the AI is...and it's what in the end makes the game unplayable. I'm holding out some hope for an extensive overhaul, but I think the game is flawed to it's core.I wish they would go back to CIV IV and start from there. Just a refresh of the graphics of that would have been light years ahead of this huge dissappointment.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Sadly it's simply not there yet.The game has a lot of potential and good ideas which are currently held back by not so good ideas and an absolutely atrocious AI. As a result the game currently thrives on abusing mechanics or the AI making anything singleplayer related a cake walk hardest difficulty included.As a civ5 veteran I'm really disapointed we got a worse AI and that some of the lessons of Civ5 were not learned for this new game.Modding is still not available at the moment I write this and the multiplayer support is barebone.I currently cannot recommend it as I'm more interested to go play Civ5 Civ4 or another series altogether. My review will change if the first expansion fixes its major problems.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Ive tried to find something good in this game and i always go back to civ5 because i feel like this game offers seriously bland gameplay and especially politics, it doesnt matter what you do the computer controlled civs will always give you the same discussions that appear at set ammount of turns after youve met them, theres nothing here that offers variety its just the same♥♥♥♥♥♥set in stone every single time.District system is purely the only good thing about this game its quite nice but overall i felt like city building felt clunky you spend the same ammount of time making districts as wonders and generally i felt like half t he game was about making workers and nothing else.Edit: also war and warmonger is literally the only way computer will play the game also adding to the absolutelly bland gameplay.When you make a quickgame it doesnt even remember last used settings like in previous civ so you spend time redoing all the settings to your liking over and over. Quality of life in the user interface does not excist.Cant seem to find unit exp bar, they just randomly get rankups.Graphics are worse than before a weird mix of realism and comic appearance and it doesnt work.UI needed more work.Powerful barbarians and unimpressive computer warfare.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Not many changes compared to Civ V, I'd recommend that game instead - especially because of the DLC policy for Civ VI.It may be worthwhile if you have played Civ V so much that you welcome every little change, but if you are new to the series save yourself the headaches and get the Game of the Year Edition of Civ V instead.

title: Recommended
comment: Personally, I like the new art style, the fifth game tried looking realistic but just looked sort of unrealistically cartoony. This game embraces the cartoony style and makes everything surprisingly more detailed.The soundtrack is phenomenal, I instantly fell in love with some of the civs audio tracks throughout the ages!The game plays a bit different and feels a bit different but is still a Civ game, I would recommend this to anybody.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As a community, we can sometimes expect too much of a developer to always get everything completely right.With the Civilization series - we are able to uniquely analyze and critique the merits and downfalls of the newest release, because we aren't dealing with a story-driven, plot-centred, or character based sequel.Each new iteration of Cilization is almost exactly the same - essentially. Hopefully though, the improvement on what the players find most enoyable is devliered well, shows thoughtful change in it's design, and allows room for future improvement.Unfortunately, after 140+ hours - I can say this is the most disappointing release ever. I won't go over my history with the series,But no matter how much people can try to defend it - everyone needs to understand that this game is incomplete, unbalanced, and far from being considered 'ready for release'.I will change my review to positive when the developers finally deliver in their promise to include everything in Civilization 6, as standard, that was in Civlization 5 and it's expansions (except WC). When they fix the AI to not declare war before meeting you, have all negative relationships, and to not interrupt you every turn. When it doesn't have crippling bugs, poor balance, reinstates features like 'Restart', Military overview, saved options, or the others that were in beta/Civilization 5 but were cut.Whilst I understand it's a game in it's own right - Civilization 6 is a sequel to the proud history it follows. In my opinion, upon release, it is the most disappointing to date, and will continue to fail the longer the developers refuse to communicate with the fans. We judge Civilization 6, and hold it to a higher standard than most, not from high expectation or greed, but because we expect it. I do not mean that we expect too much from the developers - I mean we have come to expect better from them than what we received for such a high price. Maybe that is unfair, but with all it's problems - I can fairly say that I am disappointed in the standard of what they deemed acceptable to release.I enjoy playing the game, but it was absolutely was not ready for release. It isn't worth £50 in it's current state, nor considering the mountain of DLC they will push to improve it. I know the community can cause massive problems for developers when they delay the release of a game - but they should of had the courage to make the right choice, rather than hoping it would work out.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I kind of like this game! But I also ♥♥♥♥ing hate it with a passion.
