title: Not Recommended
comment: This games servers are ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥ i swear to God it takes more time to get everyone to get in a lobby then it is to play a game. hosting a game with a few people is fine but 5+ players attempting to connect to a lobby is impossible. the server issues from civ 5 have not been fixed and it may be worse. i cannot play with my friends becasue we all can't connect to the same lobby. Also joining a saved game doesn't work either. please for the love of God fix these ♥♥♥♥♥♥ servers

title: Recommended
comment: So much potential, but so much missing or frustrating. Having played Civ since Civ 1 in '93 and only missed out on CivV I came back to Civ with CivVI. Good points, multihex city development, a tech and a civics tree, combining units into corps/armies, Causus Belli - Just War, cool archaeologists. Bad points - no railways (transfromed the world), no canals, limited religions, religions don't make the people happy (that is their primary purpose - to provide hope), Why should Saladin get the Last Prophet? What about the LDS? AI Civs are too quick to label you "warmonger" if you beat anyone who attacks you. Not enough great people. Slingers have a range of 1 - the whole point of slingers, historically, is that they could launch out to 300m and more. Ancient armies are not about individual unit types but about the mix/balance and training - so much could have been done here, huge opportunity missed to represent ancient warfare properly. A good game but not a great game, CivIV with all add-ons and History in the Making Mod is a great game. Still worth buying though!With now 400+ hours I still heartily recommend this game - and the add-ons, especially Indonesia etc. I have managed to win at Immortal level but not without resorting to nukes. I have also managed all victories except "score" which, IMO, could only happen by artificially not winning another way. So, what could be better?Historically, empires and religions both divide/rebel/schism - this has to be part of any future complete game - Civ VII. I like the religious combat although it took me 5 games to properly understand how it works. I do think that religion as "opiate of the masses" is a very strong historical fact which has been wrongly side-lined in Civ6.The end screens are most disappointing - just graphs. I used to love the turn by turn historical map plot of Civ development in Civ4 - this should be available in this game for both cities and religion. It is always good to rememeber where you started.There is no distinction between Barbarians and Rebels and there is no guerilla warfare or terrorism for that matter. All things that could and should be added.The AI is also not very good at combat, regardless of level and seems unable to work out what is usually a very simple chess calculation except that it almost nevr does tactical retreats.My final gripe, for now, is that the zoom out on the normal map is not far enough and needs to zoom out to world view.BUT - I can live with all that! As a game it has a great engaging and immersive feel. 100% buy recommend/

title: Recommended
comment: After 12 hours of gameplay, I came to a conclusion that Civilisation-6 was an experiment, developers did NOT redesign the whole game (i.e. combat is mostly the same) and left a few other previously known features mostly unchanged, but they made more focus on the small things, which may only be appreciated by limited audience (including me).Highs (SUBJECTIVE):- Visuals and UI feels more intuitive than in previous games.- War justifications result in different warmonger score: Relegious wars, Formal wars, etc.- Leaders forgive your aggression as the time progresses.- District concept is simple to grasp.- Exploration feels more interesting than in previous games,- I like the new fog of war mechanics.- When you re-prioritise your city's foucs (food, production, science...), the improved titles change their appearance (i.e. fields become greener / browner).- Continent names!- Multuple map modes (religious overview, governmental forms, etc. similar to EU4).- Each civilisation has a music theme that evolves in complexity every two eras.Lows (SUBJECTIVE):- AI: "I do not care that you have the largest tank fleet in the world, my cavemen with clubs will beat the hell of your tank's paint... and while I do that, let me build a new city on the border with you".- Starting positions seem to be poorly thought through - you start way to close to other civilisations.- Religious victory is too over-powered - should be not 51% but rather 91% of another's civilisation's cities following the religions.- Scientific boosts are over-powered (50% for most of things that you would do naturally). I end up entering Industrial era in 10th century. Should either have slighly reduced boost (i.e. 10-25%) or have higher triggering conditions.- Half of the cultural cards are rubbish.- Most of the great people do not bring great benefits.- The new happiness mechanic is not clear (may well be part of my learning curve).- Micro-management is way too admin-driven (I would like to be able to auto-renew trades based on simple conditions, such as keep this route internal with the larges production output, followed by largest income, followed by largest food, etc.).- District repariments are tedious ("Okay, bunch of rebels decided to burn a few tiles and now it will take me 20 turns to get the city of where it was and I cannot use builders to boost / auto-complete repairs).

title: Not Recommended
comment: woweee this is interestingly bad. Just play Civ 5, literally no reason to play VI over it.Pros- Finally can have my offensive units Escort my civilian units.- Districts are definitely a nice twist, although, I feel as if each district needed to be buffed/expanded, so you could have an industrial/harbor/commercial powerhouse, given the proper land.Neutral/Notes-The art style has taken a cartoon like style. I'm not a huge fan of it, but I don't necessarily hate it.-Wonders aren't exactly as often used from what I've seen, played deity and I think Hermitage(?) was still up for grabs until renaissance era.- Probably just me, but I find the whole religion combat and religion strategy confusing as a whole.- For a game with Clash of Clans like graphics, thing makes my computer run a little hot- The AI... Just, why? After so many complaints from Civ 5 over the AI, little has changed. Tsk tsk.- Want to win? F*** your science, culture and diploma- oh wait there is no diplomacy victory, domination is the only real practical way to win and is the go-to ez pz route.- Nearly all the (good) civs are military boosted for their bonus, again, say goodbye to science/culture/diplomatic victories.- City states are pretty much forgotten about, you do a quest here and there, send them some envoys and thats all you can do with them really.Stop freaking releasing half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥games then unloading a plethora of scenarios (NO ONE FREAKING ASKED FOR) and unbalanced civs for a ridiculous price. Hats off to you 2k and Firaxis, you're finally growing into a normal AAA company and becoming greedy pigs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I would love this game however there are just a few things that make this almost unplayable.first is how long it takes to move units late game. In between selecting units the game will go HEY SEE THIS MISSIONARY OVER HERE THAT YOU FORGOT ABOUT? STARE AT IT AND GIVE IT AN ORDER FORGET ABOUT THE UNIT YOU WANTED TO SELECT!!!! which makes 1 turn on a large map take maybe 15 mins, inbetween the game correcting which unit you want to select, and also the having to reassign every spy every 4 turns when you just want it to counterspy for all eternity turns this game into a clickfest and makes the game more of a chore than an actual game. also the fact that missionaries block military units path is incredibly frustrating because 1 civ most of the time ghandi will spam missionaries in your territory or on the middle of the battlefield and wreck any of your plans on having a fun game plus the lack of mod support on a game that should be a mod heaven really speaks as to how little the devs care.The other issue with this game is the difficulty. When I first started I played on prince and found my self attacked by 3 of my allies on the same turn. Me being stupid, thinking the devs built a half brained ai, had no military and died. The next game I played on settler and the same thing happened this would maybe be ok on diety but SETTLER???? I just wanted to have a fun game and not wonder how I was so naive that maybe for once a game with a working ai was realeased.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Needs work. Pretty dry AI. Diplomacy sucks. Stay tuned for another Brave New World-like expansion where they make the game good. Give it a year or two. I'm a fool to have thought this game would be awesome within the first year. Unless you only dom victory, this CIV looks awesome and feels great but plays like♥♥♥♥♥ Dictators heaven, diplomats worst nightmare. Doesn't matter what you do on any difficulty, AI hate you + they are dumb as hell.This game has potential. Keep an eye on it but DO NOT pay full price for it in this state. It has a lot of work to be done.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Horrible AI, just horrible, I can't believe they can't get proper AI programmers and testers with the resources Firaxis has, smaller companies do a much better job on other strategy games.Terrible pacing and gameplay is back to CIV3 infinite city sprawl strategies.The rest of the game is only OK, it looks good and the move to districts and wonder placement on the map is a welcome bold move.As expected, they took features present in the previous games to sell later as DLC, like the UN or world congress. Other features are refined and improved on like city-states and great people.Still playable and OK to pass the time, but I wouldn't recommend anyone to buy it yet, wait for expansions and big sales.I'd give it a 6/10.Oh also they sold the digital deluxe edition promising buyers to get the first DLCs and then only released civs and scenarios, you know stuff that any modder can do on their spare time, disgusting and borderline fraudulent move.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Love this game a lot.However it constantly crashes on me in multiplayer. No clue why it just shuts down. on my laptop it would freeze the screen. The gpu was only a 770 but only startup crashed it. Now on my new desktop with a 1070 gtx the game crashes at start up and randomly crashes in multiplayer like aforementioned. The ai is terrible I can declare war when the game says no warmonger penalty the get denounced for it, and then everyone hates me together even declaring war on me in groups without me attacking or instigating. The ai also tries to make deals then bargain for more on their side, but if i place a unit next to their capital they give me all their money and even undergarments? I just want the game to be fixed rather than submit a crash report on initial boot up because the game started twice on it's own. You know instead of another 9 dollar dlc.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game is decent so far but 6 months from release and still incomplete. The World-builder which is part of the SDK is still "hidden" and incomplete. The SDK was released only a short time ago but is incomplete. 6 months. Don't waste your money. Wait until the game is completed.UPDATE: STILL A WASTE OF MONEY ON A BROKEN GAME. READ BELOWThis game is almost a year old and instead of fix some of the worst bugs (in the AI) and fix the one tool that many people have requested (The World Builder) they just managed to break the game even more. I didn't think it was possible.Lesson learned. I will not be buying Civ 7 until at least a year after its release.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I didn't like it. I've played I think every Civ game, but not as a die hard. I especially didn't like the city building, I didn't quite get it or like the bit that I got about the sprawling cities.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just not as polished as Civ V, not an upgrade as such.I still prefer CIv V, perhaps with future DLC and updates this version may hold my interest

title: Recommended
comment: This game is a very good edition to the Civilization series.I enjoy the AI and how they are much smarter (even the barbarians). However, they are really annoying. Within the first 10 turns the Aztecs declared war on me as I had another luxury that he did not. As this happened, the other civs that he befriended within those 10 turns also instantly declared war on me. As this happened the next 2 turns were equally as worse. I had met 3 other civs (playing on Continents) of whom instantly denounced me. They are really hard to befriend. Even after 300 turns of one game.I do miss the feature that you can't rename cities or religions (or I just can't read). But you can rename units and put them into "Corps" or "Armies" which is very useful (basically a hybrid army that consists of 2 or 3 of the same unit).This game is amazing. I would recommend buying it, only if you are willing to do some research, learn the game and play much more aggresively than you normally would in any other Civ game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I tried really hard to like this game, the graphics and sondtrack are so good I wanted so bad to enjoy it, but I didn't. It made me mad, really mad, repeatedly.If you found the religion aspect of Civ 5 to be a little obnoxious or inconvenient, well the made it 100x worse in Civ 6. Prepare yourself for a never ending flood (and I mean FLOOD) of Apostles and Missionaries converting your cities regardless of whether or not you have Inquisitors stationed there (oh yeah, it's a blast), also, they can attack and kill your religious units that aren't stationed in city. It's a real hoot.As for city building, you'll be constantly fighting to build enough amenities and housing capacity to accomodate your growing population. You will forever be just slightly ahead of the growth, and if you fall behind get ready for zero growth and unhappy citizens that could revolt at any moment. Again, a real hoot.Districts: barely worth the time investment until about the industrial age, at which point they finally get the upgrades you've been waiting centuries for.Wonders: The best thing about them is their cinematic construction. Other than that, only a couple are worth more than the tile you must give up in order to build it. Sid must have been unhappy with the wonder hoarding possible in Civ 5 and made d*mn sure it didn't happen again.TL;DR: Unneccessary micromanaging and infuriating religious unit spamming kept me in a constant state of very freaking♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I finally reached the modern era as Victoria, my redcoats marched along with tanks against enemies still fielding catapults. If you can get a few friends to play, I say go for it. However, playing against the AI is incredibly dull and schizophrenic. I can honestly say I did not enjoy the time I played.The new diplomacy features do very little in a practical sense, of all the games I’ve played they hate me within a few turns no matter what I do. And the few AI I befriend will launch a surprise war with no obvious provocation. So, I just fight everyone forever because there doesn’t seem to be any other way.I expect there will be some massive patches or DLC that will tune the AI, so hopefully we won’t have long to wait.-Post Patch-The AI still acts surprisingly dull. My most recent game, within 10-15 turns of meeting a civ, they denounced and promptly declared war upon me. They then proceeded to do nothing for the rest of the game. I gave up when I found that all the AI seemed confused with the idea of a naval invasion, their entire army sat off their coast while my ships tore through them.As the player population has dropped 2/3 to practically the level of Civ5, I think in general the community has given up for the near future. Maybe after a few years of play testing they can sort out their AI logic. Until then, don't bother. I regret this purchase almost as much as No Mans Sky.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really wanted to like Civ 6, but I just can't. Most of the new features sound like a good idea, and in part they are, but most all have a big negative to them. I could type out all the problems for hours, but I will just give a few to save time.New city district system sounds good, but you are still stuck building only one thing a turn despite having all these seperate building complexes. Then builders are only good 3 times, so you have to spend extra build time on them. And if something gets damaged you have to repair it via the build system. That sometimes takes 9+ turns! It can also take several turns for your troops to simply go from one side of your city to the other.Roads are built automatically by traders. Sounds good, but that means you have to send traders to every city even if you don't want to. So you have to send one from City A to City B, City B to City C, City C to City A, and so on. You can get an engineer to build roads,... ONE TILE AT A TIME!AI leaders seem to be bipolar. They shame you over the size of your military, and then the very next turn say how impressive it is. They will delare war on you, and then just sit there and never send any troops. Also enemy units sometimes get stuck and never move from a tile.You now gain influence over city states by sending them envoys, but it's a constant see-saw battle with the AI. You send 5 envoys. They send 6. Then you send 7, so they send 8. In one game I kept losing my caravans because my max number would constantly be changing from 5 to 10 because my influence would rise and fall constantly.Religon? Nope. Not even going to go there. The changes sound good on paper, but it sucks. I turned off religion victory and just avoid all of it.Notification! Notifications have been reduced to a tiny hidden button on the lower right. I had barbarians running thru my capital and never knew. Is someone close to victory? Well you better constantly be checking the victory tab or you'll never know. I lost a game and I still don't know why! The end screen doesn't even show who or how they won!Meh, I don't want to go on any longer. I can see a good game here, but so much needs to be fixed. I'm sure modders are already working on a lot of these problems. I'd wait a few month before purchasing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Do one thing before purchasing this game. Google "Civ 6 crash to desktop" and see the numerous people plagued with this above common problem.The Good: It follows the traditional Civilization Genre of planning and strategy. There are aspects that do become tedious during gameplay. Ex. No automated production forces you to constantly choose the same item in later turns of the game.Overall: It is enjoyable If your able to play without problem.WHY I would NOT recommend this game. Games are supposed to be fun and relaxing. Only it isnt when you're 30 or 200 turns into a game and crash. You cant even reload and continue because at that point it keeps doing it on that particular moment. The issue of crashing to desktop for no rhyme or reason is very frustrating. Tenaciously, I have tried a multitude of things to fix the issue. Declared war, made trades, loaded saved games to earlier turn, changed civics etc. Checked game integrity, windows updates, turned off firewall, Reloaded drivers, Uninstalled/Re-installled game and many other things that would normally cause hiccup errors.Bottom line: There is a design flaw somewhere. I imagine it would take the development team to peel through the whole game to fix it. Something thats gonna cost the company time and money. Most likely why it hasnt been fixed yet for so many people.If you do buy the game. I wish you good luck. You have been warned... lol

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI needs to be improved a lot.

title: Recommended
comment: Impressive game, there are already many features in the vanilla game ( religions, commercial routes, 18 different empires, etc ), the game runs very smooth and so far i've found 0 bugs. The district system and politic system are very interesting, also the AI and diplocacy seems a lot better than Civ V. To be honest i also like the cartoonish sytle of the game, add a layer of visual fun. One of the best Civ game if not the best oneUpdate after the first big patch : The game has improved a lot after the first update. The Ai seems better but there's still room for more adjustments. Let's see what happe nafter the first DLC

title: Not Recommended
comment: I thoroughly enjoyed Civ V and was considerably excited for Civ VI at its release. I am a Mac player, and waited patiently for my version to come out a month later. I then played single player games and was happy, but wanted to join my other friends in multiplayer games, all PC players.Civ V became a greater game for me because I could play hours upon hours with my friends, but whenever I wanted to play Civ VI with my friends, I couldn't because of our updates not being at the same time. They would get the Australian Civ Pack and I had to wait a month to receive it, but by the time I did they had a new update making our games incompatible to play.I recently tried to have another multiplayer game since all updates were the same for both Mac and PC, and saw that they no longer can support trying to have cross-platform multiplayer play. I hope in the future they can fix the bugs that will allow multiplayer support for cross-platform, as it is what I bought Civ VI for and am utterly disappointed that it has taken 6 months for this to be addressed publicly. It should not be advertised as cross-platform if IT IS NOT.If you want to play on your own, Civ VI gives the next great challenge for the Civ play, but for Mac and PC friends to play together, it is not available and keeps me from playing the game further.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been a fan of the Civ franchise from the start. I think I've given this, in its current state, enough of a shot to make a fair assessment. It's the worst offering yet, by far. There is virtually nothing enjoyable about the game. The religion component just feels like a chore, like swatting at mosquitos. Another chore...workers (builders) are no longer able to be automated.I guess the districts are a little interesting, but they don't really add much to actual gameplay.The graphics are pretty. I like the cartoonish aspect, the map and fog of war effect are great.It's been pretty well pointed out how terrible the AI is...and it's what in the end makes the game unplayable. I'm holding out some hope for an extensive overhaul, but I think the game is flawed to it's core.I wish they would go back to CIV IV and start from there. Just a refresh of the graphics of that would have been light years ahead of this huge dissappointment.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After being out for 3 months, I picked the game up hoping the negative reviews would have been fixed with patching. This is not the case. The AI in this version of CIV is so buggy it makes the game unplayable in any way besides all out war. The game also freezes every time I try to close it to the point of needing to end the process in task manager. The UI is unintuitive and has various other bugs scattered throughout. Overall, this game is not polished or even completed to my expectations of Civ a game. I am requesting a refund and will return to Civ 4, which at least works.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Crippling bad and irrational AI that is best summed up by an anecdote:Me, Ghandi and Cleopetra are neighbors.Ghandi asks me for a Joint war against Cleopetra, and I think why not?The turn after declaring a JOINT WAR Ghandi denounces me for being a warmonger.A few turns after that he declares war on me aswell.Wait for Firaxis to release a large expansion/fixthat isn't another overcharged Civilisation shackled to Scenario packs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have played every single Civ game, and never before has a Game left me this unsatisfied and just plain dissapointed. I hope that it will get better, but considering their money loundering sceme with their Dlcs, I dont really believe it.If you do get it, I suggest buying it when its on sale, otherwise, its just not worth the full Price.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Not many changes compared to Civ V, I'd recommend that game instead - especially because of the DLC policy for Civ VI.It may be worthwhile if you have played Civ V so much that you welcome every little change, but if you are new to the series save yourself the headaches and get the Game of the Year Edition of Civ V instead.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is a very good edition to the Civilization series.I enjoy the AI and how they are much smarter (even the barbarians). However, they are really annoying. Within the first 10 turns the Aztecs declared war on me as I had another luxury that he did not. As this happened, the other civs that he befriended within those 10 turns also instantly declared war on me. As this happened the next 2 turns were equally as worse. I had met 3 other civs (playing on Continents) of whom instantly denounced me. They are really hard to befriend. Even after 300 turns of one game.I do miss the feature that you can't rename cities or religions (or I just can't read). But you can rename units and put them into "Corps" or "Armies" which is very useful (basically a hybrid army that consists of 2 or 3 of the same unit).This game is amazing. I would recommend buying it, only if you are willing to do some research, learn the game and play much more aggresively than you normally would in any other Civ game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Horrible AI, just horrible, I can't believe they can't get proper AI programmers and testers with the resources Firaxis has, smaller companies do a much better job on other strategy games.Terrible pacing and gameplay is back to CIV3 infinite city sprawl strategies.The rest of the game is only OK, it looks good and the move to districts and wonder placement on the map is a welcome bold move.As expected, they took features present in the previous games to sell later as DLC, like the UN or world congress. Other features are refined and improved on like city-states and great people.Still playable and OK to pass the time, but I wouldn't recommend anyone to buy it yet, wait for expansions and big sales.I'd give it a 6/10.Oh also they sold the digital deluxe edition promising buyers to get the first DLCs and then only released civs and scenarios, you know stuff that any modder can do on their spare time, disgusting and borderline fraudulent move.

title: Not Recommended
comment: TLDR: If you've never played Civ before, get it. If you're a veteran of the series, pass.I don't know what it is exactly about Civ6, maybe a confluence of lots of things, but for whatever reason this game is the least fun I've ever had playing a Civilization title, and I've been playing these games since Civ 2 came out. I've played every single one. Civilization 6 represents the least interesting of any of them, and I think that's because there's nothing new here that wasn't already explored - oftentimes with better mechanics - in previous games. Even the graphics are only stylistically different, and not necessarily better than Civ5.I hate to say this, but my beloved Civilization game series has gotten stale and moldy. It needs a total kick in the rear by a talented, visionary designer who can bring something fresh and novel.

title: Recommended
comment: It sure is a video game, alright-Some Guy 2016

title: Not Recommended
comment: Nice ideas, bad implementation, terrible AI, abysmal, unresponsive GUI.Subjective opinion: The visual style is a downgrade. Shove higher resolution and polygon count where the sun don't shine - a 9 million poly, 4K textured turd is still a turd, stop polishing it.Don't buy it before it is completely overhauled and patched by the devs (who am I kidding?) modders have completely fixed and balanced this mess, which might be never, since we don't even have steam workshop mods enabled yet.Was very hyped for this. Terribly disappointed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am basing this review and comparing it to civ 5 (which is a way better game). Civ 6 Is a solid game as I really enjoy the new wonder placement and district system but other than that I dont reccomend it. The AI have somehow downgraded compared to civ 5. Everyone is extremely hostile and its hard to trade and have diplomatic relations with them. Its impossible to have mods in the game and Firaxis is trying to make modding the game illegal. The DLC is extremely overpriced for the content you get and its turning into call of duty with all the dlcs. Most of the bad bugs have been fixed and everything is more clean since release. Overall, civ 5 is still a superior game.

title: Recommended
comment: Despite this game recieving a lot of flak from the community, it's almost undeniable that it delivers well as a civilization game and is a fantastic addition to the series. It does what any sequel should do and that's bringing change to an already successful series of games, if this game was the same as civ 5 then what would be the purpose in buying it? The game is good, and as a base game is far improved on the base game of civ 5 with a lot of new interesting features and systems. It's still expecting expansions and other DLCs just like civ 5 has as well! . I feel a lot of people get the skewered opion that this game is bad, simply because it has less content, the same idea that ruins each sims game upon release "why would we play this if we already have all the DLC in the old game and therefore more content" Ignoring that, this game is great, adds to the series, runs beautifully on high end machines with no framerate issues or slowing what-so-ever which has been a problem in the past for the series. I couldn't recommend more for the summer sale bundle with XCOM 2.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Being a Civ fan is hard to get to the point of feeling i need to write a DON'T RECOMEND review... but i feel i was almost robed by the Civ's team. The game lacks everything,1. IAs are stupid idiot and characters are too plain. Every character has only a couple sentences which makes the simulation of a conversation simply WRONG... AIs does things without any logic or reason.2. FULL OF BUGS. I nuked an allied and took cities without declearing war, an ally won't always join war if someone else attacks. If one of those happend you also get other bugs as laking different options while in diplomacy and other details3. The DLCs where ridiculusly expensive, they were worth not half of what i payied. NOT ONE OF THE DLCs4. VERY FEW diferences between civs, only 3 or 4 differences, in a long game you end up using the same mix-civ... result of getting to a stage when those very very little differences just don't apply... and all the civs are the same.5. Faith plays a vital rol in the game. TOO MUCHAND MANY MORE DISSAPOINTMENTSSorry for any laguage error.i'll be waiting for WAAAAYYYY better CIV VII

title: Not Recommended
comment: I do not recommend Civilization VI to play.The AI is unpredictable at best, and a nightmare of arbitrary aggression at worst; the idea of the computer having objectives (or 'agendas') sounds great, but in practice turns the game into a virtual minefield where in order to avoid provoking the AI you're restricted to doing almost none of the interesting features the game has to offer. Choose the wrong government out of a set of three? Denounced by an annoyed AI. Start building wonders and competing with other civs for the best improvements the game has to offer? Well, you can forget ever being friends with China. Never mind that it can take 100 turns to build one unless you have it in your capital. Try to gain great people? The same thing will happen with Brazil - bid farewell to any diplomatic relations. Kongo actually denounced me the turn immediately after I met them because I didn't spread my religion to them fast enough - there was a serious expectation for my scouts to be followed by a legion of missionaries, I guess. And don't even get me started on the Aztecs and their resource BS, or Greece and Germany declaring war because I want to talk to city states (you know, that innovative new system of suzerian states? That? No dice.)It's a sad game that de-incentivizes its players from doing the most interesting things in the game. The way that the AI works has made the game annoying and frustrating; especially since I honestly enjoy building up the best empire possible with all the benefits I can muster. Add in an infuriating UI that will have you punching your keyboard as your units start cycling through while you're trying to direct their paths, fighting the pathing systems all the way (though that's a carry-over from Civ 5, so I can't complain TOO much there).And don't get me started on Ghandi's mother ♥♥♥♥ing agenda. 'Nuke Happy?' Are you kidding me? You wasted an entire agenda slot for India - one of the longest surviving bastions of culture, religion and civilization itself - on a bad ♥♥♥♥ing joke? It's not even that good from a gameplay perspective. Nukes come in the late-game, so Ghandi's got the entirety of recorded history to bask in his smug irony; How am I supposed to take that kind of stupidity seriously when I'm trying to create a civilization to stand the test of time? Whatever magnitude of purpose the game possesses need only look to that kind of ridiculousness and feel it deflate into nothingness.I also wasn't a great fan of the art style - it's hard to feel truly 'epic' as a world superpower while hanging out with character models that feel like they're pulled from a pixar film. I was prepared to let that go, but the game just doesn't make up for it.I will give Civ VI one thing; however terrible the gameplay is, they packaged it in some seriously gorgeous wrapping. I give a standing ovation to the art team, the graphics designers, and Christopher Tin and other composers for the soundtrack. In Civ VI there are some truly beautiful worlds you can build - while the Ancient Era offers cities that look identical no matter what civ you choose, classical and onwards offer lovingly rendered cityscapes that show each and every building you construct (one of my favorite things in the game, as it really shows a record of what you've done beyond basic construction and food values). The music evolution through the games is gorgeous, and Sogna Di Volare is one of the most moving introductory pieces ever commited to gaming - I nearly had tears of excitement in my eyes while I waited for the game to load up. Sean Bean's smooth voice narrating the game is lovely as well.The problem is that those virtues are still just shiny wrapping paper attempting to cover up the crappy game design. It might succeed for the first hour or two of gameplay, but it doesn't take much longer than that to see past the nostalgia and hype.I have to agree with the dozens of others who've reviewed the game - buy Civ 5, get all the DLC for that with the money you'd spend here, and enjoy a gaming masterpiece with a full house of mods already created. Civ VI might be enjoyable in a year or two once the devs get in the game and the modding community does half their job for them, but it's not yet.UPDATE: I have to stick with what I've said earlier. Other reviews can tell you about how the updates to the game haven't fixed the problems in better detail than me. I won't be buying the DLC - why would I waste my money on a broken game? Firaxis needs to pull its head out of the sand and start paying attention to the serious critique its players have about their game instead of churning out more and more unneeded and largely unwanted expensive DLC. Buy Civ V and see the best that the Civilization series has to offer; you will not find it here.

title: Recommended
comment: Sofar, I have to admit, this is by far the best Civ ever on launch, but still missing some features and looking for the big expansion coming. All summed up, Civ 5 with all DLCs is better, but Civ6 looks very promissing to beat that legacy.There were major bug ruining the game also and lots of "deluxe buyers" are raging due to the poor quality of DLCs. That's capitalism for you.

title: Recommended
comment: So this review was writen after my first hour of the game.TL;DR: the game has a great atmosphere to it but has some noticable holes in it that will hopefully be fixed with expansions, i'd say pay at most $40 CAD ($30 USD) for this game (hopefully around christmas this year)Things i liked:-Combat is better-Sound effects are awesome-Love the music-the map seeds are different and more unique than civ 5-The way districts and cities work-Sean Bean (funny quotes for techs)-map modes for continents, religion, nations and more. (people coming from EU4 will like this)-Fog of war is visible on the minimap; you can see what you have vision of on the minimap.-AI IS AWESOME (i was denounced in the first 15 turns from hyper aggressive egypt because my military was too small and i was called a cruel leader by Russia that is hardcore science and art)-continents is a neat little featureThings i didn't like:-the fog of war, takes too long to update for my units vision and is hard to read-Ancient ruins/Tribes are hard to see-the movement is difficult to get used to.-did the developers just miss this? there is no ability to turn off auto unit cycle which is super annoying to me (where the game automatically jumps between units for you)-very limited ammount of map seeds (continents, pangea, fractal, inner ocean, and archipellago)-only 19 civs for people who didnt preorder (which will be changed in the future for sure)-barely any change to the pantheons (which means whoever gets one first is pretty much gurenteed to get fertility rights)

title: Not Recommended
comment: Have played all the Civ series from I, and after playing on and off for months, I would not recommend CIv VI.There is one huge problem with Civ VI-the AI. Civilization has always been essentially a solo game, you have to play against the AI. Civ VI also continues to be a game about war. The majority of units are military, it's difficult to avoid war, war is central to the game.The AI cannot fight a war in Civ VI. It is not even vaguely competent in fighting a war. You will meet armies that are far below you in technology, when the AI has had clear warning you will attack them. The AI does not update units, at least not that I notice. Units stumble forward, unprotected. There is no coordination of melee and ranged units-and forget air and navy units.Sure, AI is always hard, but other versions of CIv were more challenging militarily.Yes, districts add something to the game, but not enough to make up for the rest of the game. Early play is interesting, but the later game becomes a slog in moving large numbers of units, trying to manage endless cities, and, worst of all , knowing full well you will win the game, if you can just get thru another 100 turns of fighting, converting, or building a space ship...There is no way to fight an economic war. No corporations, you cannot trade money or demand money from opponents. Religous wars are tedious affairs that just seem to be military wars with different units. The technology tree and Wonders are not particularly diffrent from prior games. And CIv distinctions drop off over time. Playing the Aztecs in 1990 isn't that diffrent from playing the Russians.Graphics are different, but nothing particularly interesting or dramatically different from Civ VI.A big disappointment

title: Recommended
comment: China got jealous I had more wonders than them.10/10

title: Not Recommended
comment: I wanted to like this game. I've played and enjoyed every single Civilization title for the PC. I love the mechanics in principle, but the rampant bugs (seriously, still can't scroll properly?), the ridiculous AI and the constant crashes have ruined it for me.

title: Recommended
comment: Impressive game, there are already many features in the vanilla game ( religions, commercial routes, 18 different empires, etc ), the game runs very smooth and so far i've found 0 bugs. The district system and politic system are very interesting, also the AI and diplocacy seems a lot better than Civ V. To be honest i also like the cartoonish sytle of the game, add a layer of visual fun. One of the best Civ game if not the best oneUpdate after the first big patch : The game has improved a lot after the first update. The Ai seems better but there's still room for more adjustments. Let's see what happe nafter the first DLC

title: Not Recommended
comment: In Civilization VI's current state I cannot recommend this game. It's understandable that major patch deployments will result in bugs here and there but this has become such a problem with Civilization VI that I've thrown my hands up. So many broken systems resulted from the Summer Patch that it's difficult to properly enjoy a base level game of Civ 6.Honestly I could deal with it all if Fireaxis/2K would just communicate with customers. Yet here we are almost a month out and there hasn't been a single word concerning a patch. It has been so silent that we honestly have no idea if the fixes are going to happen soon or if they will be withheld until the 'Fall Update" 2-3 months from now.I'd love to update this review in the future if they can turn this game around. As it stands do not invest your money or time into Civ VI. Do yourself a favor and pickup the complete Civ V pack (often seen for $12) and enjoy.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeIncrediably slow turns(even by Civilization standard), and a cartoony UI right out of a mobile pay to win clickfest with arbitary gameplay staples from civilization franchise removed "For Reasons".This is an incrediably disappointing entry in the civilization franchise.At least I didn't spend money on this game directly, after getting it as a promotion when I bought a new graphics card.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ 5 is better has better options for city management they took most of the stuff that made civ 5 great and said to hell with it and made some stupid new crap that doesnt work nearly as well there are some good new things like different types of war and how you become friends with city states but its still not worth it over civ 5 they should have just kept civ 5s formual and add the good things in civ 6 into to make it great other than that Civ 5 is way better than this hands down this is a flop just like beyond earth was

title: Recommended
comment: After 12 hours of gameplay, I came to a conclusion that Civilisation-6 was an experiment, developers did NOT redesign the whole game (i.e. combat is mostly the same) and left a few other previously known features mostly unchanged, but they made more focus on the small things, which may only be appreciated by limited audience (including me).Highs (SUBJECTIVE):- Visuals and UI feels more intuitive than in previous games.- War justifications result in different warmonger score: Relegious wars, Formal wars, etc.- Leaders forgive your aggression as the time progresses.- District concept is simple to grasp.- Exploration feels more interesting than in previous games,- I like the new fog of war mechanics.- When you re-prioritise your city's foucs (food, production, science...), the improved titles change their appearance (i.e. fields become greener / browner).- Continent names!- Multuple map modes (religious overview, governmental forms, etc. similar to EU4).- Each civilisation has a music theme that evolves in complexity every two eras.Lows (SUBJECTIVE):- AI: "I do not care that you have the largest tank fleet in the world, my cavemen with clubs will beat the hell of your tank's paint... and while I do that, let me build a new city on the border with you".- Starting positions seem to be poorly thought through - you start way to close to other civilisations.- Religious victory is too over-powered - should be not 51% but rather 91% of another's civilisation's cities following the religions.- Scientific boosts are over-powered (50% for most of things that you would do naturally). I end up entering Industrial era in 10th century. Should either have slighly reduced boost (i.e. 10-25%) or have higher triggering conditions.- Half of the cultural cards are rubbish.- Most of the great people do not bring great benefits.- The new happiness mechanic is not clear (may well be part of my learning curve).- Micro-management is way too admin-driven (I would like to be able to auto-renew trades based on simple conditions, such as keep this route internal with the larges production output, followed by largest income, followed by largest food, etc.).- District repariments are tedious ("Okay, bunch of rebels decided to burn a few tiles and now it will take me 20 turns to get the city of where it was and I cannot use builders to boost / auto-complete repairs).

title: Not Recommended
comment: woweee this is interestingly bad. Just play Civ 5, literally no reason to play VI over it.Pros- Finally can have my offensive units Escort my civilian units.- Districts are definitely a nice twist, although, I feel as if each district needed to be buffed/expanded, so you could have an industrial/harbor/commercial powerhouse, given the proper land.Neutral/Notes-The art style has taken a cartoon like style. I'm not a huge fan of it, but I don't necessarily hate it.-Wonders aren't exactly as often used from what I've seen, played deity and I think Hermitage(?) was still up for grabs until renaissance era.- Probably just me, but I find the whole religion combat and religion strategy confusing as a whole.- For a game with Clash of Clans like graphics, thing makes my computer run a little hot- The AI... Just, why? After so many complaints from Civ 5 over the AI, little has changed. Tsk tsk.- Want to win? F*** your science, culture and diploma- oh wait there is no diplomacy victory, domination is the only real practical way to win and is the go-to ez pz route.- Nearly all the (good) civs are military boosted for their bonus, again, say goodbye to science/culture/diplomatic victories.- City states are pretty much forgotten about, you do a quest here and there, send them some envoys and thats all you can do with them really.Stop freaking releasing half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥games then unloading a plethora of scenarios (NO ONE FREAKING ASKED FOR) and unbalanced civs for a ridiculous price. Hats off to you 2k and Firaxis, you're finally growing into a normal AAA company and becoming greedy pigs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I can't put my finger on exactly what is wrong with Civ VI, compared to IV and V which I played both religously. I think the best word would be slow. The game physically runs faster and smoother than V did, yet mid to late game typically feels like more of a chore to play. On all three of the Civ games I have played, I typically like to play around with marathon type games to really immerse myself into the scenario, but Civ VI just does not do a great job of grabbing my attention.The enemy AI, much hyped in pre-release as a smarter and more realistic gang- is hilariously unprepared at standard difficulty. Gone are the attempts to create world congress deals and precarious alliances, replaced with Bismark being mad that I am sending envoys to Carthage or Norway sneering at my landlocked nation not having a sea unit. The goals of each nation overbear the international politics like Civ V's tendency to denounce on crack. By end game EVERYONE is hostile to each other and there's no way for anyone to compete with a human player.Finally, we'll get to the real reason everyone is angry with this game, and that's the laughable DLC model. Paying 5 dollars for each civilization or 3 dollars for a few maps is completely over the line. Compare to how much content released as each expansion of previous Civ games, and this feels more and more like a slap in the face to people who enjoy this series. Why would I want another civilization with even more asanine goals to deal with? I was really excited to play this game, heck I pre-ordered the digital deluxe edition. But this is just another step in the Bethesda, EA, model of more money for less content.Get Civ V with all the DLC on the next steam sale, and enjoy yourself.

title: Recommended
comment: I'm seriously addicted to this game . I tried to join Civ Anon , but I can't stop playing long enough to go to the meetings ...

title: Recommended
comment: Like all Civilization games before it, this is the pinnacle of civilzation simulation/strategy. Once again, another great Civ game. You won't need to wait for the first expansion for this one, it's good from the get-go.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A major step back from Civ 5 and even a step back from Civ BE. I would just recommend Civ 5 to anyone who wants to play Civ.

title: Not Recommended
comment: No modding support, poor AI and trivial gameplay...Firaxis should reconsider employment of their marketing guys, since they seem to have no idea about what has been shaping popularity of the series all these years and just try to copy new "fashionable" strategies that should bring more money to the company, but are actually destroying fan community and the future of Civilization.As for me, I am done with the series unless Firaxis puts some effort into creating a modding community and makes vanilla game (without future paid DLCs) somewhat playable.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have tried to get enjoyment out of it. But I just can't, its not fun. The AI is a mess it always wants to fight you or offer trade that is horribly in favor of the AI. Like every extra resource you have for just one gold a turn, bad. I have no idea what the AI is thinking and when they do fight you they throw all their ancient era units against your modern army. Every war I have fought has been terribly one sided. And they always end up hating you no matter what you do so why bother.The district aspect might be fun if you had any idea why. You can do things one time and not the another. So you just end up throwing down districts for amenitites. There is no explanation why things happen or don't happen. So you need to figure out the why most of the time. Even then sometimes you just can't figure out why. Like religions, what do they do. Why even bother? I really can't find a real reason to pursue one. I usually forget about religions until the my civ in flooded with tons of missionary units. It's like they are cockroaches, they just keep coming. I ask the the other civ to stop. They say sure and but they keep coming.I have tried many different rulers and set ups but it always ends up the same way. Me just steam rolling over the rest of the civs. I have stopped playing it because of the lack of enjoyment. I bought the digital pass package (which I now regret) so hopefully after a expansion it will get better. But for right now I have put this game aside.
