Impressions Views: 15,028so very very close! just a tiny bit more and we will have the best game since civ 4 Consider supporting me on Patreon! https://www.patreon.com/user?u=3863342 https://twitter.com/ArchWarhammer Intro...And id also add this fact: wait till the workshop is availible(the video isnt mine)

title: Not Recommended
comment: I cannot in good faith recommend a game with 15$ of DLC after couple months, and the game being 80$. Way to overpriced, if there was a seasons pass + game and it was 50$ maybe it would be worth it, but they just can't help but gouge.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Alright, so, I have logged over a hundred hours in the game so I feel competent to make a review. This is an amazing game with the exception of one critical failure, the civilization AI is terrible. Each Civ has built in things that they cannot abide. For example Rome does not like Civs that don't expand. If you don't capture lots of lands then Caesar is going to have a problem with you. Of course he also does not like it if you settle to close or have a strong military. Basically you are screwed either way with him. That pretty much sums up the diplomacy experience right there. Each leader has things it likes and dislikes so if you play with 6 or 7 of them you absolutely with♥♥♥♥♥♥off half of them. They will declare war on you, you will defend yourself then get slammed as a warmonger when you didn't even start the danged thing. It is pretty terrible and not much fun to play. Everything else is good in this version, but the AI is just a no go. This absolutely needs to be fixed and I honestly just do not understand what the developers were thinking. As much as I would love to recommend it this is a serious step back from Civ V and even from Beyond Earth, which in and of itself was a tad disappointing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Some interesting changes that will only be apparent to long time Civ players. Overall the game is fine but the price point alongside the DLC is far too much. I'm fine with the visual style but I understand why a lot of people would dislike it. Personally I would prefer a more realistic style too.Buy Civ V on sale instead and get the whole thing for $10.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I thoroughly enjoyed Civ V and was considerably excited for Civ VI at its release. I am a Mac player, and waited patiently for my version to come out a month later. I then played single player games and was happy, but wanted to join my other friends in multiplayer games, all PC players.Civ V became a greater game for me because I could play hours upon hours with my friends, but whenever I wanted to play Civ VI with my friends, I couldn't because of our updates not being at the same time. They would get the Australian Civ Pack and I had to wait a month to receive it, but by the time I did they had a new update making our games incompatible to play.I recently tried to have another multiplayer game since all updates were the same for both Mac and PC, and saw that they no longer can support trying to have cross-platform multiplayer play. I hope in the future they can fix the bugs that will allow multiplayer support for cross-platform, as it is what I bought Civ VI for and am utterly disappointed that it has taken 6 months for this to be addressed publicly. It should not be advertised as cross-platform if IT IS NOT.If you want to play on your own, Civ VI gives the next great challenge for the Civ play, but for Mac and PC friends to play together, it is not available and keeps me from playing the game further.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The bad- Extremely unbalanced- AI isn't very bright- Surprise wars declared on you for very few reasons- AI interaction in general is unpleasant- Played one round on the easiest difficulty, was immediately hated by all civs, constantly invaded or denounced- Mod support is still limited- build times are dramatically increased for everything- much more frustrating whether you're new or if you have a few hundred hours of Civ V under your beltThe good- Districts are nice- Gamestyle is very refreshing- Workers instantly building minor improvements is goodOverall, Don't buy the game yet, it needs fixing and tweaking.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been a fan of the Civ franchise from the start. I think I've given this, in its current state, enough of a shot to make a fair assessment. It's the worst offering yet, by far. There is virtually nothing enjoyable about the game. The religion component just feels like a chore, like swatting at mosquitos. Another chore...workers (builders) are no longer able to be automated.I guess the districts are a little interesting, but they don't really add much to actual gameplay.The graphics are pretty. I like the cartoonish aspect, the map and fog of war effect are great.It's been pretty well pointed out how terrible the AI is...and it's what in the end makes the game unplayable. I'm holding out some hope for an extensive overhaul, but I think the game is flawed to it's core.I wish they would go back to CIV IV and start from there. Just a refresh of the graphics of that would have been light years ahead of this huge dissappointment.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI needs to be improved a lot.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Would recommend Civ 5 over this unless this is on sale. The AI is still terrible, and requires deity to have the AI cheat massively to even have it be close.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Crippling bad and irrational AI that is best summed up by an anecdote:Me, Ghandi and Cleopetra are neighbors.Ghandi asks me for a Joint war against Cleopetra, and I think why not?The turn after declaring a JOINT WAR Ghandi denounces me for being a warmonger.A few turns after that he declares war on me aswell.Wait for Firaxis to release a large expansion/fixthat isn't another overcharged Civilisation shackled to Scenario packs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This games servers are ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥ i swear to God it takes more time to get everyone to get in a lobby then it is to play a game. hosting a game with a few people is fine but 5+ players attempting to connect to a lobby is impossible. the server issues from civ 5 have not been fixed and it may be worse. i cannot play with my friends becasue we all can't connect to the same lobby. Also joining a saved game doesn't work either. please for the love of God fix these ♥♥♥♥♥♥ servers

title: Not Recommended
comment: Sadly it's simply not there yet.The game has a lot of potential and good ideas which are currently held back by not so good ideas and an absolutely atrocious AI. As a result the game currently thrives on abusing mechanics or the AI making anything singleplayer related a cake walk hardest difficulty included.As a civ5 veteran I'm really disapointed we got a worse AI and that some of the lessons of Civ5 were not learned for this new game.Modding is still not available at the moment I write this and the multiplayer support is barebone.I currently cannot recommend it as I'm more interested to go play Civ5 Civ4 or another series altogether. My review will change if the first expansion fixes its major problems.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Not many changes compared to Civ V, I'd recommend that game instead - especially because of the DLC policy for Civ VI.It may be worthwhile if you have played Civ V so much that you welcome every little change, but if you are new to the series save yourself the headaches and get the Game of the Year Edition of Civ V instead.

title: Recommended
comment: Personally, I like the new art style, the fifth game tried looking realistic but just looked sort of unrealistically cartoony. This game embraces the cartoony style and makes everything surprisingly more detailed.The soundtrack is phenomenal, I instantly fell in love with some of the civs audio tracks throughout the ages!The game plays a bit different and feels a bit different but is still a Civ game, I would recommend this to anybody.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I didn't like it. I've played I think every Civ game, but not as a die hard. I especially didn't like the city building, I didn't quite get it or like the bit that I got about the sprawling cities.

title: Not Recommended
comment: until the updates roll out its not worth the full 60$. You'd be better off buying civ 5 and all the dlc

title: Not Recommended
comment: New graphics are nice, lack of mod support is really annoying... A.I. still sucks...In its current state I wouldn't reccomend Civ 6, stick with Civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game is decent so far but 6 months from release and still incomplete. The World-builder which is part of the SDK is still "hidden" and incomplete. The SDK was released only a short time ago but is incomplete. 6 months. Don't waste your money. Wait until the game is completed.UPDATE: STILL A WASTE OF MONEY ON A BROKEN GAME. READ BELOWThis game is almost a year old and instead of fix some of the worst bugs (in the AI) and fix the one tool that many people have requested (The World Builder) they just managed to break the game even more. I didn't think it was possible.Lesson learned. I will not be buying Civ 7 until at least a year after its release.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am a big fan of Civilization V where the different civilizations and winning options are more balanced. In this game: The barbarians and some of the civilizations makes it impossible to win other victories than domination in this game. You spend so many turns in every city building only militairy units defending yourself that nothing else gets built. If you do get the chance to build anything else you first have to build districts that takes sooooo many turns to build. Sounds fun on paper to have districts but you also have to sacrifice one square to build them and don´t expect to be able to build them all because of game restrictions and lack of city area. I feel the same about building wonders (which are not very useful at all). If you do get ahead in some of the other areas then get prepared to get attacked by rediculously many units by the AI. Then you also have to keep spending turns on building builders to repair everything. And be prepared to have to build lots of them becase they only last for 3 uses (or playing as China, 4 turns) Then fun of the game being diverse is gone.I think the game have some really good ideas in form of the eurekas, a tech tree and a civics tree, special people but the game is not fun to play unless you only go for domination victory every game you play due to the imbalances.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I was really looking forward to this game after all the enjoyment I got out of Civ V, but, unfortunately, Civ 6 just constantly tests my patience.There were some good design decisions brought in with Civ 6, but the AI seems to have really suffered for it. I'm not even talking about the constant, random denouncements or joint wars either. I mean the AI, literally, cannot use ships or planes. The AI is also pretty bad at district placement which means most AI cities won't even be worth capturing. But, of course, you have to because of the massive warmonger penalties to razing cities.The final straw for me though was discovering a bug when retaking a captured city that can cause the "cede city" option to just not appear on the trade screen. This means said city is just under perma-occupation and basically worthless. I've never really enjoyed combat in Civ 6, but a bug that's been in the game for months which makes defending yourself/retaking territory pointless just adds to the frustration of it all.Civ 6 is still a mess in its current state. It's hard to say if one expansion can fix it, but I certainly hope so.

title: Not Recommended
comment: game isnt worth it, just get civ 5

title: Recommended
comment: While there are still some annoyances, like- Tactics AI is pretty much the same as Civ V and with the new additions of unit stacking is even less able to cope with warfare- Desync issues in MP- Clunky/Slow unit management.the new additions like districts, civics and religious war make the game much more complex, but its not meaningless complexity. On the contrary, it feels much less arbitrary than "burn a great scientist for 1000 science" and it switches things up.So in the end, while this is not perfect, it is better than Civ V in every regard and there is no reason to play Civ V over this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The f'ck'n AI is still messed up! So...prepare to get attacked every now and then...even by your best friend neighbour. You simply can't trust any computer controlled empire. As soon you reach atomic age, all will be permanent angry on you, no matter what you do to avoid missunderstandings. Just forget about working diplomacy and sign treaties only on a ad-hoc base for actual benefits.Usually I'd give bad review, but all in all I encountered lot's of smaller and bigger upgrades toward former Civ games.At least upgrading/melting similar units into Corps (2x) or Armys (3x) enhances gameplay in the later eras. Remembering the awfull moving problems if your army wanted to attack a city surrounded by hills in Civ5. Now you just melt your 3 infantry into a powerfull single infantry army and go for the fight. This really changes gameplay into much better tactical experience.Also the city buildup with specialized 'gated communities' leaves you a lot of interesting choices. You pick one land/sea tile for your special site, like harbour or religious area. After this, you encounter lot's of enhancements to that site, like maybe lighthouse for the harbour, which doesn't need you to pick another tile for the build. This offers every city the possibility for unique shape. Ok, the basic system is copy from Endless Legend, but it fits quite nice into Civ6.What really get's me mad is the permanent threat of war, so you can't play game like scientist or peacefull builder as in former versions. On the other side, you are permanently questioned to do important judgments to deal with the threats. I do hope they'll patch this in the future, otherwise the game has turned into a war-beast.Anther spitting in customers face is the price level they ask for Civ6. If you could grab the game for half of current requested fee, you may get what you pay for. Any higher charge...well, how about sending me your email, so I could give you my PayPal contacts and you could just send your spare money over instead of wasting it? *subtle irony off*One may be disappointed by more and more comic graphics, but hey, it is a strategy game and I also had fun with games which only showed letters on a map instead units. So, for me it isn't too much of a problem...and the landscapes, trees, surroundings, day-and-night circle and other aspects do compensate in my eyes.There are allready mods out there (civfanatics and else), so you may also grab the common version and wait for later season pass offers.So...my short impression at the moment is, they managed to keep the 'only one more turn' feeling, but have to upgrade their way to early released beta. But except Paradox, all distributors throw out games too early at the moment. ^^____Update:After a while playing with mods quite ok, they patched Civ6 and from that time, some mods do not longer work with other mods. No reasoning. Tested hours...only new civilizations, which of course do not compromize gamecode. No chance to get a game running.So, Firaxis did it again. Review changed to negative. Can not longer recommand this game.____Biggest Bummer 2017

title: Not Recommended
comment: Stick with Civ 5 until this is about 20 bucks or $30 with all the DLC and Expansions. The game features are not a big improvement over Civ 5, and the downsides are even worse AI in so far as the military goes. Its not terrible, but I wish I had spent my 60 bucks elsewhere. They really missed the mark on this one. Perhaps the expansions will make it better. If you don't own Civ 5, buy it with all of the expansions before looking at this one, it is a better game. If you already own it, you will be disappointed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just buy Civ 5- that version is 100 times better than six.This version is a step down in every way :(

title: Not Recommended
comment: I liked the game but frankly the model on they sold the DLC is so bad. I know they are trying to make it better but even then it's too little to late.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Compared to the prior games, Civ 6 has a lot of advancements, which is great. However, it feels... dead and boring.I'll start off with the good:- Splitting the tech tree feels nice, into two sections. However, you now have situationss where you've researched everything and have a LOT of time left over.- Being able to attach special units to combat units is nice.- Being able to group units into armies (although in a very limited, crude fashion) is a nice call-back from earlier games. Could use some tweaks though (like not having it just be one type of unit with only support units in your army)- Bringing back the "Earth with True Starts" was nice... but exceptionally small (like holy crud, three cities covered the entirety of North America, make that a giant map or something next time).The Bad:- The AI is even more nonsencial than it was before! Praise me one turn, denounce me the next, for the exact same things.- The tech tree feels rather short now- The civics tree feels rather short (and half of them are useless unless you've got every city built to almost identical specs)- Crashing, oh god, the crashing (I meet the specs, before anyone asks, but it stil crashed several times, and no, I wasn't playing with mods)- AI in combat doesn't always do things that make sense (for example, I was fighting Greece, and they fielded crossbowmen and musketmen next to mechanized infantry, like 'wtf'?)- The AI doesn't always make the best use of it's assets (tons and tons of aerodromes... not a single aircraft; tons of coastline, I'm not even bothering to pillage their coastline, and they don't field a single ship against me).- The AI doesn't try to even make peace (war against Greece, again, captured 1/2 of their territory, I offered peace because the warmongering penalty was killing me, but I could've smashed them with about the 5 units I had)- Played for 17 hours, got TWO great artists in that entire time. I got more art from captured cities than I did from what I generated. And lots of ruins, but nowhere to put the relics even with me building nothing but archaeological museums).

title: Not Recommended
comment: "DLC"

title: Not Recommended
comment: Until you see patch notes saying they improved the AI i reccomend not getting the game, still a cool game but the AI prevents me from enjoying the game for a long period of time as they just seem to be very bipolar.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have changed my view of Civ 6. Even though the AI is terrible (even at the hardest level) it is pretty. Still I cannot recommend it. Because it is only good as a casual game that you can expect to always win at Deity.I am eager to see the Gold Package though which is when in past Civs they have fixed the game. For once at least it seems like a complete game at release (minus the AI) I'm eager to see what game additions they'll make with the expansions.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have played this game for a while. I have done my best to enjoy what I play. Yet after all these "updates", it still takes 45 mods just to make the game enjoyable to some degree. The DLC I never bothered buying because who wants to spend money for one civ at a time, or even a scenario? I never played Scenarios with Civ V or Civ VI. This game is utterly worthless in Civilization V's shadow. The only reason i still play it to some mild degree is for districts but thats basically the only reason. Spending $60 for a game because Districts, Yay! is a terrible terrible waste of money. If you dont mind hoarding mods to fix the game then go crazy. But I advise you to just leave this game alone.

title: Not Recommended
comment: There are numerous problems with this game, too many to list here. But there's one really HUGE downer and it's the fact that this game is so, so boring.. You'll long for Civ V constantly(even the graphics of trees and farms etc was 100 times better). After forcing yourself through 100 hours of this game it just becaomes so utterly boring you'd want to kill yourself. It's not just a matter of getting used to a different play-style, it's so booooring...

title: Not Recommended
comment: Look I admit Civ IV mods really gave that game long lasting life, still does.Civ V...well it took some expansions to really get good.Civ VI...very pricey, and after the latest "patch" now extremely crashy too.It's so promising, but I'm not recommending people pay the high price for the privledge of being Beta Testers.Months Later:Better...but still poor price point and too much DLC content that should be released as free DLC for the price the original content was. Triple A game at it's worst.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have loved the Civilization games since i discovered them 10 years ago. This game to put it frankly has ruined the franchise for me. The AI is deplorable, an enjoyable relaxing afternoon or evening playing a fun enjoyable game is not possible here.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Dummed down and not as pretty as the previous ones or immersive. Civ 4, despite its flaws was the best by far!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Still no cross-platform multiplayer. Bought it to play with friends, turns out they haven't fixed a mac/pc issue that has apparently been an issue for the last two years.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Firaxis should be ashamed. From it's gameplay and design civilization VI is a very good game. Everything else is awful. It feels like they learned nothing from Civ V. The mulitplayer lobby is extremely buggy. That makes reloading games very hard.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Because for some reason my pacifist civilization gets attacked by its own allies. Got attacked by two of my allies who I had +50 relationship score. Reloaded the game and it happened again. Kinda a tedious time sink only to be used if you have time to kill. I'll jump back on the bandwagon if Firaxis ever makes good AI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Utter disappointment especially after the previous installment raising the bar of the franchise. There are a lot of new ideas here too but somehow the magic doesn't happen this time. The religion is a pain in this version, and the novelty of new concepts like Eurekas and Civil tech tree wears off quickly to then realise it actually doesn't bring anything in term of pleasure to play.Worse, the Eurekas actually restrain your choices as you will have to plan an exact sequence to trigger as much as possible. As a result the game feels slow as the moments were you are involved making a choice are too far and between.But the most negative point is the AI. You can ruin entire AI civilisations with 3 units, it's just ridiculous.Finally the pricing policy has become too greedy.

title: Not Recommended
comment: * Numerous connection problems when doing multiplayer with friends via Steam on Windows. Some people can get in, others can't. Have to rotate hosts until you find a player who works, depite all being able to play other self-hosted games together fine. It's not consistent which player will actually be able to host.* In the classical age, a bot told me nuclear weapons were the future. Weird and out of place.* Cross-platform (Mac-Windows and Linux-Windows) play still not available after being promised in Febuary. (A bunch of content packs and a port to iPad is out though! Yay?)* Intel / AMD GPUs are not supported on Linux. Why? No idea. The game seems to work fine on amdgpu on my Linux box, but there are graphics glitches on intel.I bought the fancy digital delux edition to support a dev who was working on a Linux port of a great game, but I still can't use Linux to play with my friends on Windows, and sometimes I can't use Windows to play with my friends on Windows either. Bummer.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I like playing civ on a random, medium world combined with the single aim to be the last one standing.For me, the game is not worth the price as the AI is way to bad in seriously attacking my cities on normal or slightly higher difficulty (emperor). Either the enemy attacks with enormous armies that run around my cities without attacking and wait to be smashed, or there are no attacks at all and I conquer everything ignoring the warmonger penalties completely. In addition, there is still nearly no battle on the oceans as the AI doesn't produce enough ships.If I could choose the improvement for the next patch, I would say a multilayered AI.Of course, the game might be perfectly balanced for multiplayer games. I don't know.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Hello everyone,Steam sadly got only YES or NO. I would give that game 60% which would qualify as a Yes, but I have to vote No this time.For a triple AAA title this game was launched AGAIN in a seemingly non tested BETA state (at best).I love Civ (got quite some hours on the previous titles Civ I-V). But for a game for that price It ain't done yet.Complete imbalanced and bugged. The AI is literally not existing and gets advantages simply by cheating. It is even worse than Civ V.Diplomacy is a complete mess. Well it doesn't really exist tbh.Do not try to get a religion on higher difficulties. Just ignore it. Religion doesn't really exist for the Player. It is an AI privilidge.AI got none whatsoever Diplomacy consequences.For example:If your troops are close to AI Boarders (even if it is inside your borders) AI will complain.AI will move troops next to your capital and you can't complain it is no reason to declare war.Troops will remin there for centuries. Nothing you can do bout it.AI will convert your cities, you tell them to stop that. They agree. They do it again (promise broken) nothing you can do about it. It doesn't qulify as "causal bell" for war. same goes for spies.They attack you. YOU ARE THE WARMONGER.If you want to play the game higher than prince prepare to feel the entire game as you were Hitler.Every AI will hate you the entire game. Even if you started out to do a peaceful game.I'm not talking here about the little annoying bugs which are plentyhere a few.-Land units will attempt to engage your naval units (they encircle your ships and you can kill their entire army witha few ships)- Completly overpowered races (Germans, Sumerian)-Missionaries overrun your cities and encircle them making it impossible to move around in your own country ( I counted up to 30 units on my city)I'm used to issues with Civ shortly after launch. But this time it is even worse. Same with Civ V it was really a god game with the first expansion.A playable Civ version cost like 90 bucks here Game + first expansion.I feel that is too much...If you are a civ fan and you can wait I suggest you do so and wait for a bundle price with the first expansion.I hope that review was helpful.

title: Recommended
comment: I need to just chime in against some of the hate that I'm seeing in the reviews. Here's the thing haters: You guys have hated on every single Civilization game that has come out. You have claimed that it is bad and that the previous one (this this case Civ V) was far superior (and in some cases the "Golden Age" of Civilization games). Then the next one comes out and you sing the same tune about the one that you so boldly claimed sucked.We all recall how much you guys hated on Civ V for being hex tiles and only allowing one unit per tile. Now you love it and this game (that you played for 2-3 hours) is the one that sucks. It's a really disgusting aspect of an otherwise amazing Civilization community. And a LOT of the negative reviews are following this mantra.The game is great. It's Civ V with some improvements, changes, and a new coat of paint. They have streamlined (not dumbed down) some aspects of the game, which is a great thing. They've made it so cities require a bit more thought to manage (e.g. Wonders take up tiles). And it's overall just a fantastic new iteration into the franchise we all know and love. Sure, it needs some work. But so does every Civ game when it first comes out. I have no doubt that they will polish it up with free patches and then expand upon it further with some expansion packs.Don't believe the hate. The game is not perfect (no Civ is when it's released) but it's a great addition to the franchise and well worth your $60. You will once again spend your night saying "One more turn" until it's time to get up for work.SCORE: 9/10(Disclaimer: I have played far more than 2 hours. I played before release (not on steam) at multiple stages of development as well as the release candidate version. I've probably put in a total of 40-50 hours so far and I see no end in sight. And if you don't believe me then that's fine. I got nothing to prove and I don't really care if you believe me or not)Edits/Additions:- One of the biggest and most consistent complaints is that you can't rename cities or leaders. Really guys? It's not that big of a deal and I'm sure they will add that back in.- Just because the graphics remind you of Civilization Revolution doesn't mean the game is watered down, simplified, or dumbed down.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm sort of happy I got the game on the monthly bundle, otherwise, buying it at full value, or even on the Steam sale, would have been a total disappointment.It's incredible how six games into the franchise the opponent AI has fallen into such a pitiful state. Prepare yourself for the wonders of being denounced one turn for generating too little culture, and then the next turn be praised by the same opponent for having a lot of money in the coffers. Gone are the days where AI would try to keep a semblant of unity in their expansion strategy, now as early as medieval age, you'll see cities popping randomly, especially in small maps.It's incredible how the UI has been mashed and mangled to be almost unusable. Going through great people lists by clicking and dragging a 5 pixel tall horizontal scroll bar, is the most glaring example of the retrocess in this area I can recall. But in general every menu looks bad and unpolished.The new mechanics are also hit and miss. While I like the limited used workers, the notion of "amenities" replacing happiness is never properly explained or made visible at a top level overview. "Districts" seem like a brute force way of making players specialize their cities, but in a way that is stumped very early as the diversity of districts is connected to the total city population. Building lists are severely reduced and building overall seems far too slow, even at normal game speeds. Having to use civ tiles to build wonders is an interesting choice and it introduces a development vs. wonder victory element. However, it can also be a thinly veiled stab at a popular strategy for wonder victory where a single super productive capital could amass dozens of wonders.And while the visuals of the game are simply stunning and detailed, I am also not a fan of the cartoonish style of the leaders. Nobody feels menacing while looking like a Pixar cartoon, even if they are screaming threats of nuclear winter at you.In general, very underwhelming. Get it at a reduced price if you're a fan of turn-based games or Civ in general, but wait until one or two expansions are out and the major AI and gameplay issues are fixed for a better experience.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Needs the Civ "needs more expansions to actually be good" treatment. Currently the AI is really really awful and you can't do much when everyone inevitably decides to gang up on you.

It has the same gamefeel that the Civ games should have, while beatifully implimenting new feature and mechanics.Now, if only they could fix the AI...(I kid you not I had city state allies attacking an enemy civ with no less than 17 catapults while I used 2 field caannons and a cavalry, it was quite amusingly absurd)

title: Not Recommended
comment: After being out for 3 months, I picked the game up hoping the negative reviews would have been fixed with patching. This is not the case. The AI in this version of CIV is so buggy it makes the game unplayable in any way besides all out war. The game also freezes every time I try to close it to the point of needing to end the process in task manager. The UI is unintuitive and has various other bugs scattered throughout. Overall, this game is not polished or even completed to my expectations of Civ a game. I am requesting a refund and will return to Civ 4, which at least works.

title: Recommended
comment: Its well done IMO. Im looking at some of these reviews and they play hardly half an hour and go this is bad. Refund. Might as well just not buy it if you dont give it a chance. But thats their descision. Anyways. Feels really similiar to Civ 5. They tried something new and it was...meh. Now they went back to what works and people are still kinda meh about it. Honestly, I think a lot of work went into the art and to me thats fine. I love the new visuals and mechanics. Maybe very similiar but the visuals really make the game pop. So Im happy with my purchase and to me thats all that really matters. They could have added some more into the game and built up from civ 5. To wrap it up I like the new game, even if its very similiar. Theres a lot of new mechanics that make it different even with the similiarities. Some people disagree and thats fine. Im not an expert reviewer just someone who plays and throws his opinions out there on the game like some people do. Maybe this will help someone or maybe not.

title: Recommended
comment: Pleased overall. Civ 6 has taken a lot of heat for not being like previous Civ incarnations. I have played them all. In my opinion, this one is the best. The biggest flaw of the previous version was the auto-builder funtion. Nothing looked more uninspired than a network of roads going nowhere!However, AI still needs improvement. In most games, I find myself having three or more civs declaring war on me after making trade deals. Seems like the AI loves to gangup on the player.The newest expansion has a couple of bugs (easy fixes) barbarian units appear out of nowhere when all of your cities are happy. Alliances should be easier to make. You should have to have all of your trade routes going to a civ and bribe him twenty times only to have him say he's not ready to be an ally even though he's very friendly with you.

title: Recommended
comment: Love how the negative reviews started pouring in when the DLC’s came out, also a lot of negative reviews are people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about having to pay full price for a game. This game is good, not great but good. But it's definitely not as bad as others make it out to be….

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really wanted to like Civ 6, but I just can't. Most of the new features sound like a good idea, and in part they are, but most all have a big negative to them. I could type out all the problems for hours, but I will just give a few to save time.New city district system sounds good, but you are still stuck building only one thing a turn despite having all these seperate building complexes. Then builders are only good 3 times, so you have to spend extra build time on them. And if something gets damaged you have to repair it via the build system. That sometimes takes 9+ turns! It can also take several turns for your troops to simply go from one side of your city to the other.Roads are built automatically by traders. Sounds good, but that means you have to send traders to every city even if you don't want to. So you have to send one from City A to City B, City B to City C, City C to City A, and so on. You can get an engineer to build roads,... ONE TILE AT A TIME!AI leaders seem to be bipolar. They shame you over the size of your military, and then the very next turn say how impressive it is. They will delare war on you, and then just sit there and never send any troops. Also enemy units sometimes get stuck and never move from a tile.You now gain influence over city states by sending them envoys, but it's a constant see-saw battle with the AI. You send 5 envoys. They send 6. Then you send 7, so they send 8. In one game I kept losing my caravans because my max number would constantly be changing from 5 to 10 because my influence would rise and fall constantly.Religon? Nope. Not even going to go there. The changes sound good on paper, but it sucks. I turned off religion victory and just avoid all of it.Notification! Notifications have been reduced to a tiny hidden button on the lower right. I had barbarians running thru my capital and never knew. Is someone close to victory? Well you better constantly be checking the victory tab or you'll never know. I lost a game and I still don't know why! The end screen doesn't even show who or how they won!Meh, I don't want to go on any longer. I can see a good game here, but so much needs to be fixed. I'm sure modders are already working on a lot of these problems. I'd wait a few month before purchasing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A major step back from Civ 5 and even a step back from Civ BE. I would just recommend Civ 5 to anyone who wants to play Civ.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game does not live up to expectations...many bad new design features that frustrates you a lot when playing.And they cant even make a big world map where you start in the correct places.Last time I buy civ games!!

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game is good for about 100 hours or if you are smarter than me it is good until you realise that the AI is horrible both in mechanics and deplomacy, the gameplay is tedious (the card system and eureka! tech cost cuts) and after multiple patches the dev team still hasn't fixed these things and instead is focused on creating more leaders and civilizations to play.What good is a new leader/civ when it isn't fun playing it?

title: Not Recommended
comment: I wanted to like this game. I've played and enjoyed every single Civilization title for the PC. I love the mechanics in principle, but the rampant bugs (seriously, still can't scroll properly?), the ridiculous AI and the constant crashes have ruined it for me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Have played all the Civ series from I, and after playing on and off for months, I would not recommend CIv VI.There is one huge problem with Civ VI-the AI. Civilization has always been essentially a solo game, you have to play against the AI. Civ VI also continues to be a game about war. The majority of units are military, it's difficult to avoid war, war is central to the game.The AI cannot fight a war in Civ VI. It is not even vaguely competent in fighting a war. You will meet armies that are far below you in technology, when the AI has had clear warning you will attack them. The AI does not update units, at least not that I notice. Units stumble forward, unprotected. There is no coordination of melee and ranged units-and forget air and navy units.Sure, AI is always hard, but other versions of CIv were more challenging militarily.Yes, districts add something to the game, but not enough to make up for the rest of the game. Early play is interesting, but the later game becomes a slog in moving large numbers of units, trying to manage endless cities, and, worst of all , knowing full well you will win the game, if you can just get thru another 100 turns of fighting, converting, or building a space ship...There is no way to fight an economic war. No corporations, you cannot trade money or demand money from opponents. Religous wars are tedious affairs that just seem to be military wars with different units. The technology tree and Wonders are not particularly diffrent from prior games. And CIv distinctions drop off over time. Playing the Aztecs in 1990 isn't that diffrent from playing the Russians.Graphics are different, but nothing particularly interesting or dramatically different from Civ VI.A big disappointment

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have tried to get enjoyment out of it. But I just can't, its not fun. The AI is a mess it always wants to fight you or offer trade that is horribly in favor of the AI. Like every extra resource you have for just one gold a turn, bad. I have no idea what the AI is thinking and when they do fight you they throw all their ancient era units against your modern army. Every war I have fought has been terribly one sided. And they always end up hating you no matter what you do so why bother.The district aspect might be fun if you had any idea why. You can do things one time and not the another. So you just end up throwing down districts for amenitites. There is no explanation why things happen or don't happen. So you need to figure out the why most of the time. Even then sometimes you just can't figure out why. Like religions, what do they do. Why even bother? I really can't find a real reason to pursue one. I usually forget about religions until the my civ in flooded with tons of missionary units. It's like they are cockroaches, they just keep coming. I ask the the other civ to stop. They say sure and but they keep coming.I have tried many different rulers and set ups but it always ends up the same way. Me just steam rolling over the rest of the civs. I have stopped playing it because of the lack of enjoyment. I bought the digital pass package (which I now regret) so hopefully after a expansion it will get better. But for right now I have put this game aside.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Alright, so, I have logged over a hundred hours in the game so I feel competent to make a review. This is an amazing game with the exception of one critical failure, the civilization AI is terrible. Each Civ has built in things that they cannot abide. For example Rome does not like Civs that don't expand. If you don't capture lots of lands then Caesar is going to have a problem with you. Of course he also does not like it if you settle to close or have a strong military. Basically you are screwed either way with him. That pretty much sums up the diplomacy experience right there. Each leader has things it likes and dislikes so if you play with 6 or 7 of them you absolutely with♥♥♥♥♥♥off half of them. They will declare war on you, you will defend yourself then get slammed as a warmonger when you didn't even start the danged thing. It is pretty terrible and not much fun to play. Everything else is good in this version, but the AI is just a no go. This absolutely needs to be fixed and I honestly just do not understand what the developers were thinking. As much as I would love to recommend it this is a serious step back from Civ V and even from Beyond Earth, which in and of itself was a tad disappointing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I cannot in good faith recommend a game with 15$ of DLC after couple months, and the game being 80$. Way to overpriced, if there was a seasons pass + game and it was 50$ maybe it would be worth it, but they just can't help but gouge.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Right off, let me say that after 22 hrs of play, I am pretty much done. I really enjoy Civ V, but not Civ VI. Why? If you read some of the other DNR's many of my complaints are well spelled out.1. Comments about the "Denouncing". It does get tiresome.2. Random comments from other leaders - are they supposed to mean something? Some comments are humorous the first time they are made, but not the 6th.3. Missionaries. WAAAAY too many. Especially when they block you from moving.4. Trading. I noticed if they approach you, you make out fairly well. I never bothered to ask them, because that was one area in Civ V that I didn't like and I didn't expect it to be better.Additional Random Thoughts:Spies - there was something wrong there. I had money stolen by spies. Technology Stolen by spies. I think they sabotaged my Industrial park several times. But If I ever tried anything but listen or cultivate sources, I ALWAYS got caught, even with 74% chance of success.Barbarians - erik spelled out the issue with Barbarians pretty well in an earlier post. Here I am in the year 2030 with Barbarians popping up with Mech Infantry and AT Teams. You send in the troops and clean them out and before you depart the area, another stronghold appears with Advanced Weapons. They really need to fade away.Amenities, Housing, and Food. Most everyone else likes the Districts, but with limited space, what with all the Districts I was encouraged to build, I couldn't grow enough food to feed my population. And there was never enough Housing. Odd, I don't think the Mayor, Governor, or President is responsible for building houses. That is free market. I need more amenities, but not really sure what qualifies.Building times were too high. I tried to play this game fairly peacefully and so didn't have much of a standing army. Suddenly barbarians appear with 5 modern military units. I checked every available city and even my three biggest needed 12-17 turns to build one infantry unit. Purchase? $2400! I could have bought three and then be broke. Oh, and no planes because building the Airfield will take 50 turns.Maybe I played it wrong. I know some people really liked it, but I agree with the group that didn't. Oh, and I did play the tutorial, but there were a lot of things they did not explain.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I’m a long-time Civilization player and I have to say that this latest version is very disappointing. Extremely buggy, especially in the later game. The AI is, well, dumb and extremely annoying at times. Other civilization leaders will pop up and say things to you that make no sense whatsoever. They will denounce you for any little thing so keeping relationships good is almost impossible. The warmongering level seems to be way too aggressive. For example, war was constantly declared on me, and I became the warmonger when I started to win battles – even though I never declared war. That algorithm need serious adjusting.Combat graphics will disappear with some units and sometimes the combat will pause for a few seconds. (I have a Nvidia GeForce GTX 1080 graphics card, 32GB RAM and Intel i7 CPU so it’s not system lag.)Again, I love the franchise, but I would strongly suggest waiting until a major patch comes out and then wait for updated reviews to see if it actually fixes things that are seriously broken with the initial release.

title: Not Recommended
comment: At first I liked this game. I really wanted to like it better than previous versions of Civilization.However, after 50+ hours of game play and repeated restarts, I find that most of the improvements are in the areas of the game I never really enjoyed.I like to play a builder/diplomatic style, but the diplomacy in this version is a joke. All of the AI leaders act like petulant children. When they propose deals, you can just keep removing things from your side of it and then clicking the "What would it take to make this deal work?" button over and over until it accepts a really bad deal. Likewise, getting the AI leaders to promise to stop settling near you or stop converting your citizens lasts for all of 1 turn before they start doing it again, with no penalty available other than denouncing them or going to war.As for a builder playstyle, even on the largest map with the turn speed set to Marathon and the game level set to easy, the constant attacks by barbarians make it difficult to build out early; and if you manage to survive that (or get lucky and not have a lot of barbarians attacking you), then you end up being found by the AI --- the world always appears to be seeded with an AI civ close to you, and their scouts seem to make a beeline for you.I was hoping for a version that brings in the advisors and diplomacy from Civ III, the sea/space building capacity from Civ: Call To Power, the units/combat from Civ IV, and the city states/diplomacy/culture from Civ V. Maybe by the time they hit Civ 15...but this is probably the last version of the game I'll buy until it becomes more friendly to my playstyle again.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is by far the most annoying stupid idiotic Civ ever made. months and years of testing this game and this is your final product??? i mean cmon either these so called devs are as completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as there created AI leaders or the entire CIV staff is smoking crack.countless bugs make this game annoying from the start and it only gets worse, with the freakin AI bugging you every freakin turn letting you know what their thinking, like i give a♥♥♥♥♥♥ not to mention every single thing you do whether hostile or not makes you a bad guy and ofcoarse the AI will let you know every turn that they have denouced youcant do any decent trades without giving all you have plus 5million gold per turn, "ya sure here have 2 of my cities to for some freakin oranges".the graphics are a joke all this bulshit from the devs saying that its easy on the eyes and it will help you distinguish crap from one another well let me tell you something"everything on this damn map looks like crap so theres really nothing to distinguish from".i dont even wanna talk about the mini map completley useless...i just dont understand how ppl could in anyway give this tragedy of a game a positive vote. 4-5 hrs into this game and ull be tellin urself damn the money i just wasted 5hrs of my life. do not buy do not even try..................I say, "let CIV'S name die out with CIV5"......play warhammer

title: Not Recommended
comment: In many ways Civilization VI is a worthy and exciting successor to the franchise, but ultimately it is crippled by a few significant problems.The biggest issues I see are as follows:- The AI is poor which results in games that become predictable and boring- There are no Teams in either Multiplayer or Single player (forget playing cooperatively with your friends)- Puzzling omissions of basic quality of life features-- There is no restart button, re-rolling a start requires exiting to the menu-- There is no memory of the settings the previous game was started with, let alone a template system (this makes the first point even worse)-- There are no build queues-- There is no way to set trade route duration, or to quickly instruct a trader to repeat its last route- The naval aspect of the game is extremely underwhelmingThere are other issues, like balancing the relative importance of production, research, and so on, but I'll refrain from diving into them to state that my fundamental position is that this game is not ready to be offered at the price that is being asked. I'm a huge fan of this franchise and have high hopes for this installment, but after several disappointing patches from the development team that address virtually none of the problems I've listed, I believe players should wait awhile before making the decision to purchase Civ VI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Meh - doesn't offer much over Civ V.tl;dr Play Civ 5. At 20 hours I was pretty much bored with Civ 6.I'm a fan of Civ titles all the way back to the first Civ on my Amiga. I can't count the number of all-nighters I put in on Civ 4 and Civ 5. Civ 6 feels like it was handed to a team that wanted to go a good job but had no history with the series, and stopped working as soon as the title was "stable". I'm not sure they ever played a game to completion either, given how tedious and annoying late game is in Civ 6. If someone told me this game had 25 years of franchise gameplay refinement I would assume they were being sarcastic if I didn't know better.The Good:Builder mechanic has improved.City districts are a fun and meaningful improvement.Early-game road building by traders is an improvementEureka mechanic is an improvementTroop stacking system is an improvement (over no stacking)Great people's unique features were improvedOnly place it crashes is when exiting to desktopThe Bad:The UI: unit icons are semi-transparent on city names = can't read either. Mouse over notifications also pops up the info for tile behind the notifcation icon, blocking the notification. Nothing like the the wheel of leaders to easily and quicly see agreements between civs. Dialog with the AI's have a delay before buttons fade in and it slows down the game - though they're just invisible - they make noise when you mouse over them. New Game menu settings don't remember settings, so I have to set them every time I start a new game. Can't skip the leader intro.Later-game playability: No city production queue, no automated production, no automated builders, no automated trader route assignment or renewal, no patrol paths = an annoying late game, Despite there only being "Future Technology N" it isn't auto-researched.The AI: Others have discussed the enemy AI so I won't bother with it, other than to say the criticisms are correct. However, the friendly AI is also bad. For example: Troops on auto explore will ask what to do when encountering barbarians. You move them away from the barbarians. You turn auto-explore back on. They run straight back to the barbarians and get killed. Improving vs the enemy AI is partly learning why the suggestions offered by the friendly AI are bad.Misc:Despite being an incredibly useful early-game policy for winning games, and an integral facet of our history as a species, slavery has been removed, along with state religion. Whales and furs are supposed to be present, but I have yet to encounter them. What made these interesting in the game were changes to their value with the development of more modern technologies and civics.Many resources add variety but are not useful or unique. Might as well call them "Amenity"The religious unit combat is an interesting idea but seems half-baked in the game.Can't attack, capture, or kill great people. Want to dominate the seas? Use great admirals to blockade enemy cities. The city can't launch any ships nor can they attack your blockade. Your battleship will be completely held at-bay by a great admiral commanding a caravel navy.Antiquity sites can no longer be turned into tourist attactions. I thought that was quite fun.Barbarians: so much lost opportunity. They're pretty much the same as all previous Civs.

title: Recommended
comment: If you liked civ V you will probably like this too. It has almost every good element from civ V some new cool features. It's a game i can recommend for every civ and strategy fan.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is a giant meh. Civ IV is my favorite out of the most recent releases, if you're a civ fan this game is a better buy on a good deal, I regret paying full price.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Disapointing, slow, and boring. Sad.

title: Recommended
comment: Having played many 1000's of hours of Civ V, I was extremely happy to pay for the pre-load and even gift a couple of copies to my friends.I love the Civilization franchise and have been playing for years, and this installment has brought many new and interesting mechanics to play with for which I am impressed.The GoodI love the new districts feature. In Civ V a new city could start rolling every building possible until you had everything in one city. This is unrealistic and Civ VI makes you think hard about which buildings a new city would benefit from most and makes it possible to have certain cities specialize in different things i.e production, gold or science.The new city states mechanic is awesome, you are now able to send envoys to them which are gained over time, the more envoys, the bigger the bonus. This is also how you take CS from other Civs saving you the gold to use more usefully elsewhere.The new Civics tree is cool, your Civ is now a custom built machine thanks to the government options. This is great but could use some improvements. I would like to be able to advance in a certain area similar to Civ V, but at this stage the process is similar to the Tech tree so you will have to research a lot of meaningless diplomatic options to get to your desired government.The ability to stack troops into corps(2 sets) and armies (3 sets) is so useful when attacking the enemy, it is no longer necessary to completely surround a city with troops to successfully capture it. This is a throwback to one of my favourite Civ games Civ Rev and is a very welcome addition to the game.I love that Wonders now take up space outside of your city, preventing a player from mass producing every Wonder in the game is a good thing for me. I especially like the placement requirements, which can cause you a dilemma when the wonder you want, can only be placed on that luxury resource, the ensuing toss up in the mind has made the Wonders aspect of the game a lot more fun. I also love the new Wonder animations when complete, so beautiful.A good thing about the AI is that they seem to know when defeat is looming, and they will try everything in their power to broker a peace agreement.More to follow in next edit.................One thing I would like the makers to improve on is the AI. During my last attempt, France (at peace with) mass produced Apostles to invade my lands. Normally I wouldn't mind and would relish the challenge of fending them off to save my own religion.However in this instance there was so many of them I could not navigate my own units through my own land! This caused me to lose battles elsewhere on the map against another Civ. Which as you can imagine was super annoying.Furthermore having asked France to refrain from converting my cities, which they agreed to, the promise was broken the very next turn. The diplomacy screen did not give me any means to justice, no Casus belli for the broken promise nor the opportunity to denounce!The AI are crazy! It seems impossible to keep good relations with them. I had a moment where America offered me a Joint War Declaration against France. I agreed. Two turns later they denounced me as a Warmonger. I could not believe it, my best efforts to keep good relations squandered by the insanity of this AI.Another improvement should be the UI. It's too hard to acess information such as yeilds and troop lists and in my opinion makes the game much harder than Civ V.Having turned off the Religious Victory, the game has much the same feel as Civ V + DLCs with all the new mechanics added, it's my opinion that this is where the game needs improving to make this game perfect.More on the UI front, the city targeting button is way too small and is especially hard to click when a unit is garrisoned in the city. Also there is no notification as to when a city can target an enemy, you have to be extra vigilant.I love the new City States mechanics, however they CS themselves seem to have problem conducting warfare. For example if I have one as my ally, and we both go to war with another Civ, all of the troops amassed by the CS do not seem to try to even engage the enemy Civ, unless that Civ unwittingly sends a troop very close to them. There is an option to levy 'rent' the CS army for your own use, but I'd like to see the CS actually help and engage in war by themselves.More to follow in next edit.................Aside from the problems mentioned I find Civ VI a very enjoyable game, much better than vanilla Civ V, however there are some problems which need to be fixed, and as with Civ V, I'm sure a patch or two can solve these issues.As I have said I love this game and I love the Civilization franchise, so a huge thank you to the makers from me, but please, please fix these problems!

title: Recommended
comment: First Impressions:I was trying not to be so hyped for this game as I thought it may just be a remodel for Civilisation V...I was wrong.Good/Better Qualities of Civilisation VI:Districts are a new addition to the game which creates a more interesting and strategic approach to how you manage and develop your city. It feels that you can specialise each city you own to be more of a scientific or production city, for example. However, unlike Civ V you now do not stack buildings up in the city, you actually have to use a tile to create a district and from there you can build your separate buildings within the district. This also makes the game a little more difficult and you have to be careful of city placements to make sure you get the right bonuses, or have enough space for farms as well as the various districts.All the additions from Civ V main expansions are available in the base game of Civ VI, this makes the game seem more fleshed out and enjoyable from the beginning.New art style is quite weird to get used to, but it grows on you after a while, do not get fooled by the cartoon-ish look, the actual game, units and buildings look so much better than the previous games.The separate research for Science and Culture adds a new layer of replayability for the game. In Civ V I noticed how if you wanted to go for a cultural victory you would still have to put some work into science as well to get the right technologies, now with Civics it makes it easier to go straight to Culture from the start.Linking to the art style and districts, I really like how I can now see the buildings and wonders properly in and around my cities. This is only a small bit but I really enjoy watching my buildings being built in my districts and it actually feels like my civilisation is growing... I was getting rather tired of seeing my Oracle or stadiums being built in the sea...UI is simplistic. I have seen some reviews that are complaining that they cannolt find anything in the new UI after only playing the game a few hours. Yes it's hard to find to start with because it's so different from Civ V, but after a while I got used to where all the actions were and how to access my city.Bad/Worse Points:AI still seems a bit stupid on lower difficulties. The first Civ VI game I played I put it on a lower difficulty just to get used to the new techs and way the happiness is now local. And my God the AI were dumb, the agendas made them all hate me as soon as I found them and then even when I was a few eras ahead in technology they would still try to fight me with their horsemen vs my infantry. Maybe this is just how easy AI are supposed to work, or maybe it's a problem. I do not know.There are some glitches with the UI, the notifications that pop up on the side can bug out and won't show the message unless you wiggle the mouse around a bit. This should be patched if the developers notice it.This next point isn't really /bad/ it's just going to take a while to get used to. The local happiness (Amenities) and housing were a nice idea and is more accurate to real life. However I felt like I just jumped into a Sim City game where everyone had their own needs and moaning at me all the time. I guess it's more historically accurate but it makes the game less enjoyable.OVERALL:I've been loving this game so far, a new experience for people coming back to the series. Although there may be some balancing issues right now I am sure they will be ironed out soon.I'll give the game a 9/10 for now, may increase or decrease as updates or expansions release.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Well. Annoying. Don't like the building... fewer options in advanced setup. No mods. And more cartoony. No option for no espionage. Overall seems like a step down from Civ 5.

title: Recommended
comment: SECOND IMPRESSIONSWhile I still recommend this game and think it can be a worthy successor to Civ 5, a couple more games have made the AI problems very apparent. It is nearly impossible to get a fair deal, unless through weird jank you glitch into one. It just isn't fun to have Civs pester you with ludicrious demands like 4 luxury resources for a few pennies, turn after turn after turn.The AI declares war at the drop of a hat, even if it has no way or winning, or even reaching you. Often the AI will declare war on me for attacking the enemy they are at war with.OH. RIGHT. AND. LETS. NOT. FORGET. THE. END. GAME. CHUG. This makes multiplayer a slog, as turns take forever, and thats not counting the desync issues I have been having.I will still recommend the game, because everything wrong with it is basic coding, and the core mechanics of the game are solid. With a few patches a lot of the AI and minor bugs can be sorted out. Still, I am a little less enthusiastic about the game as I was originally.ORIGINAL REVIEWAfter the bare-bones release of Beyond Earth, Firaxis was wise to give us a Civ game that carries over almost all of the content from the previous games and its major expansions. Religion, archeology, espionage, most of it is here intact. In addition, the changes to the game have added new and interesting rinkles to the gameplay. Breakout districts for industry, commerce, happiness etc. means that you will need to plan quite a bit in advance.Overall I enjoyed my time with it so far a great deal. There are still some problems I have with it (see below) but I think this game is well worth your time. If you thought Civ V was perfect however, you might not be as blown away, so keep that in mind when making your decision. It is after all, still more of the same with slight changes or additions.PROs:+ Runs really well. No more pop-in when scrolling across the map, and frame rate remains solid even late game.+ Social policies have been broken out into their own tech tree, and you get to choose a government which allows different policies and bonus earlier in the game.+ As noted above, districts add a new layer to the game, as you will have to plan ahead to account for adjacency bonusses and space considerations for new, large improvements such as the National Park.+ Transparent diplomacy. See exactly why a Civ hates or likes you.+ Many other small changes to features such as city states, great persons etc. which increase the level of strategic decisions you can make.CONs:- There's no global government, (the UN is one of the few features that didn't make the cut), and the end-game once again can devolve into a slog when you are miles ahead but have no choice but to click "next turn" for another 3 hours before actually winning.- AI is a bit buggy. Civs might change deals randomly, often suddenly accepting horrible offers for no reason, or refusing to end a war when they are beyond defeated.- Cannot rename Civs or cities.- Suffers from (in my opinion) trade route bloat, where half your decisions in the game seem to be just reassigning trade routes.Other points.・ While promised multiple leaders per civ, it seems it is only limited to a single civ at this time. There might be more later, but when I heard about this, I thought it would be more of a core feature.・ Wonders have been rebalanced to not be as powerful as before (a good change in my opinion). They are harder to build and take up precious space for districts.・ I have encountered a single crash at around turn 360. Not sure how common this will be, so I'll keep an eye out for this.In conclusion, while not perfect, the changes are actually significant enough that it does feel like a new game while still preserving much of the core of Civ V.

title: Recommended
comment: Sid Meier’s Civilization VI, released Oct. 21, is a polished game that will have veteran Civ players and new fans of turn-based strategy telling themselves “Just one more turn” until their alarm clocks go off the next morning.Civ 6 is the latest in the series, which started with the first game’s release in 1991. Its success spawned the entire genre of video games known as 4X: explore, expand, exploit and exterminate.In each of the Civilization games, you take over a civilization and must lead your people to victory. Just as with the previous installment, Civilization 5, players can win through science, military might, the power of their culture or simply by having the highest score by 2050. Civ 6 does not keep the diplomatic victory option that was present in Civ 5. Instead, it introduces a religious victory, which requires players to make their religion dominant within every other surviving civilization.Players start off in 4000 BCE with one settler, which they can use to build a city, and one military unit, which they can use to explore the world or defend their city. Each leader and civilization has a unique ability and unique units based on that civilization’s real-world history, and the game attempts to place civilizations on the map on terrain resembling where they ruled. For instance, someone playing as Egypt is likely to find their first settler in a desert near a flood plain, while someone playing as Russia would probably find their civilization starting out in tundra.Players will spend most of their time in the game looking at the map, so the developers rendered it beautifully. Unexplored areas have a “Here there be dragons” feel to them, while areas that are explored but not visible are rendered in sepia tones. Visible areas are colored with a light, aesthetically pleasing format.After a civilization sets up its first city, it will begin to research both science and civics. Science provides technological improvements, allowing players to trade warriors for swordsmen, while civics allow a civilization to adopt more flexible and powerful forms of government. The Civics concept is new to Civ 6 and introduces a lot of ways for players to fine-tune their civilization’s growth and development through dragging and dropping “cards” into economic, military, diplomacy and wild-card slots.As cities grow, players will have to determine how to use the land surrounding a city. Civ 6’s cities expand using districts that occupy the spaces around the city center. Other turn-based strategy games, such as Endless Legend by Amplitude Studios, have played with this concept before. However, it feels more polished in Civ 6, which gives players bonuses to a cities output if they’re smart about where they build their cities and districts.Players will interact with computer-controlled civilizations through the course of the game, each of which with its own agenda: Cleopatra, for example, likes civilizations with strong militaries and dislikes civilizations with weak ones. The leaders are individually animated, and they speak in their civilizations’ language. The artwork and animation style are inviting and make you actually want to interact with them.When you’re not talking with other leaders, you’ll pick up on the music and other ambience. Geoff Knorr is the principal composer for the game music, with Christopher Tin writing the game’s main theme. The ambient music changes as you progress through historical genres and was mostly pleasing, though the Renaissance-era portions felt a bit repetitive.Sean Bean — yes, that Sean Bean — narrates the game’s introductory video — and yes, the character he’s voicing dies in the video. Bean also narrates quotes related to technologies you discover and the intro text for each civilization.While the game’s artificial intelligence is generally smart, it has its weak moments, particularly involving late-game trading. In my playthrough as Sumeria, I declared war against Gandhi. I clearly held the upper hand, but as I conquered more of his cities, his peace deals became more cringeworthy. Civilizations should realize when unconditional surrender is the only option left to them, but in Civ 6, they don’t seem to have this self-preservation instinct.Civ 6 also appears to be prone to lagging or crashing in the later stages, but these bugs are infrequent, and the game’s autosave feature keeps frustration from this at a relative minimum.The greatest value in Civ 6 comes from its replayability. The graphics, music and gameplay will make fans of almost anyone, and with 21 civilizations and limitless randomly generated maps, players will keep coming back for hundreds of hours.

title: Not Recommended
comment: On the positive side, it is Civ and when people aren't trying to murder you it is pretty fun.On the negative side - the AI is horrible, The CPU loves a good war, and if you do anything other than fend off waves of troops you will be branded a warmonger. There are pages and pages of this on the forums. It is a shame, because it really ruins an enjoyable game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So my first review,As someone who grew up with Civ 1 i'd love to be telling you how this is an improvement more fun and better, but it quite simply isnt. It looks nicer, i'll grant them that.An intricate part of Civ is how you interact with other civilizations, now to be able to that you would have to have a diplomacy system that makes sense, which it doesnt.To give you an example; the mere trading of a luxury resource for another with another civ is nigh impossible.You set it up in the deal screen, they disagree, you ask them what would make it work? Well how about half or all your money you make for 30 turns some cash on the side and the thing you want to trade for my one thing.This happens to declared friendship civ's, civ's that denounced me civ's ive never done anything too. They cannot be arsed.So there's no reasonable trade, (you can get them to trade 1 luxury resource for your 2 for example but screw that im still beeing cheated.)Warmongering: the bright lights at Civ have adressed this (so they claim)So i don't like war, i like to outshine other civ's in awesomeness, sadly some civ's dont like that so they declare war with you, which is fine.However when i then stomp their armies and or towns forcing them to obliteration other civ's hate me for it.If i let them live they will just come again.So you have a choice to either kill them totally and be done with them, which results in their friends and even enemies hating you and declaring war more often than not.Or rinse and repeat the tedious process of showing a civ it's place beneath you every so many years.The ai decision making skills are just outright bad.One last thing; The absolute nonsensical idiot that made the reset to default button in the create game section, it came after one of the first big patches and the thought made me happy.The execution of it however just makes me want to shoot you in your hands.You know how it is you set up a game as russia for example with island plates and the dumbass game just keeps setting you at the map border just because there is loads of tundra an you are left with a region you can build 2 towns on at best, with crappy ground yields etc. so restart time.So i thought wow! now i can just restart the game without having to set all the parameters again which is a tedious part of the game? No,Hell no.This button was made for people who are adjusting their game setup there an then who see what they are doing yet forget what they click , thats the only purpose of that button, an idiot aid for people that do not know what they are clicking an then want to restore what they clicked a minute before. Because leave the setup screen an come back an all your parameters are back to default, which pretty much renders the button useless in the first place.You like Civ? This Civ delivers you some 60 euro eyecandy while playing just dont get your hopes up if you expect a better game, it's worse.
