Hope all these companies go bankrupt soon so the companies that actually give Gameplay worth the money.Worst thing is the fact that mods add Civ's for free while they dare ask 5 euros for it.

title: Recommended
comment: As an empire-building game, Civ 6 performs very well. There are complex interactions, strategic trade-offs, and thematic differences in how you can play the game. The number of ways to play a game lends to an extremely high replay value.There is plenty of criticism towards the AI elements of the game. Some of this criticism is warranted, but by no means does it make the game "unfun" or "broken". As a very proficient Civ 5 player, I feel as though this iteration of the AI is more... advantaged than before. The inherent bonuses the Ai is given is far more useful than it should be at higher difficulty settings. There is almost no way to keep up. One could imagine that if the game developers focused more on balance than producing paid dlc content, that this would be a phenomenal game.It's not necessary to buy any of the dlc packs. The game is complete as a stand-alone item. That said, should you wish to expand upon the game, the modding community is very active and quite a few new features can be added through freely available mods. Several balance fixes and UI improvements can also be found in mods.Overall, the game does have some issues, but in general is very entertaining and can be played for hours on end. Would recommend for both casual and competitive players.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game was absolute garbage on release. So many things were overlooked and so many bugs. Even still it feels unfinished. It's as if they came out with the full game and then split it up as to be released in installments. As opposed to coming out with a complete game and then releasing expansions. I'm also sick of the nickle and dime DLC nonesense. In the very least put the DLC on sale. It pains me to give this a bad review beacuse I've been playing since the original Civ. It just doesn't feel like the developers really care about putting out a good product, they just care about making as much money as possible.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am a big fan of Civilization V where the different civilizations and winning options are more balanced. In this game: The barbarians and some of the civilizations makes it impossible to win other victories than domination in this game. You spend so many turns in every city building only militairy units defending yourself that nothing else gets built. If you do get the chance to build anything else you first have to build districts that takes sooooo many turns to build. Sounds fun on paper to have districts but you also have to sacrifice one square to build them and don´t expect to be able to build them all because of game restrictions and lack of city area. I feel the same about building wonders (which are not very useful at all). If you do get ahead in some of the other areas then get prepared to get attacked by rediculously many units by the AI. Then you also have to keep spending turns on building builders to repair everything. And be prepared to have to build lots of them becase they only last for 3 uses (or playing as China, 4 turns) Then fun of the game being diverse is gone.I think the game have some really good ideas in form of the eurekas, a tech tree and a civics tree, special people but the game is not fun to play unless you only go for domination victory every game you play due to the imbalances.

title: Recommended
comment: Graphics sucks, as expected (leaders look great from a technical point of view but so sad the art direction put it to waste), few issues here and there that will likely be patched at some point, mostly minor UI stuff (like missing buttons to quickly scroll between cities) but rest of game makes up for it so far !If you're a huge fan go for it its fun, if you're an enthousiast wait a couple month for patches and mods to iron things out a bit.Will update with more detail after reaching end game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: game isnt worth it, just get civ 5

title: Not Recommended
comment: It only takes 15 min to experience the core game mechanics.......Super predictable. I hope one day the developers concentrate more on the actual game then some DLC business plan #Dare to dream

title: Not Recommended
comment: I was really looking forward to this game after all the enjoyment I got out of Civ V, but, unfortunately, Civ 6 just constantly tests my patience.There were some good design decisions brought in with Civ 6, but the AI seems to have really suffered for it. I'm not even talking about the constant, random denouncements or joint wars either. I mean the AI, literally, cannot use ships or planes. The AI is also pretty bad at district placement which means most AI cities won't even be worth capturing. But, of course, you have to because of the massive warmonger penalties to razing cities.The final straw for me though was discovering a bug when retaking a captured city that can cause the "cede city" option to just not appear on the trade screen. This means said city is just under perma-occupation and basically worthless. I've never really enjoyed combat in Civ 6, but a bug that's been in the game for months which makes defending yourself/retaking territory pointless just adds to the frustration of it all.Civ 6 is still a mess in its current state. It's hard to say if one expansion can fix it, but I certainly hope so.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is a very good edition to the Civilization series.I enjoy the AI and how they are much smarter (even the barbarians). However, they are really annoying. Within the first 10 turns the Aztecs declared war on me as I had another luxury that he did not. As this happened, the other civs that he befriended within those 10 turns also instantly declared war on me. As this happened the next 2 turns were equally as worse. I had met 3 other civs (playing on Continents) of whom instantly denounced me. They are really hard to befriend. Even after 300 turns of one game.I do miss the feature that you can't rename cities or religions (or I just can't read). But you can rename units and put them into "Corps" or "Armies" which is very useful (basically a hybrid army that consists of 2 or 3 of the same unit).This game is amazing. I would recommend buying it, only if you are willing to do some research, learn the game and play much more aggresively than you normally would in any other Civ game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The more I play the more boring it occurs at its current state.1) Diplomacy sucks2) AI sucks3) Tech trees really suck4) UI more like No Eye5) Sim City Spam isnt Civilization6) No sense of progression through the ages (Lack of boosts to Culture or Science)7) Government system works but looks like crap8) All foot units (even spearmen) < Calvary spam9) Cities develop super slow10) Cinematic Screens more like Sinematic Screams for fixin11) Some Civs have some super op abilities (Rawr Carts, Ramlukes)12) Anything I didn't mention i think they did well or atleast hasn't annoyed me yet

title: Not Recommended
comment: I tried really hard to like this game, the graphics and sondtrack are so good I wanted so bad to enjoy it, but I didn't. It made me mad, really mad, repeatedly.If you found the religion aspect of Civ 5 to be a little obnoxious or inconvenient, well the made it 100x worse in Civ 6. Prepare yourself for a never ending flood (and I mean FLOOD) of Apostles and Missionaries converting your cities regardless of whether or not you have Inquisitors stationed there (oh yeah, it's a blast), also, they can attack and kill your religious units that aren't stationed in city. It's a real hoot.As for city building, you'll be constantly fighting to build enough amenities and housing capacity to accomodate your growing population. You will forever be just slightly ahead of the growth, and if you fall behind get ready for zero growth and unhappy citizens that could revolt at any moment. Again, a real hoot.Districts: barely worth the time investment until about the industrial age, at which point they finally get the upgrades you've been waiting centuries for.Wonders: The best thing about them is their cinematic construction. Other than that, only a couple are worth more than the tile you must give up in order to build it. Sid must have been unhappy with the wonder hoarding possible in Civ 5 and made d*mn sure it didn't happen again.TL;DR: Unneccessary micromanaging and infuriating religious unit spamming kept me in a constant state of very freaking♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I finally reached the modern era as Victoria, my redcoats marched along with tanks against enemies still fielding catapults. If you can get a few friends to play, I say go for it. However, playing against the AI is incredibly dull and schizophrenic. I can honestly say I did not enjoy the time I played.The new diplomacy features do very little in a practical sense, of all the games I’ve played they hate me within a few turns no matter what I do. And the few AI I befriend will launch a surprise war with no obvious provocation. So, I just fight everyone forever because there doesn’t seem to be any other way.I expect there will be some massive patches or DLC that will tune the AI, so hopefully we won’t have long to wait.-Post Patch-The AI still acts surprisingly dull. My most recent game, within 10-15 turns of meeting a civ, they denounced and promptly declared war upon me. They then proceeded to do nothing for the rest of the game. I gave up when I found that all the AI seemed confused with the idea of a naval invasion, their entire army sat off their coast while my ships tore through them.As the player population has dropped 2/3 to practically the level of Civ5, I think in general the community has given up for the near future. Maybe after a few years of play testing they can sort out their AI logic. Until then, don't bother. I regret this purchase almost as much as No Mans Sky.

title: Recommended
comment: I've started playing with CIV 4, so I'm not obssessed with the "classic" civ nor do I have unsurmountable nostalgia about how the previous games worked. That said, I've played Civ 4-5 to the point of cazy and I do love macromanaging and the turn based system. I will be recommanding Civ 6, but only because there is no "neutral" review. This is the context for this review.Graphics: (intro prettier then for Civ 5, but less inspirering for me)I don't mind the cartoony graphics, it could of been worst and they are well made. They also make it easier to spot the ressources and do make the game more appealing as far as buildings/districts go, if not "realistic".Gameplay: (Good game, but missing something...)So far I have yet to get the heart of the mecanics of this one. I love macromanaging, but this is a bit much as far as details go. The base fonctions are similar to Civ 5, but they changed a bit how they work and I still haven't wraped my head around those changes. Luckily, the menus are familiar, somewhat easy to navigate and provide lots of information. They've also made the game more challenging by limiting the use of builders/workers and pushing the importance of fresh water and surrounding hexes on districts and improvements.Old players might feel, like I do, that there is something missing...Some depth or whatever and so I recommand this game more for new player, with reserve, and eagerly await some miracle update that will make me go: "Aaah, ok! Thats more like it!".Fixings:-Make the Civclopedia available in the starting menu, not just in game.-Make the map we end up with editable in game, like in Civ 4...REALLY missed that in Civ 5.-More map types (like Earth, editable in game).-The ability to make one's own leader (customization, looks and all). I love the historic leaders, but what if I want to be game at least?

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization 6 is just... great. Tons of new mechanics and concepts, and all of them seems to be successful. No lags, good performance, no crushes. Thanks Firaxis! Hope that some issues with UI will be fixed soon ( more information in tooltops, better font size).

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game is decent so far but 6 months from release and still incomplete. The World-builder which is part of the SDK is still "hidden" and incomplete. The SDK was released only a short time ago but is incomplete. 6 months. Don't waste your money. Wait until the game is completed.UPDATE: STILL A WASTE OF MONEY ON A BROKEN GAME. READ BELOWThis game is almost a year old and instead of fix some of the worst bugs (in the AI) and fix the one tool that many people have requested (The World Builder) they just managed to break the game even more. I didn't think it was possible.Lesson learned. I will not be buying Civ 7 until at least a year after its release.

title: Recommended
comment: First Impressions:I was trying not to be so hyped for this game as I thought it may just be a remodel for Civilisation V...I was wrong.Good/Better Qualities of Civilisation VI:Districts are a new addition to the game which creates a more interesting and strategic approach to how you manage and develop your city. It feels that you can specialise each city you own to be more of a scientific or production city, for example. However, unlike Civ V you now do not stack buildings up in the city, you actually have to use a tile to create a district and from there you can build your separate buildings within the district. This also makes the game a little more difficult and you have to be careful of city placements to make sure you get the right bonuses, or have enough space for farms as well as the various districts.All the additions from Civ V main expansions are available in the base game of Civ VI, this makes the game seem more fleshed out and enjoyable from the beginning.New art style is quite weird to get used to, but it grows on you after a while, do not get fooled by the cartoon-ish look, the actual game, units and buildings look so much better than the previous games.The separate research for Science and Culture adds a new layer of replayability for the game. In Civ V I noticed how if you wanted to go for a cultural victory you would still have to put some work into science as well to get the right technologies, now with Civics it makes it easier to go straight to Culture from the start.Linking to the art style and districts, I really like how I can now see the buildings and wonders properly in and around my cities. This is only a small bit but I really enjoy watching my buildings being built in my districts and it actually feels like my civilisation is growing... I was getting rather tired of seeing my Oracle or stadiums being built in the sea...UI is simplistic. I have seen some reviews that are complaining that they cannolt find anything in the new UI after only playing the game a few hours. Yes it's hard to find to start with because it's so different from Civ V, but after a while I got used to where all the actions were and how to access my city.Bad/Worse Points:AI still seems a bit stupid on lower difficulties. The first Civ VI game I played I put it on a lower difficulty just to get used to the new techs and way the happiness is now local. And my God the AI were dumb, the agendas made them all hate me as soon as I found them and then even when I was a few eras ahead in technology they would still try to fight me with their horsemen vs my infantry. Maybe this is just how easy AI are supposed to work, or maybe it's a problem. I do not know.There are some glitches with the UI, the notifications that pop up on the side can bug out and won't show the message unless you wiggle the mouse around a bit. This should be patched if the developers notice it.This next point isn't really /bad/ it's just going to take a while to get used to. The local happiness (Amenities) and housing were a nice idea and is more accurate to real life. However I felt like I just jumped into a Sim City game where everyone had their own needs and moaning at me all the time. I guess it's more historically accurate but it makes the game less enjoyable.OVERALL:I've been loving this game so far, a new experience for people coming back to the series. Although there may be some balancing issues right now I am sure they will be ironed out soon.I'll give the game a 9/10 for now, may increase or decrease as updates or expansions release.

title: Recommended
comment: SECOND IMPRESSIONSWhile I still recommend this game and think it can be a worthy successor to Civ 5, a couple more games have made the AI problems very apparent. It is nearly impossible to get a fair deal, unless through weird jank you glitch into one. It just isn't fun to have Civs pester you with ludicrious demands like 4 luxury resources for a few pennies, turn after turn after turn.The AI declares war at the drop of a hat, even if it has no way or winning, or even reaching you. Often the AI will declare war on me for attacking the enemy they are at war with.OH. RIGHT. AND. LETS. NOT. FORGET. THE. END. GAME. CHUG. This makes multiplayer a slog, as turns take forever, and thats not counting the desync issues I have been having.I will still recommend the game, because everything wrong with it is basic coding, and the core mechanics of the game are solid. With a few patches a lot of the AI and minor bugs can be sorted out. Still, I am a little less enthusiastic about the game as I was originally.ORIGINAL REVIEWAfter the bare-bones release of Beyond Earth, Firaxis was wise to give us a Civ game that carries over almost all of the content from the previous games and its major expansions. Religion, archeology, espionage, most of it is here intact. In addition, the changes to the game have added new and interesting rinkles to the gameplay. Breakout districts for industry, commerce, happiness etc. means that you will need to plan quite a bit in advance.Overall I enjoyed my time with it so far a great deal. There are still some problems I have with it (see below) but I think this game is well worth your time. If you thought Civ V was perfect however, you might not be as blown away, so keep that in mind when making your decision. It is after all, still more of the same with slight changes or additions.PROs:+ Runs really well. No more pop-in when scrolling across the map, and frame rate remains solid even late game.+ Social policies have been broken out into their own tech tree, and you get to choose a government which allows different policies and bonus earlier in the game.+ As noted above, districts add a new layer to the game, as you will have to plan ahead to account for adjacency bonusses and space considerations for new, large improvements such as the National Park.+ Transparent diplomacy. See exactly why a Civ hates or likes you.+ Many other small changes to features such as city states, great persons etc. which increase the level of strategic decisions you can make.CONs:- There's no global government, (the UN is one of the few features that didn't make the cut), and the end-game once again can devolve into a slog when you are miles ahead but have no choice but to click "next turn" for another 3 hours before actually winning.- AI is a bit buggy. Civs might change deals randomly, often suddenly accepting horrible offers for no reason, or refusing to end a war when they are beyond defeated.- Cannot rename Civs or cities.- Suffers from (in my opinion) trade route bloat, where half your decisions in the game seem to be just reassigning trade routes.Other points.・ While promised multiple leaders per civ, it seems it is only limited to a single civ at this time. There might be more later, but when I heard about this, I thought it would be more of a core feature.・ Wonders have been rebalanced to not be as powerful as before (a good change in my opinion). They are harder to build and take up precious space for districts.・ I have encountered a single crash at around turn 360. Not sure how common this will be, so I'll keep an eye out for this.In conclusion, while not perfect, the changes are actually significant enough that it does feel like a new game while still preserving much of the core of Civ V.

title: Recommended
comment: Sid Meier’s Civilization VI, released Oct. 21, is a polished game that will have veteran Civ players and new fans of turn-based strategy telling themselves “Just one more turn” until their alarm clocks go off the next morning.Civ 6 is the latest in the series, which started with the first game’s release in 1991. Its success spawned the entire genre of video games known as 4X: explore, expand, exploit and exterminate.In each of the Civilization games, you take over a civilization and must lead your people to victory. Just as with the previous installment, Civilization 5, players can win through science, military might, the power of their culture or simply by having the highest score by 2050. Civ 6 does not keep the diplomatic victory option that was present in Civ 5. Instead, it introduces a religious victory, which requires players to make their religion dominant within every other surviving civilization.Players start off in 4000 BCE with one settler, which they can use to build a city, and one military unit, which they can use to explore the world or defend their city. Each leader and civilization has a unique ability and unique units based on that civilization’s real-world history, and the game attempts to place civilizations on the map on terrain resembling where they ruled. For instance, someone playing as Egypt is likely to find their first settler in a desert near a flood plain, while someone playing as Russia would probably find their civilization starting out in tundra.Players will spend most of their time in the game looking at the map, so the developers rendered it beautifully. Unexplored areas have a “Here there be dragons” feel to them, while areas that are explored but not visible are rendered in sepia tones. Visible areas are colored with a light, aesthetically pleasing format.After a civilization sets up its first city, it will begin to research both science and civics. Science provides technological improvements, allowing players to trade warriors for swordsmen, while civics allow a civilization to adopt more flexible and powerful forms of government. The Civics concept is new to Civ 6 and introduces a lot of ways for players to fine-tune their civilization’s growth and development through dragging and dropping “cards” into economic, military, diplomacy and wild-card slots.As cities grow, players will have to determine how to use the land surrounding a city. Civ 6’s cities expand using districts that occupy the spaces around the city center. Other turn-based strategy games, such as Endless Legend by Amplitude Studios, have played with this concept before. However, it feels more polished in Civ 6, which gives players bonuses to a cities output if they’re smart about where they build their cities and districts.Players will interact with computer-controlled civilizations through the course of the game, each of which with its own agenda: Cleopatra, for example, likes civilizations with strong militaries and dislikes civilizations with weak ones. The leaders are individually animated, and they speak in their civilizations’ language. The artwork and animation style are inviting and make you actually want to interact with them.When you’re not talking with other leaders, you’ll pick up on the music and other ambience. Geoff Knorr is the principal composer for the game music, with Christopher Tin writing the game’s main theme. The ambient music changes as you progress through historical genres and was mostly pleasing, though the Renaissance-era portions felt a bit repetitive.Sean Bean — yes, that Sean Bean — narrates the game’s introductory video — and yes, the character he’s voicing dies in the video. Bean also narrates quotes related to technologies you discover and the intro text for each civilization.While the game’s artificial intelligence is generally smart, it has its weak moments, particularly involving late-game trading. In my playthrough as Sumeria, I declared war against Gandhi. I clearly held the upper hand, but as I conquered more of his cities, his peace deals became more cringeworthy. Civilizations should realize when unconditional surrender is the only option left to them, but in Civ 6, they don’t seem to have this self-preservation instinct.Civ 6 also appears to be prone to lagging or crashing in the later stages, but these bugs are infrequent, and the game’s autosave feature keeps frustration from this at a relative minimum.The greatest value in Civ 6 comes from its replayability. The graphics, music and gameplay will make fans of almost anyone, and with 21 civilizations and limitless randomly generated maps, players will keep coming back for hundreds of hours.

title: Recommended
comment: Graphics sucks, as expected (leaders look great from a technical point of view but so sad the art direction put it to waste), few issues here and there that will likely be patched at some point, mostly minor UI stuff (like missing buttons to quickly scroll between cities) but rest of game makes up for it so far !If you're a huge fan go for it its fun, if you're an enthousiast wait a couple month for patches and mods to iron things out a bit.Will update with more detail after reaching end game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It could have been great, but it's not. Building district's and their associated buildings take way too long, leading to the game stagnating after the Classical Era. Also, turns take too long. My build is 32GB ram, a 1080 Ti, Intel 4790k CPU, and 500GB Samsung EVO SSD, which should be overkill for this game, yet it still bogs down mid-game and takes forever for AI turns to process. The religion concept is very annoying, other Civs tend to send flocks of prophets/missionaries that you can't even kill unless you have more missionaries (which IMO is a boring way to play). This leads to me declaring war on the first rival Civ to send over their religious horde. Overall it's clunky and not very polished. The latest update has led to the game crashing on me 10 minutes after starting a new game. I'm still holding out hope an expansion will come out and fix these flaws. It's still Civ so I'll play it, but playing Civ IV or V is much more enjoyable. Would recommend waiting for expansion before purchasing, but I'm not giving up hope.

title: Not Recommended
comment: AVOID!It pains me to type this review because I love the series and see 'some' great things in this game (the combining of units for example). I wanted to love this game so much. That being said I can not recommend it in its current state. The AI is embarrassingly bad. I don't even know where to begin. So bad. Which pretty much ruins the game. What else do you do in this game besides interact with the other Civs? The warmongering mechanic is disjointed and confusing to say the least. I can't even tell what they were trying to do with it. A rival civ attacks you defend yourself and now every other Civ denounces you as a war monger - WTF? Did they play test this at all? The game is plagued by balance and optimization issues. Sadly not uncommon these days but still a black eye that should make anyone balk at a $60 price tag. The game should never have been released in this shape. Until these issues are addressed I can't even recommend it on sale. Play CIV 5 instead. It's a better game at a fraction of the cost.I have 297 hours in CIV 5 and have been playing the series since the original. I look forward to a day that I can update this to a positive review but for now DO NOT BUY!!!

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'll be blunt, CIV 5 is superior in every way, this is step backwards imo the menu's are clunky, the civs are unbalenced and the gameplay in general is lack luster. I would recommend modding CIV 5 instead of buying CIV 6.

title: Recommended
comment: Took almost all the good ideas from Civ V (which was fantastic), and added a better government and city building system. Hopefully the world congress comes back in an expansion.

title: Recommended
comment: First Impressions:I was trying not to be so hyped for this game as I thought it may just be a remodel for Civilisation V...I was wrong.Good/Better Qualities of Civilisation VI:Districts are a new addition to the game which creates a more interesting and strategic approach to how you manage and develop your city. It feels that you can specialise each city you own to be more of a scientific or production city, for example. However, unlike Civ V you now do not stack buildings up in the city, you actually have to use a tile to create a district and from there you can build your separate buildings within the district. This also makes the game a little more difficult and you have to be careful of city placements to make sure you get the right bonuses, or have enough space for farms as well as the various districts.All the additions from Civ V main expansions are available in the base game of Civ VI, this makes the game seem more fleshed out and enjoyable from the beginning.New art style is quite weird to get used to, but it grows on you after a while, do not get fooled by the cartoon-ish look, the actual game, units and buildings look so much better than the previous games.The separate research for Science and Culture adds a new layer of replayability for the game. In Civ V I noticed how if you wanted to go for a cultural victory you would still have to put some work into science as well to get the right technologies, now with Civics it makes it easier to go straight to Culture from the start.Linking to the art style and districts, I really like how I can now see the buildings and wonders properly in and around my cities. This is only a small bit but I really enjoy watching my buildings being built in my districts and it actually feels like my civilisation is growing... I was getting rather tired of seeing my Oracle or stadiums being built in the sea...UI is simplistic. I have seen some reviews that are complaining that they cannolt find anything in the new UI after only playing the game a few hours. Yes it's hard to find to start with because it's so different from Civ V, but after a while I got used to where all the actions were and how to access my city.Bad/Worse Points:AI still seems a bit stupid on lower difficulties. The first Civ VI game I played I put it on a lower difficulty just to get used to the new techs and way the happiness is now local. And my God the AI were dumb, the agendas made them all hate me as soon as I found them and then even when I was a few eras ahead in technology they would still try to fight me with their horsemen vs my infantry. Maybe this is just how easy AI are supposed to work, or maybe it's a problem. I do not know.There are some glitches with the UI, the notifications that pop up on the side can bug out and won't show the message unless you wiggle the mouse around a bit. This should be patched if the developers notice it.This next point isn't really /bad/ it's just going to take a while to get used to. The local happiness (Amenities) and housing were a nice idea and is more accurate to real life. However I felt like I just jumped into a Sim City game where everyone had their own needs and moaning at me all the time. I guess it's more historically accurate but it makes the game less enjoyable.OVERALL:I've been loving this game so far, a new experience for people coming back to the series. Although there may be some balancing issues right now I am sure they will be ironed out soon.I'll give the game a 9/10 for now, may increase or decrease as updates or expansions release.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is not as good as the previous Civ games. While I like the district system, limited use builders, the way barbarians work, and the ability to set up escorts for non-combat units, the diplomancy system, religion, spying and the art style is a mess. The game doesn't feel complete and I suspect they intend to finish it with DLC rather than enhance it with DLC. I'm going to go back to playing Civ V, Beyond Earth, and Stellaris for my empire-building needs. Maybe once all the DLC is out the game will be enjoyable.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game was absolute garbage on release. So many things were overlooked and so many bugs. Even still it feels unfinished. It's as if they came out with the full game and then split it up as to be released in installments. As opposed to coming out with a complete game and then releasing expansions. I'm also sick of the nickle and dime DLC nonesense. In the very least put the DLC on sale. It pains me to give this a bad review beacuse I've been playing since the original Civ. It just doesn't feel like the developers really care about putting out a good product, they just care about making as much money as possible.

title: Recommended
comment: Having played many 1000's of hours of Civ V, I was extremely happy to pay for the pre-load and even gift a couple of copies to my friends.I love the Civilization franchise and have been playing for years, and this installment has brought many new and interesting mechanics to play with for which I am impressed.The GoodI love the new districts feature. In Civ V a new city could start rolling every building possible until you had everything in one city. This is unrealistic and Civ VI makes you think hard about which buildings a new city would benefit from most and makes it possible to have certain cities specialize in different things i.e production, gold or science.The new city states mechanic is awesome, you are now able to send envoys to them which are gained over time, the more envoys, the bigger the bonus. This is also how you take CS from other Civs saving you the gold to use more usefully elsewhere.The new Civics tree is cool, your Civ is now a custom built machine thanks to the government options. This is great but could use some improvements. I would like to be able to advance in a certain area similar to Civ V, but at this stage the process is similar to the Tech tree so you will have to research a lot of meaningless diplomatic options to get to your desired government.The ability to stack troops into corps(2 sets) and armies (3 sets) is so useful when attacking the enemy, it is no longer necessary to completely surround a city with troops to successfully capture it. This is a throwback to one of my favourite Civ games Civ Rev and is a very welcome addition to the game.I love that Wonders now take up space outside of your city, preventing a player from mass producing every Wonder in the game is a good thing for me. I especially like the placement requirements, which can cause you a dilemma when the wonder you want, can only be placed on that luxury resource, the ensuing toss up in the mind has made the Wonders aspect of the game a lot more fun. I also love the new Wonder animations when complete, so beautiful.A good thing about the AI is that they seem to know when defeat is looming, and they will try everything in their power to broker a peace agreement.More to follow in next edit.................One thing I would like the makers to improve on is the AI. During my last attempt, France (at peace with) mass produced Apostles to invade my lands. Normally I wouldn't mind and would relish the challenge of fending them off to save my own religion.However in this instance there was so many of them I could not navigate my own units through my own land! This caused me to lose battles elsewhere on the map against another Civ. Which as you can imagine was super annoying.Furthermore having asked France to refrain from converting my cities, which they agreed to, the promise was broken the very next turn. The diplomacy screen did not give me any means to justice, no Casus belli for the broken promise nor the opportunity to denounce!The AI are crazy! It seems impossible to keep good relations with them. I had a moment where America offered me a Joint War Declaration against France. I agreed. Two turns later they denounced me as a Warmonger. I could not believe it, my best efforts to keep good relations squandered by the insanity of this AI.Another improvement should be the UI. It's too hard to acess information such as yeilds and troop lists and in my opinion makes the game much harder than Civ V.Having turned off the Religious Victory, the game has much the same feel as Civ V + DLCs with all the new mechanics added, it's my opinion that this is where the game needs improving to make this game perfect.More on the UI front, the city targeting button is way too small and is especially hard to click when a unit is garrisoned in the city. Also there is no notification as to when a city can target an enemy, you have to be extra vigilant.I love the new City States mechanics, however they CS themselves seem to have problem conducting warfare. For example if I have one as my ally, and we both go to war with another Civ, all of the troops amassed by the CS do not seem to try to even engage the enemy Civ, unless that Civ unwittingly sends a troop very close to them. There is an option to levy 'rent' the CS army for your own use, but I'd like to see the CS actually help and engage in war by themselves.More to follow in next edit.................Aside from the problems mentioned I find Civ VI a very enjoyable game, much better than vanilla Civ V, however there are some problems which need to be fixed, and as with Civ V, I'm sure a patch or two can solve these issues.As I have said I love this game and I love the Civilization franchise, so a huge thank you to the makers from me, but please, please fix these problems!

title: Not Recommended
comment: There has been plenty of feedback regarding the overall gameplay and the completely unacceptable not-existing quality of the AI. I am shocked that the game was released with flaws of this magnitude and I cannot find words for my disappointment after having spent 80 EUR on the "Deluxe" edition! However, I will not write yet another detailed review of these aspects.In stead, in the vague hope that all the IMPORTANT feedback provided here by so many dedicated Civ-fans will be picked up by Firaxis and other developers with the task of getting the game beyond these humiliating defects with a XX-gb patch (sarcasm detected), I will state a couple of more practical improvement-ideas:1. Should be more options when creating a game including number of city states, several more map types, choice regarding terrain e.g. the world full of forest or rainforest.2. Should leave the last entered choices in the "create game" menu, so you dont have to put all the same choices in again if you start over.3. Reinstate the "restart game" button in the in-game menu during turn 1 in a new game.4. Currently not able to liberate city states after having taken them over at part of a negotiation (thus not having conquered them as such).5. There should be some recognition from a city state if you liberate them!6. Add the details of religious pressure to each city.7. There should be some kind of "second prize" when failing to complete a wonder first - the materials etc. you spent time on would not just disappear as is the case for now where you receive neither a production boost towards what you choose next nor gold etc.8. Add the option of your units being on alert.9. Stop centering on the city each time you click the red dot on the city when wanting to use defenses against intruders.10. And finally, regardless of my earlier promise not to, I will have to say FIX THE AI AT ONCE!!!!I will come back to CivVI after the major overhaul that hopefully awaits before Christmas - otherwise a lot of fans getting it as a gift will initiate rebellion!

title: Recommended
comment: This is my first 4X game, got it from humblebundle for such a cheap price ($10,8). I have to say the learning curve kinda hard, u need to spend some time to learn it from tutorial and couple of video tips from youtube. but once you get it, u ill enjoy it like i do :)

title: Not Recommended
comment: ".....The expansion focuses on the time periods after the invention of gunpowder and delivers 11 unique and challenging scenarios created by the development team at Firaxis as well as esteemed members of the Civ Community. Civ IV: Beyond the Sword also includes ten new civilizations, sixteen new leaders, five new wonders, and a variety of new units...."That is a part of Civ 4 BtS's description here on Steam. Look at Civ 6 now... You can buy 7 civs and 5 scenarios for £35. No expanded tech tree,no new features,no new leaders,no new units,no new buildings no new wonders.... WTF??.It's a shame. Civ was one of the best turn based strategy games series ever. You'd think as a developer and publisher get more successful and experienced they products get better and better. In reality they get only greedier. There's no passion of creating something great,unique anymore. Just pump out overpriced and contentless DLCs and milk the playerbase instead of making a proper expansion pack like Civ 4 BtS or Warlords was. This game (and many others these days) managed by businessmen who's first priority is making money no matter what, instead of someone who wants to create a great game AND make money by selling it.Shame.The game has some good ideas but overall "soulless" and unfinished,lacking.Edit: Rise and Fall is out now. Some like it,some don't. I don't have it and I won't get it till it's on sale for at least 30-40% off. Probably not even then.. I've seen many videos of it, it's just not worth £25. It doesn't have half of Civ6's content to justify half of it's price,does it??. Seriously.. Divinity O. S 2 is £30 and has content of 5 Rise and Fall's...Also,out of curiosity... I loaded Civ4 up again. I was wondering if I really wanted to could I build Stonhenge against 6 Deity AI?. Oh yeah man, easily.. All I needed to do is chose an Industrial civ ( 50%!!!! wonder bonus production) I went with Inca as they start with Mysticism tech too (unlocks Stonhenge) chopped 2 forests into it and voila...Stonehenge...You won't buid a Stonhenge in civ 6 against deity AI ever...ok,maybe once out of 100 games.. Good luck ;)Wait for another big expansion and a big sale then buy the whole Civ 6 pack for £30-40. That's what I'd do if I wasn't stupid enough to preorder it.. :)

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been playing Civ since civ 3. Let me be clear: I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THE CIV FRANCHISE. I have liked every civ game I've ever played, and even tolerated Beyond Earth. There is something about this Civ game that simply doesnt feel right. There are so many game mechanics in place that I feel are really cool, and yet somehow fall short of delivering on a well rounded experience. The district mechanic is kind of cool, until you realize that god forbid you have -1 amenities and your civ starts breaking apart at the seams and you have to entirely redistrict anything before you can even breathe. CIV 5 happiness is relatable, except that you could probably get back on track while also doing other things. The amenities however really destroy your development if you don't have them. It almost has a sim city feel to it, you know plan everything out ahead of time so that its perfect and works out. Which is perfect if you don't also have to be doing 20 other things at once. Which in Civ of course you are doing. Everything about religion is amazing: much more straightforward systme, better bonuses, create a custom religion. Except the religious combat between units. I find myself literally not caring about this aspect that the AI will live and die by religious combat as if their entire civ depends on it. Which makes it more annoying. Every civ game has its drawbacks, but these are 2 really big ones that make the game unplayayble in later stages. Also the map is super cool and I like the way it is drawn and functions, except that it kind of messes with me a little bit too. Maybe that one is just me, too used to the white clouds of previous civ games. In any event this civ game falls short of what civ 5 completed with its expansions. So maybe once the expansions are relesed and essentially change the way the game is played, it will become more enjoyable. However it shouldn't have to do that. Civ 5 expansions made a good game great. Civ 6 expansions would make a below average game good.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I will update my review as I play the game more, but these are my honest initial impressions. At present, I would not recommend this game to my friends because I don't see a compelling reason to play it over Civilization V. In many ways, I find that game to be considerably more fun than this one.I was definitely very excited to play Civilization VI. I did not watch any of the videos or read any of the reviews before purchasing this game. Considering how much I've enjoyed this franchise, I did not expect to dislike the newest iteration and I did not want to spoil any of the fun. Unfortuately, I don't presently feel this game has lived up to its awesome reputation. After five years, many of us still happily play Civ5, which says a lot about how excellent Civ is.When I started my first game in Civ6, I immediately found the UI unattractive and the game world unimpressive. The graphics seem almost infantile, as if they belong in Civ4. It feels like a huge step backward and this will likely harm my enjoyment of this game. I was also unhappy with the available options for creating a game. There are very few maps to choose from (which I'm sure will be expanded with DLC) and very few customization options (fog of war seems to be not only persistent, but also pervasive -- you must at all times have a unit in the area to remove the fog or it comes back.)I haven't played long enough to get beyond the initial era, and this in itself is kind of saying something because I've played thousands of hours of Civ5. I just did not feel compelled to continue in this one. So with that said, there's much I haven't seen. The concept of districts is appealing to me. I'm curious about many of the changes in mechanics. Hopefully with time I will come to enjoy it more. But for now, I just don't consider this a substantive improvement over Civ5 and in many ways find it far less interesting than its predecessor.For those who like this game, you might feel compelled to attack my review on a number of different counts. I ask that you be respectful of the fact that everyone will have a different opinion and different impressions of the games they play. If you like it, great. I'm not really trying to discourage anyone from purchasing it, but it would be dishonest to recommend a game that I may very well not play much myself. Civ5, to me, is still the champ; we'll see if that changes in time.One positive note: The Steam Controller works great with this game. I really enjoyed being able to use a controller.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I LOVE CIV....always have and so far im still excited to spend more time on it and feel it out. I cant say the graphics changes are too bad and the hud like icons thrown in are also fine.What I CANT take are the slight differences meant to "immerse you in the game".The instant builders whom are spent in a few improvements.The combat system is pretty broken. Ranged is extremely OP.Every game is like raging barbs. They are EVERYWHERE!!!(although I later found that there ARE ruins and auto buttons for exploration)Basically it feels like a failed attempt to improve on V by yet again changing the entire feel of the game as opposed to continuing to build on it. By forcing one to be "fully immersed" in every hex revealed on the grid...you're making me fall asleep with the tedium of nuance best left to automation. Im trying to conquer the world, not go sight seeing.Civ V gives you a clear feeling like you are creating and managing an empire..... Civ VI feels like a hot mess all over the map with no clear boundaries as to who's who or whats going on. It really feels like they took away the ability to navigate the game or control its flow in any tangible way. The removal of workers building improvements and the shift in tile improvement methods (even though the districs part is a decent concept, if not poorly inplemented) seems aimed at attracting new players who might find CIV's learning curve daunting and prefer a dumbed down "mobile-ish" version of things in order to keep their attention... a.k.a. "be more immersed"....In a nut shell Civ 6 feels like yet another game made by game developers that dont play games. Seemingly more concerned with "immersing you" in their baby and pushing the concepts they feel are noteworthy from a design standpoint than actually looking at what the player is asking for/complaining doesnt work in the current model.I hope to see some improvements as time goes on. Civ V certainly improved over time (and expansions) so who knows. I just hope Civ Beyond Earth wasnt the begining of the end of a once mightly game franchise....but hey...at least we can still play V.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Steam really needs a "Not Yet" button.First, I am a Civ veteran. I've been playing since III was released. I know my way around. This time, the game just seems off. I don't mind the unstacked cities. In fact I like the concept even if the excecution feels weird. I could learn to love it. As others have mentioned, the AI is insane. I can have the largest claimed area and Rome will still make mention that I haven't expanded. The barbarians need tweaking. Even on easier settings, I am spending most of my early game just building units to protect my one or two cities as wave after wave almost instant spawn from camps. Cleared camps will be replaced by new camps a few squares away within a single turn and then the cycle starts over. I'm pretty happy with the near complete elemination of unit automation, but it makes exploration a chore as most scouts end up "exploring" by running from the overkill barbarians. The flip side ofthe barbarian issue is that the game is boring without them, so turning them off is a bad option.Now, the technical issues: There are sound issues: the music and voice clips will stutter randomly. Clicking the ranged attack icon on a city with walls will flash the ranged attack targeting before needing to be clicked again (sometimes repeating the problem. The camera resets to the capital all the time: we need persistant unit focus. Every-so-often the mouse just doesn't seem to function completely. The cursor can moved, some UI elements can be clicked on, but not others. Switch mice and keyboards didn't resolve input issues on both PCs that I encountered these issues on.Finally, the praise. I really like the art style. I don't really want the hyper-realism that so many people have been clamouring for. The colors are bright and interesting plus the models are different and well animated. The UI is forgetable, but it stays out of the way.EDIT: After buying some of the DLC and letting the updates settle in and smooth things out, I am finding that the game is downright forgetable. I am not engaged in the game, just bored with the bad war mongering AI that offer no real challenge. Civ 6 is boring, and I hate that, but it doesn't change the reality of it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm giving a very uncertain and conditional no. There's this usual deal - if you make a sequal to game, it's only logical people will compare. And in case of civilization, the game is always exactly the same, just features change. So if you come with a sequal, it should be better then what the players already have, no? Obviously no. It's better then vanila Civ5 - but only because it incorporates features added in datadiscs. Sadly, with some of them tweaked and some removed, the whole game doesn't work nearly as well as its previous incarnation.WARNING: Wall of text ahread. If you want a conclusion, seek the last paragraph.I'll start with the good. Active research is pretty good, it keeps you active. Over a few playthroughs it gets rather repetitive, because it's usually just build 3 something or something else, but still, cool idea and it works.The districts are not bad at all. They are a tad too complicated for the difference they mean, but they are a fun decision and add dilema to the game, since a city typically won't have everything it wants now. Placement of wonders also feels pretty good, you finally won't have pyramids built in jungle and three gorges in desert. Nice touch :)So the two aspects the game was marketed with work all right. Still the bright side I kind of like how great persons now have slightly different abilities that change thematically with progress through eras (early scientist can bring belief for example). Only kind of though, since for most great persons, the dilema known from civ5 was removed. Do I use great writer for one time culture boost or great work? Should my great prophet go on conversion tour, or should he become a holy site? Not here - the role of the character is given and while merchant/scientist/engineer differs at least a bit, the only difference between writer/artist/musician is name of their works and slots they fit into. Thumb down.The removal of dilemas is responsible for a lot of my dissapointment. City states are now gained by sending "envoys" into them, envoys being gained via quests (like infulence in civ5) or via a separate "influence" resource, which is used solely for this purpose - there's no other use for it. Using money was definitely much better, addign the decision whether they should be saved for unit upgrade, used for boosting city development or invested in city state.Similar thing happened to tourism. In civ5 late game it's an important asset, because it sways other powers towards your ideology and so it matters even if you don't go for for culture victory. Not so here, it again has sole purpose and if you intend to win via diplomacy or religion, you can safely ignore its existence.Remember how you couldn't wait for your new civ5 cultural policy to be finished, because they were all strong and super useful? How every policy branch supported different playstyle? Ok, so you can forget about it. There's a policy tree similar to tech tree now, so you're more or less forced to invent everything. You get policy cards that go into government slots. There's a lot of cards and very few slots. So you'll be using maybe 5% of what you've discovered. Baaaad idea. Actually one of the worst I've encountered here.Above issues are conceptual - they are part of the game, I assume they will be tweaked in datadiscs and one just has to take them or leave them, because it's what makes the game after all. Then there's technical side though.UI is definitely a big step back. I'm constantly struggling to find information which is either hard to reach or not available at all (not even in civilopedia!!!). I was used to getting a comprehensive breakdown on almost everythign by right clicking - it's comfortable and it helps the learning curve, because it helps me understand why do the numbers look the way they do. Here I struggle with finding out what's on individual tiles, what the tile yield is, why are my people unhappy.I can't find my units - they are difficult to spot, the ones that already moved look the same as fresh ones and there's no unit list that would help me find that archer stationed in some backwater colony I've already forgotten about. Attacking from a city is an annoying minigame where you first try to move camera so that you see the attack button hidden behind city garrison and then you wave your cursor around, hoping the attack arrow will appear. If you click too soon, bad luck, it's back to step one again.The idea of chaining escort/support unit to military was good, but why the hell are they not melded together into one unit? If you get artilery with observation baloon and great general, it's two "skip turn" and one attack every turn, that's just crazy. It has also often happened to me that my ranged ship sailed right towards the enemy melee, because I had escorted admiral selected instead of main ship and didn't notice.Graphic is personal opinion, but units are less detailed and their attack animation much less interesting for me, the same goes with AI leaders who are... rather unimpressive looking and bland. But really, this is the first thing I'm willing to forgive if everything else works.AI leaders and AI in general - it really really need a patch. I can more or less put up with fact my tanks are meeting club armed warriors someone forgot to upgrade. But then there's England boldly declaring war on me. Driving 18 heavy chariots to surround my city (defended with a musketeer, ok, England is a bit backwards). And then it probably realizes attacking would be futile and just stands around, driving back and forth, doing nothing. I suspect that with such high number of units, it might even be able to break through the defenses eventually (losing 17 of them and maybe getting a city). But no, it just watches how fire from the city massacres them and that's the point where I'm considering just dropping the game till a few patches, because there's no challange in it and no fun.To give a final point - it's a good game, which is hardly a praise for a sequel of a marvelous game. It urgently needs AI patches. It would benefit from redesign of UI. Features are... okeyish. There's the feeling of novelty and there's the promise of datadiscs making it grand again. But so far it's merely good.

title: Not Recommended
comment: While this game offers many improvements over Civ5.In some ways it's a big downgrade.Let's start with the UI problems.The UI for city view looks like this[i.rdthrne.com]. I can click a few buttons and then it looks like this[i.rdthrne.com]; which, in my opinion, should be the default view. Every time I open up the city view, I have to click those buttons again. I have no clear overview of my cities or what I can do with them.When I hover over tiles I want to see immediate results. I can't do that in civ6. There's not even a setting for changing the popup speed. There was one in civ5. I can't understand why this was removed in civ6. Makes zero sense to me.When I'm in the leaderscreen it takes a second or so for the buttons to appear. I read faster than they appear, so I end up getting annoyed at it because I have to wait for the buttons to appear. Pretty annoying.Sometimes I select a unit before my turn starts with the intention to move it somewhere. Or sometimes I want to click on a unit after I've moved another unit. This game doesn't want me to. Because it automatically selects another unit that is in need of action. I've lost a settler to barbarians because of this.Barbarians. Don't get me started on the barbarians. I didn't like barbarians in civ5. They had little impact on the game beyond forcing you to build a few archers. They were annoying, but that's it. I could play with them enabled without being really impeded in the game. But in civ6.. they ruin the game. It feels like I'm constantly at war. Barbarians are literally everywhere. My scouts are all dying because they'reI am to turn them off. And that makes some civs obsolete early game. That's poor core gameplay.Workers. Each worker can only be used a finite amount of times. 3 by default, and 4 with pyramids (which require desert).I understand this is because you have to pay more attention to which tiles you improve and which ones you don't. I get that. But now I have to make workers for each city.. multiple times.. that's a lot of turns. Wasted, just on making workers.Diplomacy. I have no ♥♥♥♥ing clue what I'm doing. The tutorial didn't tell me♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the UI is unhelpful. I seriously can't figure this out. (Though I didn't play past the medieval era due to frustrations, so it might've been more obvious later on.)The tutorial. It tells you too little. Much too little. The only things I learned from this tutorial was the basic stuff; which is good, and how to attack/kill a civ. It told me nothing about diplomacy, nothing about natural wonders, nothing about sea resources or how to improve them. Next to nothing about city states. I went through the tutorial and I still spent most of my time in the game being confused. In the end it just tells you to look at the civilopedia.In the end, I spent most of my time not understanding what I was doing. And that's after 4 hours of gameplay.I can't talk about anything past the first 100 turns. Because I never went any further than that. Right now the game is unplayable to me. There are too many small annoyances.But, there are good things. And I'll mention a few of those.You can link non-combat units with combat units so they move simultaneously. This is great, I only have to move the units once, and there's no room for ♥♥♥♥ups.The unit promotion system is way better. You can clearly see what path your unit can follow in terms of promotions, and when you promote the unit it also gets healed. No more being forced to get a healing promotion because your unit is dying.The fact that you have both a tech and civics tree, as well as the government policy system with cards. This allows for a very fine customization of playing style. This is great. (Though, this added complexicity might be confusing to some)The district system and other city building/planning mechanics. This makes you slightly less reliant on good spawn positions.There are more good things (and more bad things), but I can't think of them at this moment. Great overall game, but has some really glaring issues that could ruin the experience for you. I recommend waiting until this game has some patches. (don't you dare make fixes in gameplay a paid DLC, firaxis. You don't fix your own game and then ask money for it.)I recommend you don't buy this game in its current state. The game's too much of a downgrade to be worth the 60 buck price tag. I regret buying this. I'm sure it'll be a great game 2-3 years down the line, with expansions and fixes all there. But right now it's pretty frustrating.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I kinda feel like that 2K is playing us gamers more and more. I would even say, they are now all about our money and nothing else. Easy example: compare CIV6 with its precursor - continents are by far smaller (just take a few turns to discover it completely) and no passion at all. Also does CIV5 feel by far more 'complete' (I guess this is a point which most players from CIV5 can agree).So, and what drives me now into writing this review? Let me explain it to you: I noticed that an expansion is coming and at first I was sure it is in my Deluxe Edition included - but now after checking the news, it is excluded from the 'Season Pass', so customer who bought the full edition or even the ridiculously expensive Anniversary Edition are now forced to buy that 30-dollars-DLC just to 'complete' their full game experience.It is really turning me mad, they screw around with the sports franchise (NBA and WWE - though I hate Wrestling) are nothing but hatred, XCOM 2 got an expensive DLC (War of the Chosen), Mafia 3 was a heavy disappointment in the eyes of fans of Mafia 2 and now they try to get as much milk as possible from their another big franchise cash-cow Civilization.In my humble opinion, I have no problems with boycotting 2K - in fact the most games in the last two years are ridiculous to their precursors. I will uninstall CIV 6 right now and hope that 2K will go bankrupt. I have the desire to write more insults but I have to stay strong, I just want good games and less greed for money. It is okay producing games with the intention to earn some cash, but not for the quality.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Athough the game is great for killing time - i cant recommend it.Over all its a step back from civ 5 both in graphics and in gameplay.Returning to civ5 felt like an upgrade grapics wise - it just feels more real. Recently Firaxis announced this game on iOS devices. Which makes me wonder if all this cartoony style was intentional. As a PC player i feel a bit betrayed.Single player works fine - but multiplayer is just horrible. For our group of 5 people it sometimes takes an hour of setting up the game - "error joining multiplayer session" or outright crashing randomly. Getting into game brings new problens - disconects or desyncs after a couple turns. Sometimes its outright unplayable and we fall back to civ5 which is much stabler.Gameplay wise - its got some nice ideas with districts and Wonders built on tiles but again it lacks if you compare to Civ5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ VI is probably the best Civilizations game to date. The districts system is fantastic. The graphics are amazing, most of the gameplay is staying true the formula that works, the supporting armies and corps and such are greatly improved over previous titles.It's also garbage. Theological Combat is stupid. The AI is not anything resembling intelligent. Just today I was playing and two of my friendliest allies both decided to go to war with me without provokation. How does one's two closest allies both with friendly smiles on their faces suddenly become your most hated enemies?I'll tell you how, because they rushed this game to market and once published they moved on to other projects, when they should be spending more time fixing their mistakes, which is what good development houses do.Civilizations is not just a game, it's a significantly influential educational tool. Like it or not. If it's junk, then the children of this generation are going to grow up with junk in their heads.Until the glaring problems with this game are fixed I can't recommend it, which is a bummer because I really want to.

They attacked Civ 5 when it came out, now they claim it's the greatest game ever. I'm sure when Civ 7 hits, it will be the same story. Just try the demo, if you like it buy it, or don't.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is a major downgrade form Civilization 5. The amount of work that I had to put in was insane. They need to make it less work and more fun. I spent most of my time begging to get builders made because it the only way you advance

title: Not Recommended
comment: The facts are these, when this game launched, it was rated as high as potentially possible here on Steam. Fast forward less than one year, and you have managed to raise such a cry against this pay to play method which you have developed for this game that a full 1/3rd of the players have come out against this game. In addition, those that do recommend this game have to point out the severe flaws in this games DLC and content and A.I. and general game play. It is a credit more to the people of Steam that you still have 68 percent, more than anything about this game. If you want a list of recommendations, I can only suggestone in the present, listen to the 32 to 33 percent presently saying this game is not worth buying, and the other 25 percent who wish there was a button inbetween recommend and not recommend. I have become so detached from this game because it's blatant money making goes so far beyond even my own beliefs on business that only today I noticed I still had the game downloaded due to your summer update. That is the true measure of how badly you have managed this game post launch.Edit on 2/8/2018: Deleted the game for over half a year, come back to find that the apparent solution to everyones complaints is to release a DLC for 30 dollars, 30...you think that is how much people want to pay for your DLC after the first 6 DLC, which conveniently is the amount of DLC people get with the Deluxe Edition they forked out 80 bucks for in the first place, oh joy. Not only does my recommendation still stay as a thumbs down, you'd be a moron to have bought the deluxe edition and not demand a full refund at this point, mind you, you aren't going to get one, but at this point it is on principle. So at least you paid someones wages for eventually making Civ VII, which will probably actually take DLC to unlock features, like single player, or turning up and down the volume, or exiting the game.Further Edit on 2/8/2018: So now if you don't own the DLC, you can't actually play multiplayer with your friends who do, wow, way to go Fraxis, makes me really wanna not ask for a refund for the game entirely, you know who doesn't do that to it's players? Paradox.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Big, beautiful and horribly unbalanced. It will probably improve with the expansion, but frankly I dont want to waste more money on this game yet. I bought the "digital deluxe" and feel utterly ripped off, to the point were I expect the developers to feel embarrassed.Ill just keep playing Civ V until VII ships and then pick up the complete VI at a discount.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Over a year, and I still can't play against my friends.Ever since Civ VI came out, they've claimed "cross-platform multiplayer is just around the corner," then completely ignored it in literally. every. single. update. If you get the game for Mac or Linux, you can only play against other Mac or Linux players, period. And likely forever, considering that the "we promise we'll fix this soon" messages haven't changed in 6 months.Releasing a $30 expansion pack for a game whose devs still haven't fixed the biggest day 1 bug? That's some of the laziest corporate shenanigans I've ever seen. Glad that I got this game on sale, because I can't see myself buying anything else from these developers until they get their act together.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Athough the game is great for killing time - i cant recommend it.Over all its a step back from civ 5 both in graphics and in gameplay.Returning to civ5 felt like an upgrade grapics wise - it just feels more real. Recently Firaxis announced this game on iOS devices. Which makes me wonder if all this cartoony style was intentional. As a PC player i feel a bit betrayed.Single player works fine - but multiplayer is just horrible. For our group of 5 people it sometimes takes an hour of setting up the game - "error joining multiplayer session" or outright crashing randomly. Getting into game brings new problens - disconects or desyncs after a couple turns. Sometimes its outright unplayable and we fall back to civ5 which is much stabler.Gameplay wise - its got some nice ideas with districts and Wonders built on tiles but again it lacks if you compare to Civ5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Clunky, boring, and poorly balanced for a Civ game. Diplomacy is broken, builders require unecessary levels of micro-managing, the lack of ability to queue production items makes playing any sort of long game inconvienent. Among a laundry list of other issues. Civ V is just better in every way.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm propably the only old school Civ player writing a review, because I simply do not understand why this game gets such good reviews. I'm betting they are all pretty new to Civ.I've played Civilization for over 20 years, ever since the first game was released. I was hooked from the start. Civ 2, I loved it even more. Civ 3 was such an amazing development for the game and Civ 4 was simply the best! Then came Civ 5, wich never really felt like a compleate game. productivity was harder and the size of my army was never really the same. Plus the religion was in my opinion just a waste of production. Now after 300 hours of Civ 6, I must say: I am bitterly disapointed. The game has progressed little since Civ 5. Now I have even less production and everything feels like in slow motion. Religion has moslty been copy-paste from Civ 5. And the ai is terrible. The only online games I've played have all been over in the middle age at the latest.Gone are the big armies and world domination plots, instead we have endless turns of waiting for things to get built. The best way to get production, gold or science is to send emisaries to city states or through trade routes. Workers are now compleatly under your control and you must micromanage them the entire game. The only Civ that has any productivity are the germans and in my opinion the only usable civ.By the time you reach renaissance the game becomes just to much micromanage to enjoy a bigger picture game. And if ever your army gets viped, then you are done for. No chance to rebuild after a war. If you get ravaged by war then you can pack it in.The balance of Civ 4 is in the past, where you could chose from a variety of ways to play the game and have a multiple fun ways to win and losing a war and half your territories did not mean you were down and out. Now when I reach industrial age I just soldier through the turns and go for the space race victory. Anything else just takes to long, mostly because you have to micromanage everything the entire game.As big of a disapointment Civ 5 was for me, Civ 6 is even bigger. And how the ai can be worse and worse is beyond me.If you want to play a game of Civilization, buy Civ 4. I give Civ 4 a 10/10, Civ 6 I give 3/10 and that's only for the first three ages. There is absolutely nothing new and exciting to be found here, the introduction of districts was cool when I first played it but now I see it just adds on to the micromanage of the game which is to much of to begin with.Do not buy this, unless you like to spend alot of time micromanaging and planning the same thing over and over and over and over. And then if you do, try not to expand to much or the game will just start to feel like a job that you cant wait to finish.In Civ 4 I had empires with over 100 cities and I could reduce the micromange by automating units and cities. Now the thought of controlling 25 city's is a micromanage hell.I find it really sad that my favorite game for so many years has been reduced to this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Good:1-The game is interesting to play.2.The choice to make animations and art style "cartoony" enabled the game to run on some very weak machines.3. Addicting gameplay that really does have an ability to make you play all night.....just ONE MORE turn...Bad:1. Very newbie unfriendly (the tooltips and in game help menu "civilopedia" are more like dictionaries than actuall explanations for game mechanics) as someone who first started playing CIV games with CIV6, it took me a long time and lot of Youtube instructions to learn the basics (thank you YT Channel "Quill18")2. Some civilizations are more powerful than others (in terms of traits and bonuses)(Some civilization's effects and traits are so weak and more of a chore to utilize that they feel more like an afterthought).3. PERSISTENT BUGS - even despite the games relatively "mature" age (relased Oct 2016) and multiple updates/patches, some downright stupid and easy to fix bugs are still present!!! (AI behavioural bugs mostly). Nothing game breaking but still cmon the game is almost 2 years old and these bugs are here from the release!Very Bad!!: LACK OF CONTENT FOR LONG TERM PLAY! DLC GALORE!!!1. Shameful lack of content for a game that started of as a 60EUR game!!!2. The amount of paid DLCs is riddiculous!! ( you are basically left with core game with few civilzations) While there are now more "premium DLC pay" civilzations / rulers than there was in the core game.This is EA levels of GREED!!!Its not like the DLCs are cheap either!!Shame on you Firaxis!!

title: Recommended
comment: You can not judge a game by day 0 content. The game isnt even 100% finished. So far so good. Sometimes it is good to be different. 9/10 for me. Just because I hate day 1 updates and lag.But man ain't she perty.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm not going to go on a tirade about how bad I think the game is, but I'm fairly disappointed, which sucks since I really do like the Civ series and had high hopes for Civ VI. To sum up how I feel:1. All the Civs can more or less do what another Civ can do, sometimes at a slight disadvantage.2. Districts are cool, but tedious.3. Wonder system is a plus, but you have to think ERAS ahead to make sure you can place them in your cities.4. Barbarians may as well be NAZIS because they can and will ♥♥♥♥ you at every single opportunity.5. As many have noted, in-game diplomacy is a mythical concept.6. Poland is a stand-alone DLC for $5.7. A scenario is a stand-alone DLC for $5.8. The game went on sale for a whopping 10% over Christmas, which upsets me and I already own the game :/9. Kongo has a civ, and I don't say that to be racist; legitemately, who here had heard of Mvemba a Nzinga before this game? And it ties back into Firaxis' garbage DLC scheme; if you want an extra civ, and I mean, ONE extra civ, give them 5 dollars.10. Natural Wonders are a hefty investment and aren't often worth settling for, whereas there was much more flexibility with regards to them in Civ 5.RIP Me
