comment: I'm very dissapointed. I was looking forward till the day it came out, now im looking back and thinking "That was a waste of time AND money".

title: Recommended
comment: Pros:-Pretty much everything is improved over V-Districts feature adds a lot to the city building-Strategy is a lot deeper-The map looks much nicer without the fog of war.Cons:-Awful Character design

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is all about starting with decent production. If you don't then everyone you are playing against destroys you.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Worst AI ever. I played every CIV a lot, Time I put aside last week. It is fare to easy to win. On emperor level I managed to have my bommers ready by 1850, completely overrunning my enemies who developed gunpowder but had decided to keep archers and warriors.It is a nice game, but the AI is so completely broken, that I am surpriced that they released this game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As a long-time fan of the Civ series, I can say that this a solid game. I won't fill this review with long explanations of the differences between VI and other Civ games... or with listing pros and cons. Rather, I'm just going to say that the entire experience is ruined by the unacceptable amount of time that the game takes to calculate each. Especially in the late game, even with animations turned off, the game takes 20 seconds, 30 seconds, 45 seconds, or even a full minute to calculate each turn. For this day and age, for a AAA game released from a major studi, this delay is unreasonable and shocking. I would expect each turn to take a few seconds at most.... a full minute is madness and ruins the experience. I can't take it... I'd refund if I could.

title: Recommended
comment: Unlike most of the games I get hyped for, this game completley met my expectations and much more. The developers really expanding the basics of the game like city building and structure and government structure, while only tweaking the parts of the game that were 'good' or 'okay'. Not only does it add many new things to the series, but Civilization VI is full of little things that will make you smile (Things like the music). Honestly makes Civilization V look like an unfinished, basic game. There are really no major cons of the game. If you like empire building and managing games and/or do not have the attention span to read any more reviews, empty your wallet on this beauty.

title: Recommended
comment: Product received for freeI don't write many reviews on steam but being a well seasoned Civ player I decided to do this for once.Positives:- New Styled Graphics; the cartoony goofy graphics provides a fresh new start to Civ, unlike Civ Beyond Earth, which gave new graphics but went the wrong direction. Although it will be a shock for Civ 5 players, and will take a while to adjust, it will nevertheless bring nostalgic memories to older Civ players.- Gameplay change; unlike Civ 5, this game will bring a larger focus on city building, letting you decide what you would mould your empire to become; cultural, militaristic or religious? Unlike previous installments, where the city with the biggest production produces everything, you have to more carefully decide what "district" you will build.Negatives:-Diplomacy; AI is still ♥♥♥♥ed, and declares war every century. Even Gandhi seem to be the most warmongering on the game from what I have seen (although this is the case for every Civ game for some reason) but I still hope this will be patched.-Borders; Just a small tweak but the borders are hard to differenciate from each other. A simple coloured line marks your territory. I played a game as China vs Japan and I could hardly tell the difference between our cities and empires. This is maybe because I am used to all territory to have a colour but I believe I will adjust to this.-Warfare: Although focus has been taking on infrastructure I can't help but notice that the quality of warfare has been dropped. Not only are enemies practically unconquerable until you get the Artillery unit but they also seem to be spamming units that provide buffer making it impossible to reach their cities. This again might be the AI's fault but I still appreciate they added new support units like Medic and Engineer. I also like the idea of combining units to form corps and armies, even though combining them does not provide double the damage which one might think.Conclusion:Overall this game provides a relief from Beyond Earth, and with some few patches on the AI this game will be a genuin success to the franchise.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have played Civilization since the 90's and loved every version, this version has some great ideas.You can research two items at once. You can fight religious conversion without going to war.However the interface is horrible as in,Often difficult to get a unit to move where you want, or be able to fire on another unit, it let's you try and try then suddenly will move your artillary to a location near the target so it will be killed on the next turn.I have to play in windows mode or my mouse pointer isn't visible, this puts the standard close game X on the upper right corner just above where they often put their close dialog window X I have closed the game 3 time due to this 'feature'.The custom game settings cannot be saved so if you want anything other than the standard setup you have to go through and pick each of your setting every time you start a game. Tedious and frustrating.The Options menu is vague at best, I tire of the videos shown each time an opponent talks to you but they didn't put an obvious don't show the video selection you have to reduce performance to eliminate this. (who knows if this also cuts out something I may want.)Others have covered the AI, so I won't go there, I don't know if it's any worse than Civ 5 but it certainly isn't any better. The graphics are much worse than 5 more like something from Civ 3. When moving a settler or religious person the graphics go from poor to horrible and you often can't see any details of what is on the map.Others seem confident the game will be fixed but I don't hold out the same hope, it doesn't seem to me they did any proof testing prior to the release so this version is probably just a money grab. They know it will be a best seller so they ddin't put any effort into the game. It is too bad as there was someone there who had some good ideas for improving the game but the execution is mediocre to horrible.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Too many conflicting game mechanics slammed together without proper testing. Not to meantion a serious lack of balancing and too much emphasis on military victory. I love the cultural development and how its separate to science allowing you to create a cultural utopia of cavemen. Perhaps they could have done religious development like this too? Purchasing units with faith seems to be out of place when compared to culture tech trees and the cards system. I like the idea of districts and having focused cities but REALLY? we have to use the city production to build it? It seems like the districts should form on their own at certain populations and be next to the city centre. Anyway enough rambling. The game feels like if you were to download 10 different overhaul mods and use them all at once. Many conflicts and focuses that create a cluster cluck. The Civs in the game are interesting but there's not nearly enough of them.As of a month ago the game simply wont run, Tried multiple fixes which didnt work. I feel i have spent more time trying to get the game working than actually playing the game.In sumary the game isn't bad or anything its just not as good as the other Civ games I have played. (Civ 3, 4, Revolutions, Colonisation, 5) Just go and buy any of the other Civ games mentioned and you would have a better game. Or just buy Civ 5... Oh and the other games actually work.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Do they even test these games anymore?! Buggy, unbalanced, shallow. I've loved Civilization sice the first generation, but one week into this new adventure and I'm already bored.The problem as I see it is that Firaxis is not learning from their own history. Civ V vanilla came out and it was unbalanced, buggy, lacked depth... all in all, not nearly as good as Civ IV plus the expansions. And guess what, the same thing has happened in CIV VI. It took two expansions for Civ V to become a good game and several mods for it to become a great game. So why didn't they learn their lesson from their own previous expansions? Similarly, why didn't they incorporate elements from the most successful mods into their new game? They ignore their fan base, they don't test their games, they give us half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥released... this was a money grab pure and simple.I see a lot of people saying "wait for the expansion" or "don't worry, a mod will fix that" -- shouldn't the onus be on Firaxis to release a full gaming experience? Furthermore, why are we depending on UNPAID modders to fix the problems of an expensive triple-A game title? For $60 I expect a fairly high-end (polished) game. Civ V changed a lot of things from the previous version, so I can somewhat understand why it wasn't 100% on release... but Civ VI just feels like a really dull version of Civ V. The removed a bunch of the depth that made Civ V great and only gave us a couple of game mechanics that seem like good ideas on paper but don't currently work together to increase the levels of enjoyment in the game itself.The game play is unbalanced, the graphics are a HUGE step backwards (looks like some freemium mobile game), the AI managed to get worse, the civs are boring, diplomacy is useless, religion is annoying... and basically it feels like they've nerfed most of the things that made Civ V so great."Wait for the expansions" how about wait for the bargain bin because right now this game is nowhere near where Civ V left off.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I love civ but for some reason I just can't get into this game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Solid game, but braindead AI devours a lot of fun. Patch needed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As many others have already said . . . it's kind of like a Civ game, only slower, more cluttered, and a lot clunkier. I really wanted to like it, but it's like they took Civ 5 and just made it more complicated and harder to manage, and added updated graphics and interfaces.Sorry, but I wouldn't spend $30 on this even on sale, let alone the $60 regular price . . .I think Civ 5 is a far better game . . .

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeIn my first playthrough around 200 turns religion bar stucked. I was aiming for a religion victory and I wasn't able to pass a turn because I need to update smt from religion bar. I have no way of opening my religion screen and at this point I don't even remember what I can use religion screen for. I am shift + enter'ing my turns and I am able to pass turns now. I am going to win the game by 500 turns (I am around 450 into this game) and I have some problems other than multiplayer bug, or other bugs and crashes. They can all be solved from 5 mounths from now but core mechanics won't be change most likely and they all suck.Culture mechanic is not well thought through. Wars doesn't affect tourism. You can not block your borders for other countries and your citizens. (this would lessen their tourists income and punish culture victory) as far as I know there is not a steady income for tourism, not without cards at least.Goverment choices are not as deep as they should be. Capitalism, fascism or communism need bigger difference, bonuses and disadvantages without the card system. +You shouldn't be able to change your goverment every 5 years to suit your needs. +There should be bonuses if you keep your goverment save for a long time, like if you finish the game with theocracy.Spies are too damn op. I have never got caught spying and escaped every time. I used to defend my building but i find no need for it, they can't hurt me as much as i hurt them. I stole more than 5 great pieces but noone is asking any questions. I boosted all my science options from spies and those countries I spy on aren't even on the same age as I am.AI can't handle wars. You can trick AI everytime even if they have more units then you. AI tends to suicide charge its units and settlers. I stole 2 cities from the AI by just letting AI settle. I waited for it to settle to most bizarre place and sealed its way out. Right now I am in 2010 and I can still see settlers wandering around + catapult and knights...I can go on and on about how idioutic the diplomacy is or AI uses every city state againts me but when I use other city states againts them they do not attack but just sit still to get taken by AI. Religion spreading is also bs, even on fascism or communism your cities can change religion and you have no way of enforcing your religion by military. You can't use religion as a way of starting a war or ask your allies to join the war with you.A shameful display. Back to the Total War...

title: Not Recommended
comment: Very disappointing. Lacklustre gameplay and missing some key functionality (repeat last trade route, sortable trade routes, fortify-unit-until-enemy-visible, alerts for cities that can bombard). Some irritating bugs (especially with Vikings moving from sea to land) and a clunky UI.At best this is a $20 game. I've loved Civ since I first encountered Civ 2 in my early teens. But after this farce of an unready game at a painful price point, I'm done with the series. And probably with Firaxis.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been a long time player of Civ Games since Civ 1. Civ 2 is still my favourite. Civ 5 was borderline playable, but Civ 6 I'm afraid is not for me. It's just not enjoyable and unbalanced and have to play at the easy levels and still I get annoyed. I'll play something else now. No more Civ, a shame.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've sunk several hours into this game, and will inevitibly sink several more, trying to enjoy it. There are alot of things that work, like the combat, and the boosted reserch. Unfortunatly there is more that dosnt work, the fact that you no longer now which era your in, the warmonger penitly for going to war, with anyone, the lack of distinction between improved and unimproved resources, the cartoony graphics. I bought this game played for two hrs and 5 min and cant return it. If you want it wait till its 75 % off

title: Recommended
comment: Best Civilization on launch, and I've played them all. Has some minor issues (balance, bug or two) that will almost certainly be worked out in coming patch, but otherwise is great. Customization of governments and playstyle is higher than any other Civ title and the base game includes all features from Civ 5's DLC (religion, trade, etc). Feels fully loaded already - looking forward to future DLC.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ 6 is a great game, that's more dynamic and enjoyable than Civ 5, especially vanilla Civ 5. People who are leaving ratings are complaining about bad diplomacy, (which is fair because diplomacy is always terrible in Civ games) but this is the best diplomacy that a Civilization game has ever had for its AI. They're also complaining about barbarians, science, and production imbalance. Yeah, there are things that could be improved (and they will be as expansions come out; look at the difference between vanilla Civ V and Brave New World) but I've played this game a bunch and it isn't as bad as people are making it out to be. If you don't like the barbarians, turn them off, but it's not hard to defeat them.Half of the reviewers are just mad that they have to buy some of the civilizations as a DLC. The simple solution is to not buy the DLC; the game will run just the same. The other half of reviewers must just be bad at strategy games. Complaining that you end up fighting spearman with tanks means that you're playing on too low of a difficulty. If you're taking the time to learn the new district system, challenge yourself on the higher difficulty setting, and think strategically, you'll be just fine.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As much as I want to like this game, some of the changes from Civ V are interesting, but I cannot in good conscious recommend this game. Since day 1, I have not been able to get through a game without multiple crashes. I sent a ticket into 2k and after 3 or 4 emails later, each with a long list of "troubleshooting ideas" I still can't get a couple turns into a game without crashing to desktop. Everytime I crash, I immediately say "yes" to sending in the crash report, in hopes it will get noticed and fixed.Maybe in a few months, something will finally get changed and I can enjoy this game, but untill then, this is a definite NO from me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The mechanics of this game are a wide step away from previous Civilization games; many of which make it feel more like the first part of a new series than an entry into an established IP. I have been a huge fan of the series since its inception, and this game really feels more like it was created as a mobile version than a full PC release. Graphically, the game has taken huge steps backwards, opting for a highly-saturated cartoon aesthetic than the realism that such a game really demands. In many ways, the game feels incomplete and most of the newly implemented mechanics (the government card systems, expiring workers, and AI players as a whole) really make the game feel less intuitive and effective than previous entries.I was expecting a game that built and improved upon the innovations from Civilization IV, V and Beyond Earth, yet this game has completely disposed of that feeling.Overall Synopsis: Very disappointed. Hopefully more content will be added soon that makes the game more playable. Without that, the game really has very little play value, let alone replay value.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is just not a fun game. I had hoped that they would have been able to find the fun again from Civ4, but no such luck. The magic is gone from the Civ games. Very disappointing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Terrible, broken AI. Repetitive, boring gameplay, and lackluster design. Fog of war is distracting, and confusing. Lacking a variety of gameplay options. Lack of late game content.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Well... Civilization VI. I was really hyped and eagerly waited for it's release, so much so, that I purchased the Digital Deluxe and therefore own all DLC's up to Persia & Macedonia.I will go through the positive stuff first, from the obvious and superficial downwards:The good StuffCiv Vi is a game. Some might consider it's style "Childish" and "Casual mobile" but it looks well made in that regard and has a number of little animations like spinning Watermills, doves over your Holy Sites and nice Movement Animations for Units. The Effects are again cartoony, but in a good way that fits the general Artstyle.Same goes for the they show thier Emotions clearly and whatever they say correspondes to thier animations. Good Job.The is brilliant and requires forward thinking planning to get all the bonusses, the usage of mountains that unlike in Civ V nowMaybe a bit too much so, as wonders take space as well now, so you are basically doomed to know wich victory you want to achive (If you play with enabled victories, I myself turn them off pretty often) and know exactly how you want to set your city up before you even settle it. Apart from that, the system is highly encouraging and entertaining at all times.the System of Eurekas and Inspirations is great and makes science feel more directed than in Civ V. That's actually really good.The You can throw units together to make them stronger! Great! Unfortunally, there is no visual feedback except for...three tiny stars, so thats sad. Show us that there are more unites or ships involved! Fix pls.Well that's good.Now for the or as I like to call itObviously, the . The I has no buissness here. IT's entirely disruptive, the Civs have no personality in how and where they settle, dispite the wich are a nice Ida, but in reality, are just different reasons for the A"I" to declare war on you.Everything they do is to hurt and hinder you, esspecially in how they settle:This in a Late Aplha, Early Beta State and has hardly improved over five months. Which is dumb.Oh and they cheat like every terrible player.The Is inconvenient. It's not bad, just not good. Why do you make it needlessly hard?Pointless and I have no goddarn Idea why certain bugs where left in from October and have just been fixed. WHY?`There is no point to the Digital Deluxe, because the fist DLC is worthless. Firaxis has been pumping out DLC without fixing thier darn game.Last Point!404 Not Found. DLC Factions Like Poland (Can now into Space) and Australia have culture shock abilities wich are just the worst. The steal Land. Alexander?Never stop conquesting. The Azects? Sure let them build everything in no time.England? You mean that one Civ that never survives? And who and what is a Kongo? Ohhh, the ones that declare war on everyone for not getting all religion are wiped out really early.The Civs are just extremly pooly balanced. Why, just why Firaxis.It is an ok game for now, but I can't truly recommend it as it stands now.The mistakes made by Firaxis are dumb and pointless, by the way.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As a fan of CIV, since CIV III, this game is total trash.They left out the best part! Tech tree is not even near of tech tree of CIV V, and the diplomacy is ♥♥♥♥ed up.AI is one of the worst, CIV I had better AI.Disapointed...

title: Not Recommended
comment: Visual design of the game is the worst of several iterations. The AI is utterly broken. Want to use some diplomacy? Bad luck, everyone hates you because you have no ships on a landlocked map or some other equally tedious BS. Have gone back to Civ V, hopefully the devs fix this bad game in the next DLC.

comment: I can't believe they managed to make Ghandi EVEN MORE nuke happy."Can't you see? Nuclear technology is the future!" -Ghandi 2800BCOk Ghandi...Districts and wonders taking up a tile are a great addition, but, between mods never working, the somehow devolving AI, and unit movement taking forever, play civ 5 instead.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Stay away from this game. There are many bad reviews for this game, and I ignored them... much to my regret now. Better to stay with Civ 5 BNW. Maybe, and that's a big maybe, this game will be worth playing after 2K fixes all the problems. I regret not listening to the reviews.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ 6 is a great game, that's more dynamic and enjoyable than Civ 5, especially vanilla Civ 5. People who are leaving ratings are complaining about bad diplomacy, (which is fair because diplomacy is always terrible in Civ games) but this is the best diplomacy that a Civilization game has ever had for its AI. They're also complaining about barbarians, science, and production imbalance. Yeah, there are things that could be improved (and they will be as expansions come out; look at the difference between vanilla Civ V and Brave New World) but I've played this game a bunch and it isn't as bad as people are making it out to be. If you don't like the barbarians, turn them off, but it's not hard to defeat them.Half of the reviewers are just mad that they have to buy some of the civilizations as a DLC. The simple solution is to not buy the DLC; the game will run just the same. The other half of reviewers must just be bad at strategy games. Complaining that you end up fighting spearman with tanks means that you're playing on too low of a difficulty. If you're taking the time to learn the new district system, challenge yourself on the higher difficulty setting, and think strategically, you'll be just fine.

title: Not Recommended
comment: There's a good game in here, somewhere, beneath all of it's flaws.The problem is that the game is simply buried in flaws - we're now over six months after release, and very few critical gameplay issues have actually been addressed; the AI is still incapable of using naval and air units, diplomacy is pointless, and basic things like gold income and trading are completely broken.Civ 6 is a reasonable iteration from it's predecessors, but the game is sorely lacking any real new game mechanics, other than the district system, which is a shame - it's essentially Civ 5 with cobbled-together mechanics inhereted from Civ: BE. It has huge balance issues between Civs, and a bizarre system where each time you construct a distict, the price of the next one of the same type becomes more expensive - rendering late game expansion completely impossible.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It is as if they purposely did not include features that made civ 5 playable, just to add them in later. No alert. Poor threat recognition. You cannot zoom out far enough. No mod support. Auto unit cycling, but with a lag. So if you act to fast then you just told the wrong unit to move.Plus, it is buggy. In big ways like CTD, but worse in little ways. Archers suddenly closing it to attack when they could have at range. Units that cannot skip turn unless the move first. Units that refuse to cancel or wake up until the next turn (terribly annoying with the unit cycling.)I am sure I'll love it post mod support, but right now it is uninstalled.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Quickly :Score14/20Gameplay 15/20Lifespan 18/20Scenario --/20Soundtrack 16/20Graphics 17/20Extra blabla :No. This is nowhere close to Civ IV or V...Is it a bad game ? No.Is it a great game on par with its predecessors ? NO !Red thumb cuz i'm rating a civ game here, it's supposed to be a least awesome.AI Is awful. SP quickly becomes boring.New tech/social trees, may sound like refreshing and relevant concepts, but they just poor af.Won't speak about the new road design system and the MPU know what ? u want a good civ experience ? Start with the 5th. That's it. Ofc this one still has that addictive effect like the previous ones, but it might give you the wrong idea of the serie.Just be careful with this game, i bitterly regret spendin 50 bucks on this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is total crap. UI, non functional. AI - still a joke. Gameplay? What gameplay? Crashes, bugs - and have I mentioned the BS AI? I've loved Civ for years, played every version of it - until now.

title: Recommended
comment: Product received for freeGood ol humble bundle!

title: Not Recommended
comment: I will start of by saying this is my first review of a game on steam.I just feel the need to point out glaring issues with this game that I am sorelydissapointed with.Pros:+ Graphics are nice and clean+ Duel tech trees+ Trading builds roads between cities+ Ability to mix and match civic bonus cards as needed+ Great people are limited and shared globaly+ Music and sounds are much improved+Many more diplomatic options (although this is also a con becausethey do not work correctly)Cons:- AI is horrible. There is no logic in the choices it makes. Alliances mean nothing as the AI will attack you anyway.- Turns take forever. I have a high end system and in the mid to late game I have time to do other things between turns.- Wonders take up valuble city space and are usually not worth the trouble.- Farms are just farms. There is no way to upgrade them late game as room is needed for more districts.- workers a expendable units. They have a limited number of things they can build. This is not really a con but theamount they can build for the cost is horrible unless you use cards to increse the amount.- The spy system is horrible. Too much micromanagement on the defensive end. You never have enough spy slotsto even protect one city.- There is no way to protect trade routes. Barbarians just use fast scouts and pillige them constantly as they spawn like crazy. Would be nice to be able to add escourt units attached to the trades.- war weariness is poorly designed, If you are on the defensive side of a conflict this should be minimal unless,you are loosing units and things are being pillaged. I was attack by 2 AI and never lost a unit and only had 2 minespillaged but my war weariness was so high my production almost stopped and I have riots breaking out like crazy.This should be a gradual incline as well. Not something that happens instantly. This game mechanic seems superflawed imo on alot of counts.This game is still playable. I just think this issues need to be corrected for it to be more enjoyable.For now though I cannot recommend this in it's current state.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have decided to rewrite this review for several reasons, reason one, I don't think I went into enough detail with the oringnal review, reason two, I didn't show everything the game had to offer, reason three, in the oringnal review I think I too harsh on the game. Those are my reason's for rewriting this, I know the last one will probably be critized, but this time I want to provide a more balanced review. BTW I don't think that the game deserves the unilateral support among the Major "reviewers" and I think the game can succed but it needs a more critical look at it, this is not a bad thing. Anyways on with the review.1. The Ai.There is no way to defend the terrible AI the game launched with it does not know how to (among other things) codinate attacks, manage it's economy, start a rational war and use the new system, this is indefenceable and needs to immediately fixed. Of course their not going to, but hay better to point it out then not, right.2. The new systems.The statistics for the new systems (codeword for I made them up) is that 70% had potential but failed miserabley (insert great people and religion system) 10% Failed completly (cough agenda cough) and 20% were alright (aka the new "diplomacy"). I think the main problam here is that they had the right ideas but did not take it and played it safe, this means that some of the new machanics could have been so much better an example is the diplomacy, the diplomacy is bare bones to say the least but could have been so much more, you could have diplomcy with power blocs, federations and confederations, multi national agreements, a bigger roll for nuclear weapons ect, the ideas are endlees yet they kept the civilzation Vish diplomacy, They either 1. believe that civilization 5 diplomacy was good: unlikely, 2. they were too imcompatant to fix it: very unlikly, 3. Capitialism sucks: very likely, also very sad but hay at least it's not stalin, wait how did I get to stalin from civ 6 diplomacy, weird. Anyways that is basically the same for all systems, lots of potential but it was wasted.3. City States diplomacyThis is a step in the right direction, but is still a short fall, sorta. The idea that city states shoud be earned through diplomacy rather then money is a good step forward and the idea that for each layer of support you get rewards is one of the ideas that is actually a good one. However there are problems for example yes there is a tier reward system but once you get 6 there is no reason to continue, ways to imporve on this system is to make it so that you only get the bonuses from city-states if you are the surzeain of the city-state, and add new types of city-states ect.4. Armed forces.The game does do some good here, the corp and army system have potential, the ability to stack units is a nice feature, barbarians are not the best part of the game but still better then in civ 5 and you have to have the dooms day weapons (nukes). However there is still a lot that could be improved upon for example you could make the economy, governmnet and military more interconneted, so you need a strong economy and political support a war, overwise you will risk turning the populace a against you, you could also add real reasons for war I mean the casus beli they have now is lack luster to say the least, the way to fix this to is to add new reasons, for example disarmerment, government change and puppet ect. You could also have make spies have a larger in combat, create a logistics system for supplies, have an army cap based on population and add a war economy, which would redirect the economy into war mode.5. Government and politicasThe government system is not to great, it has the up side of being a massive leap forward but has the down side of being, like the rest of the game, not being took to it's full potential. For example they could add new governments like constitutional monarchy, republic and anarchy ect, they could add a parliament system and political parties along with it, budgets that are approved, elections ect the options are endless and you can do it, but they did not do that with it instead they kept it bare bones.Other things at a glanceday/night cycle- good idea, but they could add a climate and season/weather system and natural disasters.Districts- good idea on paper, not so much in reality, could use some improvement but not that bad.Religion- despartly needs reform and has potential.Great people- Good idea and could use some improvment but alround pretty good.Builders- not bother about it.And that is it if there is anythi- Oh yeah the "DLC" thing this is the most anogying thing, i am not going after the game on this one, but 2k's business practices, the fact that they can sell the game at full price and still charge for dlc is discracful so yeah don't buy it. EVER.That is it I mean it this time.

title: Not Recommended

I've somehow declared war on myself and had war declared on me by an unencountered civilization. Had a friendly AI complain about nearby miliatry units, I had a shared border but no nearby units.

title: Not Recommended

Every. single. game. turns out like this. The diplomacy ruins this game. Any slight changes they made to gameplay and builders from civ v are overshadowed by the terrible diplomacy. Id also like to point out that the AI program is really lazy. The difference between different levels of AI is how much free stuff they are given. For a game that is mostly a single player game, the AI should at least be decent.

title: Not Recommended

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game is much too broken the more it is patched. Unless you want the frustration of having to resign 10 turns into the game at deity level because the AI declares war on turn 5 with their starting units, or because of a massive swarm of barbarian horsemen, don't bother with this installment of the Civ series. Too much restarting to be of any fun.The game seems to think it chooses the best settling position for your starting settler, but it doesn't. The settling recommendations are horrible (what was intended to be noob-friendly ended up being quite useless 90% of the time because the algorithm does not take into account eureka-triggering resources, and overall path of tech... where one is forced to beeline archery no matter what the case is, if not because of aggressive AI, and mind you 90% of them are aggressive in stark contrast to BNW, OR simply because of barbarians), and the balanced start option is far from balanced.The AI leader screens are made cartoonish and overall looked cheap as if no effort was made into designing them (compared to Civ V BNW's for example), the music overall, aside from the opening theme, is not as good as the previous installments. What is good about this game is that the map graphics, especially those of natural wonders, look great. But overall, as a fan of the Civ series, this latest one leaves a lot to be desired in terms of strategy and balance.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So, watch my profile. I play allot of civ... thats why this will be especially painful. The fact that you have to pay for DLCs that does not work properly - REALLY bothers me. This isnt a total shredding, dont get me wrong. The game is in itself good and has a solid platform that will last for many years to come, bringing hours on hours of joyous gametime with multplayer (when aspyr eventually get the cross-platform running) with fully functional ad-ons, maps, scenarios, etc. Making civ a cash cow and publishing `nearly there games` will eventually the determening factors that turns fans to other ad-ventures. Would I recommend this game right now....? No.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I wish I'd taken the negative reviews a little more seriously before wasting money on this game. As other reviewers indicate the AI is incredibly buggy. I've only played a few games and am finding the poor AI and what appears to be bad background coding is making the game unplayable. My first game (which I expected to lose) declared me the winner of a cultural victory at turn 41. Um. Okay. Thanks I guess? The next declared my AI opponent the winner for reasons I couldn't determine (at turn 110). I thought I'd try again - at turn 21 my AI opponent declared me incompetent and denounced me. Well. Fine then.It appears to me that whatever metric the game uses to drive the AI isn't in sync with the actual game state. AI comments in early game relate to later game events or states.I can't speak for multiplayer - perhaps the game is meant for that and the single player component wasn't tested properly.

title: Not Recommended
comment: this game would be a ton of fun if it actually worked when i played it, really dissapointed that all it does non stop is crash crash crash for any number of reasons.

comment: Just a few words.Pros: New city building system really rocks.Cons: Very few civs, terrible AI, discussable graphics, broken diplomacy (all hail warmongers!), horrible perfomance, no teams in multiplayer.Verdict: totally not worth its money.UPD: Well, at least (and at last) they added teamplay.

title: Recommended
comment: Based on 80+ hours throughout multiple Deity difficulty games.Civilization VI has a lot to live up to, most obviously its predecessor Civilization V.Through the use of the excellent district mechanic and various reworked older elements such as great people, spies and religion it has introduced a lot more inherent conflict that wasn't previously present. As such, I've enjoyed every single victory condition (Science, Domination, Religion and Culture) more than I have before.It still suffers from poor AI (now especially noticable due to the poorly executed agenda system) and sadly Civilization VI has suffered in the UI department as well, but regardless I've highly enjoyed my time and can definitely say it is a great basegame worthy of your time.Full review:

title: Not Recommended
comment: As a long-time fan of the Civ series, I can say that this a solid game. I won't fill this review with long explanations of the differences between VI and other Civ games... or with listing pros and cons. Rather, I'm just going to say that the entire experience is ruined by the unacceptable amount of time that the game takes to calculate each. Especially in the late game, even with animations turned off, the game takes 20 seconds, 30 seconds, 45 seconds, or even a full minute to calculate each turn. For this day and age, for a AAA game released from a major studi, this delay is unreasonable and shocking. I would expect each turn to take a few seconds at most.... a full minute is madness and ruins the experience. I can't take it... I'd refund if I could.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It is as if they purposely did not include features that made civ 5 playable, just to add them in later. No alert. Poor threat recognition. You cannot zoom out far enough. No mod support. Auto unit cycling, but with a lag. So if you act to fast then you just told the wrong unit to move.Plus, it is buggy. In big ways like CTD, but worse in little ways. Archers suddenly closing it to attack when they could have at range. Units that cannot skip turn unless the move first. Units that refuse to cancel or wake up until the next turn (terribly annoying with the unit cycling.)I am sure I'll love it post mod support, but right now it is uninstalled.

title: Recommended
comment: Product received for freeI don't write many reviews on steam but being a well seasoned Civ player I decided to do this for once.Positives:- New Styled Graphics; the cartoony goofy graphics provides a fresh new start to Civ, unlike Civ Beyond Earth, which gave new graphics but went the wrong direction. Although it will be a shock for Civ 5 players, and will take a while to adjust, it will nevertheless bring nostalgic memories to older Civ players.- Gameplay change; unlike Civ 5, this game will bring a larger focus on city building, letting you decide what you would mould your empire to become; cultural, militaristic or religious? Unlike previous installments, where the city with the biggest production produces everything, you have to more carefully decide what "district" you will build.Negatives:-Diplomacy; AI is still ♥♥♥♥ed, and declares war every century. Even Gandhi seem to be the most warmongering on the game from what I have seen (although this is the case for every Civ game for some reason) but I still hope this will be patched.-Borders; Just a small tweak but the borders are hard to differenciate from each other. A simple coloured line marks your territory. I played a game as China vs Japan and I could hardly tell the difference between our cities and empires. This is maybe because I am used to all territory to have a colour but I believe I will adjust to this.-Warfare: Although focus has been taking on infrastructure I can't help but notice that the quality of warfare has been dropped. Not only are enemies practically unconquerable until you get the Artillery unit but they also seem to be spamming units that provide buffer making it impossible to reach their cities. This again might be the AI's fault but I still appreciate they added new support units like Medic and Engineer. I also like the idea of combining units to form corps and armies, even though combining them does not provide double the damage which one might think.Conclusion:Overall this game provides a relief from Beyond Earth, and with some few patches on the AI this game will be a genuin success to the franchise.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I will start of by saying this is my first review of a game on steam.I just feel the need to point out glaring issues with this game that I am sorelydissapointed with.Pros:+ Graphics are nice and clean+ Duel tech trees+ Trading builds roads between cities+ Ability to mix and match civic bonus cards as needed+ Great people are limited and shared globaly+ Music and sounds are much improved+Many more diplomatic options (although this is also a con becausethey do not work correctly)Cons:- AI is horrible. There is no logic in the choices it makes. Alliances mean nothing as the AI will attack you anyway.- Turns take forever. I have a high end system and in the mid to late game I have time to do other things between turns.- Wonders take up valuble city space and are usually not worth the trouble.- Farms are just farms. There is no way to upgrade them late game as room is needed for more districts.- workers a expendable units. They have a limited number of things they can build. This is not really a con but theamount they can build for the cost is horrible unless you use cards to increse the amount.- The spy system is horrible. Too much micromanagement on the defensive end. You never have enough spy slotsto even protect one city.- There is no way to protect trade routes. Barbarians just use fast scouts and pillige them constantly as they spawn like crazy. Would be nice to be able to add escourt units attached to the trades.- war weariness is poorly designed, If you are on the defensive side of a conflict this should be minimal unless,you are loosing units and things are being pillaged. I was attack by 2 AI and never lost a unit and only had 2 minespillaged but my war weariness was so high my production almost stopped and I have riots breaking out like crazy.This should be a gradual incline as well. Not something that happens instantly. This game mechanic seems superflawed imo on alot of counts.This game is still playable. I just think this issues need to be corrected for it to be more enjoyable.For now though I cannot recommend this in it's current state.

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization VI is a great example of how to evolve great game mechanics. New Additions to the ruleset and changes to different mechanics make it a good game to add to your library.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ 6 is a great game, that's more dynamic and enjoyable than Civ 5, especially vanilla Civ 5. People who are leaving ratings are complaining about bad diplomacy, (which is fair because diplomacy is always terrible in Civ games) but this is the best diplomacy that a Civilization game has ever had for its AI. They're also complaining about barbarians, science, and production imbalance. Yeah, there are things that could be improved (and they will be as expansions come out; look at the difference between vanilla Civ V and Brave New World) but I've played this game a bunch and it isn't as bad as people are making it out to be. If you don't like the barbarians, turn them off, but it's not hard to defeat them.Half of the reviewers are just mad that they have to buy some of the civilizations as a DLC. The simple solution is to not buy the DLC; the game will run just the same. The other half of reviewers must just be bad at strategy games. Complaining that you end up fighting spearman with tanks means that you're playing on too low of a difficulty. If you're taking the time to learn the new district system, challenge yourself on the higher difficulty setting, and think strategically, you'll be just fine.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 4.5/10I'm udpating my review because the game is several patches in now, but unfortunately I can't change the score or my recommendation against buying the game. This is a shame because I still feel it has a lot of potential, but the patches released so far haven't done anything to address the fundamental problems with it. At best, Civ VI is still only tolerable to play for a brief period of time. Instead of "just one more turn before I quit," it's "can I force myself to take one more turn before I quit." A game shouldn't be an experience you tolerate. A root canal is an experience you have to tolerate. Games are supposed to be fun, and VI just isn't. I still can't recommend anyone spend their money on this.The fundamental problem remains that the lead designer, Ed Beach, didn't want to make a Civ game. What do I mean by that? The prior games in the franchise were randomized 4X sandbox games that emphasized empire building and management. Warfare was always a major aspect, but Ed Beach apparently wanted to make a straight up war game instead. So what he did was rig the game. Pretty much every aspect of it - from diplomacy to map seeding - is artificially weighted to make sure that AI always has a reason to hate the human player and constantly declares war.The end result of Ed Beach's ham fisted scripting makes every time you play feel exactly the same. Oh, the map and what civilzations you're playing against may change, but that's pretty much it. It's ALWAYS going to play out the same. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. By rigging the game so that the hostile AI will always declare war on you, he's turned Civ into the war game he wanted to make. You'll find youself forced to repeat the same military focused strategies every time you play. Each playthrough of prior Civ games was a different experience, and replayability has always been one of it's major selling points. Without that, the base game isn't worthy anywhere near it's heafty price tag.Pros:District System = I like unstacking the cities and the accompanying adjacency bonuses. It adds a whole new layer of strategic planning to the game. On an aesthetic level, it also gives cities a grander scale and makes them feel more like actual cities.City-States = City-states have been revamped, and have their own new diplomatic system involving assigning them envoys. As more envoys are assigned, new levels of perks are unlocked (bonuses to the capital, bonuses to districts, etc.). These bonuses are pretty generic among the different types of city-states until you reach the top level and become their suzerin (overlord). Each city state now has it's own unique top level bonus at that level that range from Lisbon giving extra gold on trade routes to a special tile improvement from La Venta, giving each a unique value.New Government System = The new government system was one of the things I was most put off by when they previewed it, but it's rapidly become one of my favorite new features allowing for greater customization and specific focus on the player's goals.Cons:Map Generation: Smaller map sizes are now larger, but larger map sizes are now smaller. It makes sense on the smaller maps since cities play wide instead of tall now, but larger maps are now too small. My biggest complaint, though, is is now a default to ensure another civ will spawn no more than X number of tiles from the player. This is set up to force early game conflict with an AI that is much more aggressive than in prior versions of the game. I don't like this at all. I - like I imagine most long time players - play for a random experience, not to be forced to follow some script the dev thinks I should. Because of this, you'll end up restarting over and over again until you get a map where you're not completely surrounded since the map generator jams city-state and civ starting locations so close together it feels like it's trying to play Tetris with them.Removal of Basic Features and Player Control: I squarely blame Ed Beach for this. He's on record in the preview videos hyping up the removal of certain features so it's a more "dynamic" experience and players have to "pay more attention." When the game released, the hostile unit alert was removed and has now been patched back in after complaints form the community, one of Ed Beach's innovations to make the player "pay more attention." At least now if a barbarian horde or enemy army shows up next to one of your fortified units, the game actually tells you. It's one of the few "positive" updates, diminished by the fact it should have been included in the game at launch. Barbarians now can't tap dance past your warrior waving spartklers without them noticing. I still can't figured what possessed him or anyone else on the design team to think this was "dynamic" instead of just being obnoxious. It's particularly annoying since the game decides it knows what you need to be looking at and constantly jerks the camera around.City growth is another major issue. After the first patch, we can finally see which tile is going to be claimed next, but the player has no control over it. All you can do is sit there and curse under your breath when you see it's going to claim a useless tile instead of a resource it could claim. There seems to be no rhym or reason to the tiles it chooses. I've seen it bypass four resource tiles - silk, horses, copper and iron - to claim an ocean tile with no resources anywhere near it. In a game about building and developing an empire, the player should have the option to manually control this. Making it random doesn't add depth, it's just handicapping the player under the false pretense of adding "challenge". This still hasn't been fixed.Barbarians: The new barbarian system is still buggy, they spawn far too early and too often. I've had three barbarian camps spawn around my capital, and been under seige by two of them by turn 7 on Prince. I've also watched camps spawn on the same tiles outside my borders over and over again after I've cleared them unless I postition a unit so it's in line of sight. If the camps keep spawing in the same locations over and over again, it's not random. It's another feature for some reason they felt needed to be scripted.Religion: In prior versions of the game, this was left to expansions and I wish it had been here. I can understand from a design perspective that it made sense to build it into the base game. With the new district system, there is now a religious districts and it makes sense to get all your districts - part of the basic mechanics - into the base game. That said, religion is broken and over-weighted.The new religious combat system is tedious and depending on what AI opponents you're facing you'll spend more time in religious combat than military combat. We also now have a Religious Victory. Quite frankly, this should be cut from the game. I'm fairly certain they only reason it's included was to justify all the work spent on religion when Diplomatic victory was left out of the game and so many other areas were crying out for more work. The religious victory mechanics now make it possible for you to loose to an AI player you haven't even met yet. The ability to achieve religious victory depends far to heavily on starting location and who is closest to the majority of civs. It feels clumsy and poorly implemented.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Well... Civilization VI. I was really hyped and eagerly waited for it's release, so much so, that I purchased the Digital Deluxe and therefore own all DLC's up to Persia & Macedonia.I will go through the positive stuff first, from the obvious and superficial downwards:The good StuffCiv Vi is a pretty game. Some might consider it's style "Childish" and "Casual mobile" but it looks well made in that regard and has a number of little animations like spinning Watermills, doves over your Holy Sites and nice Movement Animations for Units. The Effects are again cartoony, but in a good way that fits the general Artstyle.Same goes for the Leaders they show thier Emotions clearly and whatever they say correspondes to thier animations. Good Job.The unstacking of cities is brilliant and requires forward thinking planning to get all the bonusses, the usage of mountains that unlike in Civ V now feel like they actually do somethingMaybe a bit too much so, as wonders take space as well now, so you are basically doomed to know wich victory you want to achive (If you play with enabled victories, I myself turn them off pretty often) and know exactly how you want to set your city up before you even settle it. Apart from that, the system is highly encouraging and entertaining at all times.the System of Eurekas and Inspirations is great and makes science feel more directed than in Civ V. That's actually really good.The You can throw units together to make them stronger! Great! Unfortunally, there is no visual feedback except for...three tiny stars, so thats sad. Show us that there are more unites or ships involved! Fix pls.Well that's good.Now for the or as I like to call itObviously, the . The I has no buissness here. IT's entirely disruptive, the Civs have no personality in how and where they settle, dispite the wich are a nice Ida, but in reality, are just different reasons for the A"I" to declare war on you.Everything they do is to hurt and hinder you, esspecially in how they settle:This in a Late Aplha, Early Beta State and has hardly improved over five months. Which is dumb.Oh and they cheat like every terrible player.The Is inconvenient. It's not bad, just not good. Why do you make it needlessly hard?Pointless and I have no goddarn Idea why certain bugs where left in from October and have just been fixed. WHY?`There is no point to the Digital Deluxe, because the fist DLC is worthless. Firaxis has been pumping out DLC without fixing thier darn game.Last Point!404 Not Found. DLC Factions Like Poland (Can now into Space) and Australia have culture shock abilities wich are just the worst. The steal Land. Alexander?Never stop conquesting. The Azects? Sure let them build everything in no time.England? You mean that one Civ that never survives? And who and what is a Kongo? Ohhh, the ones that declare war on everyone for not getting all religion are wiped out really early.The Civs are just extremly pooly balanced. Why, just why Firaxis.It is an ok game for now, but I can't truly recommend it as it stands now.The mistakes made by Firaxis are dumb and pointless, by the way.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is so much better than Civ 5 was on release and even with G&K added as well as some of BNW.The graphics style resembles Endless Legend more than it does a mobile title, which is really refreshing compared to Civ 5's muted, clustered, and almost drowned out coloration, which makes it a very beautiful terrain and map.The AI is little different from civ 5 which doesn't bother me all too much, that familiarity is nice to have for me.Religion is a base mechanic and actually useful beyond Industrial Era, which is a big noting point for me. Also likewise espeionage is in the base game, and more useful than just spying on other civs and city states.Dealing with city states is better than before where you'd just throw money at them to be allies or hope you'd get a quest you can actually do.Also likewise the fighting and waging war was revamped but I haven't looked too much into it, but I can say it is more streamlined than what Civ 5 had.It's also pretty bug free, at least 10% of the playerbase has issues but I've found none so far, this is one of the cleanest releases of 2016.Gee Greece, how come Firaxis lets you have TWO leaders!?So yea I like it, this game is amazing, a worthy addition to the Civ series, but the $60 selling price is very steep, but considering that this came out October recently, you could nab it in your Christmas shopping.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been playing since Civ II. I've owned every game, and expansion there is, and I've loved it, until now. I also paid $80 for it, and I wasted my money. I'm not happy, so all of my thoughts are not articulated well in the below review.The Cons:1. I find it boring - Yes, boring. From Civ II to Civ V, I would stay up way later than I should and play, because I had to "just get the next turn done." But this one, isn't fun, it's boring. Mostly because all of the challenge has been removed. It's as if I'm just grinding like I would in an MMORPG, or Assassin's Creed (the new ones). It's a tragedy! Perhaps Firaxis is attempting to cater to console and facebook mobile gamers, but it's the wrong direction.2. Don't care for the graphics - The map and land and units are nice, the interface is ok. It's the people, striving for realism has been a "thing" for 20 years. Now, they look like Pixar cartoon characters. I'm interested in a game that has 100% focus on the adventure of building an empire, not how the leaders look. It seems as if, a nice package was more important than gameplay.3. This is just going to be an array of bad things: Can't re-name cities. Can't change unit names, once named. Movement is worse, and roads do almost nothing. I feel like it's a facebook game. Took me 30 minutes to figure out my unit cost. The game is sluggish. It's task based almost (elimination of the RPG part).4. And why I wrote the review: The Civilopedia, is terrible - there's no information that's useful, they got super lazy with that one. For the newbies, this is important, because sometimes for planning purposes it's important to know unit upgrades and progression, before you start to upgrade units.5. The AI is insane, and has absolutely no logic operators whatsoever, they act completely randomly. I declared war on myself, and got a warmonger penalty (WTF?) - this happened, but I didn't declare it, a screen popped up and just told me I was at war with myself. Perhaps a bug, but these people should know a thing or two about releasing a working game. The AI seemingly have no reason for disliking you or liking you. I run a peaceful game, but as TR said: "Walk softly, and carry a big stick." I'm peaceful, isolationist, but I carry with me a mighty wrath - I will destroy a civ that attacks me first. It's just how I play. I had four civ's declare war on me and I was able to lay waste to all four of them before 430BC. The sad part, not only did I not provoke them, nor did I have a government or policies they disliked, it's like they bugged out and went to war. I'm playing on Deity! Worse yet: No matter what decisions I make, the AI will always react the same. The AI should be far more intuitive and trading and diplomacy should be better at this point, it's worse than the diplomacy in Civ III. I should feel like I'm dealing with real world leaders, not angry school children (I understand the irony in that statement).6. Unit stacking is a no go. I understand limiting unit stacks to create a challenge. But at least let me stack a couple of combat units in one hex for organizational purposes. This was a bad feature in Civ IV, and V and a worse feature here.7. The Barbarians are a bigger threat than any civilization, and they're everywhere. This is a con and a pro - the biggest con is that they're more dangerous than a civilization. The pro is that they're a challenge, and I love it.8. Where is the demographic screen?9. What were you thinking with city states? Poorly executed.The Pros: What's good?1. The Policy interface is awesome, as is the entire new government interface. The policies are now like technology - good job.2. Leader traits have improved.3. Diplomacy interface is better4. Barbarians are more intense.Unfortunately, the good doesn't outweigh the bad. The game is buggy, slow, and not executed well at all. I hope this gets better in the next few patches. At this time, I will not, and cannot recommend this game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I think Civ6 is the worst game in the whole series.I never was a big fan of the hexagonal map or of removing unit stacking in Civ5. But Civ5 was a playable game.On top of that Civ6 has the mutitile cities (unnecessary, in my view), an annoying and useless diplomacy, a really stupid AI and a awfull UI.When I was younger I always imagined the new Civ games would get even closer to reality and away from this board game approach. But that never happened.I miss the city view, unit stacking, square map tiles, single tile things (remember, a tile respresents an imense amount of land) and challenging AI.But this is only my view point. Go ahead, play the game and then form your opinion.However, I suggest you to play Civ4, the better game in the series :)

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am a huge CIV fan and own every game in the series since CIV 1 (And have played them all). More recently i clocked about 1000 h in CIV 5 , so Im not a newbee in any way.Starting CIV 6 had me all worked up and it looks relly good, although you can always question the graphic style choosen.But the gameplay.....Dead stupid AI, that does not even upgrade its troops.It is not clear (to me) what implications my actions will have. Its more just build "something" and they will come.I went for a space age victory in my recent game, but ended up with (what I think was, not very clear) a cultural victory 20 round before end. I did not pay ANY attention to culture. Very nice but please explain WHY ?I can only conclude that this installment needs some serious patching before it becomes playable, stay away for now.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is just awful. I love the district idea but the AI is broken, the "revised" art and cultures make it look like a 1st grader's "friends around the world" social studies project yet the AI is all war, all the time (disappointing if you want to, you know, build a civilization or something and not play something not quite entirely unlike chess. And letting "barbarians' have multi-step strategies and develop down the tech tree is just...not understanding what barbarians are, frankly. And maybe a little bit racist on top of that.I'd had some hope that the Rise and Fall expansion would fix some of that, but being in the group of people who bought the Digital Deluxe thinking that "all DLC" didn't mean "minor DLC only," I'm not inclined to throw good money after bad. Unless Civ VII is "Civ V with districts," I'm done with the whole series.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 4/10A lot of great ideas. Unpacking cities, great person tweaks. Even the barbarian raids are a cool addition. Could use some manual roads.Two things completely sink it: no crossplatform multiplayer, and abysmal ai and ui.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Can't recommend this game currently. There are some nice additions to the game, such as more challenging barbarians, finite workers and the interesting civic tree. However, some additions are not implemented well. For example, the AI is too angry - it becomes nearly impossible to uphold good relation. Furthermore, when playing on large/huge maps, I find that some AIs have barely done anything and only have 1 city and are 2/3 eras behind when I am in the modern era, and some civs have reached the atomic era before I have reached the industrial era. I think that the tech tree could do with some tweaking to help make it more balanced. For example, in Civ 5 the progression of the tech tree felt very fluent, so that I wouldn't have those 1/2 turn techs to research when I was 2 eras ahead. However, in Civ 6, it is too easy to just follow a single branch to get the tech that you want. You know there's something wrong when you can still produce seige towers in the modern era. I'm not a huge fan of districts, and find them more of a burden distracting from the pace of the game, but I do believe they have potential.EDIT: CTD bug fixedI would still be tempted to recommend this game if it were not for the bugs - gamebreaking bugs. I can't progress beyond ~ turn 200 as I get a CTD, so I'm unable to progress into the late game. This is honestly inexcusable, especially nearly a month after release. For this reason alone, I cannot recommend this game

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been playing since Civ II. I've owned every game, and expansion there is, and I've loved it, until now. I also paid $80 for it, and I wasted my money. I'm not happy, so all of my thoughts are not articulated well in the below review.The Cons:1. I find it boring - Yes, boring. From Civ II to Civ V, I would stay up way later than I should and play, because I had to "just get the next turn done." But this one, isn't fun, it's boring. Mostly because all of the challenge has been removed. It's as if I'm just grinding like I would in an MMORPG, or Assassin's Creed (the new ones). It's a tragedy! Perhaps Firaxis is attempting to cater to console and facebook mobile gamers, but it's the wrong direction.2. Don't care for the graphics - The map and land and units are nice, the interface is ok. It's the people, striving for realism has been a "thing" for 20 years. Now, they look like Pixar cartoon characters. I'm interested in a game that has 100% focus on the adventure of building an empire, not how the leaders look. It seems as if, a nice package was more important than gameplay.3. This is just going to be an array of bad things: Can't re-name cities. Can't change unit names, once named. Movement is worse, and roads do almost nothing. I feel like it's a facebook game. Took me 30 minutes to figure out my unit cost. The game is sluggish. It's task based almost (elimination of the RPG part).4. And why I wrote the review: The Civilopedia, is terrible - there's no information that's useful, they got super lazy with that one. For the newbies, this is important, because sometimes for planning purposes it's important to know unit upgrades and progression, before you start to upgrade units.5. The AI is insane, and has absolutely no logic operators whatsoever, they act completely randomly. I declared war on myself, and got a warmonger penalty (WTF?) - this happened, but I didn't declare it, a screen popped up and just told me I was at war with myself. Perhaps a bug, but these people should know a thing or two about releasing a working game. The AI seemingly have no reason for disliking you or liking you. I run a peaceful game, but as TR said: "Walk softly, and carry a big stick." I'm peaceful, isolationist, but I carry with me a mighty wrath - I will destroy a civ that attacks me first. It's just how I play. I had four civ's declare war on me and I was able to lay waste to all four of them before 430BC. The sad part, not only did I not provoke them, nor did I have a government or policies they disliked, it's like they bugged out and went to war. I'm playing on Deity! Worse yet: No matter what decisions I make, the AI will always react the same. The AI should be far more intuitive and trading and diplomacy should be better at this point, it's worse than the diplomacy in Civ III. I should feel like I'm dealing with real world leaders, not angry school children (I understand the irony in that statement).6. Unit stacking is a no go. I understand limiting unit stacks to create a challenge. But at least let me stack a couple of combat units in one hex for organizational purposes. This was a bad feature in Civ IV, and V and a worse feature here.7. The Barbarians are a bigger threat than any civilization, and they're everywhere. This is a con and a pro - the biggest con is that they're more dangerous than a civilization. The pro is that they're a challenge, and I love it.8. Where is the demographic screen?9. What were you thinking with city states? Poorly executed.The Pros: What's good?1. The Policy interface is awesome, as is the entire new government interface. The policies are now like technology - good job.2. Leader traits have improved.3. Diplomacy interface is better4. Barbarians are more intense.Unfortunately, the good doesn't outweigh the bad. The game is buggy, slow, and not executed well at all. I hope this gets better in the next few patches. At this time, I will not, and cannot recommend this game.

title: Not Recommended

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game has all the good aspects of civ. No happiness anymore as well as only needing 2 of any goven strategic resource to produce a unit. However late game is a sh*t show. There is no infinite queue so you have to micromanage every city which is a royal pain in the a** when you conquer the world on huge map and have (I kid you not) 25 cities that you need to choose a 1 turn production for ever. single. turn. This game would be so much better if they had the gold or research infinite queue for late game so you wouldn't have to micromanage. Lots of stuff is missing from this game such as beloved paratroopers, and lots of maps however it is still a giant improvement diplomacy wise over civ V however a lot of improvement needs to go into this game to still make it worth the money.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Too many conflicting game mechanics slammed together without proper testing. Not to meantion a serious lack of balancing and too much emphasis on military victory. I love the cultural development and how its separate to science allowing you to create a cultural utopia of cavemen. Perhaps they could have done religious development like this too? Purchasing units with faith seems to be out of place when compared to culture tech trees and the cards system. I like the idea of districts and having focused cities but REALLY? we have to use the city production to build it? It seems like the districts should form on their own at certain populations and be next to the city centre. Anyway enough rambling. The game feels like if you were to download 10 different overhaul mods and use them all at once. Many conflicts and focuses that create a cluster cluck. The Civs in the game are interesting but there's not nearly enough of them.As of a month ago the game simply wont run, Tried multiple fixes which didnt work. I feel i have spent more time trying to get the game working than actually playing the game.In sumary the game isn't bad or anything its just not as good as the other Civ games I have played. (Civ 3, 4, Revolutions, Colonisation, 5) Just go and buy any of the other Civ games mentioned and you would have a better game. Or just buy Civ 5... Oh and the other games actually work.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game have some strengths but overall its not a quality game as the others in the series.*No more can you have a 1 city civ challenge at all(unless you play on very easy settings)*Ai dont seem to follow the same rules as you the player in terms of Warmonger.You declare a "protectorate" war which is said to give none warmonger penalty, and yet typical peacemaker civs(USA/India/Australia will warn you about it, and even denounce you)While the AI on the other hand can declare war upon eachother without any real impact, Persia declare war on Greece last 50+ turns, then they declare peace and 4 turns later they are allied..So much of the concepts looks cool on paper, but dont really transform into a great experience ingame.Another thing that have actually made me reconsider any games comeing from this company from now on is how blatant greedy they have become in terms of DLC's, adding mechanics that one would expect to be includeed in the base game.Dlc's should add true new features or new civs(this part is good that they do), but so much of the things in the dlc's is just new mechancis that should have been there from the start.Also the removal of diplomatic victory is a step in the wrong direction imo.unless something dramatic changes for Civ VII(if it comes as it prolly will do) I will certainly not buy it..

title: Not Recommended
comment: Do they even test these games anymore?! Buggy, unbalanced, shallow. I've loved Civilization sice the first generation, but one week into this new adventure and I'm already bored.The problem as I see it is that Firaxis is not learning from their own history. Civ V vanilla came out and it was unbalanced, buggy, lacked depth... all in all, not nearly as good as Civ IV plus the expansions. And guess what, the same thing has happened in CIV VI. It took two expansions for Civ V to become a good game and several mods for it to become a great game. So why didn't they learn their lesson from their own previous expansions? Similarly, why didn't they incorporate elements from the most successful mods into their new game? They ignore their fan base, they don't test their games, they give us half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥released... this was a money grab pure and simple.I see a lot of people saying "wait for the expansion" or "don't worry, a mod will fix that" -- shouldn't the onus be on Firaxis to release a full gaming experience? Furthermore, why are we depending on UNPAID modders to fix the problems of an expensive triple-A game title? For $60 I expect a fairly high-end (polished) game. Civ V changed a lot of things from the previous version, so I can somewhat understand why it wasn't 100% on release... but Civ VI just feels like a really dull version of Civ V. The removed a bunch of the depth that made Civ V great and only gave us a couple of game mechanics that seem like good ideas on paper but don't currently work together to increase the levels of enjoyment in the game itself.The game play is unbalanced, the graphics are a HUGE step backwards (looks like some freemium mobile game), the AI managed to get worse, the civs are boring, diplomacy is useless, religion is annoying... and basically it feels like they've nerfed most of the things that made Civ V so great."Wait for the expansions" how about wait for the bargain bin because right now this game is nowhere near where Civ V left off.

title: Recommended
comment: Based on 80+ hours throughout multiple Deity difficulty games.Civilization VI has a lot to live up to, most obviously its predecessor Civilization V.Through the use of the excellent district mechanic and various reworked older elements such as great people, spies and religion it has introduced a lot more inherent conflict that wasn't previously present. As such, I've enjoyed every single victory condition (Science, Domination, Religion and Culture) more than I have before.It still suffers from poor AI (now especially noticable due to the poorly executed agenda system) and sadly Civilization VI has suffered in the UI department as well, but regardless I've highly enjoyed my time and can definitely say it is a great basegame worthy of your time.Full review:
