title: Not Recommended
comment: First off, let me say that I have been a civ player since the very first game. I love the series and have stuck with it throughout its many iterations. I will continue to stick with it, even though I am mildly disappointed with this first version of civ 6. I may not be recommending this game right now, but, much like civ 5, I see the potential in this game to be something great after some much needed changes.-Districts: Why do these take so much production to build? Why can't their placement be cancelled in case the player makes a mistake (when no production has even been put in yet)? Why does the cost of a district increase as the game goes on? Modern construction technology should ease the creation of a district rather than make it more difficult to produce. This is an unrealistic and silly aspect of the game. It should be a steady, cheap cost the entire game. Furthermore, add in tooltips better explaining adjacency bonuses for players who don't know how to find the useful (player-made) guides on reddit or wikipedia.-Spies: I like the fact that spies defend a specific district and any adjacent districts. This encourages better city planning. However, why do spies need new orders every few turns? There should be a spy overview that allows you unassign and re-assign spies when needed, rather than being constantly prompted every few turns. This is unnecessary micromanagement that detracts from the flow of the game.-Trade Routes: Tying in with spies, why are trade routes constantly an issue? Why not allow the player to set a trade route and then cancel it when they want to rather than being forced to renew them every 10 turns or so. Late game, with over 10 trade routes going at a time, you will spend a good chunk of your time micromanaging these trade routes rather than dealing with more interesting aspects of the game. Give the player the ability to choose when/if they want to deal with this rather than forcing it down their throats every 10 turns.-Units: Why do fortified units look practically identical to units that have simply used up their movement for the turn? Previous civ games have changed the shape of the unit's icon to better visually indicate that the unit is fortified. Why can't units go on Alert rather than just Sleep or Fortify? Why do chained units require an order for each unit in the chain? Shouldn't they be controlled as a stack with the option to control separately rather than forcing separate activation?-Cities: Why is there no building queue? Every single 4x game out there has a building queue. Why can't buildings be rushed or bought out any more?-Wonders: Why is there no refund for failed attempts at building a wonder? What, the dead building just disappears and no resources are harvested from it? Why can't wonder construction be cancelled and placed differently if a mistake was made in the initial placement?-City-states: Why aren't your envoys returned to you if a city-state is conquered by another civ?-Notifications: Why does the player need to know EVERY SINGLE THING that an enemy civ does through the rather bland reports that pop up at the top of the screen? Shouldn't specific and important events be highlighted rather than "oh, civ X just settled their 20th city". Was it impossible to use the bold font for important things?-City Defense: Why is the player not notified (a la Civ 5's system) when an enemy unit is in range of city defenses? Instead we see a tiny red button below the city, but if a player is otherwise distracted they can miss their opportunity to stop a barbarian or enemy unit from ravaging half the countryside.-Barbarians: I appreciate barbarians, I do. However, it is incredibly silly that they can spawn in any fog of war tile and are immediately hostile to everyone. Not to mention their endless (and fast!) supply of units. Tell me, is it realistic that every tribe and minor civ in history was immediately hostile to everyone? No, it isn't. Perhaps make it a 50/50 chance that they are hostile, or maybe that non-hostile barbs turn into peaceful villages. Look to Endless Legend for a better system. The minor faction villages in that slowly accumulate units to aid their own defense, but rarely ever have many units roaming around. Furthermore, they might attack your units, but they never siege your cities unless you♥♥♥♥♥♥them off. The barbarian system in civ 6 is an outdated mess that worked for the older games but demands a revision for modern gaming.-Religious Victory: This victory mode, although long overdue in the series, is an absolute mess. Currently it can be summed up as "whoever spams the most apostles and missionaries wins". Religious combat is a joke and constitutes throwing melee-only units at each other until one side dies. I don't believe defensive bonuses even apply as they normally would for military units (I could be very wrong about this). Why do nearby cities lose belief if they see an apostle fail in combat? Have you ever known a religious person to be that fickle? Civ 5's religious pressure system, although imperfect, was superior to the newer system. Spamming apostles and sending them at enemy cities/apostles is not interesting gameplay.-Culture victory: Needs reworking.-Diplomacy: The agenda system seems like a good idea, but shouldn’t the AI judge you more on your actions rather than really weird “goals” or styles of play? Why does an AI that has been at peace with you the entire game, trading prosperously, suddenly decide to denounce you or declare war on you simply because you didn’t play the game exactly how they wanted you to? Historically, neighbors fought each other more than countries from all the way across the world.Would write more, but I ran out of space.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So much potential in this game, but for now if I play Civ it's going to be Civ 5. The AI is simply too incompetent to pose a challenge, once you have city walls up it's basically impossible for them to take your city.The system of "3 combat strength higher = you DOMINATE the opposing unit" needs to be reworked to give the lower unit some chance. You would think that going from 20 to 25 combat strength would be more impactful than going from 70 to 75, but it is equal impact. At this point you can take down every civ for a domination victory by forming corps with a melee unit, ranged, and 1 or 2 seige units + a great general. Each city you take helps snowball towards a MASSIVE science & culture lead...leading to more advanced units/corps/armies...you get the picture.I love many things about this game, however. The culture tree, government, policy system, district placement strategies, competing for great people, religious beliefs...all top notch.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So far this game is a terrible disappointment. 5 months on from release, the AI issues still aren't resolved. I bought the Digital Deluxe edition, paying $20 more, for access to the first four DLC packs at a supposedly better price than buying them individually. So far the 3 I've been given are selling on Steam for $4.99 each, so unless the next pack is expansion-level content with a pricetag of at least $14.99 I'm going to feel even more ripped off than I already do. Save yourself a whole lot of disappointment and just buy the Civ V complete package instead. It's an infinitely better game.Edited 4/1: the fourth piece of included DLC came out on 3/28. It's 2 more Civs and one more scenario, retail price 8.99. I saved 4 dollars by buying the deluxe, and after 6 months this game is no closer to being playable than it was at launch. Two bad games in a row for the franchise (Beyond Earth, even with Rising Tide, is no good). Hopefully they fix this but I don't know that I'm willing to spend money on the expansion content that it'll take to do that.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So Ive been playing this game for a while, 55 hours as of writing this, and im really having issues with what to do, thumbs up or down...In the end though, i will not recommend this game, although it has various good points.Plus:-The district system is very nice, forces you to consider placement of future districts and wonder while balancing the recourses nearby.-Wonders requiring a tile is smart, gives you more of a penalty if you dont finish while also taking a tile from your city if you do.-The civics tree is interesting, culture in general feels much more immersive and competative than before.-The earning of great people allows for you to play in alot of different ways and screw over your opponents by taking something that they could use.-Combat units are balanced.-The addition of projects let you produce something of worth when no buildings are available instead of just units, gold or science.Minus:-Religious victory is completely overpowered, especially in pve games. its too easy to take over another Civ with religion, especially if that Civ isnt specifically aiming for that victory.-There arent enough great works slots. especially for the Writers, there is 1 spot in an aphitheater for each city, other than that, you need wonders, which makes writers useless, especially considering they produce 2-3 pieces each.-Leader and civilization powers are weirdly specific and sometimes useless. The powers need you to have or do some very specific things that are sometimes very bad. for example, Russias leader Peter has the ability to receive ekstra science and culture from traderoutes with Civ that are more advanced than them. This means that to make greatest use of this leader, 2 victory conditions have been eliminated.-Amenities, Housing and Population. on paper it seems smart but in reality, housing and amenities stop the player from settling alot of places early in the game simply because they wont result in anything, and when playing against high level AI, early settling is key. its also not well explained what "entertainment" is in the game, as the "entertainment complex" district says it gives amenities from different sources of "entertainment".-Not alot of map options so far, it was okay in civ 5 after all the expansions but to have this little option and with very few ways of controlling how the map will form? not good.-No way to play co-op. Civ 5 had a broken way of playing co-op but at least you could still do it, here, you have no actual way of playing any real co-op, which really makes it uninteresting to do.And lastly, the big issue that everyone is annoyed with:-AI. So many new things in Civ 6 were based on giving AI an overhaul and give them personality and agenda. which they did. they just all have the same, almost immidiately denounce, go to war for petty reasons, rinse repeat. There are so many more issues with AI but this review is long enough.

title: Not Recommended
comment: wow, such a rip off. i stand here wishing i could get my money back. I am yet another long time cvilization player (as well as alpha centauri and beyond earth), giving this latest addition a bad review. The ai is horrendous (why a twenty five year old game like alpha has better ai I will never know). It seems that what matters is creating aconvolutd tech tree and impossibly boring game play. It seems to simply drag on. I truly truly wish steam would give me back my money and take the game from my list.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is difficult to review. While on the one hand it is visually stunning and optimized pretty well, the gameplay is lackluster and leaves much to be desired. The most recent DLC, Nubia, broke my game so I've not played as them. I can tell you through my 175 hours in game to not buy this game. If you liked Civ V, you won't like this game. It is a very trying experience and will make you lose your patience quickly if you let it. AI is dumb, mechanics are dumber, leaders and civs are equally as stupid.

title: Not Recommended
comment: There are some good things to be said about Civ6. The new system for religion, for example, is both more rewarding and more realistic thanks to the fact that it can be tailored to a civilizations needs or incliniations. The districting system, while not necessarily an improvement over older games, provides a fresh new way to think about city management.Unfortunately the good is lost in a sea of bad design choices. The very best example of this is the new "Eureka" system for technological development. You are essentially given one quest per tech, which cuts the cost of that tech in half if you do the quest. Such a powerful incentive means you will have to go out of your way to perform many random actions if you want to stay competetive technologically, turning the game into an RPG style deluge of meaningless tasks.Speaking of competetive, the AI is most certainly not when it comes to combat. Playing on a high level, I found myself in a situation where Brazil had a much larger army than mine. They declared war and should have easily been able to take my border city. Instead they wandered around my territory and slowly let me shoot them to peices, seldom even attacking any of my units or cities. I ground them all into meat without losing a single unit.The removal of the civ-wide "Happiness" type feature seen in Civ5 returns us to the days where explosive expansion has barely any limitations. This removes the need for the subtler strategies we developed to deal with happiness limitations and once again reduces us to a formula of pumping out settlers or soldiers as fast as possible, with infrastructure being considered only as it allows us to achieve those two previously mentioned ends.I tried it, and I wanted to love it, but I just don't want to play it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Can't recommend this game currently. There are some nice additions to the game, such as more challenging barbarians, finite workers and the interesting civic tree. However, some additions are not implemented well. For example, the AI is too angry - it becomes nearly impossible to uphold good relation. Furthermore, when playing on large/huge maps, I find that some AIs have barely done anything and only have 1 city and are 2/3 eras behind when I am in the modern era, and some civs have reached the atomic era before I have reached the industrial era. I think that the tech tree could do with some tweaking to help make it more balanced. For example, in Civ 5 the progression of the tech tree felt very fluent, so that I wouldn't have those 1/2 turn techs to research when I was 2 eras ahead. However, in Civ 6, it is too easy to just follow a single branch to get the tech that you want. You know there's something wrong when you can still produce seige towers in the modern era. I'm not a huge fan of districts, and find them more of a burden distracting from the pace of the game, but I do believe they have potential.EDIT: CTD bug fixedI would still be tempted to recommend this game if it were not for the bugs - gamebreaking bugs. I can't progress beyond ~ turn 200 as I get a CTD, so I'm unable to progress into the late game. This is honestly inexcusable, especially nearly a month after release. For this reason alone, I cannot recommend this game

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ V looks better, plays better, has better leaders and AI. Gtfo with your cashgrab bs. Last time i get hype for a damn sequel.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Yanno, I get it. Developers gotta make money, publisher's gotta take their cut, licensing fees, etc etc. It happens. There aren't any lootboxes in the game, so I'm happy, even if they are pinching us for every penny we'll spare.But I'd think for a $30 expansion that isn't even included in the "Deluxe" edition, that expansion would at least be bugtested before release.You'd think it would be.But when every game I attempt to start -- mods enabled, disabled, even with the R&F expansion ITSELF disabled -- crashes to the main menu?Yeah, I think not.Update 2/14/2018: HEY, GUESS WHAT, I GOT INTO A GAME! Great news, right?After completing my turn (the first turn), it started processing the other civs turns, with the "please wait" above the globe in the bottom right.So I waited.And waited.And, as of this moment, it's been going on 20 minutes with no sign of finishing, so I'll just let it run while I go to sleep. No, I did not install crazy/insane mods or put 500 civs on the map. It's just that them there GOOD OL' $30 WELL SPENT DLC DOIN ITS JOB.Side note: Kill me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As much as I want to like this game, some of the changes from Civ V are interesting, but I cannot in good conscious recommend this game. Since day 1, I have not been able to get through a game without multiple crashes. I sent a ticket into 2k and after 3 or 4 emails later, each with a long list of "troubleshooting ideas" I still can't get a couple turns into a game without crashing to desktop. Everytime I crash, I immediately say "yes" to sending in the crash report, in hopes it will get noticed and fixed.Maybe in a few months, something will finally get changed and I can enjoy this game, but untill then, this is a definite NO from me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The mechanics of this game are a wide step away from previous Civilization games; many of which make it feel more like the first part of a new series than an entry into an established IP. I have been a huge fan of the series since its inception, and this game really feels more like it was created as a mobile version than a full PC release. Graphically, the game has taken huge steps backwards, opting for a highly-saturated cartoon aesthetic than the realism that such a game really demands. In many ways, the game feels incomplete and most of the newly implemented mechanics (the government card systems, expiring workers, and AI players as a whole) really make the game feel less intuitive and effective than previous entries.I was expecting a game that built and improved upon the innovations from Civilization IV, V and Beyond Earth, yet this game has completely disposed of that feeling.Overall Synopsis: Very disappointed. Hopefully more content will be added soon that makes the game more playable. Without that, the game really has very little play value, let alone replay value.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Nothing new with this game compared to the last. The tone of the game is very cartoon-like, you would think after a few installments they'd at least make some better improvements to the graphics, and in game models. All-in-all I made a mistake purchasing this. DO NOT BUY WITHOUT RESEARCH!!!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Visual design of the game is the worst of several iterations. The AI is utterly broken. Want to use some diplomacy? Bad luck, everyone hates you because you have no ships on a landlocked map or some other equally tedious BS. Have gone back to Civ V, hopefully the devs fix this bad game in the next DLC.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Stay away from this game. There are many bad reviews for this game, and I ignored them... much to my regret now. Better to stay with Civ 5 BNW. Maybe, and that's a big maybe, this game will be worth playing after 2K fixes all the problems. I regret not listening to the reviews.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeI cant recommend the game. It has some interesting changes (like the districts and the religious warfare) but none of them give me the impression of being properly thought through. The AI is impossible, they rarely do anything that you could call competitive. Balancing is bad. The UI is really bad, its more of a test version than a proper polished game. The graphics do the job quite well, even though its not for everyones taste.For a polished experience with a good AI, I rather recommend to go with Civilization 5 with the Vox Populi overhaul .

title: Recommended
comment: Yeah boiiiiiiiiiiiii

title: Not Recommended
comment: 4/10A lot of great ideas. Unpacking cities, great person tweaks. Even the barbarian raids are a cool addition. Could use some manual roads.Two things completely sink it: no crossplatform multiplayer, and abysmal ai and ui.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The Civilization Series has officially taken a nose dive into a volcano. I've been playing since Civ 3 and I probably have over 2,000 hours in civ 4 and 5 combined alone and I even got the civ 4 steam edition when my disk broke. Civ 5 had some fine DLCs because they were worth the value but this... this is a shame. I'm for paid content, when it is not a cash grab that gives the fans and players so very little. bring back what Civilization once was, make civilization great again. Until then, deuces firaxis.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Good game especially if your looking for a single player turned based strategy game, can be really complex and challanging. Takes time to really get used to it. But don't buy it if your buying for the multiplayer feature its complete garbadge constant disconnections, can't host private games, get kicked from most open lobbys because there intended to be private can take hours just to hope you can stay in a full game.I don't know who wrote the net code for this game, but they must be terrible programmers, again if your planning to only play single player then this game is for you. But if you intend to play multiplayer as well then don't waste your money the people who wrote the code dosn't deserve your hard earned cash.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Not as bad as Beyond Earth, at least it's a different game this time.But no production queue, no world congress, AI that plays like a kid eating glue, and DLC that offers little for the price.This is disappointment on a whole new level.The new best game to make you want to play Civ V.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The graphics and sound are impressive. Additionally, the game is much more stable than Civ V even is currently. However, the team responsible for the game's mechanics greatly undermined those improvements. The new mechanics are often confusing, nonsensical and infuriating in the extreme. The addition of districts sounds good on paper but their implementation makes city placement an absolute headache. Expansion is now completely at the mercy of map randomization instead of just your first city like previous tiles. Additionally, districts are not explained well anywhere and the game will simply insist that "there is no suitable location for this district" without ever really explaining exactly what IS suitable. I gave up on building a harbor after seeing that message on a half dozen different maps building cities near, but not actually on the water, in spite of the fact that this is what the game explains that harbors are for. Finally, the new movement mechanics make no sense and are completely unintuitive. For instance: if you 3 hexes of movement left and you're one hex from a river, you can move 3 hexes up or down the bank, but if you want to cross you have to use 1 of your 3 moves, stopping at the water, and then waiting a whole turn to actually cross, and there's no refund of the lost movement you could have used to start crossing the water. This change was absolutely unnecessary and made something that was straight forward and turned it into something confusing for no logical reason whatsoever. There is more, but this is already long... It comes down to the mechanics designer having done a terrible, over-complicated job.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I just wanted it to be good, so damn bad.I played the hell of of Civ V, it was a great game. I eventually got tired, there were a few little niggling bits that annoyed me, wasted potential etc., but it was a good game.I wanted Civ VI to be good, if they'd taken Civ V, changed the civs around, added in their new districts mechanics, new artwork etc., I wouldn't have minded too much. If they could have improved the AI, that would have been great. I visualised great wars, alliances! Some kind of 3rd 4th 5th 6th Coalition against a great foe! Or at least, AT THE VERY LEAST, the same as Civ V, just with smarter AI.None of this came true, of course. You can't bribe wars like in Civ V (okay maybe there's some other similar mechanic, secret alliances, maybe intertwine them with the new agenda system?), nope, you either go on a joint war (you can only do this if you're friends with the joint war partner, which is incredibily unlikely), or no war at all, unless you're gonna do it yourself. You have to just sit there, as you watch one, two, three civs run away, with no way to stop them, unless you've got a large army hidden somewhere up the backside of one of your cities.I like the amenities, building an empire of more than four cities doesn't feel anywhere near as restrictive and ruinous as it was in Civ V.The agenda system is terrible. Good concept, badly, badly executed. I was playing a game on Immortal difficulty as Brazil, and found myself denounced on turn 5 by Rome, because I 'controlled very little territory'. I was in a state of constant denouncement for the rest of the game, even as I settled my sixth city, in a futile attempt to appease my Roman overlords. I won't get into the other two denouncements I received within 5-10 turns of meeting the next two civs, because they "Just plain don't like you"- it was funny the first time, haha lol a bit of comedy, but when every civ seems to do it, it's just frustrating. I feel like I spend every game trying to please every civ in the game, or one of them at least, but I just can't. I look at all their relations with eachother, and they're all besties, all having fun denouncing me. And once they decide they hate you, it seems that's it, no second chances.There's so much more I could say but I've wasted so much of my life on this game already, hoping I was wrong, that until it gets a COMPLETE overhaul (the diplomacy, at least), I'm gonna expel all thoughts of it from my mind. It just frustrates me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Too many game breaking bugs. Diplomatic deals get stuck and alt f4 is all that you can do. Unable to place districts. I bought the game this month - A cunning plan to get going after all the bugs have been fixed. HAHA oops. Do not buy this mess.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game... I really want to like it, Civ was the first real video game I ever played, but its just so broken. In my worst game (I would like to emphasize worst), The map was so cramped that my capital started 4 tiles away from another civ's capital, The Ai broken in that they LOVE to declare war on you in joint wars in the first era, so I was pressed to produce enough military power to fend them off, and then, of course, I'm the bad guy when I take a city from them. Later in the game when this ♥♥♥♥♥how has calmed down, I'm perusing the scores and see this one undiscovered civ has an absurd lead in almost every category, doubling my science score even though I'm pushing really hard for a science victory. So getting peeved and because I cant explore due to not having water access because the map is so FRIKING CRAMPED, I cheat in full map vision to so that the other civ that is doing ridiculously well, had THEIR OWN PRIVATE CONTINENT TO COLONIZE. So yea, this game is still broken.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ 6 seems to be a case of one step forward and one step back. I liked the innovations made to the base game from civ 5. The problem with the game is the absolute gutting of mod support in order to push ~9 dollar DLC that only introduce a single civ + senario at a time, and not very frequently. The think that kept me playing Civ 5 and loving the game for so long was the infinte customzation that fan modding brought. If the game felt boring, download a few mods and suddenly you have new choices to make in your next game. This game has already become played out to me, and has left a bad taste in my mouth. I am unlikly to purchase the next Civ game after the one-two punch of Beyond Earth and Civ 6. i am left with little confidence that the series can capture the magic that made it great in the first place.

comment: Big Fan of the Civilization series, and this game was great. But the number of Bugs on the Mac version renders this game completely unplayable, especially since the last update. DO NOT BUY

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's a lot of fun to play...when it's working. 2K Firaxis has done terrible/non-existant QA for the game and have introduced game breaking bug after game breaking bug.I reccomend sticking with Civ V until a more funcitonal version exists.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In it's current form I wouldn't recommend this game. It is fun and has a lot of potential and I have enjoyed playing it but there are issues that I just can't ignore anymore. Unfortunately the AI isn't very intelligent, for example sometimes they just all turn on you for no reason and all declare war, I literally have no idea why. On occasions the AI will constantly spam you for a declaration of friendship every turn leading me to denouncing them just to stop it. One turn they will love you and in their next turn they hate you. City states seem completely useless as they did in the last game, they declare war but rarely engage in any meaningful combat or make any ground. In my current playthrough I have gained 3 cities through peace deals in wars where we never came into contact or barely made contact. I simply throw 20-30 gold per turn as part of the peace deal and I exchange for one of their cities.The next set of issues for myself has to be how buggy this game can be. I am currently looking at the game on my other monitor and I am unable to transfer great works from one full museum to a museum with a free slot. When I grab an artifact to trasnfer I am greeted by a box that say's "Are you sure?" and there is no option to click yes or no. It's just a dialog box that is broken. If I hit escape it closes this dialog box and I still have the artifact attached to my cursor but I am unable to drop it into any open slots and have to just hammer escape to close the Great Works screen all together. So it's basically broken. Sometimes I task a unit to move to a certain area of the map and for no reason they just sit there forever, not moving. When I check they still have the destination set with nothing obstructing them or blocking their destination tile, they just refuse to move. Another thing this game likes to do is when I ask it to exit to desktop it just freezes up and never closes forcing me to end it's process in Task Manager. Sometimes linking a unit such as an Admiral for example to follow around a Battleship, the admiral will get left behind and bug out, causing it to not follow the unit it is linked with.Other issues are not being able to remove districts, once you've set them then they're permanent (unless you mod the game) and also no production queue as standard, a step back from the previous game. Theological combat is a bit off at times and I have had a single enemy AI Apostle just steam rolling all of my units like some God in human form. There are some Civs that are incredibly unbalanced (OP) and there needs to be some serious balancing. This is usually the case in Civ games with certain Civ's being better than others but in Civ 6 some of them are just way too good, usually in terms of their technological advancements/science generation. Conservationists are useless, seemingly can't be used anywhere on the map. Apparently they can be used, but after 80+ hours I've yet to be able to use a Conservationist unit or find anywhere suitable to use them on any of the maps I have played. My last major issue is Amenities. It just isn't clear what effects it, how and why. I know it is basically the happiness system from Civ 5 but it just feels opaque and hard to figure out at times. Some of my cities will randomly become unhappy (lack of amenities) and there are very few policy cards that address amenity issues, especially in the late game stages.Minor issue/annoyance for me is when you have an Armada of Battleships there's only 1 ship unit shown. It would be nice if there were perhaps multiple units shown however I am playing on fairly low settings at the moment and I am unsure if that effects it or not.The longer I play this game the more noticeable the issues are and more of an annoyance they become. I would be willing to look past these issues as some of them aren't too bad however this game isn't cheap and I doubt all of it's future expansions will be either. Now I do enjoy this game when I distance myself from the unitelligent and random AI and ignore some of the bugs, at it's core it has a lot of potential to be a great Civ game. Some of the changes to this game I believe are better from Civ 5 such as how resources work for example. You now only need access to 1 Iron resource to build multiple Swordsman units where as before you would have needed 1 Iron resource for each unit. However as it stands I would not recommend this game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: "Most Civ games need a years worth of patches before they really get good, maybe an expantion pack or something right?"R...right?I'm an old piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥and I've been playing civ since I could on my old 386 on dos (barely managed to since I only had like 50MB of HDD but hey) and I can tell you it's always good to deliver a product when it's finished. Because most previous civs have been at least passable on their deliverly.Unless you're looking for multiplayer then I still dont think this game is a satisfying single player experience. Why? The AI mainly, there have been several decent UI fixes that never should've been there in the first place (they felt like mid stage alpha kinda oversites) . Regardless, the UI has improved, the AI hasn't and Sean Bean is still telling you about world wonders and advances in humanity.. not bad right? Ehhhhhh.....I think this is probably the biggest the ball has been dropped on a civ game so far and in making AWESOME PRE PURCHASE EARLY RELEASE SALES the game has actually sold a bit of its noterity and renown. I played this game pretty solid for a good month (ok 80 hours but yeah I have a social life) and I just couldn't get into it like I did with Civ 5 (pre gods and kings even..)Like multiplayer? Great this game is ready for youWant a satisfying solo player experience? Stick to civ 5 for a little bit longer and hopefully an expansion will come out with a 3 page apology from the investors for clearly grabbing the devs by the balls and making them juice out an UNFINISHED GAME.I'm still a fan but I'm a butthurt weary fan now.

I'm not paying the overly expensive full price for them, and I'm ♥♥♥♥ed as a launch purchaser because buying the digital deluxe version means I'm also wasting more money. title: Not Recommended
comment: I really wish that I could recommend this game, especially after spending thousnads of hours playing the previous CIV games, however I'd be lying if I said this game wasn't broken.-AI will go from your best friend to declaring war on you instantly-AI will often send you trade requests that they themselves won't accept-AI will build 5-6 cities on the largest map then just stop (despite having large sections of the map untouched)-Conquering a city without trading the enemy nation for it during the peace conference will result in that city being "occupied" for the rest of the game - no growth ever. This is true even if you completly destroy the enemy nation-Weird graphical glitches late game/when there are multiple units on the screen (Intel i7 7700, GTX 1070. all drivers up to date)-Plan on playing a game for more than two hours? Make sure you have IiTunes, Spotify, or some other music player, as the music will just cut out after some time.-Absolutely no customer suport. Be prepared to spend more time dealing with other angry forum members than staff

title: Not Recommended
comment: After waiting a long time and many patches after the release it's still unplayable. AI has gotten slightly better as are many little things. However, I cannot complete any game. It will always crash in the end game. And there are other smaller annoyances and bugs all over the place. Sometimes support units don't follow their linked main units, sometimes keyboard scrolling gets stuck, and so on. I gave it another chance and it was not worth it. Stay away at least until the first major expansion.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Let me start by saying that i have 664 hours logged on civilization 5. I just cant comprehend how you can go backward from something that is almost perfect. The best thing about this game is the district system and the un stacking of cities. That is pretty much where the good things end. The AI is terrible, worse than civ 5.. i didnt belive the reviews i was reading before, purchased the game anyway because i love the series but oh my god its a step backwards:1. The AI doesnt want to expand thier empires, they often only have a handful of cities by the time you have 102. The AI does not want to be your friend, ever. They barely want to trade with you and the options are limited on what you can do with them.3. Expect to be declared war on for absolutely no reason but your armies will be met with AI units that dont want to attack your cities. They will instead, pillage your improvements and just inconvinience you for a few turns.4. Expect to be denounced for everything you do, even by your allies.5. Expect spain to send 5,000 apostles to your lands making your religion completely obselete (do yourself a favor and dont put them in the game)5. Even if you start a large map and keep it to 5 players, for some reason the game will put you adjacent to one or more civs, not giving you any room to grow or branch out.6. There are less map types AND no "earth" (WTF)Overall, not impressed with anything but the city districts system and the graphics.Reccomend you wait until they patch the sh** out of this game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I do not recommend this game.I am currently in the process of requesting a refund.I got conned by Beyond Earth - I refuse to be again. This game takes the best elements of previous Civ games and puts them to the torch. The deciding factor for me was when the Caravan made a road between 2 settlements (lovely principle in theory, terrible execution) and not the builder. If you don't realise what a huge deal that is - you haven't been thinking strategically enough, so I'll give you a hint - you can't place roads where you want yourself. The A.I. is terrible and has not been improved. You would have thought with such a huge following and the serious time that has now been invested in it (nearly 20 years!) they would have got it right by now, but no (vivid example - Stonehenge requires YOU to build it beside a Stone resource - does the AI require this - no - thereby practically always going to beat you to it at higher levels). So stupid, it can't even follow simple protocol. This is very lazy developing and I refuse to accomodate it.I do not recommend this product.[ edit ]I have been refused refund by Steam due to time played - i.e. 15 hours (above their 2 hour threshold).There is no way that you would find some of these issues unless you have been playing for this long. Lesson learnt - wait and read reviews. A very good review within the community was written by Anamizefan in which he goes into a lot of the issues. One telling thing though is that he hasn't finished a single game yet. It just gets too boring. I stand by what I said above - Firaxis cocked it up again . . again, you have to wait for DLC to fix something that should have been right from the start. Twice bitten, both by Firaxis - it ain't gonna happen a 3rd.

title: Recommended
comment: I should preface this review by stating that I've been an avid fan of Civilization from a very young age. In fact, I consider it a driving force that made me the history buff I am today.Would I recommend this game? Absolutely! Am I biased in saying that? Absolutely!It isn't /better/ than Civilization V, per se, but it definitely holds up to the legacy.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Was excited for this game. The sins of Beyond Earth were fogiven when they announced Civ6.When I played it, it was very clear that it was different to Civ 5. So I pushed through and in fairness the more I played it did get better. But the nagging feeling always remains that I'd still rather be playing Civ5.That's the problem. Its not (at this stage) a more interesting or enjoyable experience than last time. The Devs should be writing to people with 1000 hours (Ive got around 800) in Civ5 and asking them why. What did they love about it?What would they improve?In civ6 I feel as though I have less control and less freedom to play the way I want. And the game focuses on the things that I always found boring - like victory conditions. In all my hours I never cared about victory types and almost never finished a game. The victory types in Civ always seem so unfair and thus no clear measure of performance. So I generally ignore them, especially in Civ5 where all it does is end the game and tell you someone has won. Yawn.What was fun about Civ5 was exploring, defending, expanding, rushing to find and secure the best land and finite resources, building your empire. Once there was little cloud to explore and no land to grab before someone else, I always became quite bored with empire maintenance and building toward some uninspiring 'victory' type.I was hoping they would recognise that and withhold part of the map or make part of it usless for settlement until mid-late game. Perhaps a new technology may allow you to access or settle new areas because essentially thats the fun part.Civ5 I always found it balanced offering you tough choices without feeling like micro-managment. In Civ6 sometimes there is nothing I want my city to produce, choices of where to settle a new city are so restrictive that its not really a choice. There isnt much in the way of buildings early game so no hard decisions there. Exploring feels like a chore rather than an adventure. The art style is ugly. AI is well - insane. Plus Im not going to spend all my time reading about what makes a particular AI character happy or unhappy. AI should be intuitive if youre a good neighbour and you keep your promises and they are not an agressive AI you should have no problem. The ammount of gold you generate per turn for example, should have no baring and does really restrict the way you play if you want to keep an AI civ happy. Chosing policies is a chore and its a lot of reading with no real big picture plan. Wonders are less wonderful and the number of players who can compete for them is now even more restrictive as they bizareley wemt for 'realism', so no need to stress if you will get there first.One thing I've wanted to see for a long time is genuine unit diversity between nations or regions. Giving each civ 2 token 'unique' units that you may never even use is not exactly game changing. I wanted it to feel like there really is a difference when selecting your civ and not just a cookie cutter reskin with some minor changes or perks.Overall playing Civ6 has less of the things I enjoy. I feel less free, less in control, not as able to plan ahead, and the whole experience feels a great deal more aimless. Although there are plenty of things to work towards like completing mindless tasks for city-states for example, there are very few things on offer that I care about enough to bother working towards.I'll keep playing it because I really want to like it more. But I have a feeling Civ5 will always be the more balanced, better looking, more interesting game.Thats why im giving it a no.

title: Not Recommended

If I wanted to play a game that destroys you on the lowest settings I could select from a host of other games. I want my money back.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Stay away from this game. There are many bad reviews for this game, and I ignored them... much to my regret now. Better to stay with Civ 5 BNW. Maybe, and that's a big maybe, this game will be worth playing after 2K fixes all the problems. I regret not listening to the reviews.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The mechanics of this game are a wide step away from previous Civilization games; many of which make it feel more like the first part of a new series than an entry into an established IP. I have been a huge fan of the series since its inception, and this game really feels more like it was created as a mobile version than a full PC release. Graphically, the game has taken huge steps backwards, opting for a highly-saturated cartoon aesthetic than the realism that such a game really demands. In many ways, the game feels incomplete and most of the newly implemented mechanics (the government card systems, expiring workers, and AI players as a whole) really make the game feel less intuitive and effective than previous entries.I was expecting a game that built and improved upon the innovations from Civilization IV, V and Beyond Earth, yet this game has completely disposed of that feeling.Overall Synopsis: Very disappointed. Hopefully more content will be added soon that makes the game more playable. Without that, the game really has very little play value, let alone replay value.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In it's current form I wouldn't recommend this game. It is fun and has a lot of potential and I have enjoyed playing it but there are issues that I just can't ignore anymore. Unfortunately the AI isn't very intelligent, for example sometimes they just all turn on you for no reason and all declare war, I literally have no idea why. On occasions the AI will constantly spam you for a declaration of friendship every turn leading me to denouncing them just to stop it. One turn they will love you and in their next turn they hate you. City states seem completely useless as they did in the last game, they declare war but rarely engage in any meaningful combat or make any ground. In my current playthrough I have gained 3 cities through peace deals in wars where we never came into contact or barely made contact. I simply throw 20-30 gold per turn as part of the peace deal and I exchange for one of their cities.The next set of issues for myself has to be how buggy this game can be. I am currently looking at the game on my other monitor and I am unable to transfer great works from one full museum to a museum with a free slot. When I grab an artifact to trasnfer I am greeted by a box that say's "Are you sure?" and there is no option to click yes or no. It's just a dialog box that is broken. If I hit escape it closes this dialog box and I still have the artifact attached to my cursor but I am unable to drop it into any open slots and have to just hammer escape to close the Great Works screen all together. So it's basically broken. Sometimes I task a unit to move to a certain area of the map and for no reason they just sit there forever, not moving. When I check they still have the destination set with nothing obstructing them or blocking their destination tile, they just refuse to move. Another thing this game likes to do is when I ask it to exit to desktop it just freezes up and never closes forcing me to end it's process in Task Manager. Sometimes linking a unit such as an Admiral for example to follow around a Battleship, the admiral will get left behind and bug out, causing it to not follow the unit it is linked with.Other issues are not being able to remove districts, once you've set them then they're permanent (unless you mod the game) and also no production queue as standard, a step back from the previous game. Theological combat is a bit off at times and I have had a single enemy AI Apostle just steam rolling all of my units like some God in human form. There are some Civs that are incredibly unbalanced (OP) and there needs to be some serious balancing. This is usually the case in Civ games with certain Civ's being better than others but in Civ 6 some of them are just way too good, usually in terms of their technological advancements/science generation. Conservationists are useless, seemingly can't be used anywhere on the map. Apparently they can be used, but after 80+ hours I've yet to be able to use a Conservationist unit or find anywhere suitable to use them on any of the maps I have played. My last major issue is Amenities. It just isn't clear what effects it, how and why. I know it is basically the happiness system from Civ 5 but it just feels opaque and hard to figure out at times. Some of my cities will randomly become unhappy (lack of amenities) and there are very few policy cards that address amenity issues, especially in the late game stages.Minor issue/annoyance for me is when you have an Armada of Battleships there's only 1 ship unit shown. It would be nice if there were perhaps multiple units shown however I am playing on fairly low settings at the moment and I am unsure if that effects it or not.The longer I play this game the more noticeable the issues are and more of an annoyance they become. I would be willing to look past these issues as some of them aren't too bad however this game isn't cheap and I doubt all of it's future expansions will be either. Now I do enjoy this game when I distance myself from the unitelligent and random AI and ignore some of the bugs, at it's core it has a lot of potential to be a great Civ game. Some of the changes to this game I believe are better from Civ 5 such as how resources work for example. You now only need access to 1 Iron resource to build multiple Swordsman units where as before you would have needed 1 Iron resource for each unit. However as it stands I would not recommend this game.

title: Recommended
comment: Overall, the game is very well made; more or less all the features from the Civ 5 expansions have been implemented right from the start, and they made quite a few additional improvements here and there such as the new Casus Belli system (copied from EU4). Furthermore, the soundtrack is among the best in video games and succeeds in breathing life and personality into the game.If you were expecting a revolution in the 4X formula, I suppose you may be disappointed, but I wasn't looking for that at all in Civ 6 and am satisfied with how the game turned out.Oh, and multiplayer actually works properly this time and is a lot of fun.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Well, my recommendation to you is to keep on playing Civ 5.There are some tiny things which bother me:Cities can't be upgraded anymore in a depth that I would like to have, you have 1 or 2 buildings in the city and the rest is standing arround the city, that makes the city looks pity and also takes the depth of "build a big city where tourist come and go"Now every wonder, even the small ones just stand on a tile, they could've made a great change, wonders like the Ruhr Valley have to get one special tile, wonders like the Brandenburger Gate stand in the city.Also the tile managment is a bit confusing. You need one citizen to manage one tile, well now my citizens manage just one farm tile and 10 unbuild tile while there are plenty of unused farms. Somehow I can't change that.Remember how y'all hate the italians because they conquered all of europe and in best case you want to nuke them?Well, if don't, then you are not a Civ 6 AI since they hate you at 2010 when you had a war with them at 500 bc.Also the new city management leads to the AI spamming troops since they have nothing better to do, but luckily they don't upgrade the units and can't even manage them because they are so much so you can kill their 50 units with one archer in an ideal case (No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ here).I like some of the new ideas and the new graphics but all for one I enjoyed Civ 5 even more than Civ 6.Also 2k's DLC strategies these days are terrible. Buy Deluxe Editions, receive all the dlcs half a year later and then the game just dies. At least for XCOM2 is that the case. After the last DLC they just stopped working, sometimes a dev get's the order to change a thing or add compatibility but no great changes and I am afraid this will happpen to Civ 6 since Civ 5 vanilla was a mess compared to civ 5 now.Edit: I tried to play as Spain after I wrote this, suddenly Victoria declared war to me without no good reason just 5 rounds after I met her and surprisingly Theodor joined, who was my best friend and on my continent. We even had a declaration of friendship.

title: Not Recommended
comment: totally broken ai, unable to respond to human player. ai never upgrades units, has extremely poor military decision making, and firaxis is only interested in selling $5 civs and not in making their game playable. late game ai feels like early beta.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Another regurging of the same. Yes greatly improved graphics, awesome selection of world leaders. But much of the gameplay lacks any originality. If you've played any of the other Civ games then you've played this one. The A.I. is horrendous. Interaction with other Civ is as boring as the combat system is. Nice addtion to agendas but it didn't make the gameplay and different. Unstacking cities, and not having to build a city on coastal waters to build navy is a good addtion, but its not enough to make this a good game. They should have spent more time trying to create a different interaction with other civs other than the same old dealings.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So far this game is a terrible disappointment. 5 months on from release, the AI issues still aren't resolved. I bought the Digital Deluxe edition, paying $20 more, for access to the first four DLC packs at a supposedly better price than buying them individually. So far the 3 I've been given are selling on Steam for $4.99 each, so unless the next pack is expansion-level content with a pricetag of at least $14.99 I'm going to feel even more ripped off than I already do. Save yourself a whole lot of disappointment and just buy the Civ V complete package instead. It's an infinitely better game.Edited 4/1: the fourth piece of included DLC came out on 3/28. It's 2 more Civs and one more scenario, retail price 8.99. I saved 4 dollars by buying the deluxe, and after 6 months this game is no closer to being playable than it was at launch. Two bad games in a row for the franchise (Beyond Earth, even with Rising Tide, is no good). Hopefully they fix this but I don't know that I'm willing to spend money on the expansion content that it'll take to do that.

title: Recommended
comment: Overall, the game is very well made; more or less all the features from the Civ 5 expansions have been implemented right from the start, and they made quite a few additional improvements here and there such as the new Casus Belli system (copied from EU4). Furthermore, the soundtrack is among the best in video games and succeeds in breathing life and personality into the game.If you were expecting a revolution in the 4X formula, I suppose you may be disappointed, but I wasn't looking for that at all in Civ 6 and am satisfied with how the game turned out.Oh, and multiplayer actually works properly this time and is a lot of fun.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The Civilization Series has officially taken a nose dive into a volcano. I've been playing since Civ 3 and I probably have over 2,000 hours in civ 4 and 5 combined alone and I even got the civ 4 steam edition when my disk broke. Civ 5 had some fine DLCs because they were worth the value but this... this is a shame. title: Not Recommended
comment: So Ive been playing this game for a while, 55 hours as of writing this, and im really having issues with what to do, thumbs up or down...In the end though, i will not recommend this game, although it has various good points.Plus:-The district system is very nice, forces you to consider placement of future districts and wonder while balancing the recourses nearby.-Wonders requiring a tile is smart, gives you more of a penalty if you dont finish while also taking a tile from your city if you do.-The civics tree is interesting, culture in general feels much more immersive and competative than before.-The earning of great people allows for you to play in alot of different ways and screw over your opponents by taking something that they could use.-Combat units are balanced.-The addition of projects let you produce something of worth when no buildings are available instead of just units, gold or science.Minus:-Religious victory is completely overpowered, especially in pve games. its too easy to take over another Civ with religion, especially if that Civ isnt specifically aiming for that victory.-There arent enough great works slots. especially for the Writers, there is 1 spot in an aphitheater for each city, other than that, you need wonders, which makes writers useless, especially considering they produce 2-3 pieces each.-Leader and civilization powers are weirdly specific and sometimes useless. The powers need you to have or do some very specific things that are sometimes very bad. for example, Russias leader Peter has the ability to receive ekstra science and culture from traderoutes with Civ that are more advanced than them. This means that to make greatest use of this leader, 2 victory conditions have been eliminated.-Amenities, Housing and Population. on paper it seems smart but in reality, housing and amenities stop the player from settling alot of places early in the game simply because they wont result in anything, and when playing against high level AI, early settling is key. its also not well explained what "entertainment" is in the game, as the "entertainment complex" district says it gives amenities from different sources of "entertainment".-Not alot of map options so far, it was okay in civ 5 after all the expansions but to have this little option and with very few ways of controlling how the map will form? not good.-No way to play co-op. Civ 5 had a broken way of playing co-op but at least you could still do it, here, you have no actual way of playing any real co-op, which really makes it uninteresting to do.And lastly, the big issue that everyone is annoyed with:-AI. So many new things in Civ 6 were based on giving AI an overhaul and give them personality and agenda. which they did. they just all have the same, almost immidiately denounce, go to war for petty reasons, rinse repeat. There are so many more issues with AI but this review is long enough.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really don't like writing negative reviews but I feel at this point in time after 6 painful hours of gameplay I cannot recommend this game to previous CIV players. If you are a fan of the CIV series then you might not like this one as much. They basically overhauled a vast majority of the game and changed up a lot of things. They tend to do that with each one but honestly this one wasn't even relatively close to CIV 4 and CIV 5. Which deeply saddens me because I've put well over 500 hours in CIV 5 alone. I think that many players will enjoy this game but compared to the rest of the series this one definitely falls short by miles in comparison.

title: Not Recommended

(AI Terrible)2.The AI are a bunch of panzys when it comes to war and being agressive. (AI Terrible) oh sorry, i already said that.I have won the game 3 different ways didnt really feel to challenged on hardest level. What i discovered having it set on a harder level doesnt make the AI better, just gives them a s h i t ton of bonuses at the start of the game.There have been some interesting concepts they brought in that i liked, but didnt capitilize on encorporating previous editions of Civilization into it. Overall this game gets boring after a few goes and is repetitive, due to poor AI build into game. I wonder if Sid Meier had produced it how it would turn out?, being the original game developer. title: Not Recommended
comment: Acquired during the Humble Monthly Subscription. There's no way I'd pay full price for this game or any DLC.I've been a long time Civ player. Played a little of Civ 2 and LOTS of Civ 3. Civ 4 was OK, Civ 5 was better. Civ 6? Disappointing.The main issue is the AI. Everything you do or don't do will inspire the AI to declare war on you. There's no way to avoid war or attempt any sort of peaceful win.Add to that, it seems to be poorly optimized. During the later game I would have to wait 1-2 minutes or more between turns. And this was when it was just me and one other civ left. I would have been bored to death if I wasn't watching a show at the same time. And no, it's not that my computer is♥♥♥♥♥♥ my computer isn't amazing but it's definitely mid quality for a gaming rig.I'm sure that after the expansions come out the game will be better. But that will be another $60-100, unless you're willing to wait till the prices drop... Which will be a month or two before the next Civ game comes out.The only one winning with Civ these days is 2K.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In it's current state I can't recommend this game.The AI is absolutely horrible. My first game I went for a domination victory. Late game when I had tanks, AT crews, helicopters etc. I was still fighting horsemen and spearmen, which just made it completely boring.The AI also keeps breaking promises and there is no penalty for them doing so. For example, England started to convert my cities and I naturally told her to stop and she agreed. But the very next turn she continues to convert my cities. At this point I would like to atleast recieve a casus belli with little warmonger penalty, as she was the one to break her promise.Similar thing happend in the same game but with China. He settled a city very close to my capital, so I told him not to settle near me in the futere, he agreed. A couple of turns later I decide to settle a city myself, so I thought that I wouldn't settle west of my capital as that is where China is and that would be kind of double standard to settle close to him, just when I told him not to settle too close to me. So I decided to go east but sure enough once I created my city, he got mad at me for settling too close to him.I also have some smaller issues with the game that I can live with, but I would like to see them getting fixed.The game itself doesn't run very well. I can run The Witcher 3 at around medium-high settings, but in this game my FPS will start to drop heavily around mid-late game.And finally I can't close this game normally without my PC completely freezing. I have to force close it everytime.Now this game also have some huge improvements since Civ 5 such as combat, city planning and more.When they start updating this game, I'll hopefully be able to change this review to positive.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Disappointing that nearly a year after release, the game still lacks a world builder and cross-platform multi-player. I convinced several friends on other platforms to purchase the game via steam immediately at release. We still haven't been able to play together, and the lack of world builder and cross-platform significantly limits replay value.We all remember watching the Sim City franchise die off a few years ago. These kinds of embarrassing missed deadlines and missing features have the aroma of a dying franchise. Who will trust you and buy your products now? Obviously the joke is on me for buying a game at release that wasn't finished. The joke will be on your studio when you try to hype your next title and no one believes you.

comment: I have loved the Civilization game from its concept and snap each one up eagerly as soon as it is available, as I did with Civ VI. Unfortunately there are a few irritating points in this version that make the experience less pleasurable. I don't like to constantly have to create builders and then detail every little thing they do! How I long for the automate option and let them just get on with building on resources. The computer is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥where is spams priests ets everywhere, the tiles on which they are being unuseable and so sometimes difficult to move armies. So far I have been unable to find out how to list your units, so if you lose the location of one, they are really hard to find on a large map! Also when upgrading it was easier when you could just list units. The times I have played so far it seems impossible to get to the high level technologies before game over. Yes the graphics are beautiful and I like how you can combine units, but the gameplay just isn't up to that of Civ V. One thing I wish that they would introduce is what they had in an earlier version (Civ 3??) where you can build an outpost - afterall, who builds a city in the middle of an icy area to utilise that single resource!!! Good but could have been better!

title: Not Recommended
comment: If you play civilization games casually, you shouldn't have a problem with this installment. However, if you're looking for an immersive and engaging experience, buy civ 5 on sale instead.There are so many aspects about this game that are incredibly rushed and unbalanced. On harder difficulties, you feel as if you're playing catchup the entire time- the AI doesn't play stronger, they merely receive massive bonuses that put them hopelessly ahead until later in the game. The AI also rarely upgrades their military units, preferring instead to create new ones. It is common to fight against archers and infantry in the modern age. This breaks any sense of immersion you might have remaining after Ghandi condemns you for not having nuclear weapons in 1500 BC.In addition to all of This, civ 6 lacks any diplomatic victory option, completely restricting an entire arena of play that was very fun.My final compliant is that the developers refuse to patch even basic bugs and instead expect players to buy DLC to fix these problems. It's flat out greedy and is a giant middle finger to devoted players.There are a few things about this game that I like, however. It is far easier to look at than previous civ games and won't give you a headache if you play it too long. The UI and civic trees are innovative and easy to use but they lack depth. The district system is fantastic and causes players to focus on one specific playstyle. I also love that traders create their own roads although it is frustrating that this is the only way to build them in the early game. The relationship tabs between nations is also much clearer than in previous games but also lacks depth- there are only a couple of ways to improve diplomatic relations and these have a very limited effect.Overall, I'd give civ 6 a 2/5. Although initially fun and engaging, it completely falls apart after you see through it's pretty facade. Don't waste your $ until civ 7 is released.

title: Recommended
comment: I'm posting this because I've just spotted all the negative reviews.I'm old enough to have pre-ordered Civ I in the days when that meant going into a shop, I've played every version and variant since, and I think Civ VI is *deep breath* the best Civ ever.Let me explain why.Civ I is a timeless classic. Civ II and its expansions and forks set a new high bar and showed where Civ could go. Civ III was all about trying new things, but whilst I liked it from the start it really needed the Conquests expansion to bring the new systems together, and even then they were still a bit ropey. Civ IV was, until now, my all time favourite, and the BtS expansion is easily the best Civ expansion pack ever. The depth of strategy and systems, and a slightly fussy interface, mean it's not a great one for first-timers, but the joy of Civ is in understanding how everything works as well as using it.Civ V, however, was dire. The vanilla version was so dumbed down I was completing games in three evenings without really thinking about them, and although the expansions helped a lot it still felt like it belonged more on a console (no offence to console gamers but the reason you invest in a super-fast CPU is for games like Civ).So, knowing that a lot of Civ V's systems were to be ported to VI, along with the new map and city systems that bear a striking resemblance to Endless Legend, I wasn't sure what to expect, and the hefty price tag on the full fat version almost made it the first version I haven't pre-ordered.However! From the first seconds of the beautiful opening sequence I knew this was going to be something a bit special, possibly even as good as Civ IV. The greatest Civs (I, II, IV, forget the forks) are those where all the systems from the map, through city management, to science, diplomacy, religion and war, all work together. Where they jar against each other (III) you end up being forced into making nonsensical decisions and it breaks the immersion. Civ VI, with some early teething problems, absolutely nails this.The map is the star, and the new strategic fulcrum of the game. Firaxis did well to flatter Endless Legend, and there are other parallels that made me worry this would be too much like it, but this is still very distinctively a Civ game. And some people don't like the cartoony style, but I do because it evokes Civ I, we can agree to differ.The new city building system, also borrowed from Endless Legend, works exactly how it should do. It takes a little while to learn how to exploit it to the maximum, but then if you want something you can master in a couple of playthroughs then Civ isn't the game for you. The science system has thankfully been un-dumbed from Civ V and the structure of the tech tree has some nice nods back to Civs I and II, and the eureka system adds a bit more fun. Religion, one of the better systems in V, has largely been ported from it, and now fits better with the other systems. And culture is a similarly good port, although the culture victory is far too easy (turn if off if you're definitely going for any other victory condition).The two weaker systems were war and diplomacy, but the patches and DLC have done a lot to fix the balancing issues - even though at the moment I'd still rather not start near China (and for those wondering, Ghandi is still a warmongering ****). It's still not 100% perfect, but no system in any Civ game ever was (anyone remember diplomats in Civ I?), the point is that they all work together in a way that only the best Civs manage.So why does it have the edge over Civ IV? Partly because the visuals and sound are beautiful - the main music in the game is the traditional song Hard Times Come Again No More, and I love the way it develops into a crescendo in the late game. And partly because the late game is now worth slogging through - and yes, the cinematic ending and stats have been restored. The new map adds to the fun to be had here, so rather than just rushing towards your choice of world-ending weapon it's actually worth building a balanced force, even if you're not going for a domination victory. And it's also worth building thermonuclear weapons even just to try one and reload just to see the pretty new fireworks.So as a Civ veteran I'd say ignore the negative reviews. If you're a long time fan who wished Civ V had never happened then you should find all is forgiven. If you're new to the series then just be aware that you're making a long term investment - Civ is supposed to towards the harder end of 4X strategies but it's nowhere near as impenetrable as it seems at first. Take a few games to learn it and keep experimenting until you find a playing style that suits you.Civ VI claims the Civ crown, and reclaims its place as the best 4X ever.

title: Recommended
comment: At first, I was very skeptical of the graphics. Everything looked very "cartoonish." Once I started playing, however, I immediately fell in love. The graphics actually make the game very playable by not taking too much processing power. Sometimes 5 and even Beyond Earth became too frustrating to play those larger games with more computer/human players. The Civ team was very smart in not putting too much effort into the graphics by making sure this is playable on most hardware, even making it simple enough to easily put it on a mobile platform.As for game mechanics, this version introduces a lot and re-introduces what we love about previous versions. New to the franchise, they brought districts to the map, limited actions for builders, policy card decks, envoys, super enhanced diplomacy, and culture "researching." Then they made sure to include features that I love about previous versions like religion, choosing government, rebels, trade, and natural wonders. This makes the base game already feel really complete. It's hard to imagine what they might include in the expansions, other than new civs and maps. Or maybe I'm just blindsighted at how awesome the game already is.For long time Civilization players, this is the game we've always wanted.

title: Recommended
comment: I'm not one for leaving reviews, but I feel this game deserves some praise. While the game isn't perfect, I feel the amount of negativity surrounding other reviews isn't a fair assessment of the game. There are some loyal, passionate and long-time customers of the franchise. Civ V being regarded as such a fantastic and well balanced game, shouldn't cause negative reviews for the newest installment in the series.I think the developers made some fantastic changes to the game, while sticking to it's roots. Districts are an interesting addition to the game and I like the way Builders are used in this installment. The Technology Tree and it's Eureka moments add another layer of strategy not found in it's predecessor. Some of the Government Policy cards could use some balancing, as I often tend to use the same over and over. However, as I've played with other civs and altered my playstyle, I find myself using cards that I hadn't in the past.Sure, the AI behaves a bit odd and is something that can be easily beaten as you settle-in to the new mechanics. They also have some strange behaviors. These are not game-breaking issues and something that I'm confident that will continue to be balanced in future patches. I honestly think these minor annoyances are the reason for the negative reviews. Just because something isn't perfect, doesn't make it bad. Patches have already been introduced to adjust AI behavior while in the meantime, Steam Workshop mods have been opened up (one of which is an AI improvement mod).At the end of the day, the game still gives me that "one more turn" feeling. I'll make a mental note that I want to wrap things up, and 2 hours later I'm still playing. If that isn't the qualifier for a solid game, I don't know what is.

title: Recommended
comment: First Impressions: This review is for less then 30 mins of gameplay, Will revise it later after more playing.I have been playing the civilization series since more than 8 yrsGame runs stable and smooth so far on my old PC with Windows 7 and with AMD Phenon X4 CPU , R7700 HD card. Most new systems should be able to run it very smoothly.Players who have plaved civ 5 and are familier with the other games in the series will find this game to be a marked improvemnt in1) smoothness of gameplay-- this runs smoothly and with more FPS than Civ 5.. improved Multicore support of CPU with Direct X 12 also certainly helps.2) Visual graphics are much better.3) the game has some improvements in gameplay.. will write a detailed review on that later after more gameplay.It has improvements in the number of resources, different types of resources, barbarian units have started scouting also,Goverment type screen and associated bonuses has been introduced and its much more streamlined (replaces the earlier screen of culture based bonuses) , they way to interact with city states has changed. Research tree is much better.Cons1) One thing I did not like was that it is not easy to Auto explore as earlier. Also could not find the button to promote a unit after it gains experience easily, the developlers should do something to fix it in the patches.2) Game is overpriced as with all sidmeier games, that also prevents me fro playing many other games in the series. 2 K game/ Firfaxis should have priced at atleast 35 % lower. Also I can bet that the DLC's coming out will be sold seperately and at a high cost. Also its unlikely that this game wil go on discount anytime soon.For players who are new to to Civilization series.This is one of the best Turn based strategy games out there. The learning curve is also not very steep.In short: Go for the Game, if the price is not a deterrance.Will write a more detailed review later.
