title: Not Recommended
comment: Having played all the games in the Civilization franchise, I've never been as disappointed or frustrated with a Civilization game before as I am with Civilization VI. I had expected something more from a game that claims to have a new game engine and add a lot of features on top of Civilization V.Not only does the game completely fail to add anything, that wasn't a part of Civilization V, it even keeps all the frustrating elements of Civlization V. In some respects, I think, the frustrating elements have only gotten worse.For example, I've never enjoyed City States and routinely play Civilization V without them. Starting a game without them in Civilization VI is not even an option. I strongly disliked them because they were too easy to farm XP on for units, and the bonuses you got for courting them were far too strong. The XP farming hasn't been fixed and the bonuses are now even more powerful.Another example is the Diplomacy options: While animated leaders with native voiceacting could have been a nice touch, both Civilization V and VI fails to follow through, since the audio doesn't match the text on screen. That the other world leaders are even more random and psychotic than in Civilization V, does not help either. The illusion, that you are negotiating with a human, fails horribly when wars are declared or ended for no reason or any reason and the animated leader you're talking to is saying something different than the subtitles (or is saying nothing). Furthermore the world leaders will nag you incessantly for any reason they choose. You can decline their offer of peace for a 100 times in a row, but they will still nag you for peace every 5 turns (no kidding!) if they're loosing the idiotic war they started for no reason.Third example: Religion still functions in much the same way. The different beliefs and their mechanics are even identical to the ones in Civilization V, as are mechanics for spreading the religions, actively with preachers and passively through proximity and trade.Actually, to be fair, the game does bring a little news to the game. The mechanics with city districts and wonders being placed on the map makes the city building a little more interesting, but in my opinion it gets completely drowned out by the fact that the worst elements of Civilization V is still around. Or more precisely; that you're still playing Civilization V.Because that's the truth of it: Civilization VI is the same as Civilization V.The AI unit control is just as horrible. The City States are just as overpowered. The AI leaders are just as random. Religion spreads the same way. With very few, and forgettable, exceptions the game is the same.I would recommend against this game.EDIT: (Above was written on 6-7 hours of gameplay.)Allright, now I've played through the one and only game of Civilization VI that I will ever complete. Huge Map, Marathon, Standard difficulty. Game is way too easy and it's all too obvious that the game engine HAS NOT changed, even though it was a selling point.Just like the very forgettable Beyond Earth, Civilization VI will go straight to the dustbin of failed games. If anyone startes a petition for refunds, let me know.The AI will happily declare war against you with it's rag tag army of mediveal henchmen, even though you have Modern Armour Armies (note the plural) in striking range of their capital.The game is balanced wrong. You NEVER need to build Theatre og Campus districts. As in NEVER EVER. You can get all the culture and science you need from Monuments, Population and Trade Routes. Never waste production on a district if it isn't Harbour, Commercial, Aquaduct, Recreation, Residential or Industrial.On the other hand, you are going to spend the entire game starved for production, so build Industrial Districts ASAP and use gold whenever possible to rush construcion, and thus save production for those things that can't be bought. (Wonders, Projects, Districts)Basically, Districts are a no-brainer. There is never need og use for doing anything other than producing Industrial and Commerce/Harbour first and then Aquaduct/Residential/Recreation when the city grows. Never build a Campus, Encampment or Theatre. You DON'T need them.No-brainers are bad game design, basically.Also; infinite city sprawl is back. Since happiness is now a purely local affair, you can and should cover every square inch of the map in cities. There is no downside. Even though you pay a little upkeep per city, the expense is insignificant comparet to the per-city income that acrues from the +1/+2 trade routes you can maintain per city (through Commercial/Harbour districts).More no-brainers. More bad game design.The extreme lag that Civilization V suffered from is still around, which means that for the last 100+ turns. I've waited 3-5min per game round, even on a high end gamer PC. The game took >40 hours, but I'm sure I could have completed it in <10 hours if it wasn't for the extreme lag.What the actual f***?

comment: I actually can not understand all the bad reviews here. I played Civ 1, 3, 4, 5, BE. And I think that Civ6 is very good. And Civilization 6 breaks this rule. The only important gameplay feature which was presented in Civ5 but has been cut in Civ6 is UN. And also Civ6 introduced many new features!City districts is pretty interesting feature. It still should be polished but I already like itWonders which takes it's own cell are very good. It make game much interesting. You don't have a one city with all wonders in it anymore. This feature requires planning and thinking: do you need this wonder? Do you actually need benefit from this wonder? Are you ready to take one cell from your city (people won't work on this cell anymore)?

title: Recommended
comment: This game has done a wonderful job setting itself apart from previous entries thanks to some significant revamps. The most obvious changes came from diplomacy. It's much more intricate and realistic, though a number of AI actions still don't make much sense. But, it's far more dependent on how the player reacts as opposed to the AI programming, and that's a huge step forward for the franchise. The next big change is the districts mechanic. The series standard has been to cram all your buildings and wonders in the city proper. Now you can build different districts (such as science, culture, commerce, etc) and wonders onto their own hexes. This makes managing your space far more important and also makes even the most passive players have to consider putting in some work on their military as AIs in particular like to use hit and run tactics on those spaces when you're at war. I don't think the franchise has ever looked better, and it's a good thing because the soundtrack, while good, doesn't quite live up to the glorious standards of Civ V. Thanks to this game's numerous tweaks and balances and bold revamping of major mechanics, this should be a must buy for any strategy fans and an inivitation to return to those who felt jilted by Beyond Earth.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A great game with some deep flaws.Civ 6 does many big things right. And also a lot of small things so wrong. The UI is not streamlined at all and the game will waste your time, especially when your empire gets bigger and older. Best example is the "Future Tech" research. The game will ask you to choose it every couple of turns. At that point there is nothing else to choose, so why ask me over and over and over again? The same is true for cities who are maxed out, you still have to choose something every couple of turns. The fire-and-forget options of "give me gold/research until I change it" of former Civs is gone.And of course, again, the AI is half brain dead. This is true for troops movement on the map and also the "diplomacy" stuff.While a good AI is hard to do, most of the other stuff is easily fixable. So why is it here, at release, at full price?Before the worst problems are patched, I cannot recommend the game to anyone. Maybe except hardcore Civ fans?

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civilization is one of my favorite games, I am playing it time to time last 15 years. And this one is a promising version of it, but it also a very frustrating one. Some great mechanics allows you to stuck up bonuses, specialize and achieve more doing things smarter. So unlike older versions, you need to think how to develop and focus your cities in a way that support your overall strategy. This is great.Unfortunately, there is a lot of just stupid things that contr-balance it all. Annoying "rumors" about your own actions, animations you just need to wait through, endless friendships requests or denounces, non-sensical AI behavior. It feels like people producing the game where collecting mechanics, but not designing the game flow and player experience. You end up with crazy things like pacifist Gandhi bothering you in middle ages about his Nukes agenda. Just random nonsense that hard to follow.CIvilization games never had any historical sense, but it was possible to follow at least some story (and even enjoy replay on a minimap at the end). This version is just a mix of smart and not so smart mechanics that glue together with terrible AI and without much care for a meaningless game progression.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Buy it on sale when it's been out a year and there are a variety of mods. It's basically Civ5 + Beyond Earth, with a variation of Endless Legend districts. That may seem great on the surface, and it is to a point, but flaws and oversights are everywhere, many of which should be common sense.The AI is laughable, production queues are missing, style is overly cartoonish, diplomacy is all but non-existent, restart map button is missing, new research/civic boosters are interesting at first but basically force you down a map-based path.If I could, I would refund the game. Anyone who knows the Civ franchise should also know that you'll never be able to make a decision on about the game until long after the 2 hour Steam refund timer is up. So I keep playing despite myself. I have yet to complete a single game though, and I wonder if I'll ever really enjoy it without massive overhauls from modders. (Mod support still seems pretty limited by the way. There isn't much available on Fanatics, and there still is no steam community page as of the end of 2016.)(Additional personal aside) - I thought I would love Sean Bean as the narrator but nearly every quote is juvenile and silly. It's missing the wit and sarcasm that Nimoy and others were given in previous installments. I actually enjoy the game more with voices off, but this also turns off the diplomacy voices.

title: Recommended
comment: I have been playing Civ since Civ 1 when your settlers could get 'lost' randomly and disappear off the map. I don't have a count for the hours played in Civ 2 or Civ 3 and I have over 300 hours clocked on Civ 5. I do get the criticisms that people have of Civ 6 right now, but if you compare Civ 6 to Civ 5 and its first DLC Civ 6 still has far more advance mechanisms such as the role religion plays, how you recruit great people, the fact wonders take up tiles and each of the 'districts'. They've essentially added urban planning to this game which is a first in the franchise really beyond roads and 'improvements'. In short there is a TON of new gameplay over Civ 5 even with all of Civ 5's dlcs. I also prefer the lack of penalty for expanding your Civ in terms of city building like they did in Civ 5 with the stupid "happiness" counter, it is much more realistic in Civ6 in that it is more of a matter if you are able to support and grow that city.That being said, issues I have would be the somewhat irrational computers in terms of diplomacy and roads are much more difficult to establish which is vexxing since the early ones use trade routes to make roads and military engineers later.With all that being said Civ 6 is 100% more complete than Civ 5 was on release and I look forward to seeing expansions rather than these piddly over priced faction releases.

title: Recommended
comment: IntroductionHi I'm PotatoMcWhiskey and I do Let's Plays. If you're interested in seeing my play this game then here:YouTube™ Video: Let's Play Sid Meiers Civilization VI - Part 1 - Pericles Greece - Emperor and Chill Views: 754Let's Play Civilization VI Part 1 Let's Plays are Let's Plays of a game that doesn't have a special category worth mentioning! Civilization VI is the latest installment in the Civilization Franchise.If you're not then skip to the review.The GoodThe graphical fidelity and attention to detail is excellent.The game is very moddable and there are a ton of mods out already with hundreds more in the pipeline.There are thousands of hours of content in this game if you are looking for something you can keep around for a while then this may fill that gap.The game is different from previous games, which makes it feel fresh and interesting.The BadThere are occasional performance issues, with stuttering and flickering. It comes and goes depending on the patch.The mods that are available are not yet done through the steam workshop which is a problem, as it makes it a bit harder to access them.The modding tools also haven't been fully released yet which is a mark against the game in its current form in my opinion.The game is different from previous games, which can make it feel a bit unbalanced and unfamiliar.The UglyThe AI is quite poor and weak and not particularly fun to play against and multiplayer games take 6-12hours.You can't make teams in multiplayer, without editing the game files, so you can't have co-op games with friends. This will probably be fixed in the future!Closing comment:I would say that the game does a good job of keeping the familiar old gameplay whilst changing it up with new mechanics and a new direction. I would definitely say, if you are a civ fanatic then GET THIS GAME. If you're a new comer to the series and you're more exploratory, I would WAIT until a major sale(40-60%) so that the game has time to mature and new content put into it[It has only been 2 months since release and two content updates have been released.]This review was written on the Winter 2016 Patch of the game. I'll try to update this review as the game is updated and DLC are patched in.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I can almost mark my life as to when each new installment of civ has come out. I have devoted thousands of hours since the first days of good old civ 1. Each was a vast improvment over the previous until civ 5 came out. It clearly missed the mark and the devs should have learned their lesson and rebooted. Alas, it isn't so based upon the boring mess that is civ 6. There are so many things missing and just plain done bady I hardly know where to begin... I won't bore you with a list of peeves, but here are a few: no "sentry" function for units (they either fortify or sleep). An enemy unit can (and does) walk right up to the unit and pillage the nearby tile. All you may get is a little icon on the side showing that enemies are in your territory. Spies are a huge pain in the butt as you have to reasign them every few turns by clicking through a whole process of seemingly pointless and few "actions". Even then your districts will frequently keep getting pillaged requiring several turns of rebuilding even if a spy is assigned to counterspying. There are too many options that require tiles to build so that having a truly great city is difficult at best because you quickly run out of room to build and still keep up with food production and housing. The housing is broken from the start as you will early on continuously get warnings that more housing is needed, more housing is needed, more hous.... etc. (PLEBES NEEDED!).I expect the faithful gaming community will do the devs jobs for them and fix what is woefully broken, develop mods, and (hopefully) create entire total conversions that might make this game worth playing. As it has been released it is not only not worth $60 it isn't worth $30... I assume the pressure was on to release this game far too early and there just was not enough time to do it justice. A big reason I assume that time was a huge factor is the fact that not a single scenario or extra bit of additional content was released with the game. Huh??!!My advice to the devs is this: if you cannot do civ right then please do not do it and send this game to others who will treat it with the respect that it rightly deserves. My second piece of advice to the devs is: on a fundemental level you need to admit that civ 5 was a mistake and scrap that entire line of thinking and go back and rebuild/ reboot an entirely new concept for the civ series (usng civ 4 and the many terrific mods as a jumping off point). Because you have not admitted that civ 5 was a mistake, you have created a pile of garbage with civ 6 that did not need to be so. Poor clay produces even worse bricks and this series will keep getting worse and worse if it does not catch itself, admit and own up to its recent mistakes and get back to the greatness that stayed with civ 4 and it's predecessors. This game is boring, basic, and even more cartoony than 5 which was bad enough...

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ V is way superior to Civ VI. CIV VI is a huge disappointment. They took away a lot of what worked well in Civ V and they added a lot of BS micromanagement. Too many specialized units. Workers can't even build roads you need military engineers - cmon thats ridiculous. The game is tedious. They tried to make this game way too different from Civ V. I absolutely hate the cartoon graphics. What the heck is with that???? Fire the guy who thought this was a good idea. Leave well enough alone - Civ V graphics are beautiful and you destroyed them in this game. The graphics get super cluttered and overwhelming after things start to get built up. The units are represented by cartoon icons. Cartoon icons?? Is this 1995?? This game would have been far better if they stuck with Civ V and added some of the new features to it. title: Not Recommended
comment: I cannot honestly recommend Civ VI in its current state :- AI is bipolar, declaring war on you for no reason, two turns after declaring you their BFF and whatnot, and still cannot make smart strategic decisions. You can curbstomp them even if you are behind in tech. They do not protect their setllers, and diplomacy is utterly bonkers.- Districts are an intersting mechanic, but gone horribly wrong. You cannot relocate them, and it is nearly impossible to optimize every one of them. Did I mention they often cost more than wonders when you get past renaissance era ?- Barbarians are a constant threat, even more so than AIs. They tech up too fast, and I had more trouble with one barbarian camp than with 2 neighboring civs.- One of the greatest joys of Civ games, building your own little peaceful empire, is gone. Like it or not, you WILL have to produce an endless stream of militay units, just to defend from constant raiding by barbarians in early game, and warring AIs throwing low tech units at you.- UI is a mess. Lots of things are gone from Civ V, hidden behind several buttons. Happiness and Religion spreading are nigh incomprehensible, for example.Now I know that is is a freshly released game, and I sincerely hope that through testing, balancing and patching, Firaxis can deliver us something akin to Civ IV Beyond the Sword or Civ V Brave New World.

title: Recommended
comment: I only managed to put in an hour on release night but I can already tell this Civilization is the best yet. For anyone that is concerned about getting this game at launch because "it won't be complete" like Civ V was - fear not. This game includes virtually everything that Civ V has after 2 expansions, and then some.The new visuals are beautiful and make it much easier to tell what is happening on the map when you've got a bunch of units and improvements. "unstacking the city" was a genius move and I can already see the gameplay potential and strategical challenges that will arise from this. Splitting the civics tree and the tech tree was also genius. Music is incredible. The removal of global happiness is great - going "wide" is viable again!I have thousands of hours in the Civ genre from Civ III onwards. I expect I will put in a thousand more with CIV VI. Will update once I get some more hours and experience the "late game."*Update* I have finished my first game after ~20 hours. It was a "small" 6 player map, standard speed. I ended up going for the Science victory. The victory conditions are awesome - they feel familiar but are unique from Civ V (Except for Domination, which is the same, obviously). The AI isn't perfect, it has some issues, but the game is still very fun. Late game turns move a little slow similar to Civ V, but that is to be expected when so much is going on around the map. The separate districts you create within your cities really are an incredibly positive change to the gameplay. I just wish that as your cities grow they would visually spill into other tiles, merge together and create a "supercity" of sorts rather than each district looking like a contained unit in itself. This would be especially cool with the Neighborhood districts.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Played it for 11 hours; wanted to be as objective as possible about whether or not the game was worth it.Overall, there are several design features which look like improvements over the base game, but which have flaws that become apparent about halfway through the game. The card-based government system is a novel concept, but doesn't allow for more freedom; the majority of the options presented are terrible, while the rest are so situationally effective (based on what victory type you're attempting to win with) that there really isn't any choice at all. Parallel research and culture tracks are interesting, but victory type largely tailors your research/culture research paths down a pretty straight line. Hidden civ AI agendas appear to make AIs appear unpredictable, but their behaviors are still pretty predictable, and grow entirely predictable after you discover what their hidden agenda is. Civilizations offer drastically different powers, but are wildly imbalanced, and many of them are close to useless. And so on, and so forth - the game's features offer the illusion of choice, but optimized play involves linear paths that grow tedious after approximately the medieval era.Furthermore, there are two other major drawbacks, which are:1. Some technical functions are still buggy. Path tracing will incorrectly register hovering over locations as movement to said locations, which can lead to disadvantageous positioning (or poor combat, which can be disasterous during war). Autoexplore defaults to redundant paths and is effectively unusable. Nothing game-breaking, but annyoing and warranting of the sort of micromanagement that isn't enjoyable.2. The game is enjoyable through roughly the first 100 turns, where decisions feel meaningful and victory could go any which way. After that point, a winner has largely been determined, and the rest of the game feels like "going through the motions," and largely not worth playing. As a result, several features implemented with the game - from tourism to espionage and more - are almost vestigial because of how little they impact the parts of the game that matter.Overall, the game feels reasonably playable, and somewhat fun, but certainly not as breathtaking as one might expect from a virtually AAA title. The game might be worth purchasing at $20, but i certainly wouldn't pay $60 for it, much less $80. If you're a devoted fan of the franchise, wait until it goes on sale; if you aren't, this is a largely passable title

title: Recommended
comment: I recommended this game. Yes, this game have huge different features and mechanism compared to previous CIVs, but they put some great potential features. If you just want the "feature added", it will be bloated of course, and if you just want the "old features back", it will be just upgraded graphics.The most feature that I like is the goals tab and other UX improvements. It drives us to focus on our strategy, which kind of victory we planned. Unlike old CIVs which mechanism is somewhat "hidden", we need to learn outside the game to figure it out.The second great feature is the victory strategy which improved a lot. Now we can win the game trough military (occupied other players), religious (spreading the religion), culture (tourism), science (launch mars colonialization).The third, district mechanism. This is super awesome! Googling for it if you want details about this feature :DOther positive improvements are:- There is only single "trader" for both land and water.- Path are auto-created by creating trading way trough different cities, I liked this so much.- Country specialization now can be shown in game, which I didn't found on previous CIV (did I missed?)- Number of turns left, related to victory by time, is also very good approach on UX side.- No world domination by diplomatic, only on the removed victory strategy is positive for me, but removed united nations at all is not quite a good idea though.- Great works theming (on museum, archeological building, etc.) is so obvious, easy to understand. CIV 5 theming mechanism is too complex.For me, this game is so enjoyable even for new comer which never played old CIVs but also still make sense for old players. The UX improvements are the most great things overall, and so does graphic improvents of course.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ 6 is extremely well-done. As someone who played Civ 4 a ton but skipped Civ 5 (I lost interest in Civ for years and just recently got back into it), there are a number of new features that I really appreciate. Traders, religious and cultural victories, new units and empires, and specialized districts are all really nice additions to the game. And just like any Civ game, "one more turn" usually turns into hours at a time spent in game.There are a few things the game could do better. The map-like fog of war loses its novelty quickly and can be kind of annoying, a number of key empires were missing at launch, and the game can be unbearably slow with larger maps. It's also frustrating that single-empire DLC's cost $4.99 when they probably could (and should) have included them in the core game (I got the deluxe version for $15 more and I get free DLC, and I think it's paid for itself already). Additionally, the barbarians are ridiculous if you don't attack the outposts almost immediately; dozens can spawn on a continent in a few turns' time and pillage your improvements and buildings.That being said, I still think this game was worth the money. As for whether or not it's better than Civ 5, I can't speak to that. But I definitely recommend this game to any fans of the Sid Meier's Civilization franchise.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Buy it on sale when it's been out a year and there are a variety of mods. It's basically Civ5 + Beyond Earth, with a variation of Endless Legend districts. That may seem great on the surface, and it is to a point, but flaws and oversights are everywhere, many of which should be common sense.The AI is laughable, production queues are missing, style is overly cartoonish, diplomacy is all but non-existent, restart map button is missing, new research/civic boosters are interesting at first but basically force you down a map-based path.If I could, I would refund the game. Anyone who knows the Civ franchise should also know that you'll never be able to make a decision on about the game until long after the 2 hour Steam refund timer is up. So I keep playing despite myself. I have yet to complete a single game though, and I wonder if I'll ever really enjoy it without massive overhauls from modders. (Mod support still seems pretty limited by the way. There isn't much available on Fanatics, and there still is no steam community page as of the end of 2016.)(Additional personal aside) - I thought I would love Sean Bean as the narrator but nearly every quote is juvenile and silly. It's missing the wit and sarcasm that Nimoy and others were given in previous installments. I actually enjoy the game more with voices off, but this also turns off the diplomacy voices.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ V is way superior to Civ VI. CIV VI is a huge disappointment. They took away a lot of what worked well in Civ V and they added a lot of BS micromanagement. Too many specialized units. Workers can't even build roads you need military engineers - cmon thats ridiculous. The game is tedious. They tried to make this game way too different from Civ V. I absolutely hate the cartoon graphics. What the heck is with that???? Fire the guy who thought this was a good idea. Leave well enough alone - Civ V graphics are beautiful and you destroyed them in this game. The graphics get super cluttered and overwhelming after things start to get built up. The units are represented by cartoon icons. Cartoon icons?? Is this 1995?? This game would have been far better if they stuck with Civ V and added some of the new features to it. I'm super super disappointed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am an old time Civ player since the game's inception. Sadly, Civ6 has let me down again and again. Aside from the great graphics and cutaway scenes, the game gets boring really quickly. After about 40 hours of play, I was done and uninstalled, which surprised even me. I still believe Civ4 was the overall best game to date with Civ5 a close second. Even with the new expension, which I'm hearing nothing good about, I sadly have to give Civ6 a thumbs down.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I can almost mark my life as to when each new installment of civ has come out. I have devoted thousands of hours since the first days of good old civ 1. Each was a vast improvment over the previous until civ 5 came out. It clearly missed the mark and the devs should have learned their lesson and rebooted. Alas, it isn't so based upon the boring mess that is civ 6. There are so many things missing and just plain done bady I hardly know where to begin... I won't bore you with a list of peeves, but here are a few: no "sentry" function for units (they either fortify or sleep). An enemy unit can (and does) walk right up to the unit and pillage the nearby tile. All you may get is a little icon on the side showing that enemies are in your territory. Spies are a huge pain in the butt as you have to reasign them every few turns by clicking through a whole process of seemingly pointless and few "actions". Even then your districts will frequently keep getting pillaged requiring several turns of rebuilding even if a spy is assigned to counterspying. There are too many options that require tiles to build so that having a truly great city is difficult at best because you quickly run out of room to build and still keep up with food production and housing. The housing is broken from the start as you will early on continuously get warnings that more housing is needed, more housing is needed, more hous.... etc. (PLEBES NEEDED!).I expect the faithful gaming community will do the devs jobs for them and fix what is woefully broken, develop mods, and (hopefully) create entire total conversions that might make this game worth playing. As it has been released it is not only not worth $60 it isn't worth $30... I assume the pressure was on to release this game far too early and there just was not enough time to do it justice. A big reason I assume that time was a huge factor is the fact that not a single scenario or extra bit of additional content was released with the game. Huh??!!My advice to the devs is this: if you cannot do civ right then please do not do it and send this game to others who will treat it with the respect that it rightly deserves. My second piece of advice to the devs is: on a fundemental level you need to admit that civ 5 was a mistake and scrap that entire line of thinking and go back and rebuild/ reboot an entirely new concept for the civ series (usng civ 4 and the many terrific mods as a jumping off point). Because you have not admitted that civ 5 was a mistake, you have created a pile of garbage with civ 6 that did not need to be so. Poor clay produces even worse bricks and this series will keep getting worse and worse if it does not catch itself, admit and own up to its recent mistakes and get back to the greatness that stayed with civ 4 and it's predecessors. This game is boring, basic, and even more cartoony than 5 which was bad enough...

title: Not Recommended
comment: I cannot honestly recommend Civ VI in its current state :- AI is bipolar, declaring war on you for no reason, two turns after declaring you their BFF and whatnot, and still cannot make smart strategic decisions. You can curbstomp them even if you are behind in tech. They do not protect their setllers, and diplomacy is utterly bonkers.- Districts are an intersting mechanic, but gone horribly wrong. You cannot relocate them, and it is nearly impossible to optimize every one of them. Did I mention they often cost more than wonders when you get past renaissance era ?- Barbarians are a constant threat, even more so than AIs. They tech up too fast, and I had more trouble with one barbarian camp than with 2 neighboring civs.- One of the greatest joys of Civ games, building your own little peaceful empire, is gone. Like it or not, you WILL have to produce an endless stream of militay units, just to defend from constant raiding by barbarians in early game, and warring AIs throwing low tech units at you.- UI is a mess. Lots of things are gone from Civ V, hidden behind several buttons. Happiness and Religion spreading are nigh incomprehensible, for example.Now I know that is is a freshly released game, and I sincerely hope that through testing, balancing and patching, Firaxis can deliver us something akin to Civ IV Beyond the Sword or Civ V Brave New World.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeThis game includes some nice changes like continents and eureka moments but overall is a step down from CIV 5.Some poins which make it worse are :-Unit animation makes it so a player is able to queue his unit's attack by clicking fast, your units cant move while animations are going on. (even those who aren't under attack)-Tall city building is almost imposible, once your cities reach 10/12 pop cap is almost a dead end until late game-Terrain change is silly, with having to require full turns to enter hill or forest and no zone of control makes it harder to defend.-Graphics are a huge stepdown from civ 5 and performance wise seems about the same-You only need 1 strategic resource in order to have multiple units, 1 horse can make it so you can have 20+ war chariots or horsemen

title: Not Recommended
comment: Honestly, I wanted to like this game, but I was let down. The Districts system is a bit frustrating, as is the new movement system, the three-time-use builder, and the new agenda system for leaders (which, while I can appreciate it, seems to need improvement, as the leaders seem to not take much more than their agenda into account). All in all, the game itself fulfills the basic game, but misses the mark in terms of improvement and the other issues in the game. I mostly went to Civilization 4 or 5 or even Beyond Earth instead of Civilization 6. I can tell the developers tried in earnest to synthesize the good aspects from those games, such as the diversity in the multitude of leaders and civilizations, as well as intoducing some interesting new features such as Districts, which I personally felt that it instead should have been upgrades for improvements and being able to build cities closer together and being able to use resources that are on the same tile. Ultimately though, this has been my least favorite Civilization game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Oh this is SO frustrating! I have well over 1,400 hours sunk into Civ V – that’s 58 days, nonstop playing. That’s not counting the countless hundred of hours on Civilization 1-4. I love the series, so it pains me to say this: Civilization VI sucks.The AI is schizophrenic. Settle a city? Denouncement. Don't settle cities? Denouncement. Don't expand your borders? Denouncement. Expand too much? Denouncement. Grow your army to prevent the IA from attacking? Denouncement. Leave your army small? Denouncement.All this Denouncement eventually leads to the AI to flip out and march to war against you. But if you build a strong military to repel this attack? The AI will focus Science or Religion and win that way.We'll put it this way - I'm 14 hours deep into Civ VI, playing on the easiest level, the "I am a Wussie Man Baby! Please don’t hurt me!" and I have YET TO WIN. This should be a cake walk. I should be curb stomping everyone and everything in arms reach. I should be Brock Lesnar beating up a pack of handicapped preschoolers. And for some reason I just cant make ground.And the worst part? It took me 14 hours to figure this out. Refund for a fundamentally broken game? Hah. hah, hah. Good luck with that kid.Ah well, Back to Civ V I guess. . . .****EDIT****After trying the new patch, the AI is still broken and the game is still terrible. Go play Civ 5.

The interface, graphics, game, and all look cartoon and child-like.Everything I liked about Civ 5 is gone from Civ 6. And the worst part? Now people stopped playing Civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: commentary: (Ive been playing civ since the 1st one and will say they get better every time exept this one.)DONT BUY THIS GAME UNTILL THE PATCHES COME OUT OR NEXT EXPANSIONCIV5 set the bar so high with best graphics,more dynamics and diplomatic interactions that 6 has kind of let me down and After playing 4 civs 100% on 6 I had to give input hopeing game devs read these,PROS: I love the district idea A+, the eureka bonuses A+ , the unit promotions A+ , unit combination is so awsome!!! to form corps and armys A++++ . finally unit stacking !! and convoys , civ bonuses for picking that civ A+ but not ballanced, still addicting as hell yes ,,,,,for a lil wile ,I LOVE THE DIRECTION THEY WENT has so much promise that could change civ forever if tooled right, you can now make engineres to make landing sites and silos A++ , so glad its now way better to keep your civ happy A++ , resourse dynamics changed to best of all time only needing 1-2 of that item to make inf units A+ , CITY STATES ARE DIFERENT YOU DECIDE GOOD OR BAD.CONS: KEEP AUTO SAVES ON 1 TURN ,late game turn offs come and go and game feels rushed :(,,Diplomattic has went back to stone age and pisses me off , after all the progress in civ 5 how could they do this! after you explore somthing if you dont keep a unit there it goes to a grey catoon map of what you seen .<DEAL BREAKER> , 1/2 THE CUSTOMIZATIONS for game set up as before with no map picking all random so if you have a fav map you have to start a game 600 times to get it but the maps arnt all that good and not many of them per selection<DEAL BREAKER> , no map mod yet , they need more end game units and just more units all togeather to help fill some gaps because it take no time to go from a fighter to a jet for example , (( now heres the biggest DEAL BRAKER of all time)) , in the end game after your huge and smoke is everywere fom your victorys theres no way to turn off your citys,culture and science, for example cant click a botton to make gold or science making that city on auto and you still have to keep picking future tech over and over and over and over and over and over and over,,,So in a nut shell late game TURNS TAKE A HOUR because you are selecting crap in the citys that are done and of course you throw in a game crash after you hit next turn from time to time making you re do that dam turn a few times untill it gets passed the bug . I HOPE THIS HELPS NEW BUYERS AND TO BE CLEAR I LIKE THE ASPECT OF THIS NEW GAME BUT I PRAY TO THE SID GODS THEY FIX IT OR its possible I WILL NEVER BUY CIV GAME AGAIN or atleast not untill a few expasions come out 1stthanx for reading my rant

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is a hesitant "no" for recommendation.The game isn't bad and I believe it has the groundworks to become a great Civ game, given time and expansions.THE BAD:----------As most people have pointed out already the AI is not good. Not only is it extremely hostile towards players unless you follow extremely strict guidelines on how to please it but it's also seemingly even dumber than before when it comes to battle and religion.The strategy seems to be to mass units at the border, with no real thought to which unit goes where, declare war, rush in and unless it wins then and there the war is basically over for the AI. Units will trickle in piecemeal and die in an endless meat grinder, no matter the difficulty.Worse than these though is the graphical readability and the UI. And I'm not talking about the art style, though maybe it is a culprit in itself. It's much harder to quickly get an overview of what's on the screen when overlooking the world, the UI is a hot mess where user flow is atrocious. The Civopedia is extremely lacking, not having info for many concepts or lacking useful info on game mechanics.The fog of war, while looking nice and stylish at first, is a nightmare to look at to figure out what lies beneath it (after you've discovered the area but don't have vision).After a few hours of all this I notice major eye-fatigue which no Civ game before has given me.The game is also "clunky". This is hard to describe but think of it as the ease of control and the smooth flowing of the game. Most things are a bit of a hassle, even moving units feels somewhat stuttering sometimes. Shortcuts lack for almost everything, 5 clicks are needed where one should suffice etc. This ties in to the poor use flow for UI I talked about earlier.Tying into the clunkiness is the endless, pointless, notifications that you get spammed with or the horrendeously slow leader screens (who like the rest of the game suffer from atrocious UI).Movement. Opinions are split on this one, understandably. I can certainly see where they come from but the change to movements make military units like infantry absolute trash. It's a change which feels more tedious than anything.Lastly, and extremely subjectivem the graphical style (as opposed to readability). This is a contentious one and might not apply. I personally don't enjoy it as it has become too cartoony for me, a bit xbox live. Forests lack that nice, dense feeling and I have a harder time getting lost into the fantasy of controlling a world.THE GOOD:------------Governments and civics have really taken a turn for the better. Very interesting and potentially deep with enough possible variance to keep you interested for a long while. My favorite aspect of the game.Districts/Wonders using tiles. This imposes a dilemma for the player of how to use the tiles and what to sacrifice for a city since you can no longer be a master of all. They need some major balancing, and perhaps some things shouldn't be districts, but overall this change is great.Cities can use the ocean if a water tile is within it's borders. This I have been dreaming of since the very first Civ. Praise the sun!IN SUMMARY:--------------Needs major overhaul many things, I have vague hopes this can happen through both expansions and mods. There are good concepts lurking beneath what I feel to be an incomplete game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: (Recommended if you intend to play multiplayer)Pros- Better than its predecessor in most ways- District and wonder placement makes cities a bit more interesting- Leaders feel less unpredictable and illogical this time around- Decent visuals with great animations- Fun multiplayerCons- Abysmal AI; harder AI levels won't give you smarter opponents, just opponents with unfair advantages; you won't have any problem taking out an AI army 3-4 times the size of yours, as it is somehow less capable of waging war than the AI in Civ 5 (which was already terrible)- Not too many changes from the previous iteration- Religion feels mostly like a chore- Fair amount of bugs, although mostly minor- No "Hall of Fame"

title: Not Recommended
comment: eat my♥♥♥♥♥sid meier, i bought the digital deluxe because i was under the impression that you guys were going to give me all upcoming expansions at no additional charge. needless to say, i am wrong. i paid twenty extra bucks for a few miscellaneous civ and map packs??? seriously???? yikes dudei held back from my scathing review for awhile. I figured, “hey, give them some time. maybe after some dlc is released, and some patches are put out, the ai will actually function and other features of the game will cease being counterintuitive and useless!” unfortunately, i was unpleasantly surprised to find that, several months later, that is not the case. sorry guys.i loved civ v, i loved civ iv. hell, i grew up playing civ with my dad on our crappy 90’s desktop. civ has been a huge part of my childhood.and civ vi? between the colossal waste of money i spent buying the digital deluxe, and the fact that the game is genuinely bad, civ vi ruined it. i don’t recommend buying this game until ten years have passed and you can purchase it for 7 dollars with ALL of the dlc.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Its bad and Firaxis should feel bad. They literally ripped the diplomacy out of civ 5, stuck it in this game, and then lobotomized it because apparently civ 5 diplo was still too "smart". When we said there was no way they could make a game more boring than Beyond Earth and civ 6 HAS to be better, they said "Hold my beer".The game's pacing sucks. By the time you try to leverage an advantage a tech gives you, you've already moved on to the next. both science and culture "tech" lines are just checkboxes to hit as you get to the end of the game. The ai is even less competent than in prior versions. It looks like a mobile game, and they've darned well tried to make it play like one too, including charging an arm and a leg for new civilizations.You know, if I want to spend $$$ on endless DLC, I'll go back to playing Paradox games like EUIV, at least I'm getting some value for my $$. Which at least they put on sale during steam sales, something Firaxis apparently didn't get them memo for!

comment: Giant steaming pile of crap. I have played every Civ from the first. Civ6 is a total waste of money. They should have paid me for the 40hrs I wasted giving it a chance. If you have 3 or 5 stick with those.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really wanted to like this game and I appreciated the attempt by Firaxis to change up the gameplay by introducing newer elements, but it just didn't work out. Though the city building aspect was mostly well done, the learn curve is a bit steep. Firaxis didn't help matters with its last patch which nerfed costal city benefits.Among the aggrivations:-Diplomacy somehow managed to regress even further from previous entries. It's quite useless actually.-The reappearance of religion is fine and all, it'd just be nice if the AI didn't spam the heck out of religion units to the point where it hinders movement of your own units.-On the subject of the AI, I'm sure through many of the comments you're already well aware of the infamous warmonger metric. It's completely broken and illogical. There's nothing quite like being attacked by multiple Civs, retaliating by capturing one of their cities, and being labeled a warmonger for,.............pretty much the entire game where no other Civ likes you. That's right. No matter the number of turns, you're hated all around the world for seemingly no reason whatsoever. This leads back to why diplomacy is useless in this game.-Did I mention AI spam? Yes, well unfortunately that goes for cities too. They'll happily spam cities near your borders even after you ask them to stop and they agree. It's a cheap ploy to instigate war, lame. Not that war is difficult anyway since the AI is so terrible at it.-Don't bother building a navy, the AI sure doesn't.Bottom line, this game is nearly unplayable in its current state after two major patches. The AI sucks, the Civ penalties make no sense, and the warmonger penalty needs to be either fixed or scrapped entirely. Say what you want about Civ V, but it's a masterpiece compared to this trainwreck. Perhaps I could recommend this game after an expansion pack, but now? No way.

title: Recommended
comment: Product received for freeCouchy's thoughts on Civ VI:Great base game that innovates on the classic Civilization formula in many areas. It is genuinely fun to 'learn to civ' again for the x'th time, but bugs, features that you'd expect strangely missing, an especially helpless AI for the opponent Leaders as well as blatant exploits gradually do their part in making the whole exercise increasingly pointless.Great game. Needs a great deal of bugs and exploits fixed. As well as features missing from V put back into VI making it part of the next DLC, thank you very much. It also needs said improvements incoming sooner rather than later, as I feel I've completely wasted the last 15-20 hours I put into the game after bugs ruined the goal of victory I had been working towards since the start. Don't see myself picking this title up again until it is in a better condition. Huge let down, at this price point you expect a game to be released in a much better shape than this.While the single player AI soon becomes annoying to deal with to the point you soon stop caring to even read what they say when they contact you, Civ VI in multiplayer has so far been a great experience. We had some occational disconnects during the first days after launch, but have not experienced any multiplayer specific game stopping bugs or desyncs.Still gonna recommend the game though, its very fun despite all the flaws and shortcomings I whine about. Going to be a Civ game for the times if it gets the many fixes and improvements it needs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Easily the best Civilization game at launch that still seems to fall flat in regards to diplomacy and general AI. Culture, Religion, and Science victories are all quite fun yet I seem to be forced into Domination most games just because the AI declares war on me a turn after I meet them. I would wait until the game is ironed out before really diving in and sinking hundreds of hours though.Other than the AI, I feel like production is nerfed. I can move so far into the tech and civic trees while still struggling to create districts/wonders even into the late game. I feel as if this is a bug in the industrial district not actually adding what it says it adds to a city's production.Again, wait for the game to be ironed out with patches, (hopefully free) DLC, and the inevitable expansions.Update - Late Nov.First Patch cleaned up the interface and made it slightly easier to see some things that previously needed mods to see (like culture border growth), however the AI is still extremely lackluster. Wait for more patches.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Here are I my thoughts on on Civ 6: I've over 1000 hours on civ 5 (and probably 2000hrs combined on all previous civs) and approaching 100 on Civ 6 (I've never played Civ BE) and I think they missed the mark on this one . Let me explain:When I first played Civ 6, I didn't like the cartoonish art, was not a fan of the new builder mechanic and didn't like the monotonously colored map aka fog of war. I played several hours and then, to my delight, I started to understand the builder simplicity, appreciated the new art style. The new map style I still hated however. I finally started to get it.But, after dozens of hours of play, I couldn't ignore the painfully broken AI with completely random wars, behaviors and the strangest “friend” requests. They'll ask you to be your friend and suddenly DOW your butt. There are so many weird issues that I simply can't list them all here but to name a few more: the AI rarely attacks you after a DOW, does not defend it's positions at all and sometimes will nag you every turn for things like alliances which just slows the game down. AI has always been the worst part of the Civ series but it seems to be at its worst in the newest Civ game. There are also some graphical bugs but the game is still fairly new so I can ignore these.What really made me dislike Civ 6 however, was not particularly its flaws, but it was when I returned to Civ 5 and realized just how much of step back Civ 6 is. Everything from the map detail to color pallete (there seems to be a really nice contrast in Civ 5) to the game interface seemed “better”.I can't recommend this latest Civ game at its current stage but I hope that future add ons for it will help it “evolve” such as G&K and BNW did for Civ 5. In the meantime, I do highly recommend that you pick up Civ 5 and see for yourself the points I have outlined above.

Serious balance issues. I can't recommend this game until it addresses these basic game flow issues.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've spent only a few hours in this game and so far....it sucks! I have spent many, many hours in all of the Civ games and I just don't care to play this one, it really really sucks! they have changed certain aspects of the game and it no longer appeals to me....at all. They have tried to conserve power consumption and now allow the territory you've covered to go nearly blank again, not good but that's just one small complaint...little about this game feels right and I'm really dissapointed and after spending this much money on this game I feel betrayed. I'm not sure I care to play this game anymore...but if I do and I change my mind, I will rewrite this review but as of this day I don't recommend the game, but it's your money!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Pros:Interesting new game mechanics (limited actions for builders, Wonders needing tiles, Districts, Traders building roads, etc)Beautiful art/musicCons:Horrible combat AI: Enemy units almost never attack cities.Horrible diplomacy AI: Enemy civs hate you for just about everything, and can declare war 2 turns after telling you how much they admire youHorrible UI: Information hidden all over the place, unnecessary text ("Amenities from.." x 10), buttons that are extremely hard to click or need multiple clicks (City/Encampment attack), no "restart game" button, "Create game" screen doesn't remember your last game setup and forces you to start from scratch every timeBugs/Exploits/Glitches: With some civs, it is easier to make units, sell them and use the gold to buy buildings instead of actually producing the buildings. The AI trading is bugged and can be exploited to make them give up luxuries for close to no gold in returnThis game needs at least another 6 months of dev time.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Ill keep it as fast and simple as possible.Not as good as civ 5.10/10 would refund if it didnt take longer than 2 hours to actually get into a civ game. That part is Valves fault (gotta make that buck huh valve)Its not a bad game, in and of itself. But from civ5, its a let down. Even beyond earth was better (basically a clone of civ 5)Civ 6 takes the age old concept of the civ games - does little to nothing to change it, and presents it in a very cartoonish way.Also, im positive the map sizes are in general much smaller than civ 5 (even with the mods to enlarge it which also mess up spawn locations)The end (sadly, it probably is for the Civ line of games)

title: Not Recommended
comment: Here are I my thoughts on on Civ 6: I've over 1000 hours on civ 5 (and probably 2000hrs combined on all previous civs) and approaching 100 on Civ 6 (I've never played Civ BE) and I think they missed the mark on this one . Let me explain:When I first played Civ 6, I didn't like the cartoonish art, was not a fan of the new builder mechanic and didn't like the monotonously colored map aka fog of war. I played several hours and then, to my delight, I started to understand the builder simplicity, appreciated the new art style. The new map style I still hated however. I finally started to get it.But, after dozens of hours of play, I couldn't ignore the painfully broken AI with completely random wars, behaviors and the strangest “friend” requests. They'll ask you to be your friend and suddenly DOW your butt. There are so many weird issues that I simply can't list them all here but to name a few more: the AI rarely attacks you after a DOW, does not defend it's positions at all and sometimes will nag you every turn for things like alliances which just slows the game down. AI has always been the worst part of the Civ series but it seems to be at its worst in the newest Civ game. There are also some graphical bugs but the game is still fairly new so I can ignore these.What really made me dislike Civ 6 however, was not particularly its flaws, but it was when I returned to Civ 5 and realized just how much of step back Civ 6 is. Everything from the map detail to color pallete (there seems to be a really nice contrast in Civ 5) to the game interface seemed “better”.I can't recommend this latest Civ game at its current stage but I hope that future add ons for it will help it “evolve” such as G&K and BNW did for Civ 5. In the meantime, I do highly recommend that you pick up Civ 5 and see for yourself the points I have outlined above.

title: Not Recommended
comment: While the new "wide" cities concept introduces a much welcome dynamic to the series, pressing issues such as persistent game breaking bugs, abysmal pacing and abominable AI makes it hard for me to reccomend this game. Fireaxis, please fix this game!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Built 5 units and conquered the world. The hardest part was waiting for the turns to load.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Was playing with my friend and it was fun at first until we tried loading our save file. my friend couldn't join the game for some reason. we tried to see whether anyone had found way to bypass this problem but every time we tried we still ended up with the same result.I really can’t recommend this game at all until they fix this problem cause it really just ruin the whole game in general since it usually takes more than one day to finish a game. So, I don’t see the point in playing if we can’t finish the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I can research like the first 5 technologies in the time it takes me to build my first building....meanwhile those technologies unlocked 5 more builings/units that I won't have time to build before 20 more are unlocked. Also, units seem to require nearly as much production as buildings, making it impossilbe to really build an army if you even want a chance to progress economically, socially, spiritually or otherwise to keep pace with the technology and civic advancements. Serious balance issues. I can't recommend this game until it addresses these basic game flow issues.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Pros: Easier multiplayer mod setupCons: The quotes! Really kills the atmosphere.Just stick with Civ 5.

title: Recommended
comment: The themse song for the Russian civ is "Kalinka". Now that's classy.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Preface: Over 1000 hours played in Civ 5The Ai is so broken that Civ 6 is unplayable in single player. They will denounce you as soon as you meet them and send you deal requests with terms that they don't actually accept themselves.This game needs a complete overhaul to be anywhere near as good as Civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Easily the best Civilization game at launch that still seems to fall flat in regards to diplomacy and general AI. Culture, Religion, and Science victories are all quite fun yet I seem to be forced into Domination most games just because the AI declares war on me a turn after I meet them. I would wait until the game is ironed out before really diving in and sinking hundreds of hours though.Other than the AI, I feel like production is nerfed. I can move so far into the tech and civic trees while still struggling to create districts/wonders even into the late game. I feel as if this is a bug in the industrial district not actually adding what it says it adds to a city's production.Again, wait for the game to be ironed out with patches, (hopefully free) DLC, and the inevitable expansions.Update - Late Nov.First Patch cleaned up the interface and made it slightly easier to see some things that previously needed mods to see (like culture border growth), however the AI is still extremely lackluster. Wait for more patches.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Singleplayer is not very fun, like in any Civ game. The new systems(eureka, culture tree, districts) are polished, and up to scrap. The only one I dislike is the new resource system. Civ 5's was better. AI is completely broken. Multiplayer is still fun.It is also missing the massive army feel from Civ 5. Units feel incredibly weak and soft. Building a large army is virtually impossible. Music is also very repetative. Nice beats, but ultimately infuriating. Leaders no longer have full voices, only for greeting and being defeated.6/10Needs work on AI, combat, and music.ultimately, a step back. If they had created civ 5, but with the new features, things would have been much betterRecomended only if playing online

title: Not Recommended
comment: Wait until the DLCs.The look is fine, the civs are decient, couple bugs still going unnoticed, and... that's all I can say.This was the same thought I had when civ 5 came out, but that all changed when it was complete.Oh, and next time, try adding a civ leader that's not base on a ♥♥♥♥ing meme (Ghandi).

title: Not Recommended
comment: Completely manic tactically blind AI .. oh and they went from cool graphics and serious art of Civ 5 to some cartoony kiddy version which pretty much takes a giant dump on the whole immersion.. the game map does look pretty sweet tho

title: Not Recommended
comment: You've ruined the series with your money grabbing ideas, each new nation costs like £4? That's stupid.There's alot of issues that need to be worked on before you even start releasing new nations. What happened to the World council from Civ V? why don't you work on improving the game instead of releasing something new (which is trash) for people to buy for every week...

title: Not Recommended
comment: While I love this game andwill likely continue to play it in my spare time, I am also a diehard fanboy who has spent thousands of hours since I was 8 years old and I got Civ 3.If I were to recommend this, citystates should have more purpose. Commerce should have a winning condition, as it feels like an afterthought. Religious victory should be revamped from a quasi-combat mode. Additionally, science and culture victories are typically consolation prizes for almost getting a domination victory. Explaining tourism (the essential mechanic for a cultural victory) is hard, in part because I still do not fully understand what goes into its calculations.The lategame has been revamped fully, and is GREAT. All other iterations of Civ (thatI have played) basically had two or three contedners determined at the industrial age. With all of the different mechanics, every civilization should have a conceivable pathto a victory and most endings are intense.People complaining about the AI and diplomacy are fundamentally asking for too much. If the programmers for Civ 6 knew how to make sentient and adaptable AIs for such a complex ruleset, they should be working for IBM's Watson. That's not a sleight on the programmers at all: what I mean is that developing an answer to their complaints would be cutting-edge research. That being said, Diplomacy certainly seems to get exaggeratedly harder for the human player.In all, wait for moddable workshop content to be enabled, wait to see what the developers come up with for the expansions, and buy the micro-expansion civs and scenarios at a bundled and decreased price. It's great for the civ fan who has already bought it. But for the ones still holding out and reading reviews, you could likely hold out a bit longer and get a much better game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A friend recommended it, but in the end it's just not fun. Too different from the last ones, with game mechanics that just needlessly complicate it. Maybe further down the line when all the expansions are out and the game is cheaper it might be worth it. Especially if in a few years' time the modders have been able to improve it. But for now, not worth it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Great game and all, but £4 for 1 civ and the game isnt fully functional yet?Lol ♥♥♥♥ off firaxis, another company corupted by blind greed

title: Not Recommended
comment: Simply put, it's not fun. Whereas in civ5 everything just clicked, in civ6 nothing quite does.
