title: Not Recommended
comment: Unpolished, lacking in features, and even the features present are not well presented or explained. Tech tree feels a lot more empty now than ever before. It feels like they got rid of old features like 'health' and 'happiness' only to replace them with 'housing space' and 'amenities', both of which lack the intuitive ui and depth of the old, and really there seems to be no way to dig deeper into or look comprehensively at either feature than just looking at an individual city screen. Also is it just me or is amenities broken? It went down to like -4 in one of my cities once when I wasn't paying attention, but the penalties were the same as at -1 amenities, and apparently had been for a few dozen turns. So you can completely disregard happiness as long as you're willing to sacrifice 5% of your yields. Enemy AI is bad, even by Civ standards. Last game's homicidal Ghandhi was endearing, but now all leaders are ridiculously aggressive. The only time in 5 playthroughs I have had an AI attempt diplomacy with me was one civ who was at war with the other 4 that I knew. After he sent me a gift and praised me, and we had traded some resources (on unfair terms but no one else was trading with me and I needed gold), he then declared a surprise war on me, and never invaded. Which I am guessing is what happened between him and all other civs too, because although they were all at war for centuries, no cities ever changed hands. AI nations are impossible to trade with on terms that are not extortionate, and even bending over backwards and accepting unfair trade deals, I still have never been able to go beyond trade deals with an AI nation, even when I try to play a relatively peaceful style and deal with other more pacifisty nations. Also the only diplomatic attitude ui is emojis next to the leader's portraits, with no real explanations as to why. Every game so far, just about every nation I have met has gone to the frowny emoji within a few turns of contact, no matter how I handle things. Even better, after AI declare and subsequently bungle or abandon their wars against you, surrender never really makes much sense either. Once Japan totally surprised me, and before I could bring the bulk of my army and navy back to my unfortified and undefended capital it was surrounded by ~5 strong japanese units with more coming ashore. But no, they just kind of sat there. One of them pillaged one improvement. The rest just kind of sat on improved tiles. ONE unit attacked my capital city ONE time, and did some damage. Though if they had all attacked relentlessly, it easily would have fallen with minimal losses for the invaders. I bought an archer unit and literally built walls for like 10 turns, and bombarded the still stationary army. Once all the units in range were dead (~5 killed, ~5 remaining), Japan surrendered and gave me tons of gold for 30 turns. None of their units really went anywhere after the war either, the ones that had landed and were sitting on the border of my capital city still sat there until I decided to destroy Japan a few dozen turns later. Since that first time, every single time I have been invaded has played out in roughly this way, if they even make it to my cities. Barbarian marauders wrecking tiles are more of a pain than a serious invasion by the world's strongest AI armies, which is strange because the barbarians are AI too, and quite decent. I watched another country invading me lose most of their army to barbarian quniteremes trying to cross the ocean without naval escort, with the survivors mopped up by barbarian units on shore and 1 spearman I had been exploring the area with (who witnessed the slaughter from shore). I am guessing with the number of AI counties that declare war on me, and then offer me very favorable surrender conditions a few dozen turns later, with literally no fighting between us, have also managed to lose their invasion forces this way (?). AI is a little better at defending in wars than it is in attacking, so to keep things interesting I usually end up invading people after their first or second failed wars against me. Also the game just feels a lot smaller, in terms of city building options (districts were a really cool concept, but the ballooning costs really killed it for me, I didn't even understand what was happening until someone here explained it). The maps and armies also feel a lot smaller than in previous games. Growth feels a lot slower and more grinding too. On a huge map with 3 civs, tons of room for explosive growth, after 300+ turns of growth in these optimum conditions on regular difficulty, I have not seen any civ rise beyond a technoligically stagnant backwater that only really excels at one thing. On my huge map like this, around the year 1600, one civ had very advanced culture plicies, but was wayyyy behind in all aspects of development, the other had no special characteristics, and was far behind me(and the times) in technology, size, etc. I don't mention the third one because I believe they were wiped out by barbarians? There was a message about their death very early on, and unless they spawned rightttt next to one of the other civs, on a huge continents map, no civ killed them off. And in a more densely populated world this is even worse. I was kind of worried about the series becoming too dumbed down in Civ V, even though I eventually came to love that game after a few playthroughs. And if I can do the same with this one after a few patches and playthroughs I will amend this review. But right now, it seems the game has been dumbed down too far for my liking, and has lost that magic 'one more turn' feeling, which I can honestly say I never felt after the first few dozen turns in any of my playthroughs so far. Instead of becoming more fast paced as technology and society advance like in past games, if anything this game bogs itself down in ballooning unit and district costs in the late game, and there is no real feeling of sense or a narrative behind the actions of late game civs, or other civs at any point in history, really. I have yet to see a coalition of religions or ideologies work together or fight one another, which both civ 5 and 4 pulled off VERY well. Here, the mid to late game seems much like the early game, constant minor wars that go nowhere, and slow grinding expansion. Also sometimes someone will win a cultural or religious victory, and it can be you if you actually reach for either with any amount of effort. 3/5 of my complete playthrough have just ended with score victories, twice for me, and once for greece, who got a ton of points for advanced policies, but really wasn't relevant or powerful in any other way. None of these victories felt like winning though. I got a lot more familiar with how to manage districts, and am now playing for a science victory, but I am not sure if I am even going to finish this game. So far I just took over 2 nice big continents, and am now spamming campus districts and their buildings, while trying to hold off the religious emissaries from all civilizations who have not declared war on me. Thankfully for science, none of my enemies have been able to overcome my masterful defense strategy of: Building walls in a few cities. I don't garrison ANY cities, and right now have 2 spearmen and a warrior. The year is ~1700. When there is a threat of invasion I buy a ranged unit in the city. I should really just declare war on them so they stop sending the missionaries into my lands. Also wtf, religion mechanics never well explained, and basically no useful ui on them. To see the breakdown of city religion I need to select a missionary, but sometimes this does not even work. Also instead of the pressures from civ 5, the most indicator you will ever get of how things are going is an arrow. up or down. That tells you which religion is winning. I haven't even tried espionage because honestly I haven't needed it at all, but I doubt it adds much to the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeThe simple fact I HAVEN'T played more than three hours (EDIT: Gave it another chance, still wasn't that good) is a sin against the Civilization franchise. While it has its ambitious moments, with its fleshed-out district system and different governments as card-based perk decks, it simply doesn't add enough to the formula to warrant its hefty AAA price. Meanwhile, Civilization V and every DLC ever created for it recently went up in the sale for 33p (43¢). Think on that. Are fancy tile decors and playing cards worth an extra £49?

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's unfinished. Don't believe the 20 different articles all saying "This Civilization is the most complete game upon release they've ever made," they must've all been paid to write that. It's full of bugs and features that haven't been finished and terrible UI choices and AI that makes no sense. All of these things should've been fixed over several more months of development. I'm furious that I paid 80 dollars for this and baffled by the overwhelming support from gaming industry media who decided not to report on the glaring flaws. Wait until it's on sale in a year or two.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Wish i could give neutralThe new district system feels awesome. You build city districts, such as a campus, which enable specialised buildings in them, like library and university. Both districts and world wonders take up a map tile. The city radius of 3 tiles in any direction helps a lot with this.There are various adjacency bonuses, and sometimes terrain requirements, and a lot of different districts.Honestly this system feels like a lot of fun. every single building is visually represented, theres joy in watching your little cities grow and spread across the map.HOWEVER.Districts can't be torn down or replaced. As soon as you merely START building a district, it becomes an irrevocable feature of the landscape. If you misclicked, you'll be sorry. And when you capture an AI city with districts poorly laid outThe number of districts a city can have is limited by population. In theory this just means that ou need to grow a little more to unlock another slot. However this brings me to the second issue:There's a midgame lull, where you'll exhaust all the resources around you and your cities get stuck unable to grow, amenity buildings can only be constructed in the entertainment district. If you don't have one then you're ♥♥♥♥ed, since you can't remove an existing district to place one, and you can't keep growing without one, you can end up stuck in a corner.All of this aside, there's also a disappointingly small number of buildings you can place in each district. Generally four in total by the end of the game. And with one small exception (museum types), theres no choice in that, its just brainlessly build all four and the district is maxed out.The new tech system is interesting, the tech tree is split into scientific and cultural things, the latter using culture instead of research to unlock stuff. It does mean less focus is on science, which has previously been something you must excel at or die.The vast majority of the things in the culture tree are government policies. They come as cards you can slot into your chosen government type. each of the 10ish government choices has its own arrangement of slots.HOWEVERMany of the policy cards you unlock are frankly, awful. It feels like they weren't properly playtested, or given much attention to balance. And as a result i find myself gravitating to the same 30%ish of the cards and ignoring most of them, as the bonuses they give are too small and too situational.Given the extremely tiny number of slots a government has, versus the vast swathe of policy cards you'll unlock, you'll find yourself just not using most of them.The combat system is awful. Because its the same system from Civ V. It was awful then too. Its slightly less awful now, thanks to the addition of corps and armies - you can fuse several of the same units together into one stronger version. This new idea works but is unlocked too late to really fix things.The AI is...complicated.In terms of running an empire at least, the AI appears to be competent, a bit too much so, or perhaps they're just cheating. AI players seem to take a tech lead in the beginning, and even on a low difficulty - with me and a friend working together, we had to struggle to even keep to the middle of the pack, as AIs outstripped us in tech and military power, conquered their neighbors, and hoarded every world wonder and great person before we could get a look in.On a macro level, the AI seems very efficient at building running an empireOn a diplomatic level though, there's a lot to be desired.AI players will frequently denounce you. Its impossible to avoid upsetting someone. Maintaining even one AI friend is extremely difficult.AIs will frequently and puzzlingly offer you trades that THEY don't agree to. They'll literally put an offer on the table and say something like "there's no way i'd agree to those terms." when they brought up the subject, and explicitly contacted you to present this offer.When you're winning a war, an AI opponent will contact you to beg for peace every turn. Every single turn. There's no way to just tell them to bugger off.And AIs will frequently contact you in order to request trading some large number of great works for more of the same, constantly trading works around in an endless circlejerk of diplomacy.And for all of the above examples, if you want to view these deals that pop up in your feed, clicking the icon will freeze the game for a few seconds while it loads up the fancy animated leaderhead, just so they can waste your time with this inane spam. This happens every turn in the lategame. Often multiple times per turn from various leaders, all of the AI leaders seem to exist only to spam your inbox with meaningless drivel and absurd trade deals.Dealing with them starts to feel more like work than gaming. Thankfully you can ignore them, but you cant dismiss them. The offers will sit there conspicuously in your notification area, until you talk to the AI, which you'll need to eventually.Overpowered early barbarians, forces warrior spamCity states still insist on spamming the world with every boring detail of changes in their diplomatic relations, and they become yet another source of background noise that drags you down, wastes your attention reading it, and ever so slowly saps the fun out of the gameThe trade system is also a pain. the constantly asking you to pick a new destination for the traderoute stops being a meaningful choice. Eventually you'll just be clicking to repeat the same route, because you already have another route to all the other places. Menu is laggy as hell, because it insists on finding and displaying a fancy path for every destination you hover over, however incidentally. Pathfinding over half the size of the map is not cheap, even if you have a monstrous CPUAny AI that manages to found a religion will make its solemn duty to convert you, and everyone else, by building thousands of missionaries and sending them into your territory.These missionaries ignore closed borders, you can't keep them out. They just walk right in. And due to the stupid one unit per tile system, they block the movement of YOUR units, unless you're willing to declare war. You can kill them with troops, but declaring war makes you the bad guy and causes a relations penalty with the world.You can ask an AI to stop trying to convert your people, but they'll either refuse, or agree to stop but then keep doing it anyways.War is not fun. The AI never learns its lesson. After you're done taking a city or two, you'd think they'd show you some respect. They will beg for peace and offer you handsome rewards, but as soon as you agree to it, they'll go right back to denouncing you, trading with your enemies, conspiring against you, spying on you, closing their borders and spamming missionaries all over your lands.The only recourse you have is to completely annihilate them and take every city. You cant make vassalsThere's no building queues in cities, and no automation for workers. So every time a city or worker is done doing the one thing you told them, you have to give them the next order. And then the next, and the next. This quickly becomes a pain with a large number of cities, and leads to you probably not bothering to improve large empires. The fact that workers have limited constructions before they need to be replaced doesn't help thatSid Meier himself once said, "A game is a series of meaningful choices." and thats something i'd strongly agree withUltimately, Civ VI is a game of many, many choices. But a very large portion of them are not meaningful. The game far too often asks - nay forces you, to make decisions that are irrelevant, and to manually take actions which are tedious and should have been automated or skipped entirelyToo much of the gameplay just feels like workOverall, 5.5/10

title: Not Recommended
comment: Right now the game is not worth the buy. Not exactly rushed out but definitely missing a whole lot of polishing.The UI is a mess often lacking plenty of information you really need. For instance an entire enemy force which sets foot on your territory; there is no alert for that so you have to check everything yourself. They tried to simplify the design of the interface but instead it merely leads to more looking and clicking till you may or may not find what you have been looking for.Also the AI is completely nonfunctioning, making decision without any sense (e.g. sending units into combat that will definitely not survive or sending them into combat to simply pull them back immediately). The AI is often not capable of negotiating fair trades. Most annoying, however, is the warmongering of the AI. At times declaring war when you just met them and have not even build a second city, but at least declaring war after a while for no apparent reason. The latter happened in ever single of my games. A few times I even have been at war with someone who I have not even met.On top of this several quite annoying bugs (e.g. units with no orders and unused move points are simply forgotten without notification until you remember yourself Oh, there was that archer I haven't moved for 20 turns.) Also the loading times are way too long. I stopped the time at 1 minute and 40 seconds, playing on an SSD.To be entriely honest, the new additions (e.g. districts, policies and such) are nice and cool but feel more like DLC. There is too little new content and too many steps backwards to justify the full price.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I will list this game in the category "Disappoints of the 2016", Next to Total War: WARHAMMER, and the Elections in the USA.I loved Civ5, played the game for somewhat 400 hours and that's why I got really hyped for Civ6.From the moment I started the game I was disappointed, the animations disappointed me and the Faction-leader Models disappointmented me. Gameplay just didnt feel right. Tech Trees made no sense and Civics tree felt very insignificant. Tech Balance was way off, I easily managed to research Satalites by the year 1700 (without even focussing on tech). I don't like how Raging barbarians is on by default, forcing you to always make a huge army to even stay alive, which makes the game feel very slow.

title: Not Recommended
comment: To paraphase Neil Armstrong"One small step for gamers""One Gaint leap BACKWARDS for Civilization"

title: Not Recommended
comment: I tried to love this game... really hard. In fact, spent many hours of it. I did enjoy some... But in the end, Civ V was SO much better.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Interesting ideas, but it fails in execution. Do yourself a favor & go with Civ 5 instead, at least until the gameplay of VI is fixed.It's not bad. It's just nowhere near as good as Civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Unpolished, lacking in features, and even the features present are not well presented or explained. Tech tree feels a lot more empty now than ever before. It feels like they got rid of old features like 'health' and 'happiness' only to replace them with 'housing space' and 'amenities', both of which lack the intuitive ui and depth of the old, and really there seems to be no way to dig deeper into or look comprehensively at either feature than just looking at an individual city screen. Also is it just me or is amenities broken? It went down to like -4 in one of my cities once when I wasn't paying attention, but the penalties were the same as at -1 amenities, and apparently had been for a few dozen turns. So you can completely disregard happiness as long as you're willing to sacrifice 5% of your yields. Enemy AI is bad, even by Civ standards. Last game's homicidal Ghandhi was endearing, but now all leaders are ridiculously aggressive. The only time in 5 playthroughs I have had an AI attempt diplomacy with me was one civ who was at war with the other 4 that I knew. After he sent me a gift and praised me, and we had traded some resources (on unfair terms but no one else was trading with me and I needed gold), he then declared a surprise war on me, and never invaded. Which I am guessing is what happened between him and all other civs too, because although they were all at war for centuries, no cities ever changed hands. AI nations are impossible to trade with on terms that are not extortionate, and even bending over backwards and accepting unfair trade deals, I still have never been able to go beyond trade deals with an AI nation, even when I try to play a relatively peaceful style and deal with other more pacifisty nations. Also the only diplomatic attitude ui is emojis next to the leader's portraits, with no real explanations as to why. Every game so far, just about every nation I have met has gone to the frowny emoji within a few turns of contact, no matter how I handle things. Even better, after AI declare and subsequently bungle or abandon their wars against you, surrender never really makes much sense either. Once Japan totally surprised me, and before I could bring the bulk of my army and navy back to my unfortified and undefended capital it was surrounded by ~5 strong japanese units with more coming ashore. But no, they just kind of sat there. One of them pillaged one improvement. The rest just kind of sat on improved tiles. ONE unit attacked my capital city ONE time, and did some damage. Though if they had all attacked relentlessly, it easily would have fallen with minimal losses for the invaders. I bought an archer unit and literally built walls for like 10 turns, and bombarded the still stationary army. Once all the units in range were dead (~5 killed, ~5 remaining), Japan surrendered and gave me tons of gold for 30 turns. None of their units really went anywhere after the war either, the ones that had landed and were sitting on the border of my capital city still sat there until I decided to destroy Japan a few dozen turns later. Since that first time, every single time I have been invaded has played out in roughly this way, if they even make it to my cities. Barbarian marauders wrecking tiles are more of a pain than a serious invasion by the world's strongest AI armies, which is strange because the barbarians are AI too, and quite decent. I watched another country invading me lose most of their army to barbarian quniteremes trying to cross the ocean without naval escort, with the survivors mopped up by barbarian units on shore and 1 spearman I had been exploring the area with (who witnessed the slaughter from shore). I am guessing with the number of AI counties that declare war on me, and then offer me very favorable surrender conditions a few dozen turns later, with literally no fighting between us, have also managed to lose their invasion forces this way (?). AI is a little better at defending in wars than it is in attacking, so to keep things interesting I usually end up invading people after their first or second failed wars against me. Also the game just feels a lot smaller, in terms of city building options (districts were a really cool concept, but the ballooning costs really killed it for me, I didn't even understand what was happening until someone here explained it). The maps and armies also feel a lot smaller than in previous games. Growth feels a lot slower and more grinding too. On a huge map with 3 civs, tons of room for explosive growth, after 300+ turns of growth in these optimum conditions on regular difficulty, I have not seen any civ rise beyond a technoligically stagnant backwater that only really excels at one thing. On my huge map like this, around the year 1600, one civ had very advanced culture plicies, but was wayyyy behind in all aspects of development, the other had no special characteristics, and was far behind me(and the times) in technology, size, etc. I don't mention the third one because I believe they were wiped out by barbarians? There was a message about their death very early on, and unless they spawned rightttt next to one of the other civs, on a huge continents map, no civ killed them off. And in a more densely populated world this is even worse. I was kind of worried about the series becoming too dumbed down in Civ V, even though I eventually came to love that game after a few playthroughs. And if I can do the same with this one after a few patches and playthroughs I will amend this review. But right now, it seems the game has been dumbed down too far for my liking, and has lost that magic 'one more turn' feeling, which I can honestly say I never felt after the first few dozen turns in any of my playthroughs so far. Instead of becoming more fast paced as technology and society advance like in past games, if anything this game bogs itself down in ballooning unit and district costs in the late game, and there is no real feeling of sense or a narrative behind the actions of late game civs, or other civs at any point in history, really. I have yet to see a coalition of religions or ideologies work together or fight one another, which both civ 5 and 4 pulled off VERY well. Here, the mid to late game seems much like the early game, constant minor wars that go nowhere, and slow grinding expansion. Also sometimes someone will win a cultural or religious victory, and it can be you if you actually reach for either with any amount of effort. 3/5 of my complete playthrough have just ended with score victories, twice for me, and once for greece, who got a ton of points for advanced policies, but really wasn't relevant or powerful in any other way. None of these victories felt like winning though. I got a lot more familiar with how to manage districts, and am now playing for a science victory, but I am not sure if I am even going to finish this game. So far I just took over 2 nice big continents, and am now spamming campus districts and their buildings, while trying to hold off the religious emissaries from all civilizations who have not declared war on me. Thankfully for science, none of my enemies have been able to overcome my masterful defense strategy of: Building walls in a few cities. I don't garrison ANY cities, and right now have 2 spearmen and a warrior. The year is ~1700. When there is a threat of invasion I buy a ranged unit in the city. I should really just declare war on them so they stop sending the missionaries into my lands. Also wtf, religion mechanics never well explained, and basically no useful ui on them. To see the breakdown of city religion I need to select a missionary, but sometimes this does not even work. Also instead of the pressures from civ 5, the most indicator you will ever get of how things are going is an arrow. up or down. That tells you which religion is winning. I haven't even tried espionage because honestly I haven't needed it at all, but I doubt it adds much to the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Coming from Civ 5 and previous civs the base game here is feature complete compared to the last games. However, there are a lot of negatives here that make this game not worth the AAA price they are asking.The AI. It is atrocious, and is probably the worst AI I have played against on any strategy game(and I play a lot of them if you check my library). The AI does not know how to do diplomacy correctly, offering crazy things that make no sense. The AI does not know how to use tactics in war at all. They will send units towards your city and it may look overwhelming, but then half of them just spread out and go seperate ways for no reason allowing you to just pick them off. They try to attack your boats with their unit transport ships(this made me laugh). They will settle literally one tile away from the border of your city, and cram cities where they should not be(basically any space, even with no food).The UI. The UI has a lot of little quirks and bugs that make it annoying to use. The main complaint I have(I can't believe it's not fixed after the first patch) is the alert system. I can go a few turns before I even notice an AI player is wanting to trade or demanding something. It just pops up a little bubble on the right-side of the screen. Also these little alert notices are bugged and you cannot remove some of them or click on them to expand them sometimes.Bugs. There are to many to go over here, as I notice them nearly every play session.Graphics. The mobile cartoon look is horrible, even though I don't really care about graphics much it is worth mentioning as they are worse than Civ 5.Overall this game has potential to surpase Civ 5 in a few expansions maybe, but it will depend on how they patch the game. I don't see them making AI much better honestly(it wasn't that great in Civ 5 either). I will come back and update this review if I notice they patch out these issues, but as of this review the game is not worth $60. I would say it maybe worth grabbing it on a sale of 50% or more off.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's unfinished. Don't believe the 20 different articles all saying "This Civilization is the most complete game upon release they've ever made," they must've all been paid to write that. It's full of bugs and features that haven't been finished and terrible UI choices and AI that makes no sense. All of these things should've been fixed over several more months of development. I'm furious that I paid 80 dollars for this and baffled by the overwhelming support from gaming industry media who decided not to report on the glaring flaws. Wait until it's on sale in a year or two.

title: Not Recommended
comment: AI development on this series has quite obviously lagged behind to the point now it's derailed the game for me. This isn't a new thing, Civ hasn't had an AI that could deal with the variables at play for awhile. So the changes in the various components in each iteration feels like rearranging deck chairs on the titanic.Regret the purchase, won't happen again, this series is dead to me now.

title: Recommended
comment: I think people have forgotten how awful Civ V was launch. Like seriously that game is only good because of the expansions. I can't say this is better than Civ V Complete yet, as there are a few glaring issues (which I'll get to), but compared to Vanilla V, this is way ♥♥♥♥ing better. This actually feels like a complete game in it's vanilla state, Religion, Trade Routes ect. are all here in the Vanilla version. Hell it even fixes a lot of the complaints I had with Civ V complete. I honestly can't think of what they really need to add in expansions as of right now, other than new civs of course (Byzantium, Mayans, and Persia pls)Now about that dumbass AI (the War Elephant in the room). It still can't use 1UPT for♥♥♥♥♥♥and is basically just as bad as V's other than one new issue: the warmongering. Where the AI in V was content to just passive agressively denounce you every few turns the AI in 6 will declare war on you constanly and hate you for not following their agendas or for no reason at all. The agenda system is good on paper but in practice it means someone is always salty af. These people have no chill. I hope Firaxis fixes this at some point. Like why is Civ IV's AI from 12 years ago still infinitly better than V and VI's?Also just kind of weird but in my first complete game of this (which I played on Prince) I was in the Modern Era in 1250 AD and spent pretty much the entire game atleast 10 techs ahead of every AI, so I spent the last half of the game mowing down Saka Horse Archers and Pikemen with my machine guns, while waiting for enough tourists for a culture win. It was a very odd experience.I feel like where Civ V was an awful game made great with expansions, this will be a good (but flawed) game made great with expansions, it will probably end up being better than V a few years from now when the expansions are released. Civ IV is still easily the best Civ game though, and I don't see that changing any time soon.

title: Not Recommended
comment: its good til you realize you have to use artillery to conquer a city. its good til you realize the AI has the intelligence of a 2 year old. its good til you find out no matter how fast you build or research you will still be behind your enemies. its good until you find the most lethal unit is early settlers. its not bad at first, its even fun, until you find the approaches the game gives you to winning are literally the winning conditions :p

title: Not Recommended
comment: In Civ 5, you might feel like a King or Queen of history shaping an interesting world into your own vision. In Civ 6, you feel like a toddler fighting with other toddlers over the toys on the cartoon map that uncle Napoleon gave you to play with while he does the real work. I don’t think you should pay more than a few bob for a colour-in sheet and some crayons to be honest.Conducting diplomacy with Elmer Barbarossa or Phillip Bunny just feels too stupid on several levels. Whether it be the way they swagger as they spew outlandish nonsense, or their total inability to incorporate realpolitik into their decisions, dealing with these children playing dress-up is only ever annoying.The world and tile system is interesting and more rewarding, but unit diversity (especially with UUs) feels non-existent and culture and tech have become tediously similar. I approve of culture buffs relative to science, but having 2 long continuous trees instead of 1 on seperate screens makes planning harder than necessary. Policies are a pretty awesome idea, though it feels like they need a greater variety of buffs to play with.Dear God, please banish all of the missionaries (which I can’t even kill) to hell. Religion has gone from nearly worthless, to an irritating rush win strategy which blocks up the map with tiny sanctimonious blaggards.I could go on, but what we’re looking at here is a shoddy game, with a few great core ideas that are unfortunately buried in the manure of the rest of the game. I started finding this game annoying after my first game, 5 or 6 later and I’m still not enjoying learning it (which should be the best part). 1 game of Civ 5 later and I’m much happier.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Much worse then Civ V , needs way more work to be a decent game

title: Recommended
comment: Much more fully featured than I expected.

title: Recommended
comment: So far it has everything that made the last one great and built on the engine. I really enjoy it so far I am not very far in to my first game but I look forward to spending more time in the game.

title: Recommended
comment: The best way to look at this game is price to play:1 hour = 1 dollar(Canadian in my case)do you think you'll play this game for more than 80 hours? if not, don't buy it, but if you're someone who enjoys playing the same game but as different characters, or in this case civilizations; this game is very much worth the high price.People who keep reporting these issues with AI obviously haven't played this game more than once.Much like Civ V this game will only get better with time; once i return home i expect to have at least another 100-200 hours in the next 2 months

title: Recommended
comment: A lot of people say this is a downgrade to Civ 5 which isn't entirely true or fair.Civ 5 on release was garbage.After 2 years and Gods and Kings, Civ 5 was good.After 2 more years and Brave New World, Civ 5 became great.Civ 6 on release was bugged, but decent.After 1 year of patches, updates, and no major $30 expansion, Civ 6 is good.Civ 6, on a fundamental level, is miles ahead of its predecessors. The district system, multiple bonuses to civs and leaders, the Culture Tree, and new graphics are amazing improvements to the civ recipe. DLC civs are as pay2win as people might lead you to believe. Should you buy this game? If you've played Civ 5 to the ground and lust for more Civ then yes.

title: Recommended
comment: I'm new to the series Civilization and coming from one who hasn't played past games, this game is awesome! The graphics are cool and the game is very tactical.A lot of people will complain about the bad AI (honestly the only reason people even give bad reviews you'll notice), but it isn't that bad. The ai plays at a level that still makes it challenging, funny sometimes. The civs are extremely cool to interact with and the tech tree is very accurate, coming from a history geek.Advance through time and create the greatest civilization ever known as you listen to nice music in the background that isn't annoying like other games.The one thing I do recomend is that you look at some tutorials or walkthroughs before playing your first game because the game is very complex and requires some good thinking! Good luck advancing your civilization!

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI and UI both make this game unplayable for me. Maybe the religion and cultural aspects of the game are fun? Here's the thing though, I have a tiny army and its just steamrolling entire nations because they won't defend themselves. The UI is awful, and that extends into things like the adviser and even the cinematic cut-scenes for diplomacy. How many times am I expected to watch the same speech in Greek over and over again?

title: Not Recommended
comment: Sadly, for all it's fluff, this is not a game worth paying for. Civ V is the last decent Civ game, only because there were a lot of mods for it, but even unmodded it was not a bad game. Civ VI is just crap; a company preying on the success and popularity of a title, and in the process giving Sid Meier a bad name. If there were a way to get my $ back for this underwhelming disappointment of a game, I would go for it. My recommendation: do not buy.Pros: Looks pretty.Cons: Not very playable, poor AI, no mod tools (yet).

title: Not Recommended
comment: I love the Civ games and have even put a decent amount of time into this one as well. At first I wanted to recommend this game to everyone as the music and graphics are fantastic and really appealing. However that's about as good as it gets for the Civ game. (Compared to previous entries)First off, diplomacy doesn't exsist. You meet a civilization and your choice is to say hi or not to. (has little to no impact) Next after twidling your thumbs messing with improving your civ you get denounced. Why you may ask. Well because you're inferior of course. You don't have the tech that they are given at the very beginning so **** you. After you try to improve relations and improve your Civ they declare war on you. Why again? Oh because you're weak and dont believe in their religion. Afterwards they send their "army" which usually consist of 2 units that you obliterate. Then once you conquer them the whole world denounces you for being a "warmonger" which basically just makes you nerfed to all hell because you ****ing fought back. Like seriously did they even evolve this game?Pros:Nice GraphicsNice MusicCons:Horrible AIHorrible DiplomacyHorrible city planning (districts are cool but usually make your small piece of landmass a huge city with no space for further development)Horrible building (Sometimes I'd build a district or something and all that happens is a big red exclamation mark pops up saying something is in the way but when you bring a builder to clear the area nothing happens)Game gets boring quick (Like I said no Diplomacy so no temporary friendships or trade)Oh and trade lol, You try to make a resonable offer to a country and they will 99% of the time decline the offer, then 5 rounds later will ask you to trade all of your resources AND gold per turn for their 1 cottonI wanted to love this game so much but it just fails in every strategic endeavor. I even waited MONTHS before I reviewed this game hoping the devs would fix these issues. However, after all these months with nothing but♥♥♥♥♥♥updates and ridiculous DLC that adds things that should already be there. This game does little to nothing new that the old Civ games did better. If you want a good strategy game go look at the older Civ games or another strategy game in general. Until the Devs prove that they care this game is not worth over $20. Please fix your game Firaxis, I know you're a good company somewhere in there. Just fix this game so it can be worthy of the Civ title.

title: Recommended
comment: Warning: This game may cause you to be tired at or late for work.

title: Recommended
comment: good gem

title: Not Recommended
comment: This one's a toss-up. I won't go into every little detail here because I'm hoping that many of the problems with this game will be fixed by upcoming expansions, at which point I will update this review. In any case, right now V (with all DLC, speicifically Brave New World) is much cheaper, always on sale, and a more complete game. I think V is still the quintessential civ game right now, and if you're reading reviews seriously you probably are new-ish to civ. Wouldn't recommend to people relatively new to the franchise simply because V is better (especially singleplayer) and more balanced right now. Still can be a blast, and I'm glad I purchased it since i have several hundred hours across the civ franchise.

title: Not Recommended
comment: TLDR: Too many issues, awful AI, awful map generation.Ever since the expansion came out, I haven't managed to make it more than 50 turns without being declared war upon by the AI who somehow has far more units than I could have hoped to produce in that time frame. I had hoped that the AI would get better and more reasonable with the expansion, but they seem to have gotten worse. I can't build a builder without having four AI's denounce me and declare war five turns later. I truly enjoy the Civilization franchise, but I'm having no fun with this current iteration. To add on to the AI frustration, it doesn't help when you start a standard size map with fewer number of civs than the game calls for, and somehow two opponent civilizatons are within 15 tiles of your start location. There is nothing fun about that, you know an AI civ will declare war just for being too close.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Whilst remaining a great strategy title, the game that single handedly advanced the resource management and 4x genres to heights never before imagined, now seems to me to be something that has been subsumed and surpassed by the Total War series. And for that reason, rather than for any individual lack, I can't bring myself to thumbs up it to a modern audience. Continually pouring out sequels that offer only minor advancements ( a la Football Manager) is not going to save the license but instead quantify the maxim "flogging a dead horse". On top of this you have the globally disliked use of DLC milking. All of which can only result in the response "for diehard fans of the series only".

title: Not Recommended
comment: Plainly stated this is a terrible base game. When compared to vanilla Civilization V, this game is unplayable. Civilization IV, which I wasn’t fond of, and Civilization V by far are more coherent and fun to invest my time playing. Civilization VI on the other hand, suffers massively due to the A.I, terrible/useless Civ bonuses, lack of a decent user interface and overall terrible design. The game does benefit from certain aspects, consisting primarily of the superb soundtrack, leader animation, leader personalities, and voice acting; however, the good doesn’t out way the bad, far from it actually. Even though the leaders are nicely animated and voiced, in my opinion, the selections for many are questionable, especially for the Civs they’re representing. I don’t understand, and maybe this is because I love history, why Firaxis couldn’t get certain historical aspects correct. I understand it’s just a history game but Europa Universals, the Total War series, and Hearts of Iron, all try their best to accurately name countries and leaders. Civ V had this issue but it’s profound in Civ VI. The creators should have stuck with Civ V and adapted fan made mods into the base game. The A.I at least made some sense in Civ V as well, but in Civ VI, I had a game where I met a civilization and next turn they declared war on me without a reason. This gets frustrating constantly when compared with how the human player must declare war. I don’t understand why they didn’t mix Civ IV and Civ V’s diplomacy together for Civ VI, an example from Civ V is when the A.I is able to ask about troops on their boarder, but why couldn’t the human player get that in Civ VI? Mods adopted that ability in Civ V and it worked perfectly, so why leave it out again for the human player? The art, besides the leaders, is so lazy in this game compared to its predecessor as well. The religion icon selection is terrible and uninspired, just like Civ V. Honestly, it’s best to wait until this game is granted steam workshop support or until game changing DLC is announced.Lastly, I preordered the game and received the soundtracks as a bonus. The Civilization VI soundtrack, like I mentioned was terrific, but the 25th-anniversary soundtrack was a joke. It seemed like it was just thrown together last second and added in to convince people that they hadn’t forgotten about the 25th anniversary. A digital art book would have been nice and a more thought out anniversary soundtrack would have been appreciated.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A little background on me. I only played Civ V before this one and much like everyone else, I think that is a great game that works well.I got this game as a gift and can tell you right off the bat, the art style wasn't my thing. I've gotten over it though, and its tolerable for me. This game, could've been good, but the devs have failed (and still are) with balancing the AI.There is no balance, at all: On easier difficulties, enemy civs will almost never declare war on you. Once you get to King difficulty, its almost like it is inevitable that they will. I've never seen just one do it, each game there has been at least two of them declaring at the same time. The problem here is that on the harder difficulties civs will be extremely far ahead of you in tech no matter what, leaving you at a tech disadvantage and a numbers disadvantage.AI progession is broken: Even on easier difficulties, with sparse resources, there will always be one or two civs that are strong everywhere regardless. You could go all out on one victory situation and think "yeah, easy win", then you see a civ that already has rocket-based military, then see a notification that they have started launching space projects. Might as well quit the game. This is multiplied on difficulties past king. I've once seen a civ at this point at turn 150, which is insane.DENOUNCE, DENOUNCE, DENOUNCE, oh and DENOUNCE: This is a HUGE problem. If you so much as try and fight for land, which you some times have no choice as you may need resources, the rest of the AI players will CONSTANTLY denounce you the ENTIRE game until the end. Not only is seeing a leader denounce you get repetitive and boring, the game is penalizing you for strategic play. The cost for declaring war is WAY TOO HIGH. If the rest of the civs hate you for the one war you fought in, you cannot make border deals or research agreements for the rest of the game. Two key elements in some strategies. What makes this more frustrating is, EVEN IF A CIV DECLARES WAR ON YOU, they will hate you. You don't even have to be the one to initiate it. If a civ declares war, and you see it out until the end removing that civ, they can and will denounce you for simply defending your territory. COMPLETELY STUPID MECHANIC.AI trading: Civs in this game will try and rob you blind. They will constantly bait you for ridiculous trades. This annoys the crap out of me. I'm willing to trade stuff, but for a reasonable price. I've once seen a civ attempt to get iron from me (1 every 30 turns)........................FOR 6 GOLD. Like, are you serious?The game still has its moments, but I see broken and flat out stupid stuff like this all the time. It ruins the game. As far as I know, the most recent DLC hasn't addressed any of these issues either.I simply cannot recommend this game. A gift? Yeah, go for it. For its price tag, the ridiculous pricing of its DLC, this game's ridiculously dumb/broken AI isn't worth a dime. GET THIS GAME ON SALE, DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE................................Until they fix this AI bs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I love Civ. Played every game since Civ I. And Civ VI is a good game. But Firaxis should be ashamed of themselves for the scams they are trying to pull. You are not Paradox. Stop trying to make us pay $5 per new civ with no real gameplay updates or added mechanics. Or at least let the people who bought the game upgrade to Deluxe for the actual difference, not this %50 off deluxe for people who already own the game. Do a better job with your DLC policy and I'll be happy to make this a positive.And why would you do an update focusing on the religion morass that really just bogs down gameplay as you watch the 10 tile line of apostles come try to chant away your holy cities? It has turned me off of the religious gameplay altogether. All hail Kongo!

title: Not Recommended
comment: I played this game quite a bit over a free play weekend, and I was considering buying it during the sale as well. The game is fun and the graphics are beautiful, but there is one serious issue that prevents me from buying or recommending it.As you play the game with other AI players, they will sometimes bring units onto tiles in your city and just leave them there. When another player's unit is occupying a tile, you can't do certain things with it (like improve it). There doesn't seem to be any way to get other players' units to leave a tile besides declaring war and destroying them, which seems unreasonable for most cases. You can't ask another leader to have their units leave your borders. You can't ask the unit to move or nudge it out of the way.I did some searching and found that this issue has been reported repeatedly starting right after the release of Civilization VI in late 2016. Since it still hasn't been fixed and is detrimental to gameplay, I cannot recommend this game and I won't be playing it myself.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Hi Guys, I tried this game for a few hours but ended up requesting a refund. Just didn't see the enjoying that I used like in this game, found that I wasn't able to stack the units and felt more like a chess game which was the main reason. Just didn't see the value of putting hours of my time into this game which was a personal decision. Overall it looks great and it was a toss up to keep this game, however that was something that annoyed me to much.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Only not recommending because the game is mislabeled.It's not a strategy game it's a city builder.

title: Recommended
comment: Just played eleven hours straight.. For maximum fun. I waited until I was going to win from science scenario in three turns and dropped thermonuclear bombs on all the capitals and all of Gandhi's cities.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Feels more tedious than previous Civ games. There is a higher degree of variability in resources and choices but that doesn’t seem to translate to a more dynamic experience. Between all the various civ, tech, policy, adjacency and other bonuses I often find myself feeling like it was less of a hassle to just build what my advisor suggested than bother with all the math – rendering all the depth of the new version rather hollow. I don’t doubt that with several playthroughs you could really figure out how to maximize a civilization’s potential, but that feels more tedious than epic. All of this is thrown into even starker contrast with the AI, which doesn’t seem to be any more dynamic than previous versions.There’s some creative stuff in the game (districts are interesting, wonders on the map, separate science and culture trees). Without the benchmark of previous Civ games it would probably seem pretty good, but high expectations have been set and not met.

title: Recommended
comment: Notice that many of the bad reviews have a contradiction, they spend a crazy amount of time on a game they apparently don't like. The one at the top for example, he provides a very detailed, well-written argument for why he gave it a thumbs down. However, he played 5,000 hours before deciding this. I imagine I don't have to explain why this is a testament to how good the game is. The game is great, so great that people spend thousands of hours playing it. Then they say it wasn't worth their purchase, so I assume they must hate themselves. The only complaint I have is that it just doesn't seem like it will hold my interest after 5,000 hours, I expect more from a $60 purchase . . . . Gracious. In all seriousness, I've felt that I have gotten my money's worth after 25 hours, this game has so many fun layers to it. The soundtrack is amazing as well, adding on a new instrument with each advancement into a new era (I've only heard England's so far, and can't wait to experience the other Civilizations' themes).

title: Recommended
comment: I have completed all victory types in this game and put in a respectable number of hours at this point to come to some conclusions;Pros:- Research and Civics trees are good. Allowing the player the pivot as necessary. However some techs can be researched out of line in terms of natural progression- New UI is great, however when fighting, the fact that the attack button menu rises and falls is a bit annoying- Graphics looks great- Armies and Corps- New update fixes a lot of small issues- Culture is probably the most rewarding victory type (if you can survive all of the surprise wars)- Local happiness is a nice change but it needs a bit of work - maybe an extra early/mid-game building- Barbarians are nice and aggressiveCons:- War. Surprise wars never change. I have only played one game where I haven't had one or many surprise wars declared upon me. Sometimes forcing me to simply go for a domination victory because why not at that point.- I wish there was a system of warnings you could send to other players similar to what they do to you. Right now it's either live with it, denounce, or war.- Diplomacy is useless- AI always hates you- Random enemies don't seem very random. Typically get placed against the same group of enemies.- Religious fights between apostles are always in favour of the AI, regardless of difficulty.- On immortal dfficulty, the game has crashed taking a city. I was taking the second last civ of a domination win and basically wasted a bunch of hours- No proximity warning for units- Various other nit picky thingsOverall it's a great step forward, they just need to iron out some details

title: Not Recommended
comment: I played the Civ game that game out for the Xbox360 years ago. This PC version of Civ plays and feels almost exactly like that, which means it is an overly simplified version of what Civ games on the PC can and should be. If I wanted a simplified console version, I already have that. I was expecting much, much, much more from the PC version.GOOD:-The voice acting and dialogue is very good.-Graphics and smoothness is vastly improved - amazing.-Civics policies are introduced as a separate track from Technology, uses culture instead of science. Cool system.-Making terrain improvements consumes a builder slowly but surely. And as you advance in tech, your builders can do more things before being consumed. Very cool new twist.-Wonders are more complex, which requires more planning that previous Civ versions. (one of two areas where complexity was added or enhanced)-City planning of districts instead of one big lump in one city center requires more planning. (one of two areas where complexity was added or enhanced)MIXED-If you fall behind on the early religion wars, woe unto you because you will never recover. And overall it doesn't really add much to the game which makes the system nothing more than annoyance.-Regional production and regional amenity bonuses are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to manage properly.-You cannot add districts to a city as you please or when needed, all population driven which means you have to be overly careful in planning.-Like many other reviewers I find that the city-states are not well balanced in the bonuses they grant and take up too much territory. I find that if I don't severely limit their number during game configuration it is too easy to unbalance the game.BAD-The technology tree is *INCREDIBLY WATERED DOWN* to the point of boredom. It's bad.-The AI is pretty terrible, as other reviewers have reported.-AI starts with some pretty insane cheats, even at "average user" level.-Civs are not balanced against each other.-Overall, the game is very unbalanced.-Diplomacy is dicey at best and no-fun pretty much all the time. Meh.-Unit movement was SLOWED way, way down. Why? So much more trivial and painful now. Ugh.I think I will go back to Civ IV or Civ V and wait for Civ VII to be released. Civ VI is not worh my time or money, save your money for something else folks. I would also add that I don't give many negative reviews, so the fact that I would rate Civ VI badly says something about it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: While the phrase "dumbed down" has been somewhat watered down over the years, I feel it applies for me to Civ VI. I have happily sunk hundreds and hundreds of hours into earlier Civ games, but this... I just can't.Everything from the art style, to the UI, to the game mechanics, to the presentation... everything seems to cater to a younger demographic.My main gripes (and their descriptions) with the game are (in no particular order):Art styleAnimations (look at the leaders, how they move and gesture while talking, as a fantastic example) and colors (the world isn't pastel) are exaggerated, buildings and units look like caricatures of themselves.Not an awful game, but it's certainly not good. Roughly a 5/10, buy if it drops under $/€/£10.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I used to play a lot of CIV4 for years.After skipping CIV5 I was hoping on new fresh approach.Some ideas are great but overall execution from gameplay is far from being ready.Graphics looks great but sometimes i can see weird lines thrue screen.AI is terrible. The new combat system as idea is great (no more 100 units in 1 slot) howeverAI is not able to make any good logic how to use army. A small outdated unit in passage can stop whole army because if not killed right away other units cannot attack. Computer sometimes will move untis in random direction without clear target.Removing transport units for sea and allowing ay unit to swim is another bad move.The whole game lost balance because of that. No more fun playing Japan and building archipelago Empire.I hope with updates they will fix AIBut for now it is not worth the price (I had bought delux edition for $48)

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is a great game. On launch, I feel like Civ VI is much more complete than Civ V was. There is religious victories and the leaders have many interesting new abilities not seen in Civ V. The developers changed the movement mechanics in a way I feel makes much more sense than in Civ V. The districts are a wonderful addition to the game, making city placement even more important than in Civ V. This mechanic promotes more awareness for future city development and victory conditions.The only thing I was disappointed with at launch was the AI relationship with the player. The diplomacy is not as fleshed out as it should be. However, the cultural, religous, and military interactions with the AI is not really inhibited by this, so I was not very put out. When the DLC began to be released however, I was angry. In what world is $5 for a civilization fair? There are no real gameplay additions with these DLC packs. If the customers of Civ V were charge $5 for every civilization the developers added to the game, no one would have bought Civ VI.Maybe they are not planning on Civ VII because at $5 per DLC civ, I will not be buying.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really wanted to like Civilization VI after enjoying Civilization V (after it got its prerequisite expansions to improve upon what was a pretty mediocre vanilla game), but I just couldn't get into this new version. The art style is a big turn off, and it looks a bit too much like a cheap mobile game in that respect. It has made reading the terrain extremely hard in many cases. I find it almost impossible to pick out the goodie huts on the map, for example.I found the game at launch to have some significant balancing issues, which may have been bad luck on my part, but it is what it is. I had several games where the barbarians completely overran my position and made it impossible to survive. I had a game breaking bug that corrupted a save file in another game (which sounded like it was a common problem with Kongo?). The diplomacy is uninteresting, and unless things have changed the AI was more or less incapable of taking a city with walls.There are simply too many design problems that existed in the vanilla Civ VI for me to recommend it based on my playing experience. I've been watching the last year for more positive reviews and feedback to emerge saying that Firaxis had fixed everything in patches or after the first expansion, but the reception has still been largely lukewarm. I'd recommend that anyone interested in this game hold off for at least another expansion to see if Firaxis manages to right the ship or if it ends up sinking to the bottom of the sea -- and hopefully takes the dreadful Sean Bean tech quotes with it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I haven't played a Civ game since Civ III, after getting tired of dumb-as-doornails AI opponents and other frustrations with the series, but I thought I'd give this one a go.The city-building aspects of the game are clever and fun, requiring some real thought into design of your empire. And other aspects, like religion and the dual tech trees and society cards, are intriguing as well and fun to play around with.Alas, the AI remains dumb as doornails. No amount of good design can make up for an utterly incompotent AI design - especially when other games manage a decent if unexceptional plausibility in AI opponents. Diplomacy also lags far behind contemporary design - the diplomatic model in games like EU4 is just far more interesting, plausible and enjoyable. In Civ VI it's a pointless exercise in frustration and irrelevance.Finally, the pacing seems off - technology seems to advance way too fast for production. It often seems that you've barely produced a unit before you're off into the next age, without having had any time to do anything noteworthy in the age you were just in. The tech progress can be slowed down - but unfortunately that slows down production as well. So the relativities remain basically the same, but the game is slowed to a glacial pace.There's a lot to love in the game design, the innovations like museums and tourists and a very interesting take on great works and great leaders. Many of the flaws above can probably be fixed in some fine tuning in patches - but I suspect the completely incompetent AI will not be fixed. It's a pity, perhaps the Civ community can come up with a bit of magic modding to create an opponent worth playing - but for now I reluctantly have to give this a thumbs down.After all the criticism of bad AI in Civ V, one would have hoped Firaxis could have made more of an effort. I'm not getting burned again, no Civ VII for me...

title: Recommended
comment: [Update: Fall 2017 Update Patch]Okay, finally the game has reached a solid point where I'm flipping my review to recommended. The AI player can finally use both air and naval power, the diplomacy system is no longer a total mess, and religion is improved. If you've been on the fence about Civilization VI, now is the time to take the plunge.[Update: Australia Patch]Unfortunately Civ VI still suffers from some very annoying issues - with AI players hitting the Atomic Age about a 1,000 years early, nonsensical AI war declarations, etc. However, it is much improved since the original release and is worth a look when on-sale. One caveat is that somehow Firaxis botched the localization with their latest update and now parts of the game are in Portuguese instead of English...[Original Review:]Civilization VI has a lot of cool new design elements and is quite different from previous Civ games (for better or worse). However, what effectively ruins the game at this point are bugs, poor balance, and a terrible AI that overshadow everything else. For example, even on higher difficulty levels, the AI won't upgrade their troops. In my current game, it's the Information Age and I'm literally fighting off hoards of Slingers! The AI also has no sense of relative power, as they will declare war on you with no chance of victory; plus will ask for the sun and moon for any trade that's even remotely balanced. On the flip side, sometimes AI players will hit the Modern Age by 1000AD! These aren't game breaking on their own, just some examples; but it's the overall majority of issues that conspire to ruin the game.Wait for a patch or two before purchasing would be my advice. I'll revisit this review as the game hopefully shapes up.

title: Recommended
comment: Overall, I think this is better than the Civilization V. I'll tell briefly why.Pros:- The art is just simply amazing.- The game feels harder to win than V, it gives you more challenge.- Governments are interesting.- The different areas (ie. Commercial Hub, Neighbourhood, Aqueduct..)- Amenities and housing brings new hardness to the game.- I love the True Earth Location map.- You can spend 12 hours a day with this game easily.- Tech tree (applies to other Civs as well).- Australia DLC pure love.Cons:- Barbarians. (Thank god you can take them off)- Not that much DLC yet.- Sometimes too time consuming.- Hard to win even on easy.

title: Recommended
comment: I love that Civ VI is enough like Civ V so that I know how to play the game but that it's different enough to need to learn new systems. The victory conditions are much more involved, the graphics are amazing, the sound track evolves with you as you grow and advance and the voice of Sean Bean as narrator is absolutely perfect!I have over 300 hours game play on Civ V and, because of that, assumed going for a science victory would be a piece of cake. It's NOT! I've finished one game of Civ VI so far and won on score alone because I did not plan my cities in a way so that I could get a science win. I can't wait to start a second game and put some of the ideas I have after playing once into play and see if that helps. In short, I'm having a blast learning this game. It's, to me, the perfect addition to the Civilization series!Editing because I forgot to mention what I didn't like about the game. I wish the Builders lasted longer than 3 jobs!! I don't like not being able to see countries/city-states I don't have really good relationships with (can *see* them but not in bold colorful detail). Those are the two main things. I have an issue with religion and it's spread but, in all honesty, I think my issue is that I don't understand how freaking FAST my neighbor country was able to spawn so many apostles so fast. My cities were converted before I could benefit from my own religion.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I don't understand how people claim the AI has improved from any generation of civilization in Civilization 6. They've seemingly made it worse at land combat, the AI has more impactful starting advantages at higher difficulties but squanders them, the AI is far more inclined to give up regardless of their military power or tech lead if they've lost a few engagements (any difficulty), still have horrible trade deals (although I'm sure this is why people say the AI is better because its easy to exploit in your favor now), denounce spamming, still terrible city settlement choices and unrelenting urge to fill out map (barely justifiable with districts) and the return of the units purchased with faith mechanics that the AI hasn't the slightest clue how to use. Everything about the base game is lacking and uninspired. Just stick to Civ 5 and your favorite mod, this steaming pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥won't improve until the 1st or 2nd expansion and it still won't be an actual improvement over Civ 5.I bought this via the Humble Bundle for $12 and still feel like I was scammed. I can't imagine how the people who got suckered for $60+ feel. I won't be buying the future expansions unless massively discounted, but I can't trust this developer anymore.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have played Civ 4 and Civ 5 and was loved each and purchased all of the expanstions. This game fell short. Religion seems a very overpowered. So even if you want to go for any of the other types of wins the religion is still very much required. Example: I started a game vs the AI. I lost with in the first 20 minutes due to a player winning a religious victory. I did not discover a religion so ther was nothing I could really do about it because he was on the other side of the map.The civopidea is kinnda a joke.... I wanted to know what the abbilities for an Apostle did.... So I looked him up in the in game Civopidia..... Nope... had to google it to find out what Evangelize Belief and Start Inquisition did.Also the game is buggy. Background music is intermittant at times. The cursor over notes are intermintant. The game will not close 80% of the time and I am required to restart my PC.

If the AI ever actually conquers a city in a war it's purely by accident.I can't recommend buying this game until they do something about their AI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 478 hours on Civ 5 vs. 128 I racked up on this title should tell you which one to buy. At full price Civ 6 is no where near worth it and I can get bored of games quickly. You can still have fun, don't get me wrong (seeing as how I still managed to get 128 hrs). However, Firaxis is as greedy and inept as big studios come, charging a fraudulent $30 for DLC that does not contain anywhere near $30 of content. If you must buy this at full price really take a long think about it first. I would suggest getting the full Civ 5 bundle (all the DLC) when it's on sale for a few bucks, it's totally worth it.Summary: I do NOT recommend this game at full price. If the price comes down, yeah you can probably get plenty of hours out of it. Choice between 5 and 6? Get 5 bundle on sale.Good:-New concepts (districts)-Policy card system is not a new idea but the implementation of the separate culture tree is interesting-SMOOTH gameplay that is less buggy than Civ 5-Multiplayer works MUCH better than in 5-Graphics - if you like ths style.Bad:-Feels like a lot of content is missing (hello world congress?)-AI is still utter garbage (lazy devs not wanting to fix it)-Gameplay sometimes feels restrictive, feels like I have less options than in Civ 5 where there were more unusual but possible strategies-No proper modding tools for more specialized mods like Civ 5's IGE-Base UI is bad-Firaxis is slow and unresponsive to issues (as a full release title do not expect frequent patches or bug fixes)

title: Not Recommended
comment: jan. 2nd - 17this is a game very close to a full reccommendation. in the beginning hours you are glued to your computer, the "just one more turn" philosophy in these games are as present as ever. smart changes such as the road system has been inplemented and builders now create tile improvements instantly while now having limitided uses instead. this creates new options for optimizations of your empire. one major thing holds this title back though. its the AI. both in terms of combat and diplomacy. the ai will declare random wars and denounce you galore, but unless you are really far behind it it doesnt even try to mount attacks, and if you yourself takes one of their cities, everyone will think you are a warmonger aand denounces you, even though you were the defenderthis leads to later games where everyone hates you, but it takes nothing to defeat them since you can sit back and declare a ceasefire after x amount of turns without the enemy even having touched your borders. making allies in this is tough and not even usefull since they are so inactive anyways.your first impressions are gonna be great, but this shortcoming is propably gonna ruin it for you after 20 or so hourse, when you start to seee these things.that being said. everything else just works and it feels like, in terms of features that this game has already had the content from the civ 5 expansions packed into it. so the foundation is good and i would dare say that when firaxis finally decides to get the AI to work this will be one, if not THE finest vanilla civ game to date. untill then though, go play civ 5 with the expansions and you have a better product there, purely because the AI works there. then check back later and you can propalby grab this for a lot less by then for a product you can enjoy not just in the beginning, but to turn 5000 aswell.would really have liked to reccommend this. is odd how a game can be so close to perfection and yet so broken because of one thng.

title: Recommended
comment: I would recommend this game to any one that is interested in strategy games or has played the other civ games.You might have noticed that there are quite a few people who say this game is worse than some or even all the other civ games, I however highly disagree. Many people say that it is buggy or that the district system is unballanced. I however think the opposite.Districs: People say that a lot of the districs are wasit of a tile, this is true to some extent. You have to specialize your cities. One city can not get the job done. You have to build the districs that get adjacency bonusses, if you do not do this than some of the districs seem to be a waist. In this game they encourage empire building. Like in real life a large empire is stronger than a small one. You need many cities so you can specialise your cities with districs. This is very differnt from the other civ games. Civ 5 actully discourage empires by giving unhappyness for your number of cities but in civ 6 the more cities the better in most circumstances (In civ 6 your cities also havethere own independent hppiness).Once you learn the distric system you will find your self loving it. It can actully be kind of overpowered if you do it right. Districs are the main reason why people struggle in this game so people tend to think its flawed when in reality it is only becasue they do not fully understand the mechanic.Buggy: I have 240 hours in this game and have yet to see 1 individule bugg. If any one says the game is buggy i do not mean to come off as rude but they could not be any more wrong.What you should take away from this is that this game has very differnet game mechanics than any other civ game making it hard to start but once you learn the new mechanics it is an amazing game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Okay so there are a couple of years since they released the game now...While many of the features that Firaxis added to the game are pretty interesting and works well such as the districts feature...Sadly the game is still riddled with bugs and glitches.The annoying sound when siege equipment is moved persists.The AI is still absolutely♥♥♥♥♥♥and disturbs you with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ deals.Alliances doesn't work as you would imagine an alliance would work.Turning off unit cycling is still not implemented.I recommend picking up Civ IV instead.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really tried my best to love this game, I assure you, but it's beyond boring. I can't tell you how disappionted I am right now.I seriously thought that expansions could fix it, but nooooo.My biggest complains are:1) The Eureka system is unblanced and boring, this very system made the game tedious.2) The expansion fixed nothing, the new era system isn't even relevant. AIs are still stupid, anything other than Science Victory are still pointless and repetitive af.3) AIs still build city right on your face, most times I feel like that I had no choice but to be a warmonger.4) Wonders are not favorable any more. My favorite thing in Civ V is to rush wonders, it's really hard and rewarding, but in Civ VI wonders are pretty much worthless.The only positive point about this game is maybe the district system, but nothing other than that. Do yourself a favor, don't buy this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game, get Civ V instead, at this point, I don't even think they can fix it anymore.

title: Recommended
comment: Notice that many of the bad reviews have a contradiction, they spend a crazy amount of time on a game they apparently don't like. The one at the top for example, he provides a very detailed, well-written argument for why he gave it a thumbs down. However, he played 5,000 hours before deciding this. I imagine I don't have to explain why this is a testament to how good the game is. The game is great, so great that people spend thousands of hours playing it. Then they say it wasn't worth their purchase, so I assume they must hate themselves. The only complaint I have is that it just doesn't seem like it will hold my interest after 5,000 hours, I expect more from a $60 purchase . . . . Gracious. In all seriousness, I've felt that I have gotten my money's worth after 25 hours, this game has so many fun layers to it. The soundtrack is amazing as well, adding on a new instrument with each advancement into a new era (I've only heard England's so far, and can't wait to experience the other Civilizations' themes).
