comment: ok i'm going to do a short review:THE GAME ISN'T BAD IT JUST NEEDS TO BE FIXED,BUY IT AFTER IT'S FIXED-the AI:they are ♥♥♥♥ing stupid, no matter what you do they'll eventually denounce you for whatever the reason, trading with leaders or doing any sort of diplomacy is ♥♥♥♥ing pointless.-war with the AI: on my first game france declared war on me, and literally didn't do anything! i even captured the country with 1 ♥♥♥♥ing archer and 1 swordsman-the game itself: lately i can't even lunch the game, the game crashes on the bio screen for every leader or crashes on the main loading screen+soundtack: the soundtrack is really great and enjoyable+map: personally, i really like the map and it's really beautiful tho it sometimes gets annoying+AI: now i know that the AI are ♥♥♥♥ing stupid but the thing that surprised me is that they have their own personallity, which is nicefinal note: buy this game on a sale or wait until it's fixed,

Maybe one day, if they make enough updates and fix enough problems (with literally everything) then maybe I will change this review; but with the path Firaxis has been going down, I seriously doubt this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Coming from civ 2, civ 3, civ4 and civ 5, i find Civ 6 misses the mark. the weakest point of the game is promotions, only limited to 7 and then thats it. Modded Civ 5 had approximately 20 promotions for units and I would have expect Civ 6 to take that onboard and develop the promotions further, but they are severly lacking. Scouts are useless by about turn 100 as they have no upgrades and become cannon fodder for all and every unit. Civ 5 again allowed you to upgrade the scout to archers etc once they have no use as a scout.The graphics are cartoony, yes, but I actually like that.Religion has been hammered to be almost useless now, Civ 5 was far superior.Spys in Civ 5 were important and played a big part in stretgy, in Civ 6 again they are pointless and if you ignored them entirely your game is unaffected.Governments are also lacking, and have small impact on gamepplay, unlike civ 5 where they were important and dramtically affected gameplay/style.I like the boosting to research for doing other actions , this is a clever idea and well implemented.I normally play Japanese and for some reason I am yet to work out, I have actually yet to build a samurai believe it or not. the progression of technology seems to bypass them, even though they are the quintessential Japanese unit, go figure.The concept of districts is a copy of the concept from "another game" and though its a good idea, works well, it does force you to building on larger land masses and makes building gateway cities on narrow strips of land completely useless other than creating a passage for ships but the city will be so restricted so as to be nothing more than a gateway between oceans. Progression in the game in terms of technology takes substantially longer than in Civ 5. I always get to nukes in civ 5 but i have yet to get beyond 1900 technology in any game i have payed so far which again is odd considering I have played for 50+ hours already. Even the AI is just getting battleships, no ww2 tech.I hope they produce mods and DLC which improve the game but given to basic concepts seem flawed I am unsure if this game will ever match up to previous incarnations of Civ, which is a huges shame.I can't recommend it in its present form. You might like it so maybe give it a go just dont pay top dollar and perhaps wait for the mod scene to kick into gear more.Update - Now to add injury to the wound that is Civ 6, it now keeps developing the endless turn bug, whereby you start a game and it just sits there processing other AI players turn and you never actually get to play. This game is truly FUBAR.

title: Recommended
comment: This is an incredible strategy game. But it lacks in living up to the incredible standards set by Civ V and Civ IV.Lots of people seem to complain about the AI being horrible, but the AI is basically the same as in every other civ game, but they just have these things called Agendas now. Agendas are policies that each specific civ leader will follow. An example is Trajan, Trajan likes civs that have a larger amount of land than he does, but he dislikes ones that are smaller. Every leader has their own specific one, and you need to learn to play around them. Lots of leaders will have agendas that contradict with other leaders agendas. So unlike in Civ 5 you can't just be friendly with everyone. You have to pick out a set few civs you wish to be your allies, and stick with them and follow their agendas. This can be seen as a good or a bad thing depending on your playstyle.Another large difference in this game than in Civ 5 is the unit movement. The new way the movement system works is that you have a set amount of movement points for each unit. In civ 5 if you used 1 movement point to go onto a flat tile, you could still use the leftover movement point to move onto any other adjacent tile. But if your first move was into any other rough terrain than you would be out of movement points. In Civ 6, you can't use the 1 extra movement point in the same way as in civ 5. Flat terrain takes 1 point, and rough takes 2. If you use one movement point to move onto a flat tile near a hill, you cannot move onto the hill tile adjacent because you only have 1 movement point left. Most people don't like this new system as it makes unit movement horribly slow. And the roads were changed so they don't help as much either. This basically constricts you to using cavalry units so you can actually move around the landscape in a reasonable amount of time.One other huge difference is cities. There are 2 ways to build your empire, tall and wide. Tall is when you have only 3-5 cities with a very high population, while wide is to have tons of cities with little population. Civ 5 heavily favored tall empires, while civ 6 heavily favors wide. This is mainly due to the science and culture change. There are no more "policies" but instead there are 2 tech trees. One running off culture and the other running off science. In Civ 5 you didnt want a lot of cities because it slowed your science and culture production due to cost of policies and techs increasing the more cities you have, it was also beneficial to have a lot of population in your cities because of how the science buildings worked (Library, National College, etc.). In Civ 6, there is no penalty. You have to make as many cities as possible, and just put down tons of campuses and theater districts to generate science and culture. This will be a huge change to those going from Civ 5 to Civ 6. I personally like building wide empires more as it gives more land control and actually feels like you are trying to control and expand your empire.TL;DR: This game is incredibly different in playstyle from Civ 5 and will take getting used too, but is fun nonetheless.If the movement system is changed and if they add some more non DLC civs, then this game might rival civ 5. But as of now Civ 5 is clearly superior.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civilization VI is off to a solid start, however as is expected there is much to improve and a few things that simply feel wrong. While some may not like comparisons to CIV V given it's had allot of time to be refined, that game is also not perfect and could be improved. However I'm surprised some of the things it did right, did not come over to civ VI.At first the art style was "in your face" different, in a bad way but over time it's kind of grown on me. However some may struggle with the yield icons as they're small and hard to make out for me. A harsher dark outline would make seeing them far easier for both me and others who have trouble seeing them.The different lenses are absolutely fantastic. Being able to see the appeal of my tiles, my religious spread and where it's coming from/going to as well as the settler lense are all welcome additions. However for AI games I feel a "wanted territory" lense is despeartely needed so players can avoid expanding on a different continent, in the opposite direction only for the civ they promised not to expand towards get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off and declare war in the near future. This would also reveal AI flaws (EG if every single hex was off limits)The districts system is new and interesting. I've enjoyed trying to figure out which districts should take priority and it adds some satisfaction to city management. I feel there's too stark a difference between the good and not so good districts. A faith district is there purely for making a religion and I feel is shoved to the side when the 2 trading districts or the science/culture/hammer districts come into play. Still allot to figure out, just hoping there can be multiple viable pathways as currently there is a cookie cut way to do things as there was in civ V.From the civics, the ease with which military tech units are obtained, the need for walls to be able to shoot barbs, the sheer strength of barbs and the fact that there're more military civs than passive ones screams of the devs trying to force conflict to occur.While there're only 2 more military civs than passive ones it may not seem so bad, but when taking into account how bleh so many of the passive civ abilites feel in stark contrast to civilization V's civs, it's pretty god dam awful for those who preffered a pacifist approach.The civic system is an addition I didn't enjoy as much as I thought I would. It looked like a flexible, more customisable option but is hindered by its tech tree structure and narrow range of card abilities.In civ V, you start your tradition/liberty tree with a little boost, then gain something more upon it's completion rocketing you civ forward. Complete the piety, patronage, aesthetics or rationalism had the same effect depending on what you were up to. Add in it's contribution to encouraging war with an abundance of combat based cards.I feel no such impact or satisfaction here, and far less flexibility in getting to what I want (which there is an extreme lack of) given it now functions as a tech tree. This may be a "love it or hate it" thing, and unfortunately I'm in the hate it boat. The civ V policy trees were simply better.The science tree feels narrower and is unecesarily stretched out with overly large lines. It looks bad and feels bad to navigate, as you can't see what leads to where.While the micro management of civs it fun and all, the housing/amenities system absolutely crushes any hope of building a tall civilization. While I don't mind wonders taking up hexes, as they look sweet, like a trophy on my land, this addition only emphasises how poor a choice building tall is in civ VI, further cutting down on the avaliable options and making your civilization more optimiased to mass producing units for war.Religion also took a hit in civ VI. Many of the pantheon beliefs seem, to be quite frank,♥♥♥♥♥♥ Very few are linked to a luxury resource as in civ V and many revolve around certain terrain, most of which can be removed by an enemy or providing boosts to your military.An extremely prominent annoyance are the constant requests from AI's. Every time they send you a delegation, which is very gawd dam common you get a pretty, little cinematic. Add in multiple AI and you'll be spending more time spamming the ESC key than playing the game. I simply don't care about maming AI happy anymore, because it's so tedious and infuriating to do. Am quite shocked there's no option to disable the cinematic menus.Movement in civ VI is an extreme downfall compared to its predecessor. Instead of spending w/e movement u have left to move onto a hill, you simply won't move onto a woods/forest/hill. I found it extremely irritating being constantly told to move my units when they can't complete a turn without moving in the opposite direction due terrain being in the way and this really slows down the pace of the game, makes retrieving workers/settlers from barbs nigh impossible without going to their camp and simply feels awful in practice.Civilization VI will undoubtedly be improved in the future in many ways, but unless the issues I have with it are not only fixed but improved drastically, it will be very very difficult to justify the pay wall these fixes will be locked behind. And given their emphasis in forcing you to go to war, and my hate for the tediousness by which combat functions I'm likely to stick to civiliation V with my pacifistic science/cultural victories.. I reccomend similar players do the same as there's simply more fun to be had with civilization V for now.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I don't understand how people claim the AI has improved from any generation of civilization in Civilization 6. They've seemingly made it worse at land combat, the AI has more impactful starting advantages at higher difficulties but squanders them, the AI is far more inclined to give up regardless of their military power or tech lead if they've lost a few engagements (any difficulty), still have horrible trade deals (although I'm sure this is why people say the AI is better because its easy to exploit in your favor now), denounce spamming, still terrible city settlement choices and unrelenting urge to fill out map (barely justifiable with districts) and the return of the units purchased with faith mechanics that the AI hasn't the slightest clue how to use. Everything about the base game is lacking and uninspired. Just stick to Civ 5 and your favorite mod, this steaming pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥won't improve until the 1st or 2nd expansion and it still won't be an actual improvement over Civ 5.I bought this via the Humble Bundle for $12 and still feel like I was scammed. I can't imagine how the people who got suckered for $60+ feel. I won't be buying the future expansions unless massively discounted, but I can't trust this developer anymore.

The diffculty setting only gives their units an attack bonus, that's it. I'm playing it on the hardest setting and nobody seems interested in really attacking me. Heck nobody seems interested in attacking each other. Sure they declare war but they never do anything about it. If the AI ever actually conquers a city in a war it's purely by accident.I can't recommend buying this game until they do something about their AI.

comment: I have played Civ 4 and Civ 5 and was loved each and purchased all of the expanstions. This game fell short. Religion seems a very overpowered. So even if you want to go for any of the other types of wins the religion is still very much required. Example: I started a game vs the AI. I lost with in the first 20 minutes due to a player winning a religious victory. I did not discover a religion so ther was nothing I could really do about it because he was on the other side of the map.The civopidea is kinnda a joke.... I wanted to know what the abbilities for an Apostle did.... So I looked him up in the in game Civopidia..... Nope... had to google it to find out what Evangelize Belief and Start Inquisition did.Also the game is buggy. Background music is intermittant at times. The cursor over notes are intermintant. title: Not Recommended
comment: I will start off by saying I have not played Civ V or Beyond Earth. The last one I played was IV, so It's been a while.Overall the game is quite entertaining.I have had a lot of fun playing a online game with a friend. However, a few things as of right now prevent me from recommending this game.--Cons-AI actions are a bit strange. Rome for centuries just stacked warriors as I played as his German friend across the water. He had no stats that showed that he disliked me, constantly complemented me, and we even announced our friendship. However, when I sent a settler a good distance from his one city( Mind you he had only Rome after centuries) he sent his legions of warriors and chariots(I had knights and eventually musketeers ) over to surround his "friend"s new found border. Then declared war right when the frienship expired. I just don't get the behavior. (Played difficulty: Warlord)-Game Killing bugs: Several times have run ito issues of game progress stopping. Says a unit needs order, but everyone has moved and will not progress. Played Multi with my friend and after our turn, the AI would not finish their turn. I recommend saving a lot, atleast every 20 turns if you do play.--Personal Con/RantI am not a fan of their leader picking, it is extremely odd and forced. Gorgo being the main example, barely mentioned anywherein history besides being Leonidas's wife. Greatest achievement was scraping some wax off of a tablet that had an encoded message. She did not rule anything, her husband however did.(Even after his death, her son was king and Cleombrotus the tutor) So if you want to play the we need more women game, pick one that makes sense and actually did something. Historically most nations were ruled by men; Sorry. Same goes for Catherine of France, was excluded from ruling by the Kind, sons took over afterwars. Joan of Arc would have been a better choice.--End RantPros---The art style in my opinon is awesome. Great work. Creates a fun feel to the game.--The tutorial is a great refresher, I recommend it.--Game mechanics work well and make for some good strategies and competition.-- Sean Bean :)End Note: I will gladly change my review, when the bugs have been worked out and the AI acts a bit more reasonable.Though if you don't mind the cons I listed and can hold out, then I say go for it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is a great game. On launch, I feel like Civ VI is much more complete than Civ V was. There is religious victories and the leaders have many interesting new abilities not seen in Civ V. The developers changed the movement mechanics in a way I feel makes much more sense than in Civ V. The districts are a wonderful addition to the game, making city placement even more important than in Civ V. This mechanic promotes more awareness for future city development and victory conditions.The only thing I was disappointed with at launch was the AI relationship with the player. The diplomacy is not as fleshed out as it should be. However, the cultural, religous, and military interactions with the AI is not really inhibited by this, so I was not very put out. When the DLC began to be released however, I was angry. In what world is $5 for a civilization fair? There are no real gameplay additions with these DLC packs. If the customers of Civ V were charge $5 for every civilization the developers added to the game, no one would have bought Civ VI.Maybe they are not planning on Civ VII because at $5 per DLC civ, I will not be buying.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Dissapointment is the only word I can think of to describe this game, as it stands. At most, the game is (over all) a 3/5. The gaem is severly lacking in AI development and is still buggy. While I applaud the developers for their innovative attempt with the AI character traits to define their dispositions, the idea has not been executed well. Often other countries are upset with you for things you cannot know and will hate you forever if you declare war. In most games, all AI have denounced all other AI and the player. Thus what is the point of even caring about global relations? I would like ot add I have played all other civ games from CIV III on up and this one does not add up. I would advise waiting to buy until the developers crawl out of the hole they work in, sober up, and read the community feedback. Bring in modding support now, not later so the community can get this game back on track.

title: Not Recommended
comment: At the start, the game plays out normally like any other Civ game until about 200 turns into the late game on a standard paced game. Everything starts to become unresponsive. You are unable to view items from your sidebar. Toggling on and off turn sometimes takes multiple clicks. Sometimes you cannot even press next turn or the turn won't advance.The only way around these issues are to disconnect from the game and join back. The problems you have experienced before, will possibly show up sooner or later again. I hope this gets fixed soon as it is quite game breaking.

title: Recommended
comment: I've liked previous entries into the series and I do like this one too. While it doesn't shine like it's predecessor, it does have some good points. Deciding where to build your districts and improving them adds a layer to the game that I thought was a nice touch from a city building perspective. Mods do not disable achievements, which is one of the few gripes I had about Civ5.Diplomacy is terrible in this game. If you don't care about diplomacy and you're like me, knowing you're going to wipe out every faction including city states anyway, then that might now bother you. But I got to say it is annoying it takes so little to get denounced in the game, and happens often. I've tried actively building relations with another faction in this game, and it isn't easy and when I have managed to do it, it doesn't last long before you're going back down hill. Then there's the cartoony artstyle. Which feels like a step backwards when you compare it to Civ5. That being said, I've played some games with more cartoony visuals that I liked a great deal. So that in and of itself isn't totally a bad thing. But it does turn some people off. I was more open to it given previous games I've played that had similar approaches to that aspect, but coming directly from Civ5 to Civ6 was an adjustment.I'm recommending it because despite the things that bother me about the game, I can still have a good time with it. Some things can be offset by the talented people making mods for the game. A game shouldn't have to depend on it's modding community to make up for its faults, however. But at least it's there.

title: Recommended
comment: Oh my god, where to begin...I had "barely" played civ V (250 hours) and I beat Diety multiple times, and I must say civ VI gave me a run for my money, it is a great game for turn based strategy beginners, and veterans.If you go in expecting Civ V (like I did) you will be dissapointed, this game doesn't hold your hand as much as civ IV or Vand you will probably lose multiple times before your first victory.It is definitly the best civ since BNW, if that means anything to you.

comment: For anyone hoping for a well polished game that holds you for a long and enjoyable experience like civ 5 did, this game might not be for you.dont get me wrong this game can and is fun however late game mm (Micromanaging) espically of cities can be frustratingly annoying not to mention spies as well.it just sought of broke the game for me because i love getting up to the very end game for a big modern military showdown in a domination only match or to just keep playing after achieving another victory condition but in civ 6 you cant enjoy that stage and stay immersed when every turn i have to set my city to build an icbm for me to instantly fire off randomly when its built so my gold per turn stays high or to keep doing holysite bs because i have literally nothing i want to build what happend to putting the city to only science or gold that was great, you get to kick back and do whatever but nooope they done f*cked it up.dispite my ranting just watch a youtube video and make up your own mind about it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 1. The AI really has me worried about the longevity of the game. Can't really fix this with mods, best you could hope for is a bandage until proper AI is introduced.2. The games pacing is really not in a good spot. Production, which is an important function of the game, is too slow to have any meaningful impact on units and buildings early on.3. The games mini map is unreadable, I'm honestly confused how this is a problem since Civilization 5's mini map was clear and represented the formation of borders and countries really well.I waited years for the release of civ 6, with much anticipation. While the game genuinely does have many new and exciting features theres just way too many issues bogging the game down to fully let them shine.

title: Not Recommended
comment: What a functionally terrible Civ game. As a player since Civ III was released I am incredibly disappointed for how dumbed down, lazy, and overally hacky this game is. It's sickening. Don't misunderstand my play time, I left the game on in the background a few times.Just so everyone knows, the harder difficulty settings just result in the AI getting tons of free troops. They are still completely and utterly inept though, noticably dumber than even the earliest Civ games and infinitely more confusing. Why on the standard difficulty would a nation in the modern era build an entire army of spearmen?! WHY?! Come on.This game is painful to play and I can't bring myself to continue playing. It's depressingly thin. No more maps included, so expect to play ♥♥♥♥♥♥ random maps forever until a third party fills the gaps for a company that screwed you. Try Civ V or tell Firaxis to suck it and try Making History if you want a game that has performance over flashy garbage. Making History is only the World Wars and it's still functionally far better than this abortion.

title: Not Recommended
comment: If you want a Civ game, buy Civ5, this game is just awful..Change for the sake of change, rather than change for the sake of improvements.If you want to spend a lot of money on 1/3rd of a game, jump right in. The unfinished AI, Diplomacy and other features, clearly left open to be finished in DLC, are begging you to waste your money.And it is a waste. So far the DLC is basic stuff that should have been in the base game. The game is nowhere near ready for DLC, but hey This is Civ, the business model is sell 1/3rd the game for over full price, then drip feed the rest of the game and charge for it.It really has gone too far this time though, the base game doesn't hold any interest, and the DLC is just boring.

title: Not Recommended
comment: RECOMMEND SOMEDAY, BUT NOT YET. OK so far, but missing a few elements that I've come to expect from a Civ game (e.g. diplomacy) that I hope will be added on in subsequent expansion packs. Biggest downside is AI that doesn't seem to understand how the combat system in its own game works, but the artwork is beautiful and the game is easy to understand but has enough underlying complexity to satisfy those that want to drill down deeper. A few bugs and technical things that mistify me, like a lack of space to view your relationship stateus with another civilization and confusing move system where you end up wasting a lot of move points. Overall this game has the potential to be great, but is missing too many pieces at this point. Civ has done a great job in the past filling in the gaps, however (see Brave New World with Civ V), so I'm optimistic that they'll get it right in a couple expansions. Hold off on paying the huge price tag and see what happens as the expansions roll out.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is pretty solid, although if I were contemplating getting this game, I would strongly suggest buying civ 5 instead (assuming you don't have that either.) It is a better game, the dlc is cheaper now, and overall a better game. Still, if you were into Civ 5, chances are you will enjoy this game.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ VI still holds true to the Civ formula and this iteration does not disappoint. The new art style is enjoyable (and more friendly to weaker machines). Simple changes to movement have made movement more tactical and makes exploration a longer term project then in Civ 5. Overall, this is a worthy entry to the series and I feel it is well worth the asking price.

title: Recommended
comment: The more I play Civ VI, the more I am liking it.If you're looking for an upgraded, new, polished version of Civ V, then this is not what you're getting and you're going to be disappointed if that's what you're looking for.On the other hand, if you're willing to give it a shot, the new mechanics and the new ways to do certain things become more and more fun. So to sum things up, here's a pros and cons list after a few games:Pros:- Graphically beautiful game- New ways to manage the tiles in your city, takes some getting used to (+ City Management)- New battle animations- The tiles on which wonders can be built are restricted depending on the wonder- Tons of new resourcesCons:- Weak A.I., especially in the lower difficulties- Some playthroughs can be ruined due to intensive barbarian spawning early on- Not Civ V (if that's what you're looking for)- Feels relatively easier than past Civs, noob friendlyOverall,I find Civ VI is a nice, refreshing addition to the series that suceeded with many of the new implementations. You just have to go at it with an open mind and give things a try. New mechanics like traders building your roads are pretty good too. One thing however, is that enemy A.I. will engage in such silly battles. Like you'll have a unit with full health and a general on top of it, and the ai will still attack you with a lower tier unit that has like 10 health, killing themselves in the process. Other than a few small things here and there, the pros shine bright enough to make for a very good Civ, with lots of potential to improve it even more.8.5/10

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game has a lot of potential and has a lot more going for it than vanilla CIV. It has the potential to be something amazing down the road. However it has a long way to go.Certain issues that bother me are you dont really get as many trade routes as you used to back when the game came out. With that being your main method of building roads its pretty necessary.Another issue is, in Civ 5, If someone messed with me I could go and wipe out a few of their cities, once they knew they were going to lose, they'd offer you some of their weaker ctiies. I'd burn them down and if I liked the location I'd build a new city on top or near by the burnt down city. In CiV 6 if you get a city through a trade. You're stuck with it. The only way to burn it down is to give it back and then declare war. It's ridiculous.Huge maps feel small. In Civ 5 I could do a huge map and have A LOT of space between my nearest Civ neighbor. In this game Your nearest neighbor spawns super close and once they know where you are THEY ♥♥♥♥ING BUILD CLOSER AND CLOSER. It's infuriating. My last game played I had 4 cities. I like to keep them spaced out so the borders will expand and fill the gaps. China decided 8 cities wasn't enough and went through the one tile gap between my borders into an empty cluster that was to be filled by my border growth. He settles a ♥♥♥♥ing city right inbetween them. Meanwhile Ghandi starts sending settlers up to my region too.Thats a few of the gameplay issues I have with it so Im going to talk about some other issues with DLCFiraxis used to be known for awesome sales , however Civ 6 has over priced micro DLC. Civ and Scenario packs that run 5 each. These never go sale either. 5 is too much for a civ and a scenario I will never play.

title: Recommended
comment: Veterans of Civilization will find themselves right at home. Newcomers to the series will fall in love. Civilization VI is easy to pick up but has lots behind the scenes for the more hardcore gamer.After a somewhat rocky start with game-breaking exploits and balance issues and radio silence, Firaxis responded with a patch that took Civilization VI from good to great.This is definitely a game I will play consistantly over the years until moving on to Civilization VII.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I read the bad reviews, but I just loved 5 so much, i couldn't help but be excited. So I saved up some money and dropped the $60. I have a tight budget, but figured the return would be worth it if I played anywhere near as long as I played 5.The game randomly crashes, but not from the get go. That would be too simple. No, the crashes are truly random. 20 minutes in. Frustrating, but I can restart. 6 Hours in. Now my day is ruined. Can crash for no apparent reason at any random♥♥♥♥♥time.So I did homework, and more homework, and there is apparently no fix. A lot of people have the same problem, but no real solution has been found. Hardware be damned, this disease apparently knows no bounds. So I gave up for a few months, forgot the game existed.And then one day theres a patch. It's a big one, takes hours to download. I figure this might be it! They heard the clamoring of many angry fans and fixed the crashes! So I download it and start a game. I play all evening, no problem. Save and hop on the next day. It's a perfect weekend, my expensive new game is fixed and I have no other esponisibilites. I sink almost 10 hours into this save, and then it happens:The same. ♥♥♥♥ing. crash.Needless to say I'm absolutely crushed, I wasted a massive amount of free time that I really don't have much of these days, and I basically threw away $60, which stings. I'm done with the game, I'll probably never invest my time in it again. And I recommend that you don't either, unless you make sure that the random crashes are fixed. And I'm serious, make sure. It'll happen to you too.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have put many many hours into the Civ franchise, over 100 on Civ VI alone, and while the game isn't terrible I cannot recommend it.There's a lot of small changes to get used to, not a big issue, however a lot of important functionality has been lost in the process. One of the biggest peeves I have is the chaining of road building to merchants. No reason to send a merchant to any one of your many cities? Well most likely there will never be a road leading to that city. It's a terrible way to manage roads and serves no purpose except to make the incredibly stupid idea of disposable builders hurt a little bit less.Two, disposable builders: this is the worst change in the game. You get a few "charges" to construct improvements and then they're gone. Whomever thought this was a good idea needs to skip the planning meetings going forward. It's an awful idea that leaves a player spending loads of turns wasting away making builders. There's no longer any strategy to protecting them, simply churn out a new unit and build your improvements. There's no improvement upgrades as far as I have noticed, so once their wad is blown that's that. It's insipid at best. Also no roads get built by builders, as mentioned previously, it's impossible to connect your cities if you don't waste 20 turns of your trader's time. Considering 20 turns can be in-game equivalent to 200 years you can see how mental of a system this is (seriously 20 turns to establish a road to a city 6 hexes away in the early game is just stupid).Three, it's boring. The game very quickly becomes dull and lifeless with no real point. You pretty much have to play aggressively which means you pretty much only ever get conquest wins unless you purposefully retard your army and hold back. Not fun. There's no real sense of accomplishment, just this repetitive cycle of tech, war, and building that doesn't really matter. Just build a big army of archers in the first 50 turns and kill everyone, game over. Dull.I wanted to like this game, maybe they're saving a nice update that will make the game fun for a future $60 expansion pack, either way I'm done with it. This is a sad and unenjoyable chapter in the civ franchise, lacking basic common sense functions like road building and generally taking way too long to get anywhere in the game if you want to play other than Ghengis Khan style. Mid-game is a dull slog up the tech tree to the atomic era where you're still bored, but now have nukes. I appreciate all of the work that went into the game, but can't recommend this game at all. I have no idea why the Civ team seems to think they need to reinvent the wheel with every iteration of the game but this reinvented wheel is mostly square and doesn't roll along very well.

title: Not Recommended
comment: for all the praise I've seen about this game, I felt like it was worse than Civ V. Civ V has a merable soundtrack, I love just playing it, a very memerable soundtrack.Civ VI on the other hand has only a few actual tracks, if there are more I haven't noticed, they all sound the same. Other than that, the graphics have a very Sims 4 feel, (and no, that is not a good thing), as in it feels more like a cartoon.This game does do some good, I liked the government feature and the policy system were both very good in my opinion, but that's about all the praise I can give this game. I really wanted to like this game, especially because I spent $60 on it, but in the end, I would much rather play Civ V

title: Recommended
comment: Добавление районов буквально вдохнуло в эту игру новую жизнь. Теперь приходится чуть ли не с 4000 года до нашей эры планировать, где именно будет через пять тысяч лет построен индустриальный район, а где - Оксфордский университет. Поначалу это нервирует, но потом, когда разберешься - нравится.Еще радует, что это не голый "симс", как обычно, а в игре сразу есть и торговые маршруты, и города-государства, и шпионаж и политика на высшем уровне.Единственный минус - AI у компов какой-то неадекватный - до патча Гильгамеш нападал каждые сто лет вообще без повода, после патча все компы сразу денонсируют тебя и друг друга, если у вас разные политические системы. Как итог, все всех денонсировали. Нелогично (

title: Not Recommended
comment: Being honest, as a fan of the franchise, this game was a huge let down. One of few games I can say was not worth my 80$. In it's current state, it is not good, although the DLC may change that. My issue is, they branched from what they new. Civilization branched from its original old time graphics and map display, and original mechanics, to make a more glorified and glossy version. I, a player who has played much of Civilization V and Civilization IV didn't like all the new mechanics and graphics. Especially when it came to workers, how could you limit the charges on workers????? I haven't played much of this game for a good reason, I think my 2.9 hours spent was more to listen to its impressive soundtrack. Im not going to lie, the music is amazing, the best Civilization soundtrack so far. In the end, a soundtrack isn't worth 60-80$, not even 35.99$. So, all in all, I believe that this game cannot really do justice to the Civilization franchise, I heard reviews all saying how good the game was, but it was a major let down. Once it was released, all the media attention stopped. If you were to buy a Civilization game, make it Civilization V, this game just dropped the ball. I hope the DLC will make it worth my money, because DLC is a big part of Civilization V, but I just don't see myself wanting to play this game.

title: Recommended
comment: It's playable but not much more. Right now i am enjoying it because it's new but there are so many small things that irritate me. The game feels like a step back from civ 5. The map is filled with too much information that is useless. It comes to the point that my eyes almost hurt trying to process all the information. And the information that i want is non existing. Example of things that annoys me and or make the game nedlessy complicated:- Overall to many menues that have no real purpose- City UI is terrible, managing citizens is a nightmare with bigger citys- Don't know if religous pressure is a thing anymore but i can't find the numbers- WAR... lots and lots of WAR where nothing happens- Warmongerer penalty is a ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥. Some dumb civ declares war on you and capturing a city or two from them gets you so much warmongerer penalty that the rest of the AI civs denounce you and later declare war on you.- I miss the restart button. If you find your placement bad or don't like it you have to go back to main menu and restart. It gets old really quick.- Can't change the number of citystates and the placement is aweful. They are always in the way but the exellent bonuses you get makes you not want to kill them all.I hope to change my review to positive but wait a couple of months untill patches/mods/expansins fix the endless small annoying problems before buying2016-12-31 updateOK so i have learned to love or at least tolerate most of the things that irritate me with this game. Several of the things that annoyed me the most have been fixed. Still not as good at Civ V but on the right way.*Changed from thumbs down to thumbs up

title: Recommended
comment: I've been a civ fan since Civ3. I have created vast empires across the years, but now with Civ6, I have been able to strategize to my victory in greater depth than previously imaginable. Now with unstacked cities, and a much more intensive focus on the map, each city can be more specialized. Civ6 feels more natural in gameplay compared to its predecessors. For example, the new road mechanics are more historically-realistic; roads are made acoording to where trade happens. Though the game may have released with quite a few bugs, the fact that the developers actively update the game shows the amount of effort put in by Firaxis.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I love the Civ games and have even put a decent amount of time into this one as well. At first I wanted to recommend this game to everyone as the music and graphics are fantastic and really appealing. However that's about as good as it gets for the Civ game. (Compared to previous entries)First off, diplomacy doesn't exsist. You meet a civilization and your choice is to say hi or not to. (has little to no impact) Next after twidling your thumbs messing with improving your civ you get denounced. Why you may ask. Well because you're inferior of course. You don't have the tech that they are given at the very beginning so **** you. After you try to improve relations and improve your Civ they declare war on you. Why again? Oh because you're weak and dont believe in their religion. Afterwards they send their "army" which usually consist of 2 units that you obliterate. Then once you conquer them the whole world denounces you for being a "warmonger" which basically just makes you nerfed to all hell because you ****ing fought back. Like seriously did they even evolve this game?Pros:Nice GraphicsNice MusicCons:Horrible AIHorrible DiplomacyHorrible city planning (districts are cool but usually make your small piece of landmass a huge city with no space for further development)Horrible building (Sometimes I'd build a district or something and all that happens is a big red exclamation mark pops up saying something is in the way but when you bring a builder to clear the area nothing happens)Game gets boring quick (Like I said no Diplomacy so no temporary friendships or trade)Oh and trade lol, You try to make a resonable offer to a country and they will 99% of the time decline the offer, then 5 rounds later will ask you to trade all of your resources AND gold per turn for their 1 cottonI wanted to love this game so much but it just fails in every strategic endeavor. I even waited MONTHS before I reviewed this game hoping the devs would fix these issues. However, after all these months with nothing but♥♥♥♥♥♥updates and ridiculous DLC that adds things that should already be there. This game does little to nothing new that the old Civ games did better. If you want a good strategy game go look at the older Civ games or another strategy game in general. Until the Devs prove that they care this game is not worth over $20. Please fix your game Firaxis, I know you're a good company somewhere in there. Just fix this game so it can be worthy of the Civ title.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Being that I am a loyal fan of this series, I bought this game the day it was released (aprox 15 months ago). I gave them until now to fix the issues with the game before I wrote a review and this is all I have ever had to say about this game:It has completely broken AI and a crapload of dlc.Everything I have read about the terrible AI in other reviews is true. If they do not fix the AI in this game there is no way I will buy the next one.This game is not even worth the cheapest of sales...I mean, if you find it on the street you should just throw it in the garbage. Buy Civ 5 and thank me later.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really can't recommend this game at the moment. I'm playing Civ since part One, and never (ever) have I been so disappointed when winning a game as in Civ VI. It is a game with great mechanics, but it lacks... I don't know what, exactly, but it feels I was robbed of my Civ experience at the end of the game. Bugs aside and all. I mean, how can you "forget" to implement the "roundup-movie" at the end? That has been a signature goodie of all my wins since... well, ever. This is just something very small, but significant - and in the sum of those small things, I was almost disappointed - I will refrain from playing Civ VI in the next months.My advice for you: Go play Civ V. It's excellent. Wait for this game until Xmas 2017.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Has most of the same features as Civ 5,Some things have been improved.Others remain equally as disappointing.Diplomacy with AI is as bad as ever, with frequently unpredictable behaviour, going from being friendly to hateful with little reason, as well they are too easy to manipulate, often I found it was as easy as giving them some gold if I saw them building up troops on my border, and next turn the troops would move away, meaning I had avoided war, just by paying them off, this can be done pretty much indefinitely, guaranteeing that if you have any income, you can do whatever you want.Civilization starts are way too close together, I mean WAY TOO close, I had to modify the games lua to give me some breathing room to actually build a civilization. The number of times I had to restart a game because I would be surrounded in other civilizations, within 7 hexes of my capital, giving me no room to expand, it also helpfully means they hate me because we have 'border tension'.Warmonger penalties, as per the usual mean that most of the time you end up having all your long time allies suddenly decide you need to die, because you are winning a war.On the plus side, districts are pretty cool, once you get used to the idea of sacrificing improvements in order to build them.The tech tree however is terrible. It has such easy 'bee lining', that is often the AI, as well as the player will just avoid techs because they have terrible bonuses. I often only research them because I can, and because I like to have all my techs move forward together, not because they were good techs to research.Finally, the multiplayer is unplayable. Desyncing every 2-10 turns means you spend more time loading the game than you do playing it, and the devs have no ways of solving that, if you don't believe me, check the forums, they offer no solutions.So ultimately if you want to play a good Civ, play the last one.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Build cross multiplayer functionality and maybe I'd say this is worth it. In all honesty, it'd be much easier dealing with these S***y AI opponents if I had my friends around to deal with it too.

comment: Tbh, I purchased this game buz of the summer sale. I wanted to just play about 2 hours buz I needed to sleep earlier for tmr. title: Not Recommended
comment: I can look past some of the commonly noted issues with this most recent Civilization title such as the AI's poor use of its units / city management and while I don't agree with every design decision that was made this game brings a lot of good ideas to the series (particularly the idea of city districts). Like every iteration of the series since Civ IV I expect that this game to improve with the addition of new addons (which, of course, means paying more too).However, the diplomacy in this game is utterly broken: Not only is it enormously difficult to please the other civilizations in the first place and make them friends (there seems to be more negative modifiers then positive ones) but that whole effort is absolutely wasted when they consistantly break friendship agreements to randomly declare surprise war on you along with another civilization that they had a poor view of just a few turns before. This breaks any sense of building up lasting allies or diplomacy spiraling out of control into bad relations. It's simply random, immersion breaking and not fun.I've been playing the Civilization series since the original title. I put countless hours into Civ II and Civ IV. While I think Civ V needed some work from it's state at launch I stuck with it throughout and still had lots of fun even before the add ons; I can say the same about Beyond Earth infact! However, I'm shelfing Civ VI (and reinstalling Civ V) until there is another major update to address my main issue with the game among others. When a full on addon comes back I'll deffinately look into that too and concider purchasing (and depending how that goes, revising my review).

title: Not Recommended
comment: It is getting a negative vote just to counter the hype.It is the most dumbed down version of the game i have played. And i have been playing since Civ 1. Ofcourse earlier Civs are seen in the context of the year they were made.Unhappiness is not a thing anymore. Cover the entire map with cities. No problem.Steamrolling the map is easy now. No more massive unhapiness penalties or need to create puppet states. You can just keep every single city you conquer. No penalties.Developing science and civics is incredible easy with the boost system. Also no penalties for number of cities.All in all you can have 100 cities and there is no penalties or difficulty of running such a huge empire.Information menus are gone or poorly made. List of military units? The list of your cities can't be sorted by production, science, or whatever. So when you hit 20+ cities get ready to micromanage for 10 minutes every turn. Also no more auto-production.Overall information on anything is bad or non existant.Districts are a gimmick. They dont make the game harder or immersive. They just make you trade off a resource tile to put buildings on. Improving and exploiting resources is still important. Builders (workers) that disapear after they have done their number of upgrades is dumb.Everything is streamlined, science, civics, city states, so there are no major trade-offs to consider anymore. Everything has their separate resource and function to make it easy (and boring). Government cards is the worse idea ever. Havent dozens of cards and being able to use 4 or 5...AI is the typical launch garbage. Diplomacy is bad as usual. Combat AI is terrible. AI civ management and victory pursuit is really bad. And once again we have the scenario of tank vs spearmen back in a Civ game.It is fun enough but dont belive the hype. It is worse than previous titles.

title: Recommended
comment: forced auto unit cycle, and the benchmark function crashes upon exit.Otherwise, it's a fantastic game. I can't wait until more civilizations are added

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game is stale and boring. This is easily the worst game in the franchise. It brings nothing new to the table and it is absolutely astounding that the AI is worse than it was in the previous versions. Very little distinguishes the civilizations after the first era or two so the replay value is minimal. I bought this on sale and regret the purchase.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The new features are surface adornments to a fundamentally flawed game. They have almost zero bearing on how you play the game.This is especially insulting, considering the Community has spent years detailing feedback on what the main game's issues are.Here's a brief overview of what has not been fixed:- The AI is still batshit insane.- The Tech-Tree is still wonky and allows for startling beelining. You'll still see Caravels around before the AI even researches basic ironworking.- The production costs are still too high. Building anything takes forever.- The AI still can't hold its own in a fight.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Between scouts not starting with the ability to move freely through rough terrain, rough terrain not enterable if you only have one move point left, and not being able to build roads wherever you want, my scouts are only moving like one tile per turn. What's the point? Might as well have a horse do their job.Also the fog of war map, while a cool concept, is really visually indistinct. The unexplored parts are the same color as the explored-but-unseen parts and it's really irritating.Workers can only build three things. Then you have to build another worker! Between this and the scouts, the early game is much slower than civ 4 and 5.All that being said, as far as I can tell the developers appear to be listening to a few of the complaints (they eventually put the ability to name your cities back in, which wasn't in from the start for some reason), so it'll likely eventually be worth buying. Maybe wait until after the expansions are released.

title: Not Recommended
comment: At this point, Civilization VI is a watered down version of V that fixed one flaw of the previous game, but enhanced the endless endgame and the terrible diplomacy.Just so you know where I'm coming from--I loved Civilization Revolution and that got me started on Civ V. It was a beautiful game and a nice step up from the simplicity of Revolution while maintaining the same feel. However, after playing a round or two the problems became clear. That being said, I still enjoyed it enough to play hundreds of hours. I can't say the same for VI.Civilization VI moves the happiness system back into the background so it's no longer an issue, but the diplomacy is worse than V was. No matter how you treat your allies, the moment the alliance ends they will join the denouncing circle of poo that always seems to form. Every turn you will be denounced by the people you just fought off for being a warmonger--until they declare war on you, only to loose--and then everyone else declares war as well.In short, while I enjoy aspects of this game, I won't even bother to play it again except as a guilty pleasure for the short fun periods of initially arranging your empire before you have to deal with the endless slog of stupid AIs and the ten hours it takes to actually finish things. /End Rant.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ is love, Civ is life and it only gets better!Like with XCOM 2 Firaxis did an amazing job doing everything just better in a franchise where you think, that everything that is possible was already explored. Yes, Civ 6 does indeed prove that even more new ideas and good changes were and are feasible.When you think about the fact that Civ 5 was quite bad at release and only got really good with the addition of the DLCs you'll be amazed to think about what will be possible now with Civ 6, because it's already better than Civ 5.Now let me get back, I have to play one more turn...

title: Recommended
comment: I'm one of those people that was playing Civ 5 up until this one's release. And I never tried Beyond Earth but I know that it was a disappointment to a lot of people so hopes were high for this one.In a lot of ways, this feels like Civ 5 + the expansions, but the thing is, Civ 5 + expansions is one of the most balanced, and interesting strategy games ever made, so that's not exactly a bad starting point.Normally Civ games are pretty weak upon release and then get better as they go on with DLC, expansions, and patches. This game feels incedibly complete and balanced as it is now.Although so far the DLC offerings for this game seem pretty weak, this game is also expected to receive mod support and free updates as it goes on.The biggest difference between this and Civ 5 though, is that cities now require multiple tiles for various things you can build, which I think is a brillaint addition to the game for a few reasons. 1. Cities now feel more real as you have to specialize cities at first to focus on different bonuses, and they feel more unique as they take on different shapes and looks. Also, since wonders now take up space, you can't get a huge advantage in this game by just rushing as many wonders as you can.Another big difference is the possibility for a religious victory, which is also done very well in my opinion. There can only be a limited number of religions on the map, and whoever gets one first gets a decent advantage as you win a religious victory by converting the majority of every civilization to your religion.There's a few other differences in this game between it and Civ 5 but overall, if you've been waiting for a new Civ game, this really scratches that itch.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Right now, I cannot recommend this game.I had to stop playing because the late game turns into a slog of issuing and reissuing orders to trader and spy units. Turn times are still long... even with the game installed on an SSD.The UI is designed poorly. Bright/cartoony map colors and art styles blend in with every bit of information or indication that you need to play the game. It's hard to see what you need to see.Units auto-cycle at a slow pace after getting orders, leading to many misclicks. You may even plan to move two units. They're right next to each other. Seems intuitive you'd move one right after the other. Nope. Move one. Expect to move the other (there's a delay... everything in Civ 6 comes with a delay). Next thing you know, the game lumbers across to the other side of the world so you can switch to planning a trade route in the middle of a battle.You do a lot of trade route planning. Sid Meier's Trader Planning Simulator 2016 would be a more appropriate title. Right now I got 10 trade routes that I have to reassign to the same cities... at a pace of about once per ten turns. So every ten turns, I have to issue one hundred trade route orders. That's a lot of orders. Each one takes a bit of time as the game processes your clicks, a second or two at a time. That is, if you don't misclick during these delays.Many of the game features seem simplified compared to past titles. Potentially deep and meaningful things like espionage and religion are very shallow and don't seem compelling or useful. Civilization is a game about numbers and data. These two modes could be shut off entirely with little impact on the game itself. Missionary combat is another layer of warfare. However, it's just two melee units vying for what amounts to a miniscule bonus. But hey, they seem to put a lot of work into the animations... which I turned off because turns take forever if everyone has to show me their little song and dance.The game doesn't suffer from any performance issues as far as I can tell. It just is designed to move at a slower pace. A one second delay here, a one second delay there... it adds up.Sluggish, unresponsive, and at times, buggy UI frustrates. Tedious reassignment of trader and spy units bogs the late game almost as much as the turn times. You can move through 250 turns pretty easily. The next 50 will start to frustrate you more.The AI still doesn't know what it is doing. Only now you get the benefit of hunting for the data you want. Why is a leader suddenly unfriendly towards you? Search in the submenus. You'll find it. Well, you won't find what you want to know. You'll find some numbers without explanation. Some leader "agendas" that often contradict each other. China's leader was threatened by the number of world wonders I had, but yet also looked down on me because my culture was low.There are also some weird unit design quirks. Catapults and archers can shoot twice as far as machine guns and rangers. I tried to research the effective range of ancient weapons. The ballista seemed like it had the longest real world range at 800 meters. Guns can shoot further. It might fit in with some idea of balance in the game, but it doesn't make sense.Combat also seems to move at a slower pace due to a new design in movement points. You now need a full two points if you hope to move on to those hills. Don't expect a unit to move into a grassland and then into a forest unless you've got special upgrades. From a balance perspective, ranged units are now much more powerful due to the lack of mobility. Your melee unit can get stuck moving one square at a time as archers obliterate it. Or, you can roll across a continent picking off the enemy AI's suicide runs. They throw weak melee units at you all day with little tactical planning. Their archers are formidable. But they don't use any kind of coordination. With support units, combat is now more about the bonus from adjacent tiles. I think this just makes the AI ever weaker.If you do want to wage war, prepare for your entire game to be about warfare. The AI seems to remember everything bad thing you do and forget the good things. Lucrative trade deal for +10 relationship bonus? Gone in a few turns. Raze a city in 2600 BC? Well, everyone hates you in the modern era because of it... even the AI on other continents.30 hours in and I find myself rage quitting because of these nagging issues.Save your money. Wait for some DLC's.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm a huge fan of the Civ series so I'm really sorry to not be able to recommend this game.The AI is what makes Civ a great strategy game series; whether it's the backstabbing Montezuma, the calculating Queen Elizabeth or the reliable old friend Ghandhi -- they're your opponents. The very artificial intelligence in Civ 6 cannot win battles, accept (or offer) good deals for both parties, and is schizophrenically erratic where it comes to decisions of war and peace.On my very first and only game (on prince -- where the AI and I are on equal footing), I managed to have war declared on me twice and I built fewer than ten military units the whole game. The first time I easily conquered France (who declared war on me for some reason), while the second time Greece accused me of sending missionaries into their territory -- which I didn't even do. After conquering them both without losing a single unit, I decided to focus on technology. At the point I reached the atomic age, I realized that culture was like tech for civics. Ooops. And then I got a message that my largest rival Civ (who had a greater population) had just entered the Renaissance.The AI can't even beat me in my first game -- how is this a challenge? People gave Mafia 3 terrible reviews despite the solid graphics, great voice acting, and fun basic mechanics mostly becausse of a terminally moronic AI. That's very much the case here as the sound track, leader animinations, voiceovers, and possibly good mechanics (we'll never know without a worthy opponent). However, at least in Mafia 3 the AI had discovered gunpowder before I finished the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 2K is one of the worst. Don't buy it now like I did. Wait for a stable release, when it doesn't crash or hang at loading. Why pay full price to line their pockets for a half baked game... It will also drop in price with time, so just as an added bonus! Now with that out of the way. About the game: I can sum it up in one word. Pointless. I have always enjoyed the Civ series, but this version really doesn't offer much value. I'm not a fan of the sprawl effect. I really didn't find the micromanagement that came with selection city tiles enjoyable. And I hated the fact that the tech tree only went so far. There was so much room for more that could have been designed into it. At least some near future tech would have been fun to build and play with. Civ 5 went farther and was by far the more interesting. But if your a fan, by all means try it. Just wait until a more stable release and the eventual price drop!

title: Not Recommended
comment: The new features are surface adornments to a fundamentally flawed game. They have almost zero bearing on how you play the game.This is especially insulting, considering the Community has spent years detailing feedback on what the main game's issues are.Here's a brief overview of what has not been fixed:- The AI is still batshit insane.- The Tech-Tree is still wonky and allows for startling beelining. You'll still see Caravels around before the AI even researches basic ironworking.- The production costs are still too high. Building anything takes forever.- The AI still can't hold its own in a fight.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been playing Civ since v1. It saddens me to say this is the worst one by far. Quality of life features have been removed. I can no longer view the game from the top down without going into cartoon mode (strategy mode), workers cannot be queued (even though they can do 3 improvements before dying), you cannot make build queues anymore.... frankly this has become a game about micromanagement. I want to say it's fun but it just isn't. It's too watered down, too simple, too much about micro management. My opinion, stay away. It took me 2 hours of gameplay to realize that the Civ games as I knew them are dead.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'll start off with saying that this game, for a Civilization game, is good. But, like all Civilization games the AI diplomacy and decision making is quite poor. They will go completely across the contintents to put their second city right up against your starting city with out properly defending their starting city just ... well I don't know.. just because? The religious aspect and how the AI handles the Religious units ( spam) can be quite annoying and consume a lot of your game play. On epic + game speeds the tech progression and what not is not balanced due to being able to get bonuses in every tech due to time, not sure a fix to this but as a personal preferance it can dishearten me driving a tank around in what should only be the medieval era.
