title: Not Recommended
comment: My experience with Civ6 has compelled me to write my first ever steam review. I really would like to recommend this game, but in its current state the game has enough problems that you should wait some time for them to all get hammered out. Fortunately most of the issues seem very fixable. A bit of background, I've played every civ game since 2, logged almost 300 hours on Civ5 and have logged almost 75 hours on civ6, having beat my last playthrough on Emperor difficulty.The Good:I really like the new district system. It's added a level of complexity and 'urban planning' to the game that previous iterations lacked. It encourages you to develop many cities rather than stacking 10 wonders in your power capital like you would do in previous civs. The new cultural, policy, and government system is also a welcomed new addition. The added flexibility is nice versus in Civ5 where once you had made policy decisions you were stuck with them for the rest of the game.The eureka/inspiration system is also a cool way to add side quests to your decisions to help boost a certain policy or technology. Finally, having great people actually do different things is another interesting way to vary up gameplay, although it would be nice if some of the writing/artist/music great people could do something other than create great works.I don't think the new city-state 'envoy' system is an improvement. I do like the unique bonuses that each city state can give you, but I think civ5's system of actively courting (well, bribing) city-states to be your friend was a stronger system.I do like how happiness (now called amenities) is now per city, but it's so easy to maintain happiness level that building as many cities as possible is the best possible strategy. In civ5, there were repercussions to building/conquering too many cities, and I think civ6 went too far in the opposite direction.I don’t mind the new art style and there are some changes to the map and UI that are helpful, such as lenses that give more pertinent information about the map based on context (such as seeing religion levels when moving a religious unit), but for some odd reason a lot of useful features have been taken out of the UI. For example, in most information screens, you can’t sort information. Scrolling through a list of 20 cities to see which one is producing the most science becomes more difficult than it should.As has been said in many other reviews, the A.I. has problems. Contrary to what I've seen others say, I actually find the A.I. in the early game to be somewhat respectable. Despite the fact that they sometimes are hyper-aggressive, it is challenging to fight them, along with the ever roaming barbarians. However, part of this early challenge is due to how bad the A.I. cheats on harder difficulties. On my emperor playthrough, every other civilization I encountered had 2-3 cities with multiple workers and military units within the first 30 turns. I had barely built my first worker. When the A.I. declared war on me, units appeared to just spawn from nowhere. I don't mind a challenge, but spawning units for free in a game like this is very frustrating. Because of these bonuses, the AI will also completely dominate in culture/science. I think in the year 200 A.D., I saw Kongo change its government to a Democracy and enter the modern era. 200 A.D.!Yet despite all this cheating, the A.I. has major flaws in the mid to late game that makes them nearly harmless towards the end game. For one, once they've built around 5 cities, they stop. They will try to conquer each other (and you), but their tactical management of units isn't very good. But this biggest issue, is that for some reason, the A.I. will not upgrade their units. An A.I. in the atomic era will still have spearmen and slingers. One tank army can almost single handedly destroy an entire A.I.’s military. I'd almost wish they'd cheat and spawn throngs of tanks and infantry to just provide a challenge, but after the medieval era, they just stop caring about their military.And to pile on to the diplomacy-side of things, once you decide to conquer a city, you can forget about diplomacy for the rest of the game. Warmonger penalties, even for wars you didn't start, cannot be surmounted with any amount of diplomatic good will. For a frame of reference, an Alliance is worth +18 in relationship with the A.I. Conquering one city is -15. Conquer two cities, and you are at -30, and your ally will denounce you. Never mind you conquered the cities of a civilization your ally is also at war with. It's nonsensical.Beyond the A.I., there are a few other issues. The pace of the game doesn't feel right. I think it's because you can now 'research' two trees at once, so you get through the tech and policy trees faster. Eureka and inspiration bonuses also cause this. In Civ5, I would reach a certain era at least within a century of when that era actually happened in history (e.g., industrial era around 1800 A.D.). In civ6, I discovered flight in 1100 A.D. This is on standard speed. It feels like there are gaps in both trees that might get filled in with new techs in later expansions, so hopefully this issue improves over time.If you were new to the civilization franchise, there really would be no reason to play Civ6 over Civ5. Every civilization game has been fairly different than the previous. Whether you liked Civ5 over Civ4 or not, no one can deny that Civ5 was a completely different experience than Civ4. Civ6 feels like Civ5 with a few things refactored. And with the current A.I. and pacing issues, Civ6 isn't as enjoyable as Civ5.Nearly everything that bothers me about Civ6 seems easily fixable. I remember when Civ5 first came out, it had a lot of problems, but with two expansions and many patches, it is a really good game. Civ6 feels like it is a few balancing patches and one expansion away from being a good game. The glaring omission of a United Nations in Civ6 leads me to believe the nearly absent diplomacy of this game will be fixed in the future.So, should you buy this game now? No, don't waste your time. Buy Civ5 if you haven't already or if you already have Civ5 then start another Civ5 game. Or try another 4x game. But just like Civ5, give this game a year or two to hammer out it's issues and it will probably be great.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I would recommend not buying this game in its current form. There's simply too many bugs in the game at the moment concerning the Singleplayer AI, diplomacy and UI. Basically, the current AI is only programmed to win through domination. The other win conditions are rarely triggered unless its the human players. In addition, you have no way of tracking how close you are to the other win conditions.Diplomacy is broken at the moment, since the AI is programmed to do two actions. It will either denounce you or declare war on you. No matter how friendly you are with the AI.I regret buying the game and not waiting for it to be more polished. I will revise this review when they fix these bugs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really want to give the game a positive review but they need major patch work to AI and new systems first.+ Beautiful+ Unit stacking in mid to late game+ Districts+ In many ways an improvement on previous games- Diplomacy is broken or misexecuted (relationships don't exist & are essentially meaningless)- Promise system needs major work- AI as pertains to agendas and diplomacy is not good (the principle behind the changes is great, just poorly executed)- Warmongering and Cassus Beli needs to be rebalanced (it is crippling)- Religious combat is a bit strange (having hordes of apostles storm your territory is a major annoyance)- Many other small gripes revolving mainly around AI

title: Recommended
comment: I haven't played any of the previous Civilization games, and therefore I'm not able to compare this game to the other ones. This game however, offers everything you'd want from a turn-based strategy game in my opinion. It's very complex with a lot of different ways to play the game, and it just feels like the developers have cared a lot about the details.Personally I don't have any problems with the graphics, but I can understand that some people find it a bit too cartoonish, escpecially if you're looking at the other civilization games.Originally i bought this game for times when I just wanted to relax, but it's actually a lot funnier than i thought.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I feel like a bought a beta release. Even with the latest Winter update, there are still quirks that I find unforgivable. It's as if the programmers do not actually play the game they've developed to see if they've missed anything. Like the Alert function - was its inital omission intentional, and enough people complained that they added it back in... or did they just forget? Water units still have no Alert function.From reading other reviews, it appears this is has been the norm for a while now. While unacceptable, enough people are out there that are always going to buy a new release, and we live in an age where companies' primary concern is money.The new features and changes to the game are interesting. I've played a few games and do find it somewhat enjoyable. However, the interface is awkward and a step backwards from Civ V, in my opinion. There are a few irritating quirks. For example, I frequently have to repeatedly mouse-over the side notifcations before they actually display the description, and then once it finally displays, I can't read it because it gets blocked by the tile description pop-up for the tile that happens to be under the notification icon. Seriously? No one on the development team noticed this?? Or am I just doing it wrong?Bottom line: do not buy this until the price goes down. Stick with Civ 5. I was really looking forward to Civ 6, and this was the first time I've bought a game soon after its initial release. Lesson learned.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have been a huge fan of the Civilization games since I played the fourth title. I have spent many hours on Civ5 and I loved every minute. I never experienced problems and the gameplay was smooth. That can't be said about Civ6.Civ6 adds many new features. For example districts and unit stacking. But it suffers from a very poor AI. You will get denounced, declared war upon and get asked to trade all your resources for 3 GPT by every single country every 5 turns. Also, after advancing a few eras you will go insane from the road mechanics. Firaxis thought it'd be nice to buff the roads every few eras, so when you have walked the maximum distance, you will still have the 0.5 movement left which will result in you having to click fifty extra times every turn. The map is also very small. I have only played on the 'Continent' type map, but if you like playing against many opponents, expect at least two nations right next to you.It'd be a fun game if it actually worked properly. My computer is constantly experiencing shutdowns caused by this game. Even though my computer can run every single other game on the highest settings, it can't run this game on the lowest.As you proceed further into the game, it will gradually take more and more time between turns. Most people also knows this from Civ5. However, later in the game, if you take over an enemy's capital or cause a big event to unfold, the game will simply crash and let you experience it all over again.I really want to like this game, but Civ6 is currently so bugged it isn't enjoyable to play. I really hope they will fix these bugs in the future, because it really got some great potential. Out of five stars, I will give it two. It's close to unplayable (at least for me), but when it works I have had some fun moments.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI got worse, don't bother.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Like every other Civilization game ever, I'm going to wait for all the DLC to come out and buy the bundle when it's on sale. Because -- like every other Civilization game ever -- that's the complete and wonderful game. My reaction to the base game is always, "meh, that's fun but it feels like it's missing a lot." And by the time all the DLC is out, I love it. I tried it out during a free-to-play weekend and really worked to get through as much playtime as I could. My eyes and brain adjusted to the cartoony graphics after a few hours and there's really a lot of game mechanics that would lead me to a strong recommendation, but it just feels like there's something missing.I will wait for the DLC bundle and I will wait for it all to go on sale. Until then, I'll be over still playing Civ V.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Okay, I get that they were trying to add a lot of new mechanics, but I think maybe they went overboard. Having to designate a specific tile for wonders and for districts while adhering to the myriad rules about which wonder/district can go where gets ridiculously difficult, especially if you also want to be able to feed and house your citizens when only certain kinds of tiles can be farms, etc. And it's many times worse if you're unlucky enough to be on a small island. Once you're well into the game and your cities stop gaining new tiles at any reasonable rate and are large enough that you can no longer purchase new tiles yourself, you're pretty much stuck as you can't do anything to remove districts/wonders if you discover later that you have a more pressing need for something else. Once not even focusing your city on food is enough, you may get into a situation where your city is shrinking and you can't build anything and even if you can research something that will give you more access to food, it may only be able to be built in a district you don't have and have no place to put. I'm finding it very frustrating even on settler level. I wish you could turn off housing requirements in the advanced game setup or that something as useful as neighborhoods was available significantly earlier.

title: Not Recommended

I realized it had some very irritating issues, the biggest one for me was having Barbarians just appear as by magic every 15mins surrounding one of my cities that the A.I. knew it could do the most damage too (Teleporting Barbarians I ask you!) No, No ,No Sid don't let one of the best PC game ever made turn into some mystical farce because if you do, it will be forever remembered as crap and this game does not deserve that title.

title: Not Recommended
comment: (tl;dr It has launch day bugs and brand new bugs, updates are almost entirely focused on DLC without the effort put into patching that Civ V enjoyed. I gave it a year expecting bugfixes and while there has been some work put into fixing issues, a game that was a promising true sequel to Civ V is just not getting the support it requires to be a proper successor. Patches are not properly vetted and always introduce new issues. Do not buy Civ VI expecting proper post-launch support)AI spams users with war and/or peace offers every single turn (bug). Invisible rivers on Inland Sea map were never fixed. Barbarian scout notification warnings permanently appear on your own and random game units. Random unknown "player defeated" notifications spam you for the first third of a game, even when it's just a city-state being captured. The AI returning your own captured city when negotiating for peace results in your own city having a zero growth penalty, because for some reason it counts as a captured "foreign" city (bug). The game exe still randomly crashes for a large number of people when exiting. Default AI will give away all great works for a single luxury resource (Similar issue to the launch day balance issues, but this one is a straight up bug. All AI will trade away great works as if they have no value). These are all bugs that could've been fixed in one patch, however game updates have been minimal and will introduce new bugs as much as fix existing ones. Unlike with Civ V which enjoyed multi-page patch notes, in VI patches are focused on adding more DLC to buy.If at war the AI will move religious units into your military forces which auto-kills them for no reason. Even if you do not found ANY religion, third party AI will denounce and go to war with you because you were "converting" one of their cities. Logically this is impossible, but because killing the religious units incurs a penalty against that specific religion, all nearby uninvolved AI will pretend it was your nonexistent religion that was converting them.The AI is still relatively useless and poorly implemented. It will plant a city in the middle of four of your own despite a lack of resources, then take offense when you are forced to path units around it. You will receive a severe diplomatic penalty as a warmonger despite never starting a single war, which makes relations with other AI practically impossible if you are forced into playing defensive wars. AI will still not improve tiles with resources inside its borders, instead electing to trade more gold for them than it would to buy the workers outright to improve the tile next to its own capital.Despite the numerous upgrades in capabilities (such as unit stacking to build armies) Civ V's AI was more capable at warfare, both defense and on offense. Seige and artillery units will attempt to attack move even though its not allowed, so the AI just throws seige units at your combat troops. Even outside of war the AI will waste a hundred missionaries to convert a city that can only be converted by a prophet, which makes the AI useless at most religious victories.I could paste three more paragraphs of bugs from my previous review, but I am too lazy to verify which of those issues still exist. Maybe Civ VI will be in good shape in three years, or after the first two major expansion DLCs get released. Issues such as the great works trading make multiplayer pointless due to AI abuse, and the AI itself isn't programmed on how to defend itself even on Diety making single player equally frustrating. Give it a few more years or wait till it's 80% off, otherwise expect new bugs to be introduced with each quarterly patch.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's an interesting take on Civ mechanics. I happen to be enjoying most of the changes done to the tech tree, as well as the addition of a civic tree and a district system. However, I have to agree with the majority of reviews, this game is filled with hair-pulling bugs. I haven´t experienced a single crash in the 20+ hours I´ve played, but the bugs are really annoying. Clearly more development time was needed in order to finish the game.+ Great design and animations+ Love the tech and civic trees+ Barbarians!- Incomplete character dialogues- Dumbest AI yet- Unbalanced features (everything from civis to tech to relationships)- Crazy district repair turns (Too much production needed to repair. Sometimes cost me over 50 turns)Overall I´m happy with it. I´m pretty sure It´ll end up being like the last time and they´ll have it patched up in the months to come. Until then, I can´t fully recommend the game just yet.

title: Recommended
comment: As someone with 2230 Hours on Civilization 5, and a genuine love for the Civ series, this game feels fantastic. It's a breath of fresh air after the mediocre disappointment of Civ: Beyond Earth, Civ6 is incredbily satisfying and has tons of charm. The soundtrack is an amazing orchestral score, and the way it changes between Eras help to keep it enjoyable to listen to for a game that might last 300 turns. The changes to Espionage and Religion are also really fun, they're much more interactive than what was offered in Gods & Kings and Brave New World for Civilization 5. One of my biggest complaints it the AI seems to get confused and doesn't know what to do with itself most of the time past the Medieval Era, granted I've only played on Prince and King so, the AI might get smarter at higher difficulties. Overall, I'd say it's definantly worth picking up if you enjoyed Civilization 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: i think it goes without saying that this is a pretty good game, and they've introduced some cool new features to it. firaxis isn't known for taking comments on their games, though, so i'll just put all the flaws here, maybe someone will enjoy them.-no regenerate map button when starting a single-player game. you have to exit to main menu and wait for it to load again. this is a ♥♥♥♥ing HUGE deal, if that wasn't entirely clear. a smaller, but still relevant nuance of this is that there doesn't appear to be any starting bias (naval civilizations don't necessarily start on a coastal tile.) this was a feature (a setting, togglable on/off) in civ V. they appear to have just forgotten how. enjoy resetting.-the strategic view is far from strategic. it's actually harder to see relevant information (tile yields, improvements, units) than on the default view. the edges of tiles are not clean lines, they are strange, wildly jagged shapes.-while the 'music develops over time' aspect is pretty cool, it gets crazy repetitive in the early game.-few hotkeys and they are barely customizable. where is 'center on current unit'? why can't 'fortify' and 'sleep' be on the same button?-rather hard to figure out new concepts, for example what the heck does a delegation do? why does it cost money? is it like an embassy? can they see my capital? none of these questions are answered in-game.-barb spawn rate is obnoxiously high for Prince difficulty-no option to turn down the amount of time spent hovering on a tile before it shows you detailed information on it. you will always wait about 1.25 seconds to learn whether or not a tile has hills.-hills and flat land look ♥♥♥♥ing identical-this one is just a very basic oversight: autosaves are not ordered by date, they're ordered alphabetically. so autosave 09 is above your more recent autosave 13. how nice.-you have to go to the civilopedia to see what bonuses districts get from adjacent tiles. in general, these bonuses are pretty well-hidden and you'll probably need at least one full playthrough to understand it, meaning the information is simply presented in an unintuitive and poor way.-there are 3 menus on the 'government' foldout screen. "My Government," "Change Policies," and "View Governments." there is literally no purpose to "my government," and it gives you no information that the 'change policies' screen doesn't already show. but the useless panel is the default.-The coding on 'Escorted units' could use work. My escorted Great Generals sometimes insist that they have to move first. Speaking of units trying to move when they shouldn't, after using up a unit's movement, sometimes another unit is selected, and before I can make a choice (within about a second or so), a third and different unit is selected. Really jarring for my sense of space and direction.-Pretty much nothing gives you info 'at-a-glance;' you have to dig through menus to find whether a city has enough housing or amenities or whatnot. Again, unintuitive design is inherently bad design.-Long freezes after changing a policy setup, and some animation skips in diplomacy menu (namely in dealing with Kongo.)-Automation is poorly done (automated exploration units don't just walk AROUND barbarians) and inconsistent (you can't automate builders or archaeologists or great people that do stuff to tiles.) Did someone lose their thumb drive with those lines of code on it?-I nuked someone in peacetime. No diplomatic repercussions. What?I look forward to the non-alpha builds of this game. At least you stuck to your release date.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Running a 2.4 Ghz Win 10, 64 bit, 12 Gig Ram, dedicated video Nvidia Geforce w/ 4 Gig Video memory, a solid mid grade machine. I've never given a Sid Meier game a poor review, until today. It's a good thing I used a Steam Coupon or I'd really be annoyed. First the good: There are elements of the “District” system I really like but that system is over-relied upon making it difficult to exploit resources and districts. This makes the districts game killers on smaller maps, or if you find yourself situated on an archipelago. I like the new policy system where policies are researched and you can customize your form of government. The Envoy system for City States is pretty interesting. And the game seems pretty stable with a variety of mods. I've checked out vanilla as well as mixing it up and game runs pretty smooth. That's the positive. Basic game-play is less intuitive, as are the controls. The actual game mechanics are typical of over-engineering, in later iterations, of a franchise on decline. This game's basics have devolved rather than progressed. The pathing for units is ridiculous. I have two possible paths for a unit which knows my capital is blocked by a another fortified unit and instead of going around, it back-tracks once finding the road blocked, until the capitol and the unit blocking it are out of the line of sight. Then it does it all again bouncing back and forth. A navel unit inexplicable reverses course, on its own in the next turn, upon sighting a land based barbarian and runs the other way without instructions. Its 100a.d. And I have yet to see a single barbarian navel unit so my ships are getting no basic training. The turns take too long to process. The graphics are shoddy at best. The new fog of war is a distraction more than an improvement. I was enjoying the sound track, playing as Japan, until I met Australia. Now all I get is Waltzing Matilda followed by Didgeridoo over and over and over. I've tried lowering my casus belli with Australia hoping to get the music to switch back but nooooo, just Waltzing Matilda. Nothing against the song. If I were playing Australia it would be great. As is, its ruining any sense of immersion playing as Japan. The interface for controlling the details and micro management of cities is now decentralized with several different screens making informed adjustments more clunky than Civ V. The general graphics quality is better on the surface if you don't look to close. But, these improvements seem to me to be more tricks of glints and glossing and richness of color, while in actuality they appear lower res than the older game. This gives the units a poorly executed bland skinning. The actual city graphics seem to be an improvement and I enjoy the changes from day to night but the reliance on having to build districts before improving them really slows down production of other early game necessities. Even with the coupon, I wish I hadn't wasted the money. Also a waste of 7 hours playing as I doubt I'll return to the save game. RUN AWAY AND DONT SPEND THE MONEY UNLESS YOU HAVE IT TO BURN and keep you expectations low.

title: Recommended
comment: Veterans of Civilization will find themselves right at home. Newcomers to the series will fall in love. Civilization VI is easy to pick up but has lots behind the scenes for the more hardcore gamer.After a somewhat rocky start with game-breaking exploits and balance issues and radio silence, Firaxis responded with a patch that took Civilization VI from good to great.This is definitely a game I will play consistantly over the years until moving on to Civilization VII.

title: Not Recommended
comment: TLDR: It's not a bad game at all but I enjoyed Civ V and Civ IV way more.Not so long version: I played roughly a thousand hours on Civ IV, 505 hours of Civ V and at the time I'm writing this, I have 51.2 hours on Civ VI and even though it's possible this number will change, I highly doubt it.Civ VI is not a bad game... but they kinda took away the fun of playing the game. I've had some incredible wars I completely remember in the past games, but I barely ever fought in Civ VI. Where Civ V added to the military strategy with one unit per tile (compared to the infamous stack of doom of Civ IV) Civ VI just takes it away by removing the incentive for warmongering.This in only one example. You will probably find others when you play it... if you play it. If it's your first experience with Civilization, just pick another one...maybe...

title: Not Recommended
comment: No matter how hard I tried, I still find myself missing civ 5. It was a much better game. I loved the world congress and the international politics of banning resources, voting on a world religion, the world fair.. etc. WHY DID THEY TAKE THAT OUT? If it's removal was done so that the developers can sell it back to us in an expansion i'd be pretty annoyed. They better not charge money for that.Still haven't completed a game. I kinda get bored in the mid game.Also, I don't feel as impressive and grand when I build my glorious civ because of the terrible choice of leaders. The developers chose quirky leaders instead of iconic ones to bring about more nuanced diplomacy. For example, I never pick Egypt because Cleopatra is so exoticized and sexualized and shallow. It's so disrespectful. Whatever happened to Hatshepsut?I liked the idea of districts. But to be honest, it hasn't revolutionized the game as the developers said it would. It has not made war more nuanced. War is still a grab for cities.I also understand that the developers wanted to make diplomacy more nuanced with agendas.. but it feels like a more cosmetic change than a revolutionizing change. AI interaction is still boring..I liked the addition of the religious victory. However, pursuing it is so boring and feels like you wasted all your years of building your civilization just to buy apostles and meticulously and boringly convert cities.As a takeaway, I'm mostly soooo disappointed from the removal of the world congress and UN. And also the politics of your government type. I really liked how civ v made civs following freedom unhappy if they were surrounded by autocratic civs. i miss how you could use the world congress to ban a civ's access to a luxury resource to make their population so unhappy they staged a revolution in favour of your choice of government. Where did that go??

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have put many many hours into the Civ franchise, over 100 on Civ VI alone, and while the game isn't terrible I cannot recommend it.There's a lot of small changes to get used to, not a big issue, however a lot of important functionality has been lost in the process. One of the biggest peeves I have is the chaining of road building to merchants. No reason to send a merchant to any one of your many cities? Well most likely there will never be a road leading to that city. It's a terrible way to manage roads and serves no purpose except to make the incredibly stupid idea of disposable builders hurt a little bit less.Two, disposable builders: this is the worst change in the game. You get a few "charges" to construct improvements and then they're gone. Whomever thought this was a good idea needs to skip the planning meetings going forward. It's an awful idea that leaves a player spending loads of turns wasting away making builders. There's no longer any strategy to protecting them, simply churn out a new unit and build your improvements. There's no improvement upgrades as far as I have noticed, so once their wad is blown that's that. It's insipid at best. Also no roads get built by builders, as mentioned previously, it's impossible to connect your cities if you don't waste 20 turns of your trader's time. Considering 20 turns can be in-game equivalent to 200 years you can see how mental of a system this is (seriously 20 turns to establish a road to a city 6 hexes away in the early game is just stupid).Three, it's boring. The game very quickly becomes dull and lifeless with no real point. You pretty much have to play aggressively which means you pretty much only ever get conquest wins unless you purposefully retard your army and hold back. Not fun. There's no real sense of accomplishment, just this repetitive cycle of tech, war, and building that doesn't really matter. Just build a big army of archers in the first 50 turns and kill everyone, game over. Dull.I wanted to like this game, maybe they're saving a nice update that will make the game fun for a future $60 expansion pack, either way I'm done with it. This is a sad and unenjoyable chapter in the civ franchise, lacking basic common sense functions like road building and generally taking way too long to get anywhere in the game if you want to play other than Ghengis Khan style. Mid-game is a dull slog up the tech tree to the atomic era where you're still bored, but now have nukes. I appreciate all of the work that went into the game, but can't recommend this game at all. I have no idea why the Civ team seems to think they need to reinvent the wheel with every iteration of the game but this reinvented wheel is mostly square and doesn't roll along very well.

title: Recommended
comment: Overall excellent addition to the Civ series, but time will still tell if it has the same amount of longevity as CIV 5 did.

title: Not Recommended
comment: v1.0.0 crashes after a while. Every game. Unplayable! Please patch it

title: Not Recommended
comment: Once you put hours into this game you start to realise how much it lacks compaired to it's predecessor. It's a pretty package but under the hood it's a ♥♥♥♥ing mess.

title: Recommended
comment: While a little rough around the edges, Civ6 is a fantastic game and after a few expansions, will be a contender for "Best Civ Game".

title: Recommended
comment: All you need to know.It's not Civ V.It's slow; takes awhile to plan everything.No longer are you stuck as tradition or liberty, those things can change with every civic.War is easier without cities throwing rocks at you.Multiplayer will be slower, for sure.They stepped closer to a city planner and further from a city planner.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Yes, Civ V was not great on release, but that should be no excuse for Civ VI to continue the tradition. Civ VI is just not good enough. It should be obvious to anybody looking at the roster of leaders that Firaxis intentionally held back many features at launch which they intend to charge for later. That is just plain unethical and emulative of the beast EA.Many things are changed from how they were in Civ V, often these changes appear to be made just so they can justifiably say this game is different which somehow is understood as better. It isn't better. The unpacking of cities is a fun idea but it is not executed superbly. It is just so so. Leaders are more cartoony (the whole game is) which seems to follow in CIv Rev's footsteps not Civ V's. Things take too long to build for some reason. You have to build the district and then the buildings. Wonders look cooler but are way too big on the map.Game had obvious bugs on launch. Yes, they were patched soon enough, but still.Biggest annoyance though was buying the digital deluxe edition and finding it only included some of firaxis's cheap DLC's like, oh, here, we added one measly new leader. Yaay! No, that is not ok.Also, city states are even more irrelevant than they were in CIV V, how they pulled that if is no small wonder.Wait for the bundled version at 7.50 or so like Civ V has been for ages now. Huge letdown. Yuge!

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is a great addition to the Civ fanchise. However, for me a game breaking bug manifested itself after about 19 hours of play, causing the game to crash everytime I attempt to confirm a change of my policies. Check for updates before buying.Aditionally the AI shows some rather silly behavior, like declaring war on me with spearmen when I have tanks.Continent and Island campaigns can easily get imbalanced if a player is isolated and can develop unimpeeded.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's an interesting take on Civ mechanics. I happen to be enjoying most of the changes done to the tech tree, as well as the addition of a civic tree and a district system. However, I have to agree with the majority of reviews, this game is filled with hair-pulling bugs. I haven´t experienced a single crash in the 20+ hours I´ve played, but the bugs are really annoying. Clearly more development time was needed in order to finish the game.+ Great design and animations+ Love the tech and civic trees+ Barbarians!- Incomplete character dialogues- Dumbest AI yet- Unbalanced features (everything from civis to tech to relationships)- Crazy district repair turns (Too much production needed to repair. Sometimes cost me over 50 turns)Overall I´m happy with it. I´m pretty sure It´ll end up being like the last time and they´ll have it patched up in the months to come. Until then, I can´t fully recommend the game just yet.

title: Recommended
comment: Rise and Fall is a fantastic expansion. I left a more in-depth review on the expansion page itself explaining why I enjoyed it. The basic idea boils down to the fact that if you enjoy civilization and want something new you'll enjoy this installment.I don't quit get all the review bombing but I might be biased for it after 190 hours. I have almost 500 in Civilization 5 (+Expansions) and I enjoyed that game too.(Honestly I'm just happy Global Happiness is gone lol.)

title: Not Recommended
comment: Bought this game to play with my friend and we spend more time trying to get our multiplayer game to load than actually playing. We have tried everything, and read solutions online. Nothing works. Please fix multiplayer.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Messy interface, poorly balanced science progress vs. contruction time, ugly cartoon like theme... Civ6 it's still a very nice game but one step back with respect to Civ5 (which remains the best Civ ever).

title: Recommended
comment: Very good game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Its fun, but single player gets stale. When I try to play with friends, this game litterally flips me over, lubes me up, and ♥♥♥♥s me. This is the worst multiplayer interface, I have ever experienced in my 20 years of gaming. Please do us all a favour and fire the person that was incharge of multiplayer. I didn't think incest was legal and encouraged for enployment of the workpalce, but then i realised this is an american company.

title: Recommended
comment: nice game ...many changes in graphics and laders compared by the preveios edition .i played this series from 9 years and it's the best in historical strategy games.please add Arabic languge to the languges listاللعبة من أفضل الألعاب في مجال الألعاب الاستراتيجية مع تنوع في القادة وروعة في الجرافكس

title: Recommended
comment: I've liked previous entries into the series and I do like this one too. While it doesn't shine like it's predecessor, it does have some good points. Deciding where to build your districts and improving them adds a layer to the game that I thought was a nice touch from a city building perspective. Mods do not disable achievements, which is one of the few gripes I had about Civ5.Diplomacy is terrible in this game. If you don't care about diplomacy and you're like me, knowing you're going to wipe out every faction including city states anyway, then that might now bother you. But I got to say it is annoying it takes so little to get denounced in the game, and happens often. I've tried actively building relations with another faction in this game, and it isn't easy and when I have managed to do it, it doesn't last long before you're going back down hill. Then there's the cartoony artstyle. Which feels like a step backwards when you compare it to Civ5. That being said, I've played some games with more cartoony visuals that I liked a great deal. So that in and of itself isn't totally a bad thing. But it does turn some people off. I was more open to it given previous games I've played that had similar approaches to that aspect, but coming directly from Civ5 to Civ6 was an adjustment.I'm recommending it because despite the things that bother me about the game, I can still have a good time with it. Some things can be offset by the talented people making mods for the game. A game shouldn't have to depend on it's modding community to make up for its faults, however. But at least it's there.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Full of glitches, irritations and poor interface. Played every Civ before? Guess your way through then. Wear glasses? You will by the end of 15 mins play.Wait for the inevitable patches and add ons (probably at cost) to experience a half decent game. Bitterly disappoined.

title: Recommended
comment: As an fan of the Civilization series, in fact one who still thinks Civ II was the greatest for its time and era, Civilization VI is a very well done game, at least from what I see for the limited amount of hours I have put into this game. There is ofcourse a lot of "Un-Learning" and also with the new districts the game will seem to take one out of their comfort zone and familiarity of the mechanics we have grown used to playing prior versions of the game. Its this very uncomfort that can either be viewed as positive or a negative by players and probably the reason some have stated that its a step down from Civ. 5. Toi me these un familiar aspects makes the game challenging and also rewarding. I like the sort of integration of civics and science and also how one needs to grow the cities to grow the empire, which means this game involves planning never seen before in civilization series.I must admit I cannot understand why we are not allowed to rename cities (or maybe I have not figured it out as yet) and I also am grapling with finding out some reports I would like to see such as list of all units in ones army, or maybe they dont exist, maybe its time for me to open that tutorial :) Overall this game is a big thumbs up.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Great single player game, however, NOT recommended for those looking for multiplayer.Constant lobby issues followed by in-game synchronisation problems, however when it works it is very good fun.Single player games are a good solid civ experience and after playing the other civ games to this point I cannot wait to see where this series will go! (Hopefully wherever it goes it will be going with better multiplayer…)Unfortunately, I cannot recommend for now as the multiplayer experience was a big factor for buying this time around and for the original price paid, it should work.

title: Recommended
comment: Good game, the ai was pretty weak.3 people declared war on me, but only one of them attacked.Always got denounced.could not figure out how to finish the game in 500 turns.Probably was because I was new, and still am new.declaring war has no side affects on my land also, I was told it did at least by the info that was on civopedia.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game crashes at turn 356 everytime! Loved Civ 5 bought it day one. Waited around for a steam sale for Civ 6 as I was still having fun with Civ. Wish I never wasted my money on Civ 6! Can't even finish the first game.

title: Recommended
comment: Not as great as civ 5 - If this is one sale though buy it!

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game made me want to play Civ 5. it was the little things . the icons are very basic ... i liked the detail in 5 much better . it is an over complicated 5 done on the cheap with regards to graphics.

title: Not Recommended
comment: At the start, the game plays out normally like any other Civ game until about 200 turns into the late game on a standard paced game. Everything starts to become unresponsive. You are unable to view items from your sidebar. Toggling on and off turn sometimes takes multiple clicks. Sometimes you cannot even press next turn or the turn won't advance.The only way around these issues are to disconnect from the game and join back. The problems you have experienced before, will possibly show up sooner or later again. I hope this gets fixed soon as it is quite game breaking.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI is absolute garbage and doesn't appear to follow anything that makes any remote logical sense. I have played 500+ hours in Civ 4 and Civ 5 each. Do not buy this game right now. Second worst game at launch to now, 04-10-2017, I have ever played. FF14 original gets the worst game at launch I have ever played, haha. I am litteraly reinstalling CIv 5 now. Over an out.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Dissapointment is the only word I can think of to describe this game, as it stands. At most, the game is (over all) a 3/5. The gaem is severly lacking in AI development and is still buggy. While I applaud the developers for their innovative attempt with the AI character traits to define their dispositions, the idea has not been executed well. Often other countries are upset with you for things you cannot know and will hate you forever if you declare war. In most games, all AI have denounced all other AI and the player. Thus what is the point of even caring about global relations? I would like ot add I have played all other civ games from CIV III on up and this one does not add up. I would advise waiting to buy until the developers crawl out of the hole they work in, sober up, and read the community feedback. Bring in modding support now, not later so the community can get this game back on track.

title: Not Recommended
comment: RECOMMEND SOMEDAY, BUT NOT YET. OK so far, but missing a few elements that I've come to expect from a Civ game (e.g. diplomacy) that I hope will be added on in subsequent expansion packs. Biggest downside is AI that doesn't seem to understand how the combat system in its own game works, but the artwork is beautiful and the game is easy to understand but has enough underlying complexity to satisfy those that want to drill down deeper. A few bugs and technical things that mistify me, like a lack of space to view your relationship stateus with another civilization and confusing move system where you end up wasting a lot of move points. Overall this game has the potential to be great, but is missing too many pieces at this point. Civ has done a great job in the past filling in the gaps, however (see Brave New World with Civ V), so I'm optimistic that they'll get it right in a couple expansions. Hold off on paying the huge price tag and see what happens as the expansions roll out.

title: Recommended
comment: Contrary to what you might hear, this game is an improvement on Civ 5. The gameplay is more varied, there's more to do during a game, there are better incentives, more paths to take, more difficult choices and so on. I do believe it's genuinely more exciting than it was before. There is definitely a lot of work to be done, but as it stands, it's about on par with Civ 5 complete on the gameplay side of things.With Rise and Fall coming soon, and looking to be a huge step forward, with many gameplay complexities that layer nicely on top of what we already have, it should make for a much more advanced, yet enjoyable Civ.The problems I have with the game, are the frequent crashes and the poor performance. I run an Nvidia gtx 1080 and an AMD Ryzen 1700x and it struggles on max settings in the late game. It's a nice looking map, but reasonably low poly and the background processes should only benefit from an 8 core 3.4ghz processor. It dips to 40fps and you can see the game struggle as you pan across the map.More pressing are the crashes. Playing a single game on prince and standard speed with 6 AI, it has crashed 3 times already and I'm about 70% along the science tree. The crashes can happen at any time, for whatever reason. Just started a map? No problem, here's a crash. Released a nuke, certian that victory is yours? Nope, here's a crash. Funnily enough, the IOS version hasn't crashed on me once and development for that has been outsourced. Firaxis, up your game just a bit please.I feel like I have to address the AI, because it is the most talked about thing when it comes to this game. Yes, the AI is temperamental, yes they are hard to please, but no, they aren't (completely) broken. Having watched a fair bit of gameplay on Youtube to properly understand the game before I dived in, you can see the amount of hoop jumping you may have to do to please a neighbouring nation. The game is intricate and the rules of the game are hefty. You can't just throw money at an AI and think that's enough. You need to understand what they're after first, their leaders needs and how they function, where their placement is on the map, why they would need a certian luxury, what research they may or may not have, sending a scout to see their buildings, etc.Fair enough to that time where that AI was outrageously aggressive towards you, but an overhaul risks a complete dumb down of an intricate system that should be worth it in the end. If you can trust that Firxis will get this right eventually (and there is every chance they can, considering their track record of releasing bug ridden games that become masterpieces) then there is no need to panic, claim sacrilege, cry and everything else I've seen grown adults do over this game.I recommend this game now, if money doesn't mean much to you right now, you like 4X strategies and you don't mind some crashes and gameplay inaccuracies for the time being.Otherwise, wait until everyone changes their tone and for their sake, try to act surprised.

title: Recommended
comment: From the three hours I have played so far, this game may even surpass Civ 5 and 4. I thought I was going to be bothered by the new art style, but it looks great. Like anything else, the menues and interface take a few minutes to get used to, but thats not necessarily a bad thing. So far, the diplomacy and AI is the biggest improvement to me. Highly recomended, I predict I will log hundreds of hours.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I had really high hopes for this game which crumbled in the first few hours. Failure to explain basic game mechanics or define terms, awkward diplomacy system, bad AI. Really just disappointing over all.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Unfortunately did not reach the level of Civ 5. I see where they were trying to go with growing the city via tiles but it flounders. Seriously if I got another notice for more amenities or housing I would go crazy. Maybe if it would recognize that I am done growing this city... Got a victory but I will not be coming back.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After moving to next turn, game consistently and reproducibly crashes. Not clear how to print out a verbose bug report, get an error message back that can be Googled, etc. Software's not perfect, but please provide better tools to help end users solve their own problems, or a better product.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A huge step backwards in many wasy, to name a few:The workers now have charges and cannot be automated (even to repair). Makes it incredibly tedious for really no reason - was way better in Civ 5.Trade routes are more annoying and only last 1 journey before disppearing and you have to make another trader - tedious for no reason.Mod accessability simply isn't there. Civ 5 had workshop but also in-game access to mods. Civ 6 doesn't. You have to go to a different website and manually install.A lot of things are cool - I rather like districts. But the new worker system kind of ruins the whole game for me. It is just way too annoying of a mechanic.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Do not buy this game until some of the fundamental issues with it are corrected. I've played every Civilization game since Civilization I and this game is just awful.They have introduced complexity for no reason other than complexity. Just about every subsystem, and especially the civics, religion and city state subsystems, is significantly worse than Civ V and simply don't work. The one exception is the distict subsystem. That's actually good.The graphics are awful as well. You get tiny, tiny icons of cows and sheep that make it impossible to tell what they are. Hills look almost the same as flat land. Even the movement of units has been made annoying as hell. In previous Civ games as long as you had a movement point left you could move into a hex. Now the unit stalls until the next turn if you don't have enough movement.The decisions of the AI make absolutely no sense. AI players declare war on you randomly, denounce you for ridiculous reasons such as you have more Great People than them and generate gobs of units which just clog up the map. City states also generate tons of units which clog things up more and barbarians generate in what seems like every hidden space on the map.The game has so many fundamental issues they should just toss it and start all over again.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been trying to like the game since I like most of the Civilization games but I just can't play it long before I just shutdown the game in disgust when playing single player. The issue is the AIs, and their total irrationality. There is not rhyme or reason to their like or dislikes, and they act like someone who total psychotic as well as bipolar. No matter what AI I play with they start off disliking me and never leave that. I've had AI that I've only met their scouts once show across half the world to declare war on me. There is no deplomacy at all when dealing with them and their total irrationality drives ME crazy.While I like other portions the game besides the AIs, due to my graveyard work schedule I really can only play AI games. So in the end the AI kill the game for me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The barbarians are overpowered massively.Most other changes from civ 5 to now suck.Game claiming to support mods doesnt, so i cant fix any of the MANY issues with playing this.Requesting a refund and going right back to civ 5. Anyone else who bought this should do the same. Anyone who hasn't bought this should go buy civ 5 instead (go play civ 5 instead if you already own civ 5).

title: Not Recommended
comment: MOT ANY MORE AS UPDATE HAS RUINED IT:this update has made game unplayable and I have abandoned it: other civs can tell me not to convert their cities but I can no longer tell them the same. For things like theater square it tells me I need 10 citizens, then as soon as I have that it demands 13, then even though I catch the exact moment of turnover it bumps it up again, so I can only start these projects with new cities when it takes about 700 turns to complete

title: Not Recommended
comment: Not recommended. No matter what you do, you get denounced. The stupidest thing is that when you attacked, you fight back and end up taking one of their cities, then you suddenly become a warmonger and no matter how many turns passes, you are still a warmonger. Oh, and even if you are an ally and you have pleased the other nation in every way, you still can get surprised attacked. The alliance system doesn't work. I'm sure these problems will get fixed eventually about a year or two later, but not recommended as of current state.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I found Civ VI to be disappointing. The user interface is clumsy compared to the prior versions. The game requires too much micro-management of individual units, and the game at is slighted against conquest victories. Visually appealing, but for some reason the other leaders are shown as cartoon-like rather than .Ore realistically drawn. Very disappointed with the game play. Maybe after they issue a few DLCs it will improve, but for now I find myself playing Civ V most of the time.

title: Recommended
comment: It's got a great early to mid game. You actually have much more leeway to decide how to build a civilization.Examples: You don't really need to get useless technologies like previous games. I didn't learn how to build the most basic boats until the industrial era, just because the techs I actually need weren't entirely dependent on previous techs in the tree. Like you can get several science techs before getting any military or economic techs.Districts also help a lot. You can't build every district early because there are population limits to how many you can build, but where you build them first also really matters. Like if I care about science I'll put my science district near my capital, but also with a few flat tiles nearby to put universities or wonders on, since they all require their own tiles. Later I'll make an economic district, but I won't have a place to build a couple buildings so I will never be making as much money as I would if I built it first.Also, the government is more complex. You can build different into 10 different governments, each with there own advantages and policies that all have a serious impact on how you do things.Lastly, the city states are cooler. The straight benefits are greater, and no real 'random benefits', which was a major reason to use them in the last game. In particular, if you're an ally of a city state you can pay them a reasonable fee to take control of their entire army for 15 turns, which is huge as they usually have about 5 units. So if you have one nearby, you don't have to worry about suprise attacks as much since you can have a decent army at your disposal within the turn.Those changes make a major impact early to mid game, but if you get to the final stages they tend to matter less overall.My biggest gripe, by far, is that the AI is idiotic. It tends to be annoying with stupid demands, they may constantly declare war on you, but they tend to be terrible at actually waging war. They may ask to trade my 'open borders and luxery resource' for 3 gold total, but then i'll ask to make it even, and they'll demand all my luxery resources, open borders, and 180 gold. But not offer anything. Like they'll interupt my playing to send me that stupid a trade.

title: Recommended
comment: I've been a Civ fan since the first one--on Super Nintendo. Overall, I'd say the game is good; I don't drop 25 hours over 2 days if I'm not enjoying myself!There are a few things I really enjoyed, and a few things that I find frustrating. These may or may not matter to you:Graphics: Mixed bag here. The cartoon style for the main map and structures is dreadful--the trees look absolutely ridiculous, and the mountains aren't much better. It really does look like a mobile game in many respects, and there's nothing positive about that. However, the fog of war styling is GREAT! It looks like an old parchment map, with decorative features; it's nice to look at. And the leader animations/backgrounds are definitely eye candy. The detail on the leader backgrounds stands in stark contrast to the unpleasantly simplistic main map graphics.Research and civics: I LOVE the changes here. The things you do in the game can affect your research speed--killing enemies with a sling unit can increase the speed of archery development, for example. They've also returned to having forms of government, and this affects which kind and how many bonuses you can stack. It's more freeform, allowing a lot of flexibility in getting the bonuses to fit your play style. I think this is easily the best advancement in the Civ series.Workers: This is one part where I think they failed miserably. Workers were replaced with a builder unit. It can only construct 3 tile improvements, and then it disappears for no real reason. (Kind of like a state disbanding its road crew every few years and paying to start from scratch again each time.) While they build improvements instantly, you'll need to waste more city build time creating them. And they no longer build roads--that was split out into a military engineer unit, and happens automatically with trade units. If you like forcing the world to be shaped to your whims, you'll find this to be very obnoxious.Great People: There's been a very positive revamp here. There are more categories of great people, and they actually do a variety of useful things. Some create great works which bring in tourists, others help you speed up wonder construction, or claim new tiles. They also feel more unique than they did in Civ V.Religion: This feature has been greatly expanded over past titles. You can found the usual religions, or create a custom religion with custom bonuses. You also create special units that engage in theological warfare--"combat" without being at war, in addition to spreading your religion and stamping out competing religions. It's an interesting mechanic, but it also gets tedius when Ghandi sends constant wave after wave of these units in to deal with, lest he convert your cities...Soundtrack: I haven't really noticed it during my games. Nothing too exciting here. Might be a disappointment for some. I even checked a few times to make sure that music volume was up. I have to say that they also included the absolute worst rendition I've ever heard of Tourdion--the French medieval music. The music stands out as the least polished feature of the game. I recommend having a decent Spotify playlist going while you play.

title: Recommended
comment: WOW. This game has had me sucked in for hours on end already. I've been waiting for this game for ages and it did not disappoint to say the least. I started my first game and got obliterated. Second game, I over reached and was taken with ease. Third game, I lowered difficutly and started to get the feel of the game. All in all, I have a lot to learn but im catching on.PROS:-Good cartoony style graphics, looks great.-Smart AI who WILL take advantage of your weaknesses and mistakes.-Diverse leaders and bonuses for each.-Revamped religion with an interesting twist to stradegy.-Fresh concepts with the districts and wonders.-Great people earned in different ways offering a challenge/race to aquire them.-Movement overhaul enhancing combat and the way you get around the map.CONS:-Districts take a lot of space and leave less hammers, food, science, etc. to be had on tiles.-Building wonders is a secondary goal with steep requirements and space they take on tiles.-Cities are constantly unhappy because of lack of entertainment districts, entertainment district almost required in every city.To sum it all up, there are a lot of new concepts to the game, like, amenitites, religious combat, and districts. All of these things can be a bit confusing at first and frustrate you. Also, CIV V strategies will almost always NOT work in this CIV. The AI are smarter and the gameplay is way different.Once patches and more DLC come out, this game will rival all previous CIV games, and definitely surpass the likes of CIV V.Final Rate:9/10

comment: This is a great game. On launch, I feel like Civ VI is much more complete than Civ V was. There is religious victories and the leaders have many interesting new abilities not seen in Civ V. The developers changed the movement mechanics in a way I feel makes much more sense than in Civ V. The districts are a wonderful addition to the game, making city placement even more important than in Civ V. This mechanic promotes more awareness for future city development and victory conditions.The only thing I was disappointed with at launch was the AI relationship with the player. The diplomacy is not as fleshed out as it should be. However, the cultural, religous, and military interactions with the AI is not really inhibited by this, so I was not very put out. When the DLC began to be released however, I was angry. In what world is $5 for a civilization fair? There are no real gameplay additions with these DLC packs. If the customers of Civ V were charge $5 for every civilization the developers added to the game, no one would have bought Civ VI.Maybe they are not planning on Civ VII because at $5 per DLC civ, I will not be buying.

title: Not Recommended
comment: While the phrase "dumbed down" has been somewhat watered down over the years, I feel it applies for me to Civ VI. I have happily sunk hundreds and hundreds of hours into earlier Civ games, but this... I just can't.Everything from the art style, to the UI, to the game mechanics, to the presentation... everything seems to cater to a younger demographic.My main gripes (and their descriptions) with the game are (in no particular order):Art styleAnimations (look at the leaders, how they move and gesture while talking, as a fantastic example) and colors (the world isn't pastel) are exaggerated, buildings and units look like caricatures of themselves.Tile system and city buildingWhile it may seem like an interesting idea to have districts take up a tile space, deciding what tiles to use for what districts QUICKLY becomes an absolute chore. Optimizing is an extreme pain in the behind, and, in addition, building variety has dropped A LOT. Going from a plethora of buildings available in earlier games (with less restrictions on where and when to build them), there are only a very small number available, and they're limited to specific districts. Probably my largest problem with the game, by far.Worker and tile developmentClosely related to the above, tile development is almost an equal pain - that workers have limited amounts of actions before getting destroyed is such a ridiculous mechanical decision (artificial "depth" by introducing an arbitrary limit, yay), and their use is more limited than in earlier games as well - that they can't build roads is such an immensely stupid decision. Lack of automation and improvement options to me is a huge drawback.Not an awful game, but it's certainly not good. Roughly a 5/10, buy if it drops under $/€/£10.

comment: RECOMMEND SOMEDAY, BUT NOT YET. OK so far, but missing a few elements that I've come to expect from a Civ game (e.g. diplomacy) that I hope will be added on in subsequent expansion packs. Biggest downside is AI that doesn't seem to understand how the combat system in its own game works, but the artwork is beautiful and the game is easy to understand but has enough underlying complexity to satisfy those that want to drill down deeper. A few bugs and technical things that mistify me, like a lack of space to view your relationship stateus with another civilization and confusing move system where you end up wasting a lot of move points. Overall this game has the potential to be great, but is missing too many pieces at this point. Civ has done a great job in the past filling in the gaps, however (see Brave New World with Civ V), so I'm optimistic that they'll get it right in a couple expansions. Hold off on paying the huge price tag and see what happens as the expansions roll out.

title: Recommended
comment: I've liked previous entries into the series and I do like this one too. While it doesn't shine like it's predecessor, it does have some good points. Deciding where to build your districts and improving them adds a layer to the game that I thought was a nice touch from a city building perspective. Mods do not disable achievements, which is one of the few gripes I had about Civ5.Diplomacy is terrible in this game. If you don't care about diplomacy and you're like me, knowing you're going to wipe out every faction including city states anyway, then that might now bother you. But I got to say it is annoying it takes so little to get denounced in the game, and happens often. I've tried actively building relations with another faction in this game, and it isn't easy and when I have managed to do it, it doesn't last long before you're going back down hill. Then there's the cartoony artstyle. Which feels like a step backwards when you compare it to Civ5. That being said, I've played some games with more cartoony visuals that I liked a great deal. So that in and of itself isn't totally a bad thing. But it does turn some people off. I was more open to it given previous games I've played that had similar approaches to that aspect, but coming directly from Civ5 to Civ6 was an adjustment.I'm recommending it because despite the things that bother me about the game, I can still have a good time with it. Some things can be offset by the talented people making mods for the game. A game shouldn't have to depend on it's modding community to make up for its faults, however. But at least it's there.

title: Recommended
comment: As an fan of the Civilization series, in fact one who still thinks Civ II was the greatest for its time and era, Civilization VI is a very well done game, at least from what I see for the limited amount of hours I have put into this game. There is ofcourse a lot of "Un-Learning" and also with the new districts the game will seem to take one out of their comfort zone and familiarity of the mechanics we have grown used to playing prior versions of the game. Its this very uncomfort that can either be viewed as positive or a negative by players and probably the reason some have stated that its a step down from Civ. 5. Toi me these un familiar aspects makes the game challenging and also rewarding. I like the sort of integration of civics and science and also how one needs to grow the cities to grow the empire, which means this game involves planning never seen before in civilization series.I must admit I cannot understand why we are not allowed to rename cities (or maybe I have not figured it out as yet) and I also am grapling with finding out some reports I would like to see such as list of all units in ones army, or maybe they dont exist, maybe its time for me to open that tutorial :) Overall this game is a big thumbs up.

title: Recommended
comment: This is an incredible strategy game. But it lacks in living up to the incredible standards set by Civ V and Civ IV.Lots of people seem to complain about the AI being horrible, but the AI is basically the same as in every other civ game, but they just have these things called Agendas now. Agendas are policies that each specific civ leader will follow. An example is Trajan, Trajan likes civs that have a larger amount of land than he does, but he dislikes ones that are smaller. Every leader has their own specific one, and you need to learn to play around them. Lots of leaders will have agendas that contradict with other leaders agendas. So unlike in Civ 5 you can't just be friendly with everyone. You have to pick out a set few civs you wish to be your allies, and stick with them and follow their agendas. This can be seen as a good or a bad thing depending on your playstyle.Another large difference in this game than in Civ 5 is the unit movement. The new way the movement system works is that you have a set amount of movement points for each unit. In civ 5 if you used 1 movement point to go onto a flat tile, you could still use the leftover movement point to move onto any other adjacent tile. But if your first move was into any other rough terrain than you would be out of movement points. In Civ 6, you can't use the 1 extra movement point in the same way as in civ 5. Flat terrain takes 1 point, and rough takes 2. If you use one movement point to move onto a flat tile near a hill, you cannot move onto the hill tile adjacent because you only have 1 movement point left. Most people don't like this new system as it makes unit movement horribly slow. And the roads were changed so they don't help as much either. This basically constricts you to using cavalry units so you can actually move around the landscape in a reasonable amount of time.One other huge difference is cities. There are 2 ways to build your empire, tall and wide. Tall is when you have only 3-5 cities with a very high population, while wide is to have tons of cities with little population. Civ 5 heavily favored tall empires, while civ 6 heavily favors wide. This is mainly due to the science and culture change. There are no more "policies" but instead there are 2 tech trees. One running off culture and the other running off science. In Civ 5 you didnt want a lot of cities because it slowed your science and culture production due to cost of policies and techs increasing the more cities you have, it was also beneficial to have a lot of population in your cities because of how the science buildings worked (Library, National College, etc.). In Civ 6, there is no penalty. You have to make as many cities as possible, and just put down tons of campuses and theater districts to generate science and culture. This will be a huge change to those going from Civ 5 to Civ 6. I personally like building wide empires more as it gives more land control and actually feels like you are trying to control and expand your empire.TL;DR: This game is incredibly different in playstyle from Civ 5 and will take getting used too, but is fun nonetheless.If the movement system is changed and if they add some more non DLC civs, then this game might rival civ 5. But as of now Civ 5 is clearly superior.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civilization VI is off to a solid start, however as is expected there is much to improve and a few things that simply feel wrong. While some may not like comparisons to CIV V given it's had allot of time to be refined, that game is also not perfect and could be improved. However I'm surprised some of the things it did right, did not come over to civ VI.At first the art style was "in your face" different, in a bad way but over time it's kind of grown on me. However some may struggle with the yield icons as they're small and hard to make out for me. A harsher dark outline would make seeing them far easier for both me and others who have trouble seeing them.The different lenses are absolutely fantastic. Being able to see the appeal of my tiles, my religious spread and where it's coming from/going to as well as the settler lense are all welcome additions. However for AI games I feel a "wanted territory" lense is despeartely needed so players can avoid expanding on a different continent, in the opposite direction only for the civ they promised not to expand towards get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off and declare war in the near future. This would also reveal AI flaws (EG if every single hex was off limits)The districts system is new and interesting. I've enjoyed trying to figure out which districts should take priority and it adds some satisfaction to city management. I feel there's too stark a difference between the good and not so good districts. A faith district is there purely for making a religion and I feel is shoved to the side when the 2 trading districts or the science/culture/hammer districts come into play. Still allot to figure out, just hoping there can be multiple viable pathways as currently there is a cookie cut way to do things as there was in civ V.From the civics, the ease with which military tech units are obtained, the need for walls to be able to shoot barbs, the sheer strength of barbs and the fact that there're more military civs than passive ones screams of the devs trying to force conflict to occur.While there're only 2 more military civs than passive ones it may not seem so bad, but when taking into account how bleh so many of the passive civ abilites feel in stark contrast to civilization V's civs, it's pretty god dam awful for those who preffered a pacifist approach.The civic system is an addition I didn't enjoy as much as I thought I would. It looked like a flexible, more customisable option but is hindered by its tech tree structure and narrow range of card abilities.In civ V, you start your tradition/liberty tree with a little boost, then gain something more upon it's completion rocketing you civ forward. Complete the piety, patronage, aesthetics or rationalism had the same effect depending on what you were up to. Add in it's contribution to encouraging war with an abundance of combat based cards.I feel no such impact or satisfaction here, and far less flexibility in getting to what I want (which there is an extreme lack of) given it now functions as a tech tree. This may be a "love it or hate it" thing, and unfortunately I'm in the hate it boat. The civ V policy trees were simply better.The science tree feels narrower and is unecesarily stretched out with overly large lines. It looks bad and feels bad to navigate, as you can't see what leads to where.While the micro management of civs it fun and all, the housing/amenities system absolutely crushes any hope of building a tall civilization. While I don't mind wonders taking up hexes, as they look sweet, like a trophy on my land, this addition only emphasises how poor a choice building tall is in civ VI, further cutting down on the avaliable options and making your civilization more optimiased to mass producing units for war.Religion also took a hit in civ VI. Many of the pantheon beliefs seem, to be quite frank,♥♥♥♥♥♥ Very few are linked to a luxury resource as in civ V and many revolve around certain terrain, most of which can be removed by an enemy or providing boosts to your military.An extremely prominent annoyance are the constant requests from AI's. Every time they send you a delegation, which is very gawd dam common you get a pretty, little cinematic. Add in multiple AI and you'll be spending more time spamming the ESC key than playing the game. I simply don't care about maming AI happy anymore, because it's so tedious and infuriating to do. Am quite shocked there's no option to disable the cinematic menus.Movement in civ VI is an extreme downfall compared to its predecessor. Instead of spending w/e movement u have left to move onto a hill, you simply won't move onto a woods/forest/hill. I found it extremely irritating being constantly told to move my units when they can't complete a turn without moving in the opposite direction due terrain being in the way and this really slows down the pace of the game, makes retrieving workers/settlers from barbs nigh impossible without going to their camp and simply feels awful in practice.Civilization VI will undoubtedly be improved in the future in many ways, but unless the issues I have with it are not only fixed but improved drastically, it will be very very difficult to justify the pay wall these fixes will be locked behind. And given their emphasis in forcing you to go to war, and my hate for the tediousness by which combat functions I'm likely to stick to civiliation V with my pacifistic science/cultural victories.. I reccomend similar players do the same as there's simply more fun to be had with civilization V for now.
