title: Recommended
comment: I really like this game. I like the Artwork and Atmosphere and I think the changes with the districts was a great Idea. Sadly the "intelligent" AI is as I actually kind of expected not really that smart. I would really like to vote for "needs some rework", but as that doesn't exist I will vote for recommend, as all in all it's fine. I mean I always like the civ series, but the AI is kind of always bothering me. Also I'm not that happy with some of the fighting mechanics.So, what bothers me about the AI (I played twice on emporer)?Trading with the AI can be horrible. I mean sometimes you can try to give them 2 luxury ressources for 1 and even then they're not happy. Then again you can get your spies back for 1 gold over 25 turns, despite you just ignored them when they asked you not to spy in their territory.They're lack of overall strategy. I was at war with an AI, they attacked the city state I was allied with and killed all units there. After that they just continued without even pillaging something (including my trade routes). Other situation, I declared war and tried to attack a city. I saw that he was coming with quite some units and retreated a bit. He just keept attacking me for some time with single units and after that I took the city without problems. Another situation I had a completly defensless city (I got it from a peace treaty earlier) and declared war because I wanted his capitol and did expect to loose my city, but I didn't care. Well he didn't even attack my city -.- It's totally oblivious to the hole Situation and I actually wouldn't even mind if the AI would cheat here a bit more in sense of information.The agendas of the different AI's have sometimes really weird triggers and I have the feeling that it hinders them sometimes to work together because they have each other as much as me. It really needs some mechanics that they're working together also if they hate themself. I mean in my second game I was warmongering the whole time, but noone really cared. One declared war on me, but never attacked... I mean the only reason I made peace sometimes was because the unhapiness of my towns would skyrocket with warweariness. I personally think a city shouldn't have warweariness if it's not really close to the battles and there is no counter war propaganda (new options for spies?).Now something about the combat system. I really don't like it how it is now. This adding of stats is absolutely stupid. I had the situation where I didn't want to attack a catapult with my legion, because it would just have been a minor victory or so. His unit had defender of the belief (+10 melee strengh) makes with basic stats 33 melee vs 40 melee + he gets his +2 from the difficulty so it's already on 35, a standard swordsman. Meaning also the catapult does probably more damge when defending against an attack then when doing a ranged attack... This is just ridiculous. Stuff like this happens when you try to make stuff to simple. It makes sense to have stats, but I would strictly divide stats and bonus damage. Stats are used to compute a basic damage and afterwards you get some boni lets say for AT against tanks (in percent of the base damage). The stats would be only the main stats + unit upgrades

title: Recommended
comment: EDITED 02/10/18 FOR RISE & FALL EXPANSIONCivilization VI is beginning to live up to its potential. If you've played either of this game's direct predecessors, you'd know how fantastic this series can be. In a hopeful turn, Civ VI reaches to these heights with the R&F expansion. What really excites me, though, is that there is even more to come in terms of content. However, In spite of all its upsides, there are still a few glaring issues.Pros:Many interesting and unique playable characters - Most Civs/Leaders have enough going to make themselves stand outImportant decisions - From placing districts to choosing policies to managing era score, there's always something new to considerGood performance - Somehow, this game loads faster and runs better than Civ V on my PCLiving world - Civ VI really makes its maps feel alive, with empires ebbing and flowing as the centuries passFulfilling Experience - Civ VI R&F has done something uncommon in its series; creating rounds that are interesting from turn oneall the way to victoryIt's Civ - The franchise is so solid that its basic precepts remain fun, no matter how flawed the individual entry isModding - Civ's amazing community pulls through again. Combined with Firaxis' modding tools, the Steam Workshop flourishes once againNeutral:"Unique" visual style - Love it or hate it, Civ VI looks very different from Civ V, being cartoony and exaggeratedVarious design quirks - There are too many to detail, but it's up to you to decide whether you like being able to wipe out other Civs 10 turns into the game, or pouring dozens of turns into underwhelming wondersPassable AI - The computer foes are generally sensible, and know how to manage themselves, but are certainly no genuisesCons:Broken user interface - Wonky edge scrolling, obfuscated information, text being covered up, and a useless minimapModerate glitchiness - From small visual errors, to wonky starting positions to random crashing, it's not uncommon to play a game of Civ VI and experience some kind of issuePrice point - Yes, it's a modern AAA title. But does it have to charge so much for new content on top of an already underwhelming base game? At least there's Humble BundleConclusion:If you are a fan of strategy games and have cash to spare, or can find it on sale, try Civilization VI.

title: Recommended
comment: It is easy for a dedicated Civilization fan to find a lot of things that need improvement in Civilization VI. And I think a lot of the negative points are valid, but they are nitpicks from people who are overall having a very positive experience with the game.All of the MAJOR changes are for the better: districts, happiness, religious victory condition, builder mechanics. The small criticisms people have: the UI, the minimap, diplomacy mechanics, pacing, etc. are all things that (by my observations) were rushed to get the product out quickly and are easily patchable.Can the game be improved? Certainly. And it will be. But it already a LOT of fun to play as-is, and I don't know if I can go back to Civ IV or V anymore thanks for the major changes.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Like every other Civilization game ever, I'm going to wait for all the DLC to come out and buy the bundle when it's on sale. Because -- like every other Civilization game ever -- that's the complete and wonderful game. My reaction to the base game is always, "meh, that's fun but it feels like it's missing a lot." And by the time all the DLC is out, I love it. I tried it out during a free-to-play weekend and really worked to get through as much playtime as I could. My eyes and brain adjusted to the cartoony graphics after a few hours and there's really a lot of game mechanics that would lead me to a strong recommendation, but it just feels like there's something missing.I will wait for the DLC bundle and I will wait for it all to go on sale. Until then, I'll be over still playing Civ V.

title: Recommended
comment: The more I play Civ VI, the more I am liking it.If you're looking for an upgraded, new, polished version of Civ V, then this is not what you're getting and you're going to be disappointed if that's what you're looking for.On the other hand, if you're willing to give it a shot, the new mechanics and the new ways to do certain things become more and more fun. So to sum things up, here's a pros and cons list after a few games:Pros:- Graphically beautiful game- New ways to manage the tiles in your city, takes some getting used to (+ City Management)- New battle animations- The tiles on which wonders can be built are restricted depending on the wonder- Tons of new resourcesCons:- Weak A.I., especially in the lower difficulties- Some playthroughs can be ruined due to intensive barbarian spawning early on- Not Civ V (if that's what you're looking for)- Feels relatively easier than past Civs, noob friendlyOverall,I find Civ VI is a nice, refreshing addition to the series that suceeded with many of the new implementations. You just have to go at it with an open mind and give things a try. New mechanics like traders building your roads are pretty good too. One thing however, is that enemy A.I. will engage in such silly battles. Like you'll have a unit with full health and a general on top of it, and the ai will still attack you with a lower tier unit that has like 10 health, killing themselves in the process. Other than a few small things here and there, the pros shine bright enough to make for a very good Civ, with lots of potential to improve it even more.8.5/10

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization VI follows the traditional Civilization gameplay style. I don't think that needs any further introductions at this point so let's move on to the differences between this and its predecessor.As of course can be expected, the game got a graphical update. What I really enjoyed is the feature of building districts and you deciding where to place them. It actually makes a strategic difference where you decide to place them. Another improvement I enjoyed is that the AI became more unique personalities. Every faction has a 'personality'. For example some will be more inclined to attack you while you grow in power, while others will like you more as you grow in power. A last point I want to adress is how roads are build, roads are build by creating trade routes. This makes routes more of a strategic decision as well. Will I trade with my enemy to create routes so I can attack them faster when I'm ready? Or is the risk too great they will do it to me?However the game is far from ready from being polished. The AI's unique personalities sometimes manage to turn into an unpredictable teenager: Declaring war on you one turn and offering peace quite soon after again. The game is more limited than it's predecessor too, due to expansions and many DLC's the previous ones has.The game however is heading the right direction. As expansions continue and DLC's will get added Civilization VI will be ready to rival it predecessor. Assuming they don't forget to polish the AI and balances.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ VI still holds true to the Civ formula and this iteration does not disappoint. The new art style is enjoyable (and more friendly to weaker machines). Simple changes to movement have made movement more tactical and makes exploration a longer term project then in Civ 5. Overall, this is a worthy entry to the series and I feel it is well worth the asking price.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Between scouts not starting with the ability to move freely through rough terrain, rough terrain not enterable if you only have one move point left, and not being able to build roads wherever you want, my scouts are only moving like one tile per turn. What's the point? Might as well have a horse do their job.Also the fog of war map, while a cool concept, is really visually indistinct. The unexplored parts are the same color as the explored-but-unseen parts and it's really irritating.Workers can only build three things. Then you have to build another worker! Between this and the scouts, the early game is much slower than civ 4 and 5.All that being said, as far as I can tell the developers appear to be listening to a few of the complaints (they eventually put the ability to name your cities back in, which wasn't in from the start for some reason), so it'll likely eventually be worth buying. Maybe wait until after the expansions are released.

title: Not Recommended
comment: At this point, Civilization VI is a watered down version of V that fixed one flaw of the previous game, but enhanced the endless endgame and the terrible diplomacy.Just so you know where I'm coming from--I loved Civilization Revolution and that got me started on Civ V. It was a beautiful game and a nice step up from the simplicity of Revolution while maintaining the same feel. However, after playing a round or two the problems became clear. That being said, I still enjoyed it enough to play hundreds of hours. I can't say the same for VI.Civilization VI moves the happiness system back into the background so it's no longer an issue, but the diplomacy is worse than V was. No matter how you treat your allies, the moment the alliance ends they will join the denouncing circle of poo that always seems to form. Every turn you will be denounced by the people you just fought off for being a warmonger--until they declare war on you, only to loose--and then everyone else declares war as well.In short, while I enjoy aspects of this game, I won't even bother to play it again except as a guilty pleasure for the short fun periods of initially arranging your empire before you have to deal with the endless slog of stupid AIs and the ten hours it takes to actually finish things. /End Rant.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 2K is one of the worst. Don't buy it now like I did. Wait for a stable release, when it doesn't crash or hang at loading. Why pay full price to line their pockets for a half baked game... It will also drop in price with time, so just as an added bonus! Now with that out of the way. About the game: I can sum it up in one word. Pointless. I have always enjoyed the Civ series, but this version really doesn't offer much value. I'm not a fan of the sprawl effect. I really didn't find the micromanagement that came with selection city tiles enjoyable. And I hated the fact that the tech tree only went so far. There was so much room for more that could have been designed into it. At least some near future tech would have been fun to build and play with. Civ 5 went farther and was by far the more interesting. But if your a fan, by all means try it. Just wait until a more stable release and the eventual price drop!

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm a huge fan of the Civ series so I'm really sorry to not be able to recommend this game.The AI is what makes Civ a great strategy game series; whether it's the backstabbing Montezuma, the calculating Queen Elizabeth or the reliable old friend Ghandhi -- they're your opponents. The very artificial intelligence in Civ 6 cannot win battles, accept (or offer) good deals for both parties, and is schizophrenically erratic where it comes to decisions of war and peace.On my very first and only game (on prince -- where the AI and I are on equal footing), I managed to have war declared on me twice and I built fewer than ten military units the whole game. The first time I easily conquered France (who declared war on me for some reason), while the second time Greece accused me of sending missionaries into their territory -- which I didn't even do. After conquering them both without losing a single unit, I decided to focus on technology. At the point I reached the atomic age, I realized that culture was like tech for civics. Ooops. And then I got a message that my largest rival Civ (who had a greater population) had just entered the Renaissance.The AI can't even beat me in my first game -- how is this a challenge? People gave Mafia 3 terrible reviews despite the solid graphics, great voice acting, and fun basic mechanics mostly becausse of a terminally moronic AI. That's very much the case here as the sound track, leader animinations, voiceovers, and possibly good mechanics (we'll never know without a worthy opponent). However, at least in Mafia 3 the AI had discovered gunpowder before I finished the game.

comment: The game is stale and boring. This is easily the worst game in the franchise. It brings nothing new to the table and it is absolutely astounding that the AI is worse than it was in the previous versions. Very little distinguishes the civilizations after the first era or two so the replay value is minimal. I bought this on sale and regret the purchase.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The new features are surface adornments to a fundamentally flawed game. They have almost zero bearing on how you play the game.This is especially insulting, considering the Community has spent years detailing feedback on what the main game's issues are.Here's a brief overview of what has not been fixed:- The AI is still batshit insane.- The Tech-Tree is still wonky and allows for startling beelining. You'll still see Caravels around before the AI even researches basic ironworking.- The production costs are still too high. Building anything takes forever.- The AI still can't hold its own in a fight.

title: Recommended
comment: - Don't know why people are giving this game so much hate, personally i think that this CIV game is quite good, ive played many CIV games over the years for many many hours and i think CIV 6 is a wonderful addition to the series.- Sure there are some bugs with it, but honestly ask yourself what game have you ever played thats released and not had any bugs, this game isnt unplayable, there are some exploits but if you wanna play the game without them then just dont use them easy as that.- The game takes alot less to run than previous games which is nice- I love the new army managment system it allows you to mass a much larger and powerful army for less cost per turn and easily moving units as Squadrons instead of individual single units. (combining up to three of the same units together)- The faith and diplomacy are great and will be better once the few bugs have been fixed with it and when they expand on it- Love the new map layout/design as well as the character models.- All the difficulties are harder than in previous games which is a nice addition- Game feels like CIV 5 with a major upgrade in a very good way-Love that you dont get as bad effects of having multiple cities, you can make as many cities to your hearts content without any major debuffs affecting you- A downside would be that the AI need adjusting, they sometimes get angry for no reason or make very very unfair trade offers, for example AI: Give me all your resources and 30 gold per turn for 90 turns and i will give you 1 gold, and while your at it you might as well give me 4 of your cities. With saying that you can still alter the deals to make them more fair and they will generally accept the deal- Another downside is that the Teams option isnt implamented in the game yet in multiplayer and singleplayer modes, but you can alter a game file to activate the Teams option on bothOverall i think the game is amazing and cant wait for DLC to come out to expand the game even further

title: Recommended
comment: Still in the early stages of playing the game, but the majority of the gameplay complaints the few negative reviews levels against this game are wholey false.-The graphics are improved over Civ 5. There's just no actual arguement to be made here they are simply objectively better. You might not like the continued use of the cartoony art style that Civ has been using lately, but the quality of the graphics themselves are improved. Period. You can argue not liking the aesthetic choices but STYLE is not GRAPHIC QUALITY.-The game is not "dumbed down". To say that is just bordering on the absurd. With the inclusion of districts, housing, amenities and the removal of global happiness (bringing it to the city level) city building is far more complicated then ever, and since old "plop down city, automate it, done." mechanic that's been around since 3 or 4 has been done away with builders have become more important. They now require attention as every improvement they do (or don't do in lieu of a district) matters as builders can only produce limited improvements before expiring.-The game is not "lacking content". To be perfectly honest this is about as close as I've seen of any video game released that manages to shove in as much of the previous game's DLC as it could into the base package at launch.There are, however, a few actual problems with the game.-No city renaming. I just...can't fathom why this isn't in the game. Who the hell wants to lead the German empire and NOT have the capital be Berlin? When I play multiplayer with friends how am I supposed to rename cities for comical or taunting effect? Really now, was this THAT hard to program in?-AI is quirky. The AI in EVERY 4x sucks in my opinion so I can't really put to much weight on this.-UI scaling is locked. I don't know, maybe I'm getting old but I really can't stand playing a game with tiny text that makes me squint to read it. As it is the UI doesn't take up much room, I would of been thrilled if I could make it larger so I could actually read all the information infront of me.-Not thrilled with the leader choices. I mean sure seeing the same people over and over again gets boring, but really I'd rather have an Otto Von Bismark for Germany and I kinda miss Stalin leading Russia. This is pretty nitpicky I realize but yeah, just not pleased with the mostly c-list historic leaders. *EDIT* After playing a bit more the leaders I previously didn't really care for on paper have grown on me. They are often animated in ways that actually make them pretty damn endearing, especially Cleopatra and Catherine de Medici.-Religious spread is now much more of a mystery. I have no idea how it spreads, how far it spreads and frankly being CONSTANTLY harassed by eight Christian apostles from my neighbors running through my land screaming "HAVE YOU HEARD THE GOOD NEWS?!" gets really annoying really fast. Religious combat is a nice addition though I'll admit.Overall I see no reason to ever go back to Civ 5, it's that good and I'm excited to see where they go with future DLC.

title: Recommended
comment: Absolute positive.At first, it seems to be simple (tech tree, city management, etc.) But later time it is complex and interesting (science, civs, etc.). Graphics is nice, however completely different from previous CIV 5.I found only a few bad things, like lack of roads, crazy AI attaking without any sense, etc....but later on there are ways to go.Playing more, I still keep my rating positive. But there are many issues makes me nervous.- AI is dumb.- City states stockpile unrealistic amount of units.- Due to this, unable to move on the map to anywhere- After a while, evrybody hates evrybody, especially you.- Due to this, no way to trade.- Diplomacy is marginal. Make no sense to spend any time on it.- Religion: same as diplomacy. Do not have prophet or have it: does not matter.- Reach Democracy, Communism, etc. as soon as possible. After that, do not spend a minute on civics.- Added value of many of late game civics are marginal.All in all, much better than Beyond Earth :)

title: Not Recommended
comment: Cannot recommend that game in its current state.Overall improvements like Citi-State management is great, districts are a cool/fresh new gameplay, Religion is also pretty decentBut i encountered a major and annoying bug, which is present since a long time:When you are getting a proposal to be allied with one or more Civ's in a turn, where someone declares War at you, all allied Civ's are in an invisible War with you.Which lead to two abandoned games due to the fact, that my 5 Allied Civ's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥my borders/economic/trade routes. due to the fact, that you are allied with them, makes it impossible to see that they're attacking you until your Cities can shoot at em in proximity.Pretty hard thumbs down for such a bad KI programming. Sorry guys, thats such a huge fail and this bug is out there for a looooong time (due to internet research).Shame on you.

title: Recommended
comment: How can a game be so good and yet drive me completely up the wall with dumb issues like this one does? The underlying game is great - not only a worthy successor to Civ V (ignoring BE, because, yikes) but Civ VI's additions are really special - the new civs, the districts, the graphic overhaul (I really like it!), it's all fantastic. A bug here or there (especially with the AI) but those'll be patched out any day. The real issue is the UI - it's a train wreck, and I can't understand how it got out of beta like this.I know it's nitpicking, but it's like there are a million little nits. Still an excellent game, but it could be so much better. Hopefully the devs will get it there in short order.

title: Recommended

It's not challenging, it's ridiculous. I'll be surprised if I ever play it again.

title: Recommended
comment: Great game, changes from civ 5 are noticable and enjoyable, unlike civ beyond earth feels like an improvement on previous games. The new graphics style a little confusing to me personally. I have trouble telling tile impovements apart, and seeing units in tile improvments, but other than that looks.

title: Recommended
comment: Much like a any Bethesda game if you come into it with certain expectations you can come out of it very satisfied. Civilization has historically always had rough launches in regards to AI, multiplayer stability, and various mechanics that need to be smoothed over by patches. So do not buy this game now if you want a polished game, Civ V is still amazing.That being said this is my favorite Civilization game.They took the best aspects of previous civs, enhanced those mechanics, and added a few new changes that really change the game for the best.Hex System (civ 5)Movement System (pre-civ 5)Multiple Leader Civ Ability (pre-civ 5, only for greek civ as of now)Modding AvailableGraphicsPolicy SystemGovernment SystemReligionDiplomacy (Also see negatives)More Detailed Diplomacy (also see negatives)Civs More Aggressive (also see AI negatives)MusicCity States (more involved)Happiness now city to city (pre-civ 5)Great People now visually competitiveGreat WondersBarbarian Raid System (barbarian scounts will bring raiding parties)Religious BattlesDistrict SystemQuicker *Online* Speed OptionLenses (changes view for religion, settlement ect)Individual AI Leader TempermentAI needs a LOT of workDiplomacy needs some numbers seriously tweaked & more explicitSome mechanics need to be more explicitHad a few disconnects from MultiplayerFew things should be added in the options (ex. unit auto selection)Mini-Map looks pretty awfulI'll probably edit this as I play and as my opinion evolves but I'm personally very happy with this launch and am looking forward to the upcoming patches to fix the negatives.

title: Recommended
comment: It's a cool game. Stop complaining. If you prefer CIV V gameplay then play CIV V.Let other people enjoy this game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Completely unable to start a new game since last update. Even with mods disabled, a new game can't be started.

title: Recommended
comment: My favorite Civilization game since the first one in the series.

title: Recommended
comment: Havin' a blast!

title: Recommended
comment: Some interesting, appreciated changes from previous Civs. There's just enough that's new here to distinguish it from a souped up Civ V. Great fun for a couple of playthroughs, but not enough content to really keep me wanting to come back for more. More playable civs and scenarios will probably get me to dive back in eventually.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ VI will take me a long time to assess properly, but here are some early observations:Positive observations:-Sean Bean.-The district minigame puzzle has got potential.-The wonders are pretty.-Gold is easier to get, and plays a bigger role (cities are not always quite as dependent on hammers).-The AI agendas (visible and hidden) is a good idea.-Standard game speed seems a lot slower now, I no longer have to play on epic or marathon.Neutral observations:-There is a lot of early aggression. Barbs and AI make it very risky indeed to prioritize early expansion over building a strong military. In some games I get crushed in 50 turns by 20-30 units large AI armies. Sometimes barb camps start massive invasions pre turn 10. It is hard to imagine any way to defend properly against that.-The AI prioritize founding a religion. In order to get one of your own, you usually need to build holy site very early, even if your capital is not suited for one.-It is profitable to sell builders once they have got only one charge left, and just buy a new one. I'm not sure if this expliot is intentional or not, but it seems odd.-The randomness in the early game has got huge variation. Sometimes you can steal two settlers and build a huge empire unchallenged, other times you get overrun by five barb camps from turn 3.Negative observations:-There is a lot of info missing. I can't tell when my borders are going to expand. The wiki explains what stuff IS, not how it works (like it explains what envoys are, but not how you generate them).-There is too much to do in the early game, and next to nothing for your cities to do from mid game and onwards (other than building armies).-AI starts complaining about my civ being weak or lacking culture and whatnot pre turn ten. Give me a break, will you? I'm still building my first slinger.-Gameplay is too one dimentional. You need to build large armies and crush everyone. The peaceful civ game is dead.-"Continents" are still almost always two huge blobs of land.-Access to hammers, I mean cogwheels, are still too vital for choosing starting location.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Let me start off by saying that I bought the Deluxe Edition because I am a huge fan of the Civilization series and I was really excited for a new release. My first match was a great disappointment, mostly because a lot of mechanics had changed. But those you can definitely get used to as I did. Afterall, they're not bad, just unusually different coming from the previous titles. The fact that workers are getting used up now was an interesting move to prevent your civ from ending up with a bunch of them towards the late game with nothing to do.What I couldn't get used to is the annoying cartoony style that felt like a downgrade from Civ5, frequent multiplayer desyncs which apparently are normal enough for the devs to announce on the forums that all you have to do is save and rehost (seriously? what's next? just meet up in person and play the game on a board?) - and last but not least the AI which STILL blatantly cheats instead of applying any strategy at all.All the AI does is brainless subsidized mass-production of units (Gilgamesh: "A sale on War-Carts you say? *eyeswiden") and random attacking everything that moves. Spreading religion has also never been easier for the AI because they appear out of nowhere with 10 prophets who are scrambling to all get into THE SAME CITY; now two I could still understand, heck, maybe even three for good measure if you're currently at war with that particular civilization, but THIS?Have they fixed any of this since the release 1 1/2 years ago? Of course not, that would be insane. Makes MUCH more sense charging 5-9 euro for yet another leader with a few scenarios that I will never play. Not sure if they're actually oblivious to their player base or are outright insulting us.I regret purchasing this game, especially as a deluxe edition; for which I was hoping to receive proper expansion packs, as opposed to a few extra civilizations that I could not care any less about because they don't really add anything to the game. All in all, Civ VI is a grave disappointment and from the looks of it will remain to be just that.They should have just given Civ5 a slight UI facelift, worked on its performance and on making the AI a little more believable (Really just for the case of you protecting a small civilization throughout history, them having maybe 5% of your size tops and yet declare war on you? Please, I'd love to understand their suicidal reasoning.) - Anyway, that I would have gladly paid for.I'm also still waiting for the trivial option to have the game show the actual event probabilities! The devs may think they are doing players a favor showing us 33% when it's really 50% or 90% when it really is 100% and provide an artificially even distribution of events, but that initial feeling of "nice, I still made it" lasts exactly a few battles before you realize that the game thinks you're stupid.

title: Recommended
comment: Masterpiece of turn based strategy gamesCivilization 6 includes mostly same game mechanics than its predecessor Civ 5 but goes beyond in many ways. New district systems makes city planning more versatile and challenging. Great people and religion mechanics are enhanced since Civ 5 significantly. Changes in combat system make wars even more tactical and encourages to fast turn by turn planned battles. User interface is mostly good, especially I am pleased with clearly visible unit icons. Only bigger flaw I see in diplomacy and leaders’ agenda system that is one-dimensional and often inconsistent, but I think that it will be improved and balanced in future expansion packs for the game.

title: Recommended
comment: A fun game to play with friends or to play on your own. Each game can take a long time so if you aren't into games like that then this isn't the game for you, but if you have enjoyed the other civilization games or like games in this genre it is a good one to pick up; especially when it is on sale.

title: Not Recommended
comment: a nice game but the AI sucks really bad. Why is it not possible to implement in a turn based strategy game a reasonable acting KI???!!!It is not really fun to overrun after a while the CPU because military is ages behind or not existent. Could be the best turn based game ever.

title: Recommended
comment: Fan ♥♥♥♥ing tastic. What do you want? its good ole civ with a lot of new fun things. and best of all, it washes the stains of beyond earth out.I love it. No glitches, bugs or lag here. Smooth max graphics gameplay.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game made me want to play Civ 5. it was the little things . the icons are very basic ... i liked the detail in 5 much better . it is an over complicated 5 done on the cheap with regards to graphics.

title: Not Recommended
comment: jan. 2nd - 17this is a game very close to a full reccommendation. in the beginning hours you are glued to your computer, the "just one more turn" philosophy in these games are as present as ever. smart changes such as the road system has been inplemented and builders now create tile improvements instantly while now having limitided uses instead. this creates new options for optimizations of your empire. one major thing holds this title back though. its the AI. both in terms of combat and diplomacy. the ai will declare random wars and denounce you galore, but unless you are really far behind it it doesnt even try to mount attacks, and if you yourself takes one of their cities, everyone will think you are a warmonger aand denounces you, even though you were the defenderthis leads to later games where everyone hates you, but it takes nothing to defeat them since you can sit back and declare a ceasefire after x amount of turns without the enemy even having touched your borders. making allies in this is tough and not even usefull since they are so inactive anyways.your first impressions are gonna be great, but this shortcoming is propably gonna ruin it for you after 20 or so hourse, when you start to seee these things.that being said. everything else just works and it feels like, in terms of features that this game has already had the content from the civ 5 expansions packed into it. so the foundation is good and i would dare say that when firaxis finally decides to get the AI to work this will be one, if not THE finest vanilla civ game to date. untill then though, go play civ 5 with the expansions and you have a better product there, purely because the AI works there. then check back later and you can propalby grab this for a lot less by then for a product you can enjoy not just in the beginning, but to turn 5000 aswell.would really have liked to reccommend this. is odd how a game can be so close to perfection and yet so broken because of one thng.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Can't recommend for Linux players. Unless you like playing alone. No Linux/Windows cross-platform support. Otherwise ok.

title: Recommended
comment: Now that I can finally name my cities (Isla Truffles, Xi'an Famous Foods, Dad's House), my enjoyment of this game has gone up by at least 8%.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 478 hours on Civ 5 vs. 128 I racked up on this title should tell you which one to buy. At full price Civ 6 is no where near worth it and I can get bored of games quickly. You can still have fun, don't get me wrong (seeing as how I still managed to get 128 hrs). However, Firaxis is as greedy and inept as big studios come, charging a fraudulent $30 for DLC that does not contain anywhere near $30 of content. If you must buy this at full price really take a long think about it first. I would suggest getting the full Civ 5 bundle (all the DLC) when it's on sale for a few bucks, it's totally worth it.Summary: I do NOT recommend this game at full price. If the price comes down, yeah you can probably get plenty of hours out of it. Choice between 5 and 6? Get 5 bundle on sale.Good:-New concepts (districts)-Policy card system is not a new idea but the implementation of the separate culture tree is interesting-SMOOTH gameplay that is less buggy than Civ 5-Multiplayer works MUCH better than in 5-Graphics - if you like ths style.Bad:-Feels like a lot of content is missing (hello world congress?)-AI is still utter garbage (lazy devs not wanting to fix it)-Gameplay sometimes feels restrictive, feels like I have less options than in Civ 5 where there were more unusual but possible strategies-No proper modding tools for more specialized mods like Civ 5's IGE-Base UI is bad-Firaxis is slow and unresponsive to issues (as a full release title do not expect frequent patches or bug fixes)

title: Recommended
comment: Contrary to what you might hear, this game is an improvement on Civ 5. The gameplay is more varied, there's more to do during a game, there are better incentives, more paths to take, more difficult choices and so on. I do believe it's genuinely more exciting than it was before. There is definitely a lot of work to be done, but as it stands, it's about on par with Civ 5 complete on the gameplay side of things.With Rise and Fall coming soon, and looking to be a huge step forward, with many gameplay complexities that layer nicely on top of what we already have, it should make for a much more advanced, yet enjoyable Civ.The problems I have with the game, are the frequent crashes and the poor performance. I run an Nvidia gtx 1080 and an AMD Ryzen 1700x and it struggles on max settings in the late game. It's a nice looking map, but reasonably low poly and the background processes should only benefit from an 8 core 3.4ghz processor. It dips to 40fps and you can see the game struggle as you pan across the map.More pressing are the crashes. Playing a single game on prince and standard speed with 6 AI, it has crashed 3 times already and I'm about 70% along the science tree. The crashes can happen at any time, for whatever reason. Just started a map? No problem, here's a crash. Released a nuke, certian that victory is yours? Nope, here's a crash. Funnily enough, the IOS version hasn't crashed on me once and development for that has been outsourced. Firaxis, up your game just a bit please.I feel like I have to address the AI, because it is the most talked about thing when it comes to this game. Yes, the AI is temperamental, yes they are hard to please, but no, they aren't (completely) broken. Having watched a fair bit of gameplay on Youtube to properly understand the game before I dived in, you can see the amount of hoop jumping you may have to do to please a neighbouring nation. The game is intricate and the rules of the game are hefty. You can't just throw money at an AI and think that's enough. You need to understand what they're after first, their leaders needs and how they function, where their placement is on the map, why they would need a certian luxury, what research they may or may not have, sending a scout to see their buildings, etc.Fair enough to that time where that AI was outrageously aggressive towards you, but an overhaul risks a complete dumb down of an intricate system that should be worth it in the end. If you can trust that Firxis will get this right eventually (and there is every chance they can, considering their track record of releasing bug ridden games that become masterpieces) then there is no need to panic, claim sacrilege, cry and everything else I've seen grown adults do over this game.I recommend this game now, if money doesn't mean much to you right now, you like 4X strategies and you don't mind some crashes and gameplay inaccuracies for the time being.Otherwise, wait until everyone changes their tone and for their sake, try to act surprised.

title: Recommended
comment: Not as great as civ 5 - If this is one sale though buy it!

title: Recommended
comment: From the three hours I have played so far, this game may even surpass Civ 5 and 4. I thought I was going to be bothered by the new art style, but it looks great. Like anything else, the menues and interface take a few minutes to get used to, but thats not necessarily a bad thing. So far, the diplomacy and AI is the biggest improvement to me. Highly recomended, I predict I will log hundreds of hours.

title: Recommended
comment: Rise and Fall is a fantastic expansion. I left a more in-depth review on the expansion page itself explaining why I enjoyed it. The basic idea boils down to the fact that if you enjoy civilization and want something new you'll enjoy this installment.I don't quit get all the review bombing but I might be biased for it after 190 hours. I have almost 500 in Civilization 5 (+Expansions) and I enjoyed that game too.(Honestly I'm just happy Global Happiness is gone lol.)

title: Not Recommended
comment: Dec 22, 2016:The game is a fine addition to the line but it seems to be changing it's business model. First two DLC are both 5 dollars, and together they equal up to 1 new civ and a few scenarios.So they seem to be switching to a business model usually reserved for train simulators and sports games. I hope they'll realize quickly that Civ fans are far more discerning than the usual sports game crowd and stop trying to sap us for every penny they can. It's insulting. If I buy the season pass, I want Gods and Kings and Brave New World.If the game turns into a series of microtransactions, and I have to shell out hundreds of dollars for the game and all its DLC, I will abandon it in a heartbeat. Which will make me sad because it's easily my favorite game.July 21, 2017:I've given it the better part of a year now and still no sign of it getting better. There's still no World Congress. Which means the game still isn't even up to par with Civ 5. If it doesn't get it's act together, I'm poised to declare it the biggest let-down in gaming history. Worst disappointment for me so far. I desperately hope they make up for it with the first big DLC release. But if no such DLC is forthcoming soon, I give up. :-(

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have played every single game in the Civilization series, from Civilization 1 onwards and loved every game.this version is very much like Civ 5 but it has some cool improvements, the gameplay is good - however there is a GAME BREAKING BUG that currupts your game and makes the game crash every single time you reach a certain turn and there is no fix. I'm more than a little irritated that after spending well over 10 hours going through around 300 turns, the game keeps crashing for no reason at all every time I press next turn (on the same turn each time)Its very frustrating that there is no way I can complete the game which I invested a lot of time into and was enjoying, Outside of this bug, i'd reccomend the game highly albeit that it seems far too expensive for what it is.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Kinda good when it works. I'll get very far into a game, and then certain actions crash the game like clockwork. Reloading my saves and repeating my move crashes the game. Hoping that this is fixed sooner rather than later or I'll have to stop playing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game itself is excellent. The changes over the previous version are well thought through and there's enough core gameplay and civilisations to not need any expansions. However, there is currently a gamebreaking bug that causes games to be impossible to finish. Sometimes it happens early on, other times late into the game - the result is the same: you have to start a new game. There are numerous topics on the issue, so it's widespread.Until the gamebreaking bugs are fixed I cannot recommend this game.

title: Not Recommended

That is, if all your fellow players havent quit by then. AI is atrocious so single player is a bore. I love the Civ series but it has become unplayable.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Not worth buying, the game is still alpha-like, very buggy and unpolished.The gameplay is not fun, the IA behaves very randomly (again), the barbarians are always raging, no matter the choices you made at game start. Building an army or a simple spy takes ages, no matter how many production cogs you have. The progression feels like walking in a swamp, mostly at the game start and the late game.The addition of districts helps focusing cities in production, science, religion, culture, money or military, but feels unfinished and impractical. Adjacency bonuses are ridiculously low.The new fog-of-war system is annoying at best, and the required system specs to run the game is an insult. Come on! it's a turn based game! Somebody at the developement team didn't realize that yet.The only good thing I find about the game is the impossibility to have a wonder grabbing player, although benefits from each wonder are very reduced compared to previous iterations of the game.My overall opinion is that they could have invested the time and money making another Civ V extension instead this blushingly shameful "Endless Legend" copycat.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Multiplayer was the main reason I bought this game and it worked fine for one day then all of a sudden me and a friend of mine keep getting disconnected constantly. We had to setup Tunngle to simulate a LAN game to play it. For the ammount of cash you are charged this sort of thing should just work. Also no Co-op mode although it says it has one right here on the store page. Until these multiplayer issues are fixed I can not recommend this game.Single player is alright although it could do with some improvement such as a much, much, much, slower pace (even in marathon) during mid - late game eras. Missionaries and other religious units can wander in and out of your country at will which doesn't make sense. They should respect open/closed border deals as any other unit in the game. title: Not Recommended
comment: A poor, almost amateur, rendition of a AAA game. This game continues the trend of the popular Civilization series to coast on popularity and good looks, pouring a large budget into game assets while ignoring the AI. Despite its importance in a single player strategy game, the AI continues to get stupider with Civilization VI. Not only is the AI essentially broken, the game design is fundamentally flawed as it turns the playing experience into an exercise in micromanagement that is difficult to balance and is a nightmare to write AI for. This micromanagement serves to distract the player from the game's shortcomings: it is a single player strategy game with a hopelessly incompetent AI and poor game balance. After playing every game in the series, it is sad to see it develop like this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Originally owned this for Mac, purchased a new ASUS Strix blah blah blah laptop. Can't get past the loading screen, freezes everytime to the point where I have to restart my computer.Added steam and the game to Windows 10 Defender Exclusion List, Disabled Defender in the registry, Turned off real time monitoring, reinstalled windows, reinstalled the game multiple times, did everything I could find online, yet I am left with a broken game.So, If you somehow become one of the most unluckiest purchasers like me, stay away. But, if you're like the 99.9% of people who can actually play the game they purchased, then hey! good for you, its a great game.Thanks windows. Thanks Sid Meier'sI will never purchase anything from you guys again... coming from a guy whos invested thousands of hours in your previous games.

title: Recommended
comment: I've started playing civ with the second game. I like the changes in this game. The nations have great bonus traits. Give it a try with an open mind and not a biased one from previous games. Almost everything from civ 5 is there, and this is only the core game, without addons or dlc.If you like 4x games, civ and turn based games, this game is for you!
