title: Not Recommended
comment: This one's killed the series for me. Somehow they've taken the "Just one more turn!" feel and replaced it with a little sigh as you hit the end turn button again.I think starting up my first map sums it up. I went into the settings before starting and selected "New to Civ 6" instead of "New to Civ series"... Started up my first map, and it asked me was I new to Civ 6, or the Civ series? :/ And the tips that choice relates to have popped up every session so far, giving me a minute or so of tips every time I end my next turn after returning to the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Short note, I will make this review as detailed as I can, but since I got bored very quickly, I can't go too in depth.Overall Experience: I came into this super exited with all the new features it was going to have, I liked the new District system, and I was looking forward to it. I was a little on edge about the graphics style, but it eventually grew on me. When I bought the game I started it up, then played about 20 minutes before getting bored. I would say this is because I have a short attention span for games like this, but this is not the case, as you can see I played around 115 Hours in Civ 5 and have played around 330 hours in HOI4 and around 400 In EU4. This game to me is just boring, it doesn't have the same smoothness and charm Civ 5 had in it's interface, and I quickly found out that diplomacy is useless. Civ 5 had a very simple diplomacy system, but at least it worked. The Devs pushed the "Secret Agendas" as neat things, and in theory they are, but in practice? Not so much. If you aren't fufiling a nation's secret agenda, they are never going to ally you, and they will most likely denounce you then go to war. The AI is very fickle so even if you make an ally, there's no telling how long it will last. Lastly, Trade deals will never go in your favor, so don't even bother. Other than that, the Districts mechanic is great, and can make more spread out cities, unlike the rather condensed feeling cities of Civ 5.Pros and ConsPros:-Districts are a nice edition-City State interactions work well-Religious victory has been reintroduced, and isn't overpowered like it was in Civ 4-Other More Minor ThingsCons-Diplomacy is for the most part useless-Gets boring (Might just be me, but It's worth noting.)-Continents can be weird (Especially when dealing with Britain)-Secret AgendasTLDR; I got bored of it, tried playing it again, was still bored. Diplomacy is useless

title: Recommended
comment: do not expect it is as good as civ 5 (for now), since civ 5 got all those DLC and balance changes, and civ 6 is just getting its first major DLC, but overall, civ 5 and civ 6 got some different play style. If you wish to get a game better than civ 5, wait for the final edition, or, u can just grab it now, its your wallet :p

title: Recommended
comment: I've played Civilization since the original back in the day... and each iteration has something new to offer. Civiziation VI: Rise and Fall is outstanding! It provides much more depth than the base Civ VI and adds to the "every game is different" style of play. This game provides several different strategies to try and due the custimization options setting up your game, there is an almost unlimited style to play each new game.I recommend this game to everyone.

title: Recommended
comment: Diplomacy feels improved over previous versions. City management has an interesting added complexity with specialized districts. I like the more flexible and frequent civic advancements.Not sure why so many people have put this iteration down. I'm regretting having listened to all of the negative reviews and am ready to move on from Civ V.

title: Recommended
comment: This game takes us back to how CIV was and always has been. They have added some excellent new features. Graphics are amazing, and interface has definetly changed. I have only played alittle and havent played in year, but I really am enjoying my time with CIV.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Multiplayer was the main reason I bought this game and it worked fine for one day then all of a sudden me and a friend of mine keep getting disconnected constantly. We had to setup Tunngle to simulate a LAN game to play it. For the ammount of cash you are charged this sort of thing should just work. Also no Co-op mode although it says it has one right here on the store page. Until these multiplayer issues are fixed I can not recommend this game.Single player is alright although it could do with some improvement such as a much, much, much, slower pace (even in marathon) during mid - late game eras. Missionaries and other religious units can wander in and out of your country at will which doesn't make sense. They should respect open/closed border deals as any other unit in the game. AI city states need to stop spamming the map with units. Enough of the warriors already! Diplomacy is pointless and the AI inconsistent. For example I've found that the peace loving Ghandi himself is the most warmongering persona in the game. Constantly declaring war on you out of the blue even if you had a high friendly status with him.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I bought this game as soon as it came out and was entirely disappointed. There were so many bugs that it made the game difficult and frustrating. Alliances as we knew them in previous Civ Rev games are gone. The diplomatic options in this game are difficult to understand or they simply do not work and the AI is way too unpredictable. The game is also boring! I loved the scenario game modes in past civ rev games (like WWII in Europe in Civ Rev 4) but the scenarios in this game are... non-existent? How long do we have to wait (and how much do we have to pay) before this game becomes good? It has been over a year!!Religion is a waste of time and space in the game. I have 4-6 missionaries surrounding my cities and it is extremely annoying.It is also incredibly frustrating to learn that they are making many fixes to the game but... it will cost $30. Why do this to loyal players like me? (I have bought the last 3 Civ Rev games upon their release) Do they not want us to buy the game until they offer DLC fixes?

title: Not Recommended
comment: All around ok game, But gunna give this thing a negative as the game specifically screws you out of building wonders. I noticed that every time I was 1 turn from completing a midevil or classic wonder, some other turd civ would just then complete it. It became a regular thing as I have played this game, so I decided to run an exeriment.For example. I selected the french to get the initial wonders build bonus. then I left and created games until I got an ideal location for lots of production and food. I ran this experiment 3 times to get my production as high as possible, while having enough food to grow quick. each time i got within 1 turn of finishing and the computer would beat me.Then i made a 1v1 map, and found the civ quick with the same set up. It didnt take long to find him building a district as I built the stonehenge wonder. somehow this turd, whom was not even building stonehenge, completed it the turn before I did yet again.I dont know if Sid does this to make the game harder or just to annoy its fans. Maybe there is a bet to see how much annoying crap they can put into the games before people quit.I for one have simple switch to the "let the others build your wonders then murder those fools and take it" approach. I suppose this is the more realistic method. Maybe that is the leason Sid is aiming for.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Um porcaria de jogo!Graficos pouco atractivos e muito lentos. Pesado demais para o meu i7.A jogabilidade também está fraca.Desde o CIV4, que as versões pioram.Desaconselho.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In many ways its a step back from Civ 5 in terms of features and UI, but the base is stronger. With AI being broken and UI being frustratingly bad, I don't recommend playing this. You will finish a majority of a game and realize you've only played yourself.Wait a year for Firaxis to fix this disappointment. This is not "Best Strategy Game of the Year" material YET.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ 6 has a lot of new and interesting stuff, tons of new ideas. And I welcome everything, it feels more complex than ciV. But at the moment everything is ruined by a moronic AI: it can't fight, can't build districts properly etc.I highly recommend waiting for them to fix AI, and only then consider paying for this!p.s. my wasted 60$ made me write this

title: Not Recommended
comment: If you are a fan of Civilization V then this game is not for you. It will leave you feeling very frustated and you will rage quit many times. It's as if the development team didn't bring any quality of life from V into the new game.I was looking forward to this game for so long and it's very dissapointing. Hopefully they patch it without charging for it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is NOT as good as Civ5.The User Interface in-game is TERRIBLE! Vastly inferiour to Civ5's interface.The AI behaves weirdly and is not as responsive as in Civ5.Now it's not all bad. The cosmetic features like the map's apperance, unit stacking and city building are much better.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In its current form, I cannot recommend this game. I want to, but I can't. There are just so many little annoyances that continue to add up until a game just isn't enjoyable unless you want to go for a domination victory with everyone hating you from the start, and even then its a push. Initially, it seemed great and after waiting so long for an actual successor to Civ 5 I was delighted, however the longer you play the game the more and more obvious issues got.Big negatives for me are:- AI - every game seems to choose to annoy you rather than play tactically. every trade deal was only a deal to the other nation, you could never get a favourable deal, or even a like for like swap in most instances like in Civ 5. If you are doing better than another nation, they will denounce you. Everytime. Without fail. Not only that but nations will go way out of their way, nearly half the map in one instance, to settle a new land beside you to box you in. This, coupled with not being able to ask nations to not settle near you until after they already had, meant that to expand you had one choice. war. Which leads to the next problem...- War- this probably annoyed me most of all. There are now lots of different types of wars, each which add a little more diversity to how you conduct yourself around other nations. Surprise wars will gain you large warmongering penalties, but really these don't matter. If you have any warmongering penalty, everyone will treat you like an insane war lover. Even the nations that declared war on you and that you only fought back. If you are lucky enough to not have to fight them, rare but happened to me a few times, they will ask for peace, and throw resources and gold at you to accept. This happened to me quite alot, with nations going to war with me and after not even seeing one of their units, they would ask for peace and give me all their gold. While this was nice, it did end uip making the game very easy for a while, until everyone denounced me for warmongering.- Barbarians - unlike Civ 5, it appears raging barbarians (were barbarian units and camps will spawn alot quicker) is always on. ths means that early game, especially on larger maps, you have to spend alot more of your time, building up an army to tackle the problem, as they will not relent in attempting to attack your cities and units. also, they will be more technologically advanced than you. making it very annoying trying to combat a couple of freshly spawned barbarian units that are oikemen while you only have warriors. If this was intentional, then fair enough, however the large amount of troops you need has another consequence. Nations will fear you, and then denounce you. meaning that any attempt to brefriend them is gone before you even had a chance to make it work.Other than the above, I have had a few issues withcrashes changing civics policies later in the game, but I imagine these will be addressed sooner rather than later.Hopefully, after another patch or this will become the game it has the potential to be, but at the moment, that looks a long way off...

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just terrible. Ugly. Sluggish. Cumbersome. Not ready for prime time. To add insult to injury, after only 5 hours of gameplay (basically the time it takes to work through the tutorial), I can't get a refund from Steam. This has been a supremely awful experience. Beware!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ VI was the opportunity to revise and refine the AI, war, and what would drive opinion in the game. Sadly, Civ VI takes three steps backward. Other Civs denounce you if: you build more wonders than them or build fewer, succeed against them in war or fail, have fewer spies than them or more, expand too much or too little. There seems to be no way to earn or keep allies in this game. Hopefully in expansions to this game, the programmers will realize that warmongering is not a zero sum game and focus more on the declaration of war vs. who actually wins that war as a penalty on the player.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm just not sure what it is but I just can't get into this game the same way I did Civ 5. I've only played a few hours of it so far but in all honesty that's all I really wanted to play when a much better experience in Civ 5 was still wating for me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really want to like this game because it's got plenty of potential for greatness, but Firaxis is very slow to patch bugs, and they often break old features when introducing new ones. Fundamental gameplay was recently broken with their Rise & Fall update, and they have yet to fix it.

title: Recommended
comment: Great game! This is a high quality game for sure. I don't know why other people are complaining, the game is fantastic.First time I played I sat down 12 hours straight vs A.I.I have nothing else to say. Game is good.

title: Recommended
comment: Still in my first two paralell playthroughs, but the CIV feeling is there again. The unstacking of the cities and the split of the science tree (incl. the Inspireation/Heureka moments) are great concepts that have increased the amount of decision making and thus the immersion into the game for me.On the downside I have to admit I do not find the AI overly challenging and plus the tech speed in relation to the production output requires IMHO a re-balance, but this is not impacting my fun with the game.Again really happy with the new Civ and looking forward now to the first patches and DLCs.

title: Recommended
comment: One step forward two steps back. Graphics and new content are great. No Scrolling makes it harder to navigate the map. Does not tell where Barbarians are anymore and Barbarian Notification is iffy at best. Spies but nothing for them to do. Advisor will make you look bug eyed after a while. units that need assignments will really make you curse. Many times I was working on a war when a builder on the other side of the map got my attention. Funny thing is that the unit I had originally selected was still needing orders. Jumping from one unit to the next would be fine if first you would let me give the unit I have selected orders before you jump. Second Jumping real fast from one to another without giving me a chance to order one around is stupid.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I received a copy of version five for Christmas and have logged an insane number of very enjoyable hours playing it. When version six came out on humble bundle I couldn’t resist signing up for it. From the first time I loaded it I was unimpressed. The cartoon like animations were cute and the visuals are admittedly better the version five but there are some glaring problems and uncanny bugs that will have stopped me from even trying to go any further.1. First and foremost in my mind is the ridiculous user interface. The color combinations and text size seem to have been designed to make reading anything as difficult as possible. The box that pulls up when you click on a city or a character uses brown text on a brown background and green text on a green background as well as text that is so small that it requires me to put on my reading glasses and get right next to the screen. Compared to the crisp and legible interface on version five this is a huge disappointment.2. Along the same line both the character screen and the city screen switch sizes after a couple on moves and the bottom part is no longer visible on the screen. I thought it was an over scan problem with my monitor but it does the same thing in windowed mode so it’s a software bug.3. There is something very wrong with the AI running the barbarians, on my second try I had three horse mounted units show up and the stuck around for over thirty moves crippling any chance for a good start.4. The AI for the German group was allowed to spawn eight cities by move 100. He started on the far left on the map and spawned cities the minimum distance apart in a straight line towards my initial city.At this point I gave up, I was playing as Roosevelt with the difficulty set to prince.

title: Recommended
comment: I had many concerns about this game before release, starting with the change in art style, getting rid of global hapiness all the way through ridiculously low level of AI as seen on the pre-release streams. Most of these concerns were gone around one hour into the gameplay and I absolutely love it. It's a brand new take on civilization games and with each era progression I'm more amazed and curious how much more things did the developers add to the gameplay.Sure, AI feels a bit clunky and either is 'too aggresive' early on or very passive and just not up-to-date when it comes to maintaining a army. It's not THAT BAD though as I thought it'd be. Barbarians have been improved upon as they can be a real threat if you are not careful with your surroundings.There are many smaller bugs but it's something that can be easily fixed in a patch, if you played civ5 vanilla you should remember how bad it was. Civ6 is way better in that area, plus it has more content and features than civ5 with all DLCs which is a good sign.TL;DR:Overall: 9/10.+ No more tech beelining and doing tradition->rationalism in civics tree+ Nice split of science tech and cultural developments into separate trees+ Government system!+ Each game feels truly different because so much depends on the area you are in and the environment around you+ Loads of new and old-but-improved features that make the gameplay just awesome+ Playing wide is more than viable baby+ Super addictive (#OneMoreTurn)+ Pretty smooth UI+ Looks great (Getting used to the art style takes some minutes)+ Music, Sean Bean quotes and tons of other stuff- AI needs definitely some work- Lack of city rename feature :D- Less number of units in a unit upgrade line. Roman Legion -> Musketman, wtf?- Minimap looks terrible and is very hard to read. It's practically useless- Small UI and gameplay bugs that popup from time to time- Playing on a high end PC, time between turns can take quite a while on bigger maps.

title: Recommended
comment: Normally, I would wait to pen a review, but this game is simply that good. Virtually every system is improved on its own and now most are more interconnected than ever. Ever stage of the game feels like a competition - a very good thing. The two most impressive changes are to the cities and the tech trees: namely splitting them all up into more distinct parts. The tech tree has been streamlined by moving many important innovations into one culture-based civics tree, and the cities now have specielized districts which house most of the most important buildings. Gone are the days of almost entirely neglecting science or culture for the other.Gone, too, are the military slogs of Civ V. Now, the decision to get rid of Civ IV's "stacks of doom" in Civ V really makes sense. Instead, to ease congestion and add strategic and tactical depth, units can stack in various formations which become more useful as the game progresses. With this ability and a wider array of units overall, wars feel much more realistic. Unless your goal is to utterly crush an even matched foe 300-year-long wars are rare. The combat is entertaining in every era.If I had one criticism, it may be reserved for the victories, namely the Religious Victory. In the one game played to completion so far, Norway managed to sneak a religious victory past my American culture without even clearly meeting the express conditions because only one other civ of six even tried to hold out. Did Scythia have an extra city I didn't know about or is the majority status based on population? This I do not know and could not have known - very annoying when intentionally playing for a true late game victory. My new rule until a change is made is to immediately destroy any civ which overwhelms another civ's religion with its own. Otherwise, it's a great game which already has my vote for the best in the series.....And for those who complain about the art style - Why so serious? ;)

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's addicting, but I feel like it could be a lot better. There are many things to be desired with this game and I think that holds it back. I saw the DLC and it just adds some different civs. Very dissapointing. Be more creative please.I cannot reccomend this game due to the high number of bugs I experienced while playing this game. It feels rushed. It's definitly a fun game, but only if you can ignore broken UI, crashes, non responsivness and many others.

title: Not Recommended
comment: New Mac update (1.0.1) sucks, it crashes a loooooooooooot. I cannot continue playing the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Nothing more to say

title: Not Recommended
comment: I love Civ V. Civ VI... the game does not play... (works better in french as a pun).

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've played this game for less than an hour and the game has crashed twice; not hardware issues either. The only time I've experienced crashes from a game like this was from games in Alpha development. This game is considered a finished game. The first time was random during a singleplayer game, and the second time was after I had to restart my computer to close the game; when I opened the game again I went to change the resolution in the game menu and it crashed again. Please optimize your game. I will not be able to recommend this game until simple things like this are fixed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is put together very well, has very few bugs, and has a nice appearance. It's an armchair game that you can play with just the mouse.After playing this game for awhile there really is very little challenge to the single player game because the computer opponents won't attack you unless you go out of your way to make them mad and if they do they don't use tactics and are easily defeated. It ends up just being an economic game (which is just clicking and clicking the mouse for hours on end. More importantly, and the biggest failure, (researching technologies is a big part of the game) and you really don't feel like your research decisions make a difference.Overall, it's plain to see that the optimization towards multiplayer and tablet play has sucked the life out of what could be an amazing game. Just too much clicking and not enough challenge due to a 'dumb' AI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: With most PC games pre-publication development is divided into an Alpha and a Beta stage. When it comes to the Civilization series, there is a third gestation period; the Gamma stage if you will. This covers the period between the official game launch and the inevitable release of the two expansions that will properly flesh out and re-balance a good game and make it great and add enough new content to come within a couple of miles of justifying the added cost.If you are a big fan of turned-based strategy games and money is no object or you like being in on this third larval stage, then Civilization VI is a smart purchase right now. Otherwise, exercise some restraint and wait for the total package. If you have and still enjoy any of the older Civilization titles, keep playing them. If you don't have them, buy now and discover the many pleasures of this wonderful series.In a year or so, Civ VI will be genuinely complete and available at a reasonable price and the Gamma version of Civ VII will be on the horizon.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am not sure if there is a game out there that has a bigger discrepancy between the professional reviewers and the game-buying public. I am old enough to have been playing Civilization since the first incarnation and can say that Civ VI is by far the worst. It is the only Civ game that I actively dislike. Many reviewers have gone into great detail on the issues with the game; I would agree with most of these negative reviews. The biggest problem is the completely schizophrenic AI. Other leaders love/hate you for indiscernable reasons and often in back-to-back turns. Defending yourself gets you labeled a warmonger. In general the diplomacy function is not "deep" but rather just random. Disappointing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So there we are: Civilization VIAs a player who played Civ V for more than 700 hrs I must say I'm not quite sure about this game. It`s missing something magical like Civ V had it. Of course its "style" has been updated quite well, but is this really the way to go? In my opinion not. But you have a couple of more opportunities than back in five. And you have the DLC section as well which is mostly disliked by the community of its game. So I would say this game is a step further than five but definitely needs to improve and I`m not sure if the price is worth it. If you`re not sure if you should buy this game, go ahead ask your friends what they like at this game and get some impressions by reviews and videos.For me this game is not worth paying the full price and especially not playing it for more than 100hrs. Go buy Civ V for a cheaper price and be happy :).

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is a very disappointing game. It's a huge leap backwards from civilization 5, if you have and enjoy Civ 5 don't bother with this, if you don't have Civ 5 then get that instead.I'm just frustrated with the simple things that are missing or broken in this game.For a premium priced game, it just doesn't deliver. Lots of people will tell you things will be added and fixed and modded in time, and that may be so but for £50 i expected an improvement.There are some real game breaking bugs too, once you get the game to start (after figuring our which of the many ways it might fail to start affects you) you can be all the way to the late game before realizing a short war has left your cities crippled because war weariness doesn't go away when it should, it increases. Game ruined. This is one of many bugs you can enjoy if you stump up the premium price for this game now.Firaxis should be embarrassed at releasing this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In the current state - I would advise not to purchase the game. This will no doubt change after the game is patched. Currently, a number of game-breaking bugs exist that essentially render the game unplayable for myself, even on a machine that exceeds the recommended specs. A real shame as the gameplay mechanics are solid and I felt like this release is progress in the right direction forthe Civ series.

title: Not Recommended
comment: v.1.1Before we begin, I would like to make a note that this review is not a standing stone - it might change in both depth and final grade because of patches, updates, dlc, etc.I play this game since Civilization 1, and had certain expectations from this game, which unfortunately have not been met... yet. But this is a different story, because for now you want to know why this review goes against a mainstream - why cannot I recommend it?1. Unfinished / unpolished product. I was afraid of this most, "for this has never happened before, and here we go again..." The game is not only half-finished - in fact, it also misses some key and significant things which ALL previous civilizations had always been proud of, such as:- NO STEAMWORK- 0 scenarios (all previous games contained some scenarios in vanilla games),- 0 maps other than computer generated ones, it does not even have a simple Earth map to start with (even Civilization 1 had it).- can rename a religion - which is a bad thing in mp- though cannot rename your country or cities (which is very strange)- no auto work function for builders- no alert button for units- the game makes it clear from the start what future DLC will contain (which in my opinion is an insult to players considering the $ 80 price tag for vanilla game)Of course, many of those things will be fixed by modders sooner or later - but that would be a different game, why should Firaxis get a credit for the things they were lazy to implement on their own in vanilla game?2. AI. Lots of advertisements pointed out to the improved AI. I have not seen it, for I only see some scripted personalities which predictably react in certain way. In other words, there have been no significant improvement here:- AI still makes similar stupid mistakes as in Civilization 5 - for example, exploring with its own settlers, building cities in illogical places, having no tactics against a player other than sending waves of enemies until being defeated.- Adding to all that, AI does not know how upgrade its own troops, so you may end up in situations where you see chariots, archers, etc. accompanied by submarines... This might look funny but when it happens over and over the game not only loses immersion but also some logic.- Like in previous games, AI still spams player with useless offers, praises and denounces3. Multiplayer. I must admit that there is a big improvement here compared to civilization 5; however, it is far from being ideal. Desyncs, crashes happen very often, mp games are still very slow, especially at late game (wait times before player turns are unusually long). Also I do not understand why the game "does not officially support" more than 8 players in multiplayer (you need to manually unlock it) - even though we managed to play with 10 players, the fact that game says it is a bad sign as it only adds to what I said in point 1 about unfinished product.4. Although the district / Wonders placement is interesting in theory - it has many issues in practice which only make life harder for players (which is especially the case in mp). Thus, when the game starts, you can only guess which tiles might later be useful (where is oil, iron, etc.) - so you start building districts, Wonders, and then in late game you realize that (1) you have no room for new more districts or Wonders (if you play on small islands map, this is a big problem), (2) the above mentioned tiles contained some useful resources which now lost forever.- This would be not a big problem - (a) If the AI was in same circumstances - but unfortunately AI always know where to build due to scripts, (b) If the resources could be obtained by having Wonders on it, or (c) If the districts or Wonders could be transferred to other tiles. Now, keep in mind that you cannot remove your districts or Wonders, even if try to build it once but in few turns decide to build something else - you will be stuck with cosntruction on this tile forever.- Unfortunately, all this makes Wonders a bit useless, especially if you play an island game - where every tile might make a difference. So, I think the game will improve if players would be allowed to build Wonders in districts (for example, 1 Wonder per corresponding district) - this would greatly conserve the space on the map and simply make the map look better.- Another problem with Wonders is that sometimes they look weird - I understand some Wonders like Pyramids or Colossus must be built outside of the city but why cannot Eifel Tower, Big Ben, etc. be built in the City Centers, which is the case in real life? Also, why do they need to look bigger than an actual city on the map?There are also some bugs and mp glitches which I do not want to talk about for now - I will give developers an opportunity to fix them, for we know that they know about it - they did test a game after all, am I right?So, at its current stage the game deserves 6.0 out of 10.

title: Recommended
comment: The game is good, the AI was quite a warmongering mess at launch but has been patched rather well by now.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Poor ai made me return the game.

title: Recommended
comment: Tbh, I purchased this game buz of the summer sale. I wanted to just play about 2 hours buz I needed to sleep earlier for tmr. But time flies when you're having fun, I didn't stop until I found out the sky is already very bright in the morning. I get addicted to this game, maybe it's just buz of I never played any games of the series. But I truly think this game is fun to play. It's just my opinion.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A bit of a buggy mess. Works fine for some, not at all for others. It seems to be a gamble as to wether or not your system can run it and if it can't it seems to be a bit of a toss-up as to wether or not any of the fixes I've been able to find will actually work for you.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It is getting a negative vote just to counter the hype.It is the most dumbed down version of the game i have played. And i have been playing since Civ 1. Ofcourse earlier Civs are seen in the context of the year they were made.Unhappiness is not a thing anymore. Cover the entire map with cities. No problem.Steamrolling the map is easy now. No more massive unhapiness penalties or need to create puppet states. You can just keep every single city you conquer. No penalties.Developing science and civics is incredible easy with the boost system. Also no penalties for number of cities.All in all you can have 100 cities and there is no penalties or difficulty of running such a huge empire.Information menus are gone or poorly made. List of military units? The list of your cities can't be sorted by production, science, or whatever. So when you hit 20+ cities get ready to micromanage for 10 minutes every turn. Also no more auto-production.Overall information on anything is bad or non existant.Districts are a gimmick. They dont make the game harder or immersive. They just make you trade off a resource tile to put buildings on. Improving and exploiting resources is still important. Builders (workers) that disapear after they have done their number of upgrades is dumb.Everything is streamlined, science, civics, city states, so there are no major trade-offs to consider anymore. Everything has their separate resource and function to make it easy (and boring). Government cards is the worse idea ever. Havent dozens of cards and being able to use 4 or 5...AI is the typical launch garbage. Diplomacy is bad as usual. Combat AI is terrible. AI civ management and victory pursuit is really bad. And once again we have the scenario of tank vs spearmen back in a Civ game.It is fun enough but dont belive the hype. It is worse than previous titles.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As a fan of Civ V (2077 hours played), I was really looking forward to the release of Civ VI. Unfortunately I can't recommend this game in its current state.Firstly, this version should get credit for having many of the major game systems in the game upon release (trade, espionage and religion). Visually the game also looks quite good (although I would have prefered less cartoonish graphics, but that is just personal preference). The new district system also bring some interesting gameplay and I like that you can no longer have a single city that build all of the world wonders.The developers clearly had many good ideas, but some of them are poorly executed. The agenda system is one example of this. Meant to give each leader personality and flavor in diplomacy, it has not turned out well. One turn they will praise you, but just a few turns later they will hate you, even though nothing has changed. The religious victory is also quite mediocre. You just spam the same religious units over and over again. I don't find it to be much fun.My biggest issue is with the AI. As many others have pointed out, it is really bad. The AI does some really strange things, both in times of peace and during war. Here are some examples. Their units walks all over the place, for seemingly no good reason. They send unprotected settlers to the front lines during war. They build districts in odd locations and even though they build aeorodromes, I have never seen them use any planes. All in all the AI is great at making bad decisions. I'm also disappointed to see that difficulty levels still is all about how big of a head start the AI is given. I know this is the same as in Civ V, but i guess I had hoped for some sort of improvement, going from V to VI.Civ VI is also troubled with various UI that could have been more informative, some bugs and waiting time between turns can be very long.Lastly, I bought the game on release and I have waited until now to write a review, hoping that some of the major flaws would get fixed. I gave the game a new chance recently and unfortunately I can't see many improvements. I don't really see why I should play this version over Civ V. Actually I find Civ V to be more entertaining.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game started off fantastic. But DLC spam that have better abilities that you can't get otherwise. Base game is fine, idk about multiplayer usually stay away from it and play private matches. AI does seem really dumb in some situations and only get better by giving them cheap buffs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Sadly, I don't see this game being playable until 2018. It might be a great game by then, but it fails right now. The new concepts are promising but not balanced. Your ability to manage an empire is severely strained because you don't have proper overlays. And although the stack of death is gone, the replacement is this weird abstraction of a tactical battle being fought across a strategic map. Civ V had that same issue as Civ VI, but I had hoped they would have found a way to make war feel more natural.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's... not great, but not truly bad. The concept is solid, but the execution is buggy, the UI is very poor, and there is a pervasive lack of information about what your actions actually do in mechanical terms.It does feel like a Civ game (with all the pros and cons that implies), but it was clearly rushed out the door too soon. I would hold off for now. I imagine they'll finish the job over the next few months.

title: Recommended
comment: It's good man, very fun. Some aspects feel like you're going to have to get used to them but I think that the new leaders make up for that.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Been A civilization fan since having Elvis as my trusted advisor, first impressions for this version was good but after playing for a few hours, working hard on my Kingdom of Dirt. I realized it had some very irritating issues, the biggest one for me was having Barbarians just appear as by magic every 15mins surrounding one of my cities that the A.I. knew it could do the most damage too (Teleporting Barbarians I ask you!) No, No ,No Sid don't let one of the best PC game ever made turn into some mystical farce because if you do, it will be forever remembered as crap and this game does not deserve that title.

title: Recommended
comment: I haven't played any of the previous Civilization games, and therefore I'm not able to compare this game to the other ones. This game however, offers everything you'd want from a turn-based strategy game in my opinion. It's very complex with a lot of different ways to play the game, and it just feels like the developers have cared a lot about the details.Personally I don't have any problems with the graphics, but I can understand that some people find it a bit too cartoonish, escpecially if you're looking at the other civilization games.Originally i bought this game for times when I just wanted to relax, but it's actually a lot funnier than i thought.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Okay, I get that they were trying to add a lot of new mechanics, but I think maybe they went overboard. Having to designate a specific tile for wonders and for districts while adhering to the myriad rules about which wonder/district can go where gets ridiculously difficult, especially if you also want to be able to feed and house your citizens when only certain kinds of tiles can be farms, etc. And it's many times worse if you're unlucky enough to be on a small island. Once you're well into the game and your cities stop gaining new tiles at any reasonable rate and are large enough that you can no longer purchase new tiles yourself, you're pretty much stuck as you can't do anything to remove districts/wonders if you discover later that you have a more pressing need for something else. Once not even focusing your city on food is enough, you may get into a situation where your city is shrinking and you can't build anything and even if you can research something that will give you more access to food, it may only be able to be built in a district you don't have and have no place to put. I'm finding it very frustrating even on settler level. I wish you could turn off housing requirements in the advanced game setup or that something as useful as neighborhoods was available significantly earlier.

title: Not Recommended
comment: (tl;dr It has launch day bugs and brand new bugs, updates are almost entirely focused on DLC without the effort put into patching that Civ V enjoyed. I gave it a year expecting bugfixes and while there has been some work put into fixing issues, a game that was a promising true sequel to Civ V is just not getting the support it requires to be a proper successor. Patches are not properly vetted and always introduce new issues. Do not buy Civ VI expecting proper post-launch support)AI spams users with war and/or peace offers every single turn (bug). Invisible rivers on Inland Sea map were never fixed. Barbarian scout notification warnings permanently appear on your own and random game units. Random unknown "player defeated" notifications spam you for the first third of a game, even when it's just a city-state being captured. The AI returning your own captured city when negotiating for peace results in your own city having a zero growth penalty, because for some reason it counts as a captured "foreign" city (bug). The game exe still randomly crashes for a large number of people when exiting. Default AI will give away all great works for a single luxury resource (Similar issue to the launch day balance issues, but this one is a straight up bug. All AI will trade away great works as if they have no value). These are all bugs that could've been fixed in one patch, however game updates have been minimal and will introduce new bugs as much as fix existing ones. Unlike with Civ V which enjoyed multi-page patch notes, in VI patches are focused on adding more DLC to buy.If at war the AI will move religious units into your military forces which auto-kills them for no reason. Even if you do not found ANY religion, third party AI will denounce and go to war with you because you were "converting" one of their cities. Logically this is impossible, but because killing the religious units incurs a penalty against that specific religion, all nearby uninvolved AI will pretend it was your nonexistent religion that was converting them.The AI is still relatively useless and poorly implemented. It will plant a city in the middle of four of your own despite a lack of resources, then take offense when you are forced to path units around it. You will receive a severe diplomatic penalty as a warmonger despite never starting a single war, which makes relations with other AI practically impossible if you are forced into playing defensive wars. AI will still not improve tiles with resources inside its borders, instead electing to trade more gold for them than it would to buy the workers outright to improve the tile next to its own capital.Despite the numerous upgrades in capabilities (such as unit stacking to build armies) Civ V's AI was more capable at warfare, both defense and on offense. Seige and artillery units will attempt to attack move even though its not allowed, so the AI just throws seige units at your combat troops. Even outside of war the AI will waste a hundred missionaries to convert a city that can only be converted by a prophet, which makes the AI useless at most religious victories.I could paste three more paragraphs of bugs from my previous review, but I am too lazy to verify which of those issues still exist. Maybe Civ VI will be in good shape in three years, or after the first two major expansion DLCs get released. Issues such as the great works trading make multiplayer pointless due to AI abuse, and the AI itself isn't programmed on how to defend itself even on Diety making single player equally frustrating. Give it a few more years or wait till it's 80% off, otherwise expect new bugs to be introduced with each quarterly patch.

title: Recommended
comment: Pros, Cons, and ChangesPros- 4x in the way you would expect it- all of the major features from Civ 5 and its expansions are present although some significantly altered- new district system- new religious victory and related units- more options for espionage- more detailed information regarding what influences an AI's attitude- greater map details: cliffs and beachesCons- information screens are poorly presented; there is no way to sort cities by production etc.- somewhat limited number of buildings and units (although likely to increase with expansions)- AI makes some poor decisions (sends out builders right next to your military unit when you're at war with them)Changes (not really good or bad)- two research/development trees: the traditional tech tree and a civic tree which uses culture- government system now uses a card system, more advanced government more card slots, new cards are researched through the civic tree- wonders are now built on tiles, some of which have particular tile requirements- happiness is done on a per city basis- luxury resources only apply to 4 cities regardless of how much you have- strategic resources, without any specail wonders or government cards, require you to have 2 of them before it can be used- new housing system- unit movement rounds down- great people of the same type have differencesI am sure there are a number of other changes I'm forgetting but in short the play feels significantly differentAll things considered, it is a proper evolution of the series and I enjoyed it. With regards to price, it was more than I expected it to be, but I don't regret making the purchase. That being said, if it is a concern I imagine it will be on sale during Xmas season.

title: Recommended
comment: +No city number penalty+No global happiness-Trade route need to be manuallly specified everytime it ends-no puppet city or AI governorThe above two make playing on large map a nightmare in late game.....too many clicks

title: Recommended
comment: The opening menu music is amazing. I know that is silly, but it is. If you like civ you will love this game. If you like strategy games but haven't played the other civ games, you will love this game.I think they did a great job of tweaking the formula with enough balance, ai development, nice graphical improvements, and overall mechanic evolutions to keep it feeling fresh.A must buy for any strategy or civ fan. Trust me, you will love the main menu music.

title: Recommended
comment: While it has become the standard for lots of developers to publish unfinished games this one is a really nice surprise.Especially when compared to Civ5 at launch the new one really shines with lots of content the other one only got via dlc.I think its definately worth to buy it now and it feels nice to give money to devs that for once dont try to cheat you.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game is crashing around turn 190, so you cannot play game for the full game. Do not buy until they release a fix for the crash.2k support can not fix it at this stage, so you will be dissapointed with the money you spend and only getting the first quarter of the game to play.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 56 hours played over three re-starts! I will always LOVE civ, but heres a just a handful of quibles and why for now I cannot continue on. Or at least until the modders improve upon a few things and/ or some patches updates and DLC's game change it a bit-REALLY Needs an earth map (sorry, I know i'm being fussy and hard to please) but why does this game not have an earth map? c'mon?! Earth maps stimulate me!-the pacing REALLY needs to slow the ♥♥♥♥ down, I want to enjoy the renaissance and industrial age without going through it in 5 turns. Civ is to be savoured and the ages to be indicative of the period and not felt like it's gone in 60 sconds. By the time I have built a couple of improvments from the medeval era and settled across the map on the back of a donkey I have already found myself going into the industrial age and beyond. FGS let me FEEL the transitory vangelis conquest of paradise man! as like most of the previous games it feels brief and sometimes uneventful. As a player I really wanted to see more techs and eras everlasting, but as usual the tech tree seems to be getting shorter with every new game that gets knocked out!. NOW you've now got a 2 horse race going on, techs and cultural progression FLYING by and I am desperately trying to slow both of them down by NOT building science and cultural quarters.- the A.I. Really needs to improve and give me a game, become more competitve and develop some character (NO! ramping up the difficulty to emperor and beyond is NOT the solution as all that does is give it more resources and advantages and the ability to play faster but still acts like a buffed up superfast dumn♥♥♥♥♥br>-A.I building cities within 3 tiles of each other WHYWHYWHY WHY oh WHY does every civ game do this?? stop making the AI do this STAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAP!...when is the AI ever going to stop this obsessive behaviour? it makes me want to overdoes on my selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors! it drives me crazy!-Eureka moments! I hate them! (MY personal opinion, I gather this replaces a golden age?) all eureka moments do is make the game go faster! NOOO! FFS I get a eureka moment for building a friggin wall? i'm sure I will get one for picking my nose, just tone this madness down ! I am eureking myself into an early grave FFS!- Also wish the game had events, phenomenons and disasters to keep your experience buzzing and occupied, maybe like a massive barabarian invasion (civ1 actually had this), revolutions which spread across the map, maybe have eureka momments that 'instead' kick starts a player onto some global military dominance and becomes a danger to the rest of the world? or earth quakes etc one game that kind of does this well for example is stellaris-why do the map sizes STILL make me feel crowded? I keep bumping into other civs within 5 turns!-Lastly I think this game is WAY too pricey! For the price on offer I would expect a civ game created on a massive proportion, something legendary! something to capture the imagination! everything that was great from the last five and MORE! but no... same old weak AI, same old dumbed down tech progression, everything flying past a 100mph :(

title: Not Recommended
comment: Well, seems to be nice - but currently unplayable for me - keeps crashing after a couple of rounds whenever I finish my move during an AI move.

title: Not Recommended
comment: New Mac update (1.0.1) sucks, it crashes a loooooooooooot. I cannot continue playing the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Nothing more to say

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've played this game for less than an hour and the game has crashed twice; not hardware issues either. The only time I've experienced crashes from a game like this was from games in Alpha development. This game is considered a finished game. The first time was random during a singleplayer game, and the second time was after I had to restart my computer to close the game; when I opened the game again I went to change the resolution in the game menu and it crashed again. Please optimize your game. I will not be able to recommend this game until simple things like this are fixed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is put together very well, has very few bugs, and has a nice appearance. It's an armchair game that you can play with just the mouse.After playing this game for awhile there really is very little challenge to the single player game because the computer opponents won't attack you unless you go out of your way to make them mad and if they do they don't use tactics and are easily defeated. It ends up just being an economic game (which is just clicking and clicking the mouse for hours on end. More importantly, and the biggest failure, (researching technologies is a big part of the game) and you really don't feel like your research decisions make a difference.Overall, it's plain to see that the optimization towards multiplayer and tablet play has sucked the life out of what could be an amazing game. Just too much clicking and not enough challenge due to a 'dumb' AI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: With most PC games pre-publication development is divided into an Alpha and a Beta stage. When it comes to the Civilization series, there is a third gestation period; the Gamma stage if you will. This covers the period between the official game launch and the inevitable release of the two expansions that will properly flesh out and re-balance a good game and make it great and add enough new content to come within a couple of miles of justifying the added cost.If you are a big fan of turned-based strategy games and money is no object or you like being in on this third larval stage, then Civilization VI is a smart purchase right now. Otherwise, exercise some restraint and wait for the total package. If you have and still enjoy any of the older Civilization titles, keep playing them. If you don't have them, buy now and discover the many pleasures of this wonderful series.In a year or so, Civ VI will be genuinely complete and available at a reasonable price and the Gamma version of Civ VII will be on the horizon.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am not sure if there is a game out there that has a bigger discrepancy between the professional reviewers and the game-buying public. I am old enough to have been playing Civilization since the first incarnation and can say that Civ VI is by far the worst. It is the only Civ game that I actively dislike. Many reviewers have gone into great detail on the issues with the game; I would agree with most of these negative reviews. The biggest problem is the completely schizophrenic AI. Other leaders love/hate you for indiscernable reasons and often in back-to-back turns. Defending yourself gets you labeled a warmonger. In general the diplomacy function is not "deep" but rather just random. Disappointing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: So there we are: Civilization VIAs a player who played Civ V for more than 700 hrs I must say I'm not quite sure about this game. It`s missing something magical like Civ V had it. Of course its "style" has been updated quite well, but is this really the way to go? In my opinion not. But you have a couple of more opportunities than back in five. And you have the DLC section as well which is mostly disliked by the community of its game. So I would say this game is a step further than five but definitely needs to improve and I`m not sure if the price is worth it. If you`re not sure if you should buy this game, go ahead ask your friends what they like at this game and get some impressions by reviews and videos.For me this game is not worth paying the full price and especially not playing it for more than 100hrs. Go buy Civ V for a cheaper price and be happy :).

title: Not Recommended
comment: In the current state - I would advise not to purchase the game. This will no doubt change after the game is patched. Currently, a number of game-breaking bugs exist that essentially render the game unplayable for myself, even on a machine that exceeds the recommended specs. A real shame as the gameplay mechanics are solid and I felt like this release is progress in the right direction forthe Civ series.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A poor, almost amateur, rendition of a AAA game. This game continues the trend of the popular Civilization series to coast on popularity and good looks, pouring a large budget into game assets while ignoring the AI. Despite its importance in a single player strategy game, the AI continues to get stupider with Civilization VI. Not only is the AI essentially broken, the game design is fundamentally flawed as it turns the playing experience into an exercise in micromanagement that is difficult to balance and is a nightmare to write AI for. This micromanagement serves to distract the player from the game's shortcomings: it is a single player strategy game with a hopelessly incompetent AI and poor game balance. After playing every game in the series, it is sad to see it develop like this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Originally owned this for Mac, purchased a new ASUS Strix blah blah blah laptop. Can't get past the loading screen, freezes everytime to the point where I have to restart my computer.Added steam and the game to Windows 10 Defender Exclusion List, Disabled Defender in the registry, Turned off real time monitoring, reinstalled windows, reinstalled the game multiple times, did everything I could find online, yet I am left with a broken game.So, If you somehow become one of the most unluckiest purchasers like me, stay away. But, if you're like the 99.9% of people who can actually play the game they purchased, then hey! good for you, its a great game.Thanks windows. Thanks Sid Meier'sI will never purchase anything from you guys again... coming from a guy whos invested thousands of hours in your previous games.

title: Recommended
comment: The pinnacle of turn based strategy, still not as good as civ 5 but the potential is there. Also there is Australia.

title: Recommended
comment: Great game but stopped working after 26 hours of gameplay and I can't play it no more.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This one's killed the series for me. Somehow they've taken the "Just one more turn!" feel and replaced it with a little sigh as you hit the end turn button again.I think starting up my first map sums it up. I went into the settings before starting and selected "New to Civ 6" instead of "New to Civ series"... Started up my first map, and it asked me was I new to Civ 6, or the Civ series? :/ And the tips that choice relates to have popped up every session so far, giving me a minute or so of tips every time I end my next turn after returning to the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Short note, I will make this review as detailed as I can, but since I got bored very quickly, I can't go too in depth.Overall Experience: I came into this super exited with all the new features it was going to have, I liked the new District system, and I was looking forward to it. I was a little on edge about the graphics style, but it eventually grew on me. When I bought the game I started it up, then played about 20 minutes before getting bored. I would say this is because I have a short attention span for games like this, but this is not the case, as you can see I played around 115 Hours in Civ 5 and have played around 330 hours in HOI4 and around 400 In EU4. This game to me is just boring, it doesn't have the same smoothness and charm Civ 5 had in it's interface, and I quickly found out that diplomacy is useless. Civ 5 had a very simple diplomacy system, but at least it worked. The Devs pushed the "Secret Agendas" as neat things, and in theory they are, but in practice? Not so much. If you aren't fufiling a nation's secret agenda, they are never going to ally you, and they will most likely denounce you then go to war. The AI is very fickle so even if you make an ally, there's no telling how long it will last. Lastly, Trade deals will never go in your favor, so don't even bother. Other than that, the Districts mechanic is great, and can make more spread out cities, unlike the rather condensed feeling cities of Civ 5.Pros and ConsPros:-Districts are a nice edition-City State interactions work well-Religious victory has been reintroduced, and isn't overpowered like it was in Civ 4-Other More Minor ThingsCons-Diplomacy is for the most part useless-Gets boring (Might just be me, but It's worth noting.)-Continents can be weird (Especially when dealing with Britain)-Secret AgendasTLDR; I got bored of it, tried playing it again, was still bored. Diplomacy is useless

title: Recommended
comment: Pros, Cons, and ChangesPros- 4x in the way you would expect it- all of the major features from Civ 5 and its expansions are present although some significantly altered- new district system- new religious victory and related units- more options for espionage- more detailed information regarding what influences an AI's attitude- greater map details: cliffs and beachesCons- information screens are poorly presented; there is no way to sort cities by production etc.- somewhat limited number of buildings and units (although likely to increase with expansions)- AI makes some poor decisions (sends out builders right next to your military unit when you're at war with them)Changes (not really good or bad)- two research/development trees: the traditional tech tree and a civic tree which uses culture- government system now uses a card system, more advanced government more card slots, new cards are researched through the civic tree- wonders are now built on tiles, some of which have particular tile requirements- happiness is done on a per city basis- luxury resources only apply to 4 cities regardless of how much you have- strategic resources, without any specail wonders or government cards, require you to have 2 of them before it can be used- new housing system- unit movement rounds down- great people of the same type have differencesI am sure there are a number of other changes I'm forgetting but in short the play feels significantly differentAll things considered, it is a proper evolution of the series and I enjoyed it. With regards to price, it was more than I expected it to be, but I don't regret making the purchase. That being said, if it is a concern I imagine it will be on sale during Xmas season.

title: Recommended

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game is crashing around turn 190, so you cannot play game for the full game. Do not buy until they release a fix for the crash.2k support can not fix it at this stage, so you will be dissapointed with the money you spend and only getting the first quarter of the game to play.

title: Recommended
comment: It's got a great early to mid game. You actually have much more leeway to decide how to build a civilization.Examples: You don't really need to get useless technologies like previous games. I didn't learn how to build the most basic boats until the industrial era, just because the techs I actually need weren't entirely dependent on previous techs in the tree. Like you can get several science techs before getting any military or economic techs.Districts also help a lot. You can't build every district early because there are population limits to how many you can build, but where you build them first also really matters. Like if I care about science I'll put my science district near my capital, but also with a few flat tiles nearby to put universities or wonders on, since they all require their own tiles. Later I'll make an economic district, but I won't have a place to build a couple buildings so I will never be making as much money as I would if I built it first.Also, the government is more complex. You can build different into 10 different governments, each with there own advantages and policies that all have a serious impact on how you do things.Lastly, the city states are cooler. The straight benefits are greater, and no real 'random benefits', which was a major reason to use them in the last game. In particular, if you're an ally of a city state you can pay them a reasonable fee to take control of their entire army for 15 turns, which is huge as they usually have about 5 units. So if you have one nearby, you don't have to worry about suprise attacks as much since you can have a decent army at your disposal within the turn.Those changes make a major impact early to mid game, but if you get to the final stages they tend to matter less overall.My biggest gripe, by far, is that the AI is idiotic. It tends to be annoying with stupid demands, they may constantly declare war on you, but they tend to be terrible at actually waging war. They may ask to trade my 'open borders and luxery resource' for 3 gold total, but then i'll ask to make it even, and they'll demand all my luxery resources, open borders, and 180 gold. But not offer anything. Like they'll interupt my playing to send me that stupid a trade.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Imagine playing a game of chess on the computer and every time you up the difficulty, the computer gets an extra rook or even an extra queen. Suddenly all it needs to do to get a pawn promotion is to get to the middle of the board instead of the end. That's what playing Civ VI is like. That's ultimately why I can't just blindly recommend this game.There is a LOT I really enjoy about this game especially compared to Civ V. I really like that physical space matters when building districts and composing your city. That you can't just build any and every wonder because you need not only space fo wonders, but the appropriate land types and location. I love that you can stack units, link units, and even name them at some point to better keep track of them. I like that city-states give unique bonuses if you're suzerain of them and they actually can make a difference. City-states will actually go after barbarians, attack you if you're at war or help you if they are on your side.I've never felt like I was "doing the same old thing" each game I played. Focusing on science feels different than focusing on production and that feels different than focusing on culture. There is strategy in building up your cities and deciding on districts. That's fun. I like that.The huge issue I have which completely ruins the fun for me is how the difficulty level works. Instead of playing smarter with maybe giving itself a few advantages, rules just stop applying to them. Or I should say, it becomes even more obvious how the rules don't apply to them. They don't need to research, they don't need production or science, they just "get" things. And when you up the difficulty they just get them "faster" and at a rate that you yourself definitely cannot do. Which then makes the game more of a gamble in that you better hope for a starting position where you have the right resources close enough and no way of having four barbarian encampments surrounding you or you can just assume that you've lost the game.What ends up happening is then when you lose a game, you can't stop and think about "What could I have done better?" because it doesn't matter. If you lose a game of chess, you can think about your mistakes, where you were surprised, and what your opponent was doing and improve your own strategy. In this game, you can't do that. Because the computer isn't playing the game. . .it's only creating an environment that you exist in.Yes, Civ isn't chess. But you have to recognize that playing a game where you have to strategize in order to beat your opponents who are playing the same game as you is completely different than playing a game where it's just you in an increasingly difficult puzzle with everything stacked up against you.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Doesn't substantially improve on Civ V, and feels less polished and less user-friendly than its predecessor.The lack of automation features, opaque diplomatic interface (and insane AI), and generally magnified amount of micromanagement and busywork are the reason I'm giving this installment a thumbs down. The religion system is clunky and adds to the intense micromanagement. If missionaries, workers, scouts, etc. could be automated (as they were in previous editions...) then this wouldn't be so bad. The music and sound are boring at best and annoying at worst. There are severe balance issues between the different victory types and civilizations, with some being barely viable at all on higher difficulties.It's not all bad, though. The new Civic tree is an excellent addition and I hope it returns for future installments, and the way great people work is a welcome change as well. The civs all feel different (not all of them are interesting or balanced, but they're all unique.) The barbarians have teeth this time around and feel like a genuine part of the game instead of a stepping stone. The new fog-of-war map looks great.I'm neutral on the district system. I don't really like it, but I don't hate it, either. It's new and different, and it was worth trying. I do like that wonders take up hexes the same way a district would. It heavily incentivizes rapid expansion - which is fine, because there is literally no reason not to expand as fast as possible with the new happiness / amenities system. Sure, there are diplomatic penalties, but the crazy AI will do whatever it wants regardless of your expansion penalties.Avoid at full price. Worth picking up on sale for fans of the series just to see all the ways things can go wrong while a few other things go right.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A poor, almost amateur, rendition of a AAA game. This game continues the trend of the popular Civilization series to coast on popularity and good looks, pouring a large budget into game assets while ignoring the AI. Despite its importance in a single player strategy game, the AI continues to get stupider with Civilization VI. Not only is the AI essentially broken, the game design is fundamentally flawed as it turns the playing experience into an exercise in micromanagement that is difficult to balance and is a nightmare to write AI for. This micromanagement serves to distract the player from the game's shortcomings: it is a single player strategy game with a hopelessly incompetent AI and poor game balance. After playing every game in the series, it is sad to see it develop like this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Originally owned this for Mac, purchased a new ASUS Strix blah blah blah laptop. Can't get past the loading screen, freezes everytime to the point where I have to restart my computer.Added steam and the game to Windows 10 Defender Exclusion List, Disabled Defender in the registry, Turned off real time monitoring, reinstalled windows, reinstalled the game multiple times, did everything I could find online, yet I am left with a broken game.So, If you somehow become one of the most unluckiest purchasers like me, stay away. But, if you're like the 99.9% of people who can actually play the game they purchased, then hey! good for you, its a great game.Thanks windows. Thanks Sid Meier'sI will never purchase anything from you guys again... coming from a guy whos invested thousands of hours in your previous games.

title: Not Recommended

title: Not Recommended
comment: Short note, I will make this review as detailed as I can, but since I got bored very quickly, I can't go too in depth.Overall Experience: I came into this super exited with all the new features it was going to have, I liked the new District system, and I was looking forward to it. I was a little on edge about the graphics style, but it eventually grew on me. When I bought the game I started it up, then played about 20 minutes before getting bored. I would say this is because I have a short attention span for games like this, but this is not the case, as you can see I played around 115 Hours in Civ 5 and have played around 330 hours in HOI4 and around 400 In EU4. This game to me is just boring, it doesn't have the same smoothness and charm Civ 5 had in it's interface, and I quickly found out that diplomacy is useless. Civ 5 had a very simple diplomacy system, but at least it worked. The Devs pushed the "Secret Agendas" as neat things, and in theory they are, but in practice? Not so much. If you aren't fufiling a nation's secret agenda, they are never going to ally you, and they will most likely denounce you then go to war. The AI is very fickle so even if you make an ally, there's no telling how long it will last. Lastly, Trade deals will never go in your favor, so don't even bother. Other than that, the Districts mechanic is great, and can make more spread out cities, unlike the rather condensed feeling cities of Civ 5.Pros and ConsPros:-Districts are a nice edition-City State interactions work well-Religious victory has been reintroduced, and isn't overpowered like it was in Civ 4-Other More Minor ThingsCons-Diplomacy is for the most part useless-Gets boring (Might just be me, but It's worth noting.)-Continents can be weird (Especially when dealing with Britain)-Secret AgendasTLDR; I got bored of it, tried playing it again, was still bored. Diplomacy is useless
