title: Recommended
comment: Still in my first two paralell playthroughs, but the CIV feeling is there again. The unstacking of the cities and the split of the science tree (incl. the Inspireation/Heureka moments) are great concepts that have increased the amount of decision making and thus the immersion into the game for me.On the downside I have to admit I do not find the AI overly challenging and plus the tech speed in relation to the production output requires IMHO a re-balance, but this is not impacting my fun with the game.Again really happy with the new Civ and looking forward now to the first patches and DLCs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I received a copy of version five for Christmas and have logged an insane number of very enjoyable hours playing it. When version six came out on humble bundle I couldn’t resist signing up for it. From the first time I loaded it I was unimpressed. The cartoon like animations were cute and the visuals are admittedly better the version five but there are some glaring problems and uncanny bugs that will have stopped me from even trying to go any further.1. First and foremost in my mind is the ridiculous user interface. The color combinations and text size seem to have been designed to make reading anything as difficult as possible. The box that pulls up when you click on a city or a character uses brown text on a brown background and green text on a green background as well as text that is so small that it requires me to put on my reading glasses and get right next to the screen. Compared to the crisp and legible interface on version five this is a huge disappointment.2. Along the same line both the character screen and the city screen switch sizes after a couple on moves and the bottom part is no longer visible on the screen. I thought it was an over scan problem with my monitor but it does the same thing in windowed mode so it’s a software bug.3. There is something very wrong with the AI running the barbarians, on my second try I had three horse mounted units show up and the stuck around for over thirty moves crippling any chance for a good start.4. The AI for the German group was allowed to spawn eight cities by move 100. He started on the far left on the map and spawned cities the minimum distance apart in a straight line towards my initial city.At this point I gave up, I was playing as Roosevelt with the difficulty set to prince.

title: Recommended
comment: Overal i think it is best and most engaging civ i have played (i played Civ since Civ1, but have not played Civ5 much).Pros:- Runs smooth on average specs- Districts and wonders add whole new dimension to city planning and city placement.- Tech boosts and division of techs to 2 separate trees add some interesting considerations too.- Non-infinite workers remove "railroads everywhere" thingie that started back at Civ 1. Also turns are now much shorter because of this.- I like how great people are acquired in this iteration and how they are unique.- Barbarians are bigger threat and not just little nuisance- City states are much more intuitive and logical.Cons:- AI at prince is as stupid as usual. I don't like having to enable cheats (harder difficulties) for computer to help him alleviate this stupidness.- City UI is bad and by default show literally nothing.- Important information (like adjustment bonuses) that is present in building tooltips when you research this buildings is missing from tooltip when you want to build this buildings. And no tooltips about what building does at all if it is already built.- Civilopedia is either not intuitive or don't have some important gameplay information (I.e. not all civilization bonuses listed)- Generally tile yields should overlay resource icon and not vice versa - currently it is too tricky to see yields (press this button, press that button, zoom in).Gameplay wise i feel like i'm playing refined and finally well-though implementation of old features with most interesting (at least for me) addition at all history of series (districts).Only complaints are about UI (but i don't play UI, i play gameplay and math) and AI (it was always stupid in Civilization, so nothing new and unexpected here)

title: Recommended
comment: This is, in my opinion, a fantastic game and a definite improvement on Civilization V. The graphics are an enourmous improvement, as can be expected. The art style is highly debatable but I'm personally a fan of it. The district system works well and isn't hard to learn, and the victory types are an improvement from Civilization V - the religious victory in particular is a nice touch.The civic system is also very good, although I can see the system having one or two perfect routes in the future. I'm also a fan of the civilizations themselves, but I would like more of them in the future.There are a few problems though. The AI isn't perfect - they don't always make use of the escort system very well when it comes to Builders and Settlers and Barbarians are very strong early game; I've considered turning them off more than once. Diplomacy still needs a little work, and the envoy system took more than a few glances at to understand.As someone whose used the Enhanced UI mod for Civilization V, I also found the UI a little difficult to understand for the first few hour, but I've gotten used to it by now.T̶h̶e̶r̶e̶ ̶i̶s̶ ̶a̶l̶s̶o̶ ̶a̶ ̶r̶a̶t̶h̶e̶r̶ ̶s̶t̶r̶a̶n̶g̶e̶ ̶b̶u̶g̶ ̶w̶h̶e̶r̶e̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶g̶a̶m̶e̶ ̶r̶a̶n̶d̶o̶m̶l̶y̶ ̶h̶a̶n̶g̶s̶ ̶o̶n̶ ̶e̶x̶i̶t̶ ̶a̶n̶d̶ ̶r̶e̶f̶u̶s̶e̶s̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶c̶l̶o̶s̶e̶,̶ ̶c̶r̶e̶a̶t̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶i̶s̶s̶u̶e̶s̶.̶ ̶M̶o̶r̶e̶ ̶t̶h̶a̶n̶ ̶o̶n̶c̶e̶ ̶I̶'̶v̶e̶ ̶h̶a̶d̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶u̶s̶e̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶R̶e̶s̶t̶a̶r̶t̶-̶>̶C̶T̶R̶L̶+̶A̶L̶T̶+̶D̶e̶l̶e̶t̶e̶-̶>̶L̶o̶c̶k̶ ̶t̶r̶i̶c̶k̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶g̶e̶t̶ ̶i̶t̶ ̶t̶o̶ ̶c̶l̶o̶s̶e̶.̶ ̶D̶o̶e̶s̶n̶'̶t̶ ̶e̶f̶f̶e̶c̶t̶ ̶t̶h̶e̶ ̶g̶a̶m̶e̶p̶l̶a̶y̶ ̶b̶u̶t̶ ̶i̶t̶ ̶i̶s̶ ̶i̶r̶r̶i̶t̶a̶t̶i̶n̶g̶ ̶-̶ ̶N̶e̶v̶e̶r̶ ̶e̶v̶e̶r̶ ̶E̶x̶i̶t̶ ̶T̶o̶ ̶D̶e̶s̶k̶t̶o̶p̶ ̶w̶h̶i̶l̶s̶t̶ ̶i̶n̶-̶g̶a̶m̶e̶.̶ ̶ -> This bug appears to have been patched out; I haven't had it in months.However, for me, personally, these problems were more things I noticed and made note of than problems that ruined or negatively effected my gameplay (except perhaps the Barbarians - it was a shock initally). For others, these issues might be more irritating so, despite the fact I'm enjoying Civilization VI immensely, they are worth noting.I also know people who dislike the artstyle. As I've stated earlier, I'm personally a fan of it. The music is pretty cool too.Overall, Civilization VI is a game that, as of my first impressions, I recommend both as an improvement to Civilization V and as a game in its own right. I wouldn't say that it was a monumental improvement over Civ V Brave New World, but it certaintly is comparatively to Vanilla Civ V, and of course through expansions it has the potential to be even better.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ is a series that's long in the tooth and short in titles worth playing for many hours. Five games in a row where all civilizations play more or less the same, and everyone needs to go for conquest victory. As someone who's played every single Civ game (yes, even the one where you had to select which audio/video drivers you wanted to use every time you booted it), I'm pretty used to how it works. I expected a game or two of conquest, then maybe a half-hearted try at science or religious victory, before "getting" the game's mechanics and feeling like i'd already experienced everything it had to offer.But while I truly expected that, I bought the game so close to release because it promised to be more. Specifically, it promised to be a realization of what civ5 was trying, and failing, to do.Civ5 shook things up in a lot of ways. Hex grids, forbidding unit stacking, etc. But it landed awkwardly, and didn't fuse the new elements together well. Plus, it forsook a lot of good features from the past (religions, anyone?). Civ6, as the direct successor, did what 5 wanted to do - and more. It polished the awkward innovations, brought back the old features that were sorely missing, and wrapping it all up with the best execution of any civ game yet.Look, I could go into the specifics of these things, like unit "corps" instead of stacks, the viability of different victory conditions, an actual espionage system, a much-improved diplomacy experience, the absolutely brilliant way that civics are separated from technology, and the game-changing nature of "boosts" in research based on things you do in the actual game itself. I could laundry-list all the good things - but I don't think I need to. The gameplay is the most polished of any Civ since the first one.But I'll just pick one important thing that all these changes make: Not everyone plots the exact same course to victory. Given how boosts work, and the bifurcaton of civics/technologies, your actual plan and experience is different based on who you're playing and what the map looks like.Civ6 is a great game that doesn't need expansion packs to become that way. It didn't ship prematurely, and its core gameplay is much more engaging than any other in the series.

comment: Loved CivV. CivVI is a buggy pos that crashed more times than you have games. Why would Sid Meier put out this buggy game and take my hard earned dollars. I think the game designers had more dollars than sense.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I cannot recommend this game at this time. it feels like a polished Early-Access game instead of a full release, which is all the more a shame considering who it is coming from.The bones of a fantastic game are there, and I have no reason to believe that Fraxis won't flesh them out in the months to come. The unstacking of cities, combining military units together, researching civics like techs, boosting techs and civics. There is a lot to like here in what they have changed. Hell, you can build more than 4 cities with no noticiable penalty, which really is nice if you want to make a huge civilization.However, there are problems. Other reviewers do a great job but I just want to echo ones that stand out to me as the worst. Bugs and the AI.For a complete game, the amount of technical issues is sad. None are game breaking, but I would expect better. Sure, in two months they will probably be fixed, but I am pretty sick of how many games are being released in this sad state. The audio for the people talking in the intro video and all in game voices are too quiet and impossible to hear. I didn't even know Sean Bean was involved because he was impossible to hear, until randomly the victory screen you can hear him fine. I put a support ticket into 2k one the day the game was released and they only wrote me back today, although none of their suggestions fixed the issue. The game also randomly hangs when I go to exit it and annoying other things. Again, this will probably all be fixed, but pretty sad for basic things like this to be messed up.The AI is also awful. Sure, Civ games are way more complex then just about any other game and I cannot imagine the nightmare of making a compotent AI oppent, but the AI in Civ 6 is laughably bad. Worse than Civ 5. I would hope asking for AI that is at least as much of a challenge as it was in Civ 5 would be the base line. Instead, diplomacy is all over the place and the AI has yet to take a single city from me, even when I purposely left one undefended with no walls to see if they would take it while we were at war and they had units next to the city. Instead, the units danced around. Hell, they barely even pillaged. This problem goes away in MP, but I primarily play Civ against the AI, so this is a sad development.TL;DR: Great potential of a game with too many issues in its current state to recommend, but will probably be fixed in the future.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game showed so much promise but ultimately I really regret paying for this. The AI is completely and utterly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, the "diplomacy" could be replaced by a visual display of rolling dice which would dictate what the AI players do that round.There's absolutely no causality between your actions and the reactions from the AI. The one neighbor that has continuously denounced you since the first century of the game might never declare a war on you no matter what you do. Another one, with whom you've been friends since the beginning might suddenly declare a war while declaration of friendship is still active, then after 10 or so rounds, come back with a peace offer backed by a substantial gift. After accepting they're your friend again and offer a declaration of friendship if it happened to expire during the war.A random AI player might offer you a trade where you give them a solid lump of money, another sum each year for many rounds and even throw in a handful of various luxury resources. Oh yeah, and you get nothing in return. But trade's a trade, right?And of course AI loves to build new cities right against your borders, then complain about your military near their border. Eventually they'll declare a war and utterly crush your puny army of tanks and artillery with their indomitable war machine of two spearmans and a crossbowman.More major annoyances and countless of minor ones, but the AI issues are so gigantic that I can't even.tl;drIf you like Civilization, don't buy this. They might eventually fix it but for the love of gaming, don't let them get away with releasing crap like this.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It seems like the Digital Deluxe doesn't actually buy you all the future DLCs and you'll have to pay extra to buy the new DLCs. Be very careful before you buy it! For some reason steam doesn't have a clear link or any explanatory text next to the purchase button to explain what it includes and what it doesn't (at least not an obvious one, I spend 20 minutes looking for it). I'm only made aware of the issue after the purchase. Quite frankly I feel like I got scammed.The game itself is also full of inconveniences. Mouse scrolling doesn't always work is the one that really got my nerves. AI is still bad. Not really a fan of the new artwork either. You'll have a difficult time differentiating between unxplored territory and fog of war because they are all in the same color. Some features are indeed interesting, such as districts, but if you are trying to decide whether to buy Civilization V or VI, I definitely suggest you to stick with the former.Overall, I honestly don't feel like I got my money's worth

comment: Been playing civilization since the very first game, it seems the game reached its peak with civ5, civ 6 seems like it was rushed out, released incomplete, sluggish, unplayable, you name it, I can put 2k hours in civ 5 and still enjoy it, I played for about 150 hours constantly trying to make myself believe I'd get over the irrational AI, but it's impossible, firaxis has really been disappointing lately :( which is unfortunate, between the first 5 civ games I'd put nearly 20-50k of gameplay hours, but civ 6 is so frustrating and disappointing that I'd rather not play it at all.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game has been constantly buggy and the AI has been inexplicably terrible since launch. The UI has to be manually tweaked through files to be properly usable. Not recommended as a commercial product.The gameplay is mostly fine, though; it's a nice Civ experience with some new spice added. title: Not Recommended
comment: Personally, I've enjoyed this latest addition to the Civilization series, the focus on each civ's abilities and unique bonuses give the game a greater variety and emphasis on which civ the player chooses. At the same time, the bonuses of each civ are spread out so a certain civ isn't limited to a single victory type. Compared to previous civ games, the biggest changes are in the districts/wonders and diplomacy. I like the new requirements for wonders and the fact that they take a tile, as it prevents one civ from building all the wonders in a single city, although sometimes the requirements might be a little too picky (ie The Great Zimbabwe needing to be adjacent to a cattle resource and commercial hub) and often prevent wonders from being built until much later in the game. In terms of the diplomatic game changes, I'm surprised and slightly disappointed by the removal of diplomatic victory and world congress. I enjoyed the world congress in civ 5 and it needed some work, but it definately added to the gameplay. I enjoy the new casus belli system, and I think it could be developed further to add more reasons. An additional casus belli for claimed land and forward settling (if a couple requests to stop settling near a player in the future are ignored/denied or a promise is broken, a small casus belli could be added for any cities within 6 tiles of one your own cities) could be added to deter overly expansive ai/players.Biggest Complaints:The art style of the civs is chaotic ranging from decent to garbage- leaders such as gandhi recieved rediculous cartooned features, while victoria recieves atleast a somewhat realistic image, but still cartoon. I'd prefer a return to the attempts at realism in civ 4.Diplomatic relations are next to impossible, to be friendly with a civ, you must appeal to both of their agendas and even then any little thing can set them off, and a friendship doesn't really grant you anything-in civ 5 your friends might denounce those you denounce or even declare war with you, not so in civ 6, everyone denounces eachother and declare meaningless wars.Civ 6 is a decent game, but its not worth $50+, the price needs to be atleast halved to be worth it.

title: Recommended
comment: A great installment into the Civilization series Civ6 changes a few things up in a major way. With a full game and a half under my belt in 22 hours I'm definitely enjoying the game. However, nothing is without some flaws, so while I wholeheartedly recommend getting Civ6, these are the things that bother me, and may bother you.Movement:The change to movement that requires your unit to have enough MV to move into a hex is definitely a huge impact to combat and moving around in general. In case you are unaware of the change, now a unit needs to actually have the 2mv points in order to move into a hill or forest area, as opposed to in Civ5 where you only needed 'some' amount of mv points, and if you didn't have enough to move into the hex it would bring you to 0 and stop your unit from going forward.The reason this hurts is because it costs you extra turns to just move units around. For example getting to a river with 1 of 2 mv points you have to end your turn get the 2mv points, cross the river (which takes 2mv points) and then end your turn in order to continue forward. Previously you would have gotten to the river with 1mv point, crossed it which brings you to 0 and end your turn. On the next turn you'd have 2mv points and continue your march into the distance.I was hoping that the new system would make for slightly smarter / better AI now that they had agendas. But that still didn't stop my strongest friend (Japan) from surprise war declaring on me, even though I had a very strong military, and 2nd highest religion (behind him) and culture (behind Russia) which are all part of his Bushido agenda, and was very financially stable which was his secret agenda (Money Grubber). This was after he pulled me into a war with Russia, who he then made peace with 10-15 turns later, and left me alone to fight them for around 50+. (Still not sure how that happened, Russia just would NOT let me negotiate peace with them)The few other things, that have been awkward getting used to is amenities, and how unclear it is at first glance why / how to increase them (until you get the recreation district). The Barbarian raiding parties when you fail to catch a scout before it gets back to it's base. One of my playthroughs almost ended short because I had three raids hit my capital at once.Again, I still totally recommend the game, and plan on dumping many more hours into it, but it definitely isn't a "perfect" game either... but anyone expecting that is foolish to start with.

title: Recommended
comment: It's the best "on release" CIV game so far. I still believe CIV V (complete) to be a better game though. Worth the $60 for hardcore fans of the series. I would definitively recommend waiting for a bundle that includes DLC if you are low on cash.8==D

title: Recommended
comment: Product received for freeSuch a great time waster, you get to learn new strats and stuff like that. I got this for free so Im happy, but I wouldn't pay the full price. I would recommend this game to anyone thats got some extra cash laying around.

title: Recommended
comment: Stylized, colorful graphics, well-thought mechanics makes this iteration of the Civ franchise my favorite yet. The unstacked cities really changes how the game plays, and I'm loving it.There are a lot of negativity around the game, and to be honest I'm not sure why. The base game of Civ VI was probably the most robust and complete package of the bunch (at release). Other Civ games were and are still great, but some people seem to refuse change.All in all, I think you need to try the game for yourself, and don't give in to the bad publicity. It's a Civ game, and it's a damn good one. Give it a few turns... then one more... the one more... then it's 3AM.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been playing Civilization since the beginning and can honestly say this is the most disappointing version yet. Even on sale I feel like I wasted my money.Pros:1) National Parks2) The eureka system3) Traders creating roads as they go4) Maybe the corp/army/fleet...Cons:1) The balance between the player and the AI is completely broken. I checked and even at chieftain difficulty the AI is ridiculously over powered. This isn't Dark Souls!!2) The UI is complicated and hard to navigate.3) Production queues - where are they? Having to micromanage because it seems to be a glorified tablet game is beyond annoying.4) The AI constantly issues denouncement proclamations that you are unable to skip.5) The limit on the amount of times a builder can be used is far too small compared to the financial or production cost of creating one. Along with the inability for them to simply lay down road improvements between cities and in an automated manner.6) I can see the districts show some signs that they had potential to work, but essentially the implementation is flawed to the point of being unable to genuinely have the sense you are advancing your civilization. The initial first stage ancient era buildings should not require their specific districts to be present before they can be constructed. It is extremely frustrating to be waiting for the population to increase another few levels when in the industrial age so that you are allowed to build a library because you urgently needed to build a military district and cultural districts first.7) Lack of ability to rush a construction when not all items can be directly purchased does not work. One or the other being removed is fine, but not being able to do either results in a painful slow death if you were not able to start the game with an effective early land grab (especially combined with the districts issue).8) The various civilizations are not equally balanced against each other, instead a few are distinctly OP compared with the rest.9) Espionage technology theft should just obtain the whole technology if it is the immediately next one above the player's current level. Having to wait 12 turns to complete only half the research after waiting for the spy to deploy in the target city is just too long a wait for not enough return. At that stage of the game the chances are the player has a massive amount of science anyway or at the other end of the spectrum is hopelessly being crushed by the sh%tty AI bias that it just doesn't really work.10..) There's honestly more but at this point it seems like kicking a dead horse....Honestly what I would love to see the developers do is produce a new version of Civilization that feels like it is a worthy sequel, not just a more flawed version of the last game.Instead of having the game finish on Earth in 2050, how about instead adding in a new level of gameplay involving expansion onto the Moon, Mars and into the solar system using additional "regions". Not doing another clone of the same game set on another world as they have in 'Alpha Centauri'/'Beyond Earth', but actually adding to the existing gameplay.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have Bought all of the Sid Meier's games since Colonization and Civ1. I loved the series and doubted many of the reviews that were negative. I write few reviews. I figure that i have better things to do than complain. In this case I am making the effort because I don't want ANYONE that has bought Civ prior to this to get stuck with such an awful game. I understand the need to make changes in such a long running series. My personal feeling is that you shouldn't change more than 20% from version to version. This is a total departure from Civ 5. Even worse it just doesn't work. It is such a disappointment that I won't buy another Sid Meier game with anything but a spotless review. My question is did anyone that made this game even play a Civ game prior to it's release? If so, shame on you!

title: Not Recommended
comment: I loved CiV 5 and really wanted to love this game... but damnit, 2K is making that difficult!- The AI is not really smarter this time around. Erratic and irrational wars, denouncements to left and right and a trade system which is highly inconsistent.- There is no building queue and production options such as "wealth" and research is gone" so late game when you have a tone of cities it's spam central and each turn takes forever!!!- The UI is messy/looks bad.- The barbarians are out of control!! More often then not they spawn with a HUGE amount of units when the game starts, you fight 'em off, and then they make a come back ones a random civ sooner or later randomly decalres war on....

title: Not Recommended
comment: Simply put - it isn't fun. I loved the older Civs, but I am tired, too tired, of the broken AI.To release new iterations of this franchise without fixing the AI, means condamning it to be forever forgotten.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I am a die hard Civ 5 fan and i did not like this game, You can't really do anything with your citys you always have to be building amenities for your dumb people and as you may already know the ai is trash you are always being attacked by barbarians and the other civs will make the dumbest choices like declaring war on you for no reason.All in all just buy the complete edition of civ 5 when it's on sale

title: Not Recommended
comment: Pretty to look at, but still really rough to play.Graphics are nice, music is beautiful, improvements from V and before in regards to game mechanics.Unfortunately, I can't get through a game without a plethora of bugs, hang ups, and/or crashes. AI is moronic, denounces for no reason, goes to war but rarely attacks, etc.Glad I got it as a gift because I would not pay money for this game right now.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Unfortunately in this games current state, this game would not be something that I would be willing to recommend.Firstly, the games performance is fantastic, coming from early Civ V's consistent crashing and disconnecting in multiplayer, you will find Civ VI's loading screens and multiplayer performance a pleasant surprise after coming from Civ V. I have experienced absolutely no issues while playing this game.I feel that this game visually appears a bit crowded and difficult to decipher, the colours aren't very distinct from each other in some environments and when zoomed out the map kind of appears just like a big blob of very dull colours, when in environments like the desert however the game feels bright and visually appealing.There is something about it that I can't quite place my finger on, but with the current look of the game I struggle to get the same immersive feel that I can get in Civ V, possibly as a result of the new cartoonish art style that takes the game away from feeling like you're controlling an expansive empire and closer to the experience of a casual mobile game.Similar to a casual mobile game, the DLC are uninspiring, boring and honestly a complete waste of money. A single civilization and 'scenario' are hardly worth the $5 USD, especially if you intend on just having the DLC civilizations as an AI nation in your single player games.The AI are awful. There is simply no other way to put it. Diplomacy feels completely void of any real effect to the game, upon meeting an AI it is not whether they will be a vital ally or mortal enemy, but rather how long until you inevitably anger them to the point where they will hate you for the rest of the game? I have failed to have at least one successful alliance with any AIs in the game. Inviting their delegations appears to have no effect, and if it does, I would not know what it is, a feeling you will commonly have in this game where tool tips are either unhelpful or non-existant. Casus Belli system while welcome seems useless because worrying about your warmonger status is pointless due to the fact that everyone already hates you.In addition to the terrible diplomacy regarding other AI nations, the city-state system, while I actually appreciate the envoys that have been added to the game, losing the ability to pledge protection to a city state, be called into their wars and gift units to a city state makes it utterly useless to have any real alliance with them as you would be able to acheive in Civ V. You will now find yourself making the decision of declaring a war upon the AI invading the city-state itself and having a full scale war, or allowing them to destroy your faithful city-state ally, losing the ability to fight a form of proxy-war where you are providing units but not formally at war again allows Firaxis to continue to completely destroy any immersive feeling that may have existed in Civ VI.The UI is minimalist, and disappointing, things such as your GPT and science per turn are now presented as tiny little numbers in the top left corner. While this in itself is a bit annoying, as it really doesn't draw your attention like the previous Civ V top bar did, the real thing that disappoints me is the fact that when you are in negative GPT, it doesn't even change colour or warn you. You now have to keep up with the job of pulling out your magnifying glass every turn to see whether or not you are even making money. A similar experience with the new minimalist notifications, which again are completely unable to grab your attention with the crowded visuals of the game and you will frequently miss events.I thoroughly enjoy the new districts, religion and wonder changes, seeing your wonders stand tall next to your cities is fantastic and a great addition to the game, religion is similar to Civ V and works like a treat, the only fault that I would give it is the waves of missionaries that infect your land as you get further in the game as well as the poor AI 'agendas' which will leave you as an enemy forever despite any other diplomatic events that had occured if you do not match another nations religion.Overall, the words that I would use to describe this game is; disappointing and boring.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Sit comfy, i’m going to tell you a story.A story about me. A story from a simple worker. First, let me explain something. My life began in 250 Anno Domini, and yes, began is the right word. Taking aside the scientifical explanation ( and plethora of methaphysical contemplation of my own ) would be suitable for now, as I – Perun Of Kraków came to life on a very odd land. It always seemed eerie to me that people here can walk only in 6 directions, even when reminded that world exists as an unlimited space in which particles should be able to travel in any direction possible. Still, the people did not understand that. My only purpose seemed to be a worker and any sort of conversation with authorities seemed pointless, as proved in any occasion.The story begins in 966 Anno Domini. I was sent to build a mine, they said we needed the resource to create more powerful infantry that would finally destroy our enemy – the Civilization which was just next to Łódź. Feared by everyone, the mighty Romanians never seemed to give up, their constant pressure just outside our borders always threatened our stability.There we were, minding our business digging the dirt when suddenly – “PRRRRTTTT, PRRRRTTTT, PRRR, PRTTTTTTT” – I swear it was a dragon farting in our direction closer and closer. I never seen anything like this. A gigantic metal behemoth powered fully by farts and leaving a black trail behind it with every move it took. My co-workers stood fearlessly while I, seeing a thing almost as godly as the sun was mesmerized. It came really close. Then it opened its mouth… and from that mouth exits a man – Fredderick Barbarossa – a friend of our King. “ AGAIN – he says proudly – WIR EXTEND UNSERE HAND, BUT ZIS TIME IN FREUNDSCHAFT. WILL DU ACCEPT IT!? “.What the ♥♥♥♥ is happening. He looks at me without a slightest movement. “ WIR OFFER TRADE, EIN APFEL FOR IHRE OIL, COAL, MARBLE, IHRE SCHAUFEL UND DAS PAITING BY QIU YING. WIR ALSO WANT THE SANDALS OF HAJI HUUD”. No reaction so far from my co-workers. I chose to communicate. “Excuse me sir. I’m just a worker, though it seems this trade is a bit unfair, don’t you think?”. He looks at me and shouts magnificently – “PERHAPS ANOTHER ZEIT THEN”. He turns around in his behemoth on the adjacent tile and after a moment shouts at us – “ LET DAS BE KNOWN. DU IST EINEN ENEMY OF GERMONEY. PREPAER FUR A BLITZKRIEG”. Another minute passes and I still can’t process what happened.And then the Winged hussars came.“ KUUUUUUUUURRRRRRWAAAAAAAAA” – the mighty horsemen charging at the behemoth were surely a mesmerizing view. The destruction of them not so much. The Roman emperor looks at us from his Eiffel tower with disdain. Dwight Eisenhower, the great Polish general grabbed my arm, looked into my eyes and said the words I will never forget – “It is the rule in war, if ten times the enemy's strength, surround them; if five times, attack them; if double, be able to divide them; if equal, engage them; if fewer, defend against them; if weaker, be able to avoid them ”.I never was a historian but something seemed odd.Surrounded by chaos, destruction and pain I was surprised by our King – Jadwiga the Deformed ( Perhaps the uranium deposit right under the palace is not great for health, by what could I know, she is alive since 4000 BC ). She says – “ witam Fredderick. I offer peace. You will give me everything you have for my guarantee of non aggression pact for 10 minutes?”. “ DAS IS FAIR, HERR JADWIGA THE WISE. LET IT BE KNOWN DAS GERMONEY IS A FRIEND OF POLAN.”Have you ever had a feeling something is not right? Dwight Eisenhower ordered the archers to shoot at enemy dog and his owner and German archers were shooting at our stealth bombers. But it’s not that.Something was out of place.“ WSHHHSHHHSHHHHHHHHHHH” – A gigantic fallus was going straight to space.From the middle of Warszawa.And a single voice could be heard from our renowned scientist – Abu Al- Qasim Al- Zahrawi –“POLAN CAN INTO SPACE”.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Been playing civilization since the very first game, it seems the game reached its peak with civ5, civ 6 seems like it was rushed out, released incomplete, sluggish, unplayable, you name it, I can put 2k hours in civ 5 and still enjoy it, I played for about 150 hours constantly trying to make myself believe I'd get over the irrational AI, but it's impossible, firaxis has really been disappointing lately :( which is unfortunate, between the first 5 civ games I'd put nearly 20-50k of gameplay hours, but civ 6 is so frustrating and disappointing that I'd rather not play it at all.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game has been constantly buggy and the AI has been inexplicably terrible since launch. The UI has to be manually tweaked through files to be properly usable. Not recommended as a commercial product.The gameplay is mostly fine, though; it's a nice Civ experience with some new spice added. If you're okay with schizophrenic and terminally easymode AI, or only plan to play the game with humans, go for it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Personally, I've enjoyed this latest addition to the Civilization series, the focus on each civ's abilities and unique bonuses give the game a greater variety and emphasis on which civ the player chooses. At the same time, the bonuses of each civ are spread out so a certain civ isn't limited to a single victory type. Compared to previous civ games, the biggest changes are in the districts/wonders and diplomacy. I like the new requirements for wonders and the fact that they take a tile, as it prevents one civ from building all the wonders in a single city, although sometimes the requirements might be a little too picky (ie The Great Zimbabwe needing to be adjacent to a cattle resource and commercial hub) and often prevent wonders from being built until much later in the game. In terms of the diplomatic game changes, I'm surprised and slightly disappointed by the removal of diplomatic victory and world congress. I enjoyed the world congress in civ 5 and it needed some work, but it definately added to the gameplay. I enjoy the new casus belli system, and I think it could be developed further to add more reasons. An additional casus belli for claimed land and forward settling (if a couple requests to stop settling near a player in the future are ignored/denied or a promise is broken, a small casus belli could be added for any cities within 6 tiles of one your own cities) could be added to deter overly expansive ai/players.Biggest Complaints:The art style of the civs is chaotic ranging from decent to garbage- leaders such as gandhi recieved rediculous cartooned features, while victoria recieves atleast a somewhat realistic image, but still cartoon. I'd prefer a return to the attempts at realism in civ 4.Diplomatic relations are next to impossible, to be friendly with a civ, you must appeal to both of their agendas and even then any little thing can set them off, and a friendship doesn't really grant you anything-in civ 5 your friends might denounce those you denounce or even declare war with you, not so in civ 6, everyone denounces eachother and declare meaningless wars.Civ 6 is a decent game, but its not worth $50+, the price needs to be atleast halved to be worth it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just play Civ 5

title: Not Recommended
comment: All i have to say is just wait, wait for a sale or wait for the game to get better, right now its not as good as CIV V complete edition which is cheaper.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI is out for blood no matter what difficulty your on. It wont take long before you hate everyone but you.

title: Recommended
comment: This game has redefined nearly every mechanic from the previous game.It will take a while to readjust and re-learn how to play this Civilization.A lot of people complained about graphics. I think they are overreacting. Graphics are stylized and they are good.There is a day/night cycle which can be turned on/off to bring a little more dynamic to the world. The map itself is beautifully rendered.The problem is complexity of interface and gameplay. New players will find it easier to adjust but series veteran will have to re-learn the game. Nonetheless, it's better to have a new game than not have one.

title: Recommended
comment: In my opinion, the cartoonish look in the characters depicted and overall graphics was a step in the wrong direction from Civilization 5. However, the core gameplay mechnaics recived a huge change. The city managing and disctrict customization is new and refreshing, as well as seperate progress trees for Government and Technology. In a year's time when there will be more DLC, the game will more than likely be a true successor to Civilization 5. In the game's current state I would recommend it, but wait for a discount if you can.

title: Not Recommended
comment: (Civilization 6) is strictly better than (Civilization 5 + All DLC)Civ6 is truly a GOOD GAME. Brand new mechanics: cultural progress tree, city districts, governments, eurekas, intertwined with seriously reworked views on religion, espionage, trade routes, city states, unit movement system, etc. make the product luscious and charming. Indeed, the game became more engaging, exciting and realistic.I would say Civ6 even in its current state is better than Civ5 with a full DLC bundle.The game looks very similar to Civ5, especially, if you disregard the new visual style. Sometimes I think that Firaxis decided to switch to this cartoony graphic just in order to make people believe that it's totally a new game, while it's not.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I LOVED civ 5. I played it allot. I just can't seem to get into civ 6. The map alone is a turn off. The graphics are horrible. It feels in many ways the game has regressed rather than progress. other people have said it better than I could so i will leave that to them.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Alright, this review is based on both the base game and the Rise & Fall expansion. And, ufortunately, I don't recommend them—yet.First, some positives: the art really is impressive. I was uncertain about the more cartoony style, especially after the epicness of the Civ V art, but having played a lot of games now I have to say that Firaxis really did a great job. The detail is impressive and WYSIWYG makes a triumphant return. The result is a more living world with lots of interesting tidbits to discover. I'm still trying to find all the hidden Firaxis logos...Okay, but what about the gameplay? Eh. The expansion improved a lot of the things that were most frustrating in the base game. However, diplomacy is still shallow and little hard to understand. Combining units into formations is... busywork? As are the governors. Ugh. And the bonuses both these features provide are hard to figure out and underwhelming.But they really haven't figured out how to fix what I felt was the biggest downside of the base game: the end game is boring and undynamic. What I mean is that, compared to the end game in Civ V Brave New World, pursuing victory is a bit of slog, and the conditions don't affect one another. Pursuing tourism, for example, gets you no benefit other than closer to the cultural victory, unlike in Civ V where improved tourism came with benefits for science, trade, conquest, etc.Will they get this figured out after a third expansion? Probably. But for now, if you can wait out Firaxis, do.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ 6 has many improvements from Civ 5. These improvements include:DistrictsThe greatest improvement and the one feature that makes it hard to go back to civ 5 is districts. Districts take up a tile in your city and give you a bonus. When looking at your city from a distance you can see all the districts and wonders you have built. It makes your city seem alive and it makes where you settle a city much more important.Civic TreeIn civ 6 there are now two trees to research through, the tech tree and the civic tree. It makes researching more interesting.Eurekas and InspirationsEach tech and civic now has a task you can do to make it 50% faster to research. An example is kill a unit with a slinger to boost archery by 50%. These new mechanics make researching more competitive.You can now win the game by converting everyone to your religion. This can sometimes get annoying when an AI player rushs for a victory this way.Builders build improvements instantly but only have 3 uses. This change fits in with the district system better than workers.There are many other small improvements but those are the 5 big changes.Most of the negative reviews complain about about:The DLCs have the same price as the DLCs that were released in civ 5 so nothing has changed. Most of the DLCs (besides the expansion) only add in 1 or 2 new civs so they aren't really game changing so unless you want to play as one of those civs don't buy them.The digital deluxe edition never said it would include a expansion. It only said the first 4 DLC packs. It was later updated to 6.This is the one complaint that makes sense and that I actually agree with. The AI is not perfect. I think this is mostly because of their agendas which make it almost impossible to make all of them happy. However the game is still fun even with how the AI is. Hopefully it will be improved in future patches and updatesAnother major complaint ive seen in other reviews is the art style. In my opinion the art style in 6 is less cluttered than 5. It is a bit more cartoony than 5. However anyone whos played any other civ game than civ 5 knows that the civilization series isnt about the graphics, and that civ 5 was the only game in the series that had realistic graphics.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI SUCKS. During the early stages of my first game (playing emporer difficulty), a neighboring nation declared war on me suddeny and for no apparent reason. I built up my defenses expecting a army to attack... they never came. A few turns later i decided to start attacking my opponent. I gathered a few units and was able to take a barely guarded city at the edge of my opponents empire.Since i really didn't want to deal with war further, I started peace negotiations with my opponent. Can you guess what my rival offered me in exchange for peace? 6 of their 7 cities, including their existing CAPITAL. This lead to me absolutely domminating the match with almost no challenge whatsoever. When i saw this, my heart sunk because i sensed that something was dreadfully wrong with this game. Yet i kept on playing in hopes that these events were just a fluke. They Weren't.Almost every match I played after the one described above was plagued with horrible AI decsisions and just a lack of chellenge or fun. Any challenge the game does provide is a product of the AI being given cheese bonuses rather than making smart or strategic decsisions. The whole thing just feels manufactured, fake, and cheap.I was hoping the DLC would correct these problems. From the reviews i've seen others give that appears to not be the case. Extremely dissapointed. A terrible addition to an otherwise great series. Firaxis should focus less on shoehorning femal leaders and more on making a game with functioning AI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Do not buy CIV 61. It *starts out* 'streamlined' - meaning removal of features. No give or take in diplomacy, no way to negotiate a cease-fire between other civs. no unit list.2. It takes for freaking ever to load. Like nearly two minutes from an SSD. That's when it loads - for some reason after the first day I bought it it starts locking up on the load screens. As a matter of fact, 'slow' is the best way to describe everything in the game. You know how DVD's love to have animated menus that force you to wait several seconds before you can do anything? You know how those are neat the first time you see them and a complete pain in the♥♥♥♥♥for the rest of your life? Yeah, these aren't even neat the first time you see them. Just arbitrary delays before menu options appear.3. The AI is broken. No, I don't even know if its broken - I think its mainly an RNG with some slight modification due to leader traits. I've got guys telling me I'm a cultural backwater when I've got the highest culture rating and am a third of the way to a cultural victory and they're not even a blip. Another guy keeps telling me to be careful about debt - when I have a large income and a massive treasury. I get attacked by one guy, then when I don't agree to his piece treaty immediately everyone denounces me as a warmonger - the guy who hadn't fired a shot at anyone in 250 turns. None of it matters anyway - they're all going ot hate you if you start winning.4. The animated leaders are a marketing gimmick. They add nothing, you can't do anything until the animation is done playing and then wait for a long pause before the options menu comes up. Turn them off.5. Turns start off slow and get slower. Seriously.6. The options menu does not pause the game - seriously. I was trying to change a setting and kept getting interrupted by leaders telling me what a horrible person I was for defending myself.TL;DR - there's a few neat ideas in here, but the series peaked at CIV4 and has been going downhill. I blame consolization.Verdict: Not worth it, even on saleEDIT:So, I've put some more time in and . . . nothing's changed.I just played a Huge game on Normal speed, Hardest difficulty. 6500 years and a single war. And that war was declared, 10 turns later 4 units showed up, i killed them, 5 turns later they sued for peace.Have had one Leader (the Greek Female) *constantly berating me for 'backing down and giving in' - when I had done no such thing. Ever. Never a reason to because the only agressive people in the game were the barbarians.I've had a guy tell me off for running a debt - with 5000 gold and a 500 gold/turn income *and* not not having bought anything at all for at least 10 turns.Guys thanking me for fighting off barbarians - when the last battle I had had with the barb was 30 turns earlier.Trading? Way screwed up. These guys are willing to give you 30 - 50 gold a turn for a luxury item. And its easy to game the system as it will tell you exactly what they will and will not accept. What they offer is so low-balled compared to what you can get them to go for its disgusting.This is just a bad game.Oh, and it has that ♥♥♥♥ing annoying 2k thing where you get the 'do you want to log on to your 2k account now?' popup. Screw you guys. Frankly, this is it for 2k as far as I'm concerned. You're going into the 'do not buy games from this publisher' bin along with Ubisoft. I'm tired of your♥♥♥♥♥♥

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ VI is hardly good even for a tablet version.I was super excited while awaiting this game. Civ fun since Civ 2, I can't survive such a huge disappointment. I spent 2 hours playing singleplayer campaign and comparing my impressions with Civ IV and Civ V experience.The conclusion in unforgiving. Civ VI is less interesting, beautiful and attractive as previous titles. The whole look of the game is disgusting. Low resolution models on a maximum graphics, horrible cartoon unit animations with "KABOOM" effects and so on.The interface is cheap and icons are rude. Ah, too much pain writing this.The development of the city loss the handy interface from Civ V and becomes clunky. This can be appealed to all mechanics. I just can't understand, how this could happen.AI is just stupid. Barbarians captured the worker and leave it be. He was just standing few turns, I skip few more, nothing changes. Also, they don't like to pillage. Other Civilization start a war with just 1 catapult and warrior, that was standing still. Other Civ starts a war with tons of chariots, that need to overcome like 25 hexes. Only one can managed to do it.Unfortunately, it seems for me as a degradation of the series: graphics, gameplay and optimizations seems much poorer then in previous titles. So sad. Maybe, they made a tablet version and somehow sold it as full PC release.Refound.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Cartoony graphics and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ UI make the game completely unplayable. It's impossible to get any meaningful information just from looking at at anything at a glance like in Civ 5. It's now impossible to tell the difference between a tile with hills on it and a normal tile, and the new gimmicky fog of war graphic means you now can't tell the differences between different tile types. The insane levels of saturation make me feel like I'm going to vomit, and the unit models look like something out of Clash of Clans. Do you want to actually be informed of notifications you receive? Forget about that! Do you want to be able to see tribal villages when you "discover" them? You're out of luck. This piece of garbage is a downgrade from Civ 5, and I woudn't recommend anyone to waste their money on it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've been playing Civilization for 25 years, and there are no other game that I enjoy more to play. I'm perfectly aware that all civs have problems on release, and over the time they always made it perfect, I'm counting with it too on this one, and I believe that Civilization VI will become a great game, but at this point, the game is not yet playable, it's very nice in the first hours, but soon, the lack of a zoom out and the huge icons bad designed and placed over the units will turn it into an annoying experience. Wait a few months if you want to play it, but at this point it feels more like a good game in an early beta test with an awfully childish design.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've got a massive list of complaints about civ6, like somehow despite being the newest game in an over 20 year old franchise, somehow the AI may actually be at its worst and most annoying. a religion system that is unrewarding at best, and downright annoying most of the time. I could go on for several pages about all the issues i have with this game. however, at the end of the day the bottom line is "was it fun?" personally, when it comes to video games, i think that is the ultimate question that should be asked. was the game fun? i liked civ1, i loved civ2 and 3, civ 4 gave me years worth of fun, and despite my initial complaints civ5 turned out was pretty fun too. civ6 however, just simply was not fun. i had no fun whatsoever playing it. in fact it was so incredibly un-fun, that by the end of my 3rd match, it felt like i was toiling away at work, rather than relaxing at home with a video game. this game feels like work, and its work that only costs you, and takes from you, with little reward or benifit, you get nothing out of it.... a worst case senario for a game, in my opinion. i mean if i wanted to feel like i was working.... i would just go to work, at least there i will get paid. i will get some reward for my work. civ6 was just a laborious chore that only wasted my time.so TLDR, Civilization VI, just is not any fun to play.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Lots of neat ideas and improvements in this game, but the one has one fatal flaw- and one which is unlikely to be patched. The AI is beyond pathetic- it can't play the game at all, and what it does is illogical on top of that.This is a game you'll comp stomp once or twice, and unless you're interested in MP, there's no reason to play beyond that.

title: Not Recommended
comment: DO NOT BUY IF YOU ARE NEW TO CIVI will only be touching on the changes in respect of Civ VPROS-the Civics are a cool idea-Leader animations are pretty dope-the new particle system is amazing and also the new sounds-multiplayer isn't terrible, unlike civ 5-major improvement to the spy systemCONS-Firstly, and the most annoying issue by far is that the developers honestly don't even touch the A.I, they have been dumb as a brick for the past 3 games and i have not seen an improvment, almost like the devs don't care about challenging the older fans of the series.-turn 5 in a game and 3 A.I players declare war on me... wait for it.... FOR NO REASON-Again, A.I is so bad that every war is winnable, regardless of Army size.-The new system for handling strategic resources is just what i call "making a game noob freindly" in a beg to draw a larger crowd. 1 uranium will allow you to now build infinite amount of nukes.-Some Leader perks are just useless, honestly.-THE GAME HAS LESS UNITS! no more Cruise missiles, stealth bombers or Mechs. Paratroopers? naa gone pal. Xcom? nope. much more are missing.-Forces you to have a small, peace loving army (i'll expalin this later)-The economics of the game have not been thought through, the numbers are most likely to be arbitrary at best. even if you focus on "commerce", you will go bankrupt since even having the smallest of armies will run a very high cost! it isn't as cheap as it was in CiV 5.-The game forces you to have a wide amount of building in your cities, without these buildings the cities will rebel! So bye bye cities that you want to create for a set goal.-It's easy for your cities to starve, trust me.-Wtf is hosuing all about, terrible idea-you have to wait 10 turns before peace deal can be sent.-the game forces you to have city states on, ALWAYS!-the new FOW is good and bad, it's pretty to look at but annoying when it's in the corner of your eye.-Also Subs can no longer hide under ice... not many would know about this anyway.-also LESS BUILDINGS!Summary; half of what Civ 5 has at a AAA cost.

title: Recommended
comment: Having played all version of Civilization (mobile and console included) for more than 100 hours each, I can confidently say that this is the best and my most favourite Civilization game to date. The district system and revamped tech and civic trees breath new life into one of the most addicting games in the world. Gone are the mid game lulls, permanent warmonger penalties (for the most part) and restrictions on building a wide empire early on from Civ 5. You can tailor your experience to the way you want to play now more than ever so long as you make sure to take care of those pesky barbarians.The game is not without it's faults however. The late game, while much more engaging than previous games due to revamped victory conditions, can drag on a bit if you are not at war. The AI is also not yet competent enough at invading a human controlled player and they also receive ridiculous bonuses on higher difficulties. The game also has a problem with displaying information. For example, you will not be notified of expired trade deals, potential trade routes or even a sidebar notification for barbarians (you receive an audio cue, but sometimes it's not enough if you are playing music or playing the game on mute). This is also not a game for the casual gamer. It demands hours of your time and only after the first 40-50 hours will you begin to grasp most of the mechanics at play (even as a Civ veteran. Longer if you are not), some which you will discover on your own, others that are buried within the game's manual and civilopedia. Don't let this discourage you though. These faults are not enough to drag down an otherwise fantastic game and there is still a ton of content on the horizon.The game as is, is already more feature packed than Civ 5 after 2 expansions. The game is growing better with each update and soon will set the gold standard for all future strategy games similar to the Civilization series. I cannot recommend any stragegy game on PC more than this one right here. You will not be dissapointed.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is awesome, I can't wait to play 200+ hours of the game and keep playing it over and over again for years to come. All these recent negative reviews are ridiculous and those that wrote them are pathetic, how dare they play so much of the game and then complaining that the company made too much DLC for the game they clearly love so they can enjoy even more. Entitled people that think they should get someone else's hard work for free can go play one of those crappy free to play games while I enjoy this high quality AAA game and all the content they are willing to make EXTRA content for the game at a pretty reasonable price. Or you could, oh I don't know, browse and use any of the over 500 workshop mods for the game for FREE.Me and my wife love playing Civilization games together and can't wait to play so much of this one as well.

title: Not Recommended
comment: A straight downgrade from Civ 5. Maybe it will follow the civ tradition and have every expansion back be a great overhaul of the system, but as it currently stands this game simply isn't worth full price.Visuals: the most subjective category, but I find this game wholly unappealing artistically. The Civ leaders look like pixar rejects and the landscapes are bland and uninspired.UI: The UI is a mess, with often incredibly important information hidden or poorly represented. It also takes an egregious amount of clicks to accomplish simple tasks, like re-assigning spies to a location they are already at. Individually this wouldn't matter as much but the number and rapidity of it across a 300+ turn game is very aggravating.Music: Seems like it's mostly variations of the same track modified over the years. After my first game I was already muting in favor of a playlist in the background. Also the quotes are garbage.AI: Arguably the most incompetent released in the franchise, at least this decade. If you played civ 5 at X difficulty you can basically bump it up by 1-2 in Civ 6 because outside of early game rushes the AI is completely worthless at waging a war. Also, AI are pretty much insane, and establishing reliable relationships with one is all but impossible. Bonus points; even if you do succeed in this, they will still arbitrarily declare war on you just because. There is no late-game diplomacy akin to the U.N., so by industrial period most everyone dislikes you but it doesn't actually affect anything, turning the end of the game into a monotonous slog.Game mechanics: Aside from the fact that the game is still significantly unbalanced, there are many problems plaguing this title. The change to workers being charged base means you have to waste time spamming them into your build queues, but doesn't really add anything to the game in terms of enjoyment or skill, it's just micro-management for its own sake. Wonders take a ridiculous time to build (50-80 turns) and take up a tile, so they're often not worth it at all. Districts, what should have been the great new addition to the title, have mostly been relegated to a few essentials that are spammed forever due to the aforementioned imbalance. Lastly, the removal of any kind of happiness or corruption mechanic means that every empire will go wide every single game because there are no reasons not to. While going tall was a bit too reliable in Civ 5, swinging hard the other way isn't actually better.At the end of the day, I kick myself for buying this game so soon after launch. Take my advice and just tide yourself over with something else until they bother to fix this mess, because until then it's really not worth your time or money.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I will answer one and simple question: should you buy this gorgeous, intriguing and filled with innovations game NOW? The answer is NO, and here's why: crippled AI, balance issues, interface issues, tons of things are not explained properly, some nasty bugs, lack of map filters, unit lists, nearby enemy notifications etc.Civ superfans like myself have already got the game and enjoying it, for the rest it would be wise to wait for several updates and pick this 9/10 game when it's polished and discounted.

title: Recommended
comment: I've been playing religiously since Civ 3 with a collective 2500+ hours into the series and dabbled with Civ 1 (SNES) and Civ 2. I've put in 420+ hours into Civ 6 so far. I paid full price upon release for the digital deluxe edition. I am satisfied with its current direction and look forward to seeing this game improve with future expansions and as the selection of mods are refined and added upon.Many are quick to compare this newest installment to its fully fleshed out predecessor Civ 5 and complain that it's a step backwards. However, there's almost 7 years difference between both games. There's tons of expansions, DLCs, and mod development between them.Historically, every new release of Civ had an incubation period before it outdid its fully fleshed-out predecessor. I remember very well how much Civ 5 was lambasted by the community upon release - people were calling it the death of the series. After expansions, it's now hailed as the pinnacle of the series.Civ 6 has enough improvements (and yes, some regressions) for early adopters to enjoy and turn a blind eye to its drawbacks until it improves with the expansions. If you want to play a fully fleshed out and cheaper Civ, play 5. If you want to experiment with new features and can tolerate the drawbacks, play 6.I'm of the opinion that Civ 6 is a great entry into the series despite its initial flaws. I really enjoy the implementation of districts. I think each civ feels distinguishable in their play styles, and they feel relatively balanced - I feel you can use anyone and focus on a set of possible victory types that are best suited for that civ and make it work. Believe it or not, I'm actually a fan of the agendas too. The barbs are actually manageable despite what people say, albeit it takes way more micromanagement than in previous Civ games. The civ AI is really not that much different from Civ 5 in terms of challenge, I think. Warmongering penalties in my opinion make sense since they've last updated it, although I like using a mod that eliminates penalties in the Classical era in addition to the standard Ancient era - just my personal preference. I also use a mod that slows down science and civic progression by 2x while keeping building and unit production costs standard so I get to spend more time in each era. I do feel that they need to tweak the pace of production vs. culture vs. science. I think science and civics progress way too quickly to make use of newly trained units before they become obsolete - that said, the 2x "Take Your Time" mod does a good job of remedying that.Which brings me to my next point, a lot of the things people complain about are actually easily addressed with popular and well-maintained Steam Workshop mods (or outside of Workshop). Lack of a restart button to re-roll maps? There's a mod for that. Production queue? There's a mod for that. Crappy UI? There's mods for that. Better contrast for the fog of war? A mod for that. More challenging and 'smarter' AI? - Mod. For. That. - I could go on...Yes, absolutely there are some known bugs (even without mods). For one, you can immediately make peace with a hostile city-state after their suzerain declares war on you - this is to your advantage in single player anyway, so at least it's not frustrating, but it does break multiplayer a tiny bit if you intend to be competitive. Also, if you've conquered an AI civ's city, there's a bug that makes the negative "occupying their city" modifier stick, even if you trade that conquered city away to another civ. Finally, the game will crash on occasion, but for me its been pretty reliable thus far. It happens mostly when I alt-tab a lot.Besides bugs and crashes, there's some poorly planned out mechanics. My prime example is as follows: you can build a district on a tile, and later on if a strategic resource appears on the same tile, you'll still be able to use that resource without issues - great. However, should you want to build a district on a tile with a newly discovered resource that cannot be harvested (such as coal), then having discovered that new resource essentially blocks you from using what was previously a valid tile to build the district on. It just doesn't make a whole lot of sense.I'm confident that those above-mentioned issues will be addressed in due time. My one and only gripe about Civ 6 that can't really be fixed is the art direction and aesthetic of the 3D assets (units, tile sets, buildings, etc. - the civ leaders I think are actually really well done). I wish they had stuck with and expanded upon the more realistic look of Civ 5. I'm really not digging the cartoony look, and I admit, it makes me feel like they focus-grouped it to make the game more appealing to the mass market. That said, it's still objectively pretty to look at and relaxing.Reading some of the other comments on here, I feel that some of the grievances are misplaced. When I look at this 'vanilla' release compared to the disaster of Civ 5's initial release, this one is a much bigger improvement by that standard, and with time, I'm sure we're going to be revisiting the same cyclical narrative and hailing Civ 6 with expansions as the pinnacle of the series and bickering about how Civ 7 is a step backwards.Just make sure that when you buy Civ 6 that you are willing to take on the experience and with some expectation to get frustrated or underwhelmed with some of its aspects, but at least know that it's going to get better with age. I trust Firaxis enough at this point to have that much faith in them.

title: Recommended
comment: I understand the mixed reviews. In the beginning, I too was frustrated by the idiot child AI and the persitent crashing that plagued me after a few hundred game moves. Both of which, mind you, required lengthy restarting and reloading sequences.(!) Despite all this, I still managed to log nearly 300 hours, because the game is a truck load of fun! I usually don't care if I win or lose, as long as I get to build my cities and wonders without the moron AI interrupting me with inane banter then crashing if I try to cancel their dialog prompts too quickly. They can also be stubborn♥♥♥♥♥mules if they want your city-state. Truth be told these annoyances, while frustrating, are few and far between; except for the city-state thing. Most of your time is spent buidling beautiful, sprawling, unique cities with intricaltely crafted animations and gorgeously detailed landscapes.Since it's release, the game has been improved through updates and DLC. Sadly much of the AI interaction here feels pretty hackneyed and that's a missed opportunity. When you see the graphics you'll realize where most of your dollars were spent. The game looks and runs fantastically smooth on in 21.9. (brag) Everything about the game graphically, is top notch. The day/night cycle, the smoke, the fires, the characters, and the geography, it all looks amazing! The audio is excellent too. Every player action carries a sublimely satisfying sound cue. Sean Bean is also excellent as the narrator. His subtle and dramatic interpretations of popular quotes and phrases are often compelling. Rarely do I tire of his reading of Monty Python, but after many many plathroughs, I yearn for variety. I really liked the non-fictional/educational aspects of the game.Long Story Short: It's beautiful looking and it sounds great, but it can be dumb at times. I'm looking at you city-states. It's an improvement over its predecessors in many ways, but the AI is flat. If you enjoy sim city-esque city building, and/or RTS, you'll really enjoy this game. You can build a city, an army, a navy, and an airforce then blow the crap out of barbarians and annoying AI, or you can buff your spies and steal all their cool♥♥♥♥♥♥ I've played both IV and V, and this one hooked me more than those could. 287 hours worth of salty fun, peppered with occasional aggravation.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game has so much potential, but the developer has completely wrecked it. It is completely destroyed as of Fall 2017.Summer 2017 broke the game fundamentally, introducing several UI bugs and completely breaking AI diplomacy: AI would never join alliance or trade away their whole empire for one painting. In spite of game being unplayable in this state, we had to wait 3 months for next update, Fall 2017.With Fall 2017, some bugs were fixed (the diplomacy apparently not completely) but the game now crashes to desktop frequently.No reviewer would have given it a pass if they had the game in such a state.

comment: Longtime CIV player (started with 3 and have played the series religiously since). While I think there is a solid basis here and it is a fun game, the lack of mod tools makes me unwilling to recommend the game to CIV 5 players. It doens't offer enough new content on its own to replace CIV 5 and without the ability to mod it myself and play others' mods, it really wasn't worth the purchase to me.That being said, it's certainly not a bad game and was released in a more finished and interesting state than most civ games are. If the lack of workshop content isn't a big deal to you, go ahead and pick it up. I had fun for a few games and ended up going back to CIV 5 and 4 again. I'll be back to give CIV 6 a more honest go once the mod tools and workshop are up.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Was a huge fan of Civ 5....played it for a long time...this seems like a childlike downgrade from the previous games. The graphics are derpy and cartoonish, the AI seems very sensitive and easily gets offended at minor things. They took a lot out of this game and replaced it with minimal shiny objects which are pleasent for two or three turns until you have a large landmass of pointless things.The biggest thing that bothers me is there is no exploration like the old civ games...at the start you fart to your left and meet another leader, grunt to your right and bump into another, the third walks into your borders on turn 4...and thats on a huge map. Huge map is now roughly half the size of the old ones by the looks of things, making it seem very quick and pushed. The city states are more independant on this one and not as "please protect me" which is good...but when you offer to work with one...2 or 3 other leaders sulk because they can't addapt to being civil with one another...Ghandy still loves nukes and being a C-U-N-T.Overall, this needs to be revised in a few areas, stop being an elementary school learning software and buff up the realism of leaders being selfish, self preservative a-holes democracy controlling the media...would like to see the visuals ammended to being more realistic and the AI being more human-like alongside some good old fashioned Civ and not the sims 5 which is cautious to offend anyone.4/10...

title: Recommended
comment: So, starting out, I think Civ 5 is better (with all of its expansions). However, I've put many hours now into Civ 6 and I do think it is fun, and overall I would recommend. I think the game can be much better, and I do hope they fix stuff moving forward.Positives:- Graphics/art direction are really nice- Loooove Sean Bean in this- Gameplay is overall easy to learn and at its most fun when playing against other humans.- I like the idea of the religious war/victory- I really like the districts and the fact that you can't spam wonders (that they take a tile per each). I like the increased strategy that comes along with the district and wonder building and planning out your cities.- I like the different civilizations in the game so far, they each are pretty fun and each has a slightly different play style which has been fun to learn and try to do well with.- I think tile strategy has been improved with the amenity and appeal systems.Negatives- The religious victory and fighting is too simplistic.- The AI is the biggest drawback IMO. They are really stupid about diplomacy, will often give you their great works for pennies, are weird about trading, and dumb about war. The way the AI agendas are implemented by them seems to be poorly thought out. How the AI treats religion is one of the most annoying aspects of this game. As soon as they get religion, they will generate somehow like 3000 missionaries and spam your cities. The only way to deal with this is to either work to up your faith output so as to buy apostles (which may or may not even win trying to kill them before they die themselves), or you have to declare war on them to kill them with military units. If you are trying for a cultural or scientific victory, this is an incredibly annoying distraction.- The city/empire size balance is non-existent. Civ 5 allowed you to win with just one city. Civ 6 basically demands you build a ton of cities.- Cultural and scientific victories can take too long and be a little boring. They both need to be a little more special or have more nuance.- There is no production queue like there was in Civ 5. I would really love to see that make its way into this game.- Like Civ 5, team play is not well implemented.- The espionage system needs help - the spies rarely seem that useful.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I gave Civ VI another play through and I still don't recommend it because the game is too narrowly focused on starting location-- it just doesn't have enough balance. In Civ V, getting the best start location in multiplayer helped, but in Civ IV, you NEED certain tiles near your start location. Since chaining Eureka bonuses relies havily on certain resources being nearby, you need a good start to get tech boosts; without those, it will take you twice as long to research a tech as someone who might just have better access near their start location. Tech progression alone dramatically increases the effect of a good or bad start location compared to Civ V. Similarly, not having a certain strategic resource near your starting location could hamstring your ability to build an army (or even defend against barbarians) for an entire era since some eras have multiple units requiring the same resource (nitre, being key for a while). The new amenities feature replacing happiness seems under-developed, and success in amenities depends heavily on your starting location. If you get a bad start and it will be impossible to keep your people happy no matter what your play style, and you'll eventually get rebel barbarians spawning in your territory. War weariness then makes the game un-fun to play-- in the old games, when things weren't going your way, you could at least try to do some damage, maybe wrest a city or two from an adversary-- here, the war weariness will produce barb units in your territory faster than your best cities could produce similar units, and these will pillage every tile while your army is away fighting (or even winning) a war. The time scale is also off-- multiplayer quick games on small maps in Civ V could usually be finished in four hours if people kept the game moving. In Civ VI, it takes drastically more turns to produce anything, creating even slower gameplay; this extended production scale not only increases the effectiveness of units versus building a strong civ, but it also makes even quick games take longer, which means most multiplayer won't be able to be completed in a single afternoon. The formula for unit disbanding is much more unforgiving in this game, such that if your treasury ever dips even slightly below zero, you may lose several units a turn, instantly eliminating the effort of some twenty or thirty turns it took to produce those units. This is not at all fun-- especially because a single spy might steal from the treasury, destroying an army in one chain reaction of disbanding events. There are a number of things I would classify as bugs-- a heavy drone of mechanized units versus other background sounds or unit sounds not playing on some zoom levels-- both are jarring. Also, in single-player the AI will ask for peace nearly every trun, or to send you some emisarries, no matter how many times you say no; if there were an option to turn off the cutscenes, this might be tolerable, but the repetition quickly eats away any enjoyment of interacting with AI civs in general.
