title: Not Recommended
comment: Was a huge fan of Civ 5....played it for a long time...this seems like a childlike downgrade from the previous games. The graphics are derpy and cartoonish, the AI seems very sensitive and easily gets offended at minor things. They took a lot out of this game and replaced it with minimal shiny objects which are pleasent for two or three turns until you have a large landmass of pointless things.The biggest thing that bothers me is there is no exploration like the old civ games...at the start you fart to your left and meet another leader, grunt to your right and bump into another, the third walks into your borders on turn 4...and thats on a huge map. Huge map is now roughly half the size of the old ones by the looks of things, making it seem very quick and pushed. The city states are more independant on this one and not as "please protect me" which is good...but when you offer to work with one...2 or 3 other leaders sulk because they can't addapt to being civil with one another...Ghandy still loves nukes and being a C-U-N-T.Overall, this needs to be revised in a few areas, stop being an elementary school learning software and buff up the realism of leaders being selfish, self preservative a-holes democracy controlling the media...would like to see the visuals ammended to being more realistic and the AI being more human-like alongside some good old fashioned Civ and not the sims 5 which is cautious to offend anyone.4/10...

title: Not Recommended
comment: I wish I could give this game a nutral review. I love the Civ franchise, so I gladly bought this game when It was on sale for sixty bucks for the digital delux edition. The game is ok but definately not worth the price it's currently at, at this stage in development. In Civ five I could go for hours, but this game gets extremely repetitive after you play a few games. If it was at the price of Civ 5 I would recomend it, or if you have many friends. title: Not Recommended
comment: I've clocked in many hours in Civ III and V single-player, and I've thouroughly enjoyed my experience in them. Civ VI however, it hasn't given me a sense of enjoyment from single-player. It's bad, real bad...Pros:+the game looks gorgeous! The art is very stylized, and I find the cartoony-ness charming+City States aren't a complete pain in the♥♥♥♥♥anymore, and they actually give you cool little bonuses from being best buds with them+I like the districts, I find it adds a layer of depth that the previous ones didn't quite have+Workers have limited uses, meaning that they don't wander around with nothing to do late-game+Eureka's and Inspirations are kinda sweet+Barbarians definitely got an upgrade, they are absolutely bruuuuutal!Cons:-I honestly have no clue how Amneties work. I've been playing for like, 15 hours and I still have no clue-The map is stylized and nice, but it also makes it really confusing, and the mini-map is borderline incomprehensible.- You know when someone else builds a wonder that you are and builds it before you and you at least get some gold or production back in previous civs? No longer, all you get is a little dirt circle where you were building. You get absolutely nothing.-The music isn't that great... (except that awesome main menu music)And then the piece-de-resistance of the cons...The AI is horrendous! That new system they added that makes them look favourably or disfavourably at you depending on how you're building your civ sucks beyond all possible belief. They constantly harass you about "not focusing in art" or "not having any spys" and they are willing to go to war with you if you have a low production or some stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥like that.And when they go to war with you, (which they most certainly will) you cannot make a peace treaty, You just can't. Even when they're losing. It turns into a long grindy war, barbarians will sprout up everywhere because your people are absolutely miserable. All you can do is wait until they want to declare peace. And speaking of war...Religious warfare absolutely sucks! The AI always seems to have a million Missionaries and Apostles, and all you can do is just wait until they convert one of your cities, and just take it back with an Inquisitor. And when you start showing up at their door with your missionaries, they get all huffy and denounce you, and then some wiesenheimer will declare war on you because of it. Good idea, garbagey exectuion.In short, the main reason that this is getting a not recommended from me is that the AI is hellishly bad, it makes single player almost unplayable...If you're planning on mainly playing multiplayer, then I can probably say go ahead and buy it. I mean, it's still Civ, right?If you play single-player a bunch like me though, I just can't recommend this. Wait until a few patches or the next expansion. Use Civ V to get your Civ fix in the mean time...

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have played Civ V for over 100hrs with my friend, and we were so looking forward to the release of Civ VI. We both pre-ordered it. The day finally came and boom! No pre-game alliance allowed (i.e. no team selection option). Imagine how frustrated we were when we saw that. And it turned out that the feature existed, but just got turned off before the release.One week passed and no patch came up. So why would you sell us a game that's incomplete when you are even unable to fix it in a reasonable amount of time?Just fix all the freaking problems or return us the money.

I don't feel its a serious game unlike civilization 1 - 5.What do i like? not much tbh.The intro is good.Music is goodSean Bean is good, BUT not as good as leonard nimoy in civ 5.I think this says enough about my opinion on this game, sadly i do not like it. Ive wasted money here.

I understand a game having access to my system info such as CPU and graphics card data to aid them in future development but Civ wants to access my browsing history and any other information they think they can sell and store that information offshore where they may not have the same privacy laws we do and because they're busy THEY MAY USE A THIRD PARTY TO COLLECT THAT DATA. WTF... I paid for this game not like some Google product I use for free.

comment: I like it overall, although it still has bugs, supposedly buggy multiplayer (haven't tried it yet myself), etc.Pros:- I like the new city and district building system overall (although dunno, having to build wonders, except for some, is kinda meh)- I like that there are different wars which reduce warmongering status- Return of governments (Although personally, I'd rather give them just bonuses, and where players could choose their government positions regardless of the 'color' of position cards)- More inter-civ diplomatic stuff- Love me the soundtrack, especially the main theme and Kalinka song russians haveNeutrals:- Graphics are more cartoony. Not bad, but dunno, most leaders look silly!Cons:- Bugs. (Example: Leaders telling me I'm a warmonger despite someone else declaring a war on me, never capturing any city)- It can get slow in the late game.- Could use more soundtracks- Most wonders could still be built 'in the city centre' instead of around the city, since you could probably use those other areas for more things. (Of course, some wonders should still be there instead of districts/farms/etc)

title: Recommended
comment: When I saw that they had announced a new CIV game and I then saw that it wasn’t going to be some silly space or other type of strategy game I was ecstatic. Then when I got to some of the screenshots I was less so. Once I saw the new art style I was less excited and even considering ignoring the game completely, but that was a stupid idea as you shouldn’t judge a book by its cover, and to be fair it has grown on me.Now this game is great right now and works very well. There are some things that are missing that use to be in CIV 5, but mainly they’re not a problem for me. The only thing that I miss is the World Congress. There are some minor features that I never used, but were very popular and to be fair not hard to add into the game that should have been there, like being able to name cities. With that being said though there are many, many more things that have been added that make the game better. I now feel that all the different types of victory are much more achievable and interesting. Along with the improved victories there are also some change to the policies and civics that are amazing. They have now moved items that are less tech related and more civic related into their own tree, this makes everything a lot, lot better as it means that less time is being wasted on techs that aren’t really techs. The new policy system is great. Instead of choosing a tree to follow you instead choose a government style like democracy, fascism or communism and then you have a certain amount of policies you can assign and type of policies depends on the government style. So a fascist government will be able to have more military policies than the others. I also like the new way roads are built. And one of the last things that I love before I move onto the negatives is the new way that wonders are built. This new system is great and makes displaying and showing the wonders off amazing. Instead of it just saying that you’ve built a wonder it will now give you a short movie of its construction along with a quote. This is great. And the new levelling for units is great.Now for some of the negatives. There are some minor features that are missing that should be in, like the city naming, and other such things, but I never really used most of these so I haven’t noticed their disappearance. I do miss the world congress. And they still haven’t really fixed AI war. They’re more aggressive when they declare war on you, which I like, but when you ally with them they’re not much use. They’re defence is a lot better though. And the new builders are interesting, I like the way they work, but I also find that I am missing out on a lot of work tiles because I can’t find them. And this use to be fixable as you would just set a work to auto and they’d hook it up.So all in all I would recommend this to anyone. Whether they’ve played CIV 5 or never even played a CIV I would still recommend it to them. To be honest with all the recent games that have come out I’ve been disappointed, but this one of the only ones that I don’t regret it at all.Great game.Great new features and systems.Some minor issues.9/10

title: Not Recommended
comment: Worst CIV game yet, sadly.You now have to research ways to declare war - and cannot avoid the horriic "religion" game dynamic. Why does this matter? because the AI will spawn dozens of missionary units, who will just stand around your cities, blocking your units, blocking your trade routes, preventing you from building improvements..You can't attack them, you can't move them, you can't do anything but sit there and watch your cities die, turn by turn. After spending 20 or more turns unable to do *ANYTHING* other than sit and watch my cities die, I gave up in disgust.Beyond Earth was shoddy, poor quality and no fun to play. I had really hoped that CIV VI would be more like V, with updated graphics, rather than like Beyond Earth, with essentially no fun game play.Shame I was wrong. I want my money back, which I can't get, sadly. Only in the field of computer games can you pay so much for such a crappy, no good product, and not have any recourse.

comment: If you wonder why the stream rating is so low, there are mainly 2 reasons:1) The developer made quite some radical changes and people tend to hate change ("OMG!!! I CANNOT EMPLOY THE SAME STRATEGIES AS IN THE LAST CIV. THE DEVS ARE HORRIBLE PEOPLE AND EAT BABIES!!!!!")2) The AI is currently pretty bad. That's a fact. And it is indeed an annoying one. (Update: After the patch the AI got a little better. Still it is far from being strong)After a few mods and tweaks, this will be the best CIV in the series. I don't see any way around that. It is already a great game and the changes they made over the previous CIVs are amazing! Everything fits neatly into place. The only reason for me to pick CIV4 or CIV5 over this is the AI. And I am sure they gonna fix this soon!

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have been a civ fan since CIV2, CIV6 is one of the most anticipated game of the year for me. I decided not to write a revewi untill I have some serious play hours. Now I have played 26 hours straight into this game. I have to say DO NOT buy this game in its current formBad:1) Unbearable AI, there is no characteristics whatsever and the AI is even much worse than CIV5 IMO, the entire diplomatic aspect needs an over-haul.2) AI just attack you (or stop attacking) for no reason at all, and this stupid act of war just lasts none stop.3) The spy system is broken IMO, you simply cant defend enemy spy attack in a reasonable way4) Enemy AI is beyond stupid, entire army of catapult and range attack units just move back and forth for no reason, and I can take them all out with 2 archer.5) Wonders are simply not wonderous at all, way too plain6) There is no way to defend Nuclear attackGood:Like the new district settingNukes are finally being deadly in the right way

title: Recommended
comment: TLDR: Civ 6 is a solid and fun addition to the civ series. Pro - Polished, features complement each other, civ gameplay that gives the "one-more-turn-phenomenon." Con - AI cannot handle features and 1 unit per tile. Diplomacy is still bad. Late game usually falls flat like previous Civ games. The UI is worse than Civ 5 UI.Civ 6 pros and cons, and mixed feelings...Pros:In my opinion, all of the games features work well together. It feels like a really complex, well-made board game. New mechanics/systems that I think work well include the new workers, civics, governments, the appeal mechanic, housing and aminities.Cons:Mixed feelings:Civ 6 is a solid civ game. I have been playing civilization series since civ 3, and I have enjoyed all of them. Its hard for me to pick a favorite, but if forced to I would have to pick civ 4. I have put hundreds of hours into each, and I think each of them had strengths and weaknesses.Civ 6 was probably the best launch of any civ game I played. It was a complete game from the start. People say it is missing features, but honestly it has a ton of features. It added a lot of new mechanics, kept most old mechanics/systems, has good graphics, and maintained the hex grid/1 unit per tile game play that made civ 5 unique and complex.With all this in mind, I want to address the complaint most people bring up with every civ game. The AI. From this point, I will mainly be discussing the Civ 6 AI, and it is more of a discussion rather than a review.The civ 6 AI sucks. I suspected it would suck. Every civ AI has sucked horribly since I started playing civ 3. However, in Civ 3-4, the horrible AI got to stack all their units and it was not quite as apparent how bad the AI was in those games because the game was "simpler." With 1 unit per tile and increasing # of features/mechanics that have been implemented in Civ over time, the flaws in AI become obvious.Civ 6 is by far the most complex civ game I have played in the series. This is not a complement. I think it is a bit too complex. AI cannot handle complexity, and it makes the game look silly sometimes. I don't think people realize how complex it is to make a game that is 1 unit per tile with all the features included in civ 6. Every new game the map is randomized. Each tile has random features. Now, you throw ~8 civs on this new random map, with some random city-states, random barbarian placements, and resources.Now the map is generated and the civs (with their unique special bonuses) are placed on a map relatively randomly. You will begin to move through a tech tree where the units/districts/resources available are always changing at a different pace for each civ on the map. New to civ 6, your research/progress is map-dependent. You have to find things/accomplish things to speed up your research. Also new to civ 6 you're placing districts and wonders on the map. The AI has to have some sort of programing to make decisions. The game is complex, and I am not sure that AI that can be run on computers that meet the min requirements is robust enough to handle it.So what happens? In order to make the AI competitive, high difficulty civ AI cheats. The AI cheats in every Civ title. In Civ 6 they spam districts and units, but they do it poorly. They throw units away in war. They cannot handle 1 unit per tile combat. This is a huge negative in my opinion. However, it does NOT ruin the game.The game is still fun, it still has the civ charm. You can still min/max your civ making super power economy, high-tech military, or a tourist culture. I played it day after day at launch and really did enjoy it. At launch, I was playing on diety and winning most games. However, after one of the first big patches I had trouble on immortal and always lost on diety. Considering I always played civ 5 on immortal, I feel like the developers already had a sense of how to start changing (or buffing?) the AI to properly challenge hardcore civ fanatics. I am assuming I would still struggle to win on diety now. This does not mean the AI got "better" it just means the developers made changes to higher difficulty AI to appropriately challenge the hardcore gamer. I typed up this review because I honestly felt the huge number of negative reviews does not really reflect the quality of this game.Civ 6, in spite of its flaws, is good. Worth buying on sale for sure. I bought it at launch, and I do not regret it.

title: Recommended
comment: Game of the year here gentlemen.From refined systems, to unstacked cities to beautiful animations, world map and my personal favorite the OST.Civ. 6 builds up on its predecessors and takes the best parts of them and further polishing them.Gameplay:My favourite change for the gameplay is the specialized districts which adds another layer of strategy as well as making it easier to manage your cities once your civilization gets huge. Next is the tech tree and Eureka moments which help you plan out which way you want to progress in terms of tech. THe new Great Person points and overview is a nice touch and can help you pick best Person which fit your playstyle.Stacking units is back but only to a limit of 3 and thats a good thing unless u were a fan of civ. 4 deck wars.My only dissapointment is lack of Civs. I wish there were more civs but i understand that 2K and Firaxis focus on getting the systems right and game working. I hope more civs will be added in future *looking at you Poland and winged Hussars*-Lack of sceneriosGraphics:First reveal, many people had complaints the graphics were too cartoon-ish. Personally I find it quite asthetically pleasing and units/cities show minor differences depending on civs you are playing for example Greek Swordsman have little Spartan helmets which other civs dont. Animations for combat are beautiful such as the last kill would be a unique animation for example plaing as legion the last unit that gets killed has an animation of legion knocking them to the ground with a shield then proceed to jump over them while stabbing them. The way fog of war works is superb and you can even tell which tiles in your city are being worked on as well as buildings/wonders/districts being constructed turn by turn.Sound.Sean Bean in my opinion is a good replacement for Leonard Nimroy to be the narrator. Firaxis game even got him to record a line for which his meme is famous for (that made me chuckle when I first heard it). Christopher Tin is back and has composed an amazing opening theme that rivals to Baba Yetu. Each civilization has its own theme that changes as game progresses through. For example if you are playing Russian Civ. or meet them you can hear snippets of Kalinka which is a well known Russian song and so forth.Final Thoughts.The game is on good track I am sure people who have put in over 20 hours or so can point out finer things that I didn't pick up yet. Let's hope the devs keep a pusle on the game and interact with community and hopefully improve the game as well as giving us more content to fiddle with

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game is badly done, feels like it is missing a huge DLC. The late game research feels uneventful as doesnt bring new units so no to the usual stealth airpower, cruise missiles, marines, nuclear power plants and of course the GIANT DEATH ROBOT! Huge dissapointment. Not to mention all the bugs still present like♥♥♥♥♥♥pathfinding for naval units, that try to travel through land like the bloody vikings just carrying their boats over cliffs - no big deal for a missile cruiser! F***K!

title: Not Recommended
comment: I loved the civilization games in the past. However, with this game and attempting to play a full game I have been left angry and disappointed. A "feature" of the game where spy’s are able to steal gold has ruined the experience for me. I went from making over 250 gold per turn to being bankrupt in less than 10 turns. The negative gold is not shown and can be prepared for. You are not even able to defend against it as your spies get disbanded for having negative gold. I cannot refund this as it is a late game feature and the time is up. This has existed and is known for over a year now and has not been addressed at all. I am left disappointed and frustrated.

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization VI is a welcome addition to the series that fine tunes the gameplay of Civilization V in many ways. It is a much better launch title than Civilization V, containing virtually all the content of previous Civilization games and then some. However, some long standing issues in the franchise still remain, and may even be worse than before.First off, Civilization VI is not going to revolutionize how you play Civilization. It has many adjustments and additions, but the formula is fairly standard. The districts and the culture tree are the two biggest additions. The former adds a new layer to city building. Districts have better bonuses than standard buildings in previous games, but they take more production to build, and also use up an entire tile near your city. They are highly specialized, and locked by population count, so your cities can't possibly hope to acquire them all. In the end, you have to pick and choose which district is more viable for which city. The civics tree is also a very cool new way to handle the culture mechanics. Let's face it: culture in Civ V was dull. You open a screen, find your favored bonus, and press a button. The system has now been completely changed. You are given a civics tree, which can unlock buildings and governments, but primarily unlocks policies. Your government type restricts you to a certain number of policies of each type (there are 3 policy types and a wildcard policy). This creates a very dynamic way of managing culture.City-state interaction has also been vastly improved. Now, you gain influence in a city-state by sending envoys. These are primarily gained through diplomatic policies. The more envoys you send, the more bonuses you unlock from the city state. Militaristic city-states grant bonuses to unit production. Mercantile city-states grant additional gold. Religious city-states give you more faith, and cultural city-states give you, well, culture. If you have more than 6 envoys AND more envoys than other civilizations, the city-state becomes your vassal. They help you in war time and such, and also grant massive bonuses.Graphics aren't super important to Civilization, but my opinion on the graphics of Civ VI is mixed. On one hand, the animations are great and the environments are as gorgeous as ever, but I am not a fan of how the cities look. I liked the dynamically expanding cities of Civ V that grew with population count and actively incorporated wonders and buildings into the scenery. Everything is out of scale and cartoony now, but this will likely make older Civ players feel right at home. I also wasn't a fan of the music. The main theme is gorgeous, as always, but the in-game music is rather weak by comparison. Chances are, you will turn it off after 10 minutes and listen to a podcast instead.The only area the game really suffers is the AI, and by extension diplomacy. The AI is terrible. You are guaranteed to be at war with every other civ at some point in a match. They don't make alliances or friendships, not even for strategic gain. They wait until you are weak and declare war on you, all while berating you for being evil (I'm looking at you Saladin, you ♥♥♥♥ing hypocrite). There are almost no interactions that you can have with other civilizations besides trade deals (that they won't honor), requests to stop screwing with you (that they won't follow), and demands (that they won't cave to). The AI goes beyond stubborn and falls into outright psychotic territory at times.The game also lacks some features of Civ V, believe it or not. All of them relate to customization. You are far more limited on map types now. There are a grand total of THREE scenarios to chose from, which is pretty sad. There are not nearly as many toggleable options like Raging Barbarians (probably because it seems to be set to on by default, judging by how hard the barbarians in this game are). You can no longer name civilizations, leaders, or cities. All of these things will be missed, but they aren't bad enough losses to really hold the game down, and it adds so much in other areas that it becomes a worthy trade-off.All in all, Civilization VI is certainly a good game. It is a shame that flaws that are endemic to the series (like bad AI) have not been addressed, but none-the-less it is still a fantastic title and well worth it to long time Civilization fans.

title: Recommended
comment: Everything that was awesome about Civ V has been enhanced in Civ VI. I've already spent close to 40 hours in this game and have no doubt I'll be spending more in the near future.I do think there are some questionable design decisions, but these are mostly just nitpicks. title: Recommended
comment: สรุป 89/100 นะสำหรับผมในตอนนี้นะ แต่ตัวเกมยังมีอะไรให้ค้นหาเพิ่มอีกมีอะไรใหม่ ?-ยกเครื่องใหม่ ในเรื่องเกมเพลย์ของ ศาสนา วัฒนธรรม การบริหารพื้นที่รอบเมือง สร้างจุดเด่นของเมืองแต่ละเมือง-ระบบการปกครองแบบใหม่ (คล้ายของเดิม แต่ใส่รายละเอียดขึ้น)-ระบบควบคุมคนงานใหม่ ไม่ต้องไปเสียเวลาบริหารเยอะ-ระบบ ประชากร และค่าความสุข แบบใหม่-ระบบ ถนน (ยกเลิก)-ระบบการขุด วิจัย (ตัดระบบเดินหาของและเทคโนโลยีอออก)-ระบบการท่องเที่ยว และวัฒนธรรม-ระบบ ฮับ(การค้า อุตสาหกรรม บันเทิง) และ เมกะโปรเจค (แบบที่นักการเมืองชอบทำ)-ระบบเมืองเป็นกลาง เหมือนภาค 5-ยูนิตทางหทาร เหมือนภาค 5-ระบบภายในเกมลื่นไหลดีไม่มีหน่วงหรือเด้งหลุด แต่เข้าออกเกม โหลดนานมาก-กราฟิก ปรับมุมมองได้-อินเตอร์เฟส ใหม่หมดข้อเสีย- อินเตอร์ ชวนปวดหัวสำหรับผมนะ- กราฟิก งานศิลป์ บางคนอาจจะชอบ แต่ผมไม่ค่อยชอบ- ดนตรี ในเกม บางคนอาจจะชอบ แต่ผมไม่ค่อยชอบ- ระบบถนน และทางรถไฟ ถูกตัดออก ขาดความลึกเรื่องเทคโนโลยีโลจิคติค- ระบบการค้าระหว่างเมือง เหมือนจะดูง่าย แต่ทำเอาตาลาย 55สรุปสนุกในแบบ CIV ควรเป็น บางอย่างปรับเปลี่ยนให้ดูใหม่ แต่ core ของเกมยังเหมือนเดิม

title: Not Recommended
comment: Well What can I say, I'm a long time fan of the civilization series and I thought that they were going in the right direction when they released CIV V and it's add ons.I was extremely excited and downloaded the demo to civ6 and played it twice. I waited awhile and bought the humble bundle deal to get the full experience. But so far I'm pretty unhappy with the art direction and the cartoonish leaders. The user interface is kind of annoying and not as explanative as the previous game. Overall It feels like a step backwards and sort of lazy in it's design. It's basically an updated version of Civilization revolution.If you were expecting a game with tons of improvements, highly detailed graphics/leaders, and major improvements. Then don't buy this one and go get civ V or even IV with all expansions.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Disappointing.If you are a fan of the Civilization series, this game is probably not for you. I have played civilization games since the first one, and this is a devolution of the series. I understand the desire to appeal to greater audiences, but by dumbing down the game, it causes your core customer base to lose loyalty and interest. In a game that should have hundreds and hundreds of hours of enjoyable replayability, I don't think I would play this for 10 hours.If, however, you have never played a civilization game, then this might serve as a children's introduction to it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Not sure if I really enjoy it or not.Major issues with the AI, UI and some baffling design choices make this a hard one to recommend even with the fun i've had with it.If you are going to get it wait until it's on sale, don't pay the insane price they're asking for it at the moment.At the moment I can't recommend buying it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I don't write negative reviews.This game is so bad it deserves it. I'll write this in a good, bad, ugly format.The Good:The new district system, and, to a lesser extent, the wonders encourage you to plan your expansion. No longer do you just spam out mines, farms and wonders.The aethstetics are adorable. They're really nice and cartoony, and the animation in the leader screens is flawless.Leader and civilization traits are so much more diverse and useful now, with the unique units and buildings really making each civ stand out.The Bad:The gap between turn times is very very long. It's not a huge problem, but having to turn on quick movement and combat to complete a game in a realistic timeframe just kinda ruins it.Oh look, the rise and fall expansion has come out. The price is even more extortianate now, and if I have to pay extra to make a game playable... no thanks. I understand you need to make a profit, but it's getting ridiculous.The price tag is also a bit... big. I got it on sale, but £50?Government forms become way to difficult to handle in the late game, with all of the civics overwhelming you. At the end, I had around 70+ civics to choose from. I spent hours deciding which one to pickThe Ugly:Oh, the AI. The AI just ruins the game. To give you a picture of how bad it is, I had Sumeria and Greece as neighbours. We should be the best of friends. But nope, they don't like me because they suddenly changed their government forms, and I did something against their agendas. So they both declare war on me.(5 archers from Greece turn up)(5 archers from Sumeria turn up)(They die to a large amount of my war chariots)So I take this to my advantage, make peace with Greece (hey that rhymes) and siege a Sumerian city. All is going well when suddenly... the peace treaty with Greece expires. They declare war on me.(5 archers from Greece turn up)(They die to a large amount of my war chariots)So rinse, repeat, rinse repeat, eventually I annex both of them. Cool. Oh, by the way, everyone thinks I'm a warmonger now. (In fact, you get dubbed a warmonger just for defending yourself). Oh well, I've got infantry by this point, they're all renaissance and industrial plebs. Oh look, China declared war on me because I built a wonder, and their agenda doesn't like that. They throw a hissy fit.(5 musketmen from China turn up)(They die to a large amount of my infantry)I let China go with a peace deal, but the entire world thinks I'm a warmonger. However China's just doing fine, without anyone calling them a warmonger.You see, this is what ruins the game. A large network of agendas means that you can't be friends with one person without annoying everyone else. That isn't civ. That's accidentally walking into a group of people and having them swear at you for 5 minutes. It's horrible.3/10

title: Recommended
comment: A good series has sequels that iterate on their successors and build on them. The Civ series isn't like that, yet each game ends up being good. Civ VI is good. Great, sometimes. It's just not the new hotness it should be, but it could be there in the future.As a disclaimer, my experience with Civ VI is almost entirely with the new Rise and Fall expansion. As is the case with all Civ games, the expansions are vital.There's a lot of new features here that work pretty well, and some old ones that are tweaked for convenience and are generally better. City management has gotten the biggest overhaul this time, and I like it. Instead of being able to just build anything available in your city centers, you have to build districts that physically occupy tiles. Build them in certain areas, you can get bonuses for their respective outputs (science, culture, production, etc.) Waging war have been overhauled, now with different types of wars with varying penalties. Religious victories are a more active experience than before, requiring religious combat and inquisitions. Roads are streamlined now, made by just sending your traders out to build them as they go. Where some games in Civ V had very few roads in them, Civ VI is littered with them by the halfway point. Spies are producible now.The Rise and Fall expansion, which, again, you should buy, adds governors, loyalty, and golden age overhauls. Civs can lose their cities to rebellions if loyalty is low, which makes them ripe for the taking. Or, liberate and return them for diplomacy. Establish governors to build loyalty and upgrade them with useful buffs for the city. Achieve enough 'era events' and enter golden ages. Don't achieve enough, and you'll enter a dark age.I mentioned this game wasn't quite 'there yet,' and it's mostly because of what's missing, not what's there being bad. Diplomatic victories and the World Congress didn't make a return, and they really should have. That's the big one.The art direction is wonderful, and the map is a lot more visually interesting than the previous games. Leaders are expressive in their diplomacy screens and have a lot of personality. Sean Bean is a great narrator.Civ VI is good. It could be, and I believe it will be, better.

title: Not Recommended
comment: PositivesThe general aesthetics of the game is fantastic and looks great.The UI of the game is easy to understand and use.Game is smooth and clearly optimised well, especially during the “late game” which often hampered previous iterations.Some of the victory conditions have been better fleshed out and now with the inclusion of the religious victory.The introduction of districts as containers for buildings is excellent and makes you forward think with city planning.NegativesThe AI is completely and utterly atrocious to the point where it fundamentally ruins the game and is the reason why I simply cannot recommend it. The AI is irrational and nonsensical to the point where the game becomes an exercise in patience.The balance of most civilisations is poor and needs reworking.AI are completely incapable of any sort of strategic thinking during war and are often very easy to take out (especially naval warfare).Natural wonders in the game are almost entirely useless.In its current state, I would say that this game is simply not worth it unless you intend to play it online against friends or other real players. To summarise; The aethetics of the game are highly polished and is immediately brought down by the terrible and deeply flawed AI, for now, best avoid this game and look at other titles.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is pretty fun

title: Not Recommended
comment: Quit half-assing games and finishing them through paid dlc.

title: Not Recommended
comment: as has been noted before, the fact that AI wont defend it's own cities and that Barbarian mobs just "pop" around cities that go into anarchy with the best units available is ridiculous. They torch everything in sight and then you have to take decades in game time to revert the pillaged tiles back. where is the beta testing??? this is disgusting... and to ask for $60+ for this♥♥♥♥♥♥.. you will only put a few hours in and realise this is a joke! Very disappointed Civ fan.

title: Not Recommended
comment: With the release of the new Summer 2017 patch 7/29/17 all MODS are broken. This game is literally unplayable without the CQUI or any MOD that fixes the standard UI. I'm normally not a modder, but, this game is terrible, near unplayable, without them. The mods make CIV6. Without them this game is bad. REAL BAD.

title: Not Recommended

title: Not Recommended
comment: I played the free weekend and the first thing I noticed was the new art style which is very cartoony and felt more like a cheep mobile game, not realy what I was expecting from a civ game. The units are only in groups of 4 instead of a squad of 12 like in civ 5 which makes the battles a lot less exciting, although the new finisher animations are kinda cool. I liked how the new builder will complete their task in one turn but can only be used a limited amount of times. The coolest new game mechanic is the districts, it is so much visulaly apealing to fill your land with differend districts than tons of farms and trading posts. The wonders are much biger now and you get to watch them slowly build over time which is a realy cool new mechanic. The AI for the civs has more depth and can be very confusing but that just takes time to get used to. over all in the mecanics this is a solid game other than the AI wich can get pretty buggy but still playable. The only reason i havent bought civ 6 yet is because of the awful mobile game art style, I just hope that is fixed in civ 7. For now im sticking with civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is a Civ 5 copy/paste with improved graphics but less involved with religion, the cities and the countries you choose. Basically I expected much better. Even picking this up for 40USD I feel like i wasted money on a game ive already played for years now. I'm not sure people actually WANT fresh ideas or gameplay, they tried that with Civ AE. People disliked that game. If you are one of the people that wanted a refreshed graphics Civ5 this is your game. It is not mine.

title: Recommended
comment: Huge improvement over Civilization V. The graphics and UI will take you a while to get used to, but after an hour you'll get the hang of it. Unlike "Beyond Earth." this game feels wholly new, yet familiar. I highly recommend you pick this one up.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ 6 is a great new installment to the series. I wish I didn't wait so long to pick this up. Across my first week of owning I have spent almost 60 hours playing the game. Very complex and challenging and constantly making you think a few turns in advance to get maximum yield. You never know when you could have someone declare war on you.

title: Recommended
comment: Civ 6 is significantly different, but significantly the same as Civ 5. There are enough new elements to legitimately call this a new game, but it is easy to get started as an experienced Civilization player.Definitely a game worth pouring hundreds of hours into

title: Not Recommended
comment: For the first time in my life I'm struggling to keep on playing a Civ game and I played all of them since Civ 1, including Call to Power games. It's not a bad game, I finished it once, enjoyed it, but now on a second playthrough I get bored after a mere 30 minutes. Something is clearly not right.

title: Not Recommended
comment: What a mess, I've been playing Civs for 25 years and this one is not even worth the 12$ from humble monthly.It feels like an indie studio found a harddrive full of Civ5 assets and went hogwild in Unity to make.. this?Also they hired some drunk Irish guy to read a lot of text. The text is not very good.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI is super horrible. It can't be stressed enough.I am not a hc Civ player. I do have my history with civ 3 & 5 but I only played with AI level 5 at max. The few games I have now played in Civ 6 (with AI level 3) I haven't bothered even finishing the games because they get so boring so quickly. Just a one example: have decleared friendship with Japan, they try sneak attack and declare war - with having only 2 catapults and 1 samurai in their whole empire. Versus my field cannons and artillery...I hope the DLC's will fix the AI and diplomacy (or steam changes their refund policy because a game like Civ doesn't really open up in less than 2 hours :<)

title: Not Recommended
comment: EDIT2: Yep, this game is confirmed a waste of money. AI declare war on you without provocation, I had 5 different civs attack me at once (Within the first 5 turns of the game, mind you) for simply being peaceful. Naval units are the most useless things I've ever used in a civ game. AIs over-extend far too much, often having more than 10 cities in the first hundred or so turns. If you're looking for a good civ game, go play civ 5 or 4. They're MUCH better than this abomination.EDIT: Yes I realize i only have 20 hours in this game but my review will explain why.Having played 600+ hours on Civ V and hopping over to VI a few weeks after it came out, I am underwhelmed. The AI is poorly made, There is no build queue, You weren't even able to rename your cities when it first came out. They ALREADY HAVE DLC. What a horrible way to kick off a game.I can only honestly recommend this game if you play with friends and ONLY with friends. Unless of course you're sadistic and you play against the easy-as-pie Deity AI then go right ahead and do that.But in all seriousness I simply cannot recommend this game in its current state... at least not until it's fixed up and has an actual workshop. I know I have basically been repeating the same stuff as all the other reviews so let me add something of my own.A major problem (in my opinion) with this game is the fact that multiplayer is STILL broken. It was broken in Civ V and now it is broken again. Whenever there is a turn timer and someone disconnects, the game freezes up and does not let the turns progress. HUGE oversight with both games that I feel needs to be addressed.PROS:The district system is very well-done. It adds an extra depth to the game that the others didn't. Good job on that regard, Firaxis.The trade route system. The fact that roads are built as a result of having a trade caravan is a good addition in my opinion.Loading times. YES PLEASE. The loading times have been SIGNIFICANTLY reduced in this installment of the Civ franchise. Instead of waiting 20 minutes for the game to load and another 10 to load up a map like in Civ V, it now takes a minute or two to load the game AND the map combined. Well done.All in all, go buy Civ V with all the DLC if you want to have a good time. Don't play Civ VI unless you're a masochist or something. AI is garbage, multiplayer is broken, there is no build queue, there is already DLC. This is a sad excuse for a Civ game, to say the very least.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After 92 hours of gameplay already I am let say distraught on how the devs made this. Feels like a waste of time and a waste of a perfectly good game. Civ 5 I clocked over 500 hours into thanks to excellent AI and units. Civ 6 has numerous problems with its AI... constant suprise wars for no reason whatsoever and if you start a war all the more reason for more wars to be declared onto you, theres no leyway no halfway mark it will JUST HAPPEN even if you were friends with them.I understand the difficulty but this is ridiculous they wont start wars on themselves to start with through to the medival age (if you even get that far), you get double teammed on so you take attacks from both sides (im not saying thats a flaw thats a clever tactic), but to me this has happened every single game ive played no change when I change the options in players difficulty, random maps and resources, you will get hit straight away making starts on classic age and up all the more impossible.Other AI issues invovle that they lack the ability to level up their units. When I have helicopters and battleships the AI with have crossbows, spearmen etc etc. Almost as if they have no balance when to building cities and place themselves anywhere, this then ♥♥♥♥♥ on the challenge for late gameplay and you go around knocking out cities and units that I havnt used that unit for in at least 2000 years.For a game that was released back in late 2016 and civ 5 was released 2014 makes you wish beyond earth never existed (and lets be honest it might as well not have) so they would put their resources and time into making a better civ 6. I would love to recommend this as im a massive fan of the series I love their concept and idea and most of civ 6 new concepts are a massive improvement to civ 5 making everything simpler but for good reasons and spreading out your districts for a better producing city, but this has started to becoming a burden of simplistic AI and poor gameplay im going to have put this one down. Will possibly change review if devs start listening to the player base for once however at this moment in time nothing has changed and the patches released just keep polishing a turd. Shame.

title: Recommended

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization VI is an interesting idea - flawed, but still hopeful. If you've played Civilization V, you know what you're getting yourself into. However this time around science has been split up into tech and culture trees, meaning you'll want a good balance of both. And really that's what Civ VI excels at this time around, balance. Just about every move you make will have positive and negative repercussions down the line and everything is equally important. So just what is the most important to focus on?Mercifully Civilzation VI plays well even without intense micromanagement, and overal is a fun experience. But as I said before it is still flawed. As of this review, diplomacy is a bit one-sided and the numbers could use some adjustment. On top of that Culture victories feel a bit wonky and not as well implemented as it was in the previous game. Religious victories are tedious as well and feel more like a different version of a Domination victory. A bunch of things that can and probably will be fixed in upcoming patches and DLC expansions.If you're a big Civ fan, you'll probably enjoy VI. If you want to jump in for the first time, I'd recommend playing V with all DLCs first to get a good understanding of what you're getting into as it still feels more like a complete experience. Again, after a few patches and expansions, VI will be able to shine fully, but until then, I wouldn't blame you if you wanted to wait.

title: Not Recommended
comment: PositivesThe general aesthetics of the game is fantastic and looks great.The UI of the game is easy to understand and use.Game is smooth and clearly optimised well, especially during the “late game” which often hampered previous iterations.Some of the victory conditions have been better fleshed out and now with the inclusion of the religious victory.The introduction of districts as containers for buildings is excellent and makes you forward think with city planning.NegativesThe AI is completely and utterly atrocious to the point where it fundamentally ruins the game and is the reason why I simply cannot recommend it. The AI is irrational and nonsensical to the point where the game becomes an exercise in patience.In its current state, I would say that this game is simply not worth it unless you intend to play it online against friends or other real players. To summarise; The aethetics of the game are highly polished and is immediately brought down by the terrible and deeply flawed AI, for now, best avoid this game and look at other titles.

I'm normally not a modder, but, this game is terrible, near unplayable, without them. The mods make CIV6. Without them this game is bad. REAL BAD.

title: Not Recommended
comment: In a trend that seems more and more prevalent nowadays, Firaxis has taken everything good about the previous 5+ games, and tossed it all out the window in favor of building what amounts to an entirely new system.Gone is the ability to build what you want in your cities. Now you have to carefully manage the zones around your cities to make sure you can put in the things you want... in other words, study the lists of districts and plan what is going to go in every zone you can reach. Only three coastal spaces in this city? Better not place that required Harbor in the wrong spot if you want both a Great Lighthouse and the Colossus. Need to build the Forbidden Palace? Oh, sorry. If you do you'll have to wipe out your only iron mine because you already needed the other 5 spaces.Sorry, I don't want to have to sit here and make a 10,000 year plan for what is going where for each and every city. Civ games take long enough when you are actually playing. Forcing me to sit down and writing out a 3 page plan for each and every city is ridiculous. But if you don't, you will likely forget what you wanted where at some point during your 25 hour game and screw up the whole plan.Then we have religions. Oh religions. Such a critical part of historical understanding, and so massively flawed here.Previous games (that had a religion system) gave you a small bonus for founding it, and later maybe a slightly better one for doing more with it.Civ 6 turns this all into a whole sub section of the game where you now have to manage units and conflict just like you do with armies. You need offensive and defensive units for the inevitable holy wars, but your normal units aren't going to be terribly effective because shortly after finding another full Civ, they will flood you with their missionaries and apostles in a concentrated effort to wipe out yor beliefs. You know, that thing you founded to get you a still minor bonus.So unless you ignore your armies, you likely will not have enough of your own inquisitors to eliminate their religious invasions (and if you do ignore armies to do this, you invite actual invasion).And religion is a victory condition of the game. So it's sacrifice your cities to army invasions and lose the game to a Domination Victory or sacrifice your hard founded religion and losae the game to a Religious Victory.Turning off Religious Victory conditions don't help either. They still flood you with missionaries.Things they left in from the previous game?-- The ability of the AI to out produce you at every turn,-- The seeming clairvoyant ability of the AI to know exactly what Wonders you are building and beating you to them by 2 or 3 turns. Just close enough that you wasted 99% of the build time. Civ 5 was so notorious for this they made an achievement, so Civ 6 thinks this is a good thing.-- The fact the AI places their cities far too close to each other, so if you do conquer them, you have to raze every third city to prevent cities from arguing over valuable space, even more valuable given the level of zone planning you have to do now....OH! Yeah. razing cities leads to another new aspect. Warmongering.If you get too agressive, the AI gets mad and gangs up on you. Agressive, you know, taking a city state, or even declaring war on someone because they attacked an ally of yours. It's another case of the AI not having to follow the same rules as the player. They can declare war all they want (and they do) with no repercussions from the other AI, but YOU can't.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I loved the civilization games in the past. However, with this game and attempting to play a full game I have been left angry and disappointed. A "feature" of the game where spy’s are able to steal gold has ruined the experience for me. I went from making over 250 gold per turn to being bankrupt in less than 10 turns. The negative gold is not shown and can be prepared for. You are not even able to defend against it as your spies get disbanded for having negative gold. I cannot refund this as it is a late game feature and the time is up. This has existed and is known for over a year now and has not been addressed at all. I am left disappointed and frustrated.

The AI is some of the worst I've ever seen in a game. The diplomacy has no depth to it, and often times the other civs hate you for no reason or for the dumbest reason imaginable. There are also a lot of bugs and the game crashes/desyncs alot. This game has a long way to go before it's any good. Do NOT spend 60 dollars on this. Wait for a game of the year edition that comes with the ridiculous amounts of DLC. Buy it for 10 dollars. Then it's worth it.

title: Recommended
comment: I have seen many people review this game as more of a negative experience to which I believe is irrationally unfair and uncanny.So here is my attempt at a fairly decent but unbiased review.Sid Meier's offers users to experience a simulation of the 'perfect' world they want to create, whether you're a warmonger or pacifist no one is to judge (apart from the computer telling you how 'wrong' your government is). Coming from a Civ background I have experienced change in the game which was needed to enhance its development. There are some games similar to Civ but none that really compete in similarity; Age of Empires, Cities: Skylines, Football Manager.Judging a game because it 'crashes all the time', or 'is to slow paced', have work arounds to these issues and the variety at which you can visually change your game is amazing, from a layout perspective I love to use Pangea or a water based Earth. That is just the beginning, there are hundreds if not thousands of randomly generated maps to which you can choose the pace of your game or duration, from slow to incredibly fast where you will research sciences quickly, this is entirely up to the player and their style of game.Admittedly at a certain point where the game might not have long left or if you're going for a particular style of victory, the game, sometimes can feel boring or prolonged which I understand for some, but knowing that this specific game requires dedication and can be time consuming, why would you even buy a game like this knowing its game duration? It's about perseverance and determination to finish what you started.Civilization VI is essentially a different category of game in its raw form, no it’s not an FPS shooter or Racing game, and is one of the more niche markets where it won’t sell millions and millions of copies which I think Firaxis understand.The game is fun and the negative reviews are just taking a dig at some really unnecessary points which is unfair. The game is fun in my opinion, I think purchasing it and playing for maybe an hour or two will really give the player an idea if it's a game for them.

title: Recommended
comment: I've been playing Civ games since Civ II.Each game in the series, despite the core elements, is a vastly different experience. For me, Civ V was extremely simple - effortless, really. This one is completely different. While some elements are greatly "streamlined" (and in turn, slightly more complicated for the established Civ player), they are designed well. The removal of Global Hapiness is welcome in my opinion. The districts and non-automated improvements make you put more thought into city placement and development. I'm not sure about the resource requirements for units - it's easier, maybe just too easy at some cases. Also, the sparsity of critical resourses, like iron, coal and such makes resource wars a more common occurance than in previous installments.The Graphics are great! Most games nowadays have a very... gritty aesthetic to them. Civilization VI, with it's nice, more artistic style, vibrant color scheme and, in my opinion, light-hearted visuals is a soothing escape from modern AAA titles with ZitVision 2k and ToenailWorks HD engines. This aesthetic brings a... wishful and optimistic look to a game about conquering the world. The soundtrack this time around was so on-point that I've actually kept it on for as long as I've played. Don't get me wrong - Baba Yetu was great, but I just wasn't enjoying the soundtrack as much as this one.My main and only complaint, is the AI. Regardless of the difficulty, you simply do not have luxury of slowly building your empire from the start. The AI is hyper-aggressive from the start, the negotion AI is pretty hard to please (but can be fooled with not much effort). Despite the aggression, you can exploit the AI's inability to fully utilize their military in a logical manner. It's just a lot harder if you're a player that wants to play a non-militant leader.There are bugs here and there that cause a slight bit of frustration, but that's to be expected in the initial release.Compared to vanila versions of previous Civ games, this one is very well packaged with features. More civilization options would have been a welcome addition, but that's probably coming later on.Speaking of which, I have high hopes and a complete uncertainty as to what to expect from upcoming expansions to Civ VI. The expansions to Civ V were excellent and made an already incredible game that much more better.In conclusion, I had my initial doubts about all these new changes to the game. However, they turned out alright. Civilization VI is a very good follow-up to it's previous itterations. Although there are issues with the AI, I hope that it will be adressed with either an update or an expansion. If you are a Civ fan, you will most likely enjoy it. So far I've completed two playthroughs with Gorgo and enjoyed every single minute of the >30 hours I've put into it. From learning from my initial mistakes, to understanding advanced planning tactics, it's a great experience for fans of Civilization!

I ignore religion most gamesLackluster end-game screenEnd tech needs to be clicked on every single time, every 2-3 turns. Auto-renew?$5 'DLC' for a single civOK game with a good foundation.
