title: Recommended
comment: With 278 hours logged so far, its time to review.Lets first get this out of the way: Is Civ VI better than Civ V?--> No. Which is to say, the comparison is invalid in my opinion. Civ VI is -different- from Civ V in enough ways that, for me, it is a matter of "Which Civ do I feel like playing today?" (The answer to which is somehow never "Beyond Earth", but that is a different matter entirely.Now for my biggest issue with Civ games in general, the an account below is specific to Civ VI, but the core issue has carried over throughout the different installments:--> War mongering penalties (and AI behaviour in general).This is quite possibly down to my personal playstyle, but to me the AI always ends up a sulky child.My average game of civ progresses something like this:Found city --> Rapid expansion, ideally limiting the expansion capacity of 1 or more opponents. --> "Boxed in" opponent warns about settling too close; ignore. --> Boxed in opponent requests friendship once, twice, even three times perhaps. --> Meet other AI opponents who are happy to send delegations and act all friendly, until about 5 turns later they denounce me because I have selected a different government / I had a religious unit spread religion in their city a single time. As long as I maintain a different government / for the rest of the 6000 years spanning game just because I used a religious unit one time in their territory, these AI opponents denounce me whenever their denuciation has run out. Meanwhile --> Boxed in opponent, with declaration of friendship, declares a surprise war on me. --> Invariably, the agressor fails at every attempt to claim territory and is steadily forced out of my lands.At this point, the warmonger penalty I have incurred already exceeds that of the agressor who came to occupy my land, but, I am intent on showing this agressor the error of their ways and so I refuse their peace offerings, simply because paying me a bit of gold for 30 turns is not going to stop them from trying again later. So I push on (game progress continues)--> I pursue the agressor onto his territory and generally do not consider stopping my advance until I have claimed one of their cities (or razed it and rebuilt my own city in its place), and they are willing to cede that city and relinquish control of another city in exchange for peace. --> From this point forward all AI opponents, for the rest of the game, keep me in a continuous state of denuciation, save for the spare few turns during which they wish to make unreasonable trade offers or demands. --> Some further wars may be declared, I may or may not conquer further territory, I have not as yet sought a religious victory (mainly because a faith based economy is a tedious thing to manage in my opinion) --> Ultimately the game ends, usually with a victory for me, most commonly a science victory (although the above is also an exact representation of a cultural victory with Kongo against Russia, USA and Spain and also applies to domination victories, but the warmongering there is obvious).First issue with the above put briefly: It is a bit like the entire world holding a grudge against Greece because of Alexander the Great, or against Mongolia for Ghengis Khan. It is absolutely absurd that a war in the BC era is cause for agression in 1736 AD.Second issue: If they remember the "attrocities I committed" so well, why are they all so intent on antagonising me? Especially the AI that I so "mercilessly" defended myself against should know better than to give me attitude after what I did when they tried to invade me.So, the primary "Con" which overshadows overal gameplay for me, is one that has been an issue in Civ for several installments now: Warmongering / AI political tactics.PRO's:City building: Almost everyone mentions this, so read another review.Warfare: Combat strategy has always been vital in Civ, but since Civ V brought back the 1 unit per tile mechanics while swapping to hexagons, combat strategy has improved incredibly. The addition in Civ VI, support units, adds an interesting layer to this. Although I am not personally that big a fan of them, I do feel they provide a valuable contribution to the overal depth of warfare.Religious units: Tying in with support units mentioned above, Apostles are a very interesting unit, their capacity to assist military, cultural and religious efforts requires a little further distinction (such as the ability to choose rather than it being luck-based in terms of which promotion options you're offered) but all the components are there.Map view: Tying in with the way city building is organised in Civ V, you now get beautiful vistas of your cities, its builder-made improvements and the various wonders and districts (and district buildings) they contain. The "exploration age" design of unexplored areas of the map, and the cartographic look of the 'fog of war' keep the map view interesting."Other" Cons:Apart from my extensive rant about War Monger Penalties and AI behaviour in general, there are several interface issues I would really like to see resolvedThese mostly relate to User Interface issues:- City/Encampment attacks from garrisoned tiles: When I have a unit on a city the unit icon overlaps with the city attack icon, they shift apart when moving the map, problem with that is that clicking on the city attack icon centres the map back on the city, while it may not actually activate the city ranged attack, causing me to sometimes move the map 5 times to be able to click on the city attack icon, only to have the camera moved back without the city ranged attack being activated. It also regularly causes the wrong attack to hit an agressors (where the city attack can kill one unit but not another, and the garrisoned ranged unit can kill the other or overkill the first for example). My main issue however is with the map shifting to be able to click a button.- Auto unit cycle: For some reason, when I deactivate this and click on "a unit needs orders" it cycles through my units in a fairly sensible order, 'grouped' military units one after the other, to then move across the map. On auto cycle sadly it shifts between units completely randomly, so trying to quickly set 5 units to attack a city causes 2 to attack, the 3rd to receive an order to walk halfway across the map and the last 2 to ..do nothing until I've moved an apostle or builder that is absolutely irrelevent to ongoing events..!I'm out of text space, so I hope this is helpful. All in all Civ VI is still a great game and definitely in my top 2 favourites in the series. Don't think of it as replacing Civ V, think of it as a different way to play Civ with significant similarities to Civ V.

title: Recommended
comment: A lot of these reviews are being too hard on this game. They almost discouraged me from buying, but I'm happy I did anyway. I've played the whole Civilization legacy, and I think this is the same game I've always been playing but with tons of little tweaks and additions that will make you go "oh wow, thats a really cool thing they added".Quick list of pros:1 Combining units into corps. and armies. I think its a cool dynamic to building up your forces and making it possible for older era units to stand up to more advanced ones. Within reason. A single tank is still going to obliterate dozens of archers.2 Building districts which can specialize your cities building options and functions. Very nice addition.3 Culture and tech tree advancement is much better and dynamic, with goal oriented bonus advancements to every tech and policy.4 CITY STATES ARE FINALLY USEFUL You can buy them as a temp army and the bonus leverage they provide is competetive to aquire. Im happy they got this right.5 Workers having charges and more engaged use, rather than just automatically improving everything constantly.The AI isn't as bad as people make it sound. The personalities are determined by a public agenda, and one hidden that you only learn about if you become friendly. Its not hard to figure out how to make some happy, and its silly to think you can be on everyones good side. For instance, if a leader just really wants to build wonders, they will get mad and declare war when you build wonders. If a leader is warlike, they will like you if you have a big army and cause lots of wars. I will admit the AI is somewhat random at times, and you can consider the motivations to be a throwback to historical wars over stupid things. Yes they will sometimes declare war suddenly, but its usually because they were coerced by another leader. Sometimes they declare war and wont launch any attacks, or sometimes they will have an army ready to attack. Trading is a little more negotiable as sometimes they will lowball the hell out of you and you can barter for more. If you are unfriendly don't expect any good deal ever.Some minor complaints:1 Amenities. Which are points held by each city based off your luxury resources, but I dont understand how exactly they work or how they are distributed. They reduce production significant if you dont have enough. The game will remind you every damn turn when you dont have enough, and the debuff applies to random cities it seems.2 Still no ability to save game setup options, or a regenerate map if you are unhappy with the starting spot.3 Religion needs to be able to be turned off. Religious victory is pretty dumb, and when it matters to an AI you will just get bombarded by converters which can block your units. However, it is kind of cool they that these units can fight each other without formally declaring war. Too many leader perks rely on faith points and religious structures.4 Leaders are kinda lame imo and the perks are a little unbalanced. Recommend mods for new leaders. I need more Stalin in my life.Altogether I'm happy with this game. I think this stands up to 4 as the best civ.

title: Recommended
comment: After playing over a hundred hours of Civ 6, I am still going to leave my positive review up in hopes the Civ team gives their game more attention. Unfortunately, I have to retract my optimism that the game's AI mechanics will be balanced. Before I delve anymore into this review, I want to highlight everything Civ 6 does right:Districts are a wonderful idea and add a whole new layer of strategy to the game. City-building feels much more satisfying and wonderful than in Civ 5.Builders in replacement of workers is also a welcome change. Having 10 builders just sitting doing nothing but building roads in Civ 5 end game felt horribly wasteful and tedious to manage.Wonders are actually visible on your city now! In all my 100 hours of playing I have never--not once--skipped the little wonder movie that plays after you've completed one.I'm still a bit divided on the science/culture tree changes (can't tell if Eureka's add or retract strategy from the game) but I think it is an overall improvement from Civ 5's odd-to-manage culture system. I also have no complaints against the graphic changes in Civ 6. I've grown fond of the simpler, more exuberant art style.So why has the game received such negative reviews?Truthfully, if the AI was just as it were in Civ 5, then this game would surely be showered with all the praise that Civ 5 received. Unfortunately, the AI is broken down to its core. I no longer believe that it can be fixed with simple tweaking, and I don't think the Civ 6 team has the energy to fix it. Let me give you an example of what I mean:I begin a game as Russia. Gandhi and the Aztecs are nearby.The Aztecs and Gandhi aren't too happy with each other.I am on good terms with Gandhi.Gandhi offers to declare a joint war on the Aztecs.Hopeful to knock out the Aztecs early, I agree.The next turn Gandhi denounces me for warmongering.That right there is game breaking. Early game and late game strategies often get thrown out the window because the AI, no matter how much you strategize yourself to achieve favorable relations with them, will almost always turn their backs and denounce you for little to no reason.I was once denounced by Norway for not having a strong Navy on TURN 10!Buy when on sale if you are a Civ fan. There are enough new features that you can still enjoy the first few games before you are eventually fed up with the AI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: EDIT2: Yep, this game is confirmed a waste of money. AI declare war on you without provocation, I had 5 different civs attack me at once (Within the first 5 turns of the game, mind you) for simply being peaceful. Naval units are the most useless things I've ever used in a civ game. AIs over-extend far too much, often having more than 10 cities in the first hundred or so turns. If you're looking for a good civ game, go play civ 5 or 4. They're MUCH better than this abomination.EDIT: Yes I realize i only have 20 hours in this game but my review will explain why.Having played 600+ hours on Civ V and hopping over to VI a few weeks after it came out, I am underwhelmed. The AI is poorly made, There is no build queue, You weren't even able to rename your cities when it first came out. They ALREADY HAVE DLC. What a horrible way to kick off a game.I can only honestly recommend this game if you play with friends and ONLY with friends. Unless of course you're sadistic and you play against the easy-as-pie Deity AI then go right ahead and do that.But in all seriousness I simply cannot recommend this game in its current state... at least not until it's fixed up and has an actual workshop. I know I have basically been repeating the same stuff as all the other reviews so let me add something of my own.A major problem (in my opinion) with this game is the fact that multiplayer is STILL broken. It was broken in Civ V and now it is broken again. Whenever there is a turn timer and someone disconnects, the game freezes up and does not let the turns progress. HUGE oversight with both games that I feel needs to be addressed.PROS:The district system is very well-done. It adds an extra depth to the game that the others didn't. Good job on that regard, Firaxis.The trade route system. The fact that roads are built as a result of having a trade caravan is a good addition in my opinion.Loading times. YES PLEASE. The loading times have been SIGNIFICANTLY reduced in this installment of the Civ franchise. Instead of waiting 20 minutes for the game to load and another 10 to load up a map like in Civ V, it now takes a minute or two to load the game AND the map combined. Well done.All in all, go buy Civ V with all the DLC if you want to have a good time. Don't play Civ VI unless you're a masochist or something. AI is garbage, multiplayer is broken, there is no build queue, there is already DLC. This is a sad excuse for a Civ game, to say the very least.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After 92 hours of gameplay already I am let say distraught on how the devs made this. Feels like a waste of time and a waste of a perfectly good game. Civ 5 I clocked over 500 hours into thanks to excellent AI and units. Civ 6 has numerous problems with its AI... constant suprise wars for no reason whatsoever and if you start a war all the more reason for more wars to be declared onto you, theres no leyway no halfway mark it will JUST HAPPEN even if you were friends with them.I understand the difficulty but this is ridiculous they wont start wars on themselves to start with through to the medival age (if you even get that far), you get double teammed on so you take attacks from both sides (im not saying thats a flaw thats a clever tactic), but to me this has happened every single game ive played no change when I change the options in players difficulty, random maps and resources, you will get hit straight away making starts on classic age and up all the more impossible.Other AI issues invovle that they lack the ability to level up their units. When I have helicopters and battleships the AI with have crossbows, spearmen etc etc. Almost as if they have no balance when to building cities and place themselves anywhere, this then ♥♥♥♥♥ on the challenge for late gameplay and you go around knocking out cities and units that I havnt used that unit for in at least 2000 years.For a game that was released back in late 2016 and civ 5 was released 2014 makes you wish beyond earth never existed (and lets be honest it might as well not have) so they would put their resources and time into making a better civ 6. I would love to recommend this as im a massive fan of the series I love their concept and idea and most of civ 6 new concepts are a massive improvement to civ 5 making everything simpler but for good reasons and spreading out your districts for a better producing city, but this has started to becoming a burden of simplistic AI and poor gameplay im going to have put this one down. Will possibly change review if devs start listening to the player base for once however at this moment in time nothing has changed and the patches released just keep polishing a turd. Shame.

title: Recommended
comment: Well this is my first time playing a civ game to be honest i love tis game it probably has to be one of my favourite games, then again i have'nt played 4 and 5 which are much much better, i do plan on playing those games but this is still i nice game better than most other games i have at the moment.

title: Not Recommended
comment: NOT RECOMMENDED AT CURRENT STATE: THE AI IS ABSOLUTELY BROKEN TO THE POINT IT IS RUINING AN OTHERWISE EXCELENT GAMEPros:+Better than Civ 5 in just about every way+ beautiful soundtrack and visuals+ Runs extremely wellCons:- THE AIThe AI is currently broken and completely ruining the game it is overly aggresive and feels like it is borderline cheating by producing seemingly endless waves of army units way too advanced for the current point in the game- MINOR BUGSsome minor loading bugs and issues such as not being able to interact with the game while it is in windowed/borderless in a second monitor- DECLARING WAR FEELS BROKEN TO THE COREAI has seemingly no reprecussions for declaring war meanwhle you are instantly labeled as warmonger

title: Recommended
comment: TL;DRIn a short summary, this is an excellent game crippled by AI, which will still be very enjoyable, especially with friends.Full review(pros and cons further down)SummaryThe game has the potential to be the best in the series, it has various new mechanics, the visuals are refreshing for the series, and replayability is amazing. Although probably the only "major" so to speak problem would be the AI and how it behaves.On the matters of A.I.In the current state of the game, playing against AI is somewhere between boring and annoying.The problems the AI seem to have are the following:Another problem that is more evident in higher and lower difficulties is the unbalanced tech tree.An AI on king difficultyIn addition, the tree seems like it has multiple weird spots, such as archery not leading to anything, meaning you avoid it, fearing a waste of turns. Worse even is the top line of the tech tree, starting with sailing, which leads to compters without any intervention from the other tech lines.The UI is largely find and polished, namely the main menu being one of my favorites in gaming history (gotta love some christopher tin music), although it has some shortcomings, such as very small X buttons to exit diplomacy screens, and the auto unit-rotate feature which has caused me to waste so many movements.Players of previous civ games will know that the mid game has been nutoriously stale.Fortunately, in civ 6 this is mostly not the case, if you can build your cities properly, production wise.The game is mostly fine, although some people seem to report crashes on load, loads hanging and such, but those being pretty rare, it's not a real worry.The music for the game, composed by Christopher Tin is absolutely stellar.Some people have compared it to Baba Yetu, which won a grammy. I am one of those.is in my opinion the best main theme civ had. ever.The music for each civilization also evolves through the eras, having a very basic tune in the ancient era, and all the way to the information era, where the core melody (such as a banjo for america) remains, but has many layers added to it.Civ 6 has a very strong lineup of features and is generally very enjoyable, but due to a very annoying fault with the AI, it is somewhat problematic.

title: Recommended
comment: The District Mechanic adds some strategic element when settling cities, although its impacts are a bit obscure and need people to read either in-game encyclopaedia (which does not contain all info at times and/or has faulty entries in some details) or read/watch tutorials on-line. This is important as your cities grow and you realize you waisted Builder action on a tile that now will be removed by the district. Also very important is that once you start a district you cant cancel it and worse you cant remove it, so make sure you hit the right tile. The planing ahead should also not be exclusive to existing bonuses, looking at tiles and plan what improvements go where and thus what districts go adjacent in future, to maximise city outputs.Combat is still pretty much the same as in Civ V, which is OK I guess, with the corps/armadas mechanic that I think is not really that great tbh. Coming from EU4, I feel combat could be improved quite a bit, for example allow the creation of armies, where you can add units of various types to it.The last bit I need to mention is this rather lengthy ramble, is diplomacy. Yes they added a few ticks that are nice, but diplomacy is just as moronic as ever. There is no sense to interaction for most part and it does not help that AI actions do not reflect diplomacy information AT ALL! For example, in a game with 6 other civs, the 2 civs that were FRIENDLY! Surprise DoWed me BOTH (in different times, maybe 20-30 turns apart). What gives?Great people system is pretty good, I like this approach, but the Writers, Musicians and Artists really need to be looked at, its silly that I cant keep up with building places to store stuff these people create and that they are otherwise just useless. There should be a way to activate the person and get a % boost to cultures or a one time boost to specific wonders, like with some engineers, or even just whatever amount of culture, like scientist. In one game I had to sell great works to make use of the writers, and even that capped as they only ever buy one and only if they dont have one yet (at least thats what I gathered).

title: Recommended
comment: I love Civilzation games, but Civ 6 still needs more work. Work on A.I., mod support (PLEASE), and many other little things that make the game sometimes a drag and sort of grindy. Overall a good game though, just wished it had come out alittle later when all these little nuisances could of probably been worked out and made this game as great as Civ 5.

title: Recommended
comment: The latest version of Civilization is much like its predecessors - not perfect by any means, but still a great game, and a prime example of the 4X strategy genre. And I fully expect that it will only get better as more content is released, just like the previous versions. I fully recommend it for anyone looking for a good grand strategy game.Like most sequels, this one is at once familiar and different, so I'll focus on the changes from previous versions. On the whole, I find the game more enjoyable and there are more options to pursue tha in Civ V. I like the added strategic and thematic options that have been introduced, and generally consider the new features to be improvements. The big problem right now is that the AI struggles to provide a significant challenge for experienced players, perhaps because it hasn't learned how best to navigate the variety of significant new strategic options. Since Civ will always be primarily a single-player game, this is a significant issue, although the game remains entertaining nonetheless.The district system is probably the biggest and most obvious change, shifting the vast majority of buildings into specialized tiles and forcing a number of new strategic decisions on the player. The choice of which districts a city builds influences how the city develops, determining which buildings it can build and what types of Great People it will contribute towards, making long term planning more important since the number of districts a city can build is limited by population. Now each city will have its own unique mix of builidngs, as opposed to mostly being a copy of all your other cities. I've seen a number of opinions on the change, but personally, I like the added strategic layers the district system provides, from planning your own development in peace time to increasing the impact of raiding forces during war, since most buildings can be damaged and disabled by attacking or looting the district that houses them.Another major change is splitting the tech tree into two halves - a traditional tech tree with progress based on research and a separate civics tree where progress is instead based on culture. The tech tree unlocks buildings and units, while the civics tree unlocks diplomatic, trade, and governmental choices (mostly in the form of new policy options you can employ which let you boost specific abilities of your civ according to the needs of the moment), with Wonders split amongst the two. Additionally, both types of research can be sped significantly through achievements your civ reaches, such as building particular units or taking specific actions related to a tech or civic. Overall, I again feel the changes are positive, enabling an empire that struggles to keep up in one area to compensate by excelling in another. The boosts do tend to accelerate the speed of progress overall, since you can cut research time in half by meeting the boosting criteria, so usually the various eras are reached long before the time period they represented historically. But they do give the player another set of minigoals to focus their efforts on.The last major change is a dramatic increase in the importance of location to a wide variety of things. Districts gain boosts based on the terrain and development of tiles around them, making them more effective if properly placed. Each Wonder has a terrain-based unlock criteria in addition to the tech/civic based one, making it impossible to just build a single mega-city that racks up production and builds most of the world's Wonders based on its output alone. Again, this increases challenge and strategic options, since your plans are more closely tied to the details of the spaecific play-through. It also allows players to remain competitive for Wonders even if they aren't on the cutting edge of research, since opponents may not be able to start work on a project until long after they unlock the relevant tech.As in previous versions (and in most other 4X strategy games), the weak link is the AI. Harder difficulties are mostly just added starting resources and discounts on AI costs for all activities. The challenge of a new difficulty level is heavily front-loaded as a result - if you can survive an initial rush by AI civs fueled initial advantage in units, the game is only slightly harder at higher difficulties. The AI also seems less aggressive than in previous versions, and as long as you maintain a reasonable defensive force and aren't deliberately provocative, you can often go multiple eras without a war, much less a challenging one. The wars that do happen (whether or not they involve a human player) tend to be settled quickly and (in the case of AI vs. AI wars) indecisively. Once the balance tips towards one side, the other quickly offers peace on generous terms, knowing it probably can't rebuild it's army quickly enough to recover. If one side has managed to take an established city or two, this often means the AI will offer the majority of its available resources and an extra city or two, in addition to giving up its claims on the conquered territory.Improvements are needed in the AI's focus on achieving victory conditions, as well. It is often impossible to determine what type of victory an AI civ is pursuing, unless that strategy is being very successful. At higher difficulties, at least, each civ ought to be attempting at least one type of victory, ideally changing plans if another path seems easier while still remaining committed enough to not paralyze itself by constantly switching course. But in most games it does not appear that most of the civs are actually trying to win at all, instead sitting in a largely passive clump of medicority in all facets while one or two more successful civs push for the win. Often no AI is attempting one or more of the victory types (for instance, I've never seen an AI civ make an obvious attempt at a domination (military) victory). It would be much more challenging if these issues could be overcome and the AI would provide a more significant challenge in the late game.But despite these concerns, this is still an excellent game, and highly enjoyable for both new and experienced players.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ 2 was one of my most played games. I loved Civ 1 as well. I lost touch with the series after that.That said... the soul of Civilization seems to have been lost too. It has followed the path of large development studios that make pretty things because pretty things sell, but don't give a damn about producing mechanics that make any sense.There's all these Sean Bean voiceovers. They soon grow tiresome. I don't need everything reading to me, thanks. Meanwhile the tutorial is obnoxiously long winded with endless repetition.So I quit the tutorial after a few minutes despite being none-the-wiser on how to play. I start out as Vikings. I fiddle about with some things using the rather unintuitive UI, mostly guessing based on my past experience but seeing qutie a bit of additional complexity. I move some units near the coast. They get fired at by archers over the English Channel - y'know, that 30km sea between the UK and Europe. Oh, and over mountains too. What the ... ?I immediatelly stopped at that point. I'm not going to bother investing time learning all the crazy complexities of a game (and it throws so many numbers at you, way more than the originals, and the UI is awful with the City management dialog compressed into the corner of the screen) if they can't even design something so fundamentally simple to make sense.I'd have refunded it if I could (I got it as part of a bundle, unfortunately).

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is the worst version of Civilization since V first came out.It is boring to play, has a religion subgame that is obnoxious, and has very little to do with the rest of the game and the AI is underwhelming. It is just a slow slog until I inevitably win a Culture victory because I just don't have the energy to load up a bunch of boats to go conquer everyone.Do not buy this game if you are looking for an exciting Civ experience. I haven't been this disappointed since MOOIII: Excel the Video Game.

comment: Last turn before leaving for mars and the science victory, unleashed a thermonuclear barrage against the remaining civs as a good bye. Fantastic game.

comment: The foundation of this game is excellent but the AI is terrible and there are some serious balance and pacing issues. I already like it more than Brave New World, but I don't really feel comfortable recommending it in its current state. I think it will be an incredible game in 6-12 months and I'll change my review when they fix some of the worst problems.

They make you pay 5 USD to play 1 more civilization. AI are just as bad as previous games. I hoped they would solve some of previous stuff but no. They barely do anything. Will never buy CIV again. title: Not Recommended
comment: TL;DR : Stick with Civilization 5.Lackluster is the best word to describe this game. It does not feel like an improvement over Civilization 5. The ablity to expand your cities beyond the usual hex is nice, but not a reason to buy the game for $60. Personally, I do not like how the new game displays undiscovered territory. It seems too bright and takes attention away from the focus of the game. I didn't get a chance to interact with the AI because I was bored within 40 minutes and realized I would be requesting a refund. I wish I would've had longer to play the game so that I could write a more detailed review, but my short experience can easily be summed up with "meh".

title: Not Recommended
comment: Main reasons why negative review:- AI is bad, realy stupid:In Civ5 when a unit was wounded AI tryed to switch him with a healthy one and then heal. Civ6 - sucide squads, AI just throws units at you without anny strategy.Dont kow if a bug or stupid AI, anyway its a problem: AI didnt repair pilaged tiles at all, even when builder was around.AI spams troops and does nothing with them - huge army of war elephands just chiling in the sea, moving few tiles forward and back.- some minor bugs (cant quit game properly)- annying unit control - slow auto selection of another unit (give order and at that moment unit switches and order is given to completely another unit)hope it will be fixed/improved, otherwise its just slighty better Civ5 - not worth 60 eu- AI city placemen, looks like AI has no strategy where to place a city, packing lots of citys just 3 tiles away from each other,what means that AI doesnt thinks about district placment at all.- no restar button to reseed map with yoor selected preset (its in the game code, just not added)- no ability to select the number of citystates when seting up the game- balance, starting city place is crucial, plains are useles, you grow fast but with small amount of production you cant manage the housing and amenity needs. Hills on the other hand are overpowered

title: Not Recommended
comment: Firaxis has taken a big step back with this iteration of Civilization. I found this game for half price on a store shelf, figured i'd pick it up. Very glad I didn't pay the full Steam asking price.Basic quality of life aspects, included in past Civ games have been needlessly removed.Over priced DLC to fill out the game seems to be a complete waste of money.If I see the expansion on sale in stores, I may pick it up in the hopes that it fills out the game a little.It seems that R&F is download only, neglects to fix the main issues, and really doesn't add much content.The mod community is great for fixing the issues Firaxis has left in the game, however, relying on mods means every official update means the game becomes broken until the mods have been updated.Don't buy a game where you are continually paying to see new features added. Continue to enjoy past Civ games that can be considered complete.Best to wait a couple years until Civilization 6 is released in its finished form, it will probably be available in a boxed format with all expansions and DLC for less than Steam is asking for vanilla. All past Civ games have been.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Juvenile, cartoonish graphics and card games; that is what awaits you in Civilization VI. Instead of heading further in the artistic direction that Civilization V chose, Firaxis decided to abandon ship and design a game more relevant to the mobile platform than the PC one. This game legitimately feels like a cheap knockoff. Yes, the AI is bad, potentially even worse than V. The game is so dissapointing, that I'm feeling depressed just writing this review.Do yourself a favor and purchase one of the previous titles in this series, which are both cheaper and exponentially more enjoyable.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Would love to give this game a positive review, but... Two things.1. Every playthrough eventually hits a point where for one absurd reason or another, all opposing AI factions declare war on you. Ignoring the improvements to the AI's combat effectiveness (slight, but there), this effectively destroys any sense of realistic dimplomacy, and causes the game to become little more than a steamrolling of your troops one by one over the enemy cities, or else vice-versa.2. I payed for the delux edition. Turns out, if I had instead simply bought each worthwhile DLC pack individually, I would have saved five bucks, and could have avoided getting the pathetic viking senario, to which modders have done better variations of. Just saying, feels like a bit of a #%$^ slap to me.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Its like they let the Artists design the entire game. Its very very very pretty, and a true joy to play....But the design choices are just so insane.....I cant even comprehend why they would make them. The art style by itself is a turn off for me, but I can excuse it on the grounds of being unique, but The government system works using playing cards now... it feels like im playing Yuh-Ghi-Oh not Civililization "OH you attacked me, Now I activate my Fascism third alternative card that gives me a + 1 production to all my Militiary units" They have completely removed happiness as a mechanic, which makes it realllly easy to just absolutely steamroll the A.I. YOu declare war on the guy next to you , you conquer him use his cities to pump out more units and repeat, boom you have your entire continent before the mideval era, which means all you have to do is refocus science in all your cities, and you have nuclear submarines by the 1300s, Even on the hardest difficulty you can do this. The difficulty levels just make the AI troops stronger not smarter. The The art style makes it very difficult to distingush ceratin terrain features. The Female advisor voice actor sounds like she swallowed a razor blade. The british male voice actor is nice but he sounds Waaaaaaay too enthusiastic, They obviously can't top having lenard Nimoy in CIv IV but they could deffinitly have someone better. The Quotes they Choose are just simply, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. theres no nicer way to put it, I constently find my self asking "who the hell is that?" everytime I unlock a tech level, or a civic level. Something I am personally offended by is the fact that the developers said that the world congress wouldnt ship with the base game , becuase they wanted to see how the meta game played out. Well as fans of the game know, no world congress means no reason to explore the world, not to metion this means that they where already developing (what I can only assume to be a paid DLC) before the game even released. Also Why is Gilgamesh a Civ Leader? HE is a fictional charachter, you might as well have King Arthur as a Civ Leader. When you discover satilites and reveal the entire map, it still does that annoying parchment art style map that acts as kind of a fog of war....thats like...just no....why would you do that? I have a satilite in geosynchronus orbit over an enemy nation so My top scientists draw the map on a peice of parchment. The game self censors its violence with these reeally cartoony star pops, it remids me of the 1960's batman televison show.The game has potential. it really does but is it worth $60 in its current state, no no its not

title: Not Recommended
comment: Can't recommend at this stage. Potential to be a good game but AI is so brokenly stupid that the game gets boring pretty fast. Also not a fan of granting yield bonus and units to make it more challenging.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just another cash grab, If you like paying 60$ for a game and then another 70$ for game content they bring out aftergo for it, game play is good just like civ 5 with some improvements

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ VI's failure: The Two Salems(This review contains religious references, but is addressing a failure of the game, not initiating a debate on the subject)Civ VI has unfortunately joined the pantheon of other games which are simultaneously overtweaked and underdeveloped (Read Master of Orion 3+). But in having a selective view of historical fact, it demonstrates its ability to faor AI players over human players.Case in point, and the reason for the title of this review, is that two Salems, and several other historical events of a similar vein, is the inability to kill Missionaries with forces defending cities. 2000 years ago, soldiers were involved the removal of a key religous figure in one "Salem". Nearly 1700 years later, another "Salem" was at the center of another "religious persecution" at the hands of forces. There are more examples throughout written history, but apparentlly not where Civ VI's designers want the game to go, since you can't send city defenders after missionairies in the game.This is just one of a list of flaws with the game, but in short, if I could get my money back on this game, I would. Civ VI is a basic Civ 3 with an updated GUI.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game is highly unplayable for any length of time. There are just too many show-stopper bugs that are simply not being addressed.* "Balanced" start position is not balanced.* Barbarians are hopelessly overpowering in the early game.* Start positioning was broken completely with the Fall "patch", so you have to start 20-30 games just to get one that has a reasonable position for your capital.* The fog of war is terrible. They use the same colors for both currently not visible terrain and never-visited terrain.* The icons for visted terrains with resources are all brown, rather than having at least the shading of the resource colors.* In single-player mode, the game focuses on defeating the human far too much. Barbarians will bypass other civ or city-state units just to attack the human, even if it should be obvious that they need to attack the AI.* Many options in the game were present in Civ V, but completely missing from VI. How do I turn off spying? You don't. How do I turn off barbarians, or make them tougher? You don't. How do you get the game to use a new random seed if you go back to a saved game? You don't. All of these and many more were in Civ V, but are not in VI. How can a game "upgrade" forget important features from previous versions?* And many more.Most of all, they seem to be completely oblivious to the major issues they have. They need to have a feedback mechanism that works. If only I could get some kind of response that says they realize how bad they did and want to make it better. But, they don't seem to care about their players, beyond advertising the next expansion.There are a lot of really cool features (like eurekas, builders, districts, and more). But, not nearly enough to make up for the horrible gaffs.Overall the game is not very good at all. Unless they make fixes (BEFORE the expansion), I will avoid buying more product from them completely. I'm not about to pay for them to fix their bugs.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Yikes what a let down.They had alot of live up to compared to Civ V and I actually think they made alot of REALLY good moves. Many of the new mechanics, if explained in theory, make the game sound very exciting but in practice they just don't do anything for the game. Its so hard to put your finger on why when I played Civ V I could easily get lost in the game feeling like a fearless tyrant at the head of a great warmachine or a bonevolant diplomat engineering world peace. I just cant get there with Civ VI.First off, The AI is VERY dumb.Example, The year was ~1800, Greece had been a friend of mine for about 700 years, They were on some far away island I rarely interacted with. They suddenly they wage war on me. A few turns go by and a lone greek spearman shows up on my shore, I bombard him from my city and easily kill him. Greece sues for peace and gives me all their GPT and gems for 30 turns and go back to loving me... Like seriously wtf?The Districts are a neat way to spread out your city but they just feel like a chore to build and god forbid a rogue barbarian raids your district and you have to wait 300 years in game time to repair it.The religeon has a combat system now and I was insanely excited at first to become a pious pope type and wage a holy war sending wave after wave of missionaries to far awar lands until you're finally the dominant religeon on earth and you realize literally all that effort awards you pretty much nothing... How can they have such cool ideas and let them fall so flat?If you're winning this game is just clicking through your turns bored and if somehow you are losing it never feels like you've been out maneuvered, its usually just because the inexlicapley stupid AI all decided to declare on your at the same time for no apperant reason or gods of RNG have placed you in some barbarous anarchy nation.I keep reminding myself that Civ VI took two xpacs to get truly awesome so I wait... I sincerely hope I can come back and change my review.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Update:I had another go. This game still disappoints me.The biggest let down for me is that the Civilization franchise still hasn't figured out how to make the computer players (I refuse to call them AI - there's nothing intelligent about them) enrich the game. There are three HUGE problems for me:1. Civilization computer players suck. They always have and now I'm convinced they always will. When you increase the difficulty of this game, the computer players get more starting units, combat modifiers, research modifiers etc. That's not making the computer players more competitive. That's allowing the computer to cheat. It's the easy way out and worse, it means all those stupid decisions the computer players make on easier settings are made on the more difficult settings.2. Immersiveness went out the window in Civ V and hasn't returned for Civ VI. Specifically, the computer players are unashamedly "players" - they're not leaders of civilizations. When I saw in Civ V that Caesar didn't like me because "They think you're trying to win the game the same way they are" I face palmed so hard my brain rattled. I mean- WHAT? I don't want that! Who wants that? If I want to play Civ with friends, I will do so. Incidentally, I don't. For me, Civ isn't a multiplayer game. I don't want to play a game. I want to rule the world!!!In Civ VI you can give a player tribute to learn more about them. I shouldn't be able to know about their style of play. Stop reminding me that I am playing a game.In this sitting of Civ VI, Qin Shi Huang denounced me for "Having more wonders than they do"... I HAVE ONE WONDER! IT'S 300AD AND I HAVE BUILT ONE WONDER!!!!! Within one turn of that wonder being built, I was denounced. That's not intelligence. It makes for an absolutely miserable game. Which brings me onto the next problem...3. The computer players have absolutely no context to their decision making. In my game, I have never declared war on anyone. Three times, I have had other "players" (because I'm not dealing with countries or leaders here) declare war on me. The first time, I took one city from the offender. They denounced me ever since. The second time, I wiped that same offender out, because lets face it, they were going to keep declaring war on me. I took one city from the other player who declared war at the same time. An unrelated player now denounces me for being a war monger (yet I have started no wars) and the offending player, who confirmed I could have the city I already took as part of a peace deal, constantly denounces me for having that city. It's like the makers of the game don't want you to go to war, to take cities, TO PLAY THE GAME.As for trade - it's not trade. It's robbery. No matter how much a computer player is struggling in this game, don't expect them to trade fairly with you. No. A common theme in Civilization games is: Nobody wants to trade with you.There are so many games out there which push the envelope on visual effects. The Civilization franchise is so well placed to do the same for AI. Every time, they let the players down.Orginal:I am an avid fan of the Civilization series; I have played every PC Civilization game since Civ II. When I have that itch to play a game but not quite sure which, Civilization is always the scratch. Until now. This is, by a long long way, the worst Civilization game I have ever played. Thankfully I paid £30 on a discount site for this disappointment rather than the £50 price tag on Steam."Just one more turn" is a phrase typically used to describe how difficult it is to put a Civ franchise game down. It is equally apt to describe just how painful it is to plod on in Civ VI - I'm really having to spur myself on to give this game a chance to bite. After a second sitting, I have decided Civ VI has no teeth.Civilization games have been on a steady decline. It was the little things which made Civ II so great - the progressive throne room, the responsive city views, the entertaining live action advisors, the humourous player name victory titles. I miss those features. I now have a single boring advisor who really isn't telling me very much of use. I spend fifteen minutes at a time hitting "end turn" without actually doing anything. I've spent a millenium surrounded by four countries and not had cause to speak with them after the obligatory introduction. I am bored.Rather than "little things" making a great game, there are "little things" which make this game frustrating to play. I can't quite put my finger on it; I have a large screen, yet I feel like I can hardly see anything. I don't know if it's something funky with the cartoony graphics, or that the various helper panels take up too much room (they're not really that big) but I feel like I can't zoom out to a level to see enough of what's going on without being too zoomed out. I end up edge scrolling a lot.And that brings me onto the next problem. I always use edge of screen scrolling in Civ games - it's the intuitive way to see what's to the left, what's to the right etc. In this game, it's switched off by default. Why would you do that? Doesn't matter - at least I can switch it on. Unfortunately, the edge scrolling has been implemented / signed off by a plonker. Here's the simple requirement: "When I move my mouse cursor to the edge of my screen, move the playing window in that direction. Stop when I bring the cursor back into the playing area." That's all it needs to do. Simple. Already implemented in CIV V. But it doesn't work like that. Instead, they have implemented: "When I move my mouse cursor to within an inch of the edge of the screen, start scrolling. Stop scrolling if I go to the edge of the screen. Don't scroll diagnonally if I go to the bottom right hand corner (presumably because their are buttons there?). Do scroll if I go to click one of the buttons at the top of the screen (WHAT????). I want to feel extreme mental anguish when I use edge scrolling."Summary: Gameplay sucks. Graphics too cartoony in some aspects. Overpriced (ignore people who say this is reasonably priced - this is not an AAA game). I simply don't want to play this game and that's a shame because I loved previous installments. Goodbye Civ franchise. Let me know if you start caring about the little things again and stop pretending to be a top end graphics feast.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The only good thing about this game is how it looks. Its visuals, music and overall feel of the game are more than familiar, it’s gorgeous and that’s where my praises end.I’ve played Civilization since it came out, sometime in 1991 and have played all its iterations, including spin-offs (and its ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cousins Call to Power and Alpha Centauri) on the PC and a few outside (PlayStation, N-Gage, Nintendo) its native platform. As the series promises, this is an enjoyable game up until you’re incessantly assaulted by the AI with Missionaries, Apostles, and Inquisitors. Never have I seen a more crippling usage of Religion in a game. Of course, there is a way to protect oneself from the AI’s rabid tactic but a few rounds after successfully defending yourself from the first wave of devout invaders; one quickly realizes you are doing nothing else. This aspect of the game blatantly robs gamers of the entire Civilization experience. Speaking of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cousins, remember Civilization Call to Power? Remember that annoying little unit called the Lawyer, which attacks our cities with injunctions essentially halting its production? That was a game breaker, considering that it wasn’t all that gratifying to play to begin with. The exasperating trinity of Missionaries, Apostles and Inquisitors does the exact annoying thing.Civilization VI is a beautifully executed, aesthetically pleasing game that adds cool aspects like districts to the already awesome series but if fails miserably with the inclusion of draconian victory conditions for Religion.Hint: If Firaxis really wants religion as a victory condition, then an option for non-belief, science-based albeit secular philosophies should be included as well. A unit like “Agent of Reason” should be able to quell religious zealots effortlessly. LOL! :DCivilization VI is a beautifully executed, aesthetically pleasing game that adds cool aspects like districts to the already awesome series but if fails miserably with the inclusion of draconian victory conditions for Religion.Hint: If Firaxis really wants religion as a victory condition, then an option for non-belief, science-based albeit secular philosophies should be included as well. A unit like “Agent of Reason” should be able to quell religious zealots effortlessly. LOL! :D

title: Not Recommended
comment: This iteration of Civ can be very strong, if they patch it properly. I love the core mechanics and the improvements from earlier chapters. Why the downvote then? Well, at present status the game is just not worth its pricetag. Main problems are the subpar tactical AI and skirmish-like diplomacy system.Granted, AI and diplomacy are not a big deal if your goal is to play online. However, I only play singleplayer and the lack of development in these fields totally destroys a game for me. Tactically, the AI is unable to attack: it deploys a carpet of doom which doesn't even try to seize a city and then forgets to keep units up to date. Leaders seem to be bipolar and slaves of their agendas and seem unable to evaluate a military/political scenario. This is inexcusable, given that Firaxis was able to deploy a great diplomacy system years ago with SMAC.Honestly, I was expecting a bit more, for this price. While I'm able to forgive bad AI and diplomacy in a game like endless legend (which costs 1/3 of this), I can't do the same for a game developed from a company who used to set the standard with their products (and whose games are so pricey).

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have TONS of hours in Civ5, but I only played one game and just uninstalled it.I dont understand why they dont take all the things that worked from previous versions of a game and move them forward. I really do love the art and visuals but really don't see myself playing more than one game.They changed the wonders system so they can only be built in certain places on certain terrain and such. I LOVE building wonders. But its not fun for me in Civ6.I really feel bad but I can't recommend this game. Maybe later if they add/change game concepts. I wonder if people will spend the time to mod it. Miss the mods from Civ5.Plus, if an enemy civ coverts your city to their religion, thats it. There is no hope of getting your original religion started again. In civ5 your holy city would eventually turn back to your own religion.Pros: Good graphics, good sound and narration. I love the animation when a wonder is built.Cons: see above and no mods yet.Take care,J.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Tried it several times and it looked promising at first. But then you find out that all the extra "options" are just a disguise for more linear gameplay. In order to get ahead in the game, you can boost research by doing or building certain things, or have other things researched. All this makes that there really is only 1 way to do it right, and that is to follow the set linear development outlined by the research boosts.Furthermore, halfway down the game you are going to completely freak out about all the religious crap they put into the game. It's unbelievably frustrating to time on time again see all your religious units bite the dust in "religious combat". thats another way of saying: Absolutely 0 tactics required, just need to have more units then the other guy. Does the other guy have more units? I guess you're gona have to start over, play another 2 days untill you get to the exact same point, and then start over again. At least your development curve is so ridiculously linear that you can practically play it with your eyes closed.Don't buy it. It's utter♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

title: Not Recommended
comment: After playing a few rounds of this game I've come to realise that Civ is a long dead franchise that is microwaved and re-served to the public for top dollar. There are really few changes from the previous iterations and considering how bad Beyond Earth was I would have hoped they would have made some real changes. The barbarians have way too many units and they seem to progress as fast as the top player/AI.Major dissapointment in the Culture sector in terms of a "victory condition". Conquest is the easiest (as usual) and requires little skill aside from having 10+ cities all pumping out attacking units and going straight for the closest enemy. Trying to build up the culture needed to win is nearly impossible. Add to the fact that the AI are just simply better than you at it even on lower difficulties. This game tries way too hard to please everyone and instead spreads everything out.Policies are annoying to say the least. You get 50 policies and you have to stop and read each and every one of them every time a spot opens up. Making it tediously boring for the long game when you have to think which type of victory you want. Only to realise on the next turn that you wasted your wildcard spots on culture only to be denounced and invaded in a 5 turn span.Mildly dissapointed in the direction this game took and as usual, it's too late to get a refund. No such thing as a hard copy to return anymore just digital downloads that will never see a refund even if you're entitled to one.3/10 every other Civ was better.

title: Not Recommended
comment: After putting some hours into the game i think i can now actually comment on it.And sadly this means that i cannot recommend this game in its current state (12-4-2016).This doesnt mean that the game has no good points to it, because there are quiet a few. The music is nice except for the menu music - that one is awesome. The graphics are a matter of taste obviously, but i found them to be nice to look at - which is important when a game takes such a long time. And of course its a civilisation game - so a lot of concepts are in the game just as expected. Oh yeah, and it is surprisingly enough fun to play in spite of its shortcomings.So why not recommend it ? Simply put - with a pricetag such as this product has its flaws are - in my eyes - unforgiveable.Exiting the game after playing for "too long" (time would have to be estimated) it will just not terminate and either force you to restart your computer or find a workaround to kill the game process. Bugs like that are major things that had to be known prior to release.And then we get to the "design choices" that are seriously impeding the fun for me.Like denouncing. You will get denounced by 70% of all civs for about 70% of the game (totally not made up numbers). For just about everything. You are a warmonger. Or have a different government. Or you have no spies in the ancient era. Or too little territory. Or to big of one. It actually doent matter - its the favourite past-time of the ai.Like the warmonger concept itself. Declare war on someone ? Warmonger. Get declared on ? Warmonger. Take a city ? Warmonger. Raze a city ? Guess for yourself. Do something like that (or have it done to you) and you are a warmonger. Forever. I think its like a certifikate of participation. Everyone gets one. No idea what it should accomplish, but as of now its just a reason for getting denounced. Not that the ai needs any reason for that.Like the religion thing. Doesnt work at all. The ai send myriads of religious units over the map in order to do some sightseeing i guess. Because theres not too much conversion happening while they stroll around your country happily blocking the way for anyone. There even was a war where one ai declared on me and then couldnt get any units through the clump of religios desaster that Pedro had seemingly exiled into my country. I think our armies fought each other via radio using harsh language until in the end Pericles payed for peace. Obviously it was the religious system at work here. Following the ai logik the best use for inquisitors is to round them up, herd them into enemy territory and then sacrifice them by attacking an obviously way superior unit - thereby eradicating any trace of the corresponding religion in the area. I can only guess the design process involved a lot of "praying that it works".Like the missing balance of science/culture points and corresponding techs. where you more or less have to spam future techs from 1950 onward. If you were lazy on techs, that is.Like diplomacy. Its basically not there. The ai cheats at every opportunity. They get bonuses like no tomorrow. Sadly they also get "agendas" to determine whether they like you or not. They might like cultured civs. That means not you because of their headstart you are pitiful to them. They might like civs with lots of territory. That means not you because of their headstart you have only a third of their land. If youre lucky. And due to this they basically hate you and it only gets worse from there. Did i mention they will denounce you ?I could go on and on, but that would not achieve anything here. It seems as if almost any concept in the game is only halfway there. And more or less untested. I guess the playtesters were actually playing another game and noone noticed. This game needs a lot of work to be good, because the framework is actually here. But it is really not ok to sell this mess at a pricetag that high.And that is why i advise to not get this game now - but maybe keep an eye on it.Hope this helps at least someone out there.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I could not finish a single session without getting bored and losing interest mainly because of the following issues:The AI is terrible and frustratingly stupid. Diplomacy is broken that you are better off playing against barbarians whose actions are, at least, justified unlike the AI Civs. You will certainly get denounced just for not doing what they like like a bunch of 5-year-olds.AI interaction is really bad. The dialogs are almost always not suited with the situation they are in. They are mostly in a rude and demanding attitude even when surrendering or asking for a favor for free. Gone are the sorry attitudes of AIs from Civ V.Religion is pointless.No United Nations / World Congress - a big blow to the diplomacy, which is nonexistent anyways.The cartoony graphics does not really appeal to me. I find it lazy and not really a huge step forward from Civ V.The game presents you a nice feature of custom-building your Civ V with different districts then trolls you by removing your control over when and where you can build your roads. Aparrently, trade caravans handle the civil works on the sides. A minor issue to most maybe.This is perhaps a good game broken by dysfunctional AI and by removing features present in the previous games that are not broken.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The game is great! The new mechanics work quite well and the overall look is pretty neat... BUT (and it's a huge but!) the AI is terrible. Worst AI I've ever seen in any Civ game.The game (for me) is unplayable at the moment. So many random decisions by the AI that destroy hours of playtime.Firaxis, FIX THE AI!Update: AI seems better after some patches. But now they start to put new content as DLC in the game. Bad practice... would have expected that from Ubisoft, but not Firaxis. I'll leave it at negative... still too disappointed.

title: Recommended
comment: TL;DRIn a short summary, this is an excellent game crippled by AI, which will still be very enjoyable, especially with friends.Full review(pros and cons further down)SummaryThe game has the potential to be the best in the series, it has various new mechanics, the visuals are refreshing for the series, and replayability is amazing. Although probably the only "major" so to speak problem would be the AI and how it behaves.In the current state of the game, playing against AI is somewhere between boring and annoying.The problems the AI seem to have are the following:Another problem that is more evident in higher and lower difficulties is the unbalanced tech tree.An AI on king difficultyIn addition, the tree seems like it has multiple weird spots, such as archery not leading to anything, meaning you avoid it, fearing a waste of turns. Worse even is the top line of the tech tree, starting with sailing, which leads to compters without any intervention from the other tech lines.The UI is largely find and polished, namely the main menu being one of my favorites in gaming history (gotta love some christopher tin music), although it has some shortcomings, such as very small X buttons to exit diplomacy screens, and the auto unit-rotate feature which has caused me to waste so many movements.Players of previous civ games will know that the mid game has been nutoriously stale.Fortunately, in civ 6 this is mostly not the case, if you can build your cities properly, production wise.The game is mostly fine, although some people seem to report crashes on load, loads hanging and such, but those being pretty rare, it's not a real worry.The music for the game, composed by Christopher Tin is absolutely stellar.Some people have compared it to Baba Yetu, which won a grammy. I am one of those.is in my opinion the best main theme civ had. ever.The music for each civilization also evolves through the eras, having a very basic tune in the ancient era, and all the way to the information era, where the core melody (such as a banjo for america) remains, but has many layers added to it.Civ 6 has a very strong lineup of features and is generally very enjoyable, but due to a very annoying fault with the AI, it is somewhat problematic.

comment: A definite improvement over previous entries, Civilization VI is one of the better strategy games of its kind and is addicting on several levels. Right now there are a few weird bugs and the UI could be a little improved but overall I would recommend this to anyone who liked any of the previous titles in the series. All of the systems from previous games have been either revamped, rebalanced, or rethought completely and it shows. AI is better, explanations of what gets on the AI's good side are better, districts are a wonderful alternative to straight city upgrades so you can specialize different physical areas of your civilization, and government policies are a wonderful change from the previous systems where you now pick and choose various attributes as you see fit as part of a larger whole. I could go on for days, really; there's so much to love about this game. Buy it, try it, you won't regret it for sure.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The religion system might have a bit of truth to it in that you can't necessarily just declare war against a religion, but between the continual harassment of opposing religious minions and the war weariness disabling your functionality, I have yet to finish suffering through one session of the game. Trade routes not having a permanent/reoccuring option is also very annoying. Overall I'm trying to finish the one game I started, but I highly doubt I'll be able to bring myself to start another.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The diplomacy is completely broken compared to V and the maps feel cramped with the new city districts. There simply isn't enough space to grow your cities. Diplomacy is completely random and unpredictable. You can be 'best friends' with a civilisation one turn and with no rhyme nor reason they'll declare war on you the next turn. This hasn't been fixed yet despite this complaint being a common thread throughout the negative reviews. I love the Civ Series so I'm sad this one is so broken.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is as much of, if not more of, a let down as No Man's Sky. The graphics are terrible and cartoonish, but I believed I would be able to get over this (I never did; they are distracting and unprofessional). The AI and new "Hidden Agendas" are absolutely terrible. I struggled to get even one AI to like me. All the rest just wanted to go to war with me. Housing is a broken new system that has enormous potential, but was executed extremely poorly. The districts system also has lots of potential, but is completely broken. Production is now a commodity more sought after than gold or any luxury resource, even on Quick game mode. This game was a complete waste of $60.And the sad thing is, it didn't have to be.I wasn't that mad when I first bought this game and saw these broken aspects, because I figured that they would fix them quickly. But they didn't. Instead, they ignore their customer's complaints, and continue releasing stupid mini-DLCs just so that they can make even more money.The game also has SO MUCH potential, just everything was executed so poorly.Civ V was and is SOOOOOO much better than Civ VI. Do not waste your money on this worthless game. Do not be fooled by the legions of 9/10s and 10/10s that you see from all the "professional" reviewers. I'm not saying that they were paid off, but something definitely is not right, because this game sucks.Save your money, and your time. This game is not even worth the thought.Sincerely,And Extremely Angry Reviewer

title: Not Recommended
comment: After a few hours of playing through Sid Meier's Civilization VI, I simply had to stop. I was not enjoying myself whatsoever like I had in Civ games previous to this one. This simply did not feel like a Civ game to me. What this was, was a board game with the "Sid Meier's Civilization" name slapped on it. This simply was not an improvement from its predecesors, and quite frankly, a waste of money, especially since I spent extra to buy any existing DLC that was to come out. No DLC could save this game from what it is, and that is a downgrade; plain and simple. It might be a long time before the next release of a Sid Meier's Civilization title, but after playing this game, I am not sure it is worth getting my hopes up for.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Right off the bat, this game explains nothing to you, it simply puts you into the world and expects you to know what to do. The turns progress without you wanting them to, and the forces which YOU are supposed to be in control of pretty much do whatever they want. You have absolutely no control of what land you claim as far as I can tell, but that might just be me since the game still has not explained any of the controls. Every single time something happens on the map, the game diverts your attention from whatever you are doing to that thing, and once again, you have almost no control of what is happening. I simply would not recommend this game to anyone.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Whilst an hour and a half is perhaps not enough time to form a real opinion, I am limited to Steams 2 hour refund policy so I'm playing this one safe and requesting a refund.I thorougly enjoyed Civ IV back in the day and absoultly love the final (all DLCs) version of Civ V and was really looking forward to Civ VI. However I was reluctant to pre order (way back when) and given some of the mixed reports I opted to wait for decent sales price. Unfortunetly I feel myself siding with the more negative reviews and agree that Civ 6 feels like it took one step forward and 2 steps back. Graphically it's taken a more cartoon look ..which is neither good nor bad as some things work where others do not. Game play wise though is where the biggest diffrence happens. Once upon a time I could que things up, set workers and scouts on auto pilot and worry solely about growing my empire and army. Now I have to micro manage every little detail. Workers only last 3 turns, I have to decide what each city is going to be about before I've really started building anything and I have to plan each and every move scouts take.This may or may not be a good thing in the long term but the changes are huge from Civ V and instead of being quirky and new, I found them irritating and lackluster. Had the game not been so expensive (£42 at sales price including DLC) I may have been tempted to stick it out longer but for the price I was neither hooked nor interest in the game. A single senario Demo could have been the real deciding factor but those days are long gone. Civ V (which I bought as a full game at launch and the DLC as it released) has given me hundreds of hours of gameplay and not once have I questioned my purchase. I truely thank Fraxis for that. Civ VI however had me questioning my purchase (at least at the price) in 60 mins.As with the previous Civ games, I suspect the additional content will make all the diffrence and offer a much better gameplay experiance once it's added / released. Till then, if you don't own them I'd recommend buying Civ V + Civilization Beyond Earth instead as you'll get a much grander 2 game experiance for less money.However...I will return Civ VI. you will be re purchased and played one day. But not before you mature in content and gameplay a bit more. You're just to expensive a date for my tastes at this point.

title: Not Recommended
comment: VERY overtuned.Barbarians will swarm you to no end within the first 10 turns, forcing you to poor all your production into combat units. Did I mention they're up farther than you in the tech tree with horseback riding, archers, and spearmen?While you're fighting off the 20 Barbarian units knocking on your door, you'll find some leader. This leader HATES that you are either not expanding or have a big army. Guess who else wants to kill you now?Lastly, the district system. You can't build everything in your main city, meaning you have to juggle the new housing system, the new amenitiesm system, in adition to having to occupy various tiles for their districts, which you can't build anyway due to those barbarians.And, no, you CAN'T block the barbarians from finding your capital. In most cases they will find it on Turn 2.Save yourself some money and go back to Civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Three wortds: slow, boring, unreliable. The early stages of the game are reminiscent of past versions, and I enjoyed learning what's new and setting up a few civilizations, but have had the patience to complete the game only once, and that was a chore. Once the world gets a little complicated, the game slows down to where the time between turns stretches to minutes. I usually get up and go do something else while waiting for the next turn. Not an enjoyable way to play.And then there are the crashes. At least three times the game has crashed my system to the point that I have to shut down and reboot. One time the only way I managed that was to pull the plug, as the computer was completely frozen.I find this product to be Not Worth the Expense and Trouble.

title: Recommended
comment: I've given Civ VI a try...over 220 turns worth of it so far. Enough to have a good feel for the game. As a Civ veteran I was able to pick it all up pretty quickly and it's not too much different than Civ V. But it is different. Not sure if I really like it or not right now, kind of on the fence. I like the map, especially the effects regarding the unknown and areas you've explored. I actually rather like the districts for cities. It's different and seems to work OK. I also like that you can't spam every wonder you see. Like others, I think the AI is not very good...but it's never really all that good in a Civ game so that's nothing new. I don't like the rather cartoony feel of the explored map and the units. I don't dislike it either but it's glaringly different in look from Civ V so will take some getting used to. I am mixed about the cartoony feel of the leader screens too. Is Civ VI the best yet? I reserve judgement for now. Overall the game has a good feel and flow about it and it's certainly got that Civ 'just one more turn...' addiction going for it. And so far it hasn't felt buggy, no crashes or anything. And it works well on fairly minimal specs. But I'm also not going to stop playing Civ V yet either. Still I like Civ VI and we'll see what it looks like after they add updates to it.
