comment: Except for the graphic, nothing better than the civ V.No United NationsNo national statistics (number of citizen, number of military personnel, etc)No rankings of my cities (I need to rank them by my memory)No buliding of roads like V, the merchants always choose a sea route rather than travelling along the coast in some pacticular situations, so I can never build a road between two cities.bug:missing combat sound ramdomly in the game, no way to fix it whatever I did.The hotkeys are always broken after an hour gameplaysometimes get crush once I tried to quit the game

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've played the Civ franchise since the 2nd edition, and had high hopes for Civ 6. After all, there has not yet been an iteration that wasn't an improvement upon the previous game. Sadly, the devs either over thought this offering, or didn't bother showing it to anyone before they went live. My complaints aren't numerous, but taken as integral to the user experience, they're fatal:1) The interface is chaotic, monotone, and inefficient. Looking at a bustling game board replete with trivial, oversized and overlapping icons gives me vertigo. The fog of war/fog of exploration seems like a realistic improvement, but the layer ends up adding more busy-ness to an already crowded screen.2) Executing diplomacy and finding information on other civs or city states is onerous (not impossible). I'd expect this from a Europa game or others engineered towards well, engineers, but in a Civ game simplicity has been and should remain king. Every time you have a conversation with another Civ, not only are you forced to say Goodbye, additionally you have to click X to exit.3) The AI is TERRIBLE. Just TERRIBLE. No amount of coercion, backstabbing, aggressiveness or demands after early-mid game can trigger a war. Other Civs are spineless for the remainder of the game after losing an initial war.All told, from the first hour of play I had a niggling doubt in my head that said "Okay, its weird, but keep plugging away, it will get good." It never did. By the fourth restart with different settings, I'd completely lost interest.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game needs a lot of work. Some of the key issues include:1) Completely asinine AI. Absolutely the worst AI of any of the CIv games. Go from ally to enemy in one turn, denouce you for simply having a different government type, and every AI thinks you're a warmonger for defending yourself. One good example is, I launched a war to liberate England, including their capital. What did I get for it? Everyone denoucning me, including England. Moreover, they will denounce you and then try and trade with you the very next turn. It's almost as if it was late on a Friday for the dev team and they just "went with it as is."2) Game is simply too slow in the latter ages. Even with cities that have a strong industrial focus, it takes way too long to build anything. It shows with the AI. Their armies are typically very small, which makes the game boring. Most wars are over too fast, because no one can afford to build enough.3) No United Nations? This seems like a major oversight, as it plays a big role in Civ 5. Half of the reason to get city states on your side is lost.4) If you lose the game, you'll never know why. It simply pops up and says....you lose, game over. No stats, or details behind why you lost. Unbelieveable.5) Religion is TERRIBLE. I disable religious victories. All you do is spam as many apostles and missionaries as you can...all over the world. That's it. Relgion should go back to what it was, a branch of culture.All of this drives the game into one simple direction.....war. It's way too easy to just roll over everyone. Why struggle with anemities and resource trading when you can simply take it all? This game feels very polished in some areas, and terribly underdone in others. I'm hopeful they will fix this with quick updates.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Graphics are too cartoony, game play is so very slow due to too many new techs to get anything. Worst of all is that it constantly crashs freezing my whole computer so I have to hard shut down (control alt delete just goes to black screen with this game). Bugs and crashes need fixing ASAP!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Edit: for people looking at the digital deluxe package I do not find that 2K lived up to the promises of either content or savings. Because after the sales and discounts for DLC as well as the content included in them I would have been better suited to buy a la carte. This is my reason for going from a positive to a negative reccomendation, while the game is OK I can no longer feel this is worth the value.This is not your grandfather's civilization. This is the biggest evolution that Civ has seen yet. Gone are the old tried and true tactics that work in all situations. With Civ 5 they unstacked your armies creating tactical combat, with Civ 6 they unstacked cities creating tactical city development. The new inspiration/eureka system allows a player to strategically develop in a method that advances sciences and policy evolving gameplay even more.Debates over the cartoony art style are petty and irrelevant because it was designed to make the map more readable, and it achieves that. Though the UI and options could use some updating it is not unusable when the player learns to read it and redefines a few hotkeys. Becoming accompanied with the new lenses views helps with this.On city growth this is the biggest change and one that everyone must learn to adapt to. No longer can a player just decide that every city is a build everything one stop production facility. In part because of the new district system that forces players to focus each city in what they geography is suited for, and in the other part because you no longer have the time to really build everything with abandon. You actually can make mistakes that later on can cause you regrets. Learning to read the land and plan each city in advance proves to be a most important skill.Government and policies are a new feature that replaces the pre-existing civics system of just leveling up features of your civilization. Now you must pick and choose how your society operates and one choice must come over another, not just the constant improvement without any real mistakes possible.Religious combat adds a new level to gameplay offering tactical religious spread and defense. There is even a promotion for your religious units that can aid your standard combat units.Espionage has altered and takes a small amount of management but this allows for targeted missions and benefits. You can again steal and sabotage and you can now steal great works.Great people are now more individual offering varying differences that each civilization must compete for. One great scientist may give you science inspirations while another builds a university and another improves all your science buildings. These variations apply to all the versions of great people.Diplomacy has been improved offering all the old options and a few new effects like causus beli and information levels allowing you to peak into the motives and activities of your opponents. The new system used in regards to city states offers improved benefits for being their ally (now called suzerain) with the offset that it is more difficult to be everyone's friend. Your resource to secure them is how many envoys you can generate with them and not an object that you can buy with infinite cash. Suzerain bonuses are also unique to each city state so far and depending on how you play can be spectacular.The game plays at a much faster speed than previous versions allowing for people to complete a game sooner, personally I play on epic speed (50% longer game(I think it is actually 100% longer)) to help maintain the speed I am used to. It also offers some scenario mods for fast play multiplayer games.Overall this is a much deserved improvement to the series and the designers achieved a sincere effort on making the game more accessible for fans of the series. The UI features do make for more management in large games due to lack of automation utilities (though if you are automating everything you are missing out on the point of games like this anyways). The player will find the UI counter intuitive if they are coming out of previous Civ games and will need to learn to adapt. Some information is not clearly labeled in a numerical representation that avid gamers desire to make calculations. Players must now make decisions and choosing may result in hind sighted regrets giving each choice more impact as the game progresses. Almost all core mechanics have been improved and stability is strong and noticeable bugs are low.TLDR: Do not do that, this was written for a reason.

comment: Have been a lomg time user of the Civ franchise - I loved them all unti last year's dud, Civ Beyond Earth. Unfortunately, after giving this a good try over the last few months, I'm just not hooked. Tons of micro management to do, plus out of control barbarian and opponent bonuses - evon on a low setting. I never could seem to get traction to expand much more beyond a few cities without falling way behind in science. I'd skip this one if you have been thinking about it- it's just not the addictive Civ experience I had hoped for.

title: Recommended
comment: Although I recommend the game I'm going to outline the biggest problems with the game currently.Pros:Overall highly polished gameSean Bean is greatRelatively few gamebraking bugs (Only for Civ and Xcom is this a pro... LOL...)Interesting fleshed out mechanics (districts, wonders, adjacency combos)Cons: (biggest problem to smallest)AI is thoroughly braindead, doesn't matter if you crank the difficulty up, idiotic AI ruins your experience... You can beat any AI army with 3 well placed ranged units and a couple of well placed melee defenders. The AI will play like a 2 year old in every way, it will build wonders it doesn't need and thoroughly annoy you with unnecessary announcements. (denounce, warnings and once they ♥♥♥♥ up thier offensive request peace every turn until you kill them)Many straight up balance problems,The units are extremely cheap compared to districts, especially later onbuilders clearing resources is ridiculously powerful, you can destroy resources outside your city limits (3x3hex) and considering you can use a builder to rush production of your next builder (builder cost = ~60 production but cheaper in lower difficulty, forest clear = 60 prod.. )China OP because of above builder issue.UI is garbage tier nonsense.The auto-unit switching is infuriating (thank god for the work around)Overall, if the issues are fixed it might be the best game in the Civ series but for now you might even want to wait for a sale if you care about money...

title: Recommended

title: Recommended
comment: Although I recommend the game I'm going to outline the biggest problems with the game currently.Pros:Overall highly polished gameSean Bean is greatRelatively few gamebraking bugs (Only for Civ and Xcom is this a pro... LOL...)Interesting fleshed out mechanics (districts, wonders, adjacency combos)Cons: (biggest problem to smallest)AI is thoroughly braindead, doesn't matter if you crank the difficulty up, idiotic AI ruins your experience... You can beat any AI army with 3 well placed ranged units and a couple of well placed melee defenders. The AI will play like a 2 year old in every way, it will build wonders it doesn't need and thoroughly annoy you with unnecessary announcements. (denounce, warnings and once they ♥♥♥♥ up thier offensive request peace every turn until you kill them)Many straight up balance problems,The units are extremely cheap compared to districts, especially later onbuilders clearing resources is ridiculously powerful, you can destroy resources outside your city limits (3x3hex) and considering you can use a builder to rush production of your next builder (builder cost = ~60 production but cheaper in lower difficulty, forest clear = 60 prod.. )China OP because of above builder issue.UI is garbage tier nonsense.The auto-unit switching is infuriating (thank god for the work around)Overall, if the issues are fixed it might be the best game in the Civ series but for now you might even want to wait for a sale if you care about money...

title: Recommended
comment: As a completely new and clueless player to the Sid Meier's Civilization franchise, it took me a lot of hours of gameplay, tutorials and walkthroughs to finally learn how to properly play the game. Even at my current playtime, which is 30+ hours, I'm 100% sure that I have not explored even 1/4 of the game.Civ6 is also educational for someone like me, who doesn't know much about history. You get to learn about past civilizations and a hero that lead them to the peak of their time. You also get a description of every wonder that you build and every time you proceed on the science and culture progress, you get a quote regarding the matter that you researched which I think is also a very nice touch.I must also add that it is awesome having the ability to interact with the other leaders playing on the same session, declaring friendships, asking for alliances, doing trades, making them mad or happy with your actions etc.I can't compare Civ6 to any of the previous games because as I stated before I haven't played them. As someone who got introduced to Civ on this date and this version, I can't say I'm dissapointed that I gave this a try.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Adding new content is all well and good but more civs and features is not what this game needs and it won't matter as long as the AI doesn't get a much needed overhaul.To put it bluntly the AI is as dumb as a bag of bricks.Not only the AI can't wage war but it will routinely fail to protect its workers and settlers from both barbarians and the player (apparently moving a lonely settler within range of an enemy unit in wartime is a good idea despite the game explicitly warning you about this).The AI leaders keep berating you and denouncing you (following the Civ V tradition) but if you have a military lead the worst they can do is spamming missionaries. You don't even need to field a big army to go for domination.If you're a returning Civ player you may want to play at a higher level of difficulty (at least two or three ranks above the difficulty you're used to playing Civ V) otherwise the game will feel like you're playing on Settler difficulty.To sum things up Civ 6 brings some nice additions like the Eureka system, districts and nations and leaders that are new to the series (although I don't know why they chose an Italian who never held the crown in her name and is better known for authorising the massacre of French Protestants in one of the most notorious events in French history as the leader for France).It's a pity really because some additions are pretty good but as long as they don't improve the AI as a returning Civ player you're better off playing Civ V Brave New World, Beyond Earth Rising Tide or (if you don't mind the older graphics) Civ 4 Beyond the Sword.

title: Recommended
comment: Best Civ Yet.PROS: Extremely enjoyable and smooth.The Standard map size is much larger than previous Standard sizes. Or perhaps growth is scaled. Either way, very nice.Fog of War is the best I've seen in any game.The Policy interface allows for varied growth styles and customization in civ tactics.The cartoonish characters really add to the appeal to the game.Creating corps and then armies is an ingenious solution to stacking.The ability to transfer Great People and traders between cities breaks removes slow, laborious moving of these assets around the map. It allow you to help cities when they need it.The city-state interface leaves no guesswork as to ranks highest in their eyes.Notifications by AI players on why you are being denounced makes the game fullerCONS:AN OCEAN LINER IN A LAKE: The AI still funnels the game towards wars. War is easy, peace and stability... impossible (so far) Seemingly random, unprovoked denunciations with no notification as to why. I really deflates the all-around depth, forethought and fullness put into the game. Its like building great ocean liner, then making sail in only one or two lakes, but never the sea and never for long.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I got this game on launch. It took some time to get used to the differences, but I actually did like it on launch. That's slowly becoming not the case.I don't know if it was altered in a patch, but my main gripe is the lack of balanced starting points. Here's how civ games go for me right now.-Start game-Don't start near Iron-Don't start near Niter-Halfway through Renaissance but still using warriors-Get mad and abortUnder the "Standard" starting positions I could see this happening, but the above happens to me even when playing on "Balanced" starting positions. Yea....real balanced idiots.Another issue I have right now, which isn't as big since you can turn it off, is how OP religious and cultural (ESPECIALLY cultural) can be. Assuming I get the aforementioned resources, I can steam roll much of the AI, only to ninja lose the game because one civ on the complete opposite end of the map from me has been spamming great works the entire game, or spamming religious units the entire game. Even though you can turn them off if you wish, the point is I shouldn't have to turn them off. The game should be balanced in a way where these types of civs still have to maintain somewhat of a military if they're going to try to win this way.(Open to modifying this review as patches and fixes come in.)

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is a huge step gack from Civ V.Due to some questinable coloring choices, the game map became unnecessarily hard to read and overall management and information screens one got used to were either removed or greatly reduced in clarity and usefulness.For example the empire overview screen that lists all cities has been hidden in the "reports" submenu and was stripped of almost all functionality that made it useful: It is no longer possible to sort the list of your cities and you can no longer access a city's build queue from there - in fact you can't even navigate to the city or open its detail screen from there. Instead you'll have to scroll the list looking for the criteria you're currently interested in, memorize the city name and then scroll the game map until you find the city with that name.And this is just one example of how gameplay-central tools are just broken in this title.TL;DR: If you loved Civ V and/or Civ III, skip this title and hope that Civ VII will be a worthy successor again.

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization VI is an interesting game, it released with more content than Civ V did, it has new mechanics that allow more customization to your empire, and it still keeps that same feeling of "one more turn." I was frustrated by Civ Beyond Earth, from technical bugs to issues with progression, maybe because it was foreign to me I just couldn't get into it in the way I expected. I still had some of that anxiety going into Civ 6, maybe it wouldn't be the game I wanted it to be, that it would be a step backwards from Civ V which is one of my favorite games of all time.I think Civ 6 has the bones to be the best Civ yet, every aspect has some new level of depth or thought put into it, from great people having unique bonuses, to limiting the typical wonder spamming cities by requiring tile placement of wonders, to city state bonuses being more unique and having that race for Suzerain. I love when you find a great spot for a district with huge adjacency bonuses, setting up a great holy site or harbor really feels better than just adding a building to a production queue.That said, there is still a lot of frustration for me as a classic Civ gamer, barbarian encampments that spawn high damage horsemen or ranged ships within the first 20 turns, movement penalties being changed from Civ V, some unit autocycling problems, and even AI bugs like not upgrading or spamming too much of one type of unit. I think most of those faults are overlooked by the core of the game being much deeper. Along this line, the first fall patch to Civ 6 addressed many issues, and has me excited for future updates to improve quality of life for the game.Also, as a new father, Civ 6 is one of the few games I can play while holding my baby. I often play with the steam controller so that I can set up all the mouse actions to be controlled by one hand while I cradle the baby in my other arm.If I had to recommend one Civ game to a newcomer, I’d say you can’t beat Civ 5 with all the DLC, it has everything I love about civ and isn’t working through any bugs or UI issues, but if you have played Civ before, Civ 6 is a great addition to the series and I can’t wait to see what more they bring to the table.

title: Recommended
comment: This is a really great game. It feels as it is an expansion to Civ Rev because of it looking more cartoony and the fact that you can combine units into "corps" and "army". The game is a lot harder than civilization 5 which is what I am really used to, because of that I struggle when playing. They changed the resource system they had in Civ 5, as an example in Civ 5 if you had iron in your borders it gave you an amount when you mouse over it, in Civ 6 you only get one of that resource which means you have to waste tiles on resources, wonders, and districts.Here are my pros and consPros: Improved interface (in my opinion),better combat animation,gets rid of the social policy system from Civ 5 and replaces it with "Civics" (not Honda),ability to combine units to make a corps and army for land units besides the SAM launchers,better diplomacy, actual leader animation,better settlement recommendations,Cons: Completly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the unit movement system and unfuqulating swift and easy unit movement (I cannot move armies quick enough when at war or fighting barbarians),The♥♥♥♥♥♥of the Workers (they replaced the Worker unit with the builder. The Worker in Civ 5 had unlimited uses while the Builder unit in Civ 6 only has 3 uses per unit),Changing and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the resource system that I loved in Civ 5 as I taked about above,at random times while playing a singleplayer game about 2-3 civs will start an alliance and declare war against you which means you must always have a large and powerful military at all times (alliance wars can happen more than once),the district system which you need certain districts to build certain things like buildings and wonders and having to waste tiles and gold for districts and wonders,3 Greek civs in the game,No ability to play singleplayer scenarios,The new happiness system which makes you build stuff in cities that give you more "Housing" and "Amenities" to make your citizens happy then the system in Civ 5 where you could actually see what your current happiness was and you could build things and imporrve resources to fix,No Golden Ages,Needing the "Militarty Engineer" unit to build roads (only has 2 uses per unit) other than the Militarty Engineer the only other unit that can make roads is the Trader which builds a road on the tile it walks to when on a trade mission,So other than all of that I like this game. For the current add on content they all have negative reviews because people are expecting an add on like Gods and Kings or Brave New World for Civ 5. The only add on's out for Civ 6 are civ/scenario packs which were also released for Civ 5.The problem with the add on's for this game is that people are expecting too soon for a major add on like BNW. 2K did the same thing with Civ 5 for add on's. Between the release of Civ 5 and Gods and Kings there were civ/scenario packs which people didn't complain about then, the same thing is happening now but people are comlpaining about it for no reason.You should get this game, it's a good game to play when trying to pass time. Don't let the negative reviews for the add on's fool you, just look at Civ 5!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Everything about this game is awesome except the AI. The feel of the game and all the new mechanics are fantastic. However, the AI is terrible. "Negotiations" are painful and nearly always hostile. The AI don't make strategic decisions at all. To compensate, on higher difficulty levels they simply cheat. When I generate 2x the science as the next civ while triggering nearly all eurekas, and they stay inexplicably 4 techs behind me for (literally) ages, that's not cool. Especially when that AI player hates my guts because my civ is slightly different from theirs for any number of reasons. I would recommend that fans of the series stick to the earlier games for now.

title: Not Recommended
comment: If you came to play this game looking for a brilliant follow-up to Civilization V..... I really, honestly can't recommend it.For individuals who enjoy heavy micromanagement, a much more difficult gameplay, and balancing their resources intelligently and with potentially great amounts of sacrifice, this game is for them. The management and diffiiculty *of* that management has been cranked up to 11 with the introduction of districts and with the necessity of placing certain buildings (namely Wonders) on their own slot, it makes you have to think very hard about where you build, because you are going to have to sacrifice things like city size for production, and housing amounts for money, and entire swaths of farming space for one district or wonder (in particular the ones that must be placed in extremely specific areas).But that's not all. The changes they have made to the game's UI makes it highly unintuitive, I have yet to find how to check and manage one's army at *all*, the pathing seems to have lost in intelligence, your AI's IQ seems to be on the level of a poorly educated goldfish, builders now can only perform three actions before being used up (but at least they do it instantly rather than taking time.... although I prefered it the other way around), housing and population growth is an absolute *crisis* at times due to needing to manage it by the world around (trust me: this is one game where your 'one city challenge' is going to *REALLY* be a challenge!), familiar commands have gone completely by the wayside and the game's education system doesn't seem to be helpful toward them (I don't want to have to go to Google to find out how to build roads; I would like if the game itself taught me how to do so), and they have removed the ability to create an 'Archapelago' world, thus no longer allowing for a land of islands for those with the pirate blood ("Arrr!").And all this can be yours for the stunning price of.... $80?!For sandboxers, casual gamers, relaxed players, and people who like their AI to have some intuitiveness, I would recommend sticking with Civilization V until they make some fixes to this one (if they do). For its price, I simply cannot recommend this game; it is too expensive for something that is not worth the price of admission. Buy it only when it's on sale, and not for a penny more. I did not enjoy the game anywhere near as much as I hoped I would, and I don't foresee it becoming a game that I could play casually with the rabid drive that Civ V can take me to.The game isn't all bad. For people who like their game more intense, prefer the challenge of a heavy resource management game, are willing to overlook the painful AI, and have spreadsheets to spare, this game can be fantastic. Depending on how you build, you can develop much more strongly and more directly toward any particular type of win that you're looking for. From war districts to trade districts to religious districts, micromanagement in this game is absolutely *key*. Unfortunately, I am not one of these players, and for that reason, I have to say: "Firaxis, your game needs some work."*ESPECIALLY* in the menu area.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civilization VI is to "Civilization" game series, the same sad thing that SimCity (2013) and Societies were to "SimCity" series.This statement will talk to all serious gamers and fans of both franchises. It is so easy and slooooow... so weird that I have the feeling to play "Civilization, for dummies" version.It's not a complete failure, but you will feel seriously cheated. Because jumping from Civilization V to VI is like playing a limited beta version with cartoons design (can't stop thinking to SimCity Societies on this point). I mean... for examples... you can not rename cities, you can not remove cities states. Worker are useless. Modding is locked for now and for long. Civ's basics guys !I sincerely hope you bought the box version too. For less than 40$, you have a DVD with... the standard steam's version on it !!! (60$ on Steam ?!). Including the (limited) "pre order" stuff too ! And a really fun gift you will never have anywhere else ;) THIS IS A FAIR PRICE for what you buy.I needed changes after six years and 650 hrs with Civilization V. I was really pisssed off by Beyond Earth, but it was a spin-off ! This, is the main franchise itselft and it feels to be a joke for now... I think it's time to put red flags up, because this is taking a way that a big part of Civilization's true fans will not follow.Prefer Endless Lengend if you want a Civ like game and need some changes, much better than this one ! And definitely not a 60$ theft !You can give good reviews like dumb bots, but it will not make this game what it is not and will never be ! You got yourself scammed, stop crying and trying to find good reasons to play this game, start to be honest with others and yourself... this game sucks.

title: Recommended
comment: Lots of thumbs down lately.I think when it comes down to it, every Civ game is decent from the get-go, but never really get good until their expansions.I firmly believe that Civ VI is an improvement from Civ V pre-expansions but not better than Civ V post-expansions.But this new installment lays the groundwork for what should be a very memorable entry by the end of its life cycle. I'm having a lot of fun playing with it, and really look forward to the expansions.But it on sale.

title: Recommended
comment: Okay people, new and old. I've played this game since day-one release clocking over 200 hours and it clearly has flaws, but what people seem to be complaining about clearly isn't anything that the devs will 'fix' because it honestly doesn't need fixing.Peoples Major Complaints (and why majority should not be taken into account);The AI does not have a strategy towards combat.Yes, this is very true. They AI's strategic means of warfare is no improvement from previous titles. They practically suicide units onto your own. This can technically be seen as one of the 'actual' problems with AI. (Even though generals in history never suicided troops... *sarcasm*)The AI higher difficulties basically makes them cheat more.Again, this is true. They've done this in previous titles and never improved the AI to perform better and rather just supplement the higher difficulties. (Again, this is nothing new)In general, think more about what issue you have with this game. If these issues stem from you not winning or having a 'personally' bad time, then it's on you, not the game. If 10,000 people find a game fun, and 1 person doesn't, It doesn't mean the game is or isn't fun. It just means that what you're saying it completely driven by Bias, not factual evidence.It's a flawed game, but it is a civilzation game and it's improved a lot upon what Civ 5 was, whilst still adding it's own twist so it isn't just 'Civ 5 2.0'.My issues with this game stem from the DLC marketing, minor glitches and the typically 'cheaty' higher difficulties.People forget multiplayer has mods again, everyone wanted that back since Civ 4...

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is.... unecessary.I loved Civ5. It is one of the best games I've ever played, and definitely the best strategy game I've ever experienced. I bought a new computer just so I could play this game. I paid more for this game than I did for any other game over two years.It wasn't worth it.Civilization VI makes a handful of interesting and enjoyable changes to the near-perfection that was Civ5, while introducing a host of new changes that ruin the game's overall experience. The parallel tech and policy trees are a nice idea, as are the boosts. The loading times are the actually the worst of any Civ, including Civilization on the SNES. The district system is stupid and unnecessary, as is requiring each wonder to be built on its own tile. These can't be torn down, by the way, so think twice before building Stonehenge. The worst offense by far is the mandatory game limit of 500 turns, which as far as I can tell can't be disabled, even if Score Victory is turned off. If the game ends at 500 turns no matter what, then what's the point of disabling the Score Victory? Why does Firaxis feel the need to enforce a 500 turn limit? What's the point?Ultimately Civ6 doesn't make any positive, meaningful changes to what Civ5 did very well. There are some nice, cool touches, and a lot more stupid and frustrating touches, including the main change of the district system. If you really liked Civ5, don't buy this game. Just keep playing Civ5. Otherwise, buy Civ5.

Even though you can turn them off if you wish, the point is I shouldn't have to turn them off. The game should be balanced in a way where these types of civs still have to maintain somewhat of a military if they're going to try to win this way.(Open to modifying this review as patches and fixes come in.)

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is a huge step gack from Civ V.Due to some questinable coloring choices, the game map became unnecessarily hard to read and overall management and information screens one got used to were either removed or greatly reduced in clarity and usefulness.For example the empire overview screen that lists all cities has been hidden in the "reports" submenu and was stripped of almost all functionality that made it useful: It is no longer possible to sort the list of your cities and you can no longer access a city's build queue from there - in fact you can't even navigate to the city or open its detail screen from there. Instead you'll have to scroll the list looking for the criteria you're currently interested in, memorize the city name and then scroll the game map until you find the city with that name.And this is just one example of how gameplay-central tools are just broken in this title.TL;DR: If you loved Civ V and/or Civ III, skip this title and hope that Civ VII will be a worthy successor again.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Everything about this game is awesome except the AI. The feel of the game and all the new mechanics are fantastic. However, the AI is terrible. "Negotiations" are painful and nearly always hostile. The AI don't make strategic decisions at all. To compensate, on higher difficulty levels they simply cheat. When I generate 2x the science as the next civ while triggering nearly all eurekas, and they stay inexplicably 4 techs behind me for (literally) ages, that's not cool. Especially when that AI player hates my guts because my civ is slightly different from theirs for any number of reasons. I would recommend that fans of the series stick to the earlier games for now.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I got this game on launch. It took some time to get used to the differences, but I actually did like it on launch. That's slowly becoming not the case.I don't know if it was altered in a patch, but my main gripe is the lack of balanced starting points. Here's how civ games go for me right now.-Start game-Don't start near Iron-Don't start near Niter-Halfway through Renaissance but still using warriors-Get mad and abortUnder the "Standard" starting positions I could see this happening, but the above happens to me even when playing on "Balanced" starting positions. Yea....real balanced idiots.Another issue I have right now, which isn't as big since you can turn it off, is how OP religious and cultural (ESPECIALLY cultural) can be. Assuming I get the aforementioned resources, I can steam roll much of the AI, only to ninja lose the game because one civ on the complete opposite end of the map from me has been spamming great works the entire game, or spamming religious units the entire game. Even though you can turn them off if you wish, the point is I shouldn't have to turn them off. The game should be balanced in a way where these types of civs still have to maintain somewhat of a military if they're going to try to win this way.(Open to modifying this review as patches and fixes come in.)

title: Recommended
comment: This is a really great game. It feels as it is an expansion to Civ Rev because of it looking more cartoony and the fact that you can combine units into "corps" and "army". The game is a lot harder than civilization 5 which is what I am really used to, because of that I struggle when playing. They changed the resource system they had in Civ 5, as an example in Civ 5 if you had iron in your borders it gave you an amount when you mouse over it, in Civ 6 you only get one of that resource which means you have to waste tiles on resources, wonders, and districts.Here are my pros and consPros: Improved interface (in my opinion),better combat animation,gets rid of the social policy system from Civ 5 and replaces it with "Civics" (not Honda),ability to combine units to make a corps and army for land units besides the SAM launchers,better diplomacy, actual leader animation,better settlement recommendations,Cons: Completly♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the unit movement system and unfuqulating swift and easy unit movement (I cannot move armies quick enough when at war or fighting barbarians),The♥♥♥♥♥♥of the Workers (they replaced the Worker unit with the builder. The Worker in Civ 5 had unlimited uses while the Builder unit in Civ 6 only has 3 uses per unit),Changing and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the resource system that I loved in Civ 5 as I taked about above,at random times while playing a singleplayer game about 2-3 civs will start an alliance and declare war against you which means you must always have a large and powerful military at all times (alliance wars can happen more than once),the district system which you need certain districts to build certain things like buildings and wonders and having to waste tiles and gold for districts and wonders,3 Greek civs in the game,No ability to play singleplayer scenarios,The new happiness system which makes you build stuff in cities that give you more "Housing" and "Amenities" to make your citizens happy then the system in Civ 5 where you could actually see what your current happiness was and you could build things and imporrve resources to fix,No Golden Ages,Needing the "Militarty Engineer" unit to build roads (only has 2 uses per unit) other than the Militarty Engineer the only other unit that can make roads is the Trader which builds a road on the tile it walks to when on a trade mission,So other than all of that I like this game. For the current add on content they all have negative reviews because people are expecting an add on like Gods and Kings or Brave New World for Civ 5. The only add on's out for Civ 6 are civ/scenario packs which were also released for Civ 5.The problem with the add on's for this game is that people are expecting too soon for a major add on like BNW. 2K did the same thing with Civ 5 for add on's. Between the release of Civ 5 and Gods and Kings there were civ/scenario packs which people didn't complain about then, the same thing is happening now but people are comlpaining about it for no reason.You should get this game, it's a good game to play when trying to pass time. Don't let the negative reviews for the add on's fool you, just look at Civ 5!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Don't pay for this game, can't even start a game with the new dlc. What's the point? Just new charges every few months with a game that doesn't work. Why bring more content if the old content doesnt even work properly? Maybe I'll be able to play this DLC I bought in a few months after its release.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I wish I could give it a 1/2 a thumb. It is fun, and I've logged 36hrs (320 turns) as chinese. But it has quite a few flaws and missing elements that have always been part of the franchise. Such as lack of shortcut keys to toggle resource and yield displays, unable to rename cities, lack of detailed screens such as list of poosible trade routes like in V, lack of diplomacy options, leaders are kind of prosaic and lack personality/emotion (you can demand a city or gift them one and their facial expression never changes or do they say anything). I like the realistic art of V better but I dont hate the whimsical new art. With a FREE expansions/update or some expert modding this game could be worth $60. I have a friend who has never played a CIV game wanting to buy it. I told him to save his money and buy CIV V for a fraction of the price with all the expansions and dlc included.So yes, CIV 6 is a fun game and I'll probably keep playing it for a while but like a lot of other people have said it does not feel finished.I bought this on release date. It's since been updated to address some of the original issues. But my overall opinion of the game is still mostly negative. Now that the new game smell has worn off it kind of stinks. Civ 5 had me convinced it was the best game ever made, for a while, and it still might be. But Civ 6 has had me questioning if I even liked it since day 1. One gripe I have with it, that I didn't mention previously, that still remains is the choice of leaders. Theodore Rosovelt for US, really, not washington?! or even Lincoln? And on the same note I noticed the anti-semites at fiaxis havent included Iraeli/Jewish though the oldest CIV still in existence. Jews last appeared in Civ 2 (call to power). And I understand the obligation to include American Civ but mexican is an older civ than american but has yet to appear in any game ( and don't tell me its represented in the Aztec Civ ), because that would be like leaving out the American Civ in Civ 5 and saying it is represented by the Iriquios. Mexico has the most populous city in the Americas. But the lack of Mexico is not the reason this game failed for me, it's just one of the things it didn't do that would have made sense. But not a lot in this game makes sense, like the fact that most people are playing with more powerful computers than they were years ago when 5 came out, yet their latest installment seems to be lacking in features, details and graphics. It honestly feels like a game that should have been released for a mobile device and I have this feeling it was meant to be and probably will be eventually. If it was a $10 mobile game I would give it a thumbs up. $60 predecesor to Cive 5, nope.

title: Recommended
comment: Having played Civ since Civ IV with well over 100+ hours in V, I've already put in 51+ in VI. The game is fun, I enjoy the new set ups for the Culture vs Science trees, giving you a different way to focus on advancement. Does it have problems? Sure, the card system making some choices obsolete when you haven't advanced far enough on the other tree can be -really- annoying, but it isn't game breaking.The positives first, I guess.New Trees give a different way to advance, you can be far more focused on Culture and tourism, it isn't all tied to Science now.The new District system are really neat, especially once you get the hang of how they work and how best to plot your cities around the shared bonuses they sometimes give later on. I like having tile choices for placing Wonders and everything, you have to make choices what you feel is more important in each city. Previously, I would pretty much just build almost every possible building for each of my cities, stacking everything in them because it was generally the best way to build. Now, you can specialize specific cities with which ever districts you want to focus on.Combat is similar to Civ V, not many changes there, though some balancing has occured here and there.Personally, I've found the new map style to be nice, it can be cluttered at times, but overall I approve.Now for some negatives and drawbacks...Diplomacy AI is wonky. Warmonger penalties are currently STUPIDLY high and war is enevitible if you don't play smart. Though, it is easier to deal with if you use the diplomacy window and read the 'relationship' status. Each listed positive and negative are added/subtracted each turn, so try and maximize how those play out, otherwise you'll find yourself bottoming out real quick.UI needs some work, it's hard if not impossible to find some of the things you used to be able to easily open and look at in previous games.Load times from saved games can be extremely long, and I've had some crashing/lock-up bugs, but nothing serious and I was always able to get my game back, minus a turn or two thanks to autosaves.Some have complained about the Religion aspect, the warfare system and what not, and I agree, the AI -loves- them WAAAY too much. My first game I had to keep Missionaries sitting outside of some of my cities just to keep the AI away from them. But, in my current game, it isn't even a factor yet and I'm hitting the Modern era already, no issues with it so it may just be specific leaders.Barbarians can be a major hassle early and then again in the Medieval era, just make sure not to leave yourself undefended and clear some of their camps quick. This is more of some advice than a complaint.It's different. I like the changes from previous games, some people don't but, basically, it's Civ, it has some changes and tweaks that make it 'new' and changes how everyone is used to playing, but overall I'm really enjoying it. I am glad I pre-ordered, just be ready for the more questionable/annoying parts I just mentioned, but if you live Civ, you'll enjoy this one too.... unless you just hate change.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Ok, so here goes my first review ever! I love Civ series, but sadly this game underperforms in many factors!AI is just terrible at the moment, strange behaviour, silly settlers walking around, war declaration without a reason by friendly civ together with bunch of other civs.Map itself is a bit childish, but that is a matter of time while i'll get used to it, but things like missing information and forced switch to the yield icons (i dont like that, map looks ugly afterwards)Also I don't understand why map settings can't be saved, always have to spend several annoying minutes to setup from the start my game! :@ I think this is the first thing which enraged me pretty much!Map itself seems smaller than it used to be in Civ V!Turn timer seems to stuck when fightning with barbarians is happening (seems like a bug)!Also dont like civic policy change, at the moment seems lacking some fun, many civics are quite useless (if there were some missions from somewhere appearing, could be they would play some role, but at the moment, 95% of them seem useless)!Overall I cant recomend game at this stage :(

So annoying...."My main gripe is the fact that you have to do all this diplomacy bull♥♥♥♥♥♥ having to suck the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥of every single nation around you, and yet they don't have to suck yours. title: Not Recommended
comment: Reasons I dislike Civ VI as compared to Civ V (which was great):- A.I. is numb...- Micromanagement is tedious and repetitive.- Landscapes are unappealing and unrealistic.- Declaring war is made to be unappealing.- Overall design- Characters are goof balls and ugly cartoons taking away from the seriousness of the game (not a big deal but still).- Civ 5 wasn't entirely accurate historically but it provided the setting to let your imagination run wild and try to loosely recreate the past, which is great if you like history like I do. But in Civ 6 you can forget about it.- You complete the research for some form of tech or social like very other turn taking away from the impact these achievements actually make in the game, in Civ 5 completing a tech was a big deal and made a huge difference towards your goal.In conclusion, stagnant gameplay, massive troll.Gonna go play Civ 5, the end.

title: Recommended
comment: I went into Civ6 not entirely sure what to expect. I've played Civ5 and enjoyed it immensely, and most of the reviews about Civ6 I had read said that it didn't hold up to its predecessor in any way, so when I bought it I did not have especially high hopes. I will also note that when I bought the game, it was half off, and I most likely would not have bought it otherwise (or at least until the price was reduced).Despite my low expectations, after playing multiple games and difficulties, I can definitively say that Civ6 is an incredible game and a worth successor in the line of Civ games. It's beautifully crafted and the gameplay is actually improved somewhat over Civ5, especially in terms of fighting and the overall victory and game mechanics. It's still a challenging game that makes you think ten steps ahead of your opponents, but the difficulty settings make it so that even novice players can have a fun, engaging experience.With regards to the characters one can play, all of the new additions are fun and challenging, and as a history nut I love the wealth of lore and backstory we receive about each leader. The gameplay is just as exciting as Civ5, and in Civ6 I find it a lot easier to figure out what you need to do and where in your victory progress you are with relation to the other characters.The only thing I will say that I genuinely dislike is the new interaction menu for city states and leaders; it's easier to navigate in Civ5 than in Civ6 and for players who are new to the game, it can be a little bit frustrating to try and make heads or tails of.I don't use a gaming laptop, but Civ6 runs well on my normal Lenovo. I've had a few issues with exiting from the main menu where the game will freeze up and I have to get creative to close it, and there are a few bugs here and there with the ingame map, but nothing too serious and nothing that's made the game difficult to play.Overall, Civ6 is a fun, immersive, and challenging addition to the family of Civ games, and I would recommend it both to veterans of the franchise and newcomers who want to try out a turn-based strategy game. However, because it is a pretty expensive purchase and there are a few bugs, I generally would advise people to wait for a sale or discount on the game.

comment: Really disappointed in Civ 6. I read the reviews before purchasing and really hoped it wouldn't be as bad as they said... unfortunately, they were correct. title: Recommended
comment: When I first read about Civilization VI my "Buyers Beware" senses immediately started tingling.2K and Firaxis had made some fairly... strange development decisions previous.- Sidmeier's Starships- Civ: Beyond EarthIt felt like the franchise was becoming the same as ANNO, where every game since 1404 is literally a copy&pastewith a different tileset and some very minor adjustments.Switch to late 2016, Civ VI releases and I buy it on day one.I had informed myself from previously available reviews and Twitch streamsand realised that it was not Civ V redux minus the addons.So what is Civ VI then?It's a Civilization game alright, but the focus this time is more towards the boardgame nature ofturn based strategy games.More cartoony graphics, rules that are less realistic but instead bring more depth on the table,and a generally fairly different approach to the franchise's advanced game mechanics.Of course you're still building cities, constructing buildings, recruiting armies and researchingnuclear weaponry (Ghandi, I'm watching you...).However the way you do all of this has become slightly different.Take research for example, now you can (And theoretically have to) fullfill certainrequirements to reduce a technologies research time by half."Kill 2 barbarians with slingers" -50% research time for archers"Destroy a barbarian camp" -50% research time for ironThis holds true for both the regular research and the new politics system.The system from Civ V was completely remade and now is generally very similiar tothe way research works.Instead of research points you need culture and the politics you "research" usually don'tgive you something directly but instead grant you access to political cards and governmentswhich you can change around in the government tab.Additionally this research tree also has all the diplomatic options in it andusually there's also a building or two to be gained from this research.Other changes are the combat system, which is in it's core the same as before withminor additions like being able to order a civilian and military unit to move together.The combat itself also seems faster paced, especially once the barbarians start climbing the tech tree.Trade is working nicely (Although it required a patch first) and the AI finally stoppednagging me about everything via diplomacy.One of the downsides though is the lack of diplomatic depth that's largely missing due tothere not being a united nations congress this time.I assume it's going to be future dlc/addon material, however the lack of one really comes acrossas missing a major game mechanic.Diplomacy in itself is interesting in the many methods you can deploy to annoy or befriend the AI.Recent patches have also improved the AI logic in this regard though it still sometimes goes haywire.Now to end it with one final difference to Civ V.Instead of constructing buildings inside your city you're now forced to build districts which then harbouradditional buildings.Sometimes that means you're following a chain of constructable buildings, sometimes that means choosingbetween available buildings.In general I love this idea.It's awesome, military districts offer a second spawn point for units and with the first few buildings also grantsa military outpost that's capable of doing a second city attack on enemy units.Religious district can serve as healing stations for units with the right perks and oh crap I haven't even touched on the religion part of the game...Religion in Civ VI is much more in-depth than ever before, literally has it's own units to construct and fight with,but suffers from being very tedious at the endgame.I could write about all the cool and not so cool stuff for days me thinks.But I want to push this review out before christmas 2035, so....Is Civ VI worth your money?60€? No, that's expensive as cake.Find it for less than 60€ on other (legal!) online stores?Grab it, it's a great game, patches have made it even better and it's only at the start of it's life time.Sure, there's some minor stuff here and there and obvious addon bait waiting to happen, butit's still one of the best gmaes 2016 has to offer.If you like turn based strategy games then there's literally no way to avoid this one.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have 2375hrs on CiV V and love that game. I have played Civ's since they first came out. Yes I'm old. But with that comes wisdom along with failing body parts. Anyway, What everyone is saying is all true. The last two Civ's seem like they are lacking something to get them over the hump. Get Civ V and save your moola.

title: Recommended
comment: After reading the reviews I decided to pick this up to see if the AI was really that bad. The answer is; no it’s not bad at all. Unlike previous Civ games they gave each civilization their own unique personality. If you don’t want them to dislike you and eventually go to war with you then you have to do things they like. My first game I had over half of the AI’s in an alliance. It’s really that simple. Here are some examples. Arabia doesn’t like it if you have more wonders then them. Scandinavia likes it if you have a big military and so on and so forth.

title: Recommended
comment: Contentious personal opinion: "Even numbered Civs are the best." But that's not much of a review, so let me try again...Some people criticize the AI. My guess is that these people are not professional programmers! It's possible to improve the AI by using techniques similar to chess programs. But for 8 civs, the game would have to simulate the equivalent of 28 chess programs simultanously, except that Civ is far more complex than chess. And with the new complexities of districts giving far more choices each turn, those simulations would take a very long time. Few Civ players would want to wait that long between turns. So, as with all incarnations of Civ, the AI is a compromise mostly based on heuristics. It'll take time to get it right.Districts. This new mechanic gives a richness to the planning of every city. Great innovation.City states: Simplified interaction means no more tedious influence tracking.Cultural victory and tourism: Confusing? No. It's really enjoyable and great for learning every part of the game.Look and feel: I thought I'd hate the graphics and the colors. I was wrong. It really works.I don't really like the new movement calculations, but I can live with them.Is Civ6 perfect? No. Is it better than Civ5 at the same point in its release cycle? Yes, and by a long way. Civ5 wasn't interesting or enjoyable until around 18 months after release. Civ6 is far more addictive straightaway.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Quite simply, you're better off with Civ 5.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Just get Civ 5 instead.In making this game it feels like they decided to merge Civ Beyond Earth and Civ Revolution and those were only okay at best

title: Recommended
comment: This game is fun and more fun the more you play, I can't say it's better than civ5 but with more dlc in the future + balance changes it will be.With the addition of districts the game becomes a lot more interesting, you have to think about what you build a lot more than in earlier civ games.The eureka and inspiration stuff is definitely the down point the first few plays, but you'll get used to it and you'll learn to love the ingenuity of it.all in all, a great game, don't be afraid of it

title: Not Recommended

The AI is ridicolus, every game feels exactly the same. I hope this game develops through patches, but for now It is a waste of money. 5 is still the premire Civ game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Ditto what all reviewers generally say. What I find most distressing is the ecosystem that the game provides. the AI characters all lie somewhere between annoying and despictable. You will hate them all and never feel any urge to ally or live and let live. They are all jerks and your only two viable strategies is to either ignore them or wage genocide upon them. Its a rather depressing game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: don't recommend this game it's hard to keep your citizens happy the unit movement is horrible as unit healing and once cities get walls it's almost impossible to take them unless you've got extremly strong military units, and now you have to waste tiles for districts, and wonders, there are also fewer civs you can play as on 6. 5 has at least 3 times more civilizations you can play as. They also cut down on the amount of luxury resources in the game and they are more widespread making it harder to keep your population happy. There are also a few overpowered civs that have an unfair advantage over other civs. If you want to play civilization I recommend 5 well before 6

title: Not Recommended
comment: Bugged, cartoony graphics and a terrible feel makes up Civ 6. Civ 5 has issues at launch, but they were actually fixable because it had a good base. This isn't true for Civ 6. The graphics makes it look like it's for 15 year olds, the feel of the game is bad, unconvincing leaders and diplomacy feels useless.Don't buy this game, instead buy Civ 5 that has a much better atmosphere, advanced AI and polish. Civ 6 can't ever compete with it unless they overhaul the graphics engine and rewrite/recast the leaders. Compare ANY leader in Civ 6 to Alexander, Theodora or Elizabeth. Nothing comes close.Simply disappointing. If you've ever played a sequel and felt like the developers forgot what made the previous one good, this is one of those times. Don't waste your money.It really does feel like it is meant for a younger generation of gamers, aged 12+.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I feel betrayed by the developer. I've seen games go down this path before and fail.Civ VI starts FAR BELOW the level of where Civ V or Civ IV left off. The gameplay has changed with the new game which is fine, but the "removal" of funktionality we had in Civ IV and Civ V are gone. Multiplayer is a joke, cant even get a game because it runs through "download regions" on steam.The AI is terrible, no matter what they always popup with the same boring messages, and get offended over things that should not even affect them. Makes no sense at all.Unfortunatly it feels like we are starting from scratch again, and it should stand on it's own, NOT BEAR THE NAME of one of the best gaming series through pc gaming history. I fear it end here. The developers was warned LONG before release, even when they started showing bits and pieces, but as true conartists they completely ignored the feedback on their own forums, and whent ahead completing the game to a SUP PAR standard.Only purchase on discount. This is similar to how EA screwed the simcity franchise with that awfull cartoon builder, fireaxis is now screwing the civilization in a similar way, cartoonish and simplification that ruins the beloved game play.Now we need a new "company + developer" to come in a swoop up all us "used-to-be" loyal civ players with an alternative title, in the same way it happened with Cities: Skylines.

title: Recommended
comment: Some of the changes are annoying (builders only get 3 charges before vanishing). Other changes I didn't like but appreciate the historical accuracy of and have accepted (roads are only built by trade caravans). The gov't structure is more annoying but not terrible. The interactions with city-states has improved a little bit due to variance in how you can draw out bonuses from them.Overall, I guess I'm just glad it doesn't feel like a Civ 5 expansion pack.7/10 gameplay (compared to other Civs)9/10 graphics10/10 music

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeI have only played this game for 8 hours, as such it should be considered an "intial impression" review.I would have played this game longer, but apparently Sunday isn't an actual part of the weekend.The thing is, it's not a bad game, it's a fairly good game, I'll even give it a7/10 (seven out of ten) Rating.So why no recomendation?Because its predecessors are too damn good; and for $60 it doesn't do much to improve upon the series, even half off at $30 you're not paying for much more than what Civ 5 already has to offer.This game feels like an additional expansion to Civ 5 Complete Edition; except that for each step this game goes forward it takes a step back.-The district system is pretty cool, they took an interesting mechnic from Endless Legend and made it better.-Culture doesn't seem to grow borders as much, you're gonna spend more cash on borders here; ironically Washington from Civ5 would do better in Civ6 than the game he competed in.-Overall I liked the diplomacy mechanics, the options in interacting with other Civs and city-states are better; unfortunately while the diplomacy mechanics are better... the Civilization AI is weird, irrational, and insane.-New tech progession mechanics are pretty cool, but can also be very frustrating.-The government/civic system is different, not better or worse, just different; didn't have enough time to get a good look.-Notifications and UI took a step forward then back, you can lock military units to civilian units, but the game does not display a notification when hostiles are close. When I lost civilian units in Civ5 it was becuase I was being an idiot and sending them into hostile territory without an escort, when I lose civilian units in Civ6 it's because of my failure to micromanage babysit even while they are in cultural borders.-The biggest frustration with this game is the barbarian mechanics. There is no raging barbarian option in the map setup anymore, barbarians are either on or off; and when they're on from the very begining of the game it's raging barbarians (no joke, my first game I had 7 barbarian units swarming my capital on turn 20). The thing is, once you kill a few barbarian camps it's like they never come back. Previous Civ games had light barbarians in the ancient era, with them becoming more frequent in the mid classical era, and as the Civs would take over the map eventually barbarians would become irrelevant. Here it's barbarian insanity on turn one with them disappearing in the classical era. It also doesn't help that cities can no longer make ranged attacks.Ending the review, I would say that if you're a huge fan of the series and money is no object buy the game; but...If you have never played a Civilization game either start with Civ5 Complete Edition (DO NOT buy Civ5 without the expansions) or Civ2 (if you can find it).If you already have every previous Civilization but are looking for something different and more combat orientated take a look at Endless Legend.If you already have every previous Civilization game and don't like the adversarial nature of Endless Legend...Play Civ5 Complete Edition some more, it is the greatest 4x ever made.

comment: Bugged, cartoony graphics and a terrible feel makes up Civ 6. Civ 5 has issues at launch, but they were actually fixable because it had a good base. This isn't true for Civ 6. The graphics makes it look like it's for 15 year olds, the feel of the game is bad, unconvincing leaders and diplomacy feels useless.Don't buy this game, instead buy Civ 5 that has a much better atmosphere, advanced AI and polish. Civ 6 can't ever compete with it unless they overhaul the graphics engine and rewrite/recast the leaders. Compare ANY leader in Civ 6 to Alexander, Theodora or Elizabeth. Nothing comes close.Simply disappointing. If you've ever played a sequel and felt like the developers forgot what made the previous one good, this is one of those times. Don't waste your money.It really does feel like it is meant for a younger generation of gamers, aged 12+.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Diplomacy is outright broken in this game. Gandhi declared war on me (first sign it's broken) and I crushed them, taking a city and giving it back in the peace deal. The fact that I conquered another city, however, turned the entire world against me and for the rest of the game, people constantly would declare wars on me and lose, because they were insanely one-sided. The AI has no way of actually telling if they are capable of beating you and simply will declare war whenever they feel like you should be taken down, not when they think they can. This makes the game far too easy, predictable, and frustrating, as simply defending yourself essentially eliminates the diplomacy aspect of the game entirely: everyone refuses to work with you.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's sorta like a "Civilization Lite" where everything is a little too easy and a little too bare. It lacks a lot of the complexity in previous games. Leaders are almost always too friendly-- even barbarians are not as aggressive as they ought to be. Pretty disappointed. :(

title: Not Recommended
comment: In its current state I unfortunately have no choice but to give this game a thumbs down. And the ironic thing is that when I first started playing this game in Spring 2017, I was actually very happy with it. I played something like 160 hours, and after some very enjoyable games was ready to attempt the hardest difficulty level. And then out of the blue came the compulsory Summer 2017 patch which introduced so many absurd bugs that I haven't played at all since. AI diplomacy is quite simply broken now. For instance, the AI civs now spam you with proposals which right from the outset they aren't willing to accept. Even worse, the AI now drastically overvalues resources, and is now willing to trade multiple cities for just a single resource. In the course of only a few turns, I managed to gain more than 50 cities from three different AI civilizations, and all it cost me was a few resources and a small amount of gold. These are the worst bugs I've personally experienced, and judging from other reviews there are plenty more besides.I just can't fathom how Firaxis ever thought it was a good idea to bring the Summer patch out in its current state and ruin an otherwise good game. The aforementioned bugs should have been uncovered after only a few turns of very basic playtesting. Which means that either the developers essentially didn't test the patch at all, or that they knew about the bugs and decided to release the patch anyway. Not only this, but it's been nearly three months and these issues still haven't been acknowledged by them, let alone fixed. Very disappointing from a software house that released other excellent games such as XCOM2, and patched them in a much more professional manner.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game works, in the sense that all its components are up and running - but its all so bland, uninspired, and just plain unoptimized.Turn times (with an i7 7700HK, SSD installiong and 16gb 2667 MHz RAM) on large-huge maps with 15+ AI players plus equal to more City-states are unbearable even before midgame. It can take over a minute between turns. Actions that change the world, such as gaining new city-territory or starting a new wonder/district also have a distinct lag that can be up to a second long.Interactions with other civilizations are now much more boring than ever before. You see the 3D animated model of the civ leader, and voice acting, to a simple 2D background of something vaguely culturally relevant to that civ (White house for USA). Gone are the unique backgrounds and perspectives of Civilization 5, which added to the characterization of those civ leaders.The AI is utterly inept. In war they are unable to comprehend defense, how to plan an assault taking advantage of geography, or even how to calculate how their forces measure up to their enemies. They just run at you dying to your fortified units on forested hills because they don't know anything except attack, attack, and attack. There is no tactical retreat, or reconsideration of their chances at victory like a switch to defensive tactics when they are clearly not winning a war.Snow-balling is an issue. Its too easy to win. Unless you give the AI obscene statistical advantages like on harder difficulties, sometimes not even then, the player's ultimate victory can be decided VERY early. Playing on King Difficulty (one level above the "normal", which is Prince) I had to consciously hold back from using the smartest tactics because I wanted my competitors to survive and challenge me to the end of the game. The equilibrium is extremely unstable and nothing stops the player from steamrolling all the enemies bit by bit. No escalation, no new challenges, if you want to win nothing is literally stopping you.Don't buy unless its a sale. Its not worth the sheer waste of time. Wait until additional DLC or expansion packs (like Brave New World for Civilization 5) fix this barely-functioning game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civ V (5) fantastic. over 4000 hours logged played exclusively in "Strategy View", which has a darker screen, easier on the eyes for long playtime, and precisely and concisely identified all resources, units, and boundaries in a quick glance, all of which is missing in Civ VI (6). I very much wanted to like (love) 6 of the Civilization legacy, but I cant. I even loved Civ IV more. Civ V (5) is the all-time best. Civ VI (6) does have intricate game play and an interesting dynamic in city development. Although, the "cartoony feel" of Civ VI is reminiscent of Civ Revolutions for mobile devices (iPhoneV, etc) which I have on my phone, and I don't appreciate it, nor recommend it, in a device. Civ VI feels and looks just like the mobile phone app, and despite this, I really need Civ VI to develop a viable Strategy View and get rid of the cartoony feel. I don't foresee myself playing this Civ VI until Civ VII, or later. I will continue to play the editions but not 6. In short, I am very disappointed in the new release, and I will not, and would not recommmed it to a friend.

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's not that I don't recommend the game... I just don't recommend the game right now. Civilization V is way more worth your buck.This Civ has an awful problem with AIs. As an experienced Civ player, I believe the AIs in this one are the worst. They get angry over the smallet things and, I kid you not, will go to war with you within 20 turns and wreck you. The smallest things upset them and you can never get them on your side for long. The only "alliance" I've ever made with a character was Teddy Roosevelt, but when someone declared war on me, he considered me a warmonger and declared war on me no more than 2 turns later. Thats just a couple of examples of diplomatic AIs.On the research side, the AIs never advance in technology it seems. I've been playing games on Immortal, and I've noticed that I can get to robotics by the 1700s, but the AI is still using catapults and crossbowmen. During the 1900s I had helicopters and tanks, but the AI still had catapults and crossbowmen. They occasionally had musketmen. For some reason the AI doesn't function well at all which is literally 90% of the fun in a Sid Meier game.The graphcs are "meh". When I watched trailers of the game, I was pretty excited. When I got the game, it felt very underwhelming and cluttered. Its like you have to train your eyes to enjoy the environment because theres so much crap everywhere! The leader scene quality is awful as I don't like the "PIxar" style animation they chose for this one. I turn off leader scene quality and replace it with the 2D cutouts, its better that way. On top of that, the leader scenes don't have anything pizazzy about them like Civ V does (example: Civ V George Washington is in his office standing near lots of books and a globe or Queen Elizabeth sitting on her throne). The Civ V graphics look insanely more reliastic, which makes me enjoy it because I'm a history buff and I like to use my imagination. The childish graphics in Civ VI arent bad, but they just dont feel fitting when Civ V was realistic. I was hoping Vi would be even more realistic.Like I said, Civ V is worth more for your buck. Get that instead if you're new to Civ. You'll enjoy it way more.

title: Not Recommended

My first game I had over half of the AI’s in an alliance. It’s really that simple. Here are some examples. Arabia doesn’t like it if you have more wonders then them. Scandinavia likes it if you have a big military and so on and so forth.

title: Not Recommended
comment: 4/10Sid meiers civ was always made ligthheartedly but the graphics (especially leader portraits) Look like they were provided by a kids cartoon, it makes star wars rebels look tarantino-produced in comparison.The city state system gives players all reward for no effort.The technology tree is not properly balanced. I can build the Ruhr valley industrial complex in 1500 AD and upgrade musketmen directly to ww2 infantry.There are no panzers.To be fair, there are some positives. Technology can be progressed through certain actions (Killing enemy unit, exploration, acquiring certain resources), Districts, Cities can be specialized and span several tiles.But overall this game has been made with the flaws of previous civ games and without many of the strengths. Unless a major expansion is made, ignore it. Civilization 5 is the best civ game made, it has better civs and the gameplay mechanics are balanced to reward and respect the players effort.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeI have only played this game for 8 hours, as such it should be considered an "intial impression" review.I would have played this game longer, but apparently Sunday isn't an actual part of the weekend.The thing is, it's not a bad game, it's a fairly good game, I'll even give it a7/10 (seven out of ten) Rating.So why no recomendation?Because its predecessors are too damn good; and for $60 it doesn't do much to improve upon the series, even half off at $30 you're not paying for much more than what Civ 5 already has to offer.This game feels like an additional expansion to Civ 5 Complete Edition; except that for each step this game goes forward it takes a step back.I will mention that Civ6 vanilla (no DLC) is better than Civ5 vanilla.While I didn't get much time to play this game, here are a few features of note:-The district system is pretty cool, they took an interesting mechnic from Endless Legend and made it better.-Culture doesn't seem to grow borders as much, you're gonna spend more cash on borders here; ironically Washington from Civ5 would do better in Civ6 than the game he competed in.-Overall I liked the diplomacy mechanics, the options in interacting with other Civs and city-states are better; unfortunately while the diplomacy mechanics are better... the Civilization AI is weird, irrational, and insane.-New tech progession mechanics are pretty cool, but can also be very frustrating.-The government/civic system is different, not better or worse, just different; didn't have enough time to get a good look.-Notifications and UI took a step forward then back, you can lock military units to civilian units, but the game does not display a notification when hostiles are close. When I lost civilian units in Civ5 it was becuase I was being an idiot and sending them into hostile territory without an escort, when I lose civilian units in Civ6 it's because of my failure to micromanage babysit even while they are in cultural borders.-The biggest frustration with this game is the barbarian mechanics. There is no raging barbarian option in the map setup anymore, barbarians are either on or off; and when they're on from the very begining of the game it's raging barbarians (no joke, my first game I had 7 barbarian units swarming my capital on turn 20). The thing is, once you kill a few barbarian camps it's like they never come back. Previous Civ games had light barbarians in the ancient era, with them becoming more frequent in the mid classical era, and as the Civs would take over the map eventually barbarians would become irrelevant. Here it's barbarian insanity on turn one with them disappearing in the classical era. It also doesn't help that cities can no longer make ranged attacks.Ending the review, I would say that if you're a huge fan of the series and money is no object buy the game; but...If you have never played a Civilization game either start with Civ5 Complete Edition (DO NOT buy Civ5 without the expansions) or Civ2 (if you can find it).If you already have every previous Civilization but are looking for something different and more combat orientated take a look at Endless Legend.If you already have every previous Civilization game and don't like the adversarial nature of Endless Legend...Play Civ5 Complete Edition some more, it is the greatest 4x ever made.
