title: Not Recommended
comment: A piece of failure.For those who like big maps: huge map is so tiny, you basically run into other players every 10-15 tiles.The AI is stupid, gets dumber every version of CIV they release. They just run their worker and settlers one after another into your army and often do not fight at all while you shoot them. In my last game, an AI player has run about 8 great adminrals undprotected right into my ships over a period of about 10 turns. I don't know what the AI wanted, but it moved them all in exact one direction right into my ships. If you think this is an exception and some rare bug: nope, it is NORAML in this game.It is okay, when something is not going well, as long as the game provides you a feedback, why something happend. This game terribly fails at this point. For example the information about the AI's mood is worthless, because your best buddies which have not a single negative point against you, join declare war on you - being on another continent. Why do you provide MOOD information, if it is either incomplete or pointless? The game is full of WTF moments.There is a new barbarian system - barbarian encampments spawn scouts. When they spot your city, they try to return to their encampment to notify and then a lot of units spawn to attack your city. In the early game this includes horseman and horseman archer, even if it is turn 5 and you have only a club warrior and maybe a slinger. So it is important to intercept those scouts. This extremely limits at how you can start a game, because it is all about pumping units to protect your borders, or else you are screwed. Even when you have covered a huge area around your cities and you have killed any scout, or there were no, sometimes you get overwhelming barbarian waves out of nowhere. The game fails to give any feedback about why that happened. A sign that something weird is going on is the symbol, when a scout spots a city: it is an exclamation mark above their head. This also randomly appears on OWN units indicating that my own unit is an barbarian and has just spoted my city... I had 3 games in a row, where a scout spotted my city at round 3 and 4. With a club warrior you get at the beginning, you are up to luck whether you can intercept the scout or not. A scout has 3 and a club warrior 2 movement mounts. A warrior requires 2-4 hits to kill a scout, depending on the tile the scout is standing. So it is plain impossible to stop him from spawning barbarian waves. They kept comming with 2 horseman and 1 horseman archer AND a scout, which again spotted the city... If you love being screwed randomly with no strategy to prevent it, you will love this game.There is a system, which allows you to boost EVERY research by 50% (half research is instantly completed) when you fulfill certain conditions. For example kill a barbarian with a slinger to get archery boost. Combined with those limitations caused by the barbarians early this additionally limits the way you play the game. Why? It is softly limiting you, because you have always the same starting routine, or else you just miss out free science and get behind in research versus AI. Potentially half the research you do, you can get for free. For every tech! Whenever I started a new game, I felt forced to either WASTE science points to play different, or play the same way.Diplomacy is barelly possible. It just consists of sometimes having luck to sell something very cheap to get at least something. Enemies you have defeated and which are weaker then you don't stop denouncing you, ignoring any threats not to convert your cities religion, spy on on you or commit sabotage. In most cases you are hated and denounced.The system how you can declare someone war without having the whole world against you is amazingly BAD. Over time you get different types of casus beli, like holy war, etc. which reduce the warmonger penalty. There are problems in this system:- Certain casus beli like reconquest of own cities are unlocked later. They should be available right ahead and cause no warmonger penalty for reconquering own cities.- Some "aggressive" actions, seem not to give any casus beli - like sabotage of buildings and being detected.- Casus beli do not add together. So if someone is decouncing you, converting your cities, spying on you, commit sabotage, You do not get a slighter warmonger penalty for all that together. You have to pick one casus beli and you have first to unlock it, most of them late in the game.- Very fast, almost any casus beli still cause severe warmonger penalty.Another of those WTF moments is, when a civilization with few cities which was underdeveloped 40 turns ago, suddenly is two eras ahead of best player. Or about 90 turns of research (when going the shortest way). AI skyrocketed for example to modern age suddenly when I did not even had gun powder - from being like half an era behind me.You can't have your units at borders inside your territory or the AI get rabies. They just walk as they desire and you can't tell them anything or declare war when they do so. If you have have close borders, you can't even place two units 1 tile off the actually border inside YOUR territory without the AI freaking out.When you want to fight against a common foe and you have your units in your friends territory and protect their cities, they freak out and tell you everything about your mother.The AI in this game urgently needs a straitjacket.Then there are bugs in which dialogs won't exit or the game does not shut down, combined with amazing smart feature that cause the window of this game to stay focused on top so you can not shut down it using task manager in an easy way.Civs like england have advantage when conquering or building cities on another continent (land is divided in different continents). The problem is, that I found no option for a generated map to have undiscovered and unpopulated continent and since war instantlly kills any diplomacy for the whole game conquering is not an option too. The game oftens give you some features you can not really play out due to other game mechanics. It its very poorly conceived. This is actually one of the most frustrating things, that gets worser with every civ version - beside the AI. You have not much time to play out something in an era, because it is over to fast and you are busy "surviving" the barbarians or trying to not loose science opurtunities. If you pick a slower game paste, you just need longer to produce everything. The time for everything is just stretched like rubber, without adding more to it. Most of possibilities which are theoretical available are hard to experience in reality due to time, game mechanic and soft limitations.Many many more issues I can't recall, but when I do, I will add them.

title: Not Recommended

title: Recommended
comment: The game has been improved a lot by the Australian Summer patch and the Spring patch, it's what the game should have been at release. The AI can defend itself a lot better, plus they are more likely to be fond of you rather than just being upset and denouncing you. Diplomacy is a good bit better than Civ V IMO. The agenda system is an improvement, if your not warring Gorgo or Alexander will dislike you so if you're playing peaceful, starting next to them is a challenge.The game is at the right difficulty now IMO. In my recent Emperor game I was going for a Culture victory but fell a bit behind on Science. When I had Field Cannons and Musketmen, Australia invaded me and took me out with their tanks and Artillery. Not only did they have the more advanced tanks, they are "Army" tanks, not just single tanks.I also tried to go for a Culture victory on Emperor with Kongo, a powerful Cultural Civ, but I was really struggling. Before I used to have good success at Immortal difficulty, but I got took out fairly early on in my 3 Immortal games so far. I feel like i'll have to get a lot better before stepping up.Civ VI base game is a lot more complete than Civ V with all it's expansions. You can found an Empire rather than just going Tradition, founding 4 cities and rushing Rationalism, which was by far the superior way to go in Civ V. I also like that Spies can steal Money from other Civ's and that you can create rebellions in other Civ's cities. The ability to steal Great Works from other Civ's is nice.So overall, having put over 2000 hours into Civ IV and 849 hours into Civ VI, I say I am definitely content with how Civ VI is and like the direction it is going. IMO when it gets all it's expansions it will be superior to Civ V, and who knows, it could even challenge Civ IV.

title: Recommended
comment: TL; DR - Civ 6 Vanilla is still better than Civ 5 Vanilla + DLCs with the exception of content amount (the # of Civs/Wonders/Scenarios). That said, the work it needs is not what Firaxis' current development path appears to be prioritizing.Civilization 6 is in a weird place right now. It's been over a year since launch and only minor improvements have occurred with the game's core features, and not in its most critical failing areas (like AI). Firaxis at the same time, is only producing content "culture" packs of new civs and scenarios without any announcement about an expansion that would add new features, techs, or alter elements of balance and pacing.This has set a lot of the community against them, and frankly, they're right to do so. The individual/paired civ DLC packs are BS because they don't address the thing we all actually want: new and/or improved *mechanics* and tuning on AI and Diplomacy.That said however, I went back to Civ 5 for a minute in order to refresh my memory and . . . frankly Civ 6 at its base is fundamentally better than Civ 5 with all of its DLC with the exception of content (# of civs mostly). All the features from the fully expanded 5 are present in 6 either fully or in a way that's either improved upon or just altered in a manner that's different enough to make a direct comparison invalid.So for the question of "is this vanilla product better than the prior installment's vanilla product?" Yes. It is. It gets a thumbs up for that reason.However, this game REALLY needs new mechanical content and re-balancing/tuning. Especially when it comes to pacing the tech/civic development.Splitting technology into a tech tree and a new "Civics" tree means you burn through both more quickly (especially the civics, of which there are far fewer) and end up over developed in both well ahead of the timeframe you would expect *even when you don't focus on it*. I have consistently maxed both trees out at around the 50-60% range of turns passed in a game on normal and epic game speeds. In the late game you can develop replacement techs faster than you can build the unit a tech unlocks. It's ridiculous (you need a mod to correct this now, but you shouldn't have to).What the game needs (desperately) is an expansion like Civ 4's Beyond the Sword, which brings in some more late-game tech, potentially brings back corporations and natural disasters, rebalances the development path, and improves AI so it's less reliant on starting buffs to be competitive. Ideally, they'd improve upon that idea and integrate more modern issues too, like terrorism from non-state actors, corruption of government, and potentially civil disturbances due to cultural/ideological clash within your own civ. These elements might clash with the comic book/cartoony/PC theme the game has embraced though, which is a shame.But sticking with the release of only small content DLC packs makes me (and I think others) worried that no such expansion is on the way any time soon. You'd expect at least an announcement by now, anyway.The ball is in Firaxis' court to address the problems with their game, but all is quiet on that front thus far. Hopefully, this will change soon.(EDIT: Aaaand a week later now, they announce Rise and Fall. Here's hoping it's good!)

comment: civ 5 is so much better

title: Recommended
comment: After playing Civilization V for more then 2500 h, I have to say that I'm bit dissapointed with Civ VI.It's still nice game, but it doesn't have that " just one more turn effect" like it had Civ V.It has some nice features, but wonders are pretty much useless, road making system stupid (merchenat build your roads...)But still I will give it positive review and I still recommend this game to new players that haven't played Civilization before (and haven't got used to better features in Civ V)

title: Not Recommended
comment: It's like the other Civilization games, except with a cluttered, messy map and UI. Some people are talking about it having 'mobile' game graphics, which is pretty unfair, but I can see the point. I just think the art style and interface design kind of works against you as you try to play. The esthetic is almost an obstacle to the actual playing of the game.All the familiar stuff we like about Civ games are here. It's a pretty faithful iteration of the things we enjoy about the franchise, but for reasons I can't quite explain, it left me wanting to play earlier versions; and then it left me wanting to play Stardew Valley's new patch. I'm not trying to be a♥♥♥♥♥♥about it - but on the face, I'm not sure there's enough innovation here. Full disclosure, I have like 500 hours logged in Civ 5, so I'm not just trolling...I'm going to keep hacking at it to see if there's some hidden charm that justifies the hefty price I paid for this, but for now I honestly can't recommend it.*EDIT*Well 15 hours in and I think I'll stick with my original assessment. This isn't a bad game, it's just not a must play at release game. If you've played the hell out of Civ 5, you're not going to find much wow factor in Civ 6. I'll try again in a few months.

title: Recommended
comment: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly (Of Civilization VI)Good+ Music+ Opening cinematic+ Main menu+ Online/Multiplayer servers are more stable than those in Civ V (based on my personal experience)+ Civilizations are unique, doesn't feel like a rip-off based on older Civilization games+ Barbarians (Can be either too passive or too aggressive)+ Casus Belli (Can be used to declare wars with less/little warmongering penalties, given that certain specifications have been met)+ Districts. Each city could specialize on a certain part, may it be a focus in science, culture, military, etc.+ Religion Victory+ Eureka/Inspirations+ ESPIONAGE IS SO DAMN GOODBad- Barbarians (again, can be too passive/aggressive)- AI (Though it's not as bad as expected. Not worse but there's a vast space dedicated for this thing we call "improvement")- No policy trees/ideologies (Replaced by Governments and Civics)- In-game user interface (oh come on, just load up Enhanced User Interface and you're good to go)- Empire wide/global happiness removed, which can lead to unwanted expansionsUgly-- Those who keep on complaining on how Civ VI is a very very very very bad game. A lot of people were complaining Civ V was trash until it was bombarded with numerous patches and two big expansions.Love it.

title: Recommended
comment: Civilizations will rise & fall, but this 4X strategy game is sure to stand the test of time.Firaxis devs have gone to great length to make this installment of the franchise not just different, but better. Civilization VI takes the fun to a whole new level of intensity with the improved AI, the enhanced art, & the combat systems.I only came to Civ V lately, as in this year. I’ve barely played a bit of the predecessors, just to get an idea of what I missed before the paragon that Civ V is graced my monitor. There are balancing issues yet with Civ VI. And the achievements need more challenge. But, for those who may be waiting for some of the reviews, I will just give you my list of 16 reasons I think the game succeeds as an heir to the Civilization throne.16. Multiple full color map filters: It’s much more than just the lovely map art, & the view of a map before the world is uncovered. They improve decision making just like all the other menus in the game. Pins are added to mark the map for exploration.You can retire a GP, convert him to a collectible or unit upgrade, keep him around for passive boosts, or even pass on him altogether; saving your points for the next GP in the lineup. If you want a GP & are losing to another civ, you can throw some hard earned gold into the GP pool to steal him before they are able to recruit him.I loved having John the Baptist found my first religion. But, also you can view a gallery of all your collected art & relics anytime, which are also obtained as relics from religious martyrs, & found in villages.Where movement is slowed down from geographical features on the map, you quickly feel more boxed in at first. But, this feels more natural because you begin to live in your own civ, not really moving out to see the world until mid-game or later. This forces you to be more aware of your neighbors than it did when you branched out all over the map.This is actually going back to Civ IV &, it definitely is a no-brainer. No reason why we shouldn’t be able to bind a soldier to our settler & send him around the world. Being able to build armies & regiments takes the warfare to a new level, in terms of power on the front line in a small hex of space.Lends a greater personal investment in “The Great White Arrows,” when you know you are sending them to their death with 3 promotion levels down the drain. There is a randomization feature that is great for getting these crazy names, if you don’t want to name them Jack or Fred.Yet, options are still present for making individual road segments with the engineers. Military engineers & builders are like specialists, compared to the workers from Civ V who did it all. The trade routes system is simpler to use, but you can NOT tell where you last sent specific routes. Of course this doesn’t seem to be a problem, since it’s easier to see at a glance & by popping out the right side tab where you already have routes currently.You can boost your bank account by investing in the Commercial Hub, or beef up production, Military, or Science at any time you need an edge in a certain direction. This gives the player more control over the outcome, & certainly allows for serious strategy.Wonders are bigger. Also, you can see the great works & trade them. Camera orientation during combat needs correction. It is necessary to edit game files to gain certain optional controls that should have been in- game, like spinning the map & stopping the infernal unit auto-advance. It does have the appearance that they weren’t quite finished with this aspect of the game at release. The art & graphic changes add greatly to the experience. For example, you can hover over districts in other civs to spy out what great works are hidden in which buildings, if you are planning to steal some art.Conquering a CS removes those resources & the protection buffer they provide from the other civs. You also have the ability to conscript their military. So, it’s more to your benefit to keep the CS intact.You have a choice about whether or not to invest in training spies. You can choose what action they take; steal art, siphon money, sabotage production by burning buildings, etc. Or, you may use them as counterspies, protecting specific buildings & their adjacencies. Roleplay is enhanced by choices for escape when detected. If you capture an enemy spy, you may trade him back to the opponent, or not.Not only are the wonders showcased on individual tiles, but they’ve made the details more visible, like mine cars zipping around the track. The art & music become a part of the world around you, with increased abilities to place & move works physically.Before, you had little options for dealing with those missionaries wondering into your civ, tearing apart the fabric of your culture. You couldn’t attack them or remove them with a unit without a war dec. The inquisition is more realistic, & dying apostles leave behind relics, which can be placed in temples, or traded as valued great works or stolen. I did find it unfortunate that I can’t rename my religion to a certain denominational name if I choose the Christianity symbol. You are able to choose a generic zodiac symbol & give it a name of choice, but that really is illogical. You should ideally be given more choices in personalization, not less than in Civ V.Alliances are totally expanded, allowing you to form relationships on different levels. It’s possible to convince the AI to change its plan to attack. The AI is more responsive to diplomacy, behaves more rationally & gives you feedback on how you are meeting their agenda. You are given more options for holding the AI accountable, as in being able to denounce them, or make them pay for spying on you. Sometimes the option appears to ask them to remove their units from your borders. But, this is not yet consistent.Over time, they fade from the game as you begin to encounter other civs. I don’t encounter pirates in international waters. A slider to increase the appearance of barbs would be great. Either way, the combat is definitely one of the best improvements in the game. More siege equipment is available. The improved landscape features allow for greater defensive power. Fighting is more visible & realistic looking.Some are pulled from the Tech tree, the ideologies, & policies of Civ V. Taken together with the Tech tree, it adds a masterful touch to the gameplay & just makes more sense. With the system of card slotting & governments whichever you choose, you can reach the victory of your choice. This expansion gives more control over boosts, & allows you the chance to steamroll your game, if you are wise enough to “lead your people well.” Comments & questions are welcome.

title: Recommended
comment: I decided to write this review after all the negative reviews and comments I read.I really do not understand why. Most of them seems to originated from old Civ5 players that compare Civ6 Vanilla with a Civ5 that has been retrofitted 2 times with 2 massive expansion packs. Well this is not fair, if you want to compare Civ 6 with something you will compare it with the plain Civ5 - thus with a game without religion, great works of art and a silly unit upgrade system with which you end up with lots of melee units that had 2 or 3 (useless for them) ranged unit promotions .But even if you decide to compare it with the complete civ5 the game have all the elements and less flaws of a fully developed Cv5. It has religion, great works of art and also have interesting new concepts that vastly improve the game. Concepts such as districts (districts with their adjutancy bonuses bring a whole new way of city planning), consumable workers (no more Idle worker at the end of the game), an improved Great people system taken from the founding fathers of colonization, (I still remember myself laughing with Picasso appearance in ancient era in Civ5), the ability to create armies and armadas (a lost civ4 concept) and more. To be honest the only new concept that I do not like is the way roads created in the game.So even if you decide to compare the Civ6 vanilla with the Civ5 including both its expansion packs, thus compare a game that has 1 year of development with a game that has 6, the verdict still goes to CIV 6.Sure there are bugs (all games have them) sure the AI is silly (It was more silly in Civ5 when it first released) but all those can be corrected in the future .So If you see things with a clear mind Civilization 6 starts from a better position and with a greater potential from all its predecessors. It is more complete and It has lots of new elements that bring a fresh approach to the series. Some people just wanted a Civ5 with new graphics. Well thank god Firaxis did not listen to them.

title: Recommended
comment: Product received for freeCiv 6 is a great installment for the long running 4x series, but even with the steps it takes forward to evolve its gameplay, it also takes a few steps back. This review is after ~50 hours of game time.Full Video:lets get the bad sorted... And this is mostly contained to two areas, that do impact the game quite a bit, these are AI and the Interface.The Ai is bad. It makes illogical choices, it uses it's resources badly and even on higher difficulties and with the cheating the Ai does, it still doesn't make sense. On top of the cheating Ai, it also tries to keep up with tech by just skipping entire trees of research. Which is very frustrating when they are somehow landing on the moon, without having done any of the research. which also makes your spies quite a bit less useful.Secondly - the UI is pretty sub-par. Information is often hidden behind several screens and tabs and even explanations on certain features (how do cities without amenities rebel game? HOW?). in their quest to show us the damn pretty graphics and animations, they have stripped important information away, and in a game where every bit of information matters, that is not cool.I hope mods will fix this problem asap even if the developers don't, as most of this information is available in the game in some form. Thankfully we do have mod-support from day one and that's a good thing.As i said, there are 2 main drawbacks, and those are it - if you can deal with those this game is damn good. The removal of global happiness for a multi- faceted system is great and gives more "local" controls, the addition of district is also a nice change and provides more choices to the player and information they have to weight in.I even like the switch with the wonders taking up a physical tile and the builders having limited actions.The one aspect i'm still divided on is the tech tree, as while i love the new civics system and government options, i don't like that the tech tree feels quite dressed down due to the splitting into two segments.Overal, i like the game quite a bit and find that the major issues are very annoying and frustrating - but for me at least, not game breaking.

title: Recommended
comment: I actually cannot write an in depth review because I'm too busy playing this game. It's not an excuse, I just have a serious problem. Bottom line it improves upon Civ V in every way possible which is EXACTLY what I want to see in a sequel, the soundtrack might be the best in any game I've played, barbarians are more threatening than they are annoying now, Christopher Tin somehow topped Baba Yetu, the new graphics actually are surprisingly refreshing and fit the game very well, and the AI is much better! Teddy Roosevelt sending me apple pies instead of nuking me is a really nice change of pace. Overall, Sid Meier, I love you. This game deserves all the support it can get! EDIT: I would like to let everyone who's complaining about warmongering Civilizations in the ancient era that it makes complete sense. Since there is no warmongering penalty at the start your best bet for early expansion is to make use of battering rams and fight! That to me is pretty bad♥♥♥♥♥ The agendas DO work. Because I kept peace and didn't clear a lot of forests, Teddy Roosevelt became my ally. Frederick Barbarossa is unfriendly with me because I help a lot of city states. Keep in mind though that the game is a lot better with all the victory types enabled because otherwise everyone is going to be out to kill you. I don't feel like I needed to explain that but most people don't seem to get it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Really disappointing game.I've played every Civ and believe this one is the worst by far.AI is simply unplayable. Everyone is hostile to me regardless of my actions. In previously games diplomacy was interesting, whereas now I simply ignore it and accept I'll be attacked randomly even if there's no way the opposition can win.Units and building stop in the modern day, I miss having futuristic units.Cities are pretty boring to build now. I'm not a fan of neighbourhoods and find they really clog up the maps.Such a shame as I was really looking forward to this game. Hopefully they'll fix the AI at the very least.

title: Not Recommended

There are so many more features, and with there being less automated features you have to focus on every single little detail which is just a little overwhelming. The diplomacy aspect is way out of balance too, all the other nations almost immediately dislike you, and randomly declare war without warning.I tried playing this game about 3 different times, thinking I just did something wrong...But each time I found myself at the same conclusion...This game is just a terribad addition to the series.Currently trying to get a refund, but I'm being denied because I played 4.8 hours of it. -_-

title: Recommended
comment: (Detailed Review: https://andrearitsu.wordpress.com/2016/10/26/sid-meiers-civilization-vi-review/)I've been playing Sid Meier's Civilization since the first game in the series and for the most part I've been rather happy with the latest entry in the series. The addition of districts is nice and the government policy system is vastly improved from the last title for sure. With that said, the game is full of small, but many, flaws that really hinders the game from being as good as it should be. From game-crashing bugs to bad UI decisions, it's all a bit too much of a mess for me to fully recommend to anyone that's not already a Civilization fan at this point. So if you're on the fence or want to get into the series, wait a few months to see how what Firaxis fixes through updates. It should get better, for now it's okay.

title: Recommended
comment: IMO it's the best Civ has ever been. Fixes basically all of Civ V's problems (and there were a lot) and adds plenty of great new features.Positives:- Ideology is no longer half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and full of euphemisms. "Order, Autocracy, and Freedom" are rightly replaced with the unambiguous "Communism, Fascism and Democracy". Also the historical government options that are available from era to era are tasteful and fun to play with.- Policies (known as Civics in this game) are no longer set in stone and can be chopped and changed as needed, making it more hands on and less open to autopiloting (a la Civ V's "if in doubt chose Tradition").- Barbarians are peskier than ever (good imo).- Feels like it has all of Civ V's expansions right from the get go i.e. has religion, spying, ideology, etc.- War weariness and casus bellis add a good layer of depth to wars, and also prevents 1984-esque eternal wars (basically what always happens endgame Civ V in my experience).- AI isn't entirely incompetent (thus far, at least)- Quick load times, and crashes WAY less frequently (for me and the people I've played with at least). Like in a Civ V multiplayer game, i'd be expecting crashes every 1-2 hours. Now I can have comfortable crashless 2-4 hour games.- Lots of little neat features, e.g. builders having charges, promotions healing units, military unit corps (almost but not quite reminiscint of Civ IV's death stacks), the ability to link soliders with workers, map pins, etc- Global happiness is gone, and has been replaced with the much more involved local housing/amenities system. Which is great, I don't have to factor in my entire empire being immediately unhappy due to taking a few cities or settling a far off colony.- District system makes building cities a lot more in-depth (gotta get dem good adjacency bonuses) and less easy to autopilot.- "Eureka moment" system gives the player a rewarding amount of agency for tech and civic progress.- Gorgeous soundtrack.- Wonderful graphics for the terrain, buildings and units. Yes it's very simplistic, but personally I find it charming. Also the "map" theme they have going is great to look at. Wonders are also a treat for the eye.- Delicious UI; has a tasteful, almost steampunk design that fits every era.- Sean Bean.Negatives:- The art style the world leaders are rendered in (i.e. a kind of horrible histories-like cartoony style) is passable at best, horrible uncanny valley at worst. Cleopatra is one of the worst offenders.

title: Recommended

Or make a 'classic' UI option. This shouldn't be something that modders have to fix.Otherwise the game is solid and well featured for a first offering, with lots of new elements to play around with!Edit: By backwards I mean the minimap is on the left and unit/city information is on the right, backwards to how it was in five!

title: Not Recommended
comment: BIG DISSAPOINTMENT. Many bugs, some fatal if you don't know some undocumented tricks which may only work on PC version. You have to scour online or Group comments to find them.I've NEVER beat and CIV version on Diety level with out cheating (World Builder: give myself 3 scouts, settlers, builders, and techs), and that's with 7K hours experiene. I beat CIV 6 on Diety as easily as I did at Prince, no cheating possible. WITH ONLY a half dozen games under my belt.Interface fights you, causes mismoves, obscures key data, constant tutorial pop ups even when turned off, AI leaders far too chatty, and as so many have said, the game plays you, making it difficult for you to play the game. The competitive stance indication is next to useless: Science for instance, gives you no information until you hit the space race, and culture is completely obtuse with a moving target you cannot well grasp or evaluate.I also find many of the Leader special abilities are too difficult to apply... typically only three to six times a game can they come into play.I suspect upgrade/fixes will address some of these, as it feels like the game was prepared by newbies with the company at project management level... and they rushed it to release without good in-house or Beta testing. Too little of the old versions in the game, too many untried new ideas. DOES NOT LIVE UP TO THIS FAN'S EXPERIENTIAL EXPECTATIONS, much less any resulting from the hype.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really tried liking civ VI, I really did, but after playing it trough few times and stopping midway way too many times I just can't.The game is full of irritating issues that just pile up along the way, this is not really a review but mostly a list about things I find extremely annoying in this game.- Ai cheating on higher difficulties makes building wonders or founding religions practically impossible, game is winnable but not enjoyable because of this. You can literally get perfect production start right next to stone resource ( for example), and Ai will still always finish stonehenge before you get it half way on last two diff's, and you will never even get close getting a prophet for religion.- Some may like the narration of "comical" statements of tec's but I find it dull and really annoying in long run, not to mention the ruler animations, temper tantrums and absolutely random reactions to things. Because of this the first thing I did was to minimise all ruler effects and nowdays I just hammer esc during diplomacy, that part of the game is unberable. Ai also has a habit of asking for trade of artifact or great work they want... every single turn, despite declining their offers.- Era duration settings are unbalanced, you can have everything in the game researched by 1820's and just have future tec /civic researched for oblivion afterwards, and to earlier Ai cheating, yes you can have every tec in game by 1820's and STILL be last in science compared to ai.- The scouting barbarians. Oh where do I get stated. Fun idea at start.. yeah just stop barbarian from returning so they don't attack your cities, easy peacy right ? .. exept they scout with fastest start unit in game.. meaning if you use same unit or aren't blessed with flanking military unit, they ALWAYS manage to return before you can kill them, and then comes flood of nuisances.-AI dislike and like factors are just annoying. Settle in different continent ( and same land mass can have mutliple continents ) and you♥♥♥♥♥♥someone up, manage to get luxyry at start someone doesn't have can♥♥♥♥♥♥ai off, don't expand like madman ? pisses someone off, don't have large armies ? pisses someone off, have large armies ? pisses someone off.- There is no really efficient way of protecting city states in the game outside letting them be destroyed then liberating them, this also gets annoying in long run if you focus on that part of game.- Most of spy actions don't matter and the system is oversimplifiedly complicated as odd as it sounds. You have to protect districts separately with spies from spies but you never get enough spies to protect against all spies or even spare spies to attack opponents spies that magically know where you spy them at.,-Religious combat is a hoax really, Ai cities pump so much religion power that flipping cities is waste of time, I liked the older civ systems better.-Era and age system sucks♥♥♥♥♥ as you can ignore it entirely as the bonuses are borderline useless. ( expansion part).If you want good civ game stick to V, I have tried in so many ways to find something in this game I enjoy, but I just end up getting a sad feeling I had wasted my money on it and then cheated myself out of time just to try to justify that waste.I don't think I buy next civ game.

title: Recommended
comment: I have enjoyed Civ since 3 and didn't play much before that. I really like the changes made for 6. It is different than 5. I like it. Some people may complain like they did when you couldn't stack armies in one tile. It's nice to have to chcange your thinking some and play differently (but there is a lot of familiar stuff). Give it a go! I paid $40 and don't regret it at all!

title: Recommended
comment: I don't have any problems with it. I play with my buddies in hot seat mode like I did for Civ V. We drink beers, eat steak, and pass the wireless mouse around. It's a good time! Maybe I just reviewed my friends instead of the game...Uhh...I like the new mechanics of city building? There.

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization 6 presents a ton of new game features and challenges compared to Civ 5. I love the districts which makes you plan forward as to what districts you're going to build in each city instead of just spamming all buildings. I also think the AI is less predictable, on my first play through, Gilgamesh suddenly marched an army to my capital and declared a surprise war. Thankfully, I was able to defend using my trusty army. He eventually gave up and offered peace plus some luxury resources.I think the AI is supposed to be this way and not broken. I did experience 3 civs suddenly declaring war on me but it's really up to you to always be ready with an army in case a rogue civ suddenly wants to conquer your cities.If you're looking for something different compared to civilization 5 and for me much more difficult, then I recommend you to buy this game and not be dissuaded by the negative reviews.Until now, I still have not figured out how to win but that's part of the learning experience!Love civ 6!

title: Recommended
comment: It's alright. Like every Sid Meier's game, i'm anticipating some pretty big necessary overhauls in the form of an expansion or two. I'd be rightfully P-Oed if they didn't. I'm not a huge fan of buying seperate DLC, so that's kind of annoying. I'd rather pay a little more for an expansion including DLC and some updated concepts. It's not a bad game, and i'm not some hardcore gamer going out of their way to expose the ins and outs of the system. So far, so good. I think, to get all of it's worth, you have to play hard to your civilizations advantages, which means doing things which might be uncomfortable in the beginning like starting war before Iron is discovered. It's to your benefit that the AI aren't particularly good at waging war. Maybe that's boring to you, but for me, it's enough to sink only a few weeks of my life into this game and take a break every now and again. It's not overly addicting, and I can come right back to it and feel a deep satisfaction. It's an old system, but one with character and fresh innovations. Just needs some tweaking. Let's see the Expansions roll out over the next year or so.

title: Recommended
comment: So for those of you who don't know, Sid Meier's Civilization VI is a turn-based strategy game in which you endeavor to manufacture a realm to stand the trial of time. Become the Ruler of the World by building up and driving a development from the Ancient Era to the Information Era. Take up arms, direct discretion, propel your way of life, and clash with history's most noteworthy Leaders as you endeavor to assemble the best progress the world has ever known.Civilization VI is the best Civilization game to date. There have been numerous changes made to Civ VI from previous titles. There have been all kinds of revisions and incorporation's that have been implemented into the game by the developer Firaxis. Despite all the changes made to the game it still feels remarkebly similar to previous Civilization titles, you still build up urban areas, extend you supremacy and grow your military might. You keep on researching logical and social updates with a specific end goal to plot a specially designed way through history, from the Ancient Era to the Information Era.The art style is to a great degree, strangely bright and cartoonish. It brings to mind the console and mobile Civilization: Revolution games, intended to be significantly more available and speedy to play than the fundamental line titles. The character models for the leaders are spectacular, with amazing liveliness as well. Another reason it's delightful: the world is displayed as a map, finished with borders. Tiles your units are on or can see are hued in, while those out of range receive a dreary pencil craftsmanship look, similar to somebody's Here Be Dragons delineations on a old map. To think to what extent we endured that exhausting old fog of war for when we could have had this.Great People and Great Works have at last been revamped, the necessities to make or utilize one are significantly more particular and hazy than before. There's detail and thoughtfulness behind it, however. For example, Great People are currently exhibited as limited list of recognizably named historical figures, from a pool that is shared by everybody, in the way of Wonders.The main genuine complaint I have about the game is that the main menu appears to originate from a totally different game. The majority of the "buttons" in-game are material and welcoming, though the level outlines on the main menu scarcely look or "feel" like buttons by any stretch of the imagination. Its not a major ordeal clearly, it's only a shame that the very first thing you see takes a portion of the pop from the game itself.

title: Not Recommended
comment: As many of the other negative reviews have pointed out and for the same reasons, I think this game suffers from fundamental defects that make it difficult to enjoy. The user interface and information menus are clumsy and unintuitive. I can't sort my cities’ yields by production, gold, culture etc. The traders have the same problem with being unable to sort routes in an ascending or descending order of a particular resource. This makes the consistent management of trade routes and cities frustrating. When every other turn I have to assign spies and traders tasks, in which many times I just want them to continue what they were doing, the game becomes monotonous, and again, frustrating.Others have pointed out the player cannot customize a civ or leader. It seems the options to alter gameplay mechanics in civ v, like showing enemy moves or animating battles are not present in this current iteration. The map is cluttered and ugly, with the option of only having huge resource icons or none at all. The Civilopedia is as unwieldy and cumbersome as many other menus and largely unhelpful.Gameplay also seems broken in several regards. Diplomacy and the actions taken by the AI are largely a mystery. There is little in the game to explain its mechanics. Others have pointed out that districts get more expensive per civic, and that many wonders are better suited to the city center than their own tile. Others have pointed out that districts can’t be razed, sold etc. I can’t imagine the justification for many of the choices designers made for this game.While there is much to enjoy, this is either an unfinished product, or a poorly designed one. The fixes that need to be made are apparent. I hope those that bought early expecting a quality finished product will not be forced to pay for the necessary patches in the form DLC and expansion. I am on the whole unhappy with this product and do not recommend it.**UPDATE: In the late game caputring cities by any means is impossible as the program crashes to desktop 100% of the time, no matter how the city is captured. This is a widely reported problem with no fixes currently. UNACCEPTABLE.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'm giving this a not recommended. Why? There is only one path through every game and thats war. You cannot avoid it. The game actively encourages constant warfare with no way to counter it. Just by playing the normal game 80% of the civs will immediately dislike you - for doing things as simple as exploring, or keeping a defensive military, or not build a naval unit (despite being landlocked). Only one valid path to the game is to keep a large military.DOW - other civs will DOW on you for seemingly no reason constantly.Swarms - swarms of barbarians, religious units and massive amounts of city state units make the game a mess. There's so many units on screen its difficult to see terrain.Permanent denouncements - once you take any city from any AI that AI will denounce you constantly for the rest of the game. Thousands of years later.Linearity - due to the Eureka system, all AI's being unfriendly from the outset, no diplomacy at all and so on, there's only one way to play it. Build a big military. Thats it. So long as you have a big army the game is cake.DLCs are way too expensive - as was the game. Luckily I bought it in a sale.Worst one in the series by a very large margin.

comment: It feels extremely similar to Civ 5 in terms of game play.Its great for someone new to Civilization series, but for someone who's played Civ 5, its pretty much the same.Cons:1) The AI is better than Civ 5, but still unreasonable.2) The more cities you have, the more easily you win (same issue with Civ 5).3) The AIs are not great even at King level (I haven't tried playing at higher difficulty yet) (same issue with Civ 5)Pros:1) Better graphics2) Includes Trade (Civ 5 had it in an expansion pack)

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have hundreds of hours in Civ 3, 4, 5 and would recommend them. Every new Civ game I get means playing into the wee hours of the morning and losing sleep. Playing 6 is a chore. I keep trying to play 6 because I spent money on it and I have to try to find some enjoyment from it. There is just nothing engaging about this game. Not fun.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have been a fan of the Civilization series since I played Civilization III awhile back and honestly I couldn't believe the immersion. The feeling of being there 4,000 years ago, growing with your Civilization and seeing the landscape, architecture and technology change right before your eyes was incredible; that is completely gone from Civilization with this newest iteration.It all started in Civilization V with small things, leader portraits not changing with the eras (I.E. Roosevelt in a suit, in 4000 B.C. or Montezuma basking in the glow of a firepit in the modern age), the fact that unit stacking was no longer a reality also hurt the strategy aspect as it created a cumbersome and difficult logistics issue when moving units around, and those things carried over into Civilization VI.However, in addition to issues with immersion in Civilization VI (such as brick and masonry buildings in cities in 200 A.D., Skyscrapers in 1360 A.D., and infantry in 1500 A.D.) The Artificial Intelligence of the other opponents is the beginning of a great idea that feels incomplete, rushed, and unpolished. Not to mention the acceleration of science in the game. I can't recommend this title, the immersion is gone and I feel Firaxis is starting to mimic Electronic Arts in that they only want the money.Edit: In short, this isn't a labor of love.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Game was not released in an acceptable state and the more you play the more obvious and aggravating that becomes. It's been four or five months since release but there have been no patches or fixes to address some of its many glaring issues. Instead their focus seems to be on drip-feeding overpriced single civ and scenario dlcs.I do enjoy this game (although not as much as any of its predecessors including the panned Beyond Earth) and the potential is there for this to be a great game but I can't recommend a game that ships broken or bare bones with the promise of being fixed and good later.Avoid, wait until the "Complete" version is released and save yourself some aggravation and money.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Product received for freeDo not get this game in its current form.The gameplay is great. There are a lot of improvements compared to Civ 5. the district system is fun and trade and diplomacy works better. Before release I was afraid of the cartoony graphics, but they really work well.In its core Civ 6 is better than Civ 5. But... The AI is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to the point of gamebreaking. In my first game Brazil was on the verge of getting the science victory, I send 4 units to its capital city. Brazil follows with retreating all its units (more and higher tier than mine) and I completely destroy him because he sends one unit at a time.So, the game could still be fun. Except for the gamebreaking bugs. I am currently in my THIRD!!!! game which I can't complete after two or three hours because there is a fatal bug in the savegame. The first broken game wouldn't load anymore. The second game crashed to desktop after I ended the turn and my current game crashes when I initiate trade with Kongo or the other way around. Guess what Kongo is constantly trying to do?This game is broken. It was released almost half a year ago and this is unnaceptable.DO NOT GET THIS GAME.

title: Recommended
comment: I have been playing Civilization since it's existance. My favorite all time is probably Test of Time. I loved that you could go on to explore the Alien Planet after finishing the Space Race. With that being said.Civ 6 brought about some pretty cool changes to it.1) Districts. This is a fantastic addition to civilization because it allows, and in a way, forces you to specalize your cities. Alot of your district placements will depend on the land around you. Some cities are great for religion, others are great for production or science. No two are usually the same.2) Goverment. Goverments now use a "card system" with each card giving you a specific benfit. Early game they play a big roll in helping you grow and manage your civilization. You can boost the production of different units in your cities, generate great person points, or increase envoy gain speed, and much more. As the game progress though, you will find yourself switching these "cards" less and less as you establish a goverment to your liking.3) AI Personalities. The problem with some of the past civilization games is that you did not know why a civ acted the way they did to you. Some civs got mad and declared war or another civ suddnely loved you and made peace with you. Civ 6 does a great job of giving the player more information on how specific civilizations react to things. When you meet a civilization in Civ 6 imediaetly open up the diplomacy screen for that civ and take a look at their Agendas. This gives you a good indication on what they like and dislike. Decide who you want to be friends with, then work towards fulfilling the Agenda. (Some prefer things such as strong miilitary, high culture/religion/science, ignoring/working with city states.)4) City State changes. The City States have been changed to give you bigger rewards for investing in them. Each one gives you a specific benefit depending on their type, and the amount of envoys you place in them. Another benefit to them is you are able to higher their armies by spending gold. (Which you come by easily in most cases).Cons:1) Warmonger Penalties are too high. I do like the warmonger penalties as in real life if one country started invading and attacking other countries, it would anger others and drive them into action. With that being said, I think the penalty tends to be way to high, as civilizations tend to denounce you for a good 80% of the game just for taking one city (even if you were not the one to declare the war) I believe they need to balance this by either lowering the penalties recieved, or by decaying it at a faster rate.2) AI Smarts. The AI don't tend to be very smart even on higher difficulties after you have come to understand tricks of the game. I think in all of my games I have ever played, I have ran into maybe one time when I actually lost a city. They usually attack one unit at a time and then declare peace after a few turns. The AI has seen some minor improvements but you have more of a challenge from early game barbarians then you do from actual civilizations.OVERALL RATING 7/10Overall I give the game a 7/10. I think it is a great game that is improved as time progresses. Things that are broken are easily fixed with various workshop items. The biggest drawback, as I mentioned before, is the AI since they have the intelligence of a 2 year old many times.

title: Recommended
comment: Now I only have a few hours of playing this game, but I have over 400 hrs on Civ 5. In my opinion, this game is brutal from the get go. I am extremely experienced in Civ 4, Civ Rev, and Civ 5 and never have I gotten beaten down so easily and quickly by the AI as I have in this game. From barbarians to warmongering nations, there was no respite in my first game. As this game is very similar to civ 5, combat and war is no new thing in this game, but never have I had such a constant onslaught of military be so heavy in Prince difficulty (I figured I would play without training wheels while learned how to play the game and learning the nuances, it was not a wise choice.). I see so many complaints about a lack of challenge from other people, but frankly, I don't see it. I see this game being challenging for years to come.Also, about the DLC, I personally don't think people should be biting about add ons as if they're supposed to be expansions. Civ 5 Gods and Kings and Brave New World released a year and three years after Civ 5 was released. It's reasonable that firaxis wants to keep adding stuff to keep the game fresh as they work on the expansions, albeit the price is a bit steep (but I managed to snag a 25th anniversary edition in mid April, so I get all DLC and expansions for free, so I don't really care about the add ons.)

title: Recommended
comment: Have about 8 hours so far on this game and let me say it is a huge improvement over Civ V and I thought Civ V was fantastic to begin with. There are so many small changes that affect the outcome in the game, it is remarkable!. I do have one concern though and that is the AI, every other civ in the game I played was hostile towards me and each other but seemed to have an endless amount of gold and were able to sustain a healthy empire amidst the entirety of battle, while I was struggling to keep up. However, that was my first game and I could very likely have completely missed a new feature introduced in Civ VI. I guess I should stop treating it like Civ V! Anyways it is still a fantastic game and if you are a fan of the Civ franchise you will feel right at home with this entry!

title: Recommended
comment: I'm a long time Civ vet, having played the original Civ on the Amiga 500. Played almost all of them, however this itteration doesn't seem to grab and hold my attention as some of the earlier ones.This could be attributed to me just playing different games nowadays, as it isn't a bad game by any stretch of the imagination. You can feel the potential in the game, and the modders have been hard at work as well.The artwork is awesome (at least imho) as it just works for the game. The AI could and should be worked on still as it is lacking here and there, but that's a treat many games suffer from.The cities develop into really nice looking pieces of art.Can I recommend this game? I would say yes, it will age just fine, and keep you occupied for many an hour (if you aren't occupied with a gazillion others :) )For a rainy/snowy day.

comment: - Nuked Gandhi- Was told by him that nuclear weapons are the future right after.Get it. Great continuation of the series, almost every aspect of civ 5 was used and highly improved upon. Ai is kinda weird atm but nothing a fix or two can't fix. New features pretty much make the game, districts are fun arnd overall long-term strategy becomes more important than simply spamming cities.If you're on the edge or asking if it's as good as 5, i'd say it's better in it's launch version than civ 5 was with all addons released. Too tired to write a long review now. Released: Oct. 21st - Playtime on Oct. 22nd = 20 Hours. Should speak for itself ;)

title: Recommended
comment: I'm pretty astonished at the kind of stuff people leave in Steam reviews.The AI is no better or worse than Civ V. It's definitely not great, but it never has been. On the whole this iteration seems like Civ V vanilla plus some improvements, I'm honestly not sure what the complaints are about...The new city building mechanic is great, the districts are a nice addition as are the changes to happiness.It really seems like the only thing people can find to complain about is the AI or the graphics (if you watched literally any trailer on the game before you bought it, why would the graphics surprise you?)People with 100+ hours giving the game a "do not recommend" ? You serious?

title: Not Recommended
comment: Bought this game a few months after the initial release during a sale, assuming that like its predecessor Civ 5, it would be a good game to play with my partner. It turned out that there was not cross compatibilty between Mac and PC LAN games, so we both immediately refunded the game.I was excited to check again today now that it's been well over a year since release date, and since there's still no cross-platform in sight, I'm dropping a negative review. This is ridiculous.For the record, I'm sure the game is wonderful, and I'm very excited to try out both multiplayer and single player whenever this issue is resolved, but in the meantime I can't give a positive review.

title: Recommended
comment: Absolutely brilliant continuation to the franchise! Executed very well unlike most triple A titles today. I would recommend it at this current time and, without a doubt, later on too. My hours say it all for this game. I've already found myself checking the time at the start and it being 4:00 pm and then checking a couple of hours later and then what do I know, my alarm's going off at 10:00 am. I cannot deny the fact that this game still continues its "Just One More Turn" idea.People are often comparing this game to Civilization V a lot which is bad. This game, from what I can tell, is the best bits from each Civilization compiled into one, as well as a few improvements that haven't been attempted before, to make the best Civilization game yet. I believe this has been done fantastically!One reason my friends didn't enjoy Civilization V that much is because they found that at one point, they would be doing nothing at all (to the point where their city has nothing to produce but units). They'd mention that there weren't many units to choose from and that it would get boring quickly. This time I would say that this is no longer a problem. I found myself struggling to decide between whether I should build up an army and build up my empire or attempt to continue at my current size and military in an attempt to take the lead with a certain victory like Science, Culture or Religion. If I chose to build up my empire, I'd struggle between whether I should build a settler or builder, or if I should build a slinger or warrior. If I chose to head for a victory early, I'd have to decide between districts or improvements on my City Centre. All of this to consider as well as many new features such as boosting your techs or civics, what government suits you best and what policies will match your goals. Throughout the entire game I felt like I was always busy and this continued my addiction to clicking the "Next Turn" button.The graphics feel a lot similar to Civilization Revolution, which I did like as well as Civilization V's graphics as well, and really makes it feel like you're playing some form of board game. Unlike in Civilization V where it felt like you were spinning a globe around, this gives it the feel that you're reading a map and pin pointing unit orders and other such things alike. Either way, this does not break the immersity. You will still feel like you're ruling a Civilization as always. The graphics did not change the way I play except from the fact that I found myself panning in and out a lot more to see from different perspectives. I love their new hotkeys to rotate the camera too (ALT + LMB)!The soundtrack sounds a lot like Civilization V's and I think they have even kept some sound from that and put it into this game. That doesn't matter much though, as they've clearly done a fantastic job on their theme song. I love how the soundtrack adapted upon you entering new eras just like in various other Civilization games throughout the franchise.Now the AI should be spoken about separately, paired with the diplomacy system. Some people are going over the top when talking about the diplomacy system dragging the game down. It's not as bad as it has been portrayed. Yes, the AI are aggressive but they can also be reasoned with. All of them. I think a lot of people miss the whole idea around Agendas. I agree with the fact that, yes they're annoying considering you can't be friendly with everyone but that's not how it works in reality. Ghandi (talking about the real Ghandi, not the one that nukes everyone) was all for the peace but he couldn't befriend everyone as it just so shows looking back on how he died. Therefore, I feel like the Agenda system is somewhat a good idea. What I see as an issue with the AI at this moment in time is they will attempt to attack you for no reason (Surprise Attack). Do they gain a warmonger penalty? Yes. Do they care? Not the slightest bit. One bug I noticed was when I was allied with Cleopatra (she was my only ally at the time) it came up with something along the lines of "An allied friend has told us Cleopatra is launching a Surprise Attack on the Arabian capital." I was Arabia by the way. I was so confused. She couldn't, and never did, attack me since she was my ally. But this still tells me that no matter what your relationship with a Leader is, when they get the chance they will try their best to declare war on you.All in all, I see no other issues with this game. I love almost every piece of it and can't wait to see what DLC has to offer. I expect to be failing all my exams, losing all my friends and being disowned by my own family in the upcoming month or so. But that'll be after the next turn anyway...I rate this game:9/10.I expect that this will reach Overwhelmingly Positive reviews at some point.EDIT: I nominated Civilization VI for the "Just 5 more minutes" Award since my turns take about 5 minutes to complete each anyway. If I could nominate it for a second, it'd be the "Test of Time Award" but sadly we can't do two.PS: To those on my friends list asking if it's worth the money, yes. I would certainly say it is. However, I'd recommend buying the Deluxe Edition, so if you don't mind waiting until the price drops on that, perhaps your wait would be more worthwhile.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The released it too early, the AI isn't even in beta. The cartoonish look doesn't suit me but that's personal. The made the game overall much longer to play, even on the quick setting it feels like a marathon. Sad to say but it'll be the last CIV game I'll purchase.

All of this to consider as well as many new features such as boosting your techs or civics, what government suits you best and what policies will match your goals. Throughout the entire game I felt like I was always busy and this continued my addiction to clicking the "Next Turn" button.The graphics feel a lot similar to Civilization Revolution, which I did like as well as Civilization V's graphics as well, and really makes it feel like you're playing some form of board game. Unlike in Civilization V where it felt like you were spinning a globe around, this gives it the feel that you're reading a map and pin pointing unit orders and other such things alike. Either way, this does not break the immersity. You will still feel like you're ruling a Civilization as always. The graphics did not change the way I play except from the fact that I found myself panning in and out a lot more to see from different perspectives. I love their new hotkeys to rotate the camera too (ALT + LMB)!The soundtrack sounds a lot like Civilization V's and I think they have even kept some sound from that and put it into this game. That doesn't matter much though, as they've clearly done a fantastic job on their theme song. I love how the soundtrack adapted upon you entering new eras just like in various other Civilization games throughout the franchise.Now the AI should be spoken about separately, paired with the diplomacy system. Some people are going over the top when talking about the diplomacy system dragging the game down. It's not as bad as it has been portrayed. Yes, the AI are aggressive but they can also be reasoned with. All of them. I think a lot of people miss the whole idea around Agendas. I agree with the fact that, yes they're annoying considering you can't be friendly with everyone but that's not how it works in reality. Ghandi (talking about the real Ghandi, not the one that nukes everyone) was all for the peace but he couldn't befriend everyone as it just so shows looking back on how he died. Therefore, I feel like the Agenda system is somewhat a good idea. What I see as an issue with the AI at this moment in time is they will attempt to attack you for no reason (Surprise Attack). Do they gain a warmonger penalty? Yes. Do they care? Not the slightest bit. One bug I noticed was when I was allied with Cleopatra (she was my only ally at the time) it came up with something along the lines of "An allied friend has told us Cleopatra is launching a Surprise Attack on the Arabian capital." I was Arabia by the way. I was so confused. She couldn't, and never did, attack me since she was my ally. But this still tells me that no matter what your relationship with a Leader is, when they get the chance they will try their best to declare war on you.All in all, I see no other issues with this game. I love almost every piece of it and can't wait to see what DLC has to offer. I expect to be failing all my exams, losing all my friends and being disowned by my own family in the upcoming month or so. But that'll be after the next turn anyway...I rate this game:9/10.I expect that this will reach Overwhelmingly Positive reviews at some point.EDIT: I nominated Civilization VI for the "Just 5 more minutes" Award since my turns take about 5 minutes to complete each anyway. If I could nominate it for a second, it'd be the "Test of Time Award" but sadly we can't do two.PS: To those on my friends list asking if it's worth the money, yes. I would certainly say it is. However, I'd recommend buying the Deluxe Edition, so if you don't mind waiting until the price drops on that, perhaps your wait would be more worthwhile.

title: Recommended
comment: Definitely much better than Civ V at launch in terms of completeness and you definitely don't feel as jipped.As every professional and user review has probably said, the new district mechanic is great in terms of decision making. Also looks great too as you see certain cities specialize in certain tasks. This combined with the movement nerf and harder barbarians really make this into a completely new game for the better. The presentation and polish is even better than Civ V from what it feels as well.Some city-states are likely to become full fledged civs judging from from what I've seen so that feels a bit weird.I can see where they need to expand in terms of depth to reach the complete Civ V experience and am looking forward to it. It feels currently like a less complete Civ V with all expansions but definitely feels like a coherent gameplay experience.Definitely the best Civilization Sid Meier's made and looking forward to the expansions and more civs!

title: Not Recommended
comment: Well, I don't like this game right now. I put a whole weekend into it and tried the default settings at first. I don't like when 3 other civs can up and declare war on you, AND have more resources than they should have to do so. It doesn't look like it is possible to reach any of the advanced end game content because you get taken out sometime around the Renaissance Era while trying to stream builders and their mighty 3 charges of capability. So I tried the marathon, no turn limit, on the easiest mode with the hopes the game would slow down to allow for more fine tuned decision making and was disappointed again. 40 turns to make a builder from the word go that, of course, only has 3 actions it can do. So after 40 turns, you can get lucky to +3 your production before having to re queue another builder. 37 turns later, and so on and so forth. By the time you reach AD years, you might have a few other cities that take 116 turns to make a builder or trader in them. Right now, the game is simply unplayable to me. I think the one trait that is killing this game for me is the disposable builders. For this reason alone I cannot recommend this game to anyone else at this time.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have played every mainline civ game since the start, and i am not impressed. This game has no soul, it feels like a visually sumptuous city builder.Pros:-It looks pretty-soundtrack seems beautifulCons:-Sean Fkn Bean (seriously, if like me you are allergic to him, do NOT go near this game)-It all feels a bit clunky, if you hover over your various different currencies at the top, you will get a basic break down, but then theres no further information, clicking on it does nowt. The same thing for the new stats in your city panel, some have hover over tooltips, others simply do not.-Happiness has been replaced by utilities, but there seems again to be no way of tracking this, it doesnt even get a place on the currencies bar at the top.-No overviews (Military, Diplomatic, Trade etc. all gone)- there seems to be no way of seeing what all your potential trade routes are, it only recognises a potential trade route if you have a free trade unit in a city, and then only from that city.- no diplomacy overview, you have to go into the video diplomacy screen everytime you want to check something, and theres a lot of info i'm used to having thats just not there-NO CITY SCREEN, you now get a panel that kind of treats a city like a unit (and no way of apparently leaving the city panel without deliberatly clicking on a unit and then on the ground?)-No City build queue-'C' no longer centres on unit, and cannot bind a key to do this-Religion, they seem to have kept the bare bones (most of the beliefs from civ5 seem to be there, tithe, pagodas etc); but there seems to be no way of identifying religious pressure, are you doing well or not? is a city of yours likely to convert? dunno.-No alert setting for units, you can fortify a unit but it will not wake up if there is an enemy unit in sight-No score panel (not vital, but always gave me a sense of how i was doing)I might add more to this later, Steam have refused to refund me because i played over 2 hours, so i'm stuck with it.My advice would be do not waste 50 quid on this, wait for the first xpac when hopefully (a la Civ5) they will resolve many of these QoL issues. It has many flaws that will become clearer as more people put the hours in, i can only hope Firaxis will respond.Thank you for your time.Edit: Oh and by the way, as others have pointed out, the AI is a reckless drunk.
