title: Recommended
comment: TLDR:I have 42 hours played in the 3 days after the release of the game. I have played every Civilization game and this is my favorite one. I recommend it if you are a fan of the series or looking to try the series out. It's especially good for new players since it has a tutorial based on your experience with the Civilization franchise.My Impression:Civilization is such a complex and in depth game and to feel so intuitive to play is impressive. After all that it stays a game to that remains fun, exciting, and unpredictable after hundreds of hours of play? That’s joyous.Positive:+ The music of this game, especially the start screen is beautiful and powerful+ Voice acting is on point and is throughout the game in every aspect+ AI is realistic in the personality of the leaders. Certain leaders will spread the religions they are known for. This wasn't the case in the previous ones. The leaders act how they would if they were still alive, so very realistic.+ Amazing strategy game that defines the 4x genre+ Steam Achievements+ Steam Trading cards- Initial Civilizations introduced with the release, I was hoping for more leaders and some specific ones that were not included- Some people find the graphics cartoony, I like the graphics.- I don't like the way they do the DLC of releasing new leaders- This review was written 3 days after release and the game can still use a few balance patches to get to perfectionP.S. Civilization 4 was my favorite until I tried Civilization 6. I can only imagine it gets better with mods and DLC.

title: Not Recommended
comment: TL;DR it's not a bad game, but Civ V is superior. DLC might fix it, but it's not worth playing until then.Why don't we have a "Neutral" recommendation button? We need it for Civ VI, because while this is an acceptable entry into the series, I can't ever see any reason to play it over Civ V.There are a bunch of great new features (Districts make you feel more like you're playing Endless Legend, though that game still does tile based city building better imo), but they're all held back by some really awful design choices, a few bugs, and horrible AI.Pros:The foundation is clearly here. With 2 or 3 big expansions (DLC's bleh), it could easily be a great game.The inspiration system, makes the science and new civic tech trees feel fresh and exciting without feeling overly powerful.Natural wonders feel far better than they did in Civ V (They now tend to give bonuses to tiles around them, making controlling them far more beneficial).Global happiness is no longer a horrible limiter in the mid game.City-States no longer require massive sinks of gold to get small perks, rather you complete quests and are granted envoys who give you bonuses.Cons:Art style is awful compared to Civ V, personal preference obviously, but Civ V was a beautiful game. This feels too cartoony and isn't whimsical enough to warrant it.AI is atrocious. We're talking absolutely worse than Civ V. They'll make wars with you they can't win for no reason, will build cities in horrible spots, build districts poorly, and even get destroyed by barbarians near the start of the game. As someone who played on immortal difficulty in Civ V and really wanted better AI this is quite possibly the most disappointing thing about the whole game.Movement and combat of units is tedious due to how the system of movement has been changed. You will not catch a scout unless they corner themselves. The actual combat hasn't changed, but the changes to movement and how impactful rough terrain can be makes it all so much slower and less engaging.The UI is bad. Menus don't pop up when you click the city, but rather you need to click other buttons while the city is selected to see actual details. There's no game log of any kind so if you miss the fast messages telling you what just happened you'll never see it again. The UI also seems to be hard to directly interact with. The amount of times I try to view a notification only to select the ground beneath said notification is too high.Lastly bugs. There are tons of them. Bugs with the steam overlay, with not being able to name cities, issues with loading saves, and even a strange issue where I kept getting notified stonehenge was built, 300 turns after it'd been built.

title: Recommended
comment: I love this game, even if others don't. Just to be able to lose myself in 16 hour games is a recommend from me, not many games can keep me from getting bored and switching it off for me anymore.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is pretty much civilization 5, but less fun.The largest problem with this game, and with a lot of the civ games, is they build these complex mechanics into their game, but there's little reason to invest in them.There's little reason, because the way to win the game on higher difficulties is to spam units and take advantage of the horrendous combat AI. Yes, the AI is bad. Yes, it's worse than in civ 5. Other civs will ignore your unprotected workers/settlers. They won't pillage. They won't attack a city unless they have it surrounded. Sometimes they'll ignore your units even if they have them surrounded. I've held off wars with just two slingers against entire armies. The barbarians are a far greater annoyance in this game than any civ.In summary, here's a list of things that are worse in civ 6 compared to civ 5:Minimap (impossible to read it)UI (complicated and uninformative)AI (they can't even use the new mechanics)Policies (You'll end up using the same 3-4 cards every game)Game speed (Production takes too long)Happiness/Amenities (You can't even tell which resources are providing you amenities)Resources (They are everywhere, but also pretty unexciting)

title: Recommended
comment: A lot of people compare Civ VI to Civ V the complete edition, which by lengths is unfair. Civ VI is by far better than the base game of Civ V without the expansions. In due, time we’ll all watch this game flourish even more with the introduction of expansions. Civ VI has breath taking graphics in comparison to any other game of this category in my opinion. I’m comparing this to most 4X games such as Endless Legend, Sorcerer King and previous Civ games.I must also compliment the new combat focus, it’s by far one of the most engaging I’ve come across in a long time. The AI feels more balanced and gives a deeper depth to the game, multiplayer is a lot of fun with good friends for playful banter or a more serious approach. Barbarians are as annoying as ever xD and more aggressive than what I remember in my 175 hours of Civ V. As a fan for 4x games, I’m impressed by this game as a whole; there are a lot of positive points in Civ VI. Please don’t let others alter your thinking about a fantastic game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This is the worst CIV EVER!Not only that somebody decided to use comic graphics that look like as if they were made for brain damaged eleven year olds no - the game will either defeat you within the first 50 rounds or kill you slowly with boredom!There are three ways to play:Difficulty "Prince" or lower - you´ll either colonize Mars in the mid of 15th century while you´re fighting off bowmen with your modern tanks and bombers or you´ll directly go for domination (as everyone calls you "warmonger" until the end of time for a war started 500 B.C.) and conquer the whole world by 1200 A.D. latest.Difficulty "King" or above - either in turn 30 your (so far) best friend and neighbour will come with like 50 units which he obvoiusly produced in his only city and ovverrun you or - if you manage to survive, due to lack of neighbours or super agressive playing - you´ll end up loosing the game by turn 452 because some other pkayer managed to settle to mars or win by culture.In the meanwhile you´ll be the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of the world anyway - because every neighbour (or even Civs from the other side of the globe) will tend to attack you every now and then just out of "reason". So after the third our fourth war you may loose your nerves by again and again and again defeating their armies and negotiate peace (which will be broken anyway later) and start to destroy their cities - WARMONGER!Anyway - you´ve spend trillions of resources on military instead of culture, sience or religion (which was your imitial idea of wining the "peaceful" way) then you´ll start to conquer the world, again... :/Sounds fun! BUT it isn´t! The KI is so brutally stupid (irrespectable the difficulty) that even completely tecced CIVs will use Bowmen and Horses (maybe Knights) against Tanks, Bombers and Artilery or just don´t defend itself properly. Obviously the only move KI knows is to rush for your Cities while if attacked there is almost no defense! In the late game once you killed all ground forces a paintaking slow and boring routine of bombing, conquering and bombing again will be "the art of war".The only thing where the KI is brilliant at is to know how you´re intenting to win even it is not "aware" of you at all - once you start to build a religious district at least two or three CIVs will found their religion prior to you, so you may have the "leftovers". If you go for domination all CIVs will be super agressive in the early game until you´re to hard to conquer or attack them yourself.There are a lot of good concepts in this game - however none of them seems to be thought till the end, frustrating!

title: Recommended
comment: As a big fan of Civilization 5, I was recultant to buy part six for a long time because the negative reviews scared me off. Now I decided to give it a chance anyway (at a discount) and was pleasantly surprised. The game feels different enough to be a fresh experience. I don't get the hate because the new features actually feel well-thought-out.- Content:I'm glad to see this isn't Sims 4. The content from Civ 5 is there. They didn't, for example, remove religion to make it a DLC. Diplomacy is a little lacking, though, and there's no scenarios in the base game.- Changes I like:World wonders are now harder to build and need their own tiles (which makes sense). The city district system adds diversion because now you actually have to decide what buildings you need more. The days of spamming everything are gone. You can speed up research by doing certain tasks that have to do with the research topic. City states now require envoys instead of money. It takes much longer to befriend them now. Workers and research were also changed.- Graphics:Yes, the graphics are cartoony, and the landscape looks kinda ugly. But you get used to it... and the buildings, especially the world wonders, are detailled and nice. The video sequences look good, too.- KI:I can't say much about that because I actually never play on a higher difficulty than Prince. I get denunciated a LOT, though, for almost everything. And sometimes leaders refuse my friendship request just to propose it themselves in the very next round.- Negative thoughts:The music isn't diverse enough. Bigger maps are laggy. The advisor screen was removed. I was disappointed to see there's only one leader for each country again. And even when you start on a huge map, you'll often have another civilization right at your doorstep.

title: Recommended
comment: TLDR: Great game, 9/10, but some aspects are either left to be desired or previous Civilization games do better.First of all, what is this game for those of you who have not played the Civilization games before? It's a grand strategy game where you choose a nation/leader to begin playing in 4000 B.C. You expand, research, and progress forward through time, meeting other nations, forming alliances, fighting wars, and basically running your nation in whatever way you see fit. It's a fantastic game series for those looking for a grand strategy game.Mind you, there are many previous Civilization games that this builds off from. Honestly, from what I've experienced so far, there are a lot of great things that Civilization 6 has improved on! However, there are somethings that could be better/previous Civilization games did better.PROS:- Religion. In this game, religion seems much more organic and fluid, it's customizable to a great extent. And you can win a Religion victory by spreading your religion to all of the other nations. It was fun converting the whole world to The Kaleebian Faith.- Districts. Now some people may hate this, but I love them. You actually have to be careful where you put your cities and how close they are to your other cities. No longer can you just plop them anywhere and still get a decent production out of them. Having districts dedicated to specific tasks like industry or science is awesome to have. I can have one city in the tundra that may not have a whole lot of bonuses but because its on the shore and has like 2 fish and a crab resource nearby I can put a harbor district and capitalize on those resources. Meanwhile, a different city can be devoted to Science and Industry deeper within the continent. It gives each city a greater individual identity, rather than just being cities within my nation.- Casus Belli. This is a specific cause for war and oh my lord does this help with the AI problem. Mind you, the AI can still be troublesome (and I will touch on that in the CONS section), but it does help. If I want to go to war with a proper Casus Belli, it can greatly reduce my warmongering status among the other nations. For example, if I am Norway and declare war on Russia normally, I'll get a great warmongering status. However, if I am allied with America and Russia has conquered the American cities of New York and Baltimore, on behalf of the American Nation I can declare a Casus Belli of a Liberation War to give the cities of New York and Baltimore back to America. It gives me a way less warmongering penalty, and I can still conquer 1 or 2 Russian cities for myself and give back New York and Baltimore to America.- Civics. There are a ton more options to chose from, giving each game a different perspective on your government. You want to engage in a Holy War against Ghandi? Gear up your civics with a lot of faith benefits and the government Therocracy. Somebody giving you some problems early game but your like 2 continents away? Monarchy and boost your naval output with benefits to make your navy faster, better, and stronger. It's a nice touch to running your nation.- Personalities of different Leaders. This time around, leaders have individual goals that make them better friends with you if you lead the same way they do. However, this is both a PRO and CON. I'll explain the CON part in a second. Benefits though, if you tend to focus more on culture and science, you and Russia become the best of buds. More focused on industry and production? Japan loves you. Focused on the Economy? China is way more friendly. So depending on how you play the game, it can determine who is friend and who is disappointed in you.- Armies. Civilization 5 turned away from the endless "stacks of death" in Civilization 4, which I applaud. But Civilization 6 did it better. You can combine like units together to form an army, but can't endlessly stack them. So it's like a perfect balance between stacking units together and keeping them apart. You can't waltz in with 15 musketmen stacked in one tile and decimate a city, but you can still combine 3 to form an army and boost their damage a bit more.CONS- Resources are not limited. This is a personal grievance of mine. Civilization 5, I believe, did it right in limiting your resources. You had 6 Iron? You can only make 6 swordsmen. It eliminates the spamming of one unit and makes you utilize what you have, giving your military different kinds of troops and benefits. Civilization 6 does away with that unfortunately. With 1 niter resource, I can just keep spamming musketmen until I decide to do something else. I liked the idea to strategically create my military using what I had available. I had to choose how to use my resources very carefully.- City States. They are still here, which is awesome. But I felt that Civilization 5 had a better City State system than Civilization 6 does. In Civilization 5, you had to keep the city state's approval of you high with gifts, completing quests, and other tasks. In Civilization 6, you gain Envoys that you send to city states to better your relationship. The problem with this is that once a nation sends 6 envoys to a city state, it's pretty much their city state for the whole game. I liked the idea of Civilization 5's city state mechanic in that I can bribe and change the alliance of city states if they are allied with my enemy.- No Golden Age. I mean, the next expansion to Civilization 6 will include both a Golden Age and a Dark Age, but why were these missing from the vanilla game? I felt that a Golden Age was an important feature that allowed your nation to benefit from a great achievement for 10 turns, and could speed development up dramatically.- AI. Yes, unfortunately this is still a problem. You do one thing for your benefit, and everyone starts to denounce you. Everyone hates you. And heaven forbid if you declare a normal war on someone, you are a warmonger for all time. That's the other thing though, the AI never forgets! You declare war on China back in 1080 B.C., and everyone still calls you a warmonger in 1862 A.D. Diplomacy is shot if you go to war without a Casus Belli, and it honestly feels like the rest of the game ends up being you vs. everyone else.- Personalities of Different Leaders. Although there were some pros here, there are some cons. If you build a caravel and start exploring, England hates you because they want to always do that. If you found a religion, the Arabs and Spain will always hate you for starting a heretic religion and will be incredibly upset if your religion starts to spread to their cities. It makes the game feel a little repetitive if I keep♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the same people for the same reason. Civilization 4 and 5 had a better system with giving each leader a specific benefit and goal, and no one would get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at you if you started to do the same thing.- Style of Gameplay. I will not lie, I love this game. But compared to Civilization 5, it feels a little watered down. Not by much though. I mean, Civilization 5 has two big DLCs to bolster its experience, so I account for that.BOTTOM LINE:- This game is still a ton of fun! Mind you, when Civilization 5 came out, it didn't even have religion in the vanilla game, that came out with the Expansion Gods and Kings. So at this stage, it's hard to compare Civilization 6 with the previous iterations. If I had to pick one as the best Civilization game, I'd go with Civilization 5 with the 2 DLCs. But Civilization 6 will benefit greatly when the new DLC comes out in February. So if you're interested in this game and don't have any of the previous games, then BUY THIS GAME! But if you already own Civilization 5, wait until the DLC for Civilization 6 comes out or Civilization 6 is at a reduced price during a sale.

title: Recommended
comment: I was hesitant to buy this game as I heard a lot of negative feedback around the time of the game's launch. It has been over a year now and I can safely say that it is a fun experience. The main attraction to this game over previous iterations areDisctricts, and modding support in multiplayer, both of which allow for more interesting gameplay.I like most of the changes implemented in Civ VI including the ability to levy City State's military, requiring Wonders to take up a tile so you can't just spam them, and builders being limited to 3 uses and not able to be automated.Some things, however, are not done so well. Such as the AI and diplomacy. In one of my current games I get denounced like every 10 rounds by the congo for not spreading my religion to them. This is obviously annoying and pretty much forces me to send over a few missionaries.I have also found that the AI can just declare war fairly randomly at times, however this may just be due to my inexperience in the game.Overall I think Civ VI has improved since Civ V. I am sure this review missed some things, however I listed the features most important to me. I would suggest Civ VI, however I would probably advise to wait until its on sale for like $30 or lower.

title: Recommended
comment: Fearing that his Chinese neighbor will one day launch a rode from space on the Russian capital of St.Petersburg, Peter the great of Russia authorized his generals to wage a full on nuclear war against China. The first launch was a tactical nuke that targeted a recently captured German settlement where the Chinese had their mechanized infantry, artillary and tanks amassed near the Russian border. The next several launches however utilized Thermonuclear bombs that unleased destruction on Chinese cities and armies. The Russian army managed to penetrate 800 miles into Chinese territory before being stopped by irradiated fields that seperated it from the dying Chinese army. The launches continued over the next 5 years and primarly targeted three cities with space ports and their surrounding areas. After the space port cities where destroyed the launches where focused towords industrial towns towords Siberia and agricultural farms in the east. Peter the great wanted to make sure that these cities and their space ports could never rise again, that CHINA would never rise again.By the time of a ceasfire was signed, China has lost more than 90% of it's population and production. Radiation has reduced the acres of farmlands to rubble and the ones promising and thriving space centers have been reduced to molten piles of steel. Only the Chinese colonies in the Americas never experienced conflict. But as part of the ceasefire, the Chinese had to relinquish their American colonies aswell as a few towns close to the Russian border one of which luckly has a space port.The Russians quickly got underway to to decontaminate and rebuild the infrastrucure of their newly aquired prize. The Chinese however where not so lucky. With the loss of arable land and a complete destruction of its infrastructure, the Chinese economy tanked to the bottom. The government soon found itself unable to pay the wages of it's soldiers once memmbers of the largest amy in the world. The soldiers in turn sold their weapons on the black market or joined warlords who now roam free.The warlords pillaged Chinese villages as they pleased with no resistance from the Chinese government. Infact the warlords felt so confident that they started crossing into former Chinese territory and kidnapping Russian workers tasked with rebuilding the Russian side of the new territory. The Russian military had to be called to secure the border and to prevent intrusion from Chinese warlords. Peter certainly did not expect this as a side effect of his victory,20 years after the war not much had changed. Radiation has largely disappeard (no one knows why). The Chinese economy never recovered and warlords still roam the Chinese landscape with occasional attempts to enter the border. Chinese cities on the russian border have been rebuilt but have not recovered to pre-war levels. While the Chinese space ports rust on into history, the newely rebuilt Chinese-Russian space port on the other hand shows signs of promising. A few of the surviving and captured Chinese scientists and enginneers have been working with their Russian counterparts on launching the first Russian sattelite into space (more than 80 years since the Chinese went to Space).As he looks eastward from an army observation post near the border, Peter of Russia still wonders. Was it necessiary to drop the bombs on the great cities where innocent people ones thrived? Was it right to condmen the people of China into the hell and misery they live in? Peter after all got want he wanted but at what cost? Should the Russian government try to rebuild China either through refinancing the Chinese government or "integration"? Or should China be left upto God and the mercy of those who rule her?

comment: this game is $12 on humble bundle monthly, definately worth it.I think civ 5 was an amazing game, my only problems with civ 5 was the atrocious load times, and the terrible terrible AI. In comparison to civ 6, civ 6 has pretty good load times, but the AI although better, is still pretty bad, what specifically bothers me about the AI in both games is that they dont seem to know the value of anything when trading. what i do like about diplomacy in civ 6 is that you can choose specific reasons to go to war with another civ for reduced warmonger penalties. also spying is better. What is worse about civ 6 is the user interface, everything seems overly complicated and i often cant figure out what specific things even do at all. in civ 5 i loved using the civilopedia to clarify things, but in civ6 it barely tells you anything.I was also looking at the rise and fall DLC coming out, and it looks terrible. looking at all the new game mechanics it adds, its just doesnt make sense, nothing it adds actually seems to change the game, they just look like extra things you have to worry about in an already overly complicated game(compared to civ 5). as opposed to civ5 and beyond earth DLC they actually add new game mechanics, beyond earth dlc added stuff like floating cities and civ 5 dlc added stuff like religion and trade routes that actually made the game better (civ 6 already has the same trade routes and religion mechanics btw). however the dlc does add new leaders and all but overall the civ6 dlc looks like garbage thatd make the game even worse.p.s. im only giving this game a thumbs up cus its $12 on humble bundle right now.p.s.p.s. also half the reason i got it is cus civ5 wont work on my desktop for somereason, its just broken

title: Recommended
comment: Very much enjoying Civ VI. The pacing and the rate of technologies/civics is very well done. You actually have time to develop items unlocked from the research during this game and each one feels necessary to continue. In other civ games, I would sprint forward in research before even being able to build any buildings or units before the next tech was unlocked.I also really like the district mechanic. Each one has different buildings and reasons for being built. It definitely makes each city unique as some will be factory towns, some science/university and others entertainment cities and all flow well into the game.The diplomacy works well and is fairly logical. Different cultures do act differently towards the player depending on their agenda and can make each play through very unique.The AI looked horrible during the preview shows and very passive. It is better for the release however. I did have AI units come up and attack my units and cities. But the downside is there were never enough units to really cause me issues and the AI doesn’t have much of an understanding on how to use siege engines to take down a city, which is the same issue it had in Civ V. Several infantry units assaulting a walled city while catapults roll back and forth behind them without firing a shot.If you can get over the combat AI that was dropped as a subroutine, Civ VI is very enjoyable and provides lots of entertainment.8 out of 10

comment: I will divide my review in different parts and give my pros and cons on each one.Graphics and Animation:+ For me, the graphics are really good. I like the more styalized art, and the animation (expecially repair one) is really solid and fitting.- Not all will enjoy this graphic, so watch some videos before you buy.Gameplay:+ The turns are quick, the movement smooth (and can be put in to fast, thank god) and the battles makes sense.+ This is the first Civilization game I know that made religion fun.+/- Civs are unbalanced, but that can be a good thing- Not the biggest fan of the new movement system, but one gets used to it and the roads makes more sense now.- A.I. is really bad and makes stupid things.Pricing:- At the current state, do not buy this game unless it is at least 50% off. title: Recommended
comment: TL;DRInitial release of Civ VI: 7/10 vs Civ V 9.5/101. Many civilizations are restricted to certain playstyle, certain map conditions and certain ages. Such as Scythia or China. And the rest have trouble fighting back these specific strategies.2. The multiplayer needs many improvements. a) A faster game speed; b) Different modes/rules; c) More social elements.I have spent most of my college playing Civ V. Can't be more excited to lay my hands on the new released Civ VI. After a bunch of trails, I totally agree that the problems cause people to give downvotes are very true:1. AI(crappy at war tactics, broken diplomacy, and many others)2. UI(can't get to know some key-info, auto-focus jumping around)3. glitches & bugs(get rich by buy&sell units, win deity AI within 1-turn, freezes&frequent reloading at multiplayer, multi-language display).I have experienced all these annoy issues during my gameplay which makes me urge for patches. And I would like to add some points of my own:1. Many civilizations are restricted to certain playstyle, certain map conditions and certain ages. And the rest have trouble fighting back these specific strategies. For two examples:a. Scythian - would be your greatest nightmare if it's your neighbor and there's only plane or desert between you two in a multiplayer game started at ancient age. You have two choices: 1. Spend all your workforce building defenses and watch the rest world erecting wonders and cities so you lose in the long run. 2. Suppose he/she won't attack you and get overwhelmed by seas of horse archers so you lose quickly. However, if it is an island map or the game starts at a later age, play as Scythian would benefit little from its abilities and very likely to be defeated.b. China - the wonder rush strategy with workers at ancient/classical times would bring almost every wonder and make China almost undefeatable in the long run(You can even win deity AI with this). But this requires the game to start at ancient times, a good spawn meet all the requirements for the wonders(especially desert for the Pyramid) and not being the neighbor of someone like Scythian or Sumerian. On the other side, without the benefit of early wonders, China can hardly win a more all-round civ such as Japan or Rome in the late game with equally good plays.2. The multiplayer needs many improvements. Here're a few thoughts I have:a. A faster game speed. Even with online speed, it's still too slow for an online game. I would say it requires 10h+ to play against more than one human players for a complete game from the ancient times. (Though people usually know they can't win and quit much earlier) When playing against random people online, it would be almost impossible to save the game and reload it next time. So we do need a faster game speed.b. More game modes/different rules. The current gameplay is dominated by one thing: War. Your chance of winning a culture or science victory 100% peacefully is slim and religious victory is impossible as all your missionaries and apostles sent would be slain by force if you are close to one. Remember there is only one winner. And the rule-of-thumb is that: if you can take one city, then you can take the whole country; since there is no heavy penalty as happiness in Civ V. This makes the game experience war-oriented and monotonic: You start at attacking city-states and your neighbors, later clash large empires similar to yours and finally dominate all or very few superpowers left to pursuit a culture/science victory hindering each other with nukes. I would be very glad to see some different plays: such as an alliance of peace-loving small civs work closely together could stand still against a large warmongering one with tech/culture/economy power and walk together towards victory.c. Be more social. Though civ series have a tradition that most people spend most time play it alone with different scenarios, I strongly suggest civ series go more "social" because play with human players can be much more interesting than beating cheating and illogical AIs. This can be learned from many other successful games and I think it would definitely bring something new and fun to this legend game-series.In conclusion, I would say the initial release of Civ 6 is acceptable for a game with such high expectations from its series fans, but there is still a way to go to become another game of legend itself.

title: Recommended
comment: So, I am going to give Civ 6 a positive review. However, I am also going to recommend that you wait for amonth or two and check back at that time. Gameplay is stable, but there are a couple of minor issues that could use some tweaking.The Good Side:As a long time Civ player, I feel a throwback vibe to the days of Civ 2, which is a really cool thing. Don't ask me why, I just feel this vibe. The game is alot more indepth than previous iterations. There are now essentially 2 tech trees, one is tech and the other is civics. I'm not going to take the time to go in depth to the system, but it works.Additionally, trade routes are here again and they are really cool. The diplomacy system is new and cool also.And one more thing that I noticed that I want to mention here - There seems to be, in my opinion, alot more emphasis on the middle game than previous iterations.While the AI is functional, and even challenging, there is a learning curve with it. I "feel" as though I don't have enough control in diplomacy. Don't get me wrong, the diplomacy is cool, it just feels like the AI isn't quite all there. I think that this will probably change in a few months with patching.Additionally, and I hesitate to put this forth as a con: There is quite the learning curve. This is somewhat good though, because it indicates the depth of the game.Lastly, there are some minor tidbits that need to be patched, but certainly nothing to write home about.A must have for any long time CIv player. The "feeling" of the game very much reminds me of civ 2. I do wonder if tiles instead of hexes would have been better here, but it's really no big issue. Be prepared for a learning curve, even if you are a veteran Civ player.I would recommend that you wait for a couple of months an/or for a steam sale to get this game, unless of course you are a Civ junkie, in which case absolutely get it now. It's good. It's not blow your socks off good, nor is it just "kinda good". It's good. Don't know how else to explain it.

Whoever I play as or against it feels the same with minor changes.This review is before the release of the (overpriced) Rise&Fall Expansion. Im hoping that they can save the game in the eyes of veteran civ players.

title: Recommended
comment: First of all, like everyone else releasing games for mac users, even these guys aren't any better. Mac users are of course given low priority. The latest DLC doesn't work even after 2 month of releasing.Having said that, the game is awesome! I have been a fan of the franchise from as long as I had a computer (around 2003). Some of the things I don't like about this one is ->1. The fog of war sucks. In order to make it stylish, they have made it impossible to differentiate between grasslands, plain, hills etc. I am not sure if that was intended amd makes sense.2. Religion view is bad. If you select any religious unit, it is difficult to see the underlying terrain properly. You can't figure out where the roads are.3. Too many bugs still left. If multiple sciences get boost in one turn, then sometimes the popup message shows the same one every time.

title: Recommended
comment: Civilization (the first one) was the first game I stayed up past bedtime playing as a child. This is the first game since then I've stayed up until dawn playing without planning to. Districts and wonders taking up space are really going to shake up the formula. Some balancing adjustments still need to be made, but all in all, it's really good, keeping most of the new gameplay ideas from the Civilization V expansion packs. I wish the religious victory didn't count cities conquered, as I accidentally lost a game by capturing too many of someone elses cities though.

title: Recommended
comment: Positives:- It's relatively polished.- It runs well.- Excellent music and graphics.- All of the mechanics of Gods & Kings + Brave New World are included as base content in Civilization VI (albeit modified), no feature stripping for the sake of future expansion pack sales.- It's Civ, it's addictive and good fun.Criticisms:- I do not like how the leaders look. Their proportions are odd and too cartoony for me. They also need more voiced dialogue.- The AI has absolutely no idea how to go to war. They will attack me with horribly outdated or unsuitable units. I will have spearmen and they will rush in with a dozen mounted units. If their units lose health, they will retreat or replace them with a full health unit. I can win with a horrible army by picking off one or two of their units.- The UI is bad. Everything feels squished together and vague.- Missing or broken game options (auto cycling units, buggy edge scrolling, no WASD camera)- The AI is dumb about win conditions. No one has captured any capitals, and they have bad science & culture per turn. I'm no Civ beginner, but I didn't expect to be winning in science in my first ever match when I was not playing strategically at all, just getting an idea of what's new.-----------------------------Overall:I will still recommend Civ VI because it is good fun, but there needs to be some patching of the major problems.

comment: Single Player Review with in-depth pros and consLove or Hate? - not sure.. perhaps both? Civilization 6 has the foundations to become the best Civ out there. title: Recommended
comment: Civ VI improves on alot of features from the Civ V expansions such as a Civics tech tree in addition to a Technology tree and the new district system. While the new diplomacy features of each leader's specific goal and the reasons for war are improvments the leaders are still somewhat erratic and difficult to please (though the patch helped some) and war is very discouraged by war weariness. Overall the game is great fun and very satisfying and if you enjoyed previous Civ games you will be able to loose hundreds of hours in this one.

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game has great potential however at the current state it sadly suffer from various annoying bugs and an AI that needs more work. Also the game doesn't yet support co-op games where you play as a team in multiplayer against the AI which is the main way I like to play Civ games with my friends. So my recommendation is to wait with a purchase until the game has received more fixes from the developers.

title: Recommended
comment: Is Civ6 a perfect game? No.Is it a fun game? YesI have played every iteration of Civilization and with every change over there are complaints and issues. These are all fair enough, as things we have loved are changing. But, over time, they will sort themselves out as get used to them.Of all the vanilla releases of Civ this is, by far, the deepest. There are new mechanics and concepts that really take the series in a good direction, such as districts and AI agendas. However, they really need to polish the game a bit more, as some of these great ideas have issues (eg it can be very hard to keep anyone liking you, and there may be no way to prevent it. The warmonger penalty may be excessive. etc).But there is one GLARING negative. The AI. Civ4 and 5 both suffered with horrendous AI upon release, and 6 continues this trend. The AI is PATHETIC. They often refuse to attack, instead shuffling their units about infront of your army while being massacred by ranged attacks. They don't seem to use districts overly well... it's not thought out to flow across the empire. Instead being a random mix that doesn't necessarily help them. And it's plain too easy to win, even on the hardest difficulties.Complaints about the art style will likely fade. People hated Civ4's art initially, but now love it. It is just jarring when you look at something you are not used to. Yes, it could use some touch ups as it can be hard to distinguish hills, but overall it looks amazing.Will this get better? Yes. Civ 4 and 5 had similar issues and they were ironed out. Civ6 is still very playable and very fun. It's not up to the standards of Civ4 BTS, or Civ5 BNW, but let's not forget they had 2 expansions and then almost a year of patches to become the masterpieces they ended up being.

title: Recommended
comment: Ghandi is not the only one that is slightly unhinged in this installment of Civilization. Mbanza Kongo will go to war with you for not sharing your religion with them. Scythia will hate you if you declare war on anyone for any reason. And Teddy Roosevelt is as lovable as his namesake toy. (Though I still feel that Teddy looks more like Taft.) The new unit system is an improvement over Civ5, however there are still some things that are lacking. Unit diversity for one, there simply aren't a lot of different units. This could change through time with the game though, more civilizations and leaders could mean more units, and more technologies.Another good point is that Civ6 returns to an old concept with Civ4. Multiple leaders for each civilization creates new play styles, and reintroduces the concept of a power struggle within a culture. This should also make for some very interesting Community mods as well.

title: Recommended
comment: This game could have been incredible and it still has some fun value to it, but it fails in several ways for me. Fortunately a simple mod download fixes a lot of their issues. I have no idea who programs and approves the User Interface for Civ games, but they need some serious help. There are so many wasted clicks and quality of life enhancements that are simple, I daresay known through out the community yet fail to appear in Civ 6. But a search for the most popular mod for UI interface will make this game 100% better.The second issue is their diplomacy system. They had a good ideas, maybe, but I have no clue what they thought was being implemented. The AI hate you for ridiculous things. Not expanding fast enough, some civ's hate you. Expanding? Some civs hate you. Building wonders? LOTS of civs hate you. It is horrible and makes no sense, just like the little screens that pop up from other civs that kind of have no reason to be there.You can pretty much forget about the entire diplomacy and AI sections of the game, most Civ games suffer from this and still go on to be great, fun games. It's just a same Civ 6 didn't improve on it and actually became worse. We'll see what the next paid expansion does (and they need to reign in their corporate greed at this point...the next paid expansion had better not be another whopping $60...*grumble*)Anyway, this game still has some fun and good times ahead of it, but it falls flat without a good UI mod. That is how important a good User Interface is, a little more horrible and it would have been a game breaker for me.I would recommend this game at $40. I would NOT pay $60 for this game and won't do so again for any civ game in the future. Nothing so special here that it calls for a $60 price tag. You still need to pony up almost another $20 on top of it to get the extra civs they've released so far.

title: Recommended
comment: So, I am going to give Civ 6 a positive review. However, I am also going to recommend that you wait for amonth or two and check back at that time. Gameplay is stable, but there are a couple of minor issues that could use some tweaking.The Good Side:As a long time Civ player, I feel a throwback vibe to the days of Civ 2, which is a really cool thing. Don't ask me why, I just feel this vibe. The game is alot more indepth than previous iterations. There are now essentially 2 tech trees, one is tech and the other is civics. I'm not going to take the time to go in depth to the system, but it works.Additionally, trade routes are here again and they are really cool. The diplomacy system is new and cool also.And one more thing that I noticed that I want to mention here - There seems to be, in my opinion, alot more emphasis on the middle game than previous iterations.While the AI is functional, and even challenging, there is a learning curve with it. I "feel" as though I don't have enough control in diplomacy. Don't get me wrong, the diplomacy is cool, it just feels like the AI isn't quite all there. I think that this will probably change in a few months with patching.Additionally, and I hesitate to put this forth as a con: There is quite the learning curve. This is somewhat good though, because it indicates the depth of the game.Lastly, there are some minor tidbits that need to be patched, but certainly nothing to write home about.A must have for any long time CIv player. The "feeling" of the game very much reminds me of civ 2. I do wonder if tiles instead of hexes would have been better here, but it's really no big issue. Be prepared for a learning curve, even if you are a veteran Civ player.I would recommend that you wait for a couple of months an/or for a steam sale to get this game, unless of course you are a Civ junkie, in which case absolutely get it now. It's good. It's not blow your socks off good, nor is it just "kinda good". It's good. Don't know how else to explain it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Civilization is the strategy game for people who don't like strategy games. That being said, it's a fun game, if somewhat dull at times. I've been playing Civilization since Civilization II and have seen it develop in extensive ways over the years. Civilization has become large enough for it to be that "Basic White Girl" strategy game it always dreamed to be, largely in thanks to Civilization V.Is it deserving of it? Well...Civilization will probably always be a good, but not great, game (if you ignore Beyond Earth). The design is intuitive and it's typically really easy to get into and it tries to keep it that way. VI managed to shrug off criticism that it will just be another vanilla template to build off with paid expansions.That being said, it struggles immensely in some areas. The AI was easily the worst part about Civilization V. The interaction menus in VI are improved and offers new political choices, but they are actually even worse than they were in V, behavior-wise.My other issue lies with districts. I think they should be adjacent plots to a city, if they are to exist at all. They are very time-consuming to develop and the district limits by population don't really offer any layer of strategy. Cool concept, and that's about all it has gonig for it right now.If Civ did anything right this go around, they showed other developers what not to do in their DLC mentality. A single Civilization is equal to 8% to cost of the entire game. Buying all available DLC Civilizations as of 1/8/2018 runs a price tag of $32 for 7 Civilizations, while the Rise and Fall expansion is $30.All in all Civilization is alright. Fans of the series or players who don't want a deeper strategy experience will like this game. Avid strategy players like myself will probably not be able to maintain interest. I also wouldn't recommend if you're that guy who never ends his/her turn.

title: Recommended
comment: Sometimes a sequel launches so poorly that it takes three years to reach the same level of polish as its predecessor. Sometimes the designer of a Civ title is so grossly incompetant that the game suffers from their bad designs for its entire life cycle. And sometimes, we forget just how difficult building a Civ game engine from scratch must be.CIvilization VI is not one of these games, and it's designer is not one of those designers. The game suffers from several defects related to being built on a customized in-house engine. The game lacks polish in several areas. The user interface lacks critical information about how certain mechanics work. The game needs changes, of course.But it is entirely worth every penny spent on this game. Even with all the problems it has, it's still very enjoyable. It makes previous Vanilla Civ releases feel subpar, especially the mess that was Civ 5 at launch. The multiplayer works better at launch than Civ 5's did after its final patch.Personally, I expected the issues we have with this game. It's brand new, and we're comparing it to Civ 5 with 2 expansions and 15+ patches. In a few years, this game will be leaps and bounds ahead of where it is now, and I'm excited to see what comes next!

title: Recommended
comment: I'm biased... This was the first series of games I played at the age of 7, because I found it on my mom's laptop while she was at work and just always played it. I've grown up playing games, every genre really. This has become my all-time favorite game, period. I'm not sure theres another game that's captivated my interest for 14 hours straight, into the night, then again the very next day right after I woke up and ate. Fallout has gotten close, but at that point I was just mindlessly droning. I always felt like, and feel like, I'm accomplishing something in Civ 6. The greatest part is, Civ always has new expansions that manage to add more to an already vast game, although my expectations were exceeded, it's odd to say I expect my expectations to continue to be exceeded.TLDR; Buy this game. It's worth it.

title: Recommended
comment: I have some good things and some bad things to say about this new civ game. First of all, the positives:- It's finally a MODERN civ game with no graphic glitches on modern win 10 systems and it runs natively in 64 bits. Everything runs extremely well at max settings (4K res, all grfx settings at max.)- I LOVE the districts and that you can make every city different and unique. I also love that you control population directly, by building neighborhoods.- I love the new animations for movement and combat.- I love that the game is still extremely customizable just like civ 5. I like that I can start in any era and that I can customize the map and the game as much as I want. Unfortunately, playing on planet Earth seems to be missing, and that's the map I always use with civ 5.- I love the improved diplomacy and the new spy management section.Now for what I don't like:- Buildings and military units are MUCH HARDER to obtain. You have to play for at least 5-6 hours before you can even start considering attacking another nation. And even with resources set at max, strategic resources are MUCH HARDER to come by. Which means you'll be a lot less inclined to risk units on daring tactics, because rebuilding them would be prohibitive.- The AI is insane. Computer-controlled nations declare war on me all the time, for no reason (really? Rome is angry at me for building 30 hexes away from their closest city?) I found myself at war with 5-6 nations, none of them allied. That makes absolutely NO SENSE.- What's with the random comments on my civ from other nations? The same useless comments that repeat over and over and that don't lead to anything other than a "goodbye" button. Talk about a gratuitous waste of my time!- Why oh why are workers expended after they only built three things? And why have they become a lot harder to get? In civ 5 I'm used to hundreds of workers building and fixing things. Now even workers have become a luxury? It takes at least 10 hours before your biggest city with all the fixings can produce a worker unit every turn.- I don't particularly like the more cartoonish diplomacy animationd. I want to deal with people, not cartoons. It's pretty hard for me to take them seriously when they look like Manga characters...I don't know if I can recommend it. Unfortunately there is no neutral option, so it's either yes or no. Hopefully new versions will take care of the shortcomings and that's why I decided to recommend it. But not if you buy it right now (as in 10/23/2016.)FOR NOW IT'S **NOT** RECOMMENDED.

title: Recommended
comment: I have largely enjoyed Civ 6 so far, it perhaps isn't the complete package yet, like most Civ releases it tends to require a couple of expansions before fully rounded out and realised to its full potential.Having said that, they have transitioned nicely to the new city tile system, with districts and wonders built separately outside of the single city tile, an idea quite foreign to previous Civ titles!Multiplayer seems quite stable, without desync issues like 5.As usual you will likely find you start more games than you finish but it's a good game for chilling out for several hours over Discord as you put the world to rights whilst growing your Civilisation.The updates made to the game are slow but meaningful, adjusting the outright unreasonable AI from the initial release to a more strategic opponent and using the Civ's likes and dislikes system to a greater effect.Overall it's a game i look forward to seeing how it evolves, perhaps with a world congress like system to spice up the late game, and with more Civilisations added over time to help bolster the numbers!

title: Recommended
comment: Nice game, interesting new solutions, solid arts, nice town animation. Great soundtrack by the way. It's hard to compare different versions of Civilization games. Every game has unique balance setting. This game is interesting to play - that's what I can say for sure.So I totally recommend it.Minors:- UI. Sometimes it's terrible. You have to click at that city many times before you can select it. Sometimes UI glitch (I have "new regime available" instead of "next turn" - works as shoud, an animation bug).- Eats a lot of RAM and does not want to exit without killing the process.- Units sometimes got lost in the middle of a route. I don't like the way the planned routes are displayed.- This annoying limitation on "how many units of the same type on one cell".

title: Not Recommended
comment: pros:*building districts for different outputs.*local happiness.*units can be combined.*units upgrading can be affordable (only with discount policy).*different type of government through ages.*some buildings and units can be discovered by culture tree.cons:*AI is very likely to start war on you all the time through ages.*very hard to get a friendly civ (most of time you are hated by every one).*after middle-age, AI may place their cities in very annoying places (like one-ground-tile city near your capital).*big & good areas (almost a half continent) of the map may not be filled of any civs until the end of the game.*AI may have too many ancient & middle-age units in the last era.*space victory still too easy/fast to win.*culture tree is too big and sometimes boring.*faith war between missionaries and apostles to win religion victory, this one has no logic. Not like civ 5 when religion is an important tool to win other victories or get happiness.*no diplomatic victory or any type of victory depending on money.

title: Recommended
comment: A worthy sequel to Civ V, but lacking many of the refinements that were built into the expansions for it. However it is still a great base game with very refined battle mechanics.The non-battle strategies feel lacking at the moment, like wonder building, or focusing on science.They still have not fixed simple issues like unit-cycling Vs no cycling (Why not simply have "nearest unit first-cycling")The A.I. is still absurd, and this makes it feel less immersive than Civ IV. It constantly makes absurd claims that make me feel like I'm playing a board game with simple logic, instead of a theoretically well programmed game.All that aside, there is a lot that is good, and if you like any previous Civ game you will like this. There is just so much that could be simply fixed to make the game immersive, rather than just compettitive.I'm reccomending it, and have done so with many friends who are now Civ junkies.Cannot wait for expansions and AI tweaks (but historically they never manage to make the AI much better)

title: Recommended
comment: So I'm starting by saying I have played every Civ (including Alpha Centauri) since Civ 1 on hard floppy disks. Each Civ did something different, and 6 did cities completely different. Is it worth Steam Sale? Definitely. Is it worth full price? Yes, if you love 4x games for the building aspect but not so much on the fighting strategy.I was very dissapointed in initial release with religion being useless and the AI not trying to win as the most obvious deterrents. The current release (with all the additional civilization DLC's) feels like a full game, but it comes at the cost of DLC's which is my main complaint. If you want a game that feels huge, get Civ 3. If you want a competitive multiplayer experience, get Civ 5. If you are like me and enjoy these games for the building over several evenings' play, you'll love Civ 6.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I have invested almost 150 hours into this game. If you're a fan of the Civ series, it is still a Civ game, with a lot of new and exciting features. You will probably still have fun with this game, playing online versus your buddies is still fun, messing around with the AI can be fun.However,Due to the straight up weirdness of the AI and lack of base content, I have forgone playing this game until there is an AI patch or Mod Support. At 150 hours, I feel like I've worn through most of the fun. I rarely finish the games now, not even worried about achievements that much, just because the AI is so bad. They get mad if you do something, they get mad if you don't do something, they declare war for no reason but have no troops to fight you... Heaven forbid you declare war on anyone, because that means you're the worst person IN THE WORLD. But, then again, that still doesn't mean anything, if you build a proper army, they can't even touch you.As of right now, I wouldn't recommend the game to anyone who already has Civ V. Once these problems are solved, hopefully for free, I'm sure it will surpass Civ 5.EDIT: the DLC isn't fixing the problems, oh well.

title: Recommended
comment: This makes up for the facebook flavored version of Civ that was labeled Civ 5. No regrets.

title: Recommended
comment: Overall a very fun game (over reviews go into more detail), but I'm especially happy with the responsiveness of the Firaxis development team. When the game launched many problems were identified (discussed in detail on Reddit), and in the first patch almost all of the major issues were fixed. There are multiple Firaxis employees on the Civ reddit, so it's nice to know that complaints don't always fall on dear ears.

title: Recommended
comment: Most Sid Meier's Civilization games only reach true gameplay maturity after the expansions come out. Not CIV VI. From the get go, CIV VI has great new mechanics and refreshed old ones in interesting ways, all done expertly. Even though it still has a few kinks to iron out, such as a broken trading system, an envoy system that feels a little out of my control, a constant apostle spamming and predictable AI (higher difficulty practically only buffs the AI through bonuses instead of changing mechanics). But none of that detracts from the amazing game this is. Candidate for GOTY.Final Score:9/10.

title: Not Recommended
comment: im going with no on this game mostly because it follows such a masterpiece and doesnt take a step up from Civ 5.Placing a city is very important now, you need to have opean areas for your districts. I dont think the leaders needed a cartoon makeover. I just dont get 100% of this game yet, i understand the limited use workers and the importance of your ruling style but i just cant seem to build fast enough to keep up with the AI.

title: Recommended

title: Not Recommended
comment: This game is WAYYYY underdeveloped and unbalanced, I recommend waiting for the all the DLC. and even then check reveiws, because this game seems to have glaring unfixable aspects like religion. Not worth the money in its present state, and honestly a disappointment after CIV V

title: Recommended
comment: Best game of the franchise, I've played 3,4,5, and BE, and now this, and I can easily say that this builds upon the strengths and failings of the past games and is honestly the high point of the series, all of you complaining about the graphics "going backwards" are wrong, Cartoonish graphics hold up more in the long run than realistic graphics, and ths game feels no where near like a mobile game as I saw in some reviews. I love how their is sooooo much content on release unlike civ 5 and Beyond Earth. There is only one problem that I have and that is the AI is still kind of dumb and easy to deal with, and Firaxis/2k STOP GIVING THE AI ADDITIONAL STARTING STUFF AT HIGHER DIFFICULTIES JUST MAKE THE AI SMARTER AT HIGHER DIFFICULTIES!!! Additional starting stuff is just plain unfair! But still a good game, planning on having double what I currently have in civ 5 after 6 years, and In one month I'm already about half way to having the same time played in BE after one year. Currently in my rotation of games that I play right now and will be for several months most likely :)

title: Recommended
comment: My favorite iteration of Civilization yet (have been playing since IV) due to the new way that cities work with districts. The art direction of the game has changed since the last version of Civ and I can see why it's controversial, but it's not an issue for me. This game looks reminiscent of Civilization Revolution.What I've enjoyed in particular in this version are the campaigns, which are objective-based missions which unfold at an accelerated pace, over 50 turns. They vastly speed up the pace of Civilization which can sometimes feel slow. About a month after release Firaxis released an update for Civ VI which added a new campaign which is great - this is encouraging. Hoping for more good updates which bring new content!

title: Recommended
comment: Such a fun and amazing game after CIV V to be fair it does take a little while to get used to with playing CIV V a lot but all in all this is a game worth buying, to all the people moaning on how the AI declares war or isn't always happy with you, just simply keeps a tab on all the things e.g. troops, resources, agenders and make sure not to do something that will p*ss them off, when you click on them it even tells you what will p*ss them off and make them friendlier. But this is just my review and you yourself can judge the game, despite what other reviews say, i didn't take any advice from them and i just went out a bought the game as i was intended to regardless. The game is not the same as CIV V with the builders not been permanent and various other changes but, who wants another CIV V anyway we needed change and CIV VI provided.In conclusion, i personally would recommend this game but it's completely up to you to buy the game.

title: Recommended
comment: A deeper game than Civ 5. Has some glitches and problems that need ironed out but the devs are good at spotting problems. At first I was sad I couldn't rename my cities and then it got hotfixed thankfully. Once you get into it however, the game may consume your life!

title: Recommended
comment: A worthy successor to the Civ series. Unlike previous versions of Civ, very few features were dropped and you don't need to wait for expansions for a complete game.There are certainly flaws that will be improved with patches or expansions. Religion isn't that interesting and the AI sometimes seems to have an indecisive nature, either due to conflicting goals or just buggy behavior.Most importantly, it fully captures the feeling of One More Turn that the series is famous for. Recommended.

title: Recommended
comment: I had removed CIV5 from my "playlist" in favour of Paradox' titles, as they just felt more engaging after thousands of hours of CIV over the years, but I was of course still excited to try out CIV6. So far, some 40-50 hours in (EDIT: Apparently I'm just over 100 hours in, how the time flies), I've not been disappointed!My major takeaways, positive and negative, so far:1. I am no longer punished for building wide - wow what a feeling!2. The music is great, and it's dynamic aspects works perfectly almost making me feel like part of an epic movie.3. I like the new tech boost system, but it's still too early to tell if it's actually good for the game or not. If an optimal strategy can be found the new system might be more limiting than it is rewarding.4. However, the civets/policy system I feel adds a great deal and is a step forward.5. I like the attention made to the diplomacy system in general, but it still needs a lot of polish and tweaks. It can get quite annoying that you can never be friends with the AI unless you give them incredible bribes and also toe the line of their diplomatic agendas perfectly.6. I encountered quite a few bugs with the UI. However, no performance problem on my 2 year old machine (GPU is a GTX760).Overall I will have a lot of fun with this. Better than CIV5? Sure, why not - but I don't know if it will last as long as CIV5 did in it's present state, but I'm hopeful future updates will make it so. My favourite CIV is still CIV4 though :)

title: Recommended
comment: The game is ok now. if you going to buy it give it some time.PROS-it look good to me-the unstack citys is cool-the more diplomatic options with the AI-nuking citiesCONS-the two teck trees-not researching tecks from the beging of the game-the AI needs A LOT of workif you are thinking of getting this game wait. It will get much better in time. i can not give this a thumbs down.i can't wait for what they add.

comment: Might be the best Civilization game in a long time!

title: Recommended

More friendly, yet so complex.AI is still with minor issues here and there. UI could take little bit less space - just nitpicking.Go play it and remember just one last turn :o)Once you have taken flightYou'll decideGaze towards the sky, you'll knowThat is where your heart will feel at home.

title: Recommended
comment: Visually pleasing compared to Civ 5 as well as a lot more to do. This can be overwhelming and frustrating, though, but it is a plus once you get the hang of the districts and tile placements. I also enjoy the commentary on the wonders and watching them be built.There are many positive things on this game that beat Civ 5 and the only a few negatives. I would say that barbarians can be pretty harsh in this one, but you can work around that. There is also not an initial ally button to become allies with friends, so that is a turn off as well. The rest of the negatives just have to do with needing more civs to play as and more maps, but that will come with mods and expainsions.

title: Recommended
comment: Its Sid Meier's Civilization.What more reason do you need to buy it?You dont... go buy it.Buy it... or Ghandi will rain down Islamic Communist atomic-fire upon your head.Ghandi conqures all.... personally, I do prefer the aesthetics of Civ5 better though.Just seemed more beautiful, refined, cultured. Just a step foward.Civ6 seems in contrast like a over-colour-contrasted stylised throwback into past Civs. Yeah, its a 25th anniversary of Civ so it visually harkens back to Civs of the past (with Civ5 being the outlier in that regard) with the exeption of playstyle and features... and dont get me wrong, gameplay wise, its still a step fowards - just artistically, its a step backwards.But that didnt stop me from buying a physical collectors edition :)Its a Sid Meier game. Its a Civilization.Worth every penny <3

title: Recommended
comment: I'm biased... This was the first series of games I played at the age of 7, because I found it on my mom's laptop while she was at work and just always played it. I've grown up playing games, every genre really. This has become my all-time favorite game, period. I'm not sure theres another game that's captivated my interest for 14 hours straight, into the night, then again the very next day right after I woke up and ate. Fallout has gotten close, but at that point I was just mindlessly droning. I always felt like, and feel like, I'm accomplishing something in Civ 6. The greatest part is, Civ always has new expansions that manage to add more to an already vast game, although my expectations were exceeded, it's odd to say I expect my expectations to continue to be exceeded.TLDR; Buy this game. It's worth it.

comment: start in hot seat modeme and friend in seperate continentsresearch cartographymove army to friends locationgo to war with sumeriaretook a city that sumeria took from friendasks me for peacemade sumeria give me a citygives me a cityasks friend for peacemade sumeria give him a citygave him a city10/10

title: Recommended
comment: I have some good things and some bad things to say about this new civ game. First of all, the positives:- It's finally a MODERN civ game with no graphic glitches on modern win 10 systems and it runs natively in 64 bits. Everything runs extremely well at max settings (4K res, all grfx settings at max.)- I LOVE the districts and that you can make every city different and unique. I also love that you control population directly, by building neighborhoods.- I love the new animations for movement and combat.- I love that the game is still extremely customizable just like civ 5. I like that I can start in any era and that I can customize the map and the game as much as I want. Unfortunately, playing on planet Earth seems to be missing, and that's the map I always use with civ 5.- I love the improved diplomacy and the new spy management section.Now for what I don't like:- Buildings and military units are MUCH HARDER to obtain. You have to play for at least 5-6 hours before you can even start considering attacking another nation. And even with resources set at max, strategic resources are MUCH HARDER to come by. Which means you'll be a lot less inclined to risk units on daring tactics, because rebuilding them would be prohibitive.- The AI is insane. Computer-controlled nations declare war on me all the time, for no reason (really? Rome is angry at me for building 30 hexes away from their closest city?) I found myself at war with 5-6 nations, none of them allied. That makes absolutely NO SENSE.- What's with the random comments on my civ from other nations? The same useless comments that repeat over and over and that don't lead to anything other than a "goodbye" button. Talk about a gratuitous waste of my time!- Why oh why are workers expended after they only built three things? And why have they become a lot harder to get? In civ 5 I'm used to hundreds of workers building and fixing things. Now even workers have become a luxury? It takes at least 10 hours before your biggest city with all the fixings can produce a worker unit every turn.- I don't particularly like the more cartoonish diplomacy animationd. I want to deal with people, not cartoons. It's pretty hard for me to take them seriously when they look like Manga characters...I don't know if I can recommend it. Unfortunately there is no neutral option, so it's either yes or no. Hopefully new versions will take care of the shortcomings and that's why I decided to recommend it. But not if you buy it right now (as in 10/23/2016.)FOR NOW IT'S **NOT** RECOMMENDED.

title: Recommended
comment: Nice and fresh take on Civ. Really enjoy the fact that you have to plan out your cities more than in previous Civs where you just spam every tile with farms and mines around cities that have 15 wonders built in them because that's where all your production is.

title: Recommended
comment: Have played around 30 hours of this game in 4 days and have loved it.Even the graphics which I didn't like at first have grown on me and I can't help but be in awe at some of the views I get.There is still but of fine tuning to the AI to be done, but I understand that the AI for a game like this must be pretty complicated to code for.I've so far played a science game and a diplomatic game & a domination game and enjoyed both varieties.I really look forward to what else is put into the game.

title: Recommended
comment: Short and sweet.Positives- a worthy successor to the fantastic Civ5- Districts are amazing. The exploitation of each map tile is a lot of fun- Builders have been improved, traders now build roads which adds to the strategy.- Much improved diplomacy, spy systems, great people- Army/fleet groupings + experienced units can be named- lot's of other things!!Negatives- AI seems unbalanced- End game can be a bit of a drag- No diplomatic victory (yet)Overall fantastic game I'd give 9/10 to.

title: Recommended
comment: I have only played the base game, but the gameplay is quite good. Civ 6 features many changes from it's predicessors such as a greatly decreased emphasis on war, a much greater emphasis on managing one's empire, and the increased specialization on one's civilization. Solid game, would reccomend

title: Recommended
comment: Fantastic game!!!I am a fan of this series. And I must tell that is in the batlle of my favorite. I have been playing for hours, and enjoying each moment.The districts was a fantastic idea. The traders too. Now you can use them for internal commerce and get some good aid for your small cities. The selection of leaders is great. Not the classic leaders of all civs, but some of them really new.On the negative side we have some problems with the ui and the hotkeys (really, not having a hotkey for toggling the resource icons is annoying).In the end I must say that i can't see time pass when I'm playing... and you know... just one mor turn...

title: Not Recommended
comment: Something wrong with Eurekas and InspirationsDisticts is a great idea! They are really awesome and I think there is a bunch of cool things that can be done with districts in future versions and DLC.But I Eurekas and Inspirations (for Civics). They are too strong and force all players play same way: make everything to achieve Eurika/Inspiration to get boost. I like 'marathon' speed of the game which let me enjoy all aspects of the game, but Eurekas make game too fast even on 'marathon' speed!Please, give me a way to and make them less cheating (50% is too much, 5-10% should be enough for this concept of the game).I don't recommend this game until Eurekas and Inspirations will be fixed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Though I quite enjoy the game, I find it difficult to recommend any non-Windows version due to its repeated status as an afterthought by Firaxis, with OS X and Linux often waiting two months after a patch release date to receive it. This is culminated in Firaxis' shambolic release of Rise and Fall, offering and *optimistic* non-Windows date of If Firaxis wants to boast about their support across multiple operating systems (and promise cross platform play which is still pending more than a year and four months after release), then they need to at least put a little bit more effort into treating the non-Windows versions as more than an afterthought for Aspyr to clean up.I don't know what changed between V and VI, but this repeated bait and switch has burned through all the good will that they'd generated with their promise of continual multi-system support, and is frankly embarassing from a company that wants to bill itself as triple A.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I'd love to sit here and say I am loving this game (playing the "free weekend" on my 1 day off work while overseas. Sadly, while the game is interesting there is no way to get through a single game in a day on the "quick" game setting. Beyond that, seeing what the "Deluxe" version includes, I think I will wait for a "Game of the Year" edition ... or just pass altogether. I am NOT paying $70+ for this one. It just isn't worth it to me, and I feel for those who paid up $80 originally thinking they would get the expansion as part of said version were hosed.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Stop starting, start finishing Firaxis!We have a group that is frequently meeting to play civ rounds.Civ 6 so far is 90% efford into single player and new features that can be sold. Multiplayer only exists so they can say "we have that too".Some very big features from single player were not taken over to multiplayer.A lot of things that don't matter so much in single player, but that can make Multiplayer senseless don't get fixed.What exactly do I speak of?1. Save/Load Configuration. You implemented it in single player. Unless devs have no clue what they do, it should be a no brainer to implement that functionality into Multiplayer lobbies.2. Restart: Okay, not everybody should be able to trigger a restart on round 1. BUT why not making a multiplayer restart? Without save/load it is a pain to reconfigure everything if once again somebody landed on a 3 field island, a desert or next to ice.3. Balanced start positions: Yes there is already a feature with that name. But it does obviously not work. Typical multiplayer setting is islands or continents. You play with 4 players get placed on 4 completely different sized islands. A bit randomness is okay, But if one player can immediately place 8 cities on his island and another one can place just one more before he heeds to research shipbuilding and must hope to find some new land somewhere, that is ruining EVERY competitive multiplayer game. Versus AIs that is not much of a problem, Civ 5 and especially Civ 4 had MUCH better map generators.4. The whole damn UI: Yes it looks fancy. High res and everything. But I would trade the fancy bling bling UI for a Civ 4 UI anytime. Now with the new Rise and Fall the CQUI Mod is broken again unfortunately, so we are forced to deal with the stupid game UI. Just pay the CQUI team a fair price and implement their mod into the full game.PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE before making more content that is improving the game little work on making the UI more functional. Check the CQUI mod. Implement a build queue, Implement a build menu where you need less clicks and get a better overview than you have now. Also very usefull are demographics and the event handling that CQUI makes.5. AI is more stupid than ever before in Civ 6: Some improvements were already made, but diplomacy is a huge huge problem. Simply buying cities with money in peace negotiations was worse a few months ago, but it still is bad. Also expanding and district placement is pretty bad.6. Maps: Make better maps. In Civ 4 there were options like Island (1 big and several small islands per player). In general you need fair chances for all participants in a multiplayer game.7. Multiplayer Lobby Bugs: Fix them please. Inviting players for games does occasionally not work when you invite multiple players quickly. One of them gets stuck in the loading screen, has to restart his game and when he joins over the steam friend himself all works fine.Implement the game critical mods or make absolutely sure that the mods work when you make updates. Your game is so bad that it needs mods to make it playable like older Civ games.
