title: Not Recommended
comment: I have reverted back to CIV V.I have tried the game and find CIV VI to be slow and overbearing. Building city improvements take too long. First one must build the district to put improvements in then you must build the buildings. WHY?Next workers can only make 3 os so improvements then they disappear. Why?In the past versions, and I have played them all, once you create a worker, you kept it forever. What is the purpose of making them disappear other than to slow down the game play?What is the purpose of the districts other than to take up space on the map and hide resources? A city which always has only taken one spot on the map now takes several spaces and countless turns to develope the "districts". It slows the game down and quite honestly makes it boring for me to play.Building a military and actually using it makes you the worst type of ruler, ie a warmonger to every other player in the game...even friends. The time it takes to try and improve one's reputation is not worth it so one plays the game not reaping any benefits.Honestly, I do not like what has been done to the game and really feal I have wasted my money. You can look at my hours played in relation to the hours I still spend playing CIV V and there really is no comparison.There could be some selections put in the game set up which would eliminate the concepts of the game which one finds undesirable.I'm sure there are some interestig aspects to the game but I have not found a good enough reason to go through an entire game and see if it gets better. I am not sure if I have finished a game yet, but if I have that tells you how memorable it was not.I hate being this negative about any CIV game. I have owned them all up to this point, but I have not bought any expansion or considered buying one for this seies. For now I will wait for CIV VII if there is one and I'm sure I will be behind the power curve on game play b ut for now I will stick with CIV V.

title: Recommended
comment: It's Civ, a frequent player of the franchise will feel right at home.It's kept the same Hexagonal tiles for the world as in 5, and continues to work well. I barely remember playing Civ on square tiles from 4 and previous. The changes made from 5 have worked in some ways but not in others, The ways to win have been changed, personally I think they've got this wrong. Science is harder to achieve, which is my personal preferred way to win and I actually win by culture instead when shooting for science. A lot of people have stated that the religious victory is a little flat, but I havent tried to win that way.A lot of changes make this version of Civ feel a lot different: Districts being built on tiles to specialise them; Wonders containing their own tiles; great people being awarded differently. Civics work like the tech tree and are reaserched seperately but at the same time as tech. AI Diplomacy feels completely different with their agendas. Workers have charges and will be removed after they've been used which prevents getting to the late era with lots of workers stood doing nothing.All in all, the changes are generally good. I'm certainly enjoying a game that feels a lot more different than Civ 5 in its own way. I'm certainly enjoying it

title: Recommended
comment: This is an Amazing game, hands down. It does not simplify Civ 5 as many suggest, but makes the graphics cleaner. Workers no longer have infinite build points. but can only build 3 (Up to 5 with the Pyrimads and Serfdom) My one criticism is that the cultere system and government systed just doesn't fit. I liked it when you went down a tree as it made you develop your culture. Now you can get a cultural victory by just building resorts. Uranium is rarer, which I love, and the AI got a major improvement with agendas, now the AI will have certain agendas, and if you go against them they dislike you. When I put troops on a border and make demands, they treat it like an ultimatium, and usually comply (Unless I have 2 archer units on the border of a city with 50 defense in 2050). The AI is alot smarter, and declare joint wars on you more.Another criticism, is like in Civ 5, they add artificial difficulty, by giving the AI a bunch of advantages.

title: Recommended
comment: I have been playing Civilization since Civ III and can say unequivocally that this is an excellent addition to the Civilization family. While the late game still feels weak and the lack of a build queue as well as after victory info slides makes the game feel inferior to Civilization V, there are some fantastic improvements. Each game definitely takes longer, but that is mostly due to the increased agency. Every game of Civ VI is different and unlike previous versions, you cannot simply lay back and let the game play itself. Some people might find that off putting, but the increased involvement means more than ever that every choice you make has meaning. Civ VI is a solid 8.5/10, a score that will definitely go up with future releases. Great job Ed Beach and team!

comment: I enjoyed this civ game quite a bit, the districts are a nice touch and the civs feel balanced aside from the exploit with tomiris. single player is kinda laughable but online offers a nice pvp. if you can keep a game long enough. title: Recommended
comment: A well rounded and thought out 4x strategy game. The countinual attempts to introduce new content is a credit to the creators. There are wrinkles of course, but were talking world history here. You can't cover everything. The fact that there is as much diversity and choices available as there is, is amazing.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Solid and fun single-player experience, but multiplayer is extremely unstable. If you're lucky, the game will just crash a few times, and you'll have to put together the lobby and load up an autosave. If you're not so lucky, you'll get some weird error, do a Google search and find no answer.If you're happy to treat this as a single-player game only, you're set. If you want multiplayer, don't bother.

title: Recommended
comment: After playing Civ 5 for hundreds of hours I definitely feel like Civ 6 is a better, more solid game. It was very smooth and pleasant experience from the get-go. I haven't encountered a single bug yet. The game has certain things that may seem like flaws at first (AIs denouncing you and declaring war on you for no obvious reason) but I need more playtesting to decide if they are important enough to be mentioned at all. I can't wait to sink more hours in the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I had high hopes. The game is not new user friendly at all. The tutorial mode babies you with poor recommendations that ruin your chances of becoming an actual power. Then France comes and ruins your poorly made peaceful town with their hundreds of soldiers and warships. Where did they even find time to do that???I would not recommend it.

title: Not Recommended
comment: i've spent 6 hours trying desperately to fix the problems.... followed the advice on all forms ... and it still crashes on every start up... my system is very high end.... ran the demo perfect, got it in a bundle deal with XCOM 2 .... :( sad times.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I've tried, i really have but i can only come up with one word for this latest release of Civ and that is;Boring.It should really be great, there are some amazing new features, but i find my self not far into a game just bored.Aside from the other major issues such as AI and huge lag caused by the barbarians turn (I found if you turn barbarians off it turbo charges the turns, even through late huge map games).Rather than being "just one more turn", its more like "Oh god another turn, when will you be over...."Hopefully a full expansion will be released to fill the manotony, but it had better be cheap unlike all the terrible AI characters they are selling.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I like a few features like the culture tree and policies,monuments and more abundant and accessible wonders, BUT I truly hate the interface that takes up too much of the view and the play-doh graphics that take away the realistic feeling of being the ruler of earth-like planets, they dont even come anywhere close to giving a immersive feeling like civ V gives with great sountracks and graphics. I'm uninstalling civ 6 as I did for Beyond Earth rising tides. I REAAAAAAALLLY hope Civ VII will be a a game that I can compete with Civ V and that I can appreciate as much, if not more than Civ V. And dont get me wrong, civ 6 is not a bad game at all! no Civ game is, I just think that Civ V was so great that Aspyre should try harder to bring the master experience to the next level. And thats my opinion.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I really anticipated Civ VI since it's been announced. I have a long history of playing every Civ game in the franchise since the original.Unfortunately Civ VI at the moment is a big disappointment. The main points for me being:- AI. If Firaxis just left AI unchanged from CIV V that would have been an improvement even though it was already very weak. Now after they added new diplomatic mechanics (agendas, casus beli, etc.) and new approach to city planning, the AI is just painfully incapable of making sense. The shortcomings were already outlined by other reviewers in great detail and I fully agree with their points. Personally I was mostly anticipating CIV VI in hope of better AI, and it is a very bitter disappointment to see such poor outcome.- Problems with diplomacy is essentially a specific issue with AI, but I feel I should have a separate mention of it. In Civ V towards end-game all AI Civs were essentially hating each other without much reason. Now the devs decided to add actual artificial reasons added for them to hate each other even more fiercely than before - the Agendas. This feature just doesn't work at all. Who needs these far-fetched inflexible negative parameters ("I will hate you because...") that make diplomacy even less feasible than in Civ V?- Plenty of bugs and poor optimization. Ok, the bugs hopefully will be fixed, but it's still very annoying to se them. Some examples include broken alliance mechanics (AI units remain in your territory after alliance expires without open borders being active), pop-up messages being impossible to read, units pathfinding is a mess, etc. optimization is another issue - I have a very capable PC (Skylake i7) and yet in a 2-person hotseat game the AI turns take VERY long to complete even in a very early ancient era game! Single player games were smoother, but not sufficiently so.- Interface had some improvements (generally cleaner), but a lot of important information is very hard to find. Some information the devs just didn't bother to include at all. When and where the border expansion will happen in the city? Who cares, right? Or what's the strength of religious spread of a city? I guess some throbbing bubble is supposed to be informative on that...- Cartoonish art style. It's not too much of a big deal as it's certainly not the most important aspect of the game. I was willing to accept it if there were notable gameplay improvements made. On the other hand, seeing how ridiculous the AI is, perhaps the childish art style helps to not take AI behavior seriously. Was that your plan all along, Firaxis?- While the districts is a good feature that finally introduces some variability into cities development, the wonders are now all but irrelevant. Taking up an entire tyle (and removing its yields) and costing huge amount of production, it's just not worth investing in the wonders at all. This certainly does not help the game being more exciting.There are positives too, but for me personally the negatives just outweigh everything else. And I don't carry much hope for improvement. First it was the terrible Beyond Earth and now over-hyped and under-developed Civ VI. Not a good trend.

But the time I spent playing it felt empty.I really hope that I can still get this refunded.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Such an unbalanced game with lazy AI coding for the higher levels. Pretty graphics but a poor attempt under the hood. 2/10 for the Civ series. Inconsistancies in game play where units appear out of no where or multiple units are produced in the same turn at the one enemy city.I fail to see how this game has ranked so highly with the critics. Guess they are worried about future magazine sales than providing a true and honest account of the game.

title: Not Recommended
comment: I was pretty excited for the game and to be fair it is a pretty bold step from Civ V. I personally don't mind the art direction and the new mechanics are pretty fun to explore. That being said, the UI alone is one of the most infuriating interfaces I've ever tried to use. Personally I like to use the edges of the screen to move the map and the way that this is set up in Civ VI has to be the worst navigation I've ever experienced. Parts of the edges of the screen don't respond to the mouse and the very top the interface actually isn't what moves the map up, but instead it is the top of the game window so ie. whenever you try to vew Great Prophet progress your start scrolling to the top of the map. It's ridiculous and I don't recommend this game just cause it's so irritating to use.

title: Recommended
comment: This game is a mixed bag for now and needs to be patched along with much needed dlc. It has the potential to be the best civ game I've ever played I think but needs work. First of all, I have not been able to finish my last three games because of glitches. Either my game crashes on the same turn or I cannot advance to the next turn. Needless to say this is very frustrating but I am hopeful upcoming patches will fix this. This version is not as deep or nuanced as Civ 5 was imo. But just as they did with Civ 5, they will most likely tweek things until they get it right. I just hope they get things fixed soon.

title: Recommended
comment: This review may be a little biased as Civ 5 is one of my favourite games of all time so you have been warned.Civ 6 is great. It's as good as Civ 5 even without the DLC. The district system and the wonders being built outside of the main city tile create interesting bits of strategy. There is also a religious victory now, making religion a more viable route to go down. Oh and I can't forget the music! It's brilliant, the way it evolves throughout the eras, it's Civ for crying out loud!Buy this game, and if you can afford it get the deluxe edition. Can't wait for the dlc!

You can only read about how to play, but not what you play.Civilization could be like a learning book for kids, but its not. Really missing it!Its still hte best game in its genre.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Been playing the Civ series since Civ 1. 3 & 4 didn't get much play, but 1, 2, & V got thousands of hours of my life. Which brings me to Civ VI. I held off until it went on sale so I got it and a couple of DLCs for $12.I'm at 100 hours of play time, I have a decent feel for the game, but there are still things to learn. One thing I'm waiting to learn is "Does it get fun at some point?"The answer I've found is: "Not really."While there are some improvements for sure, there are also so many things that need fixed its not even funny.1. The AI is garbage. Its 2017, AAA games should not have AI this garbage.2. Non-sensical battles still occur: A crossbowman shouldn't be able to hurt a battleship. Ever.3. End game is a brutal, brutal slog. Pay attention to your victory conditions kids because if you don't start on them ASAP you'll be forced to click "Next Turn" again and again when its obvious you'll win.4. War is possibly the most tedious its ever been even with some improvements.5. You'll learn to really, really hate the "diplomacy" videos where you are getting denounced for no reason.6. The Ghandi thing is old tired and dead. Good lord, he's declaring war constantly come on!7, Feels like it could've used more development time to balance better.There are some nice improvements, but overall, I can't imagine how I'd feel if I'd dropped full price on the game.For $12 I don't feel like it was a bad deal, but since the game isn't usually that cheap, I can't really recommend it at this point. It needs a lot of polish to remove the grind from it and I doubt that's going to happen.

comment: Partway through my first play as Trajan and really enjoying myself. Its basically V re-vamped which is really positive! The technology boosts and civics tree makes the game much more immersive, making you feel like you're actually running an Empire. Graphics are chrisp and clean and combat is pretty decent so far but I see a few blance tweeks in the future. No bugs either so far!Only downsides so far are that there is a real lack of maps to choose from, especially my favourite Earth map plus there aren't many advanced options but I foresee both of these being recitfied with mods!

title: Recommended
comment: I'm really torn on this one. If Steam had a "ehhh" button in between Yes and No then this is one of the times that I would press it. For everything that Civ VI does better than Civ V it does something worse.First off the art style. This is one of the areas that I personally find to be much better than Civ V. The change is very subjective however and you might no like the stylized nature but I find it more aesthetically pleasing than Civ V. The more "cartoony" fits much better with the giant people running around the map than the realistic looking units IMO.While the art is nice the AI is wonky. It's not bad, but it could be much better. Compared to Civ V the AI are far more aggressive and I find this to be a welcome change. Far to often the AI in Civ V would never declare war with me. I have won multiple games playing as an isolationist working towards a science victory. In Civ VI however I have been attacked multiple times while attempting this strategy, which is nice and adds a good challenge. While the extra aggression is nice, the AI can be extremely bipolar. One turn a leader will praise me for being a strong and tough nation, and then denounce me on the next. And while the AI are more aggressive, they are aggressive for the wrong reasons. I've had war declared on me because I had a weak navy, a small amount of gold, or because my military was too large.Lastly, the districts system is a nice change from Civ V where most of my games devolved into a mindless spam of improving every owned tile, and building every building. Having to choose between a farm and a shiny new airport is nice, and keeps the game engaging.Overall Civ VI feels almost like a lateral move. The new game play additions are very welcome and really help spice up the formula. But the unpredictability of the AI really drag the whole package down. If you are still playing and loving Civ V, I would say to wait for an expansion before picking this one up. If you are looking for something new and Civ V has gone stale, then I would recommend this one.It builds and improves on Civ V in terms of game play mechanics, but most of the time I think that the AI subsists on a diet of paste and paint chips. A step up in some regards, and a step back in others.

title: Not Recommended
comment: Bought this game at launch expecting bugs and not many civs to start, and was right on both counts. What I didnt expect was 2 paid DLCs within the first month of the game, one of which puts a new civ behind a pay wall. What the ♥♥♥♥. In what world did releasing a Civ with a price tag less than a month after launch, so one that almost made it in with release, make sense to the devs. Besides it being a money grab, some of the owners of this game can't even get the new Civ if they wanted to because it has released on Mac. Don't plan on looking into this game much until more civs are released and there is a big sale to grab them all.No recommendation for this game until they release a good package deal.

title: Recommended
comment: If you have read any of the reviews of this game (in the media or otherwise) you will already know what I am about to say. This game is 100% complete right out of the gate with plenty for you to do and learn and enjoy. This game also has a great basis for increadible expansions as well as mods. This game will def last the 5+ year between it and Civ VII. BTW make sure you have plenty of time to play it when you sit down to do so. Yes it is an Turn Based Game and you can save and walk away at anytime, but as the cliché goes for this game, time will get away from you quickly. I suggest you set an alarm.

Theres enough civs for a few hours of fun but wheres are the others iconic ones from all the other games? I dont understand the direction this company is going...I really dont.

title: Recommended
comment: I can play this game easily for hours and hours, and thats coming from someone who played hundreds of hours with civ IV and V. The art style in this is hard for some to get used to, but I think it adds character and its similar to the older games. It really makes it look great and unique compared to some other games, in my opinion.So far, its a lot more fun to begin with than civ V was, thats without owning much DLC as well.The AI's random interests make it fun as well. You never know who is going to be a pain in your♥♥♥♥♥ but hey! For some reason, Norway likes me. Heck knows why yet. It's all random and a mysteryyyy!Also the barbarians so far aren't as big of a pain as they were in civ V. They can jump you, but at least you know where the scout who saw your town is, and you can kill him before he can report back to his camp.Its good.

title: Not Recommended
comment: The AI in this game needs some serious work. Honestly, the "agenda" system doesn't make for a fun experience, because it seems like that's all the AI are influenced by. These statistics are generated at the beginning of the game and determine whether or not the civ will like you or hate you based on actions such as religious expansion, military size, and other things that just happen through you playing the game. It makes the AI characters feel incredibly uninteresting and predictable, as they are only influenced by those two statistics that they recieve from the start. It really ruins the game for me, because most of my fun times in Civilization V were had through interesting diplomatic interactions.I would definitely recommend the Civilization V with all the expansions over this game.

title: Recommended
comment: Nice game, interesting new solutions, solid arts, nice town animation. Great soundtrack by the way. It's hard to compare different versions of Civilization games. Every game has unique balance setting. This game is interesting to play - that's what I can say for sure.So I totally recommend it.Minors:- UI. Sometimes it's terrible. You have to click at that city many times before you can select it. Sometimes UI glitch (I have "new regime available" instead of "next turn" - works as shoud, an animation bug).- Eats a lot of RAM and does not want to exit without killing the process.- Units sometimes got lost in the middle of a route. I don't like the way the planned routes are displayed.- This annoying limitation on "how many units of the same type on one cell".

title: Not Recommended
comment: Only 15 hours compared to...well, take a look at my hours on Civ V. All I can say is that this is the first time I have felt like the game has taken a step backwards. I'm not a fan of districts or of the smaller cities that require large empires. I can live with the art style but the game itself seems busy with so many things just in to be in (why the religious fighting?). Get it on sale but otherwise stick to Civ V.

title: Recommended
comment: The art direction is a bit lackluster, but the more you play, the more you can bear it, and maybe even appreciate it. Gameplay is top notch and arguably an improvement from Civ V. $12 was too good of a deal to pass up, and Im glad I didn't. Controversial art direction, great gameplay.

title: Recommended
comment: Pros:Graphics:The graphics look good, not a huge improvement over Civ 5 but they do look nice.CivilizationsThe Civilizations are well planned, although some feel way more powerful than others like the Germans and the Australians.Technology, Culture & GovernmentThe new boost system for technologies and civics is really cool and being able to switch between civics instead of having a set group of bonuses is awesome.The different types of governments are unique and give powerful bonuses to whatever goal you have for the game.Except for the mainstays like England, Rome, Germany and Russia, the DLC civilizations seem to be chosen at random. It's not really important though since you can use Mods to get around this, as long as you can slog through the billions of anime related civs.When you select a site to build a district at, there is no cancel button or even a relocate button. This is ridiculous and should be changed as soon as possible. In multiplayer games, if you accidentally select the wrong spot the only way to solve the problem is to restart the entire game or just accept that you f'd up and play with a handicap for the rest of the game. If this seems like a balance issue, you can always add penalties to relocating them, (i.e. it takes half the production spent to relocate it to the new spot.)The A.I. needs a improvement. Currently, a "higher difficulty" consists of giving the AI a bigger boost to their base production, science, etc. instead of a computer player that actually fights wars better or builds stronger cities. When the AI builds a city, they give almost no consideration as to how productive or successful they will be. They almost always build them right on the closest acceptable tile to their starting city.When I play Civ VI, a lot of the maps have a similar feel to them and I don't get very many unique feeling games overall.The AI seems predisposed to causing total war on any human controlled civilization that does not immediately send a delegation to them, the AI does this regardless of their relative technology level and likelihood of success.The AI blames civilizations that get attacked, giving warmongering penalties even when they are defending themselves against a surprise or formal war declaration.The Diplomacy screen for each civilization is well done, but could use way more information such as the length of time you have been at peace, if you have been denounced, what turn it happened and when the denouncement will run out and what city states they are at war with.Finding out what resources you are currently trading is a chore, if you look at the way it was done in Civ 4 it is incredibly easy to see the things you are trading but in this one you have to scroll through each resource in a huge list to see if you are already trading it to someone.I'd rate this as maybe the second best Civ in the series, only because the AI sucks so badly - hopefully they will work on it for a while instead of releasing DLCs and scenarios.

title: Not Recommended
comment: "Mixed bag" is the only way to describe Civ VI.If you're new to the 4X genre, the game is user friendly enough that you could be a competent player after around 30 hours. However, Civ V offers that same accessibility, and given how frequently the game and all its dlc goes on sale, you'd likely be better off starting there. You'd be getting hundreds of hours of content and a far more fleshed out entry in the series to sink yourself into. You'll have a better appreciation of the changes that came with this game, and you'll have a far better understanding of many of the flaws I mention below.For the players like myself who put hundreds of hours into Civ V, the game offers a treasure trove of new features as well as updates to old systems. The most important addition is the district system which makes your city's tiles feel valuable now. This allows you to specialize your cities to a far greater degree than you ever could in Civ V, and forces you to put care into city placement as well as how your workers shape its land. Its one of the nice things I've seen put in a 4X that helps break up the early to mid-game slog. Overall, the first 60 hours I played when it first released felt wonderful, and if the game remained that way I could happily recommend this as a good sequel to Civ V. The problem is that it didn't.Passed that point, it became increasingly evident how broken certain aspects of the game are and how little care went into making the game good. The AI is disgusting in how stupid they are, even for a Civ game. The new agenda system gives each Civ certain priorities that affect their opinion of other civs. This is interesting on paper, but works like♥♥♥♥♥♥in practice. Civs will almost always find something to be angry at you for, and the most egregious case is when a leader favors a civ set up for domination victory (strong military, surprise war declarations, etc) but also ♥♥♥♥ing hates them for warmongering, a penalty that is never forgotten in your 6000 years as a civilization. "Just avoid war" you might say, and that would be easy if every game there wasn't at least 2-3 AI that introduce themselves, offer you trade deals, and then declare war on you a turn later. These wars consist of them never actually sending any troops, plundering your trade routes, and then asking for peace 10 turns later. The game feels like it's forcing a gun to your head so you go for a domination victory. This isn't helped when the developers insist on releasing overpriced dlc civs that are horribly imbalanced and almost all favor war; Macedon in particular is loving it so much that he may as well be considered p2w given how hard he can steamroll the game.Other minor issues: (1) The game wasting Sean Bean on a collection of quotes that are about 45% made up or falsely attributed♥♥♥♥♥♥the devs pulled from blogs. (2) Civ imbalance in general. Civs like France are laughably weak while things like Scythia get to♥♥♥♥♥♥out horse archers that later can be helicopters. (3) Some of the leaders themselves are either ridiculous choices like Catherine de Medici for France or poor representations of the historical figure like Qin shi Huang. (4) The lack of mechanical diversty in the civs themselves. The majority of them are a give some decent war capability and then a bonus to faith, trade, culture, etc. Each new game feels bland when few civs have mechanics that make them stand out.All of this combined makes the game incredibly hard to recommend, and unless you can grab it on sale I'd wait for the game to improve with future expansions. It's not like the game is unplayable or even bad; it makes enough changes to the Civ formula that that you'll manage at least 100 hours of fun. The issue is that for a 4X, you'd have to release a trashfire of a game to not manage that. This isn't someone's first attempt at a 4X, it's Firaxis. For a studio with so much experience, the product feels surprisingly amateur.

title: Recommended
comment: I pre-ordered and couldn't wait for it to release-and I'm totally satisfied. If you're a Civ fan, then all of the mechanics are still in place with some good additions. After being disappointed with 'Beyond Earth' I was glad to see the dev didn't keep the clumsy and IMO boring and pace killing diplomacy point system.I'm taking a break from a 5 hour session-which shows Civ6 has kept that addictive, 'one more turn' magic in place. New features include a builder unit instead of worker, which gets used up after 3 turns. The civic and religious tweaks are still in place, with multiple military, economic and diplomatic perks you can unlock as you discover techs.All in all they've kept everything that was great about Civ5 in place and tweaked it for the better. The graphics are definitely Civ style, and the narration and music produce a very atmospheric experience. I'm going to be a total recluse for many months ahead, and this release and Farm Simulator 2017 are being released 5 days apart. Onwards and enjoy my fellow Civ-fanatics!!!

title: Recommended
comment: Such a fun and amazing game after CIV V to be fair it does take a little while to get used to with playing CIV V a lot but all in all this is a game worth buying, to all the people moaning on how the AI declares war or isn't always happy with you, just simply keeps a tab on all the things e.g. troops, resources, agenders and make sure not to do something that will p*ss them off, when you click on them it even tells you what will p*ss them off and make them friendlier. But this is just my review and you yourself can judge the game, despite what other reviews say, i didn't take any advice from them and i just went out a bought the game as i was intended to regardless. The game is not the same as CIV V with the builders not been permanent and various other changes but, who wants another CIV V anyway we needed change and CIV VI provided.In conclusion, i personally would recommend this game but it's completely up to you to buy the game.

title: Recommended
comment: I had removed CIV5 from my "playlist" in favour of Paradox' titles, as they just felt more engaging after thousands of hours of CIV over the years, but I was of course still excited to try out CIV6. So far, some 40-50 hours in (EDIT: Apparently I'm just over 100 hours in, how the time flies), I've not been disappointed!My major takeaways, positive and negative, so far:1. I am no longer punished for building wide - wow what a feeling!2. The music is great, and it's dynamic aspects works perfectly almost making me feel like part of an epic movie.3. I like the new tech boost system, but it's still too early to tell if it's actually good for the game or not. If an optimal strategy can be found the new system might be more limiting than it is rewarding.4. However, the civets/policy system I feel adds a great deal and is a step forward.5. I like the attention made to the diplomacy system in general, but it still needs a lot of polish and tweaks. It can get quite annoying that you can never be friends with the AI unless you give them incredible bribes and also toe the line of their diplomatic agendas perfectly.6. I encountered quite a few bugs with the UI. However, no performance problem on my 2 year old machine (GPU is a GTX760).Overall I will have a lot of fun with this. Better than CIV5? Sure, why not - but I don't know if it will last as long as CIV5 did in it's present state, but I'm hopeful future updates will make it so. My favourite CIV is still CIV4 though :)

comment: I've always loved the entire Civilization franchise so it pains me that software performance prevents me from playing this. In my brief experience the game suffered random freezing and will not give up focus to other applications (including task manager) most notably on exit where it wasn't noticed as i left the computer and the "gameplay" clock kept running so Steam won't issue a refund. Every attempt to exit the game has caused it to freeze the UI at full screen and not allow any other access until a manual power off and reboot of the system. Even if i had to manually force close teh game it would be manageble if i actually could but the lockout on focus is just shoddy code from a company that doesn;t respond to support inquiries and operates on the philosophy of "we have your money so we don;t care" definitely teh last steam game I ever buy.

title: Recommended
comment: Sometimes a sequel launches so poorly that it takes three years to reach the same level of polish as its predecessor. Sometimes the designer of a Civ title is so grossly incompetant that the game suffers from their bad designs for its entire life cycle. And sometimes, we forget just how difficult building a Civ game engine from scratch must be.CIvilization VI is not one of these games, and it's designer is not one of those designers. The game suffers from several defects related to being built on a customized in-house engine. The game lacks polish in several areas. The user interface lacks critical information about how certain mechanics work. The game needs changes, of course.But it is entirely worth every penny spent on this game. Even with all the problems it has, it's still very enjoyable. It makes previous Vanilla Civ releases feel subpar, especially the mess that was Civ 5 at launch. The multiplayer works better at launch than Civ 5's did after its final patch.Personally, I expected the issues we have with this game. It's brand new, and we're comparing it to Civ 5 with 2 expansions and 15+ patches. In a few years, this game will be leaps and bounds ahead of where it is now, and I'm excited to see what comes next!

title: Recommended
comment: I'm biased... This was the first series of games I played at the age of 7, because I found it on my mom's laptop while she was at work and just always played it. I've grown up playing games, every genre really. This has become my all-time favorite game, period. I'm not sure theres another game that's captivated my interest for 14 hours straight, into the night, then again the very next day right after I woke up and ate. Fallout has gotten close, but at that point I was just mindlessly droning. I always felt like, and feel like, I'm accomplishing something in Civ 6. The greatest part is, Civ always has new expansions that manage to add more to an already vast game, although my expectations were exceeded, it's odd to say I expect my expectations to continue to be exceeded.TLDR; Buy this game. It's worth it.

title: Recommended
comment: I have some good things and some bad things to say about this new civ game. First of all, the positives:- It's finally a MODERN civ game with no graphic glitches on modern win 10 systems and it runs natively in 64 bits. Everything runs extremely well at max settings (4K res, all grfx settings at max.)- I LOVE the districts and that you can make every city different and unique. I also love that you control population directly, by building neighborhoods.- I love the new animations for movement and combat.- I love that the game is still extremely customizable just like civ 5. I like that I can start in any era and that I can customize the map and the game as much as I want. Unfortunately, playing on planet Earth seems to be missing, and that's the map I always use with civ 5.- I love the improved diplomacy and the new spy management section.Now for what I don't like:- Buildings and military units are MUCH HARDER to obtain. You have to play for at least 5-6 hours before you can even start considering attacking another nation. And even with resources set at max, strategic resources are MUCH HARDER to come by. Which means you'll be a lot less inclined to risk units on daring tactics, because rebuilding them would be prohibitive.- The AI is insane. Computer-controlled nations declare war on me all the time, for no reason (really? Rome is angry at me for building 30 hexes away from their closest city?) I found myself at war with 5-6 nations, none of them allied. That makes absolutely NO SENSE.- What's with the random comments on my civ from other nations? The same useless comments that repeat over and over and that don't lead to anything other than a "goodbye" button. Talk about a gratuitous waste of my time!- Why oh why are workers expended after they only built three things? And why have they become a lot harder to get? In civ 5 I'm used to hundreds of workers building and fixing things. Now even workers have become a luxury? It takes at least 10 hours before your biggest city with all the fixings can produce a worker unit every turn.- I don't particularly like the more cartoonish diplomacy animationd. I want to deal with people, not cartoons. It's pretty hard for me to take them seriously when they look like Manga characters...I don't know if I can recommend it. Unfortunately there is no neutral option, so it's either yes or no. Hopefully new versions will take care of the shortcomings and that's why I decided to recommend it. But not if you buy it right now (as in 10/23/2016.)FOR NOW IT'S **NOT** RECOMMENDED.

title: Recommended
comment: Visually pleasing compared to Civ 5 as well as a lot more to do. This can be overwhelming and frustrating, though, but it is a plus once you get the hang of the districts and tile placements. I also enjoy the commentary on the wonders and watching them be built.There are many positive things on this game that beat Civ 5 and the only a few negatives. I would say that barbarians can be pretty harsh in this one, but you can work around that. There is also not an initial ally button to become allies with friends, so that is a turn off as well. The rest of the negatives just have to do with needing more civs to play as and more maps, but that will come with mods and expainsions.

title: Recommended
comment: Its Sid Meier's Civilization.What more reason do you need to buy it?You dont... go buy it.Buy it... or Ghandi will rain down Islamic Communist atomic-fire upon your head.Ghandi conqures all.... personally, I do prefer the aesthetics of Civ5 better though.Just seemed more beautiful, refined, cultured. Just a step foward.Civ6 seems in contrast like a over-colour-contrasted stylised throwback into past Civs. Yeah, its a 25th anniversary of Civ so it visually harkens back to Civs of the past (with Civ5 being the outlier in that regard) with the exeption of playstyle and features... and dont get me wrong, gameplay wise, its still a step fowards - just artistically, its a step backwards.But that didnt stop me from buying a physical collectors edition :)Its a Sid Meier game. Its a Civilization.Worth every penny <3
